title: Halachic Status of Pennies for Tzedakah After the End of Penny Production
content:
# Halachic Status of Pennies for Tzedakah After the End of Penny Production ## Frage

With recent news that the U.S. government is discontinuing the production of pennies, I’m a bit confused about how this affects the status of pennies in everyday use and, more specifically, in the context of tzedakah.

From what I understand, no new pennies will be minted, but existing pennies will continue to circulate and are still considered legal tender. However, in practice, many cash transactions may begin rounding totals to the nearest nickel, and some businesses may no longer want to deal with pennies at all.

This raises a question for me regarding tzedakah:

If someone gives charity using pennies — for example, four pennies (4¢) — does this still fully count as a valid act of tzedakah? Or does the fact that pennies are no longer being produced (and may be functionally phased out of daily transactions) affect their halachic or practical status as “real money”?

More specifically:

Since pennies are still recognized by the U.S. government as legal tender, does that alone mean they retain full monetary value for purposes of tzedakah?

If, in everyday commerce, cash totals are rounded and pennies are rarely accepted, does that change whether such a donation is considered meaningful or valid?

From a halachic perspective, is the defining factor the coin’s legal status, its market acceptability, its purchasing power, or the intent of the giver?

Would giving multiple pennies together (e.g., 4¢, 10¢, etc.) be viewed differently than giving a single penny?

Is there any precedent or discussion in halacha regarding currencies or coins that remain legal tender but are no longer produced or commonly used?

I’m asking both from a practical standpoint and a halachic one, and I’d appreciate insight from anyone familiar with Jewish law, monetary policy, or communal charity practices.

title: Footnotes on the bottom of the pages of "Doros HaRishonim" by Rabbi Y.Y. Rabinowitz
content:
# Footnotes on the bottom of the pages of "Doros HaRishonim" by Rabbi Y.Y. Rabinowitz ## Frage

https://hebrewbooks.org/pdfpager.aspx?req=20280&st=&pgnum=16

Are the footnotes on the bottom of this sefer written by the author of the sefer, Rabbi Rabinowitz? Or were they authored by someone else?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The footnotes are clearly those of an author, not of an editor (same style as main text, additional arguments and ideas rather than editorial work). Only the footnote on the first page is incomplete, and beginning with the parentheses (הערה זו...) is added by the editor. Footnotes in other volumes of the work are also written by the author (the preface mentions that this posthumous volume was not as revised as the other volumes in the series).

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

Doesn't look like it. Earlier in that very volume it says it was put out by Mossad HaRav Kook, which are known to add many scholarly footnotes to their works. There's an introduction by a Rav Y. L. Fishman and a preface by Dr. B. M. Levine, so perhaps they contributed to the footnotes. I didn't see any other indication who contributed.

I found the same edition on Otzar HaChochmah but in a seemingly older format. There, it adds a copyright page to a Dr. B. M. Lewin (Levine), who I cited above. It would seem then that he put the footnotes.

title: What is the meaning of the Hebrew markings on the flags in Cremaster 2?
content:
# What is the meaning of the Hebrew markings on the flags in Cremaster 2? ## Frage

The Cremaster cycle is a series of five loosely connected surrealist art films made between mid 90s to early 00s, filmed by a Matthew Barney, a former medical student and quarterback turned performance artist and sculptor. In Cremaster 2, which is actually the fourth since they were purposely released out of order, there is a scene where a man is marched off to be executed for murder, and someone off screen drops some flags on the ground at his feet. Each include some cryptic symbols seen throughout the series, along with Hebrew markings in thick black letters.

I'm awfully curious about the meanings of the Hebrew inscriptions on these flags and any symbolic significance they might have. As far as I know, Matthew Barney is not Jewish, and this is the only example of the Hebrew language or any other Jewish symbolism appearing int he Cremaster cycle or in any of his other works. I tried asking this on the movies/tv site too, but I figured I might have better luck asking people who actually understand the language and writing system.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

They're names of the Twelve Tribes of Israel. Specifically:

  • Ephraim (technically a sub-tribe of Joseph)
  • Issachar
  • Naphtali

title: Why does Rashi say that Yackov said he will only pass away "once", if he never passed away at all?
content:
# Why does Rashi say that Yackov said he will only pass away "once", if he never passed away at all? ## Frage

B"H

Given that Yackov didn't die, even physically and literally, why does Rashi in parshas Yayigash say Yackov said he would pass away "(only) once"?

  1. Then Israel said to Joseph, “Now I can die content, having seen your face and having seen that you are still alive.” לוַיֹּ֧אמֶר יִשְׂרָאֵ֛ל אֶל־יוֹסֵ֖ף אָמ֣וּתָה הַפָּ֑עַם אַֽחֲרֵי֙ רְאוֹתִ֣י אֶת־פָּנֶ֔יךָ כִּ֥י עֽוֹדְךָ֖ חָֽי:

אָמוּתָה הַפָּעַם - (lit.) This time I can die. The straightforward meaning is as Onkelos translates it: אִלּוּ אֲנָא מָאִית זִמְנָא הָדָא מְנַחֵם אֲנָא “If I were to die at this time, I would find comfort.” But its Midrashic explanation is: “I thought I would die twice, in this world and in the World to Come, because the Divine Presence left me and I thought that the Holy One, blessed be He, would demand punishment for your death from me. Now that you are still alive, I will only die once, in this world.” אָמוּתָה הַפָּעַם. פְּשׁוּטוֹ כְתַרְגּוּמוֹ. וּמִדְרָשׁוֹ סָבוּר הָיִיתִי לָמוּת שְׁתֵּי מִיתוֹת, בָּעוֹלָם הַזֶּה וְלָעוֹלָם הַבָּא, שֶׁנִּסְתַּלְּקָה מִמֶּנִּי שְׁכִינָה, וְהָיִיתִי אוֹמֵר שֶׁיִּתְבָּעֵנִי הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא מִיתָתְךָ, עַכְשָׁו שֶׁעוֹדְךָ חַי, לֹא אָמוּת אֶלָּא פַעַם אַחַת

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: -1)

The second death is the death that Yaakov would soon experience.

The first death Yaakov experienced was when Yoseph went missing and Yaakov became too disturbed to experience the Shechinah.

It would seem that Rashi learned that Yaakov thought he was responsible for Yoseph's situation (because he didn't stop Yoseph from being a jerk to his brothers). I have heard elsewhere that Yaakov suspected that Yoseph was alive because he was still aggrieved after he mourned for Yoseph. i.e. the mourning was ineffective because Yoseph was not really dead.

title: What is the Original Source for the Name of the Offering מנחת חינוך?
content:
# What is the Original Source for the Name of the Offering מנחת חינוך? ## Frage

The מילואים process known later to us as a “minchas chinuch” is derived from Vayikra near the beginning of פרשת צו:

(ויקרא ו:יג) זֶה קׇרְבַּן אַהֲרֹן וּבָנָיו אֲשֶׁר יַקְרִיבוּ לַה' בְּיוֹם הִמָּשַׁח אֹתוֹ עֲשִׂירִת הָאֵפָה סֹלֶת מִנְחָה תָּמִיד

From this section, חז"ל learn that when a כהן is about to do עבודה in the מקדש for the first time, he is obligated to bring a special קרבן מנחה which we now know as the מנחת חינוך (seeming to later influence the naming of the famous sefer bearing that name as a play on this korban in conjunction with the focus on the Sefer HaChinuch).

The notion of an actual obligation for כהנים to offer a special separate korban mincha when beginning עבודת המקדש for the first time appears in the following sources. Here the term “chinuch” hasn’t yet been introduced:

תוספתא שקלים ג:טז - כהן הדיוט אין נכנס לעזרה לעבודה אלא א"כ הביא עשירית האיפה משלו ועובדה בידו

ספרא צו פרשה ג:ג - כשהכהן מתקרב תחלה לעבודה מביא עשירית האיפה משלו ועובדה בידו

ברייתא ירושלמי שקלים ז:ג - …..דְּרִבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל אָמַר. עִשָּׁרוֹן מְקַדֵּשׁ. כְּשֶׁהַכֹּהֵן מִתְקָּרֵב תְּחִילָּה לָעֲבוֹדָה מֵבִיא עֲשִׁירִית שֶׁלּוֹ וְעוֹבְדָהּ בְיָדוֹ.

We see the term “חינוך” introduced into this process in the following גמרות:

ירושלמי שקלים ז:ג (המשך) - …..רִבִּי מָנָא בָעֵי מֵימַר. בּוֹ בַיּוֹם נִתְקָרֵב כַּתְּחִילָּה לָעֲבוֹדָה. בּוֹ בַיּוֹם נִתְמַנֶּה לִהְיוֹת כֹּהֵן גָּדוֹל. מֵבִיא שְׁתַּיִם. אַחַת לְחִינּוּכוֹ וְאָחַת לְחוֹבַת הַיּוֹם.

גמ' מנחות עח. - אֶלָּא מַקִּישׁ חִינּוּכוֹ לְהִמָּשְׁחוֹ: מָה הִמָּשְׁחוֹ רְבוּכָה, אַף חִינּוּכוֹ רְבוּכָה. אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: כֹּהֵן גָּדוֹל הַמִּתְקָרֵב לַעֲבוֹדָה צָרִיךְ שְׁתֵּי עֶשְׂרוֹנוֹת הָאֵיפָה, אַחַת לְהִמָּשְׁחוֹ, וְאַחַת לְחִינּוּכוֹ.

רש"י (מנחות שם) - מקיש חינוכו - דכהן הדיוט להמשחו (היינו רבוכה) וחינוכו הוא המילואים שלו אלמא דבמילואים הוי רבוכה דכהן הדיוט מביא חביתין [היינו רבוכה] ביום חינוכו לעבודה וכהן גדול בכל יום: ואחד לחינוכו - בשביל שנתחנך היום לעבודת כהן [גדול]

Finally, the first time I have seen an appearance of the actual term “מנחת חינוך” is in the Mishna Torah of the Rambam:

הלכות מעשה הקרבנות יב:ד - וְתֵשַׁע מִנְחוֹת הַיָּחִיד וְכֻלָּן קְרֵבִין לַמִּזְבֵּחַ וְאֵלּוּ הֵן. ……הַמִּנְחָה שֶׁמַּקְרִיב כָּל כֹּהֵן תְּחִלָּה כְּשֶׁיִּכָּנֵס לַעֲבוֹדָה שֶׁמַּקְרִיב אוֹתָהּ בְּיָדוֹ וְהִיא הַנִּקְרֵאת מִנְחַת חִנּוּךְ

Is there anyone prior to the Rambam who had coined the term “מנחת חינוך”?

title: Why does the Shaarei Ephraim recommend against splitting the leining between baalei kriah?
content:
# Why does the Shaarei Ephraim recommend against splitting the leining between baalei kriah? ## Frage

Shaarei Ephraim 3:6 says ideally, all of the leining in one morning should be done by one baal kriah -- even if there are multiple sifrei Torah.

לכתחלה אין לקרות ע"י קורא אחר קורא אפילו אם הקריאה בב' וג' ספרים לא יחלקו לקוראים רק אותו שהתחיל לקרות יגמור לקרוא כל הקרואים שבאותו היום

He points to Birkei Yosef 282, which I'm assuming is OC282:12:

You asked -- if a holiday or New Moon coincides with Shabbos, may the one reciting the Maftir be the same one reading the second Sefer Torah, as there is a break of kaddish between them, or is it prohibited because of a slight to the first reader? Answer: once there is a break of kaddish between them, [the first reader] is like any other member of the community, and it makes no difference if another person gets up to read the second Torah, or he himself does it.

So first off, if the Birkei Yosef allows it in the two-Sefer case, why is the Shaarei Ephraim advising against it?

Furthermore, is that the only reason to avoid dividing the leining between readers, to not slight the first reader? What's the earliest source of this? Would it apply if a shul actually split it 7 ways, in a dina deGemara "you-bench-it-you-lein-it" fashion?

I've certainly seen the very prevalent practice -- puk chazi -- of smaller communities routinely splitting it up, but is that actually defended anywhere?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

My edition of sharie Efraim corrects the citation to Machzek Beracha, and the Machzek Beracha 282:21 cites from the maharik that there should be a single individual reading the Torah, just like the Torah was given through a single emissary with Moshe Rabenu.

title: Dealing with guilt around anger at the divine
content:
# Dealing with guilt around anger at the divine ## Frage

This question has been bottled up for years but AI convinced me to ask if as it needs a human touch.

My mother passed away a few years ago, sort of young and unexpected. People told me to "grieve" but one of the strongest feelings I had was anger at Gd.

She got sick and was first neglected in a rehab center, and then transferred to the hospital during Holiday season (right around now). We all assumed she'd be fine but one day..she wasn't. It feels like the timing was bad (low staff) along with a few mistakes (tried wrong medication etc). It makes me feel like it wouldn't have taken a miracle for her to survive, just a gentle divine nudge.

So I built up this anger about the situation, and at the same time I felt guilty for being angry, since people deal with much worse. I was also scared to be angry because "how dare I" be angry when so many other things go well for me. Stories like Tisha B'Av being retribution for the spies "cries" makes me nervous to "unnecessarily" be upset.

I've never voiced or even wrote this down from fear of manifesting "smite" but honestly I think just want to repair the relationship.

How do I move forward when I'm stuck between needing to express my feelings but being terrified of the consequences.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

While Mi Yodeya can't give you personalised advice, here's a story I once heard that is true, and has relevant wisdom:

There was a holocaust survivor, a professor, and he was angry at God and abandoned Judaism. He was living in a community in Eretz Yisrael and there was a Rabbi there who was well known for being well versed in science and philosophy - a genius - and had a popular class on Torah.

Many of his friends would regularly tell him to join the class because he would enjoy it, but he refused. He didn't want to have anything to do with Rabbis or Torah, or God. People also told the Rabbi about the professor, and at some point they actually met - I believe they ended up in an elevator (lift) together.

The Rabbi asked the man to come to class, and the man refused, but they got into a chat anyway and in the end, the professor actually said that he was impressed with what the Rabbi was teaching, and enjoyed it. As they were departing the Rabbi suggested that he join the class, and the professor said no, he can't.

The Rabbi asked why he can't, and he said "you don't understand, you and me, we are not the same - we are completely different. I am angry at God because of the holocaust, I can never forgive Him. I am so angry in fact, that every Friday night, I deliberately make a meal of pork, just to stick it to Him."

The Rabbi said, "not at all! We are exactly the same, we both keep Shabbat!".

They departed and after a couple of weeks, the professor joined the class. When his friends asked him why, he said, "that Rabbi is very smart. Very very smart. Listen to what he was saying. I thought that I was too far 'gone' to have anything to do with Torah, Judaism or God. I was eating pork on Shabbat, in spite and anger. The exact opposite of what a Jew should do, but when the Rabbi made the joke that we are actually the same, there was a big truth in it. Why was I eating pork? Because I knew it angered God. And why was I doing it on Shabbat? Because I knew that Shabbat is a special day to God. In a deep sense, I am a believer, son of believers, I believe in Shabbat, I believe in God, in fact, in my anger, I am in a very close relationship with Him. Therefore, I have no reason to not join this class".

Being angry at God is obviously not ideal (and I'm sure you've read some scary literature on this), but the truth is that some of the people who are angry at Him are in a more real relationship with Him than many believers. What does Hashem want? For us to be in a real relationship with Him, with Emunah.

I can't speak to your situation and I of course recommend speaking to a Rabbi who can get to know you and your specific situation. But I'm sure if you read up on this very topic you'll find a lot of Rabbis have said very reassuring things. We are living in spiritually dark times, and Hashem is very patient and understanding. Above all, He's glad you're still thinking about Him, even if it's in anger. There are many Jews who have completely abandoned Him, and many "religious" Jews who are not as close to Him as you may be.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

Try asking yourself -- is the anger/guilt cycle helping you, or holding you back?

By all means acknowledge your feelings, but every so often we get someone here who says, "I feel so guilty about XYZ that I'm not doing mitzvos!" ... which is just making things worst. First focus on what you're actually doing every day.

There's the famous story of the group of rabbis in the early days of the Holocaust that held God on trial ... and concluded He was guilty. And then they got up and davened Mincha.

I heard one therapist comment -- "we can't control our thoughts, but we can control our thinking." So okay. You're feeling angry at G-d. A lot of religious people can have that feeling. You can acknowledge it and then move on, instead of letting it consume you.

title: Child-Friendly Financial Literacy Courses
content:
# Child-Friendly Financial Literacy Courses ## Frage

Are there any child-friendly (let's say ages 6 and up, which admittedly is a range of wildly different capabilities) and hashkafically appropriate books or courses that focus on financial literacy?

Just as a starting point, I'll define the terms as I understand them, but would be happy to hear other interpretations as well:

Financial Literacy here is being defined as learning how to properly manage money, i.e. budgeting, saving for retirement, debt management, etc.

The "hashkafic" elements would likely include attitudes relating to earning money (i.e. proper balance of hishtadlus and bitachon) and proper usage of money (i.e. giving tzedakah, less of a focus on gashmius, etc.).

While looking into this, ran into the the following resources:

An organization called Mesila (looks really good)for

Living Smarter Jewish (from the OU. Also looks good, but a bit more limited to High School and above)

The Ramsey kids program (the fact that it has giving as a key point of their curriculum is nice. Not entirely sure how aligned the overall hashkafic ideals are)

The Tuttle Twins (this might be a bit broader than what I'm looking for, it looks more Macro than Micro)

It's very possible one of these is an answer, if anyone has experience with any of them and wants to expand on it, that would work.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

There is a book Menachem and Lieba Learn to Budget by Bruchy Laufer. There are also some related episodes on the Marvelous Middos Machine show (around the song "Never take kids to a store"), in fact all 4 episodes are great although they have a much wider focus (1, 2, 3, 4).

There are also some classic Jewish stories coming from novels of Rabbi Marcus Lehmann: "Of Riches and Faith", Wanderings of a Coin, "The Treasurer's Secret"; also Gold's "Settling Accounts", which focus on sacrifices that people made in properly managing money.

Finally, some Jewish high schools offer a Personal Finance course, where they learn basic of managing money; some use a textbook "Foundations in Personal Finance" by RamseyEducation.

Finally, for those who want to have an advanced knowledge of financial markets, one can suggest "The laws of ribbis" by R' Yisroel Reisman, who discusses many complex financial products in the context of las of ribbis. Details of these products can be learned on wikipedia or investopedia.

title: Bris on Asarah b'Tevet -- how to handle the seudat mitzvah?
content:
# Bris on Asarah b'Tevet -- how to handle the seudat mitzvah? ## Frage

When a bris falls out on Asara b'Tevet, what does one do about the Seudat Mitzvah? Is it canceled, does it override the fast, or is it postponed?

Obviously the correct answer here is "Consult your local Orthodox rabbi" (or maybe even "Ask your mohel") but I'm not so much interested in a psak as I am in the question "What are the general principles here, and where can I find this discussed?".

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

I'm not a posek, ask your LOR

In terms of Psak and sources to learn the sugya more in depth:

The Rema 551:10, Mishnah Berurah O.C 551:76–77, Aruch HaShulchan 551:30, Kaf HaChayim 551:163–165, Chazon Ovadia Arba Taaniyot page. 196, and Teshuvot VeHanhagot volume 5 168:4 pasken that the בעל הברית (father of the child, mohel, and sandak) must fast the entire day on all four fasts (unless it was pushed off until another day, which is a different halacha not for now), and they can have the seudat mitzvah after the fast is over.

Reasoning, General sources and more sources:

I think the reason why this is the psak is based on the following:

Gemera in Shabbat 130a says:

רבן שמעון בן גמליאל אומר: כל מצוה שקיבלו עליהם בשמחה כגון מילה, דכתיב 'שש אנכי על אמרתך כמוצא שלל רב' - עדיין עושין אותה בשמחה

"Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Any commandment that Israel accepted upon themselves with joy—such as circumcision, as it is written, “I rejoice over Your word like one who finds great spoil”—they still perform it with joy."

Rashi ד״ה בשמחה says that שמחה means making a משתה (meal/seudat mitzvah).

What type of category in halacha is a seudat mitzvah (i.e, deoritah, derabbanan, minhag, etc.)?

The Terumat Hadeshen Siman 269, Shu"t Chavot Yair Siman 70 say that it's a minhag that we do as a celebration for the mitzvah done. Shulchan Aruch Y.D and Rema Siman 265:12 also say that it's a minhag to make a seudat mitzvah for a brit milah known as a seudat mitzvah.

What type of category in halacha are the four fasts (i.e, deoritah, derabbanan, minhag, etc)?

The Ramban in Torat HaAdam and others say that the four fasts were decreed by prophets, and all the stringencies of fasts apply.

Therefore, putting everything together: It seems that the fast pushes off the eating and drinking of the seudat mitzvah for after the fast because the fast comes from the prophets and the seudat mitzvah is a nice minhag that we have, so when they clash, the four fasts push off the seudat mitzvah.

Hope this helps!

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

My Bris was on a Asara Bteves. Bris was in the morning. My seven year old brother drank the cup of wine (years later still affecting him). Seuda was after Tzeis in the evening.

title: Are rabbis infallible?
content:
# Are rabbis infallible? ## Frage

I am in my first year at a Chabad yeshiva (mostly for convenience, I do not identify as strictly Chabad) and recently, in a debate with my Rabbi, he claimed that rabbis before ~16th century were essentially infallible in not only religious contexts, but also in many secular ones. He gave the example of the Rambam’s medical treatises which, while containing a lot of good wisdom, contains quite a few statements that are verifiably false with today’s medicine. My Rabbi said that despite this, the Rambam could not be wrong, and that perhaps we don’t fully understand the Rambam’s statement or people were simply different back then. He later gave a second example of a colleague of his who disagreed with Ibn Ezra on an issue of dikduk and then stated that Ibn Ezra (and other rabbis) essentially couldn’t be wrong in most fields.

My question is, is the opinion that rabbis are essentially infallible common in the orthodox world or is this merely a Chabad phenomenon. Given the fact that Rishonim and other early rabbis commonly disagreed with each other on hashkafa and other issues, is this “rabbinic infallibility” a recent phenomenon or does it have any real basis?

If a rishon, for example, says that in the times of David Hamelech, everyone had 8 arms, could he be considered wrong?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

This answer is based on my experience, take it as you will. First, this is not a Chabad-only position, but the general position of the Ultra-Orthodox ("Chareidim" etc.). Nonetheless, there is nuance to it:

  1. Some hold that they are sometimes fallible, especially in matters that do not directly pertain to Torah*. This will much more likely be an opinion of a more Modern-Orthodox Jew, especially one in the academic/rationalist direction. Even many Ultra-Orthodox will admit this to some degree, given that there are Gemaras that do suggest this themselves, so generally everyone holds they are ultimately human, and thus not perfect like Hashem. How much they think they are fallible is a spectrum.

  2. Some prefer to say it like this: they are indeed human and thus not perfect like Hashem, but nonetheless, we are not on the level to see their fallibility, in the same way a 7 year old who just learned the rules of chess has no way of perceiving any flaw in Magnus Carlsen's chess game (l'havdil). They are so much above us in spiritual and intellectual level, that for all practical purposes, they are perfect to us. If they say something we don't understand, or is seemingly proven wrong, we must find a way to defend them.

  3. There are some that reduce their fallibility to the limit of zero i.e. they are indeed infallible, second only in place to God. This is because they are born with special souls from lofty realms, are indeed speaking with ru'ach hakodesh or minor prophecy, and their teachings are guided by the Hand of Providence. It's important that we do not at all entertain the notion that they are fallible, chas veshalom.

There is wisdom to all 3 approaches and many fine Jews hold by each. The main thing that all Orthodox agree is that we should have a prodigious amount of respect for them, and certainly a huge dose of humility if we ever wish to take on the task of describing them as being wrong about anything.

This is part of "Emunat Chachamim" - faith in our Sages (Pirkei Avot 6:7), and is a very Jewish way of thinking. We don't worship saints, we venerate Sages. We give our respect and trust to our great Torah giants, who have proven themselves worthy of it. It has rarely let us down, and indeed, been one of the pillars of our success as a people, and as transmitters and teachers of the Torah from Sinai to this very day.

* The Lubavitcher Rebbe, I believe, wrote a letter answering how we should deal with the fact that science facts, written by some Rabbis in their Torah teachings, have been proven wrong in modern times. He answers that they were using the science of their time as a "vessel" or "garment" to explain the Torah idea. The fact is, the garment may have changed, but the truth behind the Torah idea is eternal. I've never had any trouble applying this principle

title: Why did God not want Jacob to know that Joseph was alive?
content:
# Why did God not want Jacob to know that Joseph was alive? ## Frage

The Midrash says:

[The brothers] decided: “Let us make a vow to excommunicate any one of us who tells our father, Jacob, that Joseph is alive.” Judah said: “Reuben is not here, and a vow of excommunication cannot be executed unless ten witnesses are present.” So what did they do? They included the Holy One, blessed be He, in their pact of excommunication [and God agreed]. [Midrash Tanchuma, Vayeshev 2:5]

So God agreed that Jacob must not be told. Another Midrash tells us that Jacob’s father Isaac knew prophetically that Joseph was alive, but said nothing:

The Torah says: And all of Jacob's sons and all his daughters rose up to comfort him [for the loss of Joseph]. But he refused to be comforted and said: “No, I will go down to the grave mourning for my son.” And his father wept for him. [Gen. 37:35] “His father wept for him” does not refer to Jacob weeping for Joseph, but Isaac weeping because of Jacob's deep pain... So why did Isaac not reveal to Jacob that Joseph was alive? Because Isaac thought: If the Holy One, blessed be He, has not revealed it to him, who am I to reveal it to him? [Genesis Rabbah 84:21]

The Lubavitcher Rebbe [Likutei Sichot 10 p 129ff] adds that Joseph followed the same logic. If God didn't want Jacob to know Joseph was alive, he was not going to inform Jacob either.

Why didn't God want Jacob to know that Joseph was still alive?

Added note: My question, and supporting quotes, is exclusively about God's motives for not wanting Jacob to know -- not Joseph's motives or the brothers' motives, which were addressed elsewhere.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The gemara megilla (end of first perek) says that Yosef was away from Yakov for 22 years as a punishment for Yakov not doing kibud av that same amount of time.

Now why did Yakov have to think he was dead?

  1. So he wouldnt find him.

  2. Perhaps could say like rashi in beginning of vayeshev, that Yakov wanted to take it easy, So God punished Yakov by making him think Yosef wasn't alive.

  3. Also could say Yakov was away from his parents for so long, maybe they thought he was dead. So mida k'neged mida, he thought Yosef was dead.

title: Is there a connection between the sefirot and the flower of life symbol
content:
# Is there a connection between the sefirot and the flower of life symbol ## Frage

Do the Sephirot and the Flower of Life refer to the same concept?

The Flower of Life symbol is found in archeology in Masada and the Galilee.

The Germ of Life is a small cross-section of the larger Flower of Life symbol. It’s often found on ancient Jewish tombs.

The Flower of Life is found all over the world, but considering it’s found in Israel, there must be some connection to Jewish mysticism.

Also, the word “sephirot” is similar to “sphere”, which is the 3d representation of the circles of the flower of life.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

There’s no known connection. If there ever was one, nobody knows it today.

The Flower of Life is a symbol found in archeological sites throughout the Old World. It’s been interpreted variously. Its intended meaning was likely different depending on where it popped up, and in many cases it might just be an artistic motif. It’s presence in some ancient Israelite synagogues was likely an example of the latter, as there is no known Kabbalistic reference to the Flower of Life.

The Sephirot—also called מַאֲמרוֹת, דִּבּוּרִים, שֵׁמוֹת, אוֹרוֹת, כֹחוֹת, and כְּתָרִים—are a representation of the ten Divine Traits in Kabbalistic thought, only definitively attested from the First Century.

The connection of the word “Sephirah” to “Sphere” is untenable. Firstly, the only reasonable connection is for the term to have been borrowed from Koine Greek sphéra; and that would likely have resulted in Rabbinic Hebrew ’esfḗrā, rather than our safīrā́. Secondly, Sephirot have nothing to do with spheres, except if you count some written representations as two-dimensional circles.

Lastly, the presence of an artifact in Israel does not in any way indicate a special connection to Jewish mysticism. That’s not a logical conclusion. Nothing about being crafted by Jews inherently suggests a connection to Kabbalah.

title: R' Chaninah ben Dosa's table in Olam haBa
content:
# R' Chaninah ben Dosa's table in Olam haBa ## Frage

Where can one find the story about R' Chaninah ben Dosa, that his table in Olam haBa had three gold legs instead of four, or two gold legs instead of three legs? How can we understand this story, if Olam haBa is not physical?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The source of the story is Taanit 25a, where Rabbi Chanina ben Dosa is extremely poor. His wife asks him to pray for something, he prays and receives a golden table leg. His wife sees in a dream that in the future he would be eating on a table of two legs instead of three, so she asks him to pray to have it taken back.

One interpretation is that the three legs of the table correspond to the three pillars the world stands on - Torah, prayer and acts of kindness (Avot 1:2). By living a comfortable life, Rabbi Chanina ben Dosa would be giving up on the constant need to pray, and would therefore be lacking the merit of prayer in the world to come (Maharsha). Or, if he chose to use his merit to have enough for himself, instead of using his merit to support the entire rest of the world, he would be lacking the pillar of acts of kindness, since he would no longer be providing for the rest of the world's livelihood (Ruach Chayyim, Avot 1:3).

title: Chanukah candles or Shabbos candles first on Friday
content:
# Chanukah candles or Shabbos candles first on Friday ## Frage

On Friday of Chanukah, the Kaf Hachaim O.C 679:1 says that it's because of מעלין בקודש (going up in holiness), so therefore Chanukah goes first and then Shabbat.

Why and in what way is Chanukah lighting less important in Kedushah than Shabbat candles?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

In שער הכוונות דרוש חנוכה דרוש א Rav Chaim Vital writes:

״ואמנם נבאר תחילה ענין קדושת הימים האלו ואח"כ נבאר ענין ברכות נר של חנוכה. והנה כמו שנתבאר שבשבתות ויו"ט ור"ח יש בהם תוספת קדושה על ימי החול -- גם בחנוכה ופורים יש בהם תוספת קדושה יותר מימי החול. אמנם אין מדריגתם שוה למדריגת השבתות ויו"ט ור"ח."

“We will first explain the concept of the sanctity of these days, and afterward we will explain the matter of the blessings over the Chanukah lamp. Just as it has been explained that Shabbat, Festivals, and Rosh Chodesh possess an added sanctity beyond that of weekdays, so too Chanukah and Purim possess an added sanctity greater than that of weekdays. However, their level of sanctity is not equal to the level of Shabbat, Festivals, and Rosh Chodesh.”

In שער הכוונות דרוש חנוכה דרוש א he goes on to explain that Chanukah and Purim are rooted in the Sefira of הוד (splendour). I then saw in Pardes Rimonim 23:21 and other kabbalistic Seforim that it says that Shabbat is rooted in the sefira of מלכות, which is called the שכינה. Therefore, perhaps it would seem that solely based on where Shabbat is rooted within the sefirot (מלכות) and what it corresponds to, Shabbat would have more kedusha as it is representative of the שכינה.

title: Source for this statement of the Lubavitcher Rebbe
content:
# Source for this statement of the Lubavitcher Rebbe ## Frage

I once heard in the name of the Lubavitcher Rebbe that if someone needs one thing and a person gives them something else, it's not real Ahavat Yisrael.

What is the source for this?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Since this question isnt too clear, Please treat the following as a long COMMENT, rather than an answer.

if someone needs one thing and a person gives them something else, it's not real Ahavat Yisrael.

While I don't have a definite answer for this vague question, perhaps the following point from the Sicha in Volume 27 on Parshas Acharei 1 (Os/Chapter י׳) might be in the right direction:

עס איז ניט גענוג וואס דו פירסט זיך אין אן אופן אז דער זולת האט בפועל א תועלת פון דיין הנהגה, נאר אין דעם איז אויך נוגע דיין "דרך", כוונה ומטרה: בשעת דו טוסט דעם צווייטן א טובה דארפסטו אינגאנצן זיין "אויסגעטאן" פון זיך און טראכטן דורכאויס וועגן דעם צווייטנ׳ס מצב, און אזוי ארום וועלן זיר אין דעם ניט אריינמישן קיין נגיעות ופניות וכו'.

Translation:

This translates to: "It is not enough that you conduct yourself in a way that the other person actually benefits from your conduct. Rather, your ,way, intention, and goal are also important: When you do a favor for another, you must be completely 'divested' from yourself and think entirely about the other person's situation, and in this way, no ulterior motives or self-interests will be mixed in."

This teaching may imply, that if one gives something without truly considering the other's specific needs and situation, even if it is objectively a "good thing," it falls short of genuine Ahavat Yisrael. The act of giving must stem from a deep empathy and identification with the recipient, where one's own desires or perceptions are set aside in favor of what the other truly requires

title: When was niqqud first added to the printed editions of Zohar?
content:
# When was niqqud first added to the printed editions of Zohar? ## Frage

I'm trying to figure out where we receive the niqqud tradition of the Zohar, as we see on websites like Sefaria and Torat Emet, and available in several prints today described as 'Zohar menuqqad'. As late as the early 19th century, none of the printed editions of Zohar contained niqqud: Mantua (1558), Cremona (1559), Lublin (1623), Sulzbach (1684), Amsterdam (1715), Constantinople (1736), Amsterdam (1805). I lose track of the various editions beyond this point. Niqqud also isn't included in R. Reuven Margolies's edition published in Jerusalem from 1940-46. Where do modern "menuqqad" editions of Zohar derive their niqqud? What was the first edition to include them in print?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Based on looking at some bibliographical sources, although not exhaustively, I was able to find what seems to be the first editions (not counting parts of the Zohar like Patach Eliyahu that are included in siddurim).

The first vowelized translation of the Zohar I could find is Livorno, 5637-5648 (1877-1888). This only includes the Zohar on the five books of the Torah.

The first vowelized Tikkunei Zohar appears to be Jerusalem, 5663 (1903), and Jerusalem, 5669 (1909). The former is strangely only partially vowelized; the latter fully so.

The first complete vowelized Zohar edition, including Zohar Chadash and Tikkunei Zohar, appears to be Matok MiDvash, published 5753-5761 (1993-2001), but I couldn't confirm whether the first edition was also vowelized. If not, an edition of the Zohar with the Sullam commentary (ca. 2007 according to NLI) might have been the first vowelized Zohar Chadash, and the first complete Zohar including Tikkunim might be Zohar Menukkad apparently published by Heichala DeRashbi (undated, 5773/2013 according to NLI).

I would guess that the internet "tradition" derives from the Heichala DeRashbi edition. Torat Emet (crediting Rabbi Pinchas Reuven) has a Hebrew translation that appears to be identical to the Heichala DeRashbi version. Sefaria has two Hebrew versions, one crediting Torat Emet and the other crediting Zohar Menukkad, 5773 (2013).

title: Wearing a jacket with coins on Shabbat
content:
# Wearing a jacket with coins on Shabbat ## Frage

Suppose you have a jacket and stuck within the lining/fabric of the jacket somehow is some coins (at least you think they’re coins). There’s seemingly no way to get them out (apart from ripping the jacket open). May one wear this jacket on Shabbat since the coins/muktzeh are pretty much useless and you don’t care about them?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

I'm not a posek please ask your LOR

If you ask someone who knows how to sew, they will likely be easily able to open up the coat and take the coins out (not on Shabbat, obviously).

If its right before Shabbat and one needs the coat:

The Piskei Teshuvot O.C Siman 310:13 explains that if one left the coins or any other muktzeh in their pocket (i.e a jacket) with intent that they will stay there on Shabbat such as this case, then the Mishneh Berurah there Seif Katan 30 and 31 and Magen Avraham there say that if its a pocket sewn by its edges, where the garment is NOT a wall, the pocket is a complete pouch with its own front and back and is then sewn onto or into the garment only to attach it (like a coat), the coat would not be מקוצה because the pocket is בטל to the coat, and in footnote 87 he says that one can do so even lechtachilah as long as one's intention is not for the purpose of the coins.

However, this is all with regards to muktzeh, however, I think even if it's בטל (and there might be a case to argue the other way), we still hold by the Rema O.C 310:7 that one should not use the jacket because one might go outside the eiruv and forget about the coins.

However, because this is a unique case in which the coins are in the coat itself and not in the pockets (somehow), then I would say a kal vechomer that in terms of mukteh it's batel to the jacket but would still be assur to walk out of the house with it.

title: Why do the Shevatim in Sefer Shoftim Pose the 'Less' Fundamental Question to God?
content:
# Why do the Shevatim in Sefer Shoftim Pose the 'Less' Fundamental Question to God? ## Frage

Something is strange.

Judges 1:1:

וַֽיְהִ֗י אַֽחֲרֵי֙ מ֣וֹת יְהוֹשֻׁ֔עַ וַֽיִּשְׁאֲלוּ֙ בְּנֵ֣י יִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל בַּיהֹוָ֖ה לֵאמֹ֑ר מִ֣י יַעֲלֶה־לָּ֧נוּ אֶל־הַֽכְּנַעֲנִ֛י בַּתְּחִלָּ֖ה לְהִלָּ֥חֶם בּֽוֹ׃

After the death of Joshua, the Israelites inquired of GOD, “Which of us shall be the first to go up against the Canaanites and attack them?”

But, who says someone has to go first?

Abarbanel:

כי בהיות הארץ נחלקת היה ראוי שכל שבט ושבט ילחם מלחמותיו, ולמה יהיה אחד מהם עולה תחלה

In that the land was divided (among the tribes) it was fitting that each tribe would wage its war (individually & simultaneously), and so why should one of them go up first?

ולראשונה אשיב שהיה תכלית השאלה מי יעלה לנו במלחמה תחלה, לפי שהמלחמה הראשונה היה שורש גדול לשאר המלחמות, כי להיות יהושע מת הנה אם ילחם ישראל ויהיה מנוצח מהאויבים יאמרו כלם שסר צלם מעליהם ויתחזקו להלחם בישראל, מה שלא יהיה בראותם שגם אחרי מות יהושע ישראל ינצחו אותם ויעשו גבורות כירחי קדם,

As far as the first (question) I will reply that the objective of the question (posed to God) (about) 'who will go up from us and fight first' is because this first battle was a great root to the other battles. Since Joshua was dead, if Israel would fight and be defeated by the enemies, everyone would say that their shade/protection (of God) has departed from them. They (the enemy) would grow strong to fight against Israel, which would not be (the case), if they would see that also after the death of Joshua, Israel defeated them (the enemy) and performed great deeds as days of old.

לכן היתה התשובה יהודה יעלה, ר״ל שבחר ה׳ שילחם יהודה בראשונה וזה להפחיד בגבורותיו הגוים כלם Therefore the answer (from God) is that 'Judah should go up (first)', meaning that God chose that Judah should fight battles first in order to scare the nations, all of them, through his mighty deeds.

Ok. But if they were wise enough on their own to know that there should be an initial one-on-one battle (instead of all of the tribes fighting simultaneously), then why not also know without asking God that Yehuda was the most suitable choice (due to his might and regal nature - which is obvious and discussed at length in the Torah) for starting things?!

ממה נפשך- pose both questions to God (simultaneous v an initial one-on-one, and if the latter, who goes first?) or ask neither! In fact the question of whether to wage all out war or an initial one-on-one battle, strikes me as a meta-question and thus the more appropriate question to be submitted to God.

title: Why light menorah before Shabbat candles?
content:
# Why light menorah before Shabbat candles? ## Frage

What are the reasons on a Friday evening before Shabbat we light menorah before Shabbat candles? What pushes away Tadir of lighting Shabbat candles before Menorah?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

There seem to be three reasons:

  1. The Tur O.C 679, Shulchan Aruch OC 263:10, both quote the Behag that since by lighting candles one accepts Shabbat, then one should light Chanukah candles first and then Shabbat candles, this in effect pushes away the tadir. We also pasken like this Behag in Shulchan Aruch OC 679:1. This even applies to Sefardim, who don't generally hold like this Behag for Shabbat candles. As to why Sephardim (Mechaber) light Chanukah candles first and then Shabbat candles, see Chazon Ovadia Chanukah page 176, which in summary gives an approach that even though we should apply tadir (the more frequent mitzvah comes first) but persumei nisa of lighting Chanukah candles comes before tadir, therefore lighting Chanukah candles comes first.
  2. Ben Ish Chai Parashat Vayeshev 1:20 and Kaf Hachaim O.C Siman 678:2, quoting the Sha'ar Hakavanot 109a gives a kabbalistic reason for this- see there.
  3. Kaf Hachaim O.C 679 says that it's because of מעלין בקודש (going up in holiness), so therefore Chanukah goes first and then Shabbat (see here why this might be).
### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

Mikar hadin you're right ideally one should light shabbos candles before Chanuka. My Uncle told me the reason why we're noheg to do chanuka first is because of widows and divorcees. Since they accept shabbos with their lighting they can't light menora, so we dont want them to make mistake and light shabbos candles first. I would add that it's logical since chazal were mivatel mitzvos deoraisa lest one person violate shabbos, so to override a din of tadir for a similar reason seems befitting.

title: Differences between Pharaoh’s dreams
content:
# Differences between Pharaoh’s dreams ## Frage

In the parsha of Miketz, Pharaoh’s dreams are recorded twice, first as they occurred and then as Pharaoh retells them to Joseph, with noticeable differences between the two versions.

The Stone Chumash notes that there are variations but does not explain them, merely stating that they are discussed in another work (ArtScroll Bereishis, vol. II).

I would like to know what these differences actually are and how they are understood. Is there an online source that systematically lists the variations and explains their significance?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Alshech on Beresheet 41:17 lists the variations:

"וידבר פרעה כו'. ראוי לשית לב אל השנות החלום כמה שינויים מספר התורה אל סיפור פרעה כי למעלה נאמר עומד על היאור ופרעה אמר על שפת היאור למעלה נאמר יפות מראה ולמטה יפות תואר ולמעלה נאמר עולות אחריהן מן היאור ולמטה לא הוזכר היאור. למעלה לא אמר רק רעות מראה ודקות בשר. ולמטה מפליג ואומר דלות ורעות תואר מאד לא ראיתי כו' לרוע. ולמעלה מראה ולמטה תואר וכל פסוק ותבאנה אל קרבנה וגו' לא הוזכר למעלה כלל. ולמעלה אמר וישן ויחלום שנית ולמטה אמר וארא בחלומי כאילו הכל היה כאחת. ולמעלה נאמר בריאות ולמטה מלאות. למעלה אמר צנומות ולמטה לא נאמר למעלה אומר הבריאות והמלאות ולמטה הטובות:"

"And Pharaoh said etc. It is worth noting that the dream underwent several changes from the manner it was described in the Torah to the way it was recounted by Pharaoh (to Yosef): Above it said that Pharaoh was standing on the Nile, and below it said that Pharaoh stood on the shore of the Nile. Above it said that they (the healthy cows) were handsome (יפות מראה) and below that they were (well-made) (יפות תואר). Above it said that they (the sickly cows) rose after them from the Nile and below the Nile was not mentioned. Above it said only that they (the sickly cows) were ugly and gaunt (רעות המראה ודקות) and below it expanded that they were "scrawny, ugly and gaunt—never had I seen their likes for ugliness in all the land of Egypt!" (דלות ורעות תואר מאד לא ראיתי כהנה בכל ארץ מצרים לרוע). Above it said that he (Pharaoh) went back to sleep and dreamt again, and below he said that "I saw in my dream" as though everything occurred in the same dream. Above it said "healthy" (wheat) (בריאות) and below it said "full" (wheat) (מלאות). Above it said "thin" (צנומות) (wheat) but below it did not mention this. Above it said "the healthy and full" (הבריאות והמלאות) and below it said "the good" (הטובות).

Alshech then suggested that the reason Pharaoh changed the dreams' description was because he originally recounted the dreams to his magicians and wisemen, but they offered unconvincing solutions, and he was afraid that Yosef would offer the same type of solutions. So, he changed the wording so that Yosef would reach a different conclusion. Alshech has a lengthy explanation for the reason behind each of the changes. Alshech then indicates that Yosef was aware that Pharaoh had two separate dreams, as we can see from the words "חלום פרעה אחד הוא" (Pharaoh's dream(s) is/are one).

title: If a married lady had relations with another man and tells her husband, how can she return to her husband?
content:
# If a married lady had relations with another man and tells her husband, how can she return to her husband? ## Frage

If a married lady had relations with another man and tells her husband and there were no witnesses, she isn’t believed and the husband can stay with her.

But what about shavye anafsha chaticha d'isura* for her, meaning how can she live with her husband, when she says she committed adultery?

* "they have made themself [like into] a prohibited piece [of food]". Basically, she has, by her own words, made herself like something forbidden (to herself).

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

This question is raised by the Ra"n on the mishna in Masechet Nedarim (90b), he iterates through a few attempts to answer this question.

  • Chaza"l permitted her in this case, because of the concern she is lying in order to obtain a divorce (he rejects this, because Chaza"l generally don't have the ability to actively contradict a biblical law);

  • Chaza"l retroactively nullified her original marriage, so the person she is continuing to live with is no longer her husband (the issue he raises with this answer is that if she claimed to have had relations with someone who would prohibit her to her husband, regardless of their marital status - such as a Nasin or a mamzer, she would be prohibited to her husband in that case);

  • She doesn't have the ability to declare herself forbidden, because she is "owned" by her husband, so to speak.

Tosafot loc sit cites R' Eliezer from Mainz who gives an astonishing answer - he says that the prohibition for the woman stems from and is a reflection of the man's prohibition - so seeing as technically the man is permitted to her, she is permitted to him too.

title: Upon what passages of scripture is the Jewish concept of purgation based?
content:
# Upon what passages of scripture is the Jewish concept of purgation based? ## Frage

From which scriptual sources the Jewish understanding of Gehinnom is developed from?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Iyov 36:16

Moreover, He has distanced you from that which has a narrow entrance but has unbounded width beneath. This is so that the fare upon your table might be rich.

Rabbi Eisenmann in the Artscroll Iyov edition says that according to Rashi, this is the direct reference to Gehinnom.

Isaiah 66:24 suggests a fiery moment for the wicked

They shall go out and gaze on the corpses of those who rebelled against Me: Their worms shall not die, nor their fire be quenched; they shall be a horror to all flesh.

Pesachim 54a and Nedarim 39b talk about the time when Gehinnom was created; it is based on verse:

“For its hearth is ordained of old” (Isaiah 30:33).

Midrash Tehilim on Psalms 90:12 (missing in Sefaria) derives from the verse that

Gan Eden at the right of HKBH and Gehinnom at His left

Mostly the verses are mentioned in the context of various discussions. For example, regarding who goes to Gehinnom, Tosefta Sanhedrin 13:1, Rosh Hashanah 16b - 17a, Tosefta Sanhedrin 12:5, Rosh Hashanah 17a:

Zechariah 13:9: "And I brought the third into the fire," etc., 1 Samuel 2:6: "The Lord kills and makes alive." Malachi 3:21: “And you shall tread down the wicked; for they shall be ashes under the soles of your feet”. Isaiah 66:24: “And they shall go forth, and look upon the carcasses of the men that have rebelled against Me; for their worm shall not die; neither shall their fire be quenched; and they shall be an abhorrence to all flesh”. Psalms 49:15: “And their form shall wear away the netherworld, so that there be no dwelling for Him” I Kings 8:13: “I have built You a house for dwelling [zevul] in”. I Samuel 2:10: “The adversaries of the Lord shall be broken in pieces”.

Rabbi Akiva used Isaiah 66:23 regarding the 12 months sentence.

There is a similar discussion of Gehinnom in Eruvin 19a, so that all verses mentioned there have relevance for the subject: Psalms 84:7, Isaiah 66:24 and some others. Additionally, the same gemara and Succah 32b speak of 3 entrances to Gehinnom:

Numbers 16:33: “And they, and all that appertained to them, went down alive into the pit [She’ol], and the earth closed upon them, and they perished from among the congregation”. Jonah 2:3: “Out of the belly of the netherworld [She’ol] I cried, and You did hear my voice”. Isaiah 31:9: “Says the Lord, Whose fire is in Zion, and Whose furnace is in Jerusalem”.

Afterwards, the gemara discusses 7 names of Gehinnom, which have been discussed on this forum. The relevant verses: Jonah 2:3, Psalms 88:12, Psalms 16:10, Psalms 40:3, Psalms 107:10, Isaiah 30:33.

Nedarim 8b, Midrash Bereshis Rabba 6:6 and Bereshis Rabba 26:6 discuss if there will be Gehinom in the future: Malachi 3:19, Isaiah 31:9, Isaiah 33:11.

Sefer haMafteyach by Daniel Retter on p. 91 provides all the places in the Gemara that discuss Gehinnom. The excercise of identifying the verses can be applied to all these places. The additional references are here:

  1. Gehinnom on Shabbos: Sanhedrin 65b
  2. Prayer of a maiden not to enter Gehinnom: Sota 22a
  3. Coals of a broom tree, Arakhin 15b
  4. Judgement of 12 months for the wicked, Shabbos 33b
  5. The world is like a cover of a pot in reference to Gehinnom, Taanis 10a.

title: Views on Historical Linguistics
content:
# Views on Historical Linguistics ## Frage

In academic linguistics, it’s widely accepted that just as many of today’s languages evolved from older attested languages (Italian from Latin, Syriac from Aramaic, Modern Greek from Ancient Greek, etc), those older languages are descendants of even older “Proto-Languages” and are a part of large language families (Indo-European, Semitic, Uralic, Japonic, etc).

My question is, is the opinion that Lashon Haqodesh was used to create the world and is the ‘original language’ at all reconcilable with the academic theory that Hebrew is descended from Proto-Semitic? Or do those who hold this opinion simply reject the academic theory?

My immediate theory to reconcile the two would be that Hashem created the world using Lashon Haqodesh, however either after the tower of Bavel (or maybe earlier?), Hashem dispersed the languages of the world, and in a sort of “guided evolution”, had Lashon Haqodesh evolve from Proto-Semitic. Is this a valid view? Are there any Acharonim (or the far less likely Rishonim) who speak on this issue?

title: Can a woman ever serve as a Dayan?
content:
# Can a woman ever serve as a Dayan? ## Frage

I've heard of a concept where there are circumstances where a woman may judge between two parties if both accept her. Is this accurate? Are there circumstances where a woman may serve as a judge?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

Yes, that is how the Prophetess Devorah serving as a judge is explained. The Torah states appoint for yourself a king not a queen (paraphrasing Rambam...), means anyone in non democratic position of power or leadership. Whether the election must be unanimous or not is its own debate. Interestingly enough, it's discussed now how in Israel the Rabbinate is often appointed vs in the USA and elsewhere, the congregational leaders are elected.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

The Rambam is clear that judges must be male:

We appoint to a Sanhedrin - both to the Supreme Sanhedrin and to a minor Sanhedrin - only men of wisdom and understanding, of unique distinction in their knowledge of the Torah and who possess a broad intellectual potential... We should not appoint to a Sanhedrin a man of very old age or one who does not possess male physical attributes, for they possess the trait of cruelty, nor a man who is childless, so that the judges should be merciful. [Rambam, Hilchot Sanhedrin 2:1–3]

On the other hand, if two disputants agree to let a third party arbitrate their dispute, I don't see why that would be prohibited, no matter who (or what) that third party is. (It could be a coin.)

title: Trying to track down a historical reference made by Arukh haShulchan
content:
# Trying to track down a historical reference made by Arukh haShulchan ## Frage

Whom might the Arukh haShulchan have been referring to below?

My best guess would be Philo... which of course would really be cheating, as citations go; while culturally entirely Greek, he's a Hellenized Jew and hardly impartial on the question of how the Gentile ancients would have assessed Jewish prophecy and its relation to Jewish astronomical wisdom.

וכבר אמר אחד מגדולי חכמי יוון, שחישוב המולד לישראל הוא אות ומופת על הנבואה בישראל.

And so proclaimed one of the Greek sages in considering the Hebrew calendar proof of Israel's prophetic legacy. (Source)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 8)

R Yitzchok Zilber writes regarding The eternal wisdom of the Jewish calendar here

This structure is so precise that Don Yitzchak Abarbanel reports Ptolemy was stunned by it, declaring: “This proves the Jews had prophecy.”

@Meir provided the original source for this, in Abarbanel's commentary to Shemot 12:1

עד שמפני עוצם החכמה שהיתה בחכמי ישראל בדבר הזה הפליג בטלמיוס היוני לשבח ולפאר מי שהמציא זה המחזור של י"ט שנה במלאכ' העיבור אשר לבני ישראל וכתב שזה יוכיח שהיתה ביניהם נבואה

...to the point that because of the tremendous wisdom that the Jewish sages had in this area, the Greek Ptolemy greatly praised the inventor of the 19-year intercalary cycle that the Jews used, and wrote that this demonstrates that they possessed prophecy.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

Adding to @mbloch's answer, it should be noted that there's a good chance that Abarbanel was basing himself on Ralbag (Shemot 12:2) who stated:

"ולזה הפליג באטולויאו"ס היוני לשבח מי שהמציא זה המחזור מי"ט שנה כי הוא הזמן הראשון שיקיף בחדשים ובשנים שלמים."

"...and for this reason Ptolemius the Grecian greatly praised he who invented the 19-year cycle, for this was the first calculation that followed through full months and years."

Having looked through Ptolemy's discussion of the 19-year cycle in his Almagest, Book III, I saw that he doesn't directly praise the creators of the cycle (and never mind mentioning the Jewish version of this calculation, and of course does not praise the prophets), but he does find it to be a very accurate calculation, albeit needing some tweaking, to which he dedicated a lengthy mathematic and astronomic discussion. The notion that he praised the Jews/prophets for this is probably a later idea, akin to the traditions regarding Yirmiyahu teaching/meeting Plato (for one lengthy discussion of this topic, see here), or other famous philosophers meeting other famous Jewish figures, such as King Shlomo.

title: How to refer to the G-ds in other religions?
content:
# How to refer to the G-ds in other religions? ## Frage

I have come to a dilemma in many school projects in my time at different levels of school. In high school, I remember I had to write diary entries from the point of view of a Christian woman in the French Revolution, and I had to refer to Greek G-ds when reading various Greek plays.

I never knew how to approach it. I write G-d or Hashem usually, but doing this with the G-ds of other religions seems to imply that the G-d they believe in should be revered enough that I could not spell out the word "G-d" when referring to them. I do not believe this, and when I did this in high school it always felt like a was breaking the rule to "distance yourself from idol worship" seen here in Pirkei Avos 1:7

נִתַּאי הָאַרְבֵּלִי אוֹמֵר, הַרְחֵק מִשָּׁכֵן רָע, וְאַל תִּתְחַבֵּר לָרָשָׁע, וְאַל תִּתְיָאֵשׁ מִן הַפֻּרְעָנוּת: Nittai the Arbelite used to say: keep a distance from an evil neighbor, do not become attached to the wicked, and do not abandon faith in [divine] retribution.

I have also just written the word G-d with an o in the middle, uncapitalized to show my non-belief in the other religions G-d, but even then, it seemed to me that this could be interpreted as suspending my belief in Hashem for a moment to speak of other G-ds. (Sorry if that is unclear, it's hard to explain; honestly it just felt sketchy.)

So, what should I do when referring to other G-ds?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The Torah describes idols as "elohim acheirim", i.e. "other powers":

לֹא־יִהְיֶ͏ה־לְךָ אֱלֹהִים אֲחֵרִים עַל־פָּנָ͏ַי׃

Thou shalt have no other gods beside me. [Exodus 20:3]

If you click on the link I provided above, it will show you the 11 different professional English translations available on Sefaria for translating the Torah. All but one translate the word "אֱלֹהִים" as "god". Note, even in Hebrew, the word used is the same word used for Hashem when being referred to as G-d (such as in the first pasuk of the Torah), and this is in quite a famous pasuk, being the Second Commandment!

This, indeed, is completely standard and accepted. Therefore, you are more than welcome to write "god" without worrying that you are suspending belief in Hashem or giving that impression. If you still don't like it, you could try what the 11th translation did, and use "deity". You may feel that that has the same problem, but as I've proven, even the Torah is happy to use the same word for both G-d Himself, and false gods. Don't over think it!

Nonetheless, be careful when it comes to Christianity and Islam. They are Abrahamic religions that ostensibly believe in the same God of Abraham as us, and therefore you might wish to write G-d in that context. Obviously, not for Jesus, but if they are more generally discussing G-d (which indeed, other religions might also do). Ask your local orthodox Rabbi.

It's also worth noting that it's not universally accepted that one must insert the hyphen in the word "G-d". See here: When blogging/emailing/etc., do I use "God" or "G-d"? (and this is also relevant: Writing HaShem's actual name in English) and ask your local orthodox Rabbi what custom you should follow.

title: Does the discomfort of a fast matter in relation to the spiritual benefit?
content:
# Does the discomfort of a fast matter in relation to the spiritual benefit? ## Frage

Odd question but I was curious where the Rabbis fall on this.

Fasting is a common practice in Judaism. There's a spiritual benefit associated with it. My question is how the "value" of a fast is determined and if the value changes depending on the struggle of the fast.

For example. I have a friend who suffers from ADHD. He takes a medication which makes eating for him almost impossible. In such a context, if a person took a medication which suppressed hunger, how would that impact the fast's benefit to one's soul or spiritual development?

My thoughts break down to the following possibilities:

  1. No matter what the fast is valid so don't worry about the fact it may come easier due to a necessary medication.
  2. The discomfort associated with fasting has benefit because you're suffering for God. The willingness to take on discomfort and deny yourself as a sign of love adds a second layer to the fast besides the act itself.
  3. Being able to condition yourself to discomfort is a positive character trait one should develop in general. So hiding from discomfort ultimately hides you from the benefits and growth of that discomfort.

I was curious if there were any sources discussing this.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Great question!

Within the example you gave, although your friend doesn't feel the hunger, the fast is only a preparation for teshuvah, as the Rambam says in Hilchot Taanit 5:1 (also mentioned by Mishneh Berurah O.C 549:1).

Two Major components of the fast:

1) The Gemera in Brachot 6b says that the reward for a fast day is from the tzedaka that one gives. The Meil Tzedaka 435 writes in the name of Rabbi Yehuda Hachassid that תענית (fast day) and תת עני (give to the poor) have the same letters because the fast is only complete if you give tzedaka.

2) Another major thing that we do on fast days, which is very important, is Teshuvah as mentioned above. The Gemera in Taanit 15a says that it does not state with regard to the people of Nineveh: And God saw their sackcloth and their fasting. Rather, the verse says: “And G-d saw their deeds, that they had turned from their evil way” (Jonah 3:10). And in the Prophets it says: “And rend your hearts and not your garments, and return to the Lord your God” (Joel 2:13). This teaches that prayer and fasting are insufficient, as one must do teshuvah. The Rambam Taanit 5:1 and the Mishneh Berurah O.C Siman 529:1 say that fasting brings to teshuvah, which is a major aspect. The Mishneh Berurah adds that he doesn't understand people who waste their fast day strolling around and wasting time; he says they are doing the טפל and disregarding the עיקר.

Therefore, if one gives tzedakah and has done teshuvah and doesn't feel any hunger or thirst, one has definitely impacted one's spiritual development for the good and will get rewarded immensely, as the fast is only a way that leads to teshuvah, but if one can to it without feeling the hunger like in this case than one has accomplished the goal of the fast.

(Of course, mederabbanan, those who are physically capable of fasting must fast, but I am only discussing this specific case, which can be applied to other similar types people who might be exempt from fasting because of any physical incapability and yet are still able to achieve the goal of the fast if they give tzedaka and do teshuvah- assuming they are also capable of doing that).

title: What was so impressive about Yosef's refusal to sin, if he received such a severe warning from Yaakov?
content:
# What was so impressive about Yosef's refusal to sin, if he received such a severe warning from Yaakov? ## Frage

Rashi (Genesis 39:11) brings the well known Gemara (Sota 36b - see below) that at the time that Eishes Potifar was tempting him to sin "שֶׁנִּרְאֵית לוֹ דְּמוּת דְּיוּקְנוֹ שֶׁל אָבִיו וכו'" - "Yaakov's face appeared to him etc" and it helped him withstand the temptation. That word "etc" is actually quite important here. Because if you look up the gemara it says the following:

״וַתִּתְפְּשֵׂהוּ בְּבִגְדוֹ לֵאמֹר וְגוֹ׳״, בְּאוֹתָהּ שָׁעָה בָּאתָה דְּיוֹקְנוֹ שֶׁל אָבִיו וְנִרְאֲתָה לוֹ בַּחַלּוֹן, אָמַר לוֹ יוֹסֵף! עֲתִידִין אַחֶיךָ שֶׁיִּכָּתְבוּ עַל אַבְנֵי אֵפוֹד וְאַתָּה בֵּינֵיהֶם, רְצוֹנְךָ שֶׁיִּמָּחֶה שִׁמְךָ מִבֵּינֵיהֶם, וְתִקָּרֵא רוֹעֶה זוֹנוֹת? דִּכְתִיב: ״וְרֹעֶה זוֹנוֹת יְאַבֶּד הוֹן״.

The verse states: “And she caught him by his garment, saying: Lie with me” (Genesis 39:12). At that moment his father’s image [deyokeno] came and appeared to him in the window. The image said to him: Joseph, the names of your brothers are destined to be written on the stones of the ephod, and you are to be included among them. Do you desire your name to be erased from among them, and to be called an associate [ro’eh] of promiscuous women? As it is written: “But he who keeps company with harlots wastes his riches” (Proverbs 29:3), as he loses his honor, which is more valuable than wealth. [Steinsaltz annotated translation and commentary]

The question, therefore, is what was so special about Yosef passing this test? He had this incredible vision of his father clearly explaining to him the massive consequences of his action and the terrible ramifications. We all know that we are only able to commit aveiros because we are temporarily taken over by a "Ruach Shtus" - "a spirit of folly" ("רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ אָמַר: אֵין אָדָם עוֹבֵר עֲבֵירָה אֶלָּא אִם כֵּן נִכְנַס בּוֹ רוּחַ שְׁטוּת" - Sotah 3a). Surely Yaakov's stern warning to Yosef would totally obliterate this Ruach Shtus! Can't we all say that if we had such clear visions challenging our own Ruach Shtus then we too wouldn't sin? Why is Yosef’s restraint so special?

I have a number of answers that I have come up with myself, but I am looking for answers with a source, preferably from Rishonim or pre-war Achronim.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

I have found a source that deals directly with my question!

I found this publication which in Paragraph 8 on Page 4 says the following:

The peirush Yefei To’ar on the Midrash explains at length that it cannot be that Yaakov actually appeared to Yosef at that point, because if he had, it would be no challenge for Yosef to overcome his yetzer hara. With such a revelation, who wouldn’t run away like from fire— knowing that his father is watching and warning him that he will lose his place on the Choshen if he fails?

The Yefei To’ar explains that this imagery was conjured by Yosef himself. When faced with the nisayon, he started contemplating who he is, and where he comes from. He started thinking about his heilige tatte Yaakov, and remembered the hashra’as haShechinah he had experienced in his father’s home. The avnei haChoshen represent this idea, that Hashem rests His Shechinah on the Shevatim. As Yosef thought about it, he realized that if he falls, he will be removed from the company of the Shevatim; he will no longer be able to host the Shechinah. This is what he saw in his mind’s eye.

This Yefei To'ar is on Bereishis Rabbah 87:7 and can be seen properly here

איקונין של אביו. בסוטה איתא שאביו אמר לו אם תשמע אליו ימחה שמך מבין שמות אחיך על אבני אפוד. ובאמת לפ"ז מאי רבותי' דיוסף כי מי פתי יסור לעבירה אחרי זאת. וביותר קשה לפי המדרש אבכיר (והובא במהרז"ו) היתכן כי אחרי אשר ראה יוסף איקונין של אביו וברח מפני הבושה. נכנס פעם שנייה עד שהזהירו הקב"ה באזהרה קשה כי יחריב את העולם. הלא תחת אשר ירבו הנפלאות יקטינו מעלת יוסף מאד. ובעל מגלה עמוקות כתב. כי הכוונה בזה שהשקיף עליו אור השכל שהוא דיוקנו של אביו וראה שאם יעשה כן ימחה מתוך אחיו וכן רמז בעל תהלה לדוד בח"ג פכ"ו. ולי נראה שהכוונה בזה כי בחלון בית משכיות עינו וחכמתו הציץ ביחסו והיות השכינה שורה בבית אביו וזהו היא כתיבתן על אבני אפוד לזכרון לפני ה' תמיד ובחטא זה יאבד טובה הרבה לכן פירש ולפי דברי מדרש אבכיר בכל זאת לא שב אף תוקף יצרו עד שהציץ עוד כי אם יחטא ואשם ויקלקל סדר העולם אשר הושתת על מוסדות המוסר והמדות הלא יחריב את העולם. ומה נאוה עוד שם מה שאמר לה בת חמור את וחמור אינו רואה ואני מן הרואים שנאמר וירא את המקום מרחוק. אשר פי' כי הדבקים בתאותם נכבה אור שכלם ולא יראו את האחרית אשר תצא ממעשיהם הרעים. ואנכי ממשפחה הרואה את כל דבר מרחוק ואת כל אשר יולד ממנו. וזה הוא ג"כ כוונת המדרש איקונין של אביו ראה. כי זכר את הצור אשר ממנו חוצב. כי הוא נקי וטהור מכל תאוה סוררה. ואל אביו הי' בעזרו כי יגבר עליו כח השכל ויכניע את יצרו הרע:

### Antwort 2 (Score: -1)
BS'D

"The question therefore is what was so special about Yosef passing this test?" I'm not sure necessarily that this was so special on Joseph's part. There is a strong case this was a tremendous miraculous Hizuq from G-d that saved Joseph from sinning and kept him on the path of righteousness, The sages of the Talmud even say it was because of this event that Joseph is not called the father of the 12 tribes of Israel (Sotah 36b). At the least, I think this is evidence that he did not do everything perfectly. It presents a case for אִם עוֹשִׂין לוֹ נֵס- מְנַכִּין לוֹ מִזְּכֻיוֹתָיו (Shabbath 32A) - A person who placed themself in a dangerous situation and then was saved, he has his merits reduced. Afterall, It is a recorded opinion (Sotah 36b, also see Tanhuma) that Joseph intentionally secluded himself with Esheth Potiphar to "do his needs" and only after that, he was saved via miracle that helped him snap back to reality. See Ohr HaHaim here as well.

The text (Sotah 36b.15) says he merited to have his name on the ephod and be called a Ro'eh Israel because of the 'Aveer Yaakov אֲבִיר יַעֲקֹב, Otherwise he would have been eschewed from the ephod and considered as a Ro'eh of harlots if not for the miraculous intervention (36.13). Essentially God gave Joseph a vision saying "If you do this crime, you will be defamed and called a Ro'eh of harlots." and Joseph chose not to do it, and as a result he is called instead a Ro'eh Israel (but not an Avi Israel as he would have been called). Instead of him having 12 sons, he had 2 and his brother's 10 were named for him... significant demotion (Ibid). He comes out considered righteous (but not without any blame) because of the intervention. Still, when he had the matter laid out for him miraculously from God, not unlike Parshath Re'eh רְאֵ֗ה אָנֹכִ֛י נֹתֵ֥ן לִפְנֵיכֶ֖ם הַיּ֑וֹם בְּרָכָ֖ה וּקְלָלָֽה, he could chose a blessing or a curse, he chose the blessing, which is certainly a righteous choice and that is why he is called a Ro'eh Israel and a Tzadiq. I don't think I would characterize that choice as special or great but Betzadeq. There are men who would have made the other choice, like Esau essentially made the other choice, intentionally choosing not to be considered an Avi Israel and to instead live a life of edom. When laid out for him, Yoseph realized he wanted to be on the right side of history. He did need divine intervention, he certainly could have performed better, but he is still righteous based off his conduct here.

B'H

content:
# Bereshit 40:5: Artscroll Commentary (Rashi/Midrash) ## Frage

I am seeking clarification regarding the Midrashic interpretation of the chamberlains' dreams (Genesis 40:5). The core teaching, cited by Rashi, is found in Bereshit Rabbah 88:4 (linked below).

The ArtScroll commentary on Bereshit 40:5 summarizes this interpretation:

"Each one dreamt what would eventually happen to his colleague (but not to himself), so that when each one heard how Joseph interpreted the other one’s dream, it was clear that he was surely right."

When I analyzed this commentary with my AI study assistant (Gemini), it offered the following explanation about the dream's structure:

"The dream of the baker contains both a metaphor about his own fate and an explanation about his colleague's fate."

Is this analysis correct? Is the accepted way of understanding Bereshit Rabbah 88:4 that the Chief Baker's single dream must be seen as having these two components simultaneously?

Why does the ArtScroll comment say "but not to himself"? If the dream includes the metaphor for the baker's own fate, how does the phrase "but not to himself" apply?

The original Midrash is Bereshit Rabbah 88:4.

title: Would God give us a Bible, Torah, to follow as best we could, only to change it into something entirely different like Islam, Christian or Morman?
content:
# Would God give us a Bible, Torah, to follow as best we could, only to change it into something entirely different like Islam, Christian or Morman? ## Frage 
   It explicitly commands us to not add or subtract (Devarim 4:2, Devarim 13:1):
   You shall not add to the word which I command you, neither shall you diminish from it, that you may keep the commandments of the Lord your God which I command you. [Devarim 4:2]
   
   It explicitly says that no prophet can come along and change the Torah, even if he performs miracles (Devarim 13)
   If there arise among you a prophet, or a dreamer of dreams, and he give thee a sign or a wonder, and the sign or the wonder come to pass, of which he spoke to thee, saying, Let us go after other gods, which thou hast not known, and let us serve them; thou shalt not hearken to the words of that prophet, or that dreamer of dreams: for the Lord your God puts you to the proof, to know whether you love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul.
## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

He didn't. The are all man-made, except the Torah.

It's clear as day that He would never change or replace it. There are a few inescapable truths about the Torah:

  1. It explicitly commands us to not add or subtract (Devarim 4:2, Devarim 13:1):

    לא תספו על־הדבר אשר אנכי מצוה אתכם ולא תגרעו ממנו לשמר את־מצות יהוה אלהיכם אשר אנכי מצוה אתכם

    You shall not add to the word which I command you, neither shall you diminish from it, that you may keep the commandments of the Lord your God which I command you. [Devarim 4:2]

  2. It explicitly says that no prophet can come along and change the Torah, even if he performs miracles (Devarim 13)

    כִּי־יָקוּם בְּקִרְבְּךָ נָבִיא אוֹ חֹלֵם חֲלוֹם וְנָתַן אֵלֶיךָ אוֹת אוֹ מוֹפֵת׃ וּבָא הָאוֹת וְהַמּוֹפֵת אֲשֶׁר־דִּבֶּר אֵלֶיךָ לֵאמֹר נֵלְכָה אַחֲרֵי אֱלֹהִים אֲחֵרִים אֲשֶׁר לֹא־יְדַעְתָּם וְנׇעׇבְדֵם׃ לֹא תִשְׁמַע אֶל־דִּבְרֵי הַנָּבִיא הַהוּא אוֹ אֶל־חוֹלֵם הַחֲלוֹם הַהוּא כִּי מְנַסֶּה יְהֹוָה אֱלֹהֵיכֶם אֶתְכֶם לָדַעַת הֲיִשְׁכֶם אֹהֲבִים אֶת־יְהֹוָה אֱלֹהֵיכֶם בְּכׇל־לְבַבְכֶם וּבְכׇל־נַפְשְׁכֶם׃

    If there arise among you a prophet, or a dreamer of dreams, and he give thee a sign or a wonder, and the sign or the wonder come to pass, of which he spoke to thee, saying, Let us go after other gods, which thou hast not known, and let us serve them; thou shalt not hearken to the words of that prophet, or that dreamer of dreams: for the Lord your God puts you to the proof, to know whether you love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul [Devarim 13:2-4]

  3. The Torah uses phrases like "this is forever", "eternal covenant" and "this will never be changed" more than a couple dozen times, e.g. Devarim 29:28

    הַנִּסְתָּרֹת לַיהֹוָה אֱלֹהֵינוּ וְהַנִּגְלֹת לָנוּ וּלְבָנֵינוּ עַד־עוֹלָם לַעֲשׂוֹת אֶת־כׇּל־דִּבְרֵי הַתּוֹרָה הַזֹּאת׃

    The secret things belong to the Lord our God: but those things which are revealed belong to us and to our children for ever, that we may do all the words of this Tora. [Devarim 29:28]

  4. It concludes with a reminder to remember Moshe's Torah (Malachi 3:22)

    זִכְרוּ תּוֹרַת מֹשֶׁה עַבְדִּי אֲשֶׁר צִוִּיתִי אוֹתוֹ בְחֹרֵב עַל־כׇּל־יִשְׂרָאֵל חֻקִּים וּמִשְׁפָּטִים׃

    Remember the Tora of Moshe my servant, which I commanded him in Ḥorev for all Yisra᾽el, both statutes and judgments. [Malachi 3:22]
