title: Bal tosiph on Chanukah
content:
# Bal tosiph on Chanukah ## Frage

If one was to light on the 9th day of "Chanukah" 9 candles will he be oiver bal tosiph because he added to Chanukah? And if yes, will it be with the 1st light or with the 9th one?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 10)

In שו"ת התעוררות תשובה ח"ג סימן סו the grandson of the Chatam Sofer addresses this exact question:

״והנה כיון ששייך גם במצות דרבנן ב"ת ובל תגרע המדליק ט' ימים נרות חנוכה או רק ז' ימים או שקורא מגילה גם בט"ו לשם מצוה עובר, ואם איש א' עושה מצוה אשר אינו מצווה עלי' עתה ועושה אותה בזמנה נראה מדברי הפוסקים שמותר כמבואר בשו"ע או"ח סימן י"ג שמותר ליקח טלית חבירו שלא מדעתו ולברך עליו הגם שטלית שאולה פטור אפי' מדרבנן יכול לברך עליו כמו נשים שמברכות על מ"ע שהזמ"ג הגם שאינם מחוייבים בשום פעם בה, מכ"ש איש שמחוייב לפעמים בה, וכן מצינו כ"פ שכל הפטור מן הדבר ועושהו נקרא הדיוט מ"מ אינו עובר על ב"ת כיון שהדבר בעצמותו היא מצוה, וכן אי' ברמב"ם הל' מלכים שגוי שחידש דת חוץ מז' מצוות שלו חייב מיתה, אבל אם עושה מצוה אחת ממצות התוה"ק כדי לקבל שכר מותר לעשותם, אבל אין ראיה מזה שהלא הגוי אינו מחייב בבל תוסיף.״

“And behold, since the prohibitions of bal tosif (do not add) and bal tigra (do not detract) also apply to rabbinic commandments, one who lights Chanukkah candles for nine days, or only seven days, or who reads the Megillah also on the fifteenth with the intention of fulfilling a commandment, transgresses. However, if a person performs a commandment that he is not presently obligated in, but performs it at its proper time, it appears from the words of the halachic authorities that this is permitted. This is explained in Shulchan Aruch, Orach Chaim, siman 13, that one is permitted to take his fellow’s tallit without his knowledge and recite a blessing over it, even though a borrowed tallit is exempt—even rabbinically—and nevertheless one may recite a blessing over it, similar to women who recite blessings over positive time-bound commandments even though they are never obligated in them. All the more so in the case of a man, who is obligated in them at certain times. Likewise, we find in many places that although one who is exempt from a matter and nevertheless performs it is called a hedyot (an ordinary person), he does not transgress bal tosif, since the act itself is inherently a mitzvah. And so it is stated in Rambam, Hilchot Melachim, that a gentile who innovates a new religion beyond his seven commandments is liable to death, but if he performs one of the commandments of the holy Torah in order to receive reward, he is permitted to do so. However, this is not a proof here, for a gentile is not subject to the prohibition of bal tosif.”

According to the grandson of the Chatam Sofer, if someone lights for 9 days with kavanah to fulfill the mitzvah, he is violating בל תוסיף.

I would also add that there might be an issue of מראית עין. Rashi in Kreitot 21b and Pesachim 13a says that one of the reasons why מארית עין is assur is because others might see the person doing something wrong and think its okay to do, which would certainly apply here. Even if there is a case where no one will see the candles (which should not be the case), the Gemera in Shabbat (64b, 146b) says that מראית עין is assur בחדרי חדרים (behind closed doors), and this is how we pasken in Shulchan Aruch O.C Siman 301:45.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

If he said a blessing, it is a blessing in vain, and he has taken Hashem's name in vain. If he lit without a blessing, he did nothing different from lighting candles in June.

will it be with the 1st light or with the 9th one?

The basic mitzvah is one candle. Adding another one per night is a beautification of the mitzvah, i.e. "hidur".

title: Civil Marriage before Nisuin
content:
# Civil Marriage before Nisuin ## Frage

Is one allowed to get their civil marriage license before the halachic Jewish marriage? Would there be any issues with this?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

This is allowed.

In many European countries, it is forbidden for a Rabbi to marry a couple who hasn't received a marriage license first. As such, all couples first go to the city office, or whoever is in charge of issuing such licenses, to get married.

In many cases, this is done with a close circle of family and friends followed by a drink, and takes place hours or 1-2 days before the halachic wedding. Some make it even less of a deal, by only have the couple and civil witnesses there.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

There's a difference between a "civil marriage license" and a "civil marriage".

The former merely means that you have legal permission (license) from the authorities to get married.

You can then choose how you want to get married (e.g. rabbi, church, judge, court clerk etc.).

There is nothing wrong with this, and in many places is legally required before the rabbi can perform the religious wedding ceremony.

The latter, "civil marriage", without a Halachic ceremony, can be more problematic, since it may remove a possible inhibition to pre-marital intimacy, with the couple rationalizing that it's permitted since they are legally a couple.

In addition, the is a minority opinion (Rabbi Yosef Eliyahu Henkin) who held that civil marriages are considered valid according to Jewish law, even if they do not involve a Jewish ceremony. He argued, that if a couple is known to be married by the public, they are married by virtue of their marital relations, which he considered to be binding under halacha, and would require a Jewish divorce (Get) should they decide to part ways.

title: Prohibition of Bamot during the Shiloh period - really?
content:
# Prohibition of Bamot during the Shiloh period - really? ## Frage

This related question wonders about a specific altar perhaps built at Shiloh while there was already an altar at the Mishkan in Shiloh (according to Metzudat David). My question is broader.

According to Mishna Zevachim 14:6, when Am Yisrael rebuilt the Mishkan at Shiloh, the prohibition of bamot was reinstituted. However, having looked over the first few books of Nevi'im Rishonim, it's not clear to me where the Tannaim learned this idea from. P'shat Tanach appears to contradict such a notion. Here is a list of places where worship sites (bamot, altars, houses of worship) were built in the Shiloh period (assuming this period began with Yehoshua 18:1 and ended with the destruction of the Mishkan at Shiloh in Shmuel 1:4:12-22, see Yirmiyahu 7:12 with Metzudat David and Radak), with the context implying that these were thought to be legitimate worship sites:

  • Shechem - Mikdash Hashem (Yehoshua 24:26)
  • Bochim - altar (Shoftim 2:5)
  • Ofrah of the Aviezerites - spontaneous altar (Shoftim 6:21) turned into permanent altar (6:24); second permanent altar (6:25-28)
  • Tzor'ah - spontaneous altar (Shoftim 13:19-20)
  • *Har Efraim - Beit Elohim (specifically Garev according to Sanhedrin 103b; Shoftim 17:3-5)1
  • *Dan - cultic center (not entirely specified; Shoftim 18:30-31)1
  • Beit Lechem - Beit Hashem (Shoftim 19:18; debatable)2
  • Beit El - a large altar, the location of the ark (Shoftim 20:26-27, 21:2-4 according to p'shat)

Chazal state in various places (e.g. Yevamot 90b) that Eliyahu's altar on Har Ha'Carmel was an extraordinary case of a Hora'at Sha'ah (a temporary ruling), which is what allowed him to build and use an altar outside of the Mikdash at Yerushalayim. However, it's difficult to imagine that all of these cases would have likewise been Hora'at Sha'ah. Constantly using the "excuse" of Hora'at Sha'ah effectively makes the leniency null. Moreover, some of these cases appear to have been intended for long-term use (e.g. Shechem, Ofrah, Beit Lechem, Beit El, Dan [albeit framed in the story as an illegitimate site]),3 while Hora'at Sha'ah is intended for short-term use.

In short, what exactly is the case to be made that there indeed was a prohibition of bamot during the Shiloh period? And if indeed there was a prohibition, how are all of these other cases to be understood?

1 While idolatrous with the usage of some kind of idol, the context of the story clearly indicates that Michah, his mother, his son (the first priest) the Levite (the second priest) and the Danites believed that this cultic construction was a legitimate form of worshiping Hashem.

2 The various commentators on Sefaria argue that the Levite was trying to reach Beit Hashem at Shiloh. This is also argued by Da'at Mikra. However, this is somewhat problematic in p'shat terms. The verse states: "עֹבְרִים אֲנַחְנוּ מִבֵּית־לֶחֶם יְהוּדָה עַד־יַרְכְּתֵי הַר־אֶפְרַיִם מִשָּׁם אָנֹכִי וָאֵלֵךְ עַד־בֵּית לֶחֶם יְהוּדָה וְאֶת־בֵּית ה' אֲנִי הֹלֵךְ" - Roughly translated: "We are going from Beit Lechem of Yehudah towards the base of Har Efraim where I am from (=I am from Har Efraim), and I went until Beit Lechem Yehudah, and to the House of Hashem I am going." The Levite seems to be skirting around the real reason he came to Beit Lechem, which was to seek out his concubine, who had fled there (see Da'at Mikra on Shoftim 19:18). If his final destination was Shiloh, he did not succeed in explaining away why he went to Beit Lechem in the first place. It would seem, therefore, that there was a Beit Hashem in Beit Lechem, which was his made-up excuse for going there. An altar of sorts at Beit Lechem is also indicated by verses from the post-Shiloh era, which nonetheless may hint at an established, well-known worship site (Shmuel 1:16:1-5; 1:20:6, 29).

3 There are also multiple cases of what appear to have been pre-Monarchic Israelite cultic sites identified in various archeological sites. The most famous is the altar at Har Eval, but there are also the so-called "footprint" sites (also known as "Gilgalim") around Har Menashe (see e.g. here). Whether these were officially legitimate or only supposed to be such from a colloquial perspective (as in the case of Michah's idol and house of worship) is unknown.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

The assumption that a temple contains an altar, and that an altar is built for sacrifices, is a reasonable assumption in general, but isn't true in the particular case of the time that the bamot were prohibited, as we find explicitly regarding the altar built on the Jordan, which was from the outset not intended for offering sacrifices, since doing so would have been prohibited (Yehoshua 22:10). The same may be the case regarding any other altar, and so the question only arises when we find explicitly that sacrifices were offered.

So we can safely ignore every cultic center where no sacrifice is explicitly said to be offered. This is sufficient to explain Shechem (this location is based on an explicit commandment of the Torah, Devarim 27:5), Beit Lechem (according to your conjecture), Har Efraim and Dan as well (although, as you noted, these two weren't considered legitimate, though the reason for that is apparently the idol).

Next, as you note, the prohibition can be overridden by a prophet, and this seems to be the case in Bochim, Ofrah, and Tzorah, since each sacrifice was said to be commanded by God or an angel or prophet. As above, the altar may well be permanent, without any transgression, as long as the sacrifice on it is a one-time event directed by a prophet.

Beit El is a difficult one to explain, since there was an actual offering of sacrifices, while no prophet is mentioned as approving it, nor is there any criticism of it. (1) Radak understands Beit El generically like the generic name בית ה' (possibly called that due to the geographical proximity of Shilo to Beit El), and accordingly the ark would have remained there the whole time.

(2) Alternatively, if the ark was taken out for war, even temporarily, the bamot would be permitted, even during the period of Shilo. This is stated explicitly in Yerushalmi Megilla 1:12, quoted by the Meshech Chochma ד"ה לא תעשון, which I looked at from a suggestion by M G). In fact, the Meshech Chochma also uses this insight to answer the case of Bochim as well as Beit El. The reason why bamot were forbidden in the Shilo period is because the ark wasn't moving from place to place, but when it was being transported the prohibition of bamot ceased.

(3) To address the other side, if bamot weren't permitted during that time period (contra the Meshech Chochma; the Yerushalmi is inconclusive, and may be either a statement or an unanswered question), it seems to me that it would be unthinkable to have the sacrificial service go on as normal in Shilo with the most important vessel missing, facing the ordinary altar rather than the ark. The one place to which sacrifice would have been restricted would presumably be to the location of the ark, in or out of Shilo.

title: What did Joseph do wrong in reporting his dreams?
content:
# What did Joseph do wrong in reporting his dreams? ## Frage

The Torah says:

[Joseph dreamed that]..."The sun, the moon, and eleven stars were bowing down to me.” And when he told it to his father and brothers, his father rebuked him. “What,” he said to him, “is this dream you have dreamed? Are we to come, I and your mother and your brothers, and bow low to you to the ground?” ... His father kept the matter in mind. [Genesis 37:9-11]

Why did his father rebuke him? All Joseph did was report his dream. He didn't interpret it. One can surmise he was even, himself, asking what it meant. In the culture of the day, it was common to report dreams and wonder about what they meant. In fact, there were lots of people whose job was to interpret dreams for a fee (24 in Jerusalem alone, says Berakhot 55b). So what did Joseph do wrong?

The Talmud says that the interpretation of a dream is what will actually happen. From this the Zohar asserts that when Joseph's brothers said to him “Will you reign over us? Will you govern us?” [Gen. 37:6-8], they, not Joseph, interpreted the dream negatively, "and with these words they sealed their own doom". [Zohar, Vayeshev 7:92]

title: Is a mezuzah necessary on an interior door frame from which the door has been removed?
content:
# Is a mezuzah necessary on an interior door frame from which the door has been removed? ## Frage

In my apartment, there is an interior door frame with no door; apparently someone removed the door in the past. It is still obviously a (former) door frame, though, as the typical hardware remains in place.

If a Jewish person lived in a home with a similar empty door frame, would it be necessary to have a mezuzah there?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

Maimonides (Laws of Mezuza 6:1) writes that a doorframe is only obligated in a mezuza if it has a door attached. Many other authorities though questioned if there was any good basis for that requirement (see Beit Yosef YD 286), and thus the common practice is to attach a mezuza but, out of doubt since it may not really be necessary, omit the blessing said upon affixing it (cf. Shakh ibid :15).

title: What is the meaning of Isaiah 64:5?
content:
# What is the meaning of Isaiah 64:5? ## Frage

Isaiah 64:5

And we all have become like one unclean, and like a discarded garment are all our righteous deeds, and we all have withered like a leaf, and our iniquities carry us away like the wind.

Christians try to use this to say one’s deeds can’t make one righteous.

What’s the Jewish interpretation?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

The commentaries there are clear.

According to Rashi we are "unclean" as the righteous have departed from among us and "like a discarded garment" we have rejected and thus "withered" with our sins carrying us away like the wind.

The Ibn Ezra adds similarly and notes that this "withering" is likened to us fading away.

The Malbim notes that the people are lamenting that Hashem no longer reveals Himself through miraculous means nor descends to perform wonders. And as a result of this distance, even those who try to do good are not met by G-d’s favour. The nation has become tamei (spiritually impure), both by distancing itself from holiness and by influencing one another negatively, with no one left to purify or guide them back to repentance.

Their good deeds have become superficial, like clothing worn only for show rather than garments that become part of one’s essence. They are like withered leaves rather than fruit-bearing trees, lacking substantial righteousness and true inner faith. Therefore, their sins easily sweep them away, just as a strong wind carries off a dry leaf, since they no longer have deep spiritual roots to hold them firm.

The Metzudos Dovid says like Rashi that the righteous have departed and thus there is no one there to spiritually defend them. All the good deeds are like worn-out garments as because they do not come from a wholehearted place but rather only from the pursuit of self-glorification. Thus their strength is faded like a withered leaf and their sins serve to accuse and bring punishment on them.

Radak writes that as an exiled nation we resemble something impure and disgusting. He notes that the word "עדים" - "garment" can be understood in a few ways - 1) As per the Targum, a blemished, stained garment. 2) From the Aramaic meaning of childbirth, referring to clothing dirtied with blood. 3) Or simply an old, worn-out rag. Either way, all interpretations point to a piece of clothing that is filthy and rejected. Like the Metzudos Dovid and Malbim he explains that their good deeds aren't pleasing to G-d because they are done for show, self-glorification, or out of jealousy of others, not from any sincere intent. Like a dried up leaf, the Jewish people have withered spiritually and just like the wind blows away a fallen leaf, their sins scatter them to all corners of the earth and cause their exile.

title: Does a ger have to take a Jewish name upon converting?

# Does a ger have to take a Jewish name upon converting? ## Frage

Is there a halachic requirement to take a Jewish name for a convert, or, if it’s a minhag - how binding is it? Is one allowed to keep his non-Jewish name if it doesnt mean anything bad and have it written in the ksubah etc…
Or is it permitted to take a Jewish name but to keep using the secular one in day-to-day life?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

A convert does not have to legally change their name. It is customary for a convert to take a Jewish/Hebrew name at the time of conversion, but it is not necessarily an absolute halachic requirement in all views.

See this website which writes:

  • That it is customary to change the name at the time of conversion

  • and cites שו״ת מהרשד״ם יו״ד סי’ קצ״ט that it is not an obligation, and if someone wants they may keep the non-Jewish name,

  • the site adds that שו״ת מהר״ם שיק יו״ד סי’ קס״ט says one should be careful about changing the name, so there is still a strong preference to adopt a Jewish name.

title: Pareto, Zipf and Torah
content:
# Pareto, Zipf and Torah ## Frage

The Pareto principle states that 80% of consequences come from 20% of causes, and this principle applies to almost every system you can imagine, from 80% of the wealth being owned by 20% of the population, to 20% of your carpet receiving 80% of the wear. It seems like a "rule of nature".

Very much related is Zipf's Law, which said simply is when you have a large set, e.g. the words in the Torah, the number of occurrences of each item in the set will be inversely proportional to its rank-by-occurence. The 5th ranked and fifth most popular word in Torah will make up one-fifth as many of the total words in the Torah as the 1st ranked and most popular word (if the Torah holds by Zipf's Law, which we can't find out because the question was closed. Many languages do hold by it and so many other similar systems, from city sizes to whale phonemes).

The main point is that these two issues are quite mysterious, due to how prevalent they are.

Given that these are quite important to the way the world works, and Torah is the world's blueprint, I was wondering if there is any Torah source that in any way discusses these issues in any way whatsoever.

E.g. Does the Gini coefficient (0.8:0.2) appear in Torah? Do mefarshim explain it? Its root? Do any halachos or gemaras utilise the 80/20 rule or the facts of Zipf's Law in any way? Do any Midrashim or Kabbalistic sources bring it up and try to explain them mathematically or metaphysically?

# Are there any seforim that explain hidden meaning of the trup? ## Frage

Are there any seforim that discuss trop (Torah cantillation)?

I don't need one that teaches leining; I’m looking for something that would be appreciated by someone who already knows how to lein.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

In Samech Vav maamar ש״פ ויצא - ויצא יעקב, the Rebbe lists these nistar sources as references to more information about the trop/te'amim in the following footnotes:

  1. ראה סה״מ תרנ״ח ע׳ קלז. תר״ס ע׳ טו. תרס״ג ע׳ כז. סד״ה ויאמר גו׳ לך לך (לעיל ע׳ פט). ועוד.

  2. תקו״ז תס״ט (קה, רע״א). פרדס שער כח (שער הטעמים) פ״ה. עץ חיים שער ה (שער טנת״א) פ״א (מ״ב). פ״ה. אוה״ת וארא (כרך ז) ע׳ ב׳תקנח ואילך. ב׳תקעב ואילך. סה״מ תרל״ט ח״ב ע׳ קכ. תר״ם ח״א ע׳ פא. ועוד.

  3. ראה עץ חיים שער מב (שער דרושי אבי״ע) פ״א. תו״א ויחי מח, ב. שמות נג, א. לקו״ת ויקרא ד, א. במדבר יא, ריש ע״ג. חוקת נז, ד. אוה״ת וארא שם (ע׳ ב׳תקעד ואילך). סה״מ תרל״ט שם (ע׳ קכא). תר״ם שם (ס״ע פה ואילך).

  1. See Sefer HaMaamarim 5658, p. 137; 5660, p. 15; 5663, p. 27; maamar beginning "Vayomer... Lech Lecha" (above, p. 89); and elsewhere.

  2. Tikkunei Zohar, Tikkun 69 (105a); Pardes, Sha'ar 28 (Sha'ar HaTe'amim), ch. 5; Etz Chaim, Sha'ar 5 (Sha'ar TaNTa"A), ch. 1 (M"B), ch. 5; Ohr HaTorah, Va'era (vol. 7), p. 2558 ff.; p. 2572 ff.; Sefer HaMaamarim 5639, vol. 2, p. 120; 5640, vol. 1, p. 81; and more.

  3. See Etz Chaim, Sha'ar 42 (Sha'ar Derushei ABYA), ch. 1; Torah Or, Vayechi 48b; Shemot 53a; Likutei Torah, Vayikra 4a; Likkutei Torah, Bamidbar; Chukat 57d; Ohr HaTorah, Va'era there (p. 2574 ff.); Sefer HaMaamarim 5639 there (p. 121); 5640 there (from the end of p. 85 and onward).

I haven't learned them but they might be good places to discover "hidden meanings" of the te'amim as per the title of the question. You can also learn the maamar itself as it explores the deep idea of te'amim in general.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

The sefer "Meforash Vesom Sechel" is a recommended one. Written by Rabbi Lopiansky.

The blurb writes:

Sefer Meforash Ve'Som Sechel on Chumash is a unique sefer that includes two sections:

Meforash – A collection from Targum Onkles, showing how this ancient Targum is in fact an important commentary on Chumash. Includes an introduction about the importance of Tagum Onkles.

Ve'Som Sechel – A unique collection from the Rishonim and Achronim where they show how the trup on the psukim actually teach us how to explain and reveal deeper meaning in the pasukim. Includes an important introduction to the topic of trup.

title: Does God really provide for all our desires?
content:
# Does God really provide for all our desires? ## Frage

Psalm 145:

פּוֹתֵ֥חַ אֶת־יָדֶ֑ךָ וּמַשְׂבִּ֖יעַ לְכׇל־חַ֣י רָצֽוֹן׃
You open your hand and satiate the desire of every creature.

How can we say that God provides everyone’s desires? People starve to death in the world, and everyone wants what they don’t have.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

It appears that the OP's question is a result of a confusion resulted from using the english word desire for different Hebrew words. Indeed the verse Tehilim 145:16 is translated in the Hebrew-English Artscroll Siddur as:

פּוֹתֵ֥חַ אֶת־יָדֶ֑ךָ וּמַשְׂבִּ֖יעַ לְכׇל־חַ֣י רָצֽוֹן׃

You open your hand and satisfy every living thing [with its] desire.

Similarly, the words of midrash Kohelet Rabba 1:13:1:

אָמַר רַבִּי יוּדָן בְּשֵׁם רַבִּי אַיְּבוּ אֵין אָדָם יוֹצֵא מִן הָעוֹלָם וַחֲצִי תַּאֲוָתוֹ בְּיָדוֹ, אֶלָּא אִן אִית לֵיהּ מְאָה בָּעֵי לְמֶעֱבַד יַתְהוֹן תַּרְתֵּין מָאוָון, וְאִן אִית לֵיהּ תַּרְתֵּי מָאוָון בָּעֵי לְמֶעֱבַד יַתְהוֹן אַרְבָּעָה מְאָה.

Rabbi Yudan said in the name of Rabbi Aivu: A person does not leave the world having achieved even half of his desire; rather, if he has one hundred he wishes to turn them into two hundred. If he has two hundred, he wishes to turn them into four hundred.

In the first case, if we speak about people, the Hebrew word רָצֽוֹן refers to purely spiritual or intellectual desire devoid of any physicality, such as desire of good deeds, as one can see based on Malbim below. Indeed G-d provides many avenues for one to realize his/her ratzon. If we speak about all creatures, we could use Rashi:

and satisfy every living thing [with] its desire With a sufficiency to sustain him, He satisfies his goodness, his will, and his blessing. desire Heb. רצון, apayement / apeiement in Old French, propitiation, making it appeased.

In the second case, the word תַּאֲוָה refers to purely materialistic desire. The material world is lacking indeed.

Malbim in the Sefer Yair Or usually printed in the back of Sefer haCarmel provides further distinctions between different words in Hebrew, which express desire:

חֶמְדָה - expresses desire for things that one saw with his eyes and it appeared good to him/her. Example, Nachum 2:11 - "“Plunder silver! Plunder gold!” There is no limit to the treasure; It is a hoard of all precious (i.e. desirable) objects."

תַּאֲוָה (אַוֶה) - expresses the desire also for things that one has never seen, rather due to strengthening of the power of imagination in shaping the form or making comparison, one begins to desire it, even if it is bad.

Both חֶמְדָה and תַּאֲוָה are similar, as they do not originate from intellectual contemplation.

אָבָה - it is not distinguishable from either חֶמְדָה or תַּאֲוָה, rather it refers to inclination of acceptance or support of one's heart to the words of a friend, who requests for a favor. Example: Shemos 10:27: "But Hashem stiffened Pharaoh’s heart and he would not agree (or desire - אָבָ֖ה) to let them go."

חֵפֶץ - it indicates a type of desire of one's nature or character (nefesh) for something or to play with it. Example: Isaiah 42:22: "GOD desires (חָפֵ֖ץ) for the sake of (his servant's) righteousness, that he may magnify and glorify the Torah."

רָצֽוֹן indicates only type of desire that stems from intellectual contemplation, even if one's soul (nefesh) has no desire (חֵפֶץ) for it. One expresses such a desire after intellectually thinking about the goodness of the matter or its wholesomeness, or because it is upright or proper.

### ✅ Antwort 2 (Score: 3)

Two relevant quotes:

Who is rich? He who rejoices in his lot. [Avot 4:1]

Nobody departs from the world with half of his desire gratified. If he has a hundred he wants to turn them into two hundred, and if he has two hundred he wants to turn them into four hundred. [Ecclesiastes Rabbah 1:32]

title: Source of Chochma and Binah in A'K
content:
# Source of Chochma and Binah in A'K ## Frage

In Semach Tesamach, pg. 220, the Rebbe Rashab writes:

דשרש החכמה הוא בבחי׳ מלכות דא״ק ושרש הבינה ביסוד דא״ק (ועמ״ש בהוספות תו״א בהביאור דואני נתתי)

...for the root of Chochmah is in Malchut d'Adam Kadmon, whereas the root of Binah is in Yesod d'Adam Kadmon (and see what is written in the hosafot to Torah Or, in the biur of "Va'ani natati")

I am intrigued by this, so I went and looked at that source. Unfortunately, it doesn't quite explicitly deal with what the Rebbe Rashab discusses there*, despite it mentioning these bechinot of Malchut and Yesod d'Adam Kadmon.

I did more research, and have found a little bit more information:

  1. Chabadpedia has some sources on Malchut D'AK and explains how it is related to shevirat hakelim, Knesset Yisrael, and Shechina
  2. Chapadpedia also has some sources on Yesod D'AK, and connects it to the source of Mitzvot, the root of Tikkun, the source of Yosef HaTzaddik.
  3. I found this note to Likkutei Torah Re'eh which introduced a "tzarich iyun" on the roots of Chochma and Binah, at least in Atzilut
  4. I have found 2 ma'amarim by the Mittler Rebbe that seem highly relevant: אדם כי יקריב מכם from Pelach HaRimon and ויאמר גו' לך לך from Torat Chaim*. In the former, he references " בסידור בדרוש וביאור דיוצר הרים: שהחכמה מל' דא"ק והבינה מבחי' יסוד דא"ק: דרושים לחתונה קלו, א. מאמרי אדה"א דרושי חתונה ח"א ע' רכט."

On top of this, I've learned (in פדה בשלום נפשי י״ט כסלו עזר״ת) how Malchut D'AK is related to the Zayin Melachim Kadmain (Tohu), and Yesod D'AK being related to Hadar. This also appears in the Chabadpedia links above.

title: What is the correct pronunciation of the name רפאל?
content:
# What is the correct pronunciation of the name רפאל? ## Frage

What is the proper pronunciation of the name רפאל? Is it pronounced RAfael or REfael? Does it differ between Ashkenazim and Sephardim?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

In Tanakh (specifically דברי הימים א כ״ו:ז׳), the word is vocalized רְפָאֵל. The diacritic under the first letter is called “Shva”, and is pronounced “e” syllable-initially; ergo, “Refael” is more correct.

This has been the case for around a thousand years: Word-initial Shva was pronounced “e” by the Tiberian Masoretes, and the corresponding vowel in the Palestinian Masoretic tradition was pronounced “e” universally.

The English word “Rafael” is borrowed from the Latin transliteration (raphael) of the Greek transliteration (Ῥᾱφᾱήλ) of the proto-Masoretic pronunciation (/raˌfāˈ’ēl/) of the name, where the first vowel was actually “a”.

As far as I know, the pronunciation of this first vowel as “a” completely disappeared in the Masoretic era, and therefore has no remnant in any modern reading tradition.¹

¹The Yemenite tradition does pronounce this vowel as “a”. Either this was preserved from the Babylonian Masoretic tradition—in which case my last paragraph is wrong—or this is a Yemenite innovation differing from the original Masoretic “e”.

title: Is Numbers 15:39 (3rd paragraph of the Shema) a circular grammatical construct?
content:
# Is Numbers 15:39 (3rd paragraph of the Shema) a circular grammatical construct? ## Frage

I'm not sure how to parse this line grammatically:

וְלֹֽא־תָת֜וּרוּ אַחֲרֵ֤י לְבַבְכֶם֙ וְאַחֲרֵ֣י עֵֽינֵיכֶ֔ם אֲשֶׁר־אַתֶּ֥ם זֹנִ֖ים אַחֲרֵיהֶֽם׃

What does אֲשֶׁר־אַתֶּם mean here? I would understand it as "that unto them", but what would the 'them' be referring to?

My best guess at a direct translation of the passage is as follows:

'They shall not follow after their hearts or after their eyes, which unto themselves lust after themselves.'

Is this correct?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

This is based on a fundamental grammatical error.

The words תָתוּרוּ, לְבַבְכֶם, עֵינֵיכֶם, and אַתֶּם are not third-person, but second-person. The only word here in the third person is אַחֲרֵיהֶם.

The excerpt should rather be translated as follows:

You shall not follow after your hearts or after your eyes, which you lust after them.

(That last clause is a bit awkward in English. A less literalistic translation might have it as "after which you lust".)

For context, the third-person inflections of these words are יָתוּרוּ, לְבָבָם, עֵינֵיהֶם, and הֶם.

# What is the treaty with death and the limit of the grave in Isaiah 28? ## Frage

What does Isaiah 28 mean in regards to.

Isaiah 28:15 reads

Because ye have said, We have made a covenant with death, and with hell are we at agreement; when the overflowing scourge shall pass through, it shall not come unto us: for we have made lies our refuge, and under falsehood have we hid ourselves: 28:16 Therefore thus saith the Lord GOD, Behold, I lay in Zion for a foundation a stone, a tried stone, a precious corner stone, a sure foundation: he that believeth shall not make haste.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

I'm not sure exactly what understanding you have of the text, so I will steer you to one rabbi's explanation of this section of Isaiah:

Steinsaltz Introductions to Tanakh, Isaiah, Section Preface 20 (Isaiah 28:1–29) Rebuke of a Hedonistic Society

The upper classes of Ephraim and Judah would regularly drink and make merry. They would eat to excess, dress flamboyantly, engage in witty repartee, and joke about their situation, continuing to live their lives with no regard for Torah and morality. They would derisively deflect the warnings of the prophet and concern for the future. The prophecies in this section are directed at this reality. The first prophecy refers to the arrogance of the drunkards in the decadent city of Samaria, and the second addresses the inhabitants of Jerusalem, who will also be stricken. The prophecies describe a corrupt society whose members ignore those seeking to offer them the opportunity to escape their situation and show them how to correct their ways. In their indifference, they dismiss the Torah and any attempts to rebuke them, as though the words were spoken in a foreign language or intended for children. The prophet’s harsh tone betrays his contempt for these people. Interspersed with these harsh comments are consolations to the remnant who will survive, describing the honorable, just, and stable society that will be established in the future. These prophecies contain many recurring metaphors and images, some which are obscure.

title: What precisely does the Syrian conversion takana prohibit?
content:
# What precisely does the Syrian conversion takana prohibit? ## Frage

The famous Syrian takana on conversions reads as follows, with the prohibition[s] bolded for emphasis:

A RABBINICAL PROCLAMATION

Adar 5695 (February 1935)

We have observed the conditions prevailing in the general Jewish community, where some youth have left the haven of their faith and have assimilated with non-Jews; in certain cases they have made efforts to marry gentiles, sometimes without any effort to convert them, and other times an effort is made for conversion to our faith, an action which is absolutely invalid and worthless in the eyes of the law of our Torah. We have therefore bestirred ourselves to build and establish an iron wall to protect our identity and religious integrity and to bolster the strong foundations of our faith and religious purity which we have maintained for many centuries going back to our country of origin, Syria.

We, the undersigned rabbis, constituting the Religious Court, together with the Executive Committee of the Magen David Congregation and the outstanding laymen of the community, do hereby decree, with the authority of our Holy Torah, that no male or female member of our community has the right to intermarry with non-Jews; this law covers conversions, which we consider to be fictitious and valueless. We further decree that no future rabbinic court of the community should have the right or authority to convert male or female non-Jews who seek to marry into our community. We have followed the example of the community in Argentina, which maintains a rabbinic ban on any of the marital arrangements enumerated above, an edict which has received the wholehearted and unqualified endorsement of the Chief Rabbinate in Israel. This responsa is discussed in detail in Devar Sha’ul, Yoreh Deah, Part II to Part VI. In the event that any member of our community should ignore our ruling and marry, their issue will have to suffer the consequences. Announcements to this effect will be made advising the community not to allow any marriage with children of such converts. We are confident that the Jewish People are a holy people and they will adhere to the decision of their rabbis and will not conceive of doing otherwise.

Questions

  • What is being prohibited?
    • According to this ban, can a Syrian marry a child of a convert? Or a grandchild?
    • Does this ban prohibit marriage only? Does it prohibit performing conversions?
    • Does the ban prohibit married gerim from joining a Syrian congregation?
  • What precisely is called "fictitious and valueless"? Conversion for the sake of marriage or conversion in general?

Sources please

title: What is the alternative division system marked in Koren Tanakh (e.g., at Gen. 2:4, 3:22, 5:1)?
content:
# What is the alternative division system marked in Koren Tanakh (e.g., at Gen. 2:4, 3:22, 5:1)? ## Frage

While reading the Koren Tanakh, I noticed an additional system of divisions besides the familiar medieval chapter numbers. For example, at Genesis 2:4 the text is marked with a ב, and similar markings appear at 3:22, 5:1, and 6:9, as if new “chapters” begin there. These do not align with the standard chapter system.

What exactly are these divisions?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

As pointed out above, these are called seder divisions. They are at least as old as the great Masoretic manuscripts that most modern Hebrew Bibles are based on. For instance, here is the seder marker (a kind of stylized big samekh) in the margin of the Leningrad Codex at Genesis 2:4:

I have colored it red using Google (Gemini) "Nano Banana." (Hence the white diamond shape in the corner.) But in the original, it is just in black ink.

Here is a link to an image of the full page (page 2A) of the Leningrad Codex from which this small, edited image came.

The seder divisions often (but far from always!) line up with aliyah divisions. E.g. at Gen 3:22 in my Koren Tanakh, I can see that the start of the third seder of Genesis (seder ג) lines up with the start of the fourth aliyah of the first parashah of Genesis, i.e. aliyah רביעי of parashat בראשית of sefer בראשית:

An online edition showing seder and aliyah divisions is the Hebrew Wikisource edition of MAM (מקרא על פי המסורה).

title: Rashi's note on the almah "incapable of giving birth" in Isaiah 7:14
content:
# Rashi's note on the almah "incapable of giving birth" in Isaiah 7:14 ## Frage

In his Commentary on the Tanakh, Rashi states among other things the following words on the almah of Isaiah 7:14:

"Immanuel [lit. God is with us. That is] to say that our Rock shall be with us, and this is the sign, for she is a young girl, and she never prophesied, yet in this instance, Divine inspiration shall rest upon her. This is what is stated below (8:3): “And I was intimate with the prophetess, etc.,” and we do not find a prophet's wife called a prophetess unless she prophesied. Some interpret this as being said about Hezekiah, but it is impossible, because, when you count his years, you find that Hezekiah was born nine years before his father's reign.
And some interpret that this is the sign, that she was a young girl and incapable of giving birth".

Do we know which commentaries Rashi is referring to when he says that "some interpret that this is the sign, that she was a young girl and incapable of giving birth"?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Partial answer:

A few scholars suggest that this was supposedly a reference to the Christian interpretation of the word "almah" as virgin. According to them, Rashi probably originally included an argument against this interpretation, but it was lost over time, perhaps due to censorship or scribal error, or, perhaps, as Yehuda Rosenthal suggested, the whole sentence was a Christian addition to the commentary.1

However, I'm a bit skeptical of these proposals. I checked a number of 13th century manuscripts of Rashi's commentary on Isaiah (the oldest ones I've found so far) and they're all pretty much the same in this passage - no hint of any censorship or scribal error.2 Of course, that doesn't preclude either of the two options; they may have indeed occurred prior to the 13th century. But that would of course make them very old changes, taking place apparently not long after Rashi died (ca. 1105 CE, the early 12th century), which considerably lowers the odds of this actually being some kind of censorship or scribal error.3

I have not yet found any who suggest that Rashi based himself on earlier commentators, but I'll update if I find any such statement.

1 See for example: Nehemias Kronberg, Raschi als Exeget: mit besonderer Rücksicht auf das Sprachwissenschaftliche in seinem Bibel-Commentar, Breslau 1882, p. 11, n. 1; Rabbi Yitzchak Maarsen, Parshan-Data, Amsterdam 5690/1930, p. 23, n. 24 (in Hebrew); Rabbi Yaakov Shor, "The Source of Wisdom" (מקור חכמה), in: Rabbi Yehuda Leib Maimon (ed.), Sefer Rashi (ספר רש"י), Jerusalem 5716/1956, p. 457, n. 6 (can be found on Otzar Hachochmah); Yehuda Rosenthal, "Rashi's Anti-Christian Polemic on Tanach" (הפולמוס האנטי־נוצרי של רש"י על התנ"ך), in: Yehuda Rosenthal, Studies and Sources (מחקרים ומקורות), Jerusalem 5727/1967, p. 111 (can be found on Otzar Hachochmah).

2 Ms. British Library, Harley 150, p. 135r (1257); Ms. St. Petersburg, Russia Ms. EVR I 11, p. 70r (from before 1271); Ms. St. Petersburg, Russia Ms. EVR I C 6, p. 99v (1285); Ms. Wrocław, Poland Ms. 104 II, p. 70v (1288); Ms. Palatina Library, Parma, Italy, Cod. Parm. 3260, p. 110r (13th century); Ms. Berlin, Germany, Or. fol. 122, p. 78v (13th century).

3 It remains possible, however, that all of those 13th century manuscripts that I checked followed one particular (perhaps faulty) textual tradition of Rashi's commentary, while other manuscripts, perhaps even ones which are dated later than the 13th century, preserve a more accurate textual tradition.

title: Why did Yackov want to get the level of tohu from esav if he already has Lavan (Ohr ein sof)?
content:
# Why did Yackov want to get the level of tohu from esav if he already has Lavan (Ohr ein sof)? ## Frage

B"H

In Torah Ohr, Vayishlach, it says how Yackov, being from the world of Tikun, and especially how he already refined all of the levels of Tikun in atzilus (ox, donkey, sheep, servant and maidservant) it was now ready to reach the source of Esav in the world of tohu beyond atzilus, because he thought Esav has already refined himself to get to that level.

The question is that the Alter Rebbe says that when yackov said "with Lavan I have dwelled", as a proof that he has refined all of the levels of atzilus (ox, donkey etc.) he said that "because yackov reached the level of "the supermnal whiteness" (loven haelyon), which, relative to that "light is like dark", and he was able to refine tikkin from that

In the end of the last maamar from Vateitzei it's said that loven haelyon refers to the "ohr ein sof", light without end, which is why Lavan in this world changed the conditions of the sheep from big spotted to little spotted to rings etc, because relative to Ohr Ein Sof, all of those lower levels (which in general throughout chassidus and kabbalah refer to:

Brudim (big spots)= tikkin (big vessels) Nikudin (little spots)= tohu (small vessels)

Akudim (rings around their ankles)= beginning of Adam kadmon beyond even tohu, where all vessels are "bound" (akud) add one

Were able to be changed from one to the other

So it's implied that even within the sheep of Lavan themselves yackov already reached tohu, and even more than that, it seems like he already reached ohr ein sof that's beyond tohu (Lavan), so why did he need to "get" to tohu through esav now?

Alter Rebbe 's words describing "loven haelyon" at the end of Vateitzei:

וזהו וישכם לבן בבקר פי' לבן דקדושה הוא בחי' לובן העליון דהיינו בחי' אור עצמותו ומהותו של אא"ס ב"ה כמשל מראה וגוון לבן שאינו דומה לכל המראות וגוונים שהגוונים שלהם נתהוו ע"י צבע משא"כ מראה וגוון לבן הוא עצמות הדבר ומהותו שלא נשתנה ולא נתהוה ע"י צבע. וכן הוא עד"מ אור א"ס ב"ה בעצמו ובכבודו דלית בי' בחינת גוונין כלל דלית מחשבה תפיסא בי' ואני ה' לא שניתי כתיב. ולכן כתיב והחליף את משכורתי עשרת מנים אם כה יאמר נקדים כו'. שכל הבחי' עקודים ונקודים נתהוו ונשתלשלו ממנו ובירידתם והשתלשלם הם נקראים בשם עקודים ונקודים משא"כ בראשיתם ומקורם הם בטלים ונכללים ואינם עולים בשם כלל ולכן יכול הוא להפך מבחי' עקודים לבחי' נקודים ומנקודים לעקודים ואין זה שינוי לפניו ית' כב"י מאחר שהם בטלים במציאות ואינם עולים בשם כלל לא שייך שם שינוי כלל (וזלע"ז לבן דקליפה מחליף משכורתו ממש ברמאות).

Says pretty explicitly that the "Loven haelyon" corresponds to the ohr ein sof

So if Yackov already has the ohr ein sof (with Lavan I have dwelled), which is even able to switch tohu with tikkun on its own, why does he need tohu from esav?

title: Who was the first person to make kiddush shabbat on wine?
content:
# Who was the first person to make kiddush shabbat on wine? ## Frage

Who was the first person to make kiddush shabbat on wine?

Does it go back to Adam haRishon (ע"ה), Noach(ע"ש), the Avot, was it instituted by Moshe(ע"ש), David(ע"ש), Suleiman(ע"ש) or is it a completely post-exilic practice (it was never done before post-exilic institution)?

cf: Why was proscription of wine accepted by the Beta Ezrael but not other communities?

Was a 'Shabbat Dinner' ritual practiced in the desert?

Has anyone ever published a guide to Melaveh Malkah (מלווה מלכּה)?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

It seams the earliest reference in text would be the Mishna Berachos 8:1 followed by Tosefta Berachos 5:3 with a somewhat more explicit reference appearing slightly later in Gemara Pesachim 106a

The Rambam in Hilchos Shabbos 29:6 explains that the usage of wine was instituted by our sages.

Tosfos on Pesachim 106a uses two sources from Tenach to connect wine and kiddush but there still doesn't seem to be any record of kiddush made on wine earlier than the above sources. However there isn't much available text between Tenach and Mishna anyway.

To answer your question, the first person was most likely the member of Chazal that instituted it roughly in the late Second Temple period or early post-Temple era around 1st-2nd century CE.

title: Inner reasons for certain halachot of pru urvu
content:
# Inner reasons for certain halachot of pru urvu ## Frage

We learn in SA EH 1:5-6 that if one has a boy and a girl, and they pass away, are infertile, or do not have grandchildren, one has to continue performing pru urvu until they have at least one grandson and granddaughter from 2 different children (Tosfot seems to hold that 2 grandsons is also fine - see Chelkat Mechockek 7; Beit Shmuel 9).

I want to ask, what is actually going on, in the penimiut? Firstly, has one actually done the mitzva when they had the children, and now they have to "do it again", or did they actually not do it?

Then, if the inner reasons are to complete the Divine Name, empty the well of souls, and complete the Divine Image (see Derech Mitzvotecha, Mitzvat Pru Urvu), then this all is seemingly completed by the first son and daughter, regardless of whether they produce more children or not? So whence, the inner reason for these halachot of grandchildren? Or do the inner reasons not align with the outer reasons in this case?

I am looking for a source-based answer.

title: Does the word "rock" appear in Genesis/Bereshit chapter 49?
content:
# Does the word "rock" appear in Genesis/Bereshit chapter 49? ## Frage

I was watching this episode of "Tenak Talk (TeNaCh)", and I found a claim that I'm unable to verify:

Does the word for “rock" appear in Genesis/Bereshit chapter 49?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

Yes, Bereshit 49:24

ותשב באיתן קשתו ויפזו זרעי ידיו מידי אביר יעקב משם רעה אבן ישראל

Yet his bow stayed taut, And his arms were made firm By the hands of the Mighty One of Jacob— There, the Shepherd, the Rock of Israel [JPS translation]

Technically, אבן is more a "stone", but it's fine to translate it as rock in this context. צור is more considered the right translation of "rock", and this does not appear in Sefer Bereshit at all as far as I can tell.

title: Luz, the city and hazel
content:
# Luz, the city and hazel ## Frage

We read last week in Parshat Vayeitzei that the name of the place Yaakov Avinu named Beth-El was previously called Luz (see Ber.28:19).

Later in the same Parsha (Ber.30:37), we are told that one of the rods that Yaakov Avinu placed in the troughs, was made out of Luz, translated as hazel.

What connection is there between hazel and the city name Luz?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

The midrash (Ber. Rabba 69:8) teaches that the city was named after the almond tree at its entrance:

אָמַר רַבִּי סִימוֹן לוּז הָיָה עוֹמֵד עַל פִּתְחָהּ שֶׁל עִיר. רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בְּשֵׁם רַבִּי פִּנְחָס בַּר חָמָא אָמַר לוּז הָיָה עוֹמֵד עַל פִּתְחָהּ שֶׁל מְעָרָה וְהָיָה לוּז חָלוּל וְהָיוּ נִכְנָסִין דֶּרֶךְ הַלּוּז לִמְּעָרָה, דֶּרֶךְ הַמְּעָרָה לָעִיר

Rabbi Simon said: Luz [an almond tree] was located at the entrance of a city. Rabbi Elazar said in the name of Rabbi Pinḥas bar Ḥama: Luz was located at the entrance of a cave. There was a hollow almond tree and they would enter the cave through the almond tree and through the cave to the city.

title: Is there a talmudic source for reciting part of Hallel on the last six days of Pesach?
content:
# Is there a talmudic source for reciting part of Hallel on the last six days of Pesach? ## Frage

Rambam in Hilchot Chanukah 3:7 writes:

בְּרָאשֵׁי חֳדָשִׁים קְרִיאַת הַהַלֵּל מִנְהָג וְאֵינוֹ מִצְוָה ... לְפִיכָךְ קוֹרְאִין בְּדִלּוּג ... וְכֵן בִּשְׁאָר יְמֵי הַפֶּסַח קוֹרְאִין בְּדִלּוּג כְּרָאשֵׁי חֳדָשִׁים:‏

On Rosh Chodesh reciting Hallel is a custom but not a commandment ... therefore it is read with skipping [some passages] ... and similarly on the remaing [six] days of Pesach one reads with skipping, like on Rosh Chodesh.

Now, the custom to read a partial Hallel on Rosh Chodesh is recorded in Taanit 28b. But what about the custom on the latter days of Pesach? Is that recorded anywhere in the Talmud? If not, where do we first see the appearance of such a custom?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

The Frankel/Goldschmidt maḥzor for Pesaḥ says that the only reference to "half-Hallel" (הלל בדילוג) in the Talmud is for Rosh Ḥodesh, and the earliest source for Pesaḥ is from the Geonim. See p14:

‮... ולפי המקורות התנאיים ומנהג א״י העתיק אין הלל בשאר ימי הפסח כלל כי אינם חלוקים מיו״ט ראשון בקרבנותיהם. הלל בדילוג (המכונה לעתים ״חצי הלל״) לא היה ידוע בא״י בתקופת המשנה והתלמוד ונודע לראשונה בתלמוד הבבלי על ראש־חודש (תע׳ כח ע״ב), ולעניין חוה״מ פסח נזכר כעניין ידוע ומובן בימי הגאונים. (הערה: ה״ג, סוף הלכות לולב, עמ׳ ‬357‮; אמנם בסרע״ג לא נזכר הלל של חוה״מ פסח ואולי אין זה אלא טעות.)

... and according to the Tannaitic sources and the old practice of Erets Yisra'el, Hallel is not said at all in the remaining days of Pesaḥ because they are not distinguished from the first Yom Tov day as to their offerings. Hallel with skipping (sometimes called "half Hallel") is unknown in Erets Yisra'el in the time of the Mishna and the Talmud and is first mentioned in the Talmud Bavli regarding Rosh Ḥodesh (Taanit 28b), and as for Ḥol HaMo'ed Pesaḥ, it is attested as a known and self-evident practice in the times of the Geonim. (footnote: Halachot Gedolot, end of the laws of lulav, page 357; however, in Seder Rav 'Amram Gaon, Hallel on Ḥol HaMo'ed Pesaḥ is not mentioned, but perhaps this is simply a mistake.)

The passage in Halachot Gedolot starts here. There, only Ḥol HaMo'ed is mentioned, but other Geonic sources mention all remaining days of Pesaḥ. For example, in Siddur Rav Sa'adia Gaon, the Gaon writes: ואמא פי אלסתה איאם אלאכ֗ר ליס יקאל אלא בעצ֗ה (translation: but on the other six days, we only say part of it [Hallel]).

title: The Fall of Edom
content:
# The Fall of Edom ## Frage

Shalom,

וַיֹּ֨אמֶר ה' לָ֗הּ שְׁנֵ֤י (גיים) [גוֹיִם֙] בְּבִטְנֵ֔ךְ וּשְׁנֵ֣י לְאֻמִּ֔ים מִמֵּעַ֖יִךְ יִפָּרֵ֑דוּ וּלְאֹם֙ מִלְאֹ֣ם יֶֽאֱמָ֔ץ וְרַ֖ב יַעֲבֹ֥ד צָעִֽיר׃

Acording to Bereshit 25:23 and Rashi to this verse, whenever Edom is strong, it means that Israel is weak. And likewise, if Israel is strong, then Edom must be weak. רש''י mentions b.Megilla 6a, where the same idea is depicted with the cities of Jerusalem and the city of Caesarea, which represents Edom / Rome.

Why then we (Jews) are not commanded to boycott the Western world? Or should we at least be happy if the Western world collapses? Why haven't I never heard something similar? Is this just a process that happens at the End of times?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

There can be several answers to this question, which really speak about the same idea:

  1. According to Rav Yom-Tov Schwarz's book "Eyes to See", chapter 24, The Primary Mission of a Jew today is for the World to Extol G-d and the Jews on Account of His Conduct. The essay is included in Part VII Relations with Non-Jews on pages 262 - 282. It deals with the mitzvah of kiddush Hashem:

... the central focus of our anticipation for future redemption is concentrated effort on the kiddush HaShem before the eyes of all the nations which will occur at that time - thus reversing the longstanding era of chilul HaShem before the eyes of the gentiles that began with the Temple's destruction and will continue as long as we remain in exile amongst the nations, as Rashi explains in Tractate Yoma 86a. Commenting on the verse in Ezekiel 36:20 "They came among the nations where they came, and they desecrated My holy Name, when it was said of them, 'These are the people of HaShem, yet they departed his land,'" Rashi writes:

For it is stated, "They desecrated My holy Name," In what way was it desecrated? When the gentiles in whose midst they were exiled said of them, "Look! These are the people of HaShem, but He could not save them from being exiled." Thus, G-d's name is desecrated, and G-d's honor is diminished.

We do not have any specific commandments for our relationship with Edom (except for marriage with Edomite converts). Due to mixture of nations that occured under Assyrian and Babylonian kings, we do not know which nation is made out of Edomites. Therefore, the main focus, according to R. Schwarz (and many sources that he brings - Rambam, Maharal, Sforno, Smag, etc.) must be in mitzva observance and kiddush HaShem.

  1. The understanding of what it means to be strong in Judaism comes from Pirkei Avos 4:1:

Who is mighty? He who subdues his [evil] inclination, as it is said: “He that is slow to anger is better than the mighty (i.e. strong); and he that rules his spirit than he that takes a city” (Proverbs 16:32).

As we see in the present world, some nations and political leaders seek to create disorder in the world often because these people carry inside many conflicts which they cannot address.

  1. The Western Society with its freedoms is much closer to the Jewish ideal as compared to every other society that we lived under in any part of the world. Many changes that occurred in recent years in Europe and America actually destroy western society and turn in into a totalitarian socialist one. Free business carries much G-dliness as it builds relations among people. Boycotting it will be destroying the efforts of many people who built it turning the wheel of history backwards.

title: Why are they called Terafim?
content:
# Why are they called Terafim? ## Frage

Two levels to this question:

  1. What does Terafim mean?
  2. Meta: why does the Torah use the word Terafim when describing them? If that's their real name, then perhaps it would have been better for the Torah to not use the real name, as it might come across as honouring idolatry, plus saying the names of idols is generally not allowed. If it's not their real name, then why did the Torah choose to call them that?
## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

R. Aryeh Kaplan offers a good summary of rabbinic literature on this word in his commentary The Living Torah (Gen. 31:19)

Teraphim in Hebrew, sexual images, from the word turpha (Tanchuma 12; Zohar 164a). These were images having human form (cf. 1 Samuel 19:13). In some cases, they were made out of the shrunken head of a first-born infant (Targum Yonathan; Tanchuma 12). They were not necessarily idols (Rambam, from 1 Samuel 19:13; Judges 17:5, 18:5), but here they were used for idolatrous purposes (Genesis 31:30; Zohar). In general, they were used as a meditative device to obtain messages (Hosea 3:4, Zechariah 10:2; Ibn Ezra; Radak; Ralbag; Rashi on Ezekiel 21:26). The teraphim would be tapped, inducing a relaxed, meditative state (Zohar 164a, from 2 Samuel 24:16; cf. Yad, Avodath Kokhavim 11:6; Chinukh 510).

As for why the Torah specifically uses this name, the Ramban gives one suggestion that goes along with his interpretation:

שֶׁהֵם כֵּלִים לְקַבֵּל הַשָּׁעוֹת, וְיִקְסְמוּ בָּהֶם לָדַעַת עֲתִידוֹת, וְהַמִּלָּה נִגְזֶרֶת מִלְּשׁוֹן "רְפֵה יָדַיִם" (שם ב יז ב) "נִרְפִּים אַתֶּם נִרְפִּים" (שמות ה יז), יִקְרְאוּ אוֹתָם "תְּרָפִים" לִרְמֹז בִּשְׁמָם כִּי דִּבּוּרָם כְּמוֹ נְבוּאָה רָפָה, תָּבֹא בָּרֹב וּתְכַזֵּב לְעִתִּים רְחוֹקוֹת, כְּמוֹ שֶׁאָמְרוּ (זכריה י ב) "כִּי הַתְּרָפִים דִּבְּרוּ אָוֶן". וְהִנֵּה יַעֲשׂוּ אוֹתָם קְטַנֵּי אֲמָנָה לָהֶם לֵאלֹהִים, לֹא יִשְׁאֲלוּ בַּשֵּׁם הַנִּכְבָּד וְלֹא יִתְפַּלְּלוּ אֵלָיו, רַק כָּל מַעֲשֵׂיהֶם בַּקְּסָמִים אֲשֶׁר יַגִּידוּ לָהֶם הַתְּרָפִים.

These are vessels to receive a knowledge of the hours, and they divine with them in order to gain knowledge of future events. The word teraphim is derived from the expressions: ‘rephai’ (weak) handed; ‘nirpim’ (idle) ye are, idle. They are called “teraphim” in order to hint by their name that their words are like a weak prophecy, usually occurring as a prophecy for many days hence and turning out to be false, just as the prophets have said, For the teraphim have spoken vanity. People of little faith set them up for themselves as gods. They do not seek to know by the glorious name of the Eternal, nor do they offer their prayers to Him. Rather, their deeds are guided by divination revealed to them by the teraphim.

Similarly, the Shadal argues that this was not their real name, and that they were known as elohim:

אמנם התרפים נ"ל שהם כלים שהיו קוסמים בהם לדעת העתידות והנסתרות, והיו נקראים אלהים, לא שהיו עובדים אותם ממש, אלא שהיו חושבים שהאל או האלילים משפיעים על הכלים ההם ומודיעים הנסתרות על ידם (קרוב לענין העגל שעשו ישראל, והעגלים שעשה ירבעם, ופסל מיכה)

Although the above-mentioned teraphim were instruments used to perform magic to know the future and the hidden, and were called elohim, they did not actually worship them. They thought that God or the idols influenced those instruments and revealed the hidden through them (similar to the case of the calf that Israel made, and the calves that Jeroboam made, and Micah's statue)

The idea of whether these are idols or not (and what it means to call them by name) is a separate question. In the above explanation, these objects are referred to as terafim in the Torah (rather than elohim) to hint that they are for people of little faith.

title: Did Eliyahu (ע"ה) get semikah from Achiya haShiloni (ע"ה)?
content:
# Did Eliyahu (ע"ה) get semikah from Achiya haShiloni (ע"ה)? ## Frage

In Bava Batra 121b it says Eliyahu ha-Navi (ע"ה) saw Achiya ha-Shiloni (ע"ה). Here it says Eliyahu (ע"ה) ‘received’ the Oral Torah from Achiya (ע"ה): Mishneh Torah, Transmission of the Oral Law Trans. by Eliyahu Touger, Moznaim Publishing

Elsewhere it says that Eliyahu (ע"ה) was a musmak of Achiyah haShiloni (ע"ה).

What source is there for this, did Eliyahu (ע"ה) receive Semikah from Achiya (ע"ה) and how did Eliyahu (ע"ה) and Achiya haShiloni (ע"ה) meet?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

There are a couple of sources from before the Rambam's time which may have served as a basis for his statement regarding the connection between Eliyahu and Achiyah as student and teacher:

Yerushalmi Eruvin 5:1:

"רִבִּי חֶלְבּוֹ רִבִּי חוּנָה בְשֵׁם רַב. כְּתִיב וַיֹּאמֶר אַלִיָּהוּ הַתִּשְׁבִּי וגו׳. וַהֲלֹא אַלִיָּהוּ טִירוֹנִין לנְּבִיאִים הָיָה. אֶלָּא מְלַמֵּד שֶׁכָּל עֲמִידוֹת שֶׁעָמַד לִפְנִי אֲחִיָּה הַשִּׁילוֹנִי רַבּוֹ כִּילּוּ עָמַד לִפְנֵי הַשְּׁכִינָה."

"Rebbi Ḥelbo, Rebbi Ḥuna in the name of Rav: It is written, Eliahu from Tisbe said, etc. Was not Eliahu a novice1 among the prophets? But it teaches that all the time he was standing before his teacher Aḥiyya from Shilo it was as if he stood before the Divine Presence.

Sefer Taggai/Taggin (date unknown, but known at least from the Geonic [pre-Rishonic] period], see Hebrew Wiki entry):

"הדין ספרא תאגי דאסיק עלי הכהן מן י"ב אבנים שהקים יהושע בגלגל, ומסרו לשמואל, ושמואל מסרו לפלטי בן ליש, ופלטי בן ליש מסרו לאחיתופל, ואחיתופל מסרו לאחיה השילוני, ואחיה השילוני מסרו לאליהו..."

"This is the book of Taggai which Eli the Priest brought from the twelve stones that Yehoshua set up in the Gilgal, and he passed it down to Shmuel, and Shmuel passed it down to Palti ben Laish, and Palti ben Laish passed it down to Achitofel, and Achitfoel passed it down to Achiyah Ha'Shiloni, and Achiyah Ha'Shiloni passed it to Eliyahu..."

As for how they met, if Eliyahu is Pinchas and Achiyah was part of the Exodus generation, then they either met circa the Exodus or Wilderness-Wandering period, or when both of them lived at Shiloh, perhaps when Pinchas served as High Priest, or they could have met at a later time.2 If Eliyahu isn't Pinchas, then it still isn't a stretch to imagine that if he wanted to study Torah and/or prophecy, he would have gone to the main prophet at the time, the aged Achiyah.

1 For an unclear reason the Sefaria translation prefers understanding "טירונין" as "ruler", supposedly from "טרן" (tyrant). However, it seems that Jastrow is correct that it comes from Greek τίρων (tiron, novice), and that is the way the word is used in Modern Hebrew today (usually in reference to an IDF soldier undergoing basic training).

2 And it may also be noted that seemingly a bit randomly, Chronicles 1:9:20 mentions Pinchas serving as "Nagid" ("prince", some kind of priestly position, perhaps High Priest) in the Tent of Meeting while listing priests and Levites during the time of David. Though the term is "לפנים", as though this took place in times passed, the mention may indicate Pinchas's longevity.

title: Why didn’t Yerovam ben Nevat simply make a new temple without cow worship?
content:
# Why didn’t Yerovam ben Nevat simply make a new temple without cow worship? ## Frage

Melochim 1 12:26-33 discusses how Yerovam made two alternate temples focused on a golden calf in each because he was concerned he would lose his monarchy if people would continue going to the Beis Hamikdash in Yerushalyim. Among the things he introduced there and the worst of them was the two golden calves to be semi worshipped. Why did he need to do that for? As Chazal say part of his argument was that since Achiyah HaShiloni had prophesized his kingdom it is a legitimate one and therefore in the need of its own Beis Hamikdash. He even went so far as to use an anti-idol worship argument and said that we should no longer go Yerushlayim because it has been too defiled by the idol worship structures and actions of Shlomo Hamelech’s wives. Etc.

Why couldn’t he simply make those arguments and build a variant temple without introducing idol worship of his own in it? Particularly when he himself did not seem to actually believe in it and secretly sent his wife to consult with Achiyah HaShiloni over the idolatrous prophets in his kingdom.

I’m aware that he argued that if Ahron made a golden calf when Moshe was gone, it must be that there is an intrinsic value to golden cows and that is why he specifically used golden cows as the form of worship but that sounds like a justification as opposed to an intrinsic compelling reason to do something. A new variant temple should have been a much easier sell without bringing the Egel in it.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

It seems to me that your working assumption is that once the Temple was constructed, all members of Am Yisrael instantly forgot the old ways of using the bamot and other previous forms of worship. In such a reality, it would probably indeed make more sense to push for a separate monolithic temple in the Kingdom of Israel to rival the one in Yerushalayim.

However, the continuous usage of bamot throughout the entire First Temple period, even during the reigns of righteous kings (e.g., Melachim 1:15:14; 22:43-44; 2:12:3-4; 14:3-4; 15:3-4; 34-35; etc), seems to indicate the opposite: Many members of the nation clung to the old ways. Perhaps there were select periods where worship was mostly, if not entirely, focused at the Temple, but there was always a historical memory of an apparent legitimacy of bamot-usage. There are indications of the continuous survival of other such heterodoxies among Yisrael. For example, the bronze snake made by Moshe became a cultic object called Nechushtan (eventually destroyed by Chizkiyahu in Melachim 2:18:4); many generations prior Gideon made some kind of golden ephod which apparently became the subject of a certain form of cultic worship (Shoftim 8:24-27); and the Name of Hashem is invoked multiple times throughout the story of the statue of Micha and the Danites, which indicates that in the minds of those involved, they were worshipping Hashem in a legitimate fashion. Recall that even when the Tabernacle was already set up in Shiloh, the 2.5 Transjordanian tribes set up their own altar (Yehoshua 22:10-34). Officially it was only supposed to be a model altar, for no practical use. But how long do you suppose a perfect copy of an altar remains unused?1

Not to defend these customs, but there is some logic in bamot, which represent a decentralized model of worship - in a society where making sacrifices is a daily business and part of everyone's life, it's much easier bringing a sacrifice to a local cultic center rather than hauling it all the way up to the capital. Yerushalayim is fine for most of the Kingdom of Judah (although is still quite some walking distance from the edges of the kingdom), but most of the other tribes were located much farther away. Synagogues, in a sense, are a continuation of the local bamot. Or rather, they are based on the same basic human necessity: a place of worship that's just a stone's throw away (more or less).

In my opinion, Yerovam took advantage of these lingering heterodox beliefs and customs by institutionalizing (or perhaps, reinstitutionalizing) the bamot and other old concepts: bringing back the golden calf in a decentralized form (two instead of one), reinstituting the non-kohen priests of the bamot (see Rabbi Yehuda's opinion in Mishna Zevachim 14:10 that there was no necessity of kohanim in the bamot; this view may also be indicated by Targum Yonatan on Shmuel 1:1:1 which states that Elkanah divided up kodashim [despite being a Levite]), reactivating two important ancient Israelite centers of worship: Dan and Beit El, and so forth. For a discussion of the background of various elements of the new/old cult set up by Yerovam, see this answer.

In other words, Yerovam's argument was likely that he was reinstituting a form of worship of Hashem (and not pagan idols!) that had long been considered perfectly legitimate by many members of Am Yisrael (though whether Yerovam himself entirely believed in the legitimacy of what he was doing may be debatable. But it's also possible that he convinced himself over time).1 And to further legitimize this new/old religion, as well as further distancing the tribes who were part of his kingdom from the Kingdom of Judah, he denounced the Temple in Yerushalayim, thereby sealing the deal.

1 The gemara in Bavli Sanhedrin 102a notes that Yerovam received a stamp of approval from Achiyah Ha'Shiloni. The commentators are largely in agreement that Achiyah intended to approve all halachically legitimate rulings by Yerovam, however the approval convinced many people from Yisrael to believe that Achiyah also approved the religion Yerovam set up, and as such it turned out to be a mistake on Achiyah's part to sign such a writ of approval. Perhaps Yerovam also became convinced that this was Achiyah's actual intention.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

All of the kohanim worked at and had an interest in Solomon's temple. if he were to make his temple the same thing, he would only get the second rate fringe cohanim and if its worship was similar, people could compare them. also. if the people remained accustomed to the same kind of worship, it would be easier for them to revert back. he made them worship idols to burn the bridge

as for why he put the 2 sites at dan and bet el, it couldn't have been for convenience because those places are at the edge of the kingdom.

title: Does the Rebbe Rashab in Samach Tesamach agree with the Mittler Rebbe in Sha’ar HaYichud about Sefirot before the Tzimtzum?
content:
# Does the Rebbe Rashab in Samach Tesamach agree with the Mittler Rebbe in Sha’ar HaYichud about Sefirot before the Tzimtzum? ## Frage

To keep it short and to the point, the Rebbe Rashab brings the Pardes and Etz Chaim about the Sefirot pre-Tzimtzum. He does this in a number of places, but in particular, he mentions it at length in Samach Tesamach.

The Rebbe Rashab cites Pardes Shaar HaTzachtzachot / Arichei HaKinuyim ("עשר ספירות הגנוזות במאצילן") and Etz Chaim Shaar 41 ch. 7 ("אין שם דמות וספירה ח״ו") when speaking of what exists before the tzimtzum. In Sameach Tesamach he writes (sampling two lines):

  • "בעצמות אינו שייך ספירות ח״ו, אבל באור א״ס שייך ספירות אלא שלא יש מספר לספירות שם..."
  • "באמת באור א״ס אינו שייך שיש שם מציאות ספירות... אלא ... קריאת שמות בלבד..."

This exact point is discussed by the Mittler Rebbe in Sha'ar HaYichud, chapters 7-10, although he doesn't quote his sources.

  • "בעצמות לא יתכן לומר עדיין ענין עשר ספירות כלל..."
  • "ובאמת גם בבחינת העצמות דאור אין סוף... כלול בעצמו י׳ ספירות... עד ולאו מכל אלין מדות כלל."

Note that the Mittler Rebbe uses the Pardes' "version", and the Rebbe Rashab quotes both. Throughout the hemshech, the Rebbe Rashab generally uses them like this:

"such and such idea is proven/disproven by the Pardes version, and all the more so the Arizal version".

It sounds like he isn't decided which he takes as correct, if either.

My question:

  • How do Chabad mefarshim understand the relationship between these two discussions?

  • Is there an explicit reconciliation in the later Rebbeim, or other Chabad writings, about how the Rebbe Rashab's treatment in Samach Tesamach fits with the Mittler Rebbe's approach in Sha'ar HaYichud? Do they actually differ?

  • Does the Rebbe Rashab disagree (unthinkable!), or is he just framing the same idea differently, or am I the one making the mistake?

I am especially interested in answers based on Chabad sources (Rebbeim, he'arot, biurim etc.), but I'm also open to non-Chabad analysis on the issue.

EDIT: When I was learning this ma'amar from Samech Vav on Shabbat, I saw that the Rebbe Rashab used the Pardes version of the concept consistently. I almost came and gave that as an answer, until I saw last night this ma'amar from Torah Ohr by the Alter Rebbe, who seems to use the Arizal version consistently (once again, I would find it unthinkable to discover that the Rebbe Rashab and Mittler Rebbe would disagree with the Alter Rebbe, especially over something as fundamental as this).

I am just getting more and more interested by this idea by the day so hence I offer a bounty for any good information anyone can provide.

title: Question about "Day or Two Days" in Parashat Mishpatim
content:
# Question about "Day or Two Days" in Parashat Mishpatim ## Frage

In Parashat Mishpatim, there is a law about when someone hits their servant. The pasuk discusses a case where if the servant remains alive for a certain period, the owner is not punished because the servant is his property. The Torah uses the phrase "day or two days" (יוֹם אוֹ יוֹמַיִם).

My question is: How long exactly does the Torah require here? Is it one full day? Or must it be two complete days? The Hebrew says "yom o yomayim" - literally "day or two days" - but this seems unclear to me.

I was thinking about this, and something interesting occurred to me when I looked at the Hebrew letters. When you spell out the word "day" (יוֹם) fully - meaning יוד, ואו, מם - it comes to a certain numerical value. And when I calculated the value of the next words "or two days" (אוֹ יוֹמַיִם), I noticed they have the same gematria! Could this be hinting at something about how to understand the time requirement?

Does anyone know what the classical commentaries say about this? Is there a halachic ruling on the exact time period meant here?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The classic commentary of Rashi, in the name of the Mechilta, says that the Torah must mean one full day of 24 hours:

CONTINUE A DAY OR TWO, HE SHALL NOT BE AVENGED — If the master is free of the death penally in case of the servant remaining alive one day, is it not logical that he is free if he lives two days (what need is there for Scripture to add יומים)? But it adds it to show that the term יום is to be defined by יומים — “a day that is like two days”. And what kind of day is thereby meant? A period of twenty-four hours (a day which comprises a part of two separate days) (cf. Mekhilta).

Your gematria is a nice touch in showing how while the Torah names two times, it is a way of saying one time that shares aspects of both.

title: Why wasn’t Lavan’s blessing explicit?
content:
# Why wasn’t Lavan’s blessing explicit? ## Frage

In the seventh reading of Parshat Vayetze (32:1) the Torah tells us that Lavan blessed his [grand]sons and daughters.

However concerning Rivkah in Chayeh Sarah (24:60) the Torah explicitly states “Our sister may you grow into thousands of myriads! And may your descendants take possession of the cities of their foes!”

Why the disparity between the two?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

After some time thinking about this question I came up with an idea.

Yitzchak’s second blessing to Ya’akov in Toldot (28:4) he said, “May He grant you the blessing of Avraham, to you and to your offspring with you, etc.” was the same blessing that he received from Hashem by virtue of being Avraham’s offspring, which Avraham initially received directly from Hashem.

Likewise, it could be said that the blessing that was given to Rivkah his sister was the same blessing that he gave to his grandsons being the descendants of Rivkah and by extension to his daughters, and therefore did not need to be repeated again.

title: Why was Yaakov "angry" with needing to prepare for his meeting with Esav?
content:
# Why was Yaakov "angry" with needing to prepare for his meeting with Esav? ## Frage

Rashi on Bereishis (32:22) says:

על פניו. כְּמוֹ לְפָנָיו, וְכֵן חָמָס וָשֹׁד יִשָּׁמַע בָּהּ עַל פָּנַי תָּמִיד (ירמיהו ו'), וְכֵן הַמַּכְעִסִים אֹתִי עַל פָּנַי (ישעיהו ס"ה); וּמִ"אַ עַל פָּנָיו, אַף הוּא שָׁרוּי בְּכַעַס, שֶׁהָיָה צָרִיךְ לְכָל זֶה (בראשית רבה) - The Midrash connects the word פניו in על פניו with פנים anger — Yaakov was also angry that it should be necessary for him to do all this.

However, the Midrash Bereishis Rabbah (76:8) itself that Rashi quotes says:

וַתַּעֲבֹר הַמִּנְחָה עַל פָּנָיו וגו', אַף הוּא בְּעָקָא - “The gift went before him [al panav]” – Yaakov, too, was distressed.

The Meforshim on the Midrash explain בְּעָקָא as either referring to anger or distress, and Rashi himself on the Midrash says יעקב שרוי לו בצער שהיה צריך לכל אלה - Yaakov was distressed at needing to do all this preparation for Esav.

Why was Yaakov "angry" at the cards Hashem dealt him? (We don't find him held accountable for being upset.)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Rashi (Bereishis 32:22) brings the Midrash that the word פניו is connected to כעס, and Yaakov felt a kind of “anger” over the preparations for Esav. But this clearly cannot mean ordinary ka’as, which Chazal strongly condemn (Nedarim 22b).

Most Meforshim understand the Midrash as describing a painful frustration, not sinful anger.

  1. The “anger” was over being forced into a lower mode of avodah

Yaakov is the ish tam yoshev ohalim — his avodah is ruchniyus and temimus. The whole structure of messengers, gifts, strategy, and splitting the camp was a yeridah in madreigah for him.

The Midrash (Bereishis Rabbah 76:8) itself says בצער היה — “he was distressed.” Rashi on the Midrash explains: שרוי לו בצער שעשה כל זאת — he was upset that he had to be involved in such things at all.

Not upset at Hashem — upset at the situation.

  1. The frustration was directed at Esav and the matzav, not at Hashem

We find similar language by Moshe Rabbeinu (Bamidbar 31:14) where he “got angry,” yet no one suggests it was an aveirah. It was a reaction to ra and danger.

Yaakov’s emotional reaction was toward the reality of Esav, and what that evil forced him to do.

  1. Hishtadlus itself was painful for someone on Yaakov’s level

Ideally, Yaakov’s zechuyos would suffice. Having to rely on “doron, tefillah, milchamah” showed that the world wasn’t holding on the spiritual level he wished for. That gap between the ideal and the actual is the ka’as the Midrash describes.

  1. This did not contradict Yaakov’s bitachon

Despite this inner tza’ar, Yaakov follows the correct derech completely — preparing, praying, and planning as Chazal outline.

There is no rebellion, no complaint, and no flaw in emunah. It is simply the hurt of a tzaddik forced into the world of Esav.

⸻

Summary:

Yaakov’s “anger” was not anger in the ordinary sense. It was the spiritual distress of a tzaddik who must descend from his natural madreigah and handle worldly tactics because of Esav’s presence in the world. The Midrash’s language reflects pain, not impropriety.
