title: Leah getting annoyed at Rachel about the dudaim
content:
# Leah getting annoyed at Rachel about the dudaim ## Frage

You'll have to excuse me for not bringing my source, except I saw it in the Schottenstein Chumash, and my mind seems to remember it was Ibn Ezra or Ramban (perhaps someone can help if they know, otherwise I can try and look it up later) but...

It is said that Leah got annoyed at Rachel for asking for some dudaim, because she felt that Rachel was being self-centred (or something similar). It went further on to say that Leah was annoyed that Rachel married Yaakov after Leah, creating this competitiveness in the marriage in the first place (see Sforno).

I was really taken aback by this. How can we reconcile this with the fact that Leah was a Tzaddeket? Leah knew that Rachel was supposed to marry Yaakov and he was tricked into marrying Leah instead. Despite that Rachel didn't want Leah to be embarrassed so gave her the passwords etc during the marriage.

So, it seems to me that in the name of normal human decency, Leah should a) feel bad that due to their father's evil, Leah married Yaakov when that wasn't his or Rachels initial intention - basic bashfulness is a trait specific to the Jewish people... and b) feel grateful that despite that, Rachel looked after her and made it as pleasant as possible.

Instead, she now is annoyed at Rachel, has no empathy that Rachel has no children, and in fact thinks that Rachel did something wrong by proceeding as planned and marrying her love, Yaakov? It just doesn't add up to me.

I get that Leah was also a victim in all this, and had her own problems of feeling unloved, but should that really be a cause for this indecent reaction?

Help me understand.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

I had a thought about this once, I don't recall seeing it anywhere, so I'll share it.

Leah had eyes ruined from all her crying, as Rashi brings from Chazzal, she thought she was going to marry Esav since they were both the older sibling.

ועיני לאה רכות. שהיתה סבורה לעלות בגורלו של עשו ובוכה שהיו הכל אומרים שני בנים לרבקה ושתי בנות ללבן, הגדולה לגדול והקטנה לקטן:

My chidush is that although we always mention these prayers in praise of her, we never seem to focus on the outcome of her crying. I would suggest that Leah heard about Yaakov sneaking and getting the bechora and blessings, and she assumed, perhaps rightfully, that Yaakov was now her true match. And maybe she even believed it was her prayers that helped him succeed. Based on this theory we could understand how Leah believed it was Rachel who not only 'practically took her husband' but was even more incensed after the duda'im incident.

I would offer a slight proof that they knew about the bechora and bracha incidents, as Yaakov was not shy about his sneakiness when he told Rachel he was a brother of her father in this regard.

ומדרשו אם לרמאות הוא בא גם אני אחיו ברמאות

Of course this could get complicated to the point of impossible if we assume like Chazzal that Rachel and Leah were very young and there were multiple decades between Yaakov's escape and arrival by Lavan.

title: Why does Yackov ask "Havayah should be for me Elokim", only after returning to his father's house?
content:
# Why does Yackov ask "Havayah should be for me Elokim", only after returning to his father's house? ## Frage

B"H

In Vateitzei Yackov made a vow and saying "if Hashem will be with me and give my bread and clothes... I will return in shalom to the house of my father, and Havayah will be for me Elokim".

What exactly does he mean by "Havayah will be for me Elokim", only after returning to his father's house? We know that Havayah and Elokim are one all the time, "know this day and take it to heart, that Havayah is Elokim in the heaven above and in the earth below, there's nothing else"?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Sefer Hamaamarim 5679 by the Rebbe Rashab has a maamar called וידבר אלקים את כל הדברים כו׳, which is one of the clearest maamarim I've ever learned on the concept of what it means that "Havaya is Elokim" in that pasuk:

In this maamar, the Names Havayah and Elokim are explained as two modes of Divine revelation: Havayah is the simple, undivided light - Hashem Himself as transcendent and beyond grasp, while Elokim is the power of limitation and the vessels that measure and channel that light to enable a relationship with Him. Elokim can conceal, but its deeper role is to make Havayah receivable, like digging out a channel that draws water from a powerful river into a measured flow, so the water becomes available and useful.

On this basis the maamar reads Yaakov’s phrase “and Havayah will be for me Elokim” to mean: the very light of Havayah should shine for him through Elokim in a way that does not hide but reveals, so that Hashem Himself is internalised within Yaakov's soul (kelim) and generates love and awe. This is the unification “Havayah–Elokim are one,” where the letters of Elokim serve as channels that reveal the light of Havayah inwardly.

[The maamar further contrasts the Avots’ attainment with the later giving of the Torah: the Avot drew the “lower Havayah” (Z'A of Atzilut) by effecting the unification of Havayah and Elokim, ensuring that Elokim would not obscure the light of Havayah. Yaakov’s wording “Havayah will be for me Elokim” is presented as part of that level. At Matan Torah, however, the “higher Havayah” was revealed: Hashem's true Essence, via Torah as inner light and mitzvot as encompassing light, surpassing what the Patriarchs accessed. Thus, within the maamar’s frame, Yaakov’s phrase expresses Havayah revealed through Elokim on the plane available before Sinai, not the higher revelation that came with the Torah]

Now, why the timing - "when I return in peace", etc? The answer to this is found in מאמר ושבתי בשלום תשל"ח. Yaakov is about to embark on a descent into "the real world" where Havaya is very obscured. It is a world of concealment, and by passing through it in peace - by passing the test - he will elevate himself so that he can indeed see that Havaya is Elokim.

(I used AI to help copy edit parts of this answer, but I have learned both maamarim and confirm what is written is correct)

# Source for parable about wandering attention during tefillah ## Frage

There's a well-known parable about concentrating during tefillah.

A person walks through the fair and looking at the various items on sale. Suddenly, he is struck in the chest. He sees nobody in the area. Then, he is struck again. He realizes he's in the middle of שמונה עשרה and has just finished סלח לנו.

What is the source for this parable, and what further details are there?

I recall an alternative variant, in which R' Levi Yitzchak of Berdichev said שלום עליכם to someone who'd just finished שמנה עשרה, because he'd managed to travel around the world in his head during that time.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

The source seems to be R' Sholom Schwadron

Rabbi Ephraim Schwartz says he heard this parable from R' Schwadron himself. In this blog post he writes:

There’s a great story I remember from when I was in Yeshiva, back in the day a million years ago, when the great Maggid, Reb Shalom Shwadron came to speak to us. He told a story of how he was once walking through a beautiful field on a gorgeous day. The sun was shining so bright, he was surrounded by flowers and trees, he could even hear the birds chirping all around him. Suddenly though he felt someone punch him in the chest. He looked around and no one was there. Hmmm that seemed strange. A second later though he felt another punch in his chest. This time though he heard himself mumble words.

Selach lanu Hashem ki chatanu, mechal lanu ki fasashanu- forgive me Hashem for we have sinned. And then it hit him- excuse the pun- he had hit himself for he was in middle of Shemona Esrei and just started daydreaming.

The parable is also quoted in an article on Page 8 of this publication with the following source:

(Heard from Rabbi Moshe Grossman in the name of Rabbi Sholom Schwadron zt”l)

This Hebrew website also attributes the parable to R' Schwadron providing a specific location of this market/fair.

הגאון רבי שלום שבדרון זצ"ל נהג לספר על יהודי שהסתובב בשוק מחנה יהודה כאשר הוא תר אחר דוכן בו מוכרים תפוזים... ופתאום - בום! הוא קיבל אגרוף בחזה... ולאחר כמה שניות שוב פעם אגרוף בחזה! כאשר הוא ניסה לבדוק מי מכה אותו באמצע השוק הוא תפס כי הוא עצמו מכה על חזהו - בברכת סלח לנו

title: Buying luxury food for shabbos if one gets government assistance
content:
# Buying luxury food for shabbos if one gets government assistance ## Frage

B"H

The Torah says "make your shabbos like a weekday, and don't become dependent on the community".

It says in Shulchan Aruch that even though one is supposed to have nice food for shabbos, if they receive tzedakah, they shouldn't get extra fancy food.

Is a healthy able bodied Jew who gets government assistance if any kind (including but not limited to food stamps) allowed to buy luxury items for shabbos meals, or should they only buy regular weekday food while they are receiving it?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

I don't know whether and when government assistance is considered tzedakah, especially in a case where it's apparently undeserved. But the premise of your question is flawed:

It says in Shulchan Aruch that even though one is supposed to have nice food for shabbos, if they receive tzedakah, they shouldn't get extra fancy food.

Not quite. It says that if you have a choice between shabbos luxuries and self-sufficiency, it's better to downgrade your shabbos and avoid accepting charity. Once you're already receiving tzedakah, there's no reason to refrain from honoring shabbos. In fact, you can even collect extra for shabbos in such a case (Aruch HaShulchan Y"D 253:1).

title: Why does Yaakov make a vow?
content:
# Why does Yaakov make a vow? ## Frage

Why is Yaakov Avinu the one to make a vow? Why didn't Avraham Avinu make a vow when he needed G-d's help at any of the difficult points in his life? Where did Yaakov learn this approach from; how did he know it was appropriate to make stipulations with G-d?

Bereishit 28:20–22: וַיִּדַּר יַעֲקֹב נֶדֶר לֵאמֹר: אִם יִהְיֶה אֱלֹהִים עִמָּדִי, וּשְׁמָרַנִי בַּדֶּרֶךְ הַזֶּה אֲשֶׁר אָנֹכִי הֹלֵךְ, וְנָתַן לִי לֶחֶם לֶאֱכֹל וּבֶגֶד לִלְבֹּשׁ, וְשַׁבְתִּי בְשָׁלוֹם אֶל בֵּית אָבִי, וְהָיָה ה' לִי לֵאלֹהִים. וְהָאֶבֶן הַזֹּאת אֲשֶׁר שַׂמְתִּי מַצֵּבָה, יִהְיֶה בֵּית אֱלֹהִים; וְכֹל אֲשֶׁר תִּתֶּן לִי עַשֵּׂר אֲעַשְּׂרֶנּוּ לָךְ.

  1. And Jacob made a vow, saying: “If God will be with me, and will guard me on this way that I am going,
  2. and will give me bread to eat and clothing to wear, and I return in peace to my father’s house, then the LORD shall be my God.
  3. And this stone, which I have set up as a pillar, shall become a house of God; and of all that You give me, I will surely tithe it to You.”
## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

The answer is discussed by Nechama Leibowitz in "New Studies in Bereshit (Genesis)", parashas Vayetze, essay 2. The English translation is by Aryeh Newman. I will follow her essay in answering the OP's question with some rearrangement for brevity. In fact, most of the ideas can be found in the supercommentaries on Rashi on Bereshis 28:20, and I will indicate the relevant supercommentaries.

One should be aware, this is a classic question which has been addressed by midrashim. The way the OP phrased it, essentially can be found in Abarbanel on the Torah Bereshis 28.10.6:

How could Jacob act like those who serve upon the condition of receiving a reward, by saying, "If G-d will be with me and keep me and give me ... " so and so, the he would accept Him as his G-d. Conversely, then, He would not perform these things for him, He would not be his G-d and he would not serve Him? His grandfather Abraham did not act thus, but was tried many times and without temptation.

The following midrash Bereshis Rabba 70:4 is an answer to OP's question. It is used to clarify Rashi's comment by R. Eliyahu Mizrachi on Bereshis 28:20:

Rabbi Abbahu and Rabbi Yoḥanan, one said: The narrative requires rearranging (i.e. chronologically speaking, Yaakov's vow was uttered before the Divine promise to keep him, etc.). The other said: It requires no rearrangement. The one who said: the order was wrong, said so because he wondered how it was possible for Yaakov to say, If G-d will be with me, when G-d had already promised to be with him? How does the one who says the narrative requires no rearrangement, understands the words "If G-d will be with me?" It is, rather, that this is what Yaakov said: ‘If the conditions that G-d promised me - to be with me and to protect me, are fulfilled, then I will fulfill my vow.’

As Nechama Leibowitz explains:

According to the first view that the order is wrong, Yaakov's vow was not a reaction to the divine promise, but the reverse. Yaakov prayed and petitioned for guardianship and protection, made his promisses and vowed his vow: "If G-d will be with me," after which came a dream and blessings as an answer to hos prayer. According to this Midrash, the Almighty ony reveals Himself after a man approached Him first, in the sense of Tehilim 145:18: "The LORD is near to all who call Him, to all who call Him with sincerity." The reason why R. Abbahu wished to change the order of the narrative, was because it implied Yaakov's lack of faith in the Divine promise.

How does R. Yoḥanan meet the same objection without changing the order? Surely, his answer: "If the conditions that G-d promised me are fulfilled" hardly meets the objection. Yaakov is still casting doubts on the certainty of the Divine promise., but we must understand Yaakov's words in the Midrash to mean: *If I prove worthy of all promises. The promises of protection to the righteous are not absolute and unconditional, but depend on him maintaining his standards of conduct and not deviating to an evil path. The Righteous man cannot assume that he has been granted an irrevocable title deed to comfort and protection, and he has no longer to stand in awe of his Master, but can do as he likes. On the contrary, man stands in judgement at every moment of his existence, and at any time, his judgement can change. This point is brought in Midrash Bereshis Rabba 76:2, which can be found in Ramban on Bereshis 28:20:

Rav Huna said in the name of Rabbi Aḥa: “Behold, I am with you” (Genesis 28:15); “if God will be with me”? (Genesis 28:20). Rather, from here [we learn] that there is no promise to the righteous in this world.

Nechama Leibowitz continues with explanation:

Ramban explains that the "reason for the condition, the if qualification, was lest sin should intervene." Yaakov then did not, G-d forbid, cast doubts on the Almighty's word, displayed no lack of faith with Him. Perhaps, as a result of his long stay at Lavan's in alien environment, he might succumb to heathen influences. He doubted his own ability to withstand temptation. He might not ultimately prove worthy of the kindnesses promised by G-d. Perhaps sin would soil him. Yaakov did not cast doubts on G-d and His credibility, but on himself and his capacity to withstand temptation.

Therefore, Yaakov's vow should be viewed as a protection as we see in Sifrei Devarim 31:5:

"And Jacob vowed a vow, saying, etc." Now would it occur to anyone that Jacob our father would say (Ibid.) "If G-d will be with me … and He will give me bread to eat and a garment to wear (21) and I return in peace to my father's house, and (only then) He will be a G-d to me!" (Obviously,) He will be a G-d to me in any event. How, then, is "and He will be a G-d to me" to be understood? That His name repose upon me, that no "base matter" issue from me from beginning to end.

The words of Sifrei Devarim support the position of Ramban as explained. However, Rashi and Rashbam seem to use this midrash defending the position that once Hashem promised, it should materialize contrary to Bereshis Rabba 76:2. The Netziv addresses this difference in HaEmek Davar on Bereshis 28:21, second comment:

The sense of the text supports Ramban that it is the consequent cause, and not Rashi's view. It means that he would not rely on his own might and the power of his hand, but would keep G-d continually in front of him to leed him. Whilst away from home, with Lavan, it was natural for him to place his trust in G-d and not rely on his own efforts. But it was possible for him to be completely self-reliant at home, in his father's house. Regarding this he made his vow and stated that even there, G-d would be his guide and support. In actual fact, though the contingency of "the Lord shall be my G-d" is dependent, in the main, on man himself, on his own will, nevertheless the Divine assistance is necessary. It was necessary for Divine providence to be behind him at every step. Therefore, Yaakov worded it as a consequent condition that he could fulfill, if the Divine promisses were realized.

title: Is a garment with tzitzis that was specially made for a woman a Lo Yilbash
content:
# Is a garment with tzitzis that was specially made for a woman a Lo Yilbash ## Frage

Can a woman wear a garment with tzitzis that was specifically made for a woman?

This article says that many poskim maintain that pants designed for women are okay for women to use. Can their reasoning be extended to a garment with tzitzis that was made for women?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

The Maharam Schick writes in his responsa Yore Deah 173 that according to the Taz (182:4) the prohibition of "Lo Yilbash" only applies when wearing a garment for the sake of beauty. In the case of wearing a garment for a mitzvah, there is no prohibition of "Lo Yilbash."

Furthermore the Rema writes in Orach Chaim 17:2 that if a woman wishes to wear tzitzit, she has that option. However since it would look like she is trying to appear more observant, they should not wear tzitzit.

Now, whether a woman should wear tzitzit is another question and current practice is not to. In the end, consult your LOR.

וישמש באימה וכו' וכתב בס' מדרש תלפיות דז"ן ע"ב ודקמ"ג. ע"ב דבשעת הזיווג יצייר נגד עיניו צורת האותיות התורה וכו' והביאו הרו"ח או' ד'

title: In places south of the Equator (South America, Africa) their winter is our summer. Why don't they say V'ten tal u'mater l'bracha?
content:
# In places south of the Equator (South America, Africa) their winter is our summer. Why don't they say V'ten tal u'mater l'bracha? ## Frage

Those of us living in the Northern Hemisphere begin to sat V'sayn Tal U'Matar l'vracha around Dec 4 or Dec 5. Yet people living in the Southern Hemisphere continue to say V'sayn B'racha, only mentioning Tal U'matar in the Bracha of Shema Koleinu because in Eretz Yisroel they are saying V'sayn Beracha.

Why is there the disparity?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

The northern hemisphere and southern hemisphere have opposite summer and winter, therefore there is a debate when to pray for rain in the south.

The northern hemisphere follows Rashi (Ta'anit 10a) who states that the custom is to just follow Bavel. This itself is novel because different places need rain at different times, its not just summer and winter. In places like NY, it rains more in the summer than in the winter. (I think its the same in all of the Americans, I know that in Panama and Costa Rica which are in the northern hemisphere it rains more in the summer too but they call it winter since it's their rain(ier) season).

Being Jews, we have every possible opinion regarding the southern hemisphere.

  1. Do the same as the north
  2. Do the opposite of the north
  3. Do the middle ground, in Shome'a T'fillah say v'ten tal umattar (Be’artzenu Hakedosha - Rav Ben Sion Abba Shaul)
  4. Say like north unless rain is harmful at that time in that location

See Magen Avot, YUTorah, Yeshiva.co

title: Question about spiritual gates in sixth millennium in Zohar
content:
# Question about spiritual gates in sixth millennium in Zohar ## Frage

According the Sohar https://www.sefaria.org/Zohar.1.117a.3 become important spiritual gates open in specific years from the sixth millennium. This text say that in this time special opportunities for spiritual development are there. Can someone explain me more detailed which years exactly are meant and what kind of gates this are?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

B"H

The Rebbe in Likkutei Sichos, parshas Noach, Sicha #2 explains that this prophecy of the zohar is saying that in the Hebrew year 5600 (600th year of the 6th millennium, corresponding to the 600th year of Noach's life when the "windows of the heavens" opened and the "wellsprings of the deep" opened up), that there's going to be me "wisdom" from the heavens, new divine wisdom, and new "water" (wisdom) from the Earth.

The Rebbe says that the wisdom from the heavens corresponds to the publishing of Torah Ohr around that time, and the wisdom of the Earth refers to the industrial revolution at that time

The Rebbe asks why the Zohar connects these two things together. It is understandable that the revelation of the inner secrets of Torah is a preparation for the times of Moshiach, but how does the development of secular science and technology help us enter the Messianic era. Since they are mentioned together, the physical wisdom must serve the spiritual goal.

The explanation is based on the principle that everything G-d created was made for His honor and for the sake of the Torah. Therefore, the true purpose and perfection of these scientific advancements are achieved only when they are utilized for serving G-d.

The Rebbe adds a crucial warning here. This explanation does not mean one should attend college or universities to learn these subjects. The atmosphere in those institutions is often filled with ideas that deny Divine Providence and lacks modesty, which presents a serious spiritual danger. The Rebbe is discussing the purpose of the wisdom itself, not giving permission to study it in an environment that is harmful to one's faith.

The specific connection between technology and Moshiach is that in the Messianic era, the physical flesh itself will see G-dliness. It will not just be a spiritual understanding but a tangible experience. Modern technology provides a physical example of this. For instance, the telephone and radio allow a voice to be heard instantly across great distances. This gives us a tangible way to understand the concept that an Eye sees and an Ear hears everything. It makes the idea of G-d's constant presence feel real to our physical senses, which helps a person act properly.

Furthermore, just as the Sages say gold was created primarily for the Holy Temple, these technologies were created primarily to spread Torah. When the inner dimension of Torah is broadcast over the radio, the words of G-d physically fill the entire world, reaching even places where no people are present. This provides a taste of the prophecy that the earth will be filled with the knowledge of G-d.

Finally, the Rebbe explains that science itself is moving closer to Torah. In the past, science viewed the world as being composed of many separate, distinct elements. As science advances, it discovers that matter and energy are interchangeable and seeks a single unifying force in nature. This scientific realization that the world is essentially one unity reflects the spiritual truth of the absolute Unity of G-d taught in Chassidus. By revealing the unity within the physical world, science prepares the world to recognize the Unity of the Creator.

title: How does work the - 231 gates - of letter permutation in Sefer Yetzirah?
content:
# How does work the - 231 gates - of letter permutation in Sefer Yetzirah? ## Frage

I hear about this old Jewish book, Sefer Yetzirah, and they say it have something with 231 gates. Is about how you can make combinations from the 22 Hebrew letters, like mixing them together in different ways. I not understand exactly how it working, but sound like mystical mathematics or something?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

B"H

The concept of "231 gates, forward and backwards" from Sefer Yetzitah means you line up every letter in a circle, the, start for Aleph, and draw a line from Aleph to Beis, then from Aleph to Tuf etc., and when you finish Aleph, do the same for Beis.

If you do that, there's a total of 462 "Gates" (two letter Hebrew combinations made by the lines). Of these, half (231) are exactly the reverse of the other, hence "231 gates forwards and backwards".

The Tanya quotes that passage as saying that even creations that are not explicitly mentioned in the account of creation still constantly receive their life force from those very same Hebrew words, through an elaborate system of switching some Hebrew letters with others through the 231 gates forwards and backwards etc.

title: Why does the Torah only explicitly forbid certain deviant sexual behaviors and not others?
content:
# Why does the Torah only explicitly forbid certain deviant sexual behaviors and not others? ## Frage

The Torah explicitly forbids sexual relations with animals. It seems clear that this behavior occurred in the ancient world. However other deviant sexual behaviors (known as paraphilias) are not mentioned as explicitly forbidden. I would like to understand why the torah explicitly forbids bestiality but does not mention other deviant forbidden sexual behaviors (specific types exist but are intentionally omitted here for reasons of modesty). Alternatively the Torah could simply indicate that all sexual activity outside of (normal) male-female union is proscribed, without the need to mention animals or other behaviors at all.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Presuming that most if not all of these behaviors result in zera levatalah, then the question really would boil down to why that's not listed as one of the 613 mitzvos, for which there's already a question on this site (and several related ones). Aside from the various answers there (at least one of which states that some Rishonim do count it as such), it's also worth noting what R. Schneur Zalman of Liadi writes in his Tanya (ch. 7):

וְלָכֵן לֹא הוּזְכַּר עֲוֹן זֶרַע לְבַטָּלָה בַּתּוֹרָה בִּכְלַל בִּיאוֹת אֲסוּרוֹת, אַף שֶׁחָמוּר מֵהֶן, וְגָדוֹל עֲוֹנוֹ בִּבְחִינַת הַגַּדְלוּת וְרִבּוּי הַטּוּמְאָה וְהַקְּלִיפּוֹת שֶׁמּוֹלִיד וּמַרְבֶּה בִּמְאֹד מְאֹד בְּהוֹצָאַת זֶרַע לְבַטָּלָה, יוֹתֵר מִבִּיאוֹת אֲסוּרוֹת. רַק, שֶׁבְּבִיאוֹת אֲסוּרוֹת מוֹסִיף כֹּחַ וְחַיּוּת בִּקְלִיפָּה טְמֵאָה בְּיוֹתֵר, עַד שֶׁאֵינוֹ יָכוֹל לְהַעֲלוֹת מִשָּׁם הַחַיּוּת בִּתְשׁוּבָה, אֶלָּא אִם כֵּן יַעֲשֶׂה תְּשׁוּבָה מֵאַהֲבָה רַבָּה כָּל כָּךְ, עַד שֶׁזְּדוֹנוֹת נַעֲשׂוּ לוֹ כִּזְכֻיּוֹת. מִפְּנֵי שֶׁנִּקְלְטָה בִּיסוֹד דְּנוּקְבָא דִקְלִיפָּה הַמְקַבֶּלֶת וְקוֹלֶטֶת הַחַיּוּת מֵהַקְּדוּשָּׁה, מַה שֶּׁאֵין כֵּן בְּזֶרַע לְבַטָּלָה, שֶׁאֵין שָׁם בְּחִינַת נוּקְבָא דִקְלִיפָּה, רַק שֶׁכֹּחוֹתֶיהָ וְחַיְילוֹתֶיהָ מַלְבִּישִׁים לַחַיּוּת שֶׁבַּטִּפּוֹת, כַּיָּדוּﬠַ לְיוֹדְﬠֵי חֵן:

The gist is that with zera levatalah there's no "recipient," unlike in forbidden relationships, and therefore the type of teshuvah needed to rectify it is of a different kind.

Now, assuming that some of these behaviors (reliance on a certain item of clothing, for example) can be incorporated into a male-female relationship without zera levatalah or other implications, then presumably there's no reason for them to be forbidden per se.

title: What is the meaning of the letter Aleph?
content:
# What is the meaning of the letter Aleph? ## Frage

What ultimate meaning or encryption does the letter Aleph א hold?

The Hebrew letter Alef (א) is visually composed of three parts:

One Yud (י) on top - this letter has the numerical value of 10 One Yud (י) on the bottom - also with the numerical value of 10 A diagonal Vav (ו) in the middle connecting them - with the numerical value of 6

When you add these numerical values together: 10 + 10 + 6 = 26

What happened here? Ancient Hebrew aleph, bull's head...?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

One meaning is to "teach". It famously writes in Iyov 33:33:

אִם־אַ֭יִן אַתָּ֥ה שְֽׁמַֽע־לִ֑י הַ֝חֲרֵ֗שׁ וַאֲאַלֶּפְךָ֥ חָכְמָֽה

But if not, you listen to me; Be still, and I will teach you wisdom.

For a deeper understanding, take a look at this from Chabad here - I will endeavour to summarise later on.

### ✅ Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

אלף can mean oxen (e.g., Deuteronomy 28:4), and the ancient Hebrew form of the letter א represented the head of an ox.

title: What does the Milui technique mean in Kabbalah?
content:
# What does the Milui technique mean in Kabbalah? ## Frage

Could someone do this using an example, for example? - אלף הי יוד הי אלף דלת נון יוד יוד הי ויו הי - explain?

A deeper meaning is explained in:

Sha'arei Orah, Tenth Gate, First Sefirah Gates of Light, trans. by Rabbi Amiram Markel and Rabbi Yehudah S. Markel, 2023

מי אל כמוך נושא עון ועובר על פשע לשארית נחלתו לא החזיק לעד אפו כי חפץ חסד הוא (מיכה ז, יח):

https://www.sefaria.org/Sha'arei_Orah%2C_Tenth_Gate%2C_First_Sefirah.1

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Hashem created the world through His Divine speech and the roots of creation (and emanation) are through His Divine Names. This article explains it.

His Names can be written in full (milui) but in different ways; ה can be written הי ,הא or הה, for example. Therefore His Name י-ה-ו-ה can be written in full in various ways, giving different gematrias. Each of those is the root of a Divine Emanation. The classical four given are Shem M'a (45), Ba'n (52), Sa'g (63), A'v (72), based on the following miluim respectively:

  • יוד־הא־ואו־הא (45)
  • יוד־הה־וו־הה (52)
  • יוד־הי־ואו־הי (63)
  • יוד־הי־ויו־הי (72)

These correspond to various Kabbalistic configurations. Ultra simplified, Shem M'a and Ba'n correspond to masculine and feminine, including Chochma and Binah at every level, or Z'on in particular. A'v and Sa'g also correspond to Chochma and Binah respectively, but generally at higher levels, in our soul and in the Seder Hishtalshelut. See the first chapters of Sha'ar HaYichud by the Mittler Rebbe for a more on point explanation of these latter Names.

[The one you've brought is a yichud and a milui and is more complicated (also I'd rather not turn Mi Yodeya into a Kabbalistic miluim explanation service, if you know what I mean) so I won't look into it to see if I can find an explanation for it, but hopefully this answers the broader question.]

title: Do the dead need extra mercy or not?
content:
# Do the dead need extra mercy or not? ## Frage

“In שמונה עשרה we say:

מכלכל חיים בחסד מחיה מתים ברחמים רבים:

The living is sustained with kindness, while the dead are revived with abundant mercy.

As עיון תפילה explains: since the dead can no longer do מצוות or earn זכותים on their own, they need more mercy. But we know that people can daven or learn לעילוי נשמת someone who has passed away. So, why do they need extra רחמנות?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Rabbi Zev Leff shlita in his Shemoneh Esrei: The Depth and Beauty of Our Daily Tefillah (Targum Press - 2008) pp.59-60 writes:

G-d's power as manifest through the forces that He exercises in this world begins with the fact that He "sustains life with benevolent kindness" - unearned and given in the hope and understanding that one will utilize that gift to earn eternal life. However, the resurrection of the dead is performed "brachamim rabim" - with great mercy, but not with chesed, totally gracious. It has to be deserved at least minimally...

...Rabbi Moshe Cordevero explains that techiyas hameisim itself is a great mercy to the soul. In its spiritual abode, following this temporal life, the soul is incomplete and years to be reunited with the body where it can reach greater perfection. In this vein, the souls in Gan Eden longingly await techiyas hameisim as we in this world longingly await Mashiach.

The manner in which techiyas hameisim occurs will also reflect great mercy. G-d will bring back the body fully clothed and healed of all of its infirmities and handicaps that it had in its first earthly existence. The era of resurrection will be a time when G-d will express His ultimate mercy, and this will be more significant than the act of resurrection itself.

Rabbi Noson Weisz shlita writes in his Prayer Works: How Words of Prayer Move the World (Feldheim - 2011) pp.255-256 the following:

The life-support system of pure chesed energy the Almighty provides to us in Olam Hazeh is sufficient to maintain us in our present state. However, it is not powerful enough to propel us into Olam Haba. To endow this chesed energy with enough power to restore us to life, it must be transformed into a substance of higher octane. That is a feat accomplished by mixing in abundant amounts of rachamim.

Rachamim, as explored in relation to the first blessing of the Amidah, is itself an admixture of chesed and din. The introduction of din into the energy flow is necessary because chesed, as described earlier, is comparable to free-flowing water. It simply spreads out and covers all available space, producing no thrust in any one direction. Therefore, chesed alone cannot break through the mightiest barrier of all - death - which separates this world from the World to Come...

For chesed to penetrate the barrier imposed by death, it must be propelled by tremendous force. That is why the brachah is called Gevuros. It calls upon G-d's might, which is expressed in our world through din. Din provides the propulsion required to push us pass the death barrier...

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

A possible answer from יום ב׳ דר״ה תער״ג - אני לדודי ודודי לי

The concept of Chesed flows in an inner manner. We feel Chesed inside, as a sensation, and in Hashem's Hashgacha, His Chesed is called an "Ohr Penimi", an internal light that provides goodness and blessing to us in a specific, tailored way, to the very penimius of our life.

The concept of Rachamim Rabbim is not so. This is correlated to Hashem's Etzem Ohr Ein Sof. It is an external, all pervasive Rachamim, far more powerful, but also external - makif.

Given that the dead do not have access to this Chesed - their Neshama is no longer "in" (penimi) a body to perform Avodah for drawing this penimius light, nor have a keli to receive it, therefore they require sustaining from Hashems Etzem Ha'Ohr - His Rachamecha Rabbim, while we who are alive are capable of receiving from both. Hence we ask here for Hashem's Chasadim Tovim (as well as His Rachamim Rabim in Yotzer Ohr).

title: What does ־וֹן mean?
content:
# What does ־וֹן mean? ## Frage

שמעון, פשון, גדעון, אלון, and some other names end with ון.

What is the function of this suffix?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

According to "Phonology and Morphology of Biblical Hebrew" by Hebrew linguist Joshua Blau, section 4.4.6.6: the suffixes -ān, -ōn are noun formation suffixes from verb roots among a number of other ways to create abstract nouns. The form -ān, such as קָרְבָּן (offering) is thought to be the original form which under some phonetical rules turned into -ōn. See also E. Kautzsch Gesenius' Hebrew Grammar Section 85: subsection XI. Nouns with Afformatives, paragraph 54.

The most complete treatment of these suffixes can be found in Jouon and Muraoka "A Grammar of Biblical Hebrew", Section 88-M Forms with Sufformatives. It distinguishes the following cases:

Abstract Noun Case Qatalān > Qittalōn

It is made up of qatal+ān. This form of abstract noun, as expected, becomes קְטָלוֹן in Hebrew, which is found only in רְעָבוֹן (famine). Elsewhere qatalān has a doubling of a second consonant (i.e. getting dagesh-chazak). This secondary doubling was perhaps due to the need to preserve the three vowels, which give a form a characteristic aspect. The doubling may also have originated in certain nouns for some phonetic reason and then spread to others.

Thus we have examples עִוָּרוֹן (blindness) from עִוֵּר; or עִשָּׂרוֹן (a tenth part) from עַשֵׂר.

The primitive first vowel a (patach) has been only preserved in שַׁבָּתוֹן (abstention from work) probably under the influence of שַׁבָּת. (There is also a curious Greek name of the city Ακκαρων, Akkadian Amqarruna, while Hebrew is עֶקְרוֹן). Everywhere else, the a (patach) is weakened to i (hiriq) to create a form קִטָּלוֹן (qittalōn) probably because it is far from the last stressed syllable ōn. In the construct state or with a suffix the form becomes קִטְלוֹן (qitlon, no dagesh), and if the first consonant is gutteral hireq becomes segol:

Examples: musing הִגָּיוֹן with construct הֶגְיוֹן; tenth part עִשָּׂרוֹן with plural עֶשְׂרוֹנִים. Exception Ezekiel 27:27 עִזְבוֹנִַיִך

More examples: remembrance זִכָּרוֹן with construct זִכְרוֹן and plural זִכְרוֹנִים. This pattern follows: breaking שִׁבָּרוֹן; deposit פִּקָּדוֹן; hard work עִצָּבוֹן; arid land צִמָּאוֹן; hasty flight חִפָּזוֹן; confidence בִּטָּחוֹן; desolation שִׁמָּמוֹן. There is no dagesh in ר so we get עֵרָבוֹן with segol becoming tzere, however curiously there is a Greek form ἀρραβών. Also horror דֵּרָאוֹן.

In ל"ה verbs (the last letter of the root is ה turns into י) we find likewise: vision חִזָּיוֹן (however there is a form חָזוֹן described below). Musing הִגָּיוֹן; a kind of song שִׁגָּיוֹן; polished plate גִּלָּיוֹן; purity נִקָּיוֹן; annihilation כִּלָּיוֹן; and no dagesh in ר: pregnancy הֵרָיוֹן. Besides these forms with י, there are some common forms that are likely influenced by Aramaic or Syriac: vision חָזוֹן close to Aramaic חֶזְוָּנָא; and similarly iniquity עָוֹן; good will רָצוֹן; highness גָאוֹן; tumult הָמוֹן; leanness רָזוֹן; anger חָרוֹן.

In the ע"י verbs (a two-letter root with a vowel י in-between, such as to judge דִין) the pattern is qat + -ān. I.e. the previously mentioned forms of ל"ה verbs could have also been influenced by these forms. We have: joy שָׂשׂוֹן (root שׂישׂ); pride זָדוֹן; insolence לָצוֹן.

Exception: perdition אַבַדּוֹן with dagesh in ד; although the Aramaic אַבְדָן in Esther 9:5.

Bereshis 3:16 has הֵרֹנֵךְ which violates the form הֶרְיוֹנֵךְ or alternatively הֲרוֹנֵךְ as the rule would dictate.

Abstract Noun Case Qitlān

It can be represented as either קִטְלוֹן or קִטְלָן (no dagesh in the second letter). Examples: success כִּשְרוֹן, advantage יִתְרוֹן; lack חֶסְרוֹן.

Also the anomalous Hebrew forms, acquisition קִנְיָן; building בִּנְיָן; business עִנְיָן. These words do not have attested construct form.

Abstract Noun Case Qutlān

Examples: table שֻׁלְחָן; offering קָרְבָּן; loss אָבְדָן

Adjectival Case

Often occurs when the suffix -ān > וֹן is added to certain nouns. Examples: preceding or eastern קַדְמוֹן from east קֶדֶם; last אַחֲרוֹן from behind אַחַר; first רִאשׁוֹן from head רֹאש. The last formation is made by analogy with the two-consonant roots: extreme קִיצוֹן from end קֵץ; outer חִצוֹן from חוּץ; middle תִּכוֹן from תוֹך. Similarly, lower or inferior תַּחְתּוֹן; superior or Most High עֶלְיוֹן

There are also cases when the suffix is added to the feminine form as in Aramaic. For example, tortuous עֲקַלָּתוֹן; and in case of nouns for serpents לִוְיָתָן, נְחֻשׁתָּן.

Diminutive form

Examples: pupil of the eye (little man) אִישוֹן; little moons or crescents שַׂהֲרֹנִים; perhaps the names of some reptiles such as horned snake שְׁפִיפוֹן; basilisk צִפְעֹנִי

For example, the name שִמְשוֹן can be read as little sun from sun שֶמֶש. As far as the names in the question, there exist established etymologies for them:

  1. Shimon שמעון - based on Bereshis 29:33 the son is a result of Hashem's hearing of Leah's distress, just like the offering קרבן is a result of a sacrifice.

  2. Pishon פשון - Based on Rashi to Bereshis 2:11, who either quotes Habakuk 1:8 וּפָ֖שׁוּ פָּרָשָׁ֑יו - "their steeds gallop", which gives abstract noun for the river name - the result of rushing water; or the fact that they grow flax (פשתן) (Genesis Rabbah 16:2) - i.e. that the river water (פָשׁה - male) is the source of growth of the linen (פשת - female).

  3. Gidon גדעון. The root גדע means to chop off, cut off. Hence גדעון is someone who chopped many soldiers, i.e. a mighty warrior as given by Alfred Kolatch "The Name Dictionary".

  4. Alon/Eilon אלון - means oak tree. The Klein dictionary gives two etymologies. The first appears as an abstract noun derivation from from אול:

אֵלוֹן - m.n. oak. [Properly ‘a large strong tree’, and like אֵלָה (= terebinth; oak) derived from אול ᴵ (= to be strong). cp. אִילָן.].

The second is diminutive from אלה:

אַלּוֹן - m.n. oak. [Related to Akka. allānu; related also to אֵלוֹן, to which it stands as אַלָּה (terebinth) or אֵלָה (terebinth).]

  1. With the name Aharon אהרן the etymology is unclear as explained here and also the The Name Dictionary by Kolatch, the possibilities include:
  • הרה to conceive, become pregnant; as well as to teach, implant seeds of knowledge. It creates an unusual abstract noun from a future 1st person אֶהֱרֶה I will conceive/implant seeds of knowledge.
  • הר mountain, which makes a diminutive small mountain. It would be the case with the name הָרָן, but does not explain the initial א.
  • אור light, illuminate - also creates an abstract noun, but does not explain the change of ו into ה.
  • רנן to give ringing cry, to shout of joy. If this is a source of an abstract noun, it is unusual even if one starts from the hiphil form הִרְנִין
  • The Kolatch dictionary also suggests that the Arabic word for messenger is close. Unfortunately, I do not know Arabic, and standard translation for messenger is rasoul.
  • אהר this is a Syriac/Aramaic root meaning to sexually arrouse (see the A Syriac Lexicon by Michael Sokoloff, p.12). This would make a great case of an abstract noun, a result of arousal with intent to conceive, although the Hebrew equivalent is אחר, with ח instead of ה. Women in Mitzraim approached men, who were extremely tired from hard labor. Women aroused them to have relations to conceive children.

title: How effective are proofs in revealing truth?
content:
# How effective are proofs in revealing truth? ## Frage

If so many sound arguments can be crafted for any individual case, how does one pick / determine ‘the truth’? Were these arguments flawed even to those producing them (Would they really believe them and if so how could they reconcile (so many) clearly interceding/interfering understandings? Would they weigh and choose those arguments (individually or collectively) that made the strongest point and adjudicate in that likeness? Additionally and primarily, if so many arguments can be constructed in one specific direction or way, how does that effect our understanding of the effectiveness of proofs in order to reveal truth?

Sources : Rebbe Meir was the greatest of his generation and could argue many ways In addition Bavli and even moreso in Yerushalmi, speak about how sages wanting to serve as dayanim in the Sanhedrin would need to be able to offer proofs of things which were (clearly) not true, and the Midrash even supports that this was common even for children to do in the days of Dovid HaMelech. I also found this helpful resource.

(Thanks for your recommendations!)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

I heard a story from Rabbi Manis Friedman that might be relevant. It's about the Alter Rebbe. It's a two parter and both are relevant. Part 1:

A father, whose son had been attending Yeshiva, came to the Alter Rebbe and told him how proud he was of his son, that he had made huge progress and was very talented in gemara. The only thing was, this talent was going to his son's head, and the son was getting arrogant. The father was quite repulsed by him, to be honest, and wanted advice from the Alter Rebbe. The Rebbe told him to come back with his son.

When they returned the Alter Rebbe asked him which sugya he was learning, and then when the son told him, asked a very good question on the sugya. The son couldn't work out the answer, so the Rebbe said "no matter, but you agree at least that it's a good question right?" and the son said "yes, amazing question!", and the Alter Rebbe retorted "no it isn't!" and immediately gave an answer that destroyed the question. The son was amazed, and the Alter Rebbe asked him again, "so, that was a good answer wasn't it?" and the son again exclaimed "yes, profound!" and the Alter Rebbe did the same: "no it isn't!" and immediately brought a devastating kashe on the answer.

This proceeded several times, "good kashe, no?", "yes, fantastic!", "no it isn't!", teretz, etc. etc. After a while, the Rebbe eventually turned to the father and said, "nu, I thought you told me that your son was talented in gemara?". Indeed, the experience brought the son down a peg, and the son walked out a head shorter, but also a great deal more humble.

The son joined the Alter Rebbe's class, and a few years later, we get part 2:

The son came in for a yechidus with the Alter Rebbe. As they were catching up, including talking about what they were learning at the time, the Rebbe said "what do you think of the Mordechai on our sugya?". The son said, "to be honest, I didn't really get it. His answer is very shver, and seemingly unnecessarily so". The Rebbe asked why he thought that, and the son said "I can think of at least 3 better, simpler and easier answers". The Rebbe asked him what they were and he proceeded to list them out. The Rebbe then said "very good, and there are others too" and proceeded to give another 6.

After he was done, the Alter Rebbe then proceeded to dismantle every single one of the 9 answers, one by one, until all that was left was the Mordechai. The son was stunned. Then the Alter Rebbe turned to the son and said "and you want to know the difference between a Rishon and an Acharon? Do you think the Mordechai had to go through all 10 answers before realising that the one he gave was the only one? No, not at all. He went straight for the correct answer".

How is this relevant? Well, you make a strong case by bringing the gemara in Eruvin 13b that says that Rebbi Meir's mind was so profound, that he could give a proof that something is pure, and another proof that something is impure and nobody could work out which proof was better. He had a student who could make 48 proofs either way, and the gemara brings evidence of another student from Yavne who could bring 150!

What is this telling us? That there is no truth? That there is no such thing as proof? No, I don't think so. I think this is telling us that the ability to assess proof is a skill that has a huge ladder of mastery to climb - they couldn't make Rabbi Meir the posek ador because he was too high up the ladder, they couldn't make use of his reasoning (the key point: if they could, they would have). This actually is the root of why people are so very capable of reasoning out anything they want - something we see today very prevalently in the world of social media: our character traits directly affect our thinking.

We have an "intellectual soul", and a "vital, natural soul" (i.e. our emotional being), and the former is enclothed in the latter. This means that our heart is נתפס, "grasps" the mind, and is thus able to influence it. It is able to "bribe" the mind, and thus alter its reasoning. In the words of the great-great-great-grandson of the Alter Rebbe, The Frierdiker Rebbe:

כמו שאנו רואים בחוש שהחפץ ותשוקת הלב מטה את השכל להשכיל דוקא כחפץ לבבו, ובפרט בענין הנוגעללבו ה״ה משכיל בזה כמה השכלות וממציא המצאות מופלגות והכל רק כחפץלבבו, עד שאינו יכול השכיל ולהשיג כלל באופן אחר ואינו מבין כלל איך יכול להיות באופן אחר כו׳, ואמיתת הענין הוא לא כלפי האמת כלל

And we see tangibly that the desire and will of the heart inclines the intellect to understand specifically as the heart desires, especially in a matter that touches the heart. He will then grasp this with many intellectual arguments and produce astonishing innovations, all only according to the desire of his heart, to the point that he cannot understand in any other way at all, and he cannot comprehend how it could be otherwise. And the truth is that none of this corresponds to actual truth whatsoever. [ הבאים ישרש יעקב יציץ ופרח ישראל כו׳ from ספר המאמרים תרפ"ה]

This influence is practically unavoidable, which is why the only way to ensure that our thinking and reasoning are accurate, good and have a chance of attaining the "actual truth" is if our heart is thoroughly good as well. Basically, the ladder is, at least in part*, our character traits**.

Ultimately though, if we work hard, and apply morality to our thinking process - integrity, intellectual honesty, rid ourselves of laziness, arrogance etc. - the truth is within reach through reason and proof. As the Alter Rebbe showed, with enough tenacity, one can bring an end to the cycle of kashe and teretz and we can have hope of getting closer to understanding Hashem and what He wants from us. This is why our Sages, our Gedolim, had perfect character traits - if they didn't, they wouldn't be Gedolim!

Indeed, this is exactly what the Rebbe Rashab (the great-great grandson of the Alter Rebbe) explains in ש״פ תולדות - ויתן לך in ספר המאמרים תרס"ו (Hemshech Samech Vav):

“The essential idea of pilpul is that the first comprehension… immediately becomes the subject of many questions… until the matter is completely hidden… However, it does not remain in concealment. Rather, after all the concealments and absence of understanding, one reaches the true comprehension of the matter… At that point, all the questions and concealments are automatically resolved, and the light of truth shines forth with greater clarity and purity.”

“What brings one to the true essence of the matter are specifically the questions and concealments… through questioning and pilpul, one clarifies all the dross and impurities within the intellect — like filtering wine many times — until the light of truth shines.”

“This is ‘He has set me in darkness’ — this is the Babylonian Talmud — whose path is or chozer (reflected light): to obscure through many questions, not to remain in darkness, but to reach the ‘essential concealment’ of chochmah from which a deeper light emerges, and to purify the dross so that a higher light of truth shines.”

“Yerushalmi often gives clear rulings with less pilpul (or yashar, direct light), while Bavli’s toil reaches the ‘essential concealment’ — the level of Torah that ‘only Elokim understands its path’ — attained specifically by striking the flint through toil and questions.”

“Although toil in Torah became necessary after Moshe struck the rock… this very concealment yields a superior advantage: by laboring through garments and questions, one reaches the true essence of Torah as it is in absolute essential concealment — the King’s delights in His Essence.”

“Therefore, the multitude of halachic details, safeguards, and even stringencies are not a flaw but a feature — drawn from supernal wisdom and great love — instruments to refine good from the Tree of Knowledge, so that truth emerges clarified.”

“He will act for those who wait for Him… those who press and delve to discern the clarified truth. Through strenuous analysis and many questions, one returns to the source, the essential concealment, from which infinite revelation flows.”

(I used my AI assistant to extract these quotes from my personal copy of the ma'amar, and ChatGPT to translate them, and I went through them to ensure their accuracy)

All in all he explains:

  • There is a purpose to pilpul, the phenomenon that you pointed out i.e. that we have multiple competing proofs that we have to work through etc.
  • It happened after Moshe hit the rock, but is ultimately for the good. For this reason Bavli is considered "superior" in some respect to "Yerushalmi", because it contains far more pilpul.
  • The purpose is discussed at length in the ma'amar and is off topic to the question, but it boils down to us attaining the truth in a stronger, clearer and deeper way, and brings Essential Nachat Ru'ach to Hashem
  • The way it works is also discussed at length if you wish to learn it (and others have recommended the works of Ramchal as well)

  • He states emphatically that the truth is attainable through this process. There is truth, and there is proof, and pilpul is the path that Hashem set up for it.

Nonetheless, due to the confounding issues (even though they are superficial, they are real), it's realistic to say that not all of us can reach the truth in all cases, all of the time. Despite that, Hashem wants us to continue trying, pray for success, trust our Tzaddikim, and above all know that He rewards us for our effort anyway.

* everyone also has a different intellectual strength, based on their merit and the garment fashioned for them by the purity of their parents (see המשך שמח תשמח in ספר המאמרים תרנ"ז by the great-great grandson of the Alter Rebbe, the Rebbe Rashab for a complete treatment of the topic of the ko'ach hamaskil in the soul), and this is another potential (superficial) confounding factor in a person's ability to reach the truth.
** Rabbi Dovid Gottleib has a great shiur on this. He opens by saying that the first time he heard that intellectual acumen is highly dependant on morality, he found it counter-intuitive - why should it matter? It's certainly not a secular belief. Listen to the shiur for his detailed explanation of this point. If you have trouble accessing it, try the download link on his audio tapes page (it's called Virtue & Intellect)

title: Finding Rivka - Abraham's Servant
content:
# Finding Rivka - Abraham's Servant ## Frage

Shalom,

While reading again chapter 24 of Bereshit, I was wondering why Abraham himself did not go to look for a wife for his son, Isaac.

Any answers?

Thank you!

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

The Netziv explains in in HaEmek Davar on Bereshis 24:1:

ואברהם זקן. הקדים הכתוב להודיע לפני הענין המסופר בפרשה זו שאברהם היה זקן בא בימים מבואר שהוא נוגע להענין כי לולא זה לא היה מצוה לעבדו אלא הוא בעצמו היה מזדרז למצוה רבה זו ליתן אשה ליצחק שבזה תלוי כל התכלית:

Avraham was now old Prior to the matter described in the chapter (the journey to find a wife for Yitzchak), the verse informs that Avraham became old, advanced in years, to connect it to the matter of (the required journey). If not for that, he would not command his servant, rather by himself he would eagerly perform this great mitzvah to marry his son Yitzchak to a woman, since all fruits of his own labor depended on it.

Furthermore, Netziv adds:

אבל משום שהי׳ זקן בא בימים. היינו שהי׳ מחשב כמה ימים עוד יחיה ע״כ הי׳ חושש אולי ימות בדרך רב כזה. אמנם בלי זה הטעם הי׳ רשאי לילך בעצמו לארם נהרים. אע״ג שהיה מוזהר ללכת משם. כבר ביארנו שממעשה העקידה הותר לו לחשוב מארץ הזאת ולזכרה. וה״נ הותר לו הליכות עראי לשם:

However, because he became old, advanced in years he (Avraham) contemplated how many years he had left (in his life), and therefore, he suspected that he could die from such a long journey. Otherwise, without this reason, he would have been permitted to go by himself to Aram Naharaim (Between Rivers, Mesopotamia). Even though (Avraham) was warned against going there (his father's house at the time of Lech Lecha), we have already explained that after the experience of Akkeida, it became permitted to (Avraham) to go back from that land and recall it. I.e. he was permitted to go occasionally there (to Aram Naharaim).

title: Source for the GR"A holding that a Mil is 22.5 minutes long?
content:
# Source for the GR"A holding that a Mil is 22.5 minutes long? ## Frage

I was reading "The Great Z'manim Debate" by Rabbi Ahron Notis and he seems pretty convinced by the later chapters that the GR"A holds that a Mil is 22.5 minutes long. He bases it on the fact that he explains that the Gemara was talking about the equator when it said that Alot Hashachar is 1 hour and 30 minutes before sunrise. (22.5 x 4 = 90).

But if I wanted to write this fact as a source, would I put this calculation Rabbi Notis quotes in O"H 261:11? Or is there a clear source where the GR"A states that a Mil is 22.5 minutes?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

The clearest source for the Gra's 22.5 minute mil is probably in his Bi'ur to Orah Hayim 459:2:

ומיל ג' שמינית

and a mil is three eighths [of an hour = 22.5 minutes]

However, it's worth noting that this quote appears in the middle of a very lengthy piece, whose conclusion is somewhat unclear.

Thus, although for example Bi'ur Halacha to 459:2 seems to understand that the Gra held of a 22.5 minute mil, Hazon Ish Orah Hayim 123 understands that the Gra at the end of his comment actually concluded that the correct calculation leads to an 18 minute mil.

title: What did a Ger Toshav do when Eretz Yisroel was at war?
content:
# What did a Ger Toshav do when Eretz Yisroel was at war? ## Frage

What did a Ger Toshav do when Eretz Yisroel was at war? The halachos of who does and who does not go out to war whether a milchemes mitzva or milchemes (cf Rambam hilchos Melochim 7:1-15) seem to be only addressed to Jews who were following all Torah laws. What were the non-Jewish Gerei Toshuv doing when those wars were taking place? Were they neutral? In an outsider volunteer support unit? etc.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

There doesn't appear to be a one-size-fits-all answer.

Yaavetz, Migdal Oz, Even Bochen, Pinah 1 states that p'shat Tanach indicates that the Keini (descendants of Yitro) were gerei toshav, not Israelites. They were involved in a couple of wars:

  • During the battle between the northern tribes led by Devorah and Barak, and the Canaanites led by Yavin and Sisera, Chever the Keinite, husband of Yael, is stated to have separated from the rest of the Keinites and to have agreed to a peace treaty of sorts with the Canaanites. Practically, however, he seems to have opted out of active involvement in the war. A kind of biblical Switzerland, if you will. Yael decided to break the neutrality by killing Sisera (Shoftim 4:11, 17-22).
  • When Shaul went to battle Amalek, he warned the Keinites, who lived in the vicinity, to clear out, otherwise they will be attacked as well. They chose to heed his warning and leave (Shmuel 1:15:6).
  • Not exactly a war, but David was placed by Achish king of Gath in Tziklag with the expectancy that he would use his strategic position to rob Judahites (thus proving his complete betrayal of Am Yisrael). David claimed to have robbed various Judahite territories in the Negev, including the Negev of the Keinites, though he actually robbed other southern nations (the Geshurites, Gizrites, and Amalekites) (Shmuel 1:27:8-12). After defeating the Amalekites in a later battle, he split the loot between the Judahite territories, including elders of Judah who lived in the Negev of the Keinites (Shmuel 1:30:30). This indicates that at this stage the Keinites began mixing in with the Judahites and David did not consider them fair game for robbery (hence his earlier decision to leave them alone in ch. 27). The Keinites probably had some sort of treaty with the Judahites (possibly indicated also by their mention in the Judahite genealogical lists in Divrei Hayamim 1:2:55).

On the other hand, there were several non-Jews in David's government and army:

  • Ovil the Ishmaelite, in charge of David's camels.1
  • Perhaps Yechedyahu the Meronothite (according to Malbim), in charge of female donkeys.
  • Yaziz the Hagarite, in charge of flocks.
  • Perhaps Tzelek the Ammonite, one of Yoav's arms-bearers.2
  • Yitmah the Moabite, another warrior.
  • Cherethites and Peletites - non-Israelite units in David's army. For possible ethnic identifications, see here.
  • Six hundred Gittites (from Gath Plishtim), among them Itai the Gittite - Plishtite warriors in David's army (e.g. Shmuel 2:15:18-22).

These individuals obviously did not remain neutral during wartime. We see especially the military personnel going to war on David's behalf and protecting him from Avshalom.

So I suppose what a ger toshav did during wartime depended on that person or clan's standing within Eretz-Yisraeli society.

1 Note that אבל in Arabic refers to a camel expert. See אגרת רבי יהודה בן קוריש, Katz edition, p. 61, n. 1 (can be found on Otzar Hachochmah).

2 However, there is a place in Eretz Yisrael called Kefar Ha'amoni/Kefer Ha'amonah (Ktiv/Kri).

title: Why didn't Yitzchak ask Rivka to say that she is his sister in the same fashion that Avraham did?
content:
# Why didn't Yitzchak ask Rivka to say that she is his sister in the same fashion that Avraham did? ## Frage

In Bereishis 12:10-13, we find that there is a famine in the land and Avraham and Sarah are forced to go down to Egypt to obtain food. Avraham pleads with his wife Sarah to say that she is his sister, lest she say she is his wife and they will kill him.
Why don't we find a similar conversation with Yitzchak and his wife Rivka in Parshas Toldos? Why does Yiztchak take it for granted that Rivka will simply go along with the plan and he on his own, without consulting her, says "she is my sister??

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

According to the Alshich the situations of Avraham and Yitzchak were fundamentally different. The entire dynamic in Gerar was not the same as the dynamic in Egypt:

וישאלו אנשי המקום כו'. ששאלו לאשתו ולא לו כי הוא יאמר אחותי מאימת מות פן יהרג לנושאה כי בעולת בעל יש להם. ע"כ שאלו לאשתו כי היא תאמר אישי פן יקחוה כי זה מוראה ולא תחוש פן יהרג בעלה כי ברית כרותה לאבימלך עם אביו. אך הוא בשומעו לא הניחה להשיב פן תאמר אישי הוא ויהרג. ע"כ קפץ והשיב הוא ויאמר אחותי היא ולא מיראת אבימלך כי הלא היה לבו בטוח בו על אשר כרת עם אברהם ברית. וגם יזכור מה שאירע לו עם שרה אמו. אך מה שירא לאמר אשתי הוא על אנשי המקום. וזהו פן יהרגוני אנשי המקום כו' וכאשר ארכו לו שם הימים נתן לב לאבימלך להסתכל בדבר. באומר כי לא יתכן היה יצחק שרוי בלא אשה ימים רבים. וישקיף וירא אותו מצחק שהוא ענין נשוק וחבוק אז ויקרא כו' הנה לפנינו כי אשתך היא ואומר אך הוא למעט כי לא ראה התשמיש ממש כ"א קרוב אליו שהוא הצחוק כמדובר ואיך אמרת אחותי היא. ולא אמר למה אמרת כלומר הנה כדי לשקר אתם מקרבים הדבר כמ"ש אברהם אחותי בת אבי כו' אך אתה איך אמרת אחותי היא. איך הוא התואנה שבקשת כי הלא אין זאת בת אביך. וזה יתכן כיון במלת אך לומר אברהם היתה שרה אשתו ואחותו בת אביו. אך זו הנה אשתך בלבד ולא אחותך בת אביך. ויאמר אליו יצחק כי אמרתי פן אמות ומותר לשקר מאימת מות ע"ד נשבעים להרגים ולחרמים כו'

“And the men of the place asked…” - They asked about his wife and not about him, because if they would ask him, he would say, “She is my sister.” That answer comes from fear of death, lest they kill him in order to take her, for they possessed the practice of taking a married woman. Therefore they asked her about her husband, for she would say, “He is my husband,” lest they take her, as that is where her fear lay, and she would not worry that her husband would be killed, for a covenant had been made between Avimelech and her father-in-law (Avraham).

However, when he (Yitzchak) heard that they were asking her, he did not allow her to answer, lest she say, “He is my husband,” and he would be killed. Therefore he quickly answered in her stead, and he said, “She is my sister.” This was not because he feared Avimelech, for his heart was confident in him because he (Avimelech) had made a covenant with Avraham. He also remembered what had happened with Sarah his mother. What he feared to say was “She is my wife” on account of the men of the place. And this is what is meant by the verse: “lest the men of the place kill me…” And when many days had passed there, Avimelech turned his attention to look into the matter, saying that it was impossible that Yitzchak would be dwelling without a wife for so many days. So he looked out and saw him ‘metzachek’ - which means an act of kissing and embracing. Then he called (Yitzchak)… “Behold, she is indeed your wife!” And he said “however”, to indicate that he had not seen the actual act of intercourse, only something close to it - i.e., the tzchok (playful intimacy) mentioned.

“And how did you say, ‘She is my sister’?” He did not say, “Why did you say…?” Meaning: he was not accusing him of lying; for just as Avraham had said, ‘She is my sister, the daughter of my father…’, so too here. But you, how could you say ‘She is my sister’? What claim were you intending? For she is certainly not your father’s daughter. And this is the meaning of the word “ach” (“however”), to imply: Avraham’s situation was different, for Sarah was both his wife and also his sister, the daughter of his father. But this one (Rivkah) is only your wife, and not your sister, your father’s daughter. Yitzchak answered him: “For I said, ‘Lest I die.’” And it is permitted to lie out of fear of death, just as we find that oaths are permitted to one who is threatened with being killed or placed under a ban, etc.

In short:

  • Avraham had to speak with Sarah because she would naturally say, “He is my husband,” which would endanger him.
  • Rivkah also would naturally say, “He is my husband,” but for a different reason: she feared being taken and did not fear for Yitzchak’s life because of Avimelech’s covenant with Avraham.
  • The men of Gerar questioned Rivkah first, intentionally, because they knew Yitzchak would say “my sister.”
  • Yitzchak had no chance to brief her beforehand; he overheard them asking her and jumped in.
  • He answered for her to prevent her from telling the truth and endangering him.
  • Therefore, unlike Avraham, Yitzchak could not rely on Rivkah cooperating, nor did he have time for a discussion.

title: Why do we say the second paragraph of the Shema every day, והיה אם שמוע, if there are no noticeable consequences for not listening?
content:
# Why do we say the second paragraph of the Shema every day, והיה אם שמוע, if there are no noticeable consequences for not listening? ## Frage

The second paragraph of the Shema, והיה אם שמוע, warns that if we abandon God’s commandments, we’ll be expelled from the promised land. But practically we don't see that now.

So why do we include this in our daily prayers?

You could even argue that saying these verses every day becomes a drawback. It can leave a person thinking there are no consequences at all, because in this case, where the Torah gives a direct warning, we aren’t seeing it play out.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Before we attempt to answer the question let's first understand the simple meaning of the verse. Why indeed do we not see the consequence as is explained in the verse? We have today most Jews in Israel who are not following the Torah. So why is God not expelling them? [Chas Vshalom!]

If I remember correctly there are some classical commentaries explaining that the direct consequences of our actions are not fully seen and felt these days because the relationship that God had with the Jews during earlier times untill the end of the Holy Temple era was a much closer one in which there was a more cause-and-effect relationship that God has with the Jews.

The consequences did happen, just as the verse says. The books of Neviim spell it out in full: when the people went off course, there were wars, deaths, tragedies, and expulsions.

So based on this understanding of the verse we can answer our original question. (This explanation is my own thought, perhaps there are commentaries that agree or disagree, please let me know in the comments.)

We read the והיה אם שמוע so that we are reminded everyday of the close relationship that we once had with God and to train ourselves to yearn for that close relationship once again.

It is just like in any relationship between a husband and wife or between two other friends. If a husband acts rude to his wife and his wife doesn't have any reaction at all then you can assume that the relationship is not that great.

And so we read these verses everyday to remind ourselves of the close relationship that we CAN and SHOULD have with God.

title: Why did Eliav ben Reuven name his son Dathan?
content:
# Why did Eliav ben Reuven name his son Dathan? ## Frage

As we know from Bereshis 37:17 the name of the place where Yosef encountered his brothers was called Dothan:

The man said, “They have gone from here, for I heard them say: Let us go to Dothan.” So Joseph followed his brothers and found them at Dothan (דֹתָֽן).

Therefore, if Eliav ben Reuven called his son Dathan (דָתָ֨ן, see Bamidbar 16:1), the son's name carried a reference to a place where Yosef was sold. What intent could Eliyav have when naming this son in this case? What is the connection between the names otherwise?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

The word "Dotan" most likely stems from Semitic "Dut" (דות), which refers to a type of well or watering hole (although there are those that disagree; see e.g. Talshir here), which explains why there was a hole to throw in Yosef in that area. One linguist, Mordechai Betzalel Schneider, suggested that perhaps the name Datan could stem from the same root.1 Shmuel Loewenstamm in the Encyclopedia Mikrait entry for "Datan" (in Hebrew) followed the opinion of Martin Noth that Datan comes from Akkadian datnu, meaning "strong". In short, it's debatable whether there is an actual etymological connection between Datan and Dotan.

If, indeed, there is some connection between Datan and Dotan, perhaps there was an intent in remembering Reuven's (ultimately failed) attempt to save Yosef at Dotan (Beresheet 37:17-22, 29-30).2 Another possibility that I can think of is that it was a prophetic name: Dotan was the place where the split between the brothers occurred, for it was there where they sold Yosef. Dotan and his brother Aviram tried to cause similar disunity and turmoil among Bnei Yisrael.

1 In a book review published in the Hebrew newspaper Ha'Olam 40 (September 24th, 1926), p. 750; for a clearer reprint of the relevant passage, see Yoel Elitzur, ''Hadut' - 'Dut'. A Damaged Word or Variant Original Versions?' (in Hebrew), Lĕšonénu 48/49 (5785/1985), p. 139. And see further this note by Elitzur.

2 Several other members of Bnei Yisrael appear to be named after toponyms in Eretz Yisrael, e.g. Gilad ben Machir; Machir himself might be named after the sale and Gilad might be named after the place where the Yishmaelim came from (see here); Chevron the Levite (Shemot 6:18); Shimron ben Yissachar (for the toponym, see e.g. here), and so forth.

title: Saying usually unacceptable things during an emotionally dramatic/cathartic moment?
content:
# Saying usually unacceptable things during an emotionally dramatic/cathartic moment? ## Frage

I know that (obviously) things like swearing, taking Hashem's name in vain and saying a lashon hara is forbidden, but what is the Talmud's opinion about doing so during a moment when you are a complete emotional mess, especially if these things happen alone or in front of one party when you're trying to explain your opinion to them and you don't have a filter on your speech. I know it would be ideal not to need a filter in order to not swear or say lashon hara, but this also seems to contradict the Talmudic opinion that you shouldn't stop students while they study the Talmud and have differing opinions if they are getting mad at each other and cross social boundaries such as politeness. (I tried to find the source for this in the Talmud, but could not, so if anyone knows that please tell me. My rebbe said this was in the Talmud, so I'm pretty sure it's in there.) I am wondering if this is extended to things like what I mentioned.

So my question is: Is it okay to lashon hara, swear, or say Hashem's name in vain when you are in an "emotional purge" state, (or a catharsis) namely while you are alone or with a party not involved in the matter?

As always, thank you! <3
