title: seeming contradiction in mishnah berurah
content:
# seeming contradiction in mishnah berurah ## Frage

In Mishnah Berurah 63:12, he writes that if one did not say Baruch Shem k'vod Malchuso L'olam vo'ed with application he is required to read Shema again, this time with application. But in Mishnah Berurah 61:29, he writes, "If one did not say this (he's talking about Baruch Shem k'vod Malchuso l'olam vo'ed), there are conflicting opinions among the Poskim as to whether or not he must be made to go back and say it." Then he cites the Beyur Halacha where he brings proof that once it is after the event one need not repeat krias Shema if he did not say it. There seems to be a contradiction in the two Misnah Berurahs. In the first case, he says that he is required to read Shema again if he didn't say Baruch Shem with kavanah, but in the second case he says that even if he omitted Baruch Shem altogether, he wouldn't have to repeat krias shema. What is the explanation of this?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

ערוך השולחן, אורח חיים ס״א ו׃

ודע שיש מי שכתב בלשון זה: אם לא אמר "ברוך שם כבוד מלכותו לעולם ועד" – אין מחזירין אותו (ב"ח שלטי גיבורים). ולבוש כתב שאפילו אמרו, ולא אמרו בכוונה – צריך לחזור. עד כאן לשונו (מגן אברהם סעיף קטן י"א). ולי נראה דלא פליגי כלל. דוודאי אם לא אמרו והתחיל פרשת "ואהבת" – אין מחזירין אותו, כיון שלא הוזכרה בתורה. ואף אם ירצה לאומרה בין פרק לפרק – אין לה שייכות שם כמובן. והלבוש אומר שאם אמרה ולא אמרה בכוונה, ועדיין לא התחיל "ואהבת" – צריך לחזור עוד פעם לאמר בכוונה. וכן נראה לי עיקר לדינא. (ולפלא שלא מצאתי זה בלבוש כלל, עיין שם.)

And know that there are those who have written in this manner: if one did not say "Blessed be the name of the glory of His kingdom forever and ever", he is not required to repeat [the recitation] (Beit Yosef quoting Shiltei Gibborim). And the Levush wrote that even if one did say it, but did not say it with intention, he must repeat it. Thus is his wording (Magen Avraham s'k 11). And it appears to me that there is no dispute at all between them. For certainly, if one did not say it and has already begun the paragraph of "Ve'ahavta", he is not required to go back, since this phrase is not mentioned in the Torah. And even if he wishes to say it between the paragraphs, it does not belong there, as is evident. And the Levush is stating that if one said it but without intention, and has not yet begun "Ve'ahavta", he must go back and say it again with proper intention. And so it appears to me to be the correct halachic ruling. (And it is surprising that I did not find this in the Levush at all – see there.)

See the Biur Halacha in 61 for more detail.

Basically:

  • if you are before Ve'ahavta, and you said it without kavana, repeat (some say also repeat the Shema line). It's relevant to kabbalat ol.
  • if you are after Ve'ahavta, even if you didn't say it at all, don't go back as it's a later addition and not de'oraita - yotze bedi'eved (some say just say it wherever you are when you remember, other say this is incorrect).

Therefore it's not actually a stira, it's 2 different cases and each follows its own principle (in bold).

title: Goy planted trees for Yid without permission Erev Shabboss Bain Hashmoshois
content:
# Goy planted trees for Yid without permission Erev Shabboss Bain Hashmoshois ## Frage

We ordered three trees to be planted in our front garden. (The gardener ordered them for us). One tree arrived on Tuesday when we were out : postman left it by the side of our front door, as he does with our parcels. Gardener said the other two would come Thursday - they didn't. He messaged he would come Friday midday to plant. And the other trees delivery was now said to arrive Friday. At 3pm he arrived and asked for that tree. Other two still hadn't come. He said delivery would be later. We told him clearly twice that it's late, he must stop work at 15:45 because it's Shabboss. He works for all of the Jewish neighbours for many years and he said , "Yes yes I know." I took out the dustbin at 15: 44 and he was gone and that one tree was planted. When the men left to Shul a few minutes later, by the zeman, all was the same-gardener had gone and that one tree was planted. But when the men came home from shul later, two new trees had been planted. Three neighbours said they saw the gardener planting them. Please advise.

title: Tekhelet hidden on purpose
content:
# Tekhelet hidden on purpose ## Frage

I was recently told by someone that the sages hid the tekhelet on purpose because it was expensive and thus differentiated between poorer and richer Jews.

Are there any sources that back this claim?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

I have not found any sources that state that the sages hid the techelet because of its costliness. Whoever told you this may have misinterpreted a common historical explanation for the midrashim that state that the techelet was "hidden" (נגנז),1 which is that over time, especially due to the economic machinations of the Byzantine Empire, making techelet became more difficult and buying it became more expensive, and so gradually less and less people used it,2 until it disappeared from usage altogether. See for example Ephraim S. Ayil, 'Philological Insights on Tekheleth', Hakirah 37 (2025), pp. 296-301. A different, more spiritual explanation was suggested by Rabbi Yisrael Krauss, 'When was the Techelet Hidden and Why?' (in Hebrew), Vehaya Lachem Letzitzit 12 (5778/2018), pp. 83-87, though it does not contradict the natural processes that led to the gradual disappearance of the techelet (see pp. 85-86).

1 See: Tanchuma (Buber) Shelach 29:1; Tanchuma Shelach 15:1; Bamidbar Rabbah 17:5, and thought to perhaps be hinted at in Bavli Bava Batra 74b and Sifri Devarim 354:7.

2 Mordechai Kirshenbaum, 'Seventy Five Years to the Renewal of the Techelet' (in Hebrew), Sinai 53 (5723/1963), p. 161 wrote as much (can be found on Otzar Hachochmah):

"מכאן, שאין כוונת המדרש שנגנזה התכלת ושלא נמצאה כלל, אלא לפי שלא היתה מצויה אצל כלל ישראל בשל יוקרה הרב, ואף קשה היה להשיג אומן בקי ומומחה במלאכת הצביעה, על כן משתמש המדרש בלשון "נגנז", כלומר: נשתכח (ראה רש"י פסחים סב, ב: "נגנז - נשתכח"). אבל באמת היה החלזון מצוי, אלא שיכלו להשיגו יחידי סגולה בלבד ובייחוד העשירים והמקורבים למלכות."

"Therefore, it must be said that the midrash did not mean that the techelet was hidden away and could not be found at all, but rather since it was not found by all of Israel because of its great cost, and since it was also difficult to find an expert craftsman knowledgeable in the art of the dyeing, therefore the midrash used the phrasing "hidden", meaning: forgotten (see Rashi on Pesachim 62b: "Hidden - [means] forgotten"). But in actuality the snail was found, but only special people could get it, and especially rich men and those close to the royal court."

title: Does Hebrew really have 7 words for gold?
content:
# Does Hebrew really have 7 words for gold? ## Frage

St. Jerome, Letter 64 to Principia (Scheck 🇬🇧 transl., Exegetical Epistles vol. 1 pp. 268-98)—when commenting on Ps. 44:10 ("The queen stood on thy right hand, in gilded clothing")—claims:

there are seven words for gold in Hebrew.
Septem quippe apud Hebraeos auri vocabula sunt.

I thought Hebrew had very few words overall, so I was surprised to hear St. Jerome claim that Hebrew has 7 words for gold. Is that true? If so, what are they?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 12)

Refer to the Gemoro in Yoma 44b which writes expressly that there are 7 different expressions of gold:

אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: שִׁבְעָה זְהָבִים הֵן: זָהָב, וְזָהָב טוֹב, וּזְהַב אוֹפִיר, וְזָהָב מוּפָז, וְזָהָב שָׁחוּט, וְזָהָב סָגוּר, וּזְהַב פַּרְוַיִם. זָהָב וְזָהָב טוֹב, דִּכְתִיב: ״וּזְהַב הָאָרֶץ הַהִוא טוֹב״. זְהַב אוֹפִיר — דְּאָתֵי מֵאוֹפִיר. זָהָב מוּפָז שֶׁדּוֹמֶה לְפָז. זָהָב שָׁחוּט — שֶׁנִּטְוֶה כְּחוּט. זָהָב סָגוּר — בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁנִּפְתָּח כָּל הַחֲנוּיוֹת נִסְגָּרוֹת. זְהַב פַּרְוַיִם — שֶׁדּוֹמֶה לְדַם הַפָּרִים

Rav Ḥisda said: There are seven types of gold mentioned in the Bible: Gold, and good gold, and gold of Ophir (I Kings 10:11), and glistering gold (I Kings 10:18), and shaḥut gold (I Kings 10:17), and closed gold (I Kings 10:21), and parvayim gold (II Chronicles 3:6). The Gemara explains the reason for these names: There is a distinction between gold and good gold, as it is written in the verse: “And the gold of that land is good” (Genesis 2:12), which indicates the existence of gold of a higher quality. Gold of Ophir is gold that comes from Ophir. Glistering [mufaz] gold is so named because it resembles the luster of pearls [paz] in the way it glistens. Shaḥut gold is named as such because it is very malleable and is spun like thread [shenitve keḥut]. Shaḥut is a contraction of the words shenitve keḥut. Closed gold is so called because when a shop opens to sell it, all the other shops close, as no one is interested in purchasing any other type of gold. Parvayim gold is so called because its redness resembles the blood of bulls [parim].

Let's explore this further...

  1. "זהב" the most common. For example, it says about the Aron Kodesh (holy ark) - Shemos 21:11

וְצִפִּיתָ֤ אֹתוֹ֙ זָהָ֣ב טָה֔וֹר מִבַּ֥יִת וּמִח֖וּץ תְּצַפֶּ֑נּוּ וְעָשִׂ֧יתָ עָלָ֛יו זֵ֥ר זָהָ֖ב סָבִֽיב

Overlay it with pure gold—overlay it inside and out—and make upon it a gold molding round about.

  1. "סגור" - refined gold. For example, refer to I Melachim 6:20:

וְלִפְנֵ֣י הַדְּבִ֡יר עֶשְׂרִים֩ אַמָּ֨ה אֹ֜רֶךְ וְעֶשְׂרִ֧ים אַמָּ֣ה רֹ֗חַב וְעֶשְׂרִ֤ים אַמָּה֙ קֽוֹמָת֔וֹ וַיְצַפֵּ֖הוּ זָהָ֣ב סָג֑וּר וַיְצַ֥ף מִזְבֵּ֖חַ אָֽרֶז

The interior of the Shrine was 20 cubits long, 20 cubits wide, and 20 cubits high. He overlaid it with solid gold; he similarly overlaid [its] cedar altar.

Rashi there explains:

זָהָב סָגוּר. פֵּרְשׁוּ בּוֹ רַבּוֹתֵינוּ: בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁנִּפְתָּח לִמָּכֵר, כָּל חֲנֻיּוֹת אֲחֵרוֹת נִסְגָּרוֹת. וְיוֹנָתָן תִּרְגֵּם: דְּהָב טָב, רוֹצֶה לוֹמַר: מִי שֶׁיֵּשׁ לוֹ מִמֶּנּוּ, סוֹגְרוֹ לְעַצְמוֹ.

Refined gold. Our Rabbis explained this [סגור], that at the time [this type of gold] was offered for sale, all other stores were closed [=נסגרות]. But [Targum] Yonoson rendered this as “good gold,” i.e., he who possesses this gold “locks” it [סוגרו] for himself.

  1. "פז" - fine gold For example Tehillim 19:11

הַֽנֶּחֱמָדִ֗ים מִ֭זָּהָב וּמִפַּ֣ז רָ֑ב וּמְתוּקִ֥ים מִ֝דְּבַ֗שׁ וְנֹ֣פֶת צוּפִֽים

More desirable than gold, than much fine gold; sweeter than honey, than drippings of the comb.

Radak there explains:

ומפז הוא הזהב הטוב הנקי וזהו

Fine gold – that is, the good and purified gold; and this is it

  1. "בצר" - Gold or silver ore a more generic term for riches For example Iyov 22:24:

וְשִׁית־עַל־עָפָ֥ר בָּ֑צֶר וּכְצ֖וּר נְחָלִ֣ים אוֹפִֽיר

If you regard treasure as dirt,Ophir-gold as stones of the wadi

Ralbag there says straight out that it is gold, whereas Ibn Ezra likens it to silver.

  1. "כתם" - For example Eicha 4:1:

אֵיכָה֙ יוּעַ֣ם זָהָ֔ב יִשְׁנֶ֖א הַכֶּ֣תֶם הַטּ֑וֹב תִּשְׁתַּפֵּ֙כְנָה֙ אַבְנֵי־קֹ֔דֶשׁ בְּרֹ֖אשׁ כׇּל־חוּצֽוֹת

Alas! The gold is dulled, Debased the finest gold! The sacred gems are spilled At every street corner.

Rashi there explains; A collection of beautiful gold articles used as ornaments is called כֶּתֶם.

  1. "חרוץ" - a brilliant, fine gold.

For example Mishlei 16:16:

קְֽנֹה־חָכְמָ֗ה מַה־טּ֥וֹב מֵחָר֑וּץ וּקְנ֥וֹת בִּ֝ינָ֗ה נִבְחָ֥ר מִכָּֽסֶף

How much better to acquire wisdom than gold; To acquire understanding is preferable to silver.

For a bit more background on this type of gold, note the verse in Tehillim 68:14:

אִֽם־תִּשְׁכְּבוּן֮ בֵּ֤ין שְׁפַ֫תָּ֥יִם כַּנְפֵ֣י י֭וֹנָה נֶחְפָּ֣ה בַכֶּ֑סֶף וְ֝אֶבְרוֹתֶ֗יהָ בִּירַקְרַ֥ק חָרֽוּץ

Even for those of you who lie among the sheepfolds there are wings of a dove sheathed in silver, its pinions in fine gold.”

Rashi there writes:

בִּירַקְרַק חָרוּץ. פָּתַר דּוּנָשׁ בֶּן לַבְרַט: הֶחָרוּץ הוּא זָהָב, וְלָכָךְ נְתָנוֹ הַמְשׁוֹרֵר אֵצֶל הַכֶּסֶף, וִירַקְרַק הֶחָרוּץ הוּא הַזָּהָב אֲשֶׁר יוּבָא מֵאֶרֶץ הַחֲוִילָה וּמֵאֶרֶץ כּוּשׁ, זָהָב טוֹב מְאֹד מְאֹד (בראשית ב:יא-יג; איוב כח:יט). לֹא הוּא יָרוֹק וְלֹא הוּא אָדוֹם, וְלָכָךְ קְרָאוֹ יְרַקְרַק; כְּמוֹ ״לָבָן אֲדַמְדָּם״ (ויקרא יג:מב) – שֶׁאֵינוֹ לֹא לָבָן וְלֹא אָדוֹם. לְכָךְ נִכְפַּל: יְרַקְרַק, אֲדַמְדָּם

With brilliant gold Heb. בירקרק חרוץ. Dunash the son of Labrat interpreted חרוּץ as gold. Therefore, the Psalmist juxtaposed it to silver, and ירקרק חרוץ is the gold brought from the land of Havilah and from the land of Cush; very good gold, neither yellow nor red. Therefore, it is called ירקרק, as (Lev. 13:42): “reddish white (לבן אדמדם),” which is neither white nor red. Therefore, it is doubled: אדמדם, ירקרק.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 4)

Six words are listed in the Jewish Encyclopedia entry for Gold: זהב, פז, בצר, סגור, כתם, חרוץ (Zahav, Paz, Betzer, Segor, Ketem, Charutz). As @ba pointed out, Jerome considers the seventh to be אופיר (Ophir) (see e.g. Vulgate Psalms 44:10, compare Hebrew).

### Antwort 3 (Score: 1)
  1. זהב – Zahav (Most Common)
  2. פָּז – Paz (9 times across the Tanach)
  3. כֶּתֶם – Ketem (9 times across the Tanach)
  4. בֶּצֶר – Betzer (e.g. Job 22:24, see also Job 22:25, 36:19)
  5. חרוץ – Harutz (e.g. Psalms 68:14, Tosafot to Nedarim 32a, Proverbs 8:10)
  6. סְגוֹר – Segor (e.g. Job 28:15)
  7. דְּהַב - Dehav (Aramaic form of זהב, appears across Daniel and Ezra)

Sources:

https://ohr.edu/8859

https://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/6737-gold

title: Does God possess a bodily form?
content:
# Does God possess a bodily form? ## Frage

God is described in the Tanakh as being seated on a glorious throne in the highest heaven. He is elsewhere described in the Tanakh as having a face, hands, feet, a mouth, eyes, a nose, hair, etc.

No man can see God and live, although angelic beings can see God and live, as their nature consists of the same immortal composition as God.

So does God possess a bodily form?

title: Should one despair of a potential terrible situation?
content:
# Should one despair of a potential terrible situation? ## Frage

In bGittin 57b the Talmud relates the following tragic story (translation from Sefaria)

אמר רב יהודה אמר שמואל, ואיתימא רבי אמי, ואמרי לה במתניתא תנא: מעשה בארבע מאות ילדים וילדות שנשבו לקלון, הרגישו בעצמן למה הן מתבקשים, אמרו: אם אנו טובעין בים – אנו באין לחיי העולם הבא? דרש להן הגדול שבהן: ״אמר ה׳ מבשן אשיב, אשיב ממצולות ים״ – ״מבשן אשיב״, מבין שיני אריה; ״אשיב ממצולות ים״, אלו שטובעין בים.
Rav Yehuda says that Shmuel says, and some say that it was Rabbi Ami who says this, and some say that it was taught in a baraita: There was an incident involving four hundred boys and girls who were taken as captives for the purpose of prostitution. These children sensed on their own what they were expected to do, and they said: If we commit suicide and drown in the sea, will we come to eternal life in the World-to-Come? The oldest child among them expounded the verse: “The Lord said, I will bring back from Bashan, I will bring them back from the depths of the sea” (Psalms 68:23). “I will bring back from Bashan,” i.e., from between the teeth [bein shen] of the lion, and “I will bring them back from the depths of the sea” is referring to those who drown in the sea for the sake of Heaven.
כיון ששמעו ילדות כך, קפצו כולן ונפלו לתוך הים. נשאו ילדים קל וחומר בעצמן, ואמרו: מה הללו, שדרכן לכך – כך; אנו, שאין דרכנו לכך – על אחת כמה וכמה! אף הם קפצו לתוך הים.״.
When the girls heard this, they all leapt and fell into the sea. The boys then drew an a fortiori inference with regard to themselves and said: If these girls, for whom sexual intercourse with men is their natural way, act in such a manner, then we, for whom sexual intercourse with men is not our natural way, should all the more so conduct ourselves likewise. They too leapt into the sea

The implication of this story is that this behavior was appropriate, however there is a principle mentioned in bBerachot 10a that a person should not despair of a potential terrible event

אפילו חרב חדה מונחת על צוארו של אדם, אל ימנע עצמו מן הרחמים.
Even if a sharp sword rests upon a person’s neck, he should not prevent himself from praying for mercy.

title: Polytheistic roots of Judaism
content:
# Polytheistic roots of Judaism ## Frage

I am very interested in understanding the historical roots of the God that is universally worshipped today, the one revered by billions across Christianity, Judaism, and Islam. It is understood that idol worship was widespread in ancient Israel. Is the scholarly view correct that one of these earlier deities (or 'idols') was somehow elevated to become the sole God worshipped by much of the world today?

If so, is it true that other deities, such as Baal (the storm god), were subsequently demoted? In essence, is the religion based on the narrative of how one deity became HaShem?

Furthermore, I've noted a possible connection between the word Asher (attributed to HaShem) and the goddess Asherah, who was also worshipped. Could you please shed light on these topics and explain the process of how exactly this transformation happened?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

Since you asked this on the Judaism SE, I will give a Judaism-based answer. As already noted in the comments, Judaism does not hold that belief in God began with idolatry but the other way around. First there came God who created the universe (and all of reality), as per the first two chapters of Genesis (and mentioned elsewhere in Tanach as well). Then there came the first humans who worshipped God. Some generations later, idolatry began as a perversion of the original belief in God. This process was summarized well by Maimonides in Laws of Foreign Worship and Customs of the Nations 1:1-2:

"During the times of Enosh, mankind made a great mistake, and the wise men of that generation gave thoughtless counsel. Enosh himself was one of those who erred.
Their mistake was as follows: They said God created stars and spheres with which to control the world. He placed them on high and treated them with honor, making them servants who minister before Him. Accordingly, it is fitting to praise and glorify them and to treat them with honor. [They perceived] this to be the will of God, blessed be He, that they magnify and honor those whom He magnified and honored, just as a king desires that the servants who stand before him be honored. Indeed, doing so is an expression of honor to the king.
After conceiving of this notion, they began to construct temples to the stars and offer sacrifices to them. They would praise and glorify them with words, and prostrate themselves before them, because by doing so, they would - according to their false conception - be fulfilling the will of God. This was the essence of the worship of false gods, and this was the rationale of those who worshiped them. They would not say that there is no other god except for this star. [...]

After many years passed, there arose people - false prophets - who told [their nations] that God had commanded them to say: Serve this star - or all the stars - sacrifice to it, offer libations to it, build a temple for it and make an image of it so that all people - including the women, the children, and the common people - could bow to it. [...] In this manner, the people began to make images in temples, under trees, and on the tops of mountains and hills. [...]
Subsequently, other deceivers arose and declared that a specific star, sphere, or angel had spoken to them and commanded them: Serve me in this manner. He would then relate a mode of service [telling them:] Do this, do not do this. Thus, these practices spread throughout the world. People would serve images with strange practices - one more distorted than the other - offer sacrifices to them, and bow down to them. As the years passed, [God's] glorious and awesome name was forgotten by the entire population. [...] The Eternal Rock (a title for God) was not recognized or known by anyone in the world, with the exception of a [few] individuals: for example, Chanoch, Metushelach, Noach, Shem, and Ever. The world continued in this fashion until the pillar of the world - the Patriarch Abraham - was born."

Maimonides does not clarify how idolatry began again after the flood, given that Noah was a righteous, God-fearing man and presumably directed his three sons to follow in his footsteps. The resurgence of idolatry in the post-deluvian world was discussed by Rabbi Chananyah Elchanan Chai Hakohen in his book Bamot Ba'al on the history of idolatry (from a Jewish perspective, of course) (my translation):

"[...] Sin couches at the door and the evil inclination leads others astray and causes them to sin, and it awakens the hearts of men to leave the straight path and to trip them during every generation [...] and immediately upon exiting the Ark, the inclination turned their hearts to this foolishness and to destroy their path [...] for already Ham son of Noah was known around as the man who revealed his father's nakedness and he cohabited in the Ark [...] and undoubtedly he was the first to be guilty of this as well. And as evidence of this we find in books of mythology that the nation most greatly awash in the vice of idolatry after the spreading out of the nations was the land of Egypt [...] and undoubtedly after the flood its masters were strengthened in their conviction, after seeing that the sun intensified after the flood more than it had been before, as stated by Rabbi Shem Tov ben Shem Tov."1

This indicates that post-deluvian idolatry first began with sun worship, which led to the worship of other planets and stars, and that led to the worship of all other false deities. Some of these perversions, as indicated by both Tanach, later Jewish sources and archeology, included mixing forms of the worship of the One True God with idolatrous notions. For example, the golden calf in the wilderness and later the two golden calves in the Kingdom of Israel (the so-called "Northern Kingdom"), or the "Y. and (his?) Asherah" found in a couple of sites. Neither reflect the original form of worship of God. They are mutilations of the original modes of worship.

The scholarly argument is highly speculative. It is based on several assumptions, one being that monotheism developed from earlier more primitive religions, e.g. Animism. There is no concrete evidence for this. Another is that archeological findings represent the everything and all (never mind that archeology isn't a hard science [I typically avoid calling it a science at all] and that archeological conclusions are disproven fairly often, as new sites are excavated, new artifacts uncovered and new studies produced. I say this as an archeology doctoral student, who has also worked in the field a bit). A third assumption is that Tanach is solely the work of a significantly later very specific sect of priests and/or affiliated individuals who were essentially part of a conspiracy to hide the supposed polytheistic origins of the faith of Israel, but were pretty incompetent at it (given that modern scholars have been able to "rediscover" these so-called origins). Once again, none of these theories have any actual hard evidence.

So, in essence, Judaism is not about one deity becoming "The Deity", because He Was and Is and Will Always Be the One God. It is about people who stay true to the One God and do their part in fixing the world - one of its main problems being people who have been led astray from the path of the One God and must be guided back.

1 According to Rabbi Avraham Ibn Ezra (Genesis 9:14), the appearance of the rainbow only after the flood, despite being a natural occurrence, should be understood as an after-effect of the sun becoming stronger after the flood. The gist of this idea, according to Rabbi Chananyah, is that while all forces of nature were essentially rebooted during the flood, the sun was the only body to not be rebooted but rather to receive an upgrade. This led Ham and his sons to conclude that the sun was a mighty entity that should be worshipped.

title: What was the origin or background of the Witch of Endor? Why did Saul + company eat?
content:
# What was the origin or background of the Witch of Endor? Why did Saul + company eat? ## Frage

What is the origin or background of the Witch of Ein Dor (1 Shmuel chapter 28)? There is no explicit mention of her origin. However, Joshua 17:11 mentions Ein Dor as one of the Canaanite towns that the tribe of Menashe "could not dispossess" (next pasuk).

A reason to suspect that she may be Jewish was that she sacrificed and prepared meat (and bread) for them to eat, and they ate (1 Shmuel 24-25). For the Israelites necromancy is explicitly forbidden in the Torah, but there is no shortage of incidences in Nach where the Jews went astray and worshipped idols. However, the halacha of who performs slaughter may certainly have been different in those times.

Was the witch of Ein Dor an Israelite? In view of what her origin was, do mefarshim discuss the episode of the witch slaughtering the cow and preparing it for them to eat with bread?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Yalkut Shimoni (Nach 140) identifies her as Tzefaniah, the mother of Avner, which would make her Jewish.

Necromancy and other forms of magic have historically been used to inveigle people into idolatry (see Rambam, Hil. Avodah Zarah 11:16), but in and of themselves they're really no different than most other aveiros for which one is liable to kares or the death penalty. Just as a person who commits adultery or eats cheilev isn't thereby precluded from shechitah, neither is a magician.

(In fact, some poskim permit using otherwise forbidden forms of sorcery when lives are at stake - see Shach, Yoreh De'ah 179:1. That certainly wouldn't be the case if they were considered actual idolatry.)

title: Adversarial Chavruta Style - applies to Chassidut?
content:
# Adversarial Chavruta Style - applies to Chassidut? ## Frage

I like to learn Chassidut. Chassidut is based heavily on Kabbalah, and therefore it most likely falls under a "bashamayim hi" lomdus. See this question: Does 'not in heaven' apply to kabbalah?

This means there's not really the idea of pilpul, etc. Kabbalah is "received" as-is, and it's only our job to learn it and understand it. We don't argue it and innovate with it.

Does that mean that one should seek a different type of Chavruta when learning Kabbalah? I've noticed something when I learn Chassidut with two people, my best friend and my wife. Both of them, are "on my side"; they love me, and they don't feel the slightest drop of competitiveness or disrespect with me, and visa versa - there's no jealousy at all when one of us figures something out that the other missed. We just celebrate each other's achievement and are glad to understand things better.

Unlike when I learn Gemara, I find that this method of learning Chassidut is GREAT. I absorb and understand my learning literally 10-100 times better when going through it with them.

I just want to know, is there an official source that actually says that when it comes to learning Chassidut b'chavruta, one should do so in a non-adversarial approach? Does it have more tips about how a "chavruta" should look?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

See the Rebbe's Ma'amer Padah B'Shalom 5741 where he addresses this exact idea with regards to the differences between learning the revealed parts of Torah and the hidden parts of Torah.

Quoting a small piece:

ג) והנה בהבירור דתורה יש חילוק בין הבירור שע"י גליא דתורה להבירור שע"י פנימיות התורה21. דבהבירור שע"י לימוד גליא דתורה צריך להיות הלימוד בענינים אלו שצריכים לבררם, ומהטעמים על זה שהתורה נתלבשה בדברים גשמיים וגם בדברים האסורים ועד לטענות של שקר22, הוא, בכדי לפעול הבירור גם בענינים אלו23. וזה שגם הבירור שע"י גליא דתורה נק' בשם בירור בדרך מנוחה24 הוא מפני שגם ענינים אלו (דברים האסורים וגם טענות של שקר) כמו שהם בתורה25, הם תורה, תורת אמת, ומכיון שגם דברים אלה שבתורה הם דבר ה'26, הלא כה דברי כאש27 מה אש כו' אף דברי תורה אינן מקבלין טומאה28, הרי שהתורה היא תמיד במקומה ומדריגתה (דבר ה'), והבירור הוא בדרך ממילא. אלא שאעפ"כ אין זה דומה להבירור שע"י פנימיות התורה, דבהבירור שע"י גליא דתורה הרי זה גופא שהתורה מדברת בנוגע לדברים גשמיים וכו', הרי זה ענין של ירידה29 כביכול, אלא שגם לאחרי ירידתה והמשכתה למטה היא תורה, דבר ה' (ולא שיורדת ומתלבשת בענין אחר). משא"כ הבירור שע"י פנימיות התורה, מכיון שפנימיות התורה היא אילנא דחיי (שאינה מלובשת בטו"ר)30, הרי הבירור שנעשה עי"ז הוא שלא בדרך התלבשות כלל.

title: What's the connection between Avraham & Eliezer / Yaakov & Yosef?
content:
# What's the connection between Avraham & Eliezer / Yaakov & Yosef? ## Frage
  • Avraham and Eliezer – Bereishis 24:2 “...שִׂים נָא יָדְךָ תַּחַת יְרֵכִי” Avraham makes Eliezer swear to find a wife for Yitzchak—not from the Canaanites.
  • Yaakov and Yosef – Bereishis 47:29 “...שִׂים נָא יָדְךָ תַּחַת יְרֵכִי” Yaakov makes Yosef swear not to bury him in Egypt, but in Eretz Yisrael.

In both, someone is made to swear. Why? What do the two situations have in common that warrants an oath?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: -1)

It is essential to comprehend the role and significance of oaths within Judaism in order to address this question with scholarly completeness. According to the Aderet Eliyahu (Rabbi Yosef Chaim), an oath may be construed as a form of spiritual "binding" or "commitment" that imparts an additional stratum of accountability and gravity to an individual's actions. One might therefore posit that in both instances under consideration, an oath was administered so as to underscore the solemnity and importance of the respective undertaking. Both the selection of a wife for Isaac and the burial of Jacob in Canaan constituted tasks of paramount significance and spiritual importance, necessitating such supplementary binding. Furthermore, one might draw attention to the symbolism inherent in these oaths, both of which pertain to the connection with the land of Canaan. This could suggest that the oaths likewise represent an emphasis upon the significance of the Land of Israel within Judaism. The question presents an analysis of two situations in which an oath was administered. The oath appears to constitute a significant component of the interaction between the characters and raises questions concerning the meaning and purpose of the oath. The halakhic principles in this matter concern the use and significance of oaths in the Torah. Oaths are frequently employed in the Torah to reinforce obligations or to emphasize the gravity of a statement or promise. In Genesis 24:2, Abraham causes Eliezer to swear an oath to ensure that he does not procure a wife for Isaac from among the Canaanites. In Genesis 47:29, Jacob causes Joseph to swear an oath to ensure that he is buried in the Land of Israel rather than in Egypt. In the Gemara (Nedarim 2a), there is discussion of how oaths may be taken and annulled. In the Gemara (Shevuot 36b), it is explained that it is forbidden to take an oath unnecessarily. The Rishonim and Acharonim discuss the use of oaths in various contexts. The Rambam (Hilkhot Shevuot 2:1) explicates that an oath serves to confirm the veracity of a statement or to obligate a person to perform an action. A potential objection might be that oaths in the Torah are not invariably employed in an identical manner, and that the specific contexts of the two aforementioned cases might highlight different aspects of the use of oaths. The majority opinion appears to be that oaths in the Torah serve to obligate a person to perform an action or to emphasize the gravity of a statement. A minority opinion might propose that oaths in the Torah may also possess symbolic or ritual functions that transcend their juridical function. It is important to distinguish between different types of oaths in the Torah and their various functions and meanings in different contexts. Upon weighing the arguments, it appears that oaths in the Torah serve to obligate a person to perform an action or to emphasize the gravity of a statement. This appears to hold true in both of the aforementioned cases. It is observed that the common denominator between the two situations under discussion lies in the employment of the oath. This functions as a means of emphasizing the significance of the obligation and underscoring the gravity of the respective situation. In the Talmud, the significance of the oath and its function as an emphasis upon the binding nature and gravity of an obligation is highlighted (Shevuot 36b). An oath serves not merely to confirm the veracity of a statement, but also to emphasize the gravity of a situation or task. The gravity of the oath is made manifest in Judaism by the fact that the abuse of an oath is regarded as a most serious transgression. From this one may deduce that the significance of the oath in Jewish ethics and Jewish law ought not to be underestimated.

title: Avimelech & Pichol name significance
content:
# Avimelech & Pichol name significance ## Frage

Continuing the idea of looking for Biblical name significance, like Lot name significance and Efron name significance, what is the name significance of Avimelech and Pichol which are found both in Parshat Toldot and Parshat Vayera?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Avimelech is a combination of two words : "Avi" "Melech". it means "Father" "King" (in the Hebrew).

It is obviously a generic title for a king.

Pichol is a combination of two words : "Pi" "col". it means "Mouth" "Everything" (in the Hebrew).

It is the title of a commanding officer of the military describing that by his mouth is everything commanded.

(The modern equivalent is English "General Officer". Lower officers command their specific pool of authority. "Generals" command everything "in general".)

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

According to Hebrew and Aramaic Lexicon of the Old Testament (HALOT) by Koeler and Baumgartner, the title can be found in the Tell el-Amarna Tablets as Abimilki. R. H. Guggenheimer in his Torah peirush suggests that the Pelishtim adopted the ruling titles from Canaanim. He says that in the days of Avraham the people who lived in Gerar were Canaanim, and in the days of Yitzchak they became Pelishtim. The full quote can be found here. So Avimelekh is both father of the nation and king as suggested by @DavidKenner.

Regarding the name Pichol, its translation into Septuagint is Φικολ and Φικολος. Based on Jastrow dictionary, the entry אפיקולוס - Afikolos found in Tosefta Chulin 8:1, suggests looking in the entry for אבקולס - Eucolus, (father of R. Zechariah in the story of Kamtza and bar Kamtza, Git. 56a). In Greek, the name Εὔκολος is read Efkolos and it means easily satisfied, contented; easy based on the Logeion at the University Of Chicago.

A similar name in the Mediterranean region also existed in Ancient Italy, Fico, as described on What the Name,

is derived from the Latin word “ficus,” which means “fig tree.” In ancient Rome, the fig tree was a symbol of peace and prosperity.

Other sites suggest Spanish origin of the name (same etymology).

Alternatively, based on etymology on line, the italian noun piccolo (small) can be traced to Vulgar Latin root pikk- (little) related to piccare (to pierce) (see pike (n.1)).

title: From where does Chazal learn that "yeiush" determines whether a lost object is still the property of the one who lost it?
content:
# From where does Chazal learn that "yeiush" determines whether a lost object is still the property of the one who lost it? ## Frage

I'm learning Bava Metzia 21b, and it seems to be a foregone conclusion amongst the amoraim that יאוש ("yeiush") determines whether a person who lost an object still owns it or not.

Usually I'd expect a מניין (from where do we know) question on this, as yeiush is not mentioned in the mishnayos. However, none appears.

The question is brought up and "answered" in the Yerushalmi (https://www.sefaria.org/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Metzia.2.1?lang=bi) as a drasha from Devarim 22:3, though I don't really understand how their drasha answers their question.

It seems almost arbitrary that Chazal decided that the mental state of the original owner would determine would or not the object is still owned by him. I might have thought that the objective reality of the situation would determine whether an object is considered to still belong to a person and hence require its return or an object is considered to be ownerless. Although this seems somewhat similar in practical application to Rava's opinion that an object is considered ownerless even before yeiush if we know that upon realizing that the object was lost the owner will have yeiush, Rava still clearly subscribes to the idea that it's the mental state of the original that determines the ownership (just that the mental state can affect the ownership retrospectively).

So why do all the amoraim seem to be in agreement that yeiush is the determining factor?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

  1. You shall not see your brother's ox or sheep straying, and ignore them. [Rather,] you shall return them to your brother.

  2. But if your brother is not near you, or if you do not know him, you shall bring it into your house, and it shall be with you until your brother seeks it out, whereupon you shall return it to him.

  3. So shall you do with his donkey, and so shall you do with his garment, and so shall you do with any lost article of your brother which he has lost and you have found. You shall not ignore [it].

  • Deut. 22:1-3

Mi Yodeya : Lost Object of a Minor/Orphan

The ownership of objects in Torah Law revolve around a system explained throughout the Talmud which is called "Kinyan" or "Acquisition".

Basics of Kinyan: (General Rules)

  1. A person may not acquire ownership of an object without performing an act called a specific "Kinyan" the Torah assigned for that object.

  2. A person may not transfer the object's ownership to another person without a new "Kinyan" taking place between themselves and the new owner.

  3. If someone says they acquired an object by using a non-kinyan method ("I saw it first") it doesn't count. Likewise, if someone used the wrong method of kinyan for a certain circumstance. it also doesn't count. See Talmud Baba Metziah 2b.

  4. If an object is properly acquired by someone, it stays put in their ownership forever; unless the owner allows a new person to take it from them via a new valid kinyan act; or the owner abandons the item, making it ownerless ("Hefker").

Therefore, the OP's suggestion that a physical event be enough to declare that an object has moved out from the ownership domain of person A to that of person B or to a zone called (Hefker) "ownerless", is impossible in the Torah system. This impossibility was suggested by the OP with the term: "the objective reality of the situation".

There is no "objective reality of the situation" that can transfer ownership away from an owner. Rather, the object remains always attached to you once you own it. This is true even if an atomic bomb blew the item into the next country. It still belongs to you until a proper freewill kinyan is performed transferring the object.

Such Kinyanim (when done with intent to transfer ownership) are listed in the Talmud and sourced in the Torah. Examples: Handing an item to your friend, picking up an item high enough into the air, leading away a horse or cow, digging a hole on a piece of real estate, paying money, etc. etc.

An exception* to this rule is that of the "lost object" which can transfer out of the ownership of a person and into Hefker status if the owner gives up hope with legal free will. ("yeush")

*(Other exceptions to the pure Kinyan system are a sister in law whose husband dies childless, instantly being acquired by the surviving brother as a wife; and the money of inheritance transferring instantly from the father to the son without any freewill act of kinyan, upon the father passing away.)

The Torah recognizes that if a person realizes that reality most likely will have destroyed the item or kept it forever away from him, then he will stop wasting his time over it and allow it to become Hefker.

When does this not work? It doesn't work with children. A minor cannot "realize legally" to have "yeush" and give up on ever finding the object again. The minor therefore keeps the object wherever it is. No one can take it regardless of the "reality of the situation" because a minor cannot legally decide to give up.

See the link again from above

The Halacha of the minor proves that we are not talking about an event of reality triggering the lost object going to Hefker (or else a minor's object would also be Hefker.) Rather it depends on an adult's legal mind to abandon hope of return; albeit coupled with a difficult reality situation like a river washing away the object.

This entire secret is hinted in the extra wording of the verse we quoted at the beginning above.

...and so shall you do with any lost article of your brother which he has lost and you have found.

The bolded words seem to be extra. The first two verses clearly describe a loss and find before we get to verse #3

Which he has lost ... refers to the fact that he cannot find it.

BUT

... and you have found. means that he knows other responsible people can in fact find it so there is nothing to give up on yet!

However, if he lost it and you can also not normally find it, then it seems very lost indeed to the point that normal people now give up on finding it.

In that case the Torah allows the object to move out of the person's ownership into Hefker as a lost object the finder may keep.

The extra words in the Torah are emphasizing an attitude, not just the situation in reality. (already explained by verse 1-2)

(That is the D'rashah from the Yerushalmi mentioned by the OP.)

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

Tosfos Bava Kammah 66a ד"ה מוצא אבידה and Tosfos Bava Metziah 27a ד"ה מה שמלה, writes that the source is from the word "שמלה", the Chachamim derived that the obligation to return a lost object is only when the owner can identify his object-"Siman" and therefore is demanding- requesting its return, but if the owner gives up,and is not demanding its return, then the finder make keep the object. מה שמלה מיוחדת שיש שיש בה סימנים ויש לה תובעין

title: Why don't we say אברהם ובניו, since ישמעאל did תשובה?
content:
# Why don't we say אברהם ובניו, since ישמעאל did תשובה? ## Frage
  • At the end of Chayei Sara, when buring Avraham, the Torah writes Yitzchak before Yishmael to tell us that Yishmael did Teshuvah and understood that although he was older, since Yitzchak was a greater Tzadik - he should go first.
  • By Shabbos Mincha Shemonah Esrei, we say אברהם יגל יצחק ירנן יעקב ובניו ינוחו בו, that Avraham, Yitzchak, Yaakov and Yaakov's sons all kept Shabbos. Since Avraham had a Yishmael and Yitzchak had an Eisav, it could not be said about them that their sons also kept Shabbos. However, Yaakov had twelve sons who were צדיקים, so we say יעקב ובניו ינוחו בו.
  • If Yishmael did Teshuvah, that means that he would've kept Shabbos with Avraham, Sarah, and Yitzchok. Then, why don't we say אברהם ובניו יגל, if indeed, Yishmael did Teshuvah?
## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Indeed, Ishmael made teshuvah during the life of Avraham, so that he meritted to burry Avraham together with Yitzchak, as we find in Bereshis 25:9:

His sons Isaac and Ishmael buried him in the cave of Machpelah, in the field of Ephron son of Zohar the Hittite, facing Mamre,

Rashi notes:

ISAAC AND ISHMAEL — From this we gather that Ishmael repented of his evil ways (cf.Bava Batra 16b) and yielded the precedence to Isaac. This is what is meant by the “good old age” mentioned in connection with Abraham (Genesis Rabbah 38:12).

At the same time, after the death of Avraham, the Torah says, about Ishmael and his descendands, Bereshis 25:18:

They dwelt from Havilah, by Shur, which is close to Egypt, all the way to Asshur; they camped (literally, he fell) alongside all their kin/brothers.

There Rashi notes:

נפל (literally, he fell) means "he dwelt", as (Judges 7:12) “Now the Midianites and the Amalekites and all children of the East dwelt (נופלים) in the valley.” Here it says “He fell” and there (16:12) it says “In the presence of all his brethren shall he dwell”. But it may be explained thus: before Abraham died it could be said “He would dwell in security: after he died, “he fell” (Genesis Rabbah 62:5).

Midrash Rabba, Rashi's source, states this even harsher:

[nafal, literally, fell down], but elsewhere it says [of Ishmael]: “He will dwell [yishkon] [among all his brethren]” (Genesis 16:12). The explanation is that all the days our patriarch Abraham was alive – yishkon. When our patriarch Abraham died – nafal. Before - he did not extend his hand against the Temple – yishkon (he dwelled); once he extended his hand against it (see Psalms 83:3–19) – nafal (He fell in stature.). In this world – yishkon; but in the future – nafal.

The midrash indicates that Ishmael returned to his evil ways after the death of Avraham, which resulted in his falling in statue.

Additionally, one can learn the same idea from Rashi on Bereshis 21:17 based on Eicha Rabba 2:4:

באשר הוא שם WHERE HE IS — According to the actions he is now doing shall he be judged and not according to what he may do in future. Because the ministering angels laid information against him, saying, “Master of the Universe, for him whose descendants will at one time kill your children with thirst will You provide a well?” He asked them, “What is he now, righteous or wicked?” They replied to him, “Righteous.” He said to them, “According to his present deeds will I judge him.” This is the meaning of what is written: “[For God hath heard the voice of the lad ] באשר הוא שם in that condition in which he now is” (Genesis Rabbah 53:14). Where did he (Ishmael) kill Israel with thirst? When Nebuchadnezzar carried them into exile — as it is said, (Isaiah 21:13, 14) “The burden upon Arabia … O ye caravans of Dedanites, unto him that is thirsty bring ye water! etc.” When they were bringing them near the Arabians the Israelites said to their captors, “We beg of you bring us to the children of our uncle, Ishmael, who will certainly show pity to us”, as it is said, “O ye caravans of the Dedanites (דדנים)”; read not דדנים but דודים, kinsmen. — These indeed came to them bringing them salted meat and fish and water-skins inflated with air. The Israelites believed that these were full of water and when they placed them in their mouths, after having opened them, the air entered their bodies and they died (Eichah Rabbah 2:4).

The fact that the ministering angels referred to Ishmael himself, and not to his descendands directly, implies that the problem started with Ishmael and he had not fixed it in the last part of his life.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

A) It’s actually debated whether the Avot kept the mitzvot or not. According to several opinions, even Avraham didn’t keep Shabbat.

B) Even assuming the Avot kept the mitzvot, Yishmāʿēl wasn’t one of the Avot. He was never part of our nation, so even after repenting and becoming righteous, there was no reason for him to keep Shabbat.

title: Gid Hanashe and Kodoshim
content:
# Gid Hanashe and Kodoshim ## Frage

Related: How can there be a custom which creates Nosar?

The Rambam in Maaseh Korbonos 6(4) poskins like what appears to be the conclusion of the gemara Chulin perek Gid Hanashe Chullin 90b

Rav Huna says: The sciatic nerve of a burnt offering is not placed upon the altar with the rest of the animal. Rather, one removes it and places it on the circular mound of ashes in the center of the altar.

further on there

But since he removes it from the thigh, why does he bring it up to the altar? One cannot bring the thigh up to the altar after the sciatic nerve has been removed because it is stated with regard to one who sacrifices offerings that are damaged or unattractive: “Present it now unto your governor; will he be pleased with you, or will he accept your person? says the Lord of hosts” (Malachi 1:8)

Whoa. How long does that take? Did we just add a big chunk of time - on top of the Mizbeach - for every korbon olah? What about the שמנו של גיד and קנוקנות, peripheral m'd'rabanan parts next to the real gid hanashe - they are discussed earlier in the gemara on amud א. Maybe it would not be allowed to remove them; since they are actually meat they have an obligation to be burned as part of the meat of the korbon.

The conclusion of the gemara later Chulin 96a is that only one section of the gid hanashe is forbidden by the Torah, the part right over the cup of the thigh. Is that all the Rambam meant, even if there is more of it that isn't food? Can that be done quickly? Why not remove the rest of it, the part that isn't food if it has no obligation as meat of the olah?

Is anyone allowed on top of the mizbeach besides the Cohanim, who could help? There isn't that much room up there for menakerim while the Cohanim try to get by! If this is a (relatively) slow procedure, what did they do on Yom Tov when so many people needed to bring an olas r'iyah?

title: Does Judaism teach that Elohim made the universe in Bereishith/Genesis 1?
content:
# Does Judaism teach that Elohim made the universe in Bereishith/Genesis 1? ## Frage

To me, Bereishith 1 seems to be talking about a renovation of a preexistent world. For example, it seems there was a preexistent ocean. What Elohim was said to have done is to:

  • make a reservoir in the sky with water from the preexisting bottomless waters

  • to pull dry land out of the waters below and place it on a mysterious foundation.

Gen JPS Tanach 1917, Bereshith 1:1-9

[1]In the beginning God created the heaven and the earth. [2]Now the earth was unformed and void, and darkness was upon the face of the deep; and the spirit of God hovered over the face of the waters. … [6]And God said: ‘Let there be a firmament in the midst of the waters, and let it divide the waters from the waters.’ [7]And God made the firmament, and divided the waters which were under the firmament from the waters which were above the firmament; and it was so. [8]And God called the firmament Heaven. And there was evening and there was morning, a second day. [9]And God said: ‘Let the waters under the heaven be gathered together unto one place, and let the dry land appear.’ And it was so.

Additionally, see JPS Tanach 1917 Psalms 24:1-2.

A Psalm of David. 1The earth is the LORD’S, and the fulness thereof; The world, and they that dwell therein. 2For He hath founded it upon the seas, And established it upon the floods.

Psalms 104 states that G-d's house is on beams on the rain reservoir:

JPS 1917 Psalm 104 3–5

3Who layest the beams of Thine upper chambers in the waters, Who makest the clouds Thy chariot, Who walkest upon the wings of the wind; 4Who makest winds Thy messengers, The flaming fire Thy ministers. 5Who didst establish the earth upon its foundations, That it should not be moved for ever and ever;

Is my analysis wrong?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

No, Judaism teaches that God created the universe. See the first verse of the Bible, Bereishis 1:1 (loose translation from Chabad.org):

א: בְּרֵאשִׁ֖ית בָּרָ֣א אֱלֹהִ֑ים אֵ֥ת הַשָּׁמַ֖יִם וְאֵ֥ת הָאָֽרֶץ

1: In the beginning of God's creation of the heavens and the earth.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

The creation had already happened at this point in bereishis and Adam and Chava were the last of creations to be made and added to the earth that Gd created.

There is no reference to anything preexisting before creation as that wouldn't make any sense and here the ocean that is being referred to was just completed days ago prior to Adam.

title: Did the rebuilt Jerusalem or the Temple feature a moat?
content:
# Did the rebuilt Jerusalem or the Temple feature a moat? ## Frage

Daniel 9:25:

ותדע ותשׂכּל מן־מצא דבר להשׁיב ולבנות ירוּשׁלם עד־משׁיח נגיד שׁבעים שׁבעה ושׁבעים שׁשּׁים וּשׁנים תּשׁוּב ונבנתה רחוב וחרוּץ וּבצוק העתּים

And you shall know and understand that from the emergence of the word to restore and to rebuild Jerusalem until [the] anointed king [shall be] seven weeks, and [for] sixty-two weeks it will return and be built street and moat, but in troubled times.

Does this imply that the rebuilt City and/or Temple had a moat?

I notice that the Greek, Modern Greek and Latin version all say "wall," if that is relevant:

[Dan 9:25 Brenton English Septuagint] [25] And thou shalt know and understand, that from the going forth of the command for the answer and for the building of Jerusalem until Christ the prince [there shall be] seven weeks, and sixty-two weeks: and then [the time] shall return, and the street shall be built, and the wall, and the times shall be exhausted.

Latin (Vulgate):

[Dan 9:25 VUL] [25] Scito ergo, et animadverte: Ab exitu sermonis, ut iterum aedificetur Ierusalem, usque ad Christum ducem, hebdomades septem, et hebdomades sexaginta duae erunt: et rursum aedificabitur platea, et muri in angustia temporum.

Latin into English: Know therefore, and understand: From the going forth of the word, that Jerusalem should be built again, until Christ the Prince, there shall be seven weeks, and threescore and two weeks: and the street shall be built again, and the wall in the strait of times.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

title: Is it disrespectful to today's Jews to wear a cross and star of David necklace?
content:
# Is it disrespectful to today's Jews to wear a cross and star of David necklace? ## Frage

I am not a Jew through Jewish law, my grandfather on my dad's side was a full Jew and I am a newer Christian. I do, however, feel very connected to Judaism and I'm a strong supporter of Israel. Anyway, I was wondering if it would be disrespectful to wear a Magen David and cross necklace to show my support of Israel and Judaism? I understand how it could be seen as offensive and I have no wish to be.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

From a purely ethical standpoint there's nothing wrong with wearing the two as historically speaking the six sided star only recently "became" the Star of David. The six pointed star has existed in ancient Babylonian and Mesopotamian cultures, and was very prominently used by Muslims who would even adorn their Mosques with it and called it the Seal of Solomon. They claimed it was the symbol on Solomons ring which he used to enslave or capture demons. Which also explains why Wiccans still use this symbol for their witchcraft. The symbol has also been used in flags of countries such as Nigeria whom are not Jewish.

But the six pointed star has mostly been abandoned by other cultures and Jews have repurposed the six sided star and claimed it as a symbol of David. And so in our modern world the symbol is mostly associated with Jews and Judaism. And so when it comes to modern cultural understanding I would offer you the following question:

As a Christian, how would you feel if a Muslim wore a cross with a Crescent and Moon and told you that they are a very proud Muslim who also supports Christians.

I think you would come to the opinion that some Christians would be okay with this, but probably most wouldn't. And most wouldn't because it doesn't feel great to have someone who believes that their religion replaces yours to be wearing "your symbol" alongside their symbol which replaces yours.

What I would recommend instead is JUST to wear a star of David like the great Louis Armstrong used to do. He was Christian, and those who knew him knew he was Christian, but his support for Jews meant he would wear a star of David out of respect for Jews, and not wear a cross with it. If you would have asked Louis why he wore the star of david he would tell you about the Jewish family who helped raise him as a small child, helped him buy his first trumpet, and would show up to his shows even into adulthood. By wearing a star of david you can tell anyone, Jewish or not Jewish that you support the Jewish people, that it's part of your family history. Instead of saying you are such a big Christian that you also support Judaism

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

The Jewish star isn't a holy symbol nor is it necessarily exclusively owned by Jews. Anyone is free to use symbols as they want to. More importantly than what jewelry a person wears is understanding it would be inappropriate to proselyte Christianity to Jews. This of course isn't directly related but is important to keep in mind.

title: How much time elapsed between Sarah Imenu's death and her burial?
content:
# How much time elapsed between Sarah Imenu's death and her burial? ## Frage

A few things I think I know: According to many she died the day of Akeidas Yitzchak which according to many was on Rosh Hashana.

Seeing as Akeidas Yitzchak on Har Hamoria was potentially at least a 3 day journey from where Avraham had been initially we can say at least there was a 3 day gap between her death and her burial. However, there are other details here to consider which may extend the time frame.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The gemara in Moed Kattan 27b says:

אַל תִּבְכּוּ לְמֵת וְאַל תָּנוּדוּ לוֹ {ירמיהו כ״ב:י׳} אַל תׇּבְכּוּ לְמֵת יוֹתֵר מִדַּאי וְאַל תָּנוּדוּ לוֹ יוֹתֵר מִכְּשִׁיעוּר הָא כֵּיצַד שְׁלֹשָׁה יָמִים לְבֶכִי וְשִׁבְעָה לְהֶסְפֵּד וּשְׁלֹשִׁים לְגִיהוּץ וּלְתִסְפּוֹרֶת מִכָּאן וְאֵילָךְ אָמַר הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא אִי אַתֶּם רַחְמָנִים בּוֹ יוֹתֵר מִמֶּנִּי.

“Weep not for the dead, neither bemoan him” (Jeremiah 22:10): “Weep not for the dead” is referring to excessive mourning; “neither bemoan him” more than the appropriate measure of time. How so? What is the appropriate measure? Three days for weeping, and seven for eulogizing, and thirty for the prohibition against ironing clothing and for the prohibition against cutting hair. From this point forward the Holy One, Blessed be He, says: Do not be more merciful with the deceased than I am. If the Torah commands one to mourn for a certain period of time, then that suffices.

When Avraham comes to Sarah, the verse says: וַיָּבֹא֙ אַבְרָהָ֔ם לִסְפֹּ֥ד לְשָׂרָ֖ה וְלִבְכֹּתָֽהּ, Avraham came to eulogize Sarah and cry for her.

That seems to be backwards!?

The relevant answer that I heard (Rabbi Daniel Glatstein brought it, I do not remember who he said it from) was that when Avraham got there, the three days of crying were over, so he started with the eulogies first, and afterwards he did he three days of crying.

That would mean that 3+7+3= 13 days after her death, Sarah was buried.

# In Devarim 6:9, why does מְזוּזֹ֥ת בֵּיתֶ֖ךָ not appear in the construct form, מְזוּזֵי ביתך? ## Frage

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

‏◌ֵ‏י is the construct form of the plural masculine noun suffix.

The plural feminine noun suffix (-ōt), such as that at the end of מזוּזֹת, doesn’t change in construct.

title: How did Edom become Rome?
content:
# How did Edom become Rome? ## Frage

How is it that the tiny kingdom of Esau, east of the Holy Land, went overseas to become the mighty empire of Rome?

Or did a descendant of Edom go up North to Troy and sailed with Aeneas to the west?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

There is a very good write up on this point here.

The first phase of this growth into Rome was:

At the beginning of the thirty-sixth chapter of Genesis, the royal roll call of Esav's descendants takes a curious turn at verse thirty-one; the names of the rulers are not from Edom—they are foreigners. According to the commentary Me’Am Lo’ez,, the Edomites were unable to find anyone among their ranks that they trusted or even capable of ruling them, so they sought foreigners to install as their monarchs. In Genesis 36:32, we learn that Bela, son of Beor was the first foreigner to reign over Edom.

In Sefer HaYashar it relates that Bela came from the region Dinhabah where he became close to a ruler called Angeas (possibly related to Aeneas - one of the founders of Rome). The text notes that Bela was anointed as king by the people of Esav (Edom), and Edom hired Angeas’s army as mercenaries for battle.

An additional link was Zepho, the son of Eliphaz and grandson of Esav (see Bereishis 36:15)

The Sefer HaYashar tells us that Zepho became the king of the Kittim, an ancient people identified by Jewish commentators as the Romans. Rashi (Bamidbar 24:24) confirms that Kittim refers to Rome, and the Ramban makes a similar connection, interpreting "Goiim" in Genesis 14:1 as a reference to the Roman king. The Gemara (Sanhedrin 106a) also links the Kittim to the Romans, specifically mentioning Roman legions in connection with the ships from Kittim in Bamidbar 24:24.

The Midrash Rabbah refers to another figure, Magdiel, a descendant of Esav, interpreting him as a prophetic reference to the Roman Emperor Diocletian. Rabbi Ammi, is reported to have prophesied that Magdiel’s rise to power signified the beginning of the end for the Roman Empire’s old structure, with Diocletian as one of the last kings. Rabbi Ammi’s vision seems to foreshadow the transition from the Roman Empire’s earlier incarnation to its later form, culminating in the reign of Constantine the Great.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 4)

While there are certainly traditions suggesting that Rome literally descended from Edom, not everyone agrees. According to these opinions, there is no question.

R. Yosef ibn Kaspi to Devarim 23:20 writes that the there are no Edomite inhabitants of Europe.

Similarly, R. Avraham ibn Ezra to Bereishit 27:40 makes it clear that the Romans were not Edomites, but were only identified as such after the Empire adopted Christianity as its official religion, since (according to Ibn Ezra) the earliest adherents of Christianity were Edomites.

Also, Shadal (ibid.) writes that the Romans were not Edomites, but that the Jews called them that when the Romans oppressed them, transferring the name of their historical enemy (Edom) onto their new one (Rome). This was especially true once Herod took power who was an Edomite and bad to the Jews (and, I would add, a client of the Romans).

title: Havdalah Candle on Motzei Shabbos Chanukah
content:
# Havdalah Candle on Motzei Shabbos Chanukah ## Frage

To my understanding, the reason we extinguish the havdalah candle immediately after havdalah is to demonstrate how the candle was lit for the purpose of a mitzvah, and not for general use. However, lighting Chanukah candles is also a mitzvah! Furthermore, there does exist a concept of "joining" two mitzvot (many have the custom to burn their lulav with their chametz on Erev Pesach).

Is it permissible to use the Havdalah candle as the shamash to light Chanukah candles?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

R Yaakov Goldstein (here) rules one can use the Havdala candle as shamash arguing that

the entire reason for lighting a shamash is to ensure that one does not make use of the other candles and to make it recognizable that the other candles were lit for the sake of a mitzvah. Accordingly, not only should it be permitted to use a torch [havdala candle] for the shamash, but on the contrary, it could even be considered preferable. By doing so, you make a clear distinction between the candles of obligation and the shamash. Additionally, it provides more light than regular candles.

OU Israel's Torah Tidbits brings the same ruling in their summary of the halachot of Hanuka on motzei Shabbat.

Those who say havdalah first can light their Shamash for the Chanukah candles with the havdalah candle before extinguishing it, thus dovetailing two mitzvot.

title: Sources for centrality of Shmoneh Esrei in our liturgy
content:
# Sources for centrality of Shmoneh Esrei in our liturgy ## Frage

There are numerous sources that look at the shemoneh esrei / the Amida, and provide information on its structure, the various kavannos, the associated halachos etc., but I am specifically chasing some introductory quotes/sources that state it represents a central tenet within our davening.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Mishneh Torah Hilchot Tefillah ch.1:

1 It is a positive Torah commandment to pray every day, as [Exodus 23:25] states: "You shall serve God, your Lord." Tradition teaches us that this service is prayer, as [Deuteronomy 11:13] states: "And serve Him with all your heart" and our Sages said: Which is the service of the heart? This is prayer. The number of prayers is not prescribed in the Torah, nor does it prescribe a specific formula for prayer. Also, according to Torah law, there are no fixed times for prayers.

...

4 When Israel was exiled in the time of the wicked Nebuchadnezzar, they became interspersed in Persia and Greece and other nations. Children were born to them in these foreign countries and those children's language was confused. The speech of each and every one was a concoction of many tongues. No one was able to express himself coherently in any one language, but rather in a mixture [of languages], as [Nehemiah 13:24] states: "And their children spoke half in Ashdodit and did not know how to speak the Jewish language. Rather, [they would speak] according to the language of various other peoples." Consequently, when someone would pray, he would be limited in his ability to request his needs or to praise the Holy One, blessed be He, in Hebrew, unless other languages were mixed in with it. When Ezra and his court saw this, they established eighteen blessings in sequence. The first three [blessings] are praises of God and the last three are thanksgiving. The intermediate [blessings] contain requests for all those things that serve as general categories for the desires of each and every person and the needs of the whole community. Thus, the prayers could be set in the mouths of everyone. They could learn them quickly and the prayers of those unable to express themselves would be as complete as the prayers of the most eloquent. It was because of this matter that they established all the blessings and prayers so that they would be ordered in the mouths of all Israel, so that each blessing would be set in the mouth of each person unable to express himself.

So, according to Rambam, the method by which we are mandated (rabinically) to fulfill the biblical command to pray is precisely by reciting the amidah.

title: Efron name significance
content:
# Efron name significance ## Frage

After the post last week on Lot name significance, what's the significance of Efron, since he seems to play a key role?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

My own theory is that the name Efron (עפרון) is intended to hint at Chevron (חברון): In Semitic languages, including Hebrew, ע can be switched with ח and פ can be switched with ב. We know from Tanach that the original name of Chevron was Kiryat Arba (Beresheet 23:2, Yehoshua 14:15, etc.). I think the Israelites renamed Kiryat Arba in honor of Efron's willingness to sell the Machpelah Cave to Avraham. The form Chevron was favored rather than Efron because it contains the root חבר (friend), to symbolize the hand of friendship Efron extended toward Avraham.1 We similarly find that the city of Shomron, which was bought by Omri and turned into Israel's capital, was named after its original owner, Shemer (Melachim 1:16:24).

Linguist Dr. Moshe Zaidel (חקרי לשון, pp. 41-42, can be found on Otzar Hachochmah) proposed something similar, that Efron should be identified with Arba, the patriarch of the giants of Kiryat Arba (Yehoshua 14:15; per Targum Pseudo-Yonatan on Devarim 1:28), with the root of Arba, רבע, being contained in Efron, again with the letter-switch. The Israelites renamed Kiryat Arba after Efron, but it was easier for them to pronounce the form Chevron, so that's what they used.

1 Following this reasoning, it also occurred to me that Efron's father's name, Tzochar (צחר), also contains a ח, which can be switched with an ע, which would form Tzo'ar (צער). This might mean that Efron was originally from Tzo'ar, a place also connected to Avraham's story - it was one of the Jordan plain cities saved by Avraham (when it was still named Belah), and Lot eventually escaped there following the destruction of Sodom and the other cities. Perhaps this background also explains Efron's decision to agree to sell the cave, perhaps as thanks to Avraham. I've written about the topic of Efron's name more in detail in a couple of blog posts (here and here).

### Antwort 2 (Score: 3)

עפרן (as spelled uniquely in the verse when he is paid) is 400 in Gematria, equal to the amount he took (Baal Haturim). It is also the Gematria of רע עין, or stingy. (Gur Aryeh)

His name relates to עפר, or dirt. That fits for someone whose contribution to history is selling a burial place. The letters could also be rearranged to פרען, or payment, speaking to his greedy nature.

title: The Apparent Contradiction between 2 Chronicles 21:12 and 2 Kings 2:9
content:
# The Apparent Contradiction between 2 Chronicles 21:12 and 2 Kings 2:9 ## Frage

How could the king of Judah have received a letter from Elijah after the latter had been taken up to heaven?

And it was that they were going, walking and talking, and behold a fiery chariot and fiery horses, and they separated them both. And Elijah ascended to heaven in a whirlwind - 2 Kings 2:11.

And a letter came to him from Elijah the prophet, saying, "So said the Lord, the God of David your father: Because you did not go in the ways of Jehoshaphat your father and in the ways of Asa, the king of Judah - 2 Chronicles 21:12.

What justifications are given for the apparent contradiction between the two passages?

Suggested Answers and Evaluation

  1. "The whirlwind dropped him back on Earth" -
    Unlikely due to 2 Kings 2:17.
  2. Elijah wrote it before ascending with instructions as to when to deliver it.
    This would be a prophecy and he was a prophet.
  3. Elijah dictated the letter from heaven.
    We have nothing similar to this in the Bible.
  4. Elijah returned from heaven.
    Had this happened, I expect the Bible would tell us more about it.

Based on the inputs which I have received so far, it seems most likely that Elijah wrote it before he ascended.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

A few commentators on the verse in Chronicles - Radak, Metuzdat David, Chomat Anach - suggest that Elijah revealed himself to another prophet, that prophet wrote down his words and delivered the letter to the king. Ralbag (and Rabbi Steinsaltz agrees this is the simplest explanation) suggests that this was a prophecy made by Elijah before his ascension (and evidently written down by someone and delivered at the correct time by a messenger, presumably another prophet or one of the sons of the prophets [students of prophets]).

title: What does בדאית mean (Bereshit Rabbah 48:18)
content:
# What does בדאית mean (Bereshit Rabbah 48:18) ## Frage

“The Lord said to Abraham: Why is it that Sarah laughed, saying: Shall I indeed bear a child, and I have grown old?” (Genesis 18:13). “The Lord said to Abraham: Why is it that Sarah laughed, saying: [Shall I indeed bear a child, and I have grown old?]” – bar Kappara said: Peace [between spouses] is a great thing, as even Scripture spoke untruths in order to establish peace between Abraham and Sarah. “Sarah laughed to herself, saying: After my languishing, shall I have youth, and my husband is old?” But He did not say this to Abraham, but rather, “Why is it that Sarah laughed, saying: Shall I indeed bear a child, and I have grown old?” The verse does not say as Sarah said: “My husband is old,” but rather, “I have grown old.”

bar Kappara said: כתובים דברו בדאית (where I make bold above text)

What does בדאית means in this context?

[I know there is a similar question. In this question, however, I'd like to know the exact meaning of a hebrew word]

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The root בדא means something like "to fabricate", "to concoct" or "to invent". See Melachim I:12:33 and Nechemia 6:8.

So the sense of the Midrash is like the translation you brought "Scripture spoke untruths" or maybe "presented a fictitious account".

title: Is Ibn Ezra’s long note under Genesis 18:13 misplaced?
content:
# Is Ibn Ezra’s long note under Genesis 18:13 misplaced? ## Frage

Genesis 18:13 reads,

וַיֹּ֥אמֶר יְהֹוָ֖ה אֶל־אַבְרָהָ֑ם לָ֣מָּה זֶּה֩ צָחֲקָ֨ה שָׂרָ֜ה לֵאמֹ֗ר הַאַ֥ף אֻמְנָ֛ם אֵלֵ֖ד וַאֲנִ֥י זָקַֽנְתִּי׃

And the Lord said to Avraham, Why did Sara laugh, saying, Shall I indeed bear a child, who am old?

On Sefaria, the long comment placed under this verse discusses Abraham’s interaction with the three visitors and God’s words about Sodom (vv. 2–3 and 17–22). Is that really the correct location of Ibn Ezra’s comment, or an editorial misplacement?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 8)

Interesting question.

I checked a couple of versions of Ibn Ezra's commentary to verify that this is indeed the original location of the commentary:

  1. What I gather is the editio princeps (first printing) of Ibn Ezra's commentary, Napoli 5248 (1487-1488) (link).
  2. What is listed as the oldest (dateable) manuscript copy of the commentary on the NLI's Ktiv project, MS Fir. Lau. Or. 104 (link).

Both have this comment in the same location.

I then checked a few supercommentaries on Ibn Ezra. The only reference to this issue (albeit not entirely explicit) that I found (though there may be others, especially supercommentaries that haven't been printed) is Da'at Ezra by Rabbi Nechemiah Sheinfeld (can be found on Otzar Hachochmah), who wrote between Ibn Ezra's comment on the letter Mem in אמנם and the "problematic" commentary on the three visitors (p. 230):

"עתה חוזר רבינו לשאלה שעסק בה בתחילת הפרשה: מי היו שלושת האנשים."

"Now our rabbi returns to the question which he had been examining in the beginning of the parsha: Who were these three men."

So, yes, technically this comment should have been at the start of the parsha. But, apparently, the Ibn Ezra went into a kind of "tangent" (so to speak) in clarifying the first verses of the parsha, and then went back to the first issue he had been dealing with (in the second verse of the parsha), which is the identity of the three visitors.

title: How do angels look?
content:
# How do angels look? ## Frage

According to Genesis 18/1-2, Abraham perceived in the spiritual dimension 4 beings, three of whom had physical bodies.

Lot was not spiritually endowed nor was he righteous. According to Genesis 19/1, he saw with his physical eyes 2 of the beings from Genesis 18, and he was able to identify them as angels.

If he didn't see anything special about these men, he'd have ignored them as he did with his fellow men. But, he noticed something special about them, which is why he approached them. How did he distinguish these 2 men as being special?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The Bereishis Rabbah 50:2 writes:

אָמַר רַבִּי תַּנְחוּמָא אָמַר רַבִּי לֵוִי אַבְרָהָם שֶׁהָיָה כֹּחוֹ יָפֶה נִדְמוּ לוֹ בִּדְמוּת אֲנָשִׁים, אֲבָל לוֹט עַל יְדֵי שֶׁהָיָה כֹּחוֹ רַע נִדְמוּ לוֹ בִּדְמוּת מַלְאָכִים

Rabbi Tancḥuma said that Rabbi Levi said: To Avraham, whose power was great, they appeared in the image of men; to Lot, whose strength was inferior, they appeared in the image of angels.

The commentaries on the Midrash there shed some more light.

Firstly, the Eitz Yosef explains:

אברהם שהיה כחו יפה. להשגת מראות אלהים לא היו מראות המלאכים נורא בעיניו אלא כמו ראיית האנשים אבל לוט שהיה כחו רע פי' שלא היה רגיל בנבואה נדמו כמלאכים

Avraham, whose spiritual strength was great, since he was accustomed to perceiving Divine visions, the sight of angels was not awe-inspiring in his eyes, but appeared to him as the sight of ordinary men. However, Lot, whose strength was weak — meaning, he was not accustomed to prophecy, therefore they appeared to him as angels.

In other words, this refers not to physical strength, but to spiritual capacity. Avraham, being accustomed to prophetic revelation (“מראות אלהים”), had a high level of spiritual perception. As such, when angels came to him, their presence did not appear extraordinary — they seemed to him like human beings. Lot, on the other hand, lacked this prophetic refinement (“שלא היה רגיל בנבואה”), so the angels appeared to him in their more awe-inspiring, celestial form — “כמלאכים.”

Also note the Peirush Maharzu there that builds on this concept and adds further points worth noting.

שהיה כחו יפה. להשגת מראות אלהים וכמ"ש ר"פ כ"ז גדול כח הנביאים שמדמים הצורה ליוצרה. וכ"ש למלאכים. משא"כ לוט. וכמ"ש במנוח מות נמות כי אלהים ראינו. או שהיה כחו יפה במע"ט כמ"ש פ' ל"א סי' י'

‘Whose strength was great’ — refers to his capacity to perceive Divine visions. As it is stated earlier (at the beginning of chapter 27): ‘Great is the power of the prophets, for they liken the Form to its Creator’, and all the more so, they can perceive angels without awe. This was not the case with Lot, as it is written regarding Manoach: ‘We shall surely die, for we have seen a divine being’ (Judges 13:22). Alternatively, ‘his strength was great’ refers to his excellence in good deeds, as stated above (chapter 31, section 10).

So the Peirsh Maharzu offers two points:

The Maharzu offers two interpretations of the phrase “שהיה כחו יפה” (“whose strength was great”):

Prophetic strength: (Like the Eitz Yosef) Avraham possessed a powerful prophetic faculty — he could perceive even Divine visions (מראות אלהים) without fear. The Maharzu cites an earlier Midrash (Bereishis Rabbah 27:1): “Great is the power of the prophets, for they liken the Form (the Divine appearance) to its Creator.” Since prophets can behold the Divine itself, it follows even more so that they can behold angels without being overwhelmed. Lot, however, lacked this spiritual strength, and therefore was awed by the angels — similar to Manoach in Shoftim 13:22, who feared death upon seeing an angel (“We will surely die, for we have seen a divine being”).

Moral strength: Alternatively, the phrase may refer not to prophetic ability but to strength in good deeds (מעשים טובים), as discussed earlier in Bereishis Rabbah 31:10 - (I'm not sure about this source - it doesn't bring out this point - unless Sefaria has different segmentation of the Midrash?).
