title: "Harmless" pranks - does such a thing exist? Is it good or bad?
content:
# "Harmless" pranks - does such a thing exist? Is it good or bad? ## Frage

There is a genre of pranks that are considered "harmless". The definition varies, but generally speaking, the rough definition can be "a prank that ends up with the victim laughing, having enjoyed the experience". I suspect that the Torah would consider all pranks some form of harm, even harmless ones, as they at absolute best involve a little bit of genevat da'at, and genevat zman. Also, not everyone is going to laugh, especially if the victim is having a very bad day.

On the other hand, maybe I am being too "strict" and maybe the potential laughter at the end is worth it as simcha can be really important! It would be interesting to know what halachic principles really do apply to pranks, and if they can all be extended to the most harmless of pranks. Or, is this all just "fifth book of Shulchan Aruch"-grade questioning?

Here are some examples of pranks that are generally considered "harmless":

  1. Blowing bubbles into the air when someone is not looking and when they wonder where the bubbles came from, act like you are as clueless as them - leading them to think there are random bubbles floating around.
  2. Asking someone a question for directions to a non-existent place, the joke being the name of the place is actually really silly/funny and obviously not real, but the delivery was done so well that the person initially thought they misheard.
  3. Take a copy of your friend's desk photo, reproduce it but photoshop in Uncle Moishy's face over your friend's, and put that into the photo frame (over the original) when he is not looking, and see how long it takes him to notice (someone did this to a Rabbi of mine once in Yeshiva).

Nobody gets hurt, or scared, or (hopefully) embarrassed. Most people will enjoy having this done to them. Note: I've added the contemporary halacha tag for those who want to tackle the "social media" side of things.

title: Lot name significance
content:
# Lot name significance ## Frage

Most of the characters so far found since Parshat Bereshit bear significance and meaning, either on a pshat or on a remez/drash/sod level. For instance:

  • Adam
  • Chava
  • Kayin
  • Noach
  • Avram/Avraham
  • Sarai/Sarah
  • Ishmael
  • Itzchak

I was wondering about the case of Lot לוט. To what Hebrew root, gematria, acronym, remez or other is Lot's name connected to, and what would be the significance?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

1.) The peirush Sulam explains that לוט denotes a curse in Aramaic.

Text of Sulam:

מיד וילך אתו לוט וכו': זהו הנחש שנתקלל והעולם נתקלל בסבתו. כלומר, ע"כ מכנה הכתוב להנחש בשם לוט, כי לוט, פירושו קללה בלשון ארמית, והוא שנתקלל והביא קללה להעולם.

2.) The Be'er Mayim Chaim al HaTorah explains the root of the word to mean hidden(wrapped up.

Text:

וזה הדבר אשר שיבח הכתוב את אבינו אברהם, ואמר וילך אתו לוט נודע בחינת לוט הוא היצר הרע האורב אל האדם טמון בקרבו והוא לוטה בשלמה להחטיא את האדם, אבל באברהם הנה הלך אתו עמו, והיצר הרע השלים עמו, להיותו אוהב שמו בכל לבבו בשני היצרים יצר טוב ויצר הרע שעם כל כוחות תאוות הרעים הִתְאַוָה לה' המיוחד

"He(Lot) is wrapped in a garment in order to cause man to sin."

Lot has the aspect of the Yetzer Harah within him.

### ✅ Antwort 2 (Score: 5)

Yehuda Dvir in his essay "Lot", Talpiyot 7:2-4 (5721), pp. 432-442 (can be found on Otzar Hachochmah) noted the following possible meanings for Lot:

  • Hidden, from the Akkadian word litu, meaning screen (מסך).1,2
  • Curse, from Aramaic (as noted by @sam).
  • A kind of fragrant plant or perfume, per Beresheet 37:25 and 43:11.

Dvir suggested that whatever the original meaning of Lot, the way the Torah describes him and his descendants shows that the Torah's intended meaning for his name was the negative "curse", as a kind of midrash shem (an exegesis-based etymology for a person's name to emphasize a certain idea).

1 I did not find such a word with this exact meaning. Phonetically similar words with similar meanings include: līṭu (garment or cloth), lattu (a container of standard capacity), lâṭum (to confine or keep in check, relevant also for animals as wrap around, or bind an enemy, etc). Per Black et al, A Concise Dictionary of Akkadian.

2 Dvir doesn't appear to state this, but I recall seeing somewhere a suggestion that a few members of Avraham's family had names related to the moon, to indicate that their background was of moon-worshipping idolaters: Terach from Yare'ach (or Yerach, Hebrew for moon), Lot from hidden, as in the moon is often hidden, and Lavan from Levanah (a Hebrew synonym for Yare'ach). This makes some sense, as Ur was one of the centers for the worship of the Mesopotamian moon god Sin, and might explain why the family decided to settle in Charran, as that city was also a renowned center for the worship of Sin.

title: Deeper meaning of "field of knives" being harvested with the "horn of a donkey"?
content:
# Deeper meaning of "field of knives" being harvested with the "horn of a donkey"? ## Frage

B"H

The gemara in Bechoros brings a debate between Rabbi Yehoshua and the wise men of Athens, where they asked different riddles to test his wisdom

משרא דסכיני במאי קטלי בקרנא דחמרא ומי איכא קרנא לחמרא ומי איכא משרא דסכיני

They asked him another question: With what does one harvest a field of knives? Rabbi Yehoshua answered: With the horn of a donkey. They said to him: But is there such an item as a horn of a donkey? He said to them: But is there such a thing as a field of knives?

משרא דסכיני במאי קטלי ליה ערוגה דסכיני במה קוצרין אותה:

The simple meaning is obvious: a ridiculous/nonsensical question deserves a ridiculous answer, a question without a premise can be dismissed without a premise.

But I've heard that all of the questions they asked are really deep philosophical debates of perspective that even continue to the modern day.

For example another question they asked earlier was:

מילחא כי סריא במאי מלחי לה אמר להו בסילתא דכודניתא ומי איכא סילתא לכודנתא ומילחא מי סרי

The sages of Athens then asked another question: When salt is spoiling, with what does one salt it to preserve it? Rabbi Yehoshua said to them: With the placenta of a mule. They said to him: But is there a placenta of a mule? Rabbi Yehoshua said to them: And does salt spoil?

סיליתא שיליא:

Similar idea but I heard that by "salt" they were referring to the Torah, which was meant to preserve the Jewish ppl. And the greeks were claiming that in the new "progressive" Greek era, the Torah that said was getting old and spoiled.

Then the answer of "placenta of a mule", a mule is a combination of a horse and a donkey, two seemingly strong animals, which should have the advantages of both, implying maybe one can mix the Torah around with Greek culture to keep it modern

But "do mules have placenta?", if one tries to mix the Torah with other things to try to get the best of both, it won't actually reproduce and continue. To which he answered "does salt spoil?", that the Torah never gets old, because it's totally beyond time and eternally relevant.

Based on this similar way of thinking, what is the deeper metaphorical meaning of the field of knives?

I've heard bits and pieces but not sure exactly what the full explanation is, based on what I think I understand from it so far I think it might mean something about a field representing life and growth with knives representing destruction , and the "field of knives" the greeks were asking how can the Jewish ppl hope to "harvest" and thrive in the exile, a place of destruction, to which he answered "the horn of a donkey", a non existent instrument implying that the survival of the Jewish ppl is really from a place that's beyond understanding, similar to a donkey which represents bittul, self nullification to Hashem, within the chomer (physicality) of the physical world, reaching a place beyond the world and beyond "existence" as we understand it, especially through the hope and yearning, while in exile, for moshiach who will arrive on a donkey.

But the the answer? I'm not so sure. And even the setup, I would need verification if I'm on the right way of understanding it. Looking for authoritative sources/commentaries

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

As requested, the Artscroll Bechoros 8b(8), the comments 57-58 address the OP's question. There are 3 answers, first: a semi-joke by Maharal (but see for explanation in the second answer) in comment 57, second an extended answer of Maharsha in the first part of the comment 58, third an answer of GR"A at the end of the comment 58:

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

B"H

My own theory based on the commentaries mentioned in Y DJ's answer:

They say one explanation of the field of knives is the exile, and the horn of the donkey is moshiach

Another explanation says the field of knives is the righteous people suffering in this world, why does it happen etc.

Maybe from chabad chassidus, one can say that the field of knives relates to the general concealment of Hashem in the physical world and specifically the exile (which itself is a deeper meaning of the suffering of the righteous, due to the concealment of Hashem), the "Tzimtzum" of the light, giving the world an appearance of something separate, perhaps the knives could represent limitations, something that cuts things to precise measurements, and field of knives could maybe refer to seder histalshilus, or the light of the Kav (line), which "measures out" the necessary life of all worlds and beings

How is it possible to harvest a field of knives, how can we hope to have the revelation of Hashem in this physical, lowly world?

"The horn of a donkey", as mentioned in other commentators the donkey in this context could also refer to the chomer, physically, of the world, and the horn of a symbol of "strength". In chassidus the horn is associated with Keser, the highest it the Sefiros

Perhaps the horn of the donkey is the level of bittul, nullification that we can achieve, to Hashem, through emunah and Torah and mitzvos which access a place beyond the physicality (horn of a donkey).

"Is there a horn of a donkey?"

How can we hope that such a high level of Hashem's light achieved through self nullification can have a real effect on our world? Maybe when the day "does it exist" it could mean "does it exist within the limitations of the world (field of knives), to be order to affect it, or only beyond the world?"

Then "is there a field of knives", through the revelation of the Atzmus the essence of the Creator who is found equally above and below, we realize that the Tzimtzum the entire time is not literal, and retroactively we realize that the revelation already exists everywhere, we just have to uncover it

title: A puzzling item in Psalm 107
content:
# A puzzling item in Psalm 107 ## Frage

Psalm 107 contains four verses that are almost the same. They differ in the first and last words, which sound almost the same. And there is an extra vav in one of them.

107:6: וַיִּצְעֲק֣וּ אֶל־יְ֭הֹוָה בַּצַּ֣ר לָהֶ֑ם מִ֝מְּצ֥וּקוֹתֵיהֶ֗ם יַצִּילֵֽם׃

107:13: וַיִּזְעֲק֣וּ אֶל־יְ֭הֹוָה בַּצַּ֣ר לָהֶ֑ם מִ֝מְּצֻ֥קוֹתֵיהֶ֗ם יוֹשִׁיעֵֽם׃

107:19: וַיִּזְעֲק֣וּ אֶל־יְ֭הֹוָה בַּצַּ֣ר לָהֶ֑ם מִ֝מְּצֻ֥קוֹתֵיהֶ֗ם יוֹשִׁיעֵֽם׃

107:28: וַיִּצְעֲק֣וּ אֶל־יְ֭הֹוָה בַּצַּ֣ר לָהֶ֑ם וּֽ֝מִמְּצ֥וּקֹתֵיהֶ֗ם יוֹצִיאֵֽם׃

Sefaria says they mean exactly the same:

In their adversity they cried to the LORD, and He rescued them from their troubles.

Why the repetition, why the small difference, and do they indeed mean the same?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The four crying is the four kinds of people who are required to say the Bracha HaGomel. The Zohar and Radak note that there is no difference between the צ and ז. Malbim notes צעקה is the proper description of the cry of the those in distress in the open desert or sea, where there are no walls to prevent their shouts from spreading far and wide. However, the cries of those confined to the prison cell or sickroom are contained by restrictive walls and so their shouts are best described with the word זעקה.

From Artscroll Tehillim. When you read it again within that context, I think it makes a bit more sense.

If I might add, see the shape of a צ, it goes out horizontally and then up to the right and left vs the ז only goes up.

content:
# Why was Avraham concerned about the impurity of Niddah, but not about impurity of the dead? ## Frage

The (Pirkei De’Rabbi Eliezer 36:16) says that the reason why Avraham didn’t serve the bread to the guests was because Sarah became a Niddah while preparing the bread, thus causing the bread to become impure.

The question is: the Midrash then says that when Avraham ran after the calf, it entered the cave where Adam Harishon was buried, and Avraham followed it into the cave.

If so, Avraham seemingly became impure as well, since he entered a cave where there was a dead body - so why was he not concerned about serving the guests and standing above them under the same tree, which would seemingly cause the food to become impure?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The righteous do not impart impurity even in death. Ramban Chukas 19:2

" The reason for the impurity conveyed by a corpse is [due to man’s sin committed through] the instigation of the serpent, for those who die by “the Divine Kiss” do not [in fact] convey impurity according to the law, this being the [sense of the] saying of the Rabbis: “The righteous do not convey impurity [when dead].” It is for this reason that Scripture states, This is ‘chukath’ of the law, meaning: [this is] that which is “hollowed out” from the [Written] Torah, namely, the Oral Torah. Therefore it is a [female] heifer and must be red, [symbolic] of the attribute of justice. It is given to Eleazar inasmuch as it must be slaughtered before him, even [though it may actually be slaughtered] by a non-priest, because the deputy High Priest [i.e., Eleazar] supervises the performance thereof, so that it should be done in accordance with his intentions, and so that they should not entertain any improper thoughts about it, as do the nations [of the world] and Satan [as mentioned above]." Sefaria Link

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

B"H

Tumas Meis only applies to Jews. Adam was a goy (Bava Basra 58a).

Avraham kept the entire Torah before it was given, so Sarah was under the laws

title: Reason for the mourning custom of banging in a nail?
content:
# Reason for the mourning custom of banging in a nail? ## Frage

There is a Chabad custom at the end of shiva to bang a nail into the floor where the avel sat. The underlying source for this custom is absent from the materials I could find online and is described as 'obscure' here. I would like to know where this custom comes from and the meaning or symbolism it conveys.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Partial answer:

Various sources, like the link you brought, mention this custom but find no source for it. However, a similar custom by Libyan Jews was recounted by Nachum Slouschz in his book ספר המסעות, vol. 2, p. 104 (can be found on Otzar Hachochmah):

"...בני משפחה שמתו שנים מבניה בשנה אחת ויש לחשוש שמא ימות גם בן שלישי...מיד בשובם מן הקבורה הם נועצים מסמר בדלת - שזוהי סגולה בדוקה כדי שמלאך המות יפסח עליה ויעבור."

"Members of a family of which two sons died in one year and there's a fear that a third may die...immediately upon returning from the funeral stick a nail into the door - a tried-and-tested charm (segulah) to ascertain that the Angel of Death will pass over that [door] and continue on."

While I doubt that Chabad received this custom from Libyan Jews, in my research of Jewish segulot and kemeot (amulets), I found that on occasion nails were used, for various types of charms and amulets. Sometimes they were inscribed with special words or names, and often as part of the ritual they were banged into a door or another object. So it seems that Jews in various communities had such similar customs. I don't recall any specifically like the custom recounted by Slouschz, but then again, I read perhaps thousands in recent months and don't have perfect memory. If I come across an Ashkenazic segulah formula that is intended to defend from death and involves nails, I'll edit that in.

The usage of nails as amulets is ancient. Already Mishna Shabbat 6:10 mentions a custom of using a nail from a crucifixion as an amulet (the Bavli clarifies that it was used for healing sicknesses). The custom, as the gemara itself indicates, is of non-Jewish origin, but finds leniency in halacha because it is intended for healing. The medieval usage of nails probably developed from this older custom, and the Libyan custom most likely developed from that, and perhaps the Chabad custom as well.

Another possible reason for the Chabad custom was suggested in the book Mourning & Mitzvah: A Guided Journal for Walking the Mourner's Path through Grief to Healing by Anne Brener, p. 104:

"In some Jewish communities, for example, shiva is ended by hammering a nail into a wooden board. This rich image acknowledges that it is time to end the period of numbness and withdrawal and begin to face the reality of loss. The loud rap of the hammer is a sensory alarm clock. It wakes up the mourner and penetrates the layers of his or her withdrawal, just as the nail penetrates the board."

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

Upon further research, but without a source, there is an example of placing a nail into a hard surface as a sort of remembrance that a significant event took place at that spot.

This idea is found in Yerushalmi Chagigah 3:1 wherein, after intercalculating the year in the valley of Rimmon, the following statement was made

אתיי מיזל לון אמרין אתון נחוי עובדינן. והוה תמן חד כיף דשייש והוה כל חד וחד נסיב חד מסמר וקבע ליה בגויה והוא נחת ושקע כהדין ליישא. עד כדון מיתקרי כיפא מסמרא.
When they were leaving they said, come and let us record our act. A rock of marble was there. Each of them took a nail and fixed it in it; it descended and sank in as in dough. Until now it is called the rock of nails.

Perhaps this is the source for this custom, as a reminder of the significance of the mourning which was completed there

title: Sarah giving Hagar to Avraham and Mishlei 30:21
content:
# Sarah giving Hagar to Avraham and Mishlei 30:21 ## Frage

I’ve just come across this in the Artscroll Beresheit commentary:

Mishlei 30:21-23 says ‘For three things the earth shudders, there are four it cannot tolerate: a slave who has become a king; a fool when he is filled with food; an unloved woman when she gets a husband; and a handmaid that is heir to her mistress.’

Yet we know Sarah gave Hagar to Avraham. How do we explain this? Were Avraham and Sarah ‘upsetting the order of things’, and if so, did they know it - and proceeded anyway? Was this a nisayon involving the choice of the lesser of two evils?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Sara gave Hagar to Avraham with good intentions. She specifically gave Hagar as a wife and not a concubine so that the offspring should be from a full marriage relationship and so that it serve as a merit for Sarah.

As per the Eitz Yosef's explanation on Bereishis Rabbah 45:3

ולא לפילגש שכוונת שרה היתה כדי שיצא זרע הנולד מאישות גמור. גם שתהא גבירה כמותה ותהיה לה שרה באמת. וזכותה יעמוד לה

(As a wife) and not as a concubine - for Sarah’s intention was that the offspring should be born from full marital relations. Additionally, [the wife] should be a lady like herself, and she should truly be Sarah (i.e.a higher status than a concubine's child would typically have). And her merit will stand for her."

title: why is children dying a just punishment for breaking a vow?
content:

title: Does a mistaken blessing cover other present foods it otherwise only covers after-the-fact, when it's not been corrected (i.e. after taking a bite)?
content:
# Does a mistaken blessing cover other present foods it otherwise only covers after-the-fact, when it's not been corrected (i.e. after taking a bite)? ## Frage

Say I have an apple, an orange, and a cucumber in front of me. I intend to say Boreh Peri HaEtz first, to cover the tree-fruit first as per halacha (SA OC 211:3), so I pick up the apple. However, I accidentally said Boreh Peri Ha'adamah, and then take a bite.

Now, if I had not taken a bite, the Kaf HaChaim states that I should put down the apple, and take the ground-fruit, i.e the cucumber, take a bite, and then say Boreh Peri HaEtz on one of the fruit. This seems to imply that in his case, I did not actually cover the tree-fruit (otherwise the beracha would be levatala).

Regarding my case, one could argue that since I took a bite out of the apple already, we can rely on SA OC 206:2

היו לפניו פרי האדמה ופרי העץ ובירך על פרי האדמה ונתכוין לפטור את פרי העץ יצא:

If one had before him produce of the ground and produce of the tree, and he blessed on the ground produce, intending to cover the tree produce, he has fulfilled his obligation.

and I shouldn't repeat my beracha (see also Kaf HaChaim 206:13 which covers the case of a mistaken beracha not needing to be repeated, but again, also slightly different). But I don't know. On the one hand, I did intend to cover the orange (and the apple), but I actually said the wrong beracha, so maybe it's more similar to the Kaf HaChaim's case, which explicitly covers mistaken berachot?

So, what's the right operating halachic principle to apply to my case? Should I say Boreh Peri HaEtz on the orange, or not?

title: Why did the female snake receive an additional curse?
content:
# Why did the female snake receive an additional curse? ## Frage

The Gemara (Bechorot 8a) says that the snake was cursed that its pregnancy should last for seven years.

Now without getting into the question as to whether the pregnancy of snakes lasts for that long nowadays, my question is as follows:

The Torah talks about the snake in the masculine form, so it would seem that it was a male - so why did the female snake receive the curse of being pregnant for seven years?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

The answer could possibly be that the male snake instigated the sin, and Hashem embedded reproductive suffering in the natural biology of all animals (including the female snake), as Gemera in Bechorot 8a mentions other animals gestation period which are very long as well. Also, it's perhaps similar to the Rashi in Beresheit 1:22 who writes that the animals were in need of a bracha as well, but Hashem did not bless them, in order that the snake not be might not be included in the blessing, and therefore it comes out that many animals have reproductive suffering in their natural biology because of the lack of the bracha of pru urvu as well. This is also similar to Adam’s sin, causing humans to die — including women — even though Adam alone was directly addressed.

title: Erva in front of portrait of Talmid Chacham/Tzaddik/Gadol
content:
# Erva in front of portrait of Talmid Chacham/Tzaddik/Gadol ## Frage

Is there any inyan of not being dressed modestly in front of a portrait of a Tzaddik? I understand that it's unlikely to be a halachic issue, due to the fact that one is allowed to go to the mikva when a Tzaddik is there so kal vechomer, but it might be something that is frowned upon for other reasons.

I've heard of people covering portraits of Rebbeim when getting changed etc. out of Kavod/Yirah. Is this sourced anywhere? Maybe the inyan that Yosef remembered the face of his father for chizuk?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

Thanks @Shababnik for suggesting looking over the footnote from V'ein Lamo Michshol. It brings the opinion of Tzitz Eliezer that one should treat portraits with respect:

וכיוצא בזה כתב בשו"ת ציץ אליעזר (חלק טז סימן כז), שאין מן הצורך להשתדל להנפיק תמונות של גדולים וצדיקים על גבי בולים, דהא הרבה תמונות יתגלגלו לאחר מכן ברחובות, ורוב העם לא ינהגו בהם בכבוד הראוי. ע"כ.

“Similarly, the Tzitz Eliezer (vol. 16, siman 27) writes that it is unnecessary to issue stamps bearing the images of great rabbis or tzaddikim, for the images will eventually be cast about in the streets, and most people will not treat them with proper respect.”

Interestingly, the Shu"t Binyan Av (II:17) states that it is a flawed custom because it accustoms children to focus on the external aspect of the Tzaddik, his face, but in the same teshuva, he writes that disseminating pictures is a disrespect because it turns them into mere "commodities sold in the marketplace", and "playthings for children".

There are many opinions there as well about how there is a spiritual/psychological benefit to seeing the face of a Tzaddik, even as a portrait.

See also this Derher article about how the Rebbe Rayatz underwent a huge project to try and collect all the portraits he could of his fellow Rebbeim for exactly this purpose, even though both his father and great grandfather (the Tzemach Tzeddek) objected to being painted/photographed (but we did end up getting portraits of both due to very interesting circumstances). His grandfather, the Rebbe Maharash did have a portrait made, which only recently surfaced from his descendants. I asked a Chabad friend of mine, who is a Shaliyach, and he said that they avoid putting portraits of the Rebbe(im) in the bedroom, for the reason of not getting dressed in front of it.

It seems like there is an inyan here, even among those who object to the notion of considering the external features of a Tzaddik to be inspiring in and of themselves.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 4)

See the sefer V’ein Lomo Michshol available here online, who, while not directly addressing your question, says that one should preferably not let a picture lie about on the floor.

יש אומרים שיש להימנע מלחלק תמונות של צדיקים לילדים כפי שמצוי כיום בכמה חברות תהילים בארץ, מפני שהתמונות עלולות לבוא לידי בזיון, ומכשילים בכך את ילדי ישראל. אולם המנהג להקל בזה. ועל כל פנים, עדיף יותר לחלק לילדים תמונות גדולות של צדיקים וגדולי ישראל, כדי לתלותם בבית, ולקיים מה שנאמר "והיו עיניך רואות את מוריך".

Some say one should refrain from distributing pictures of tzaddikim (righteous individuals) to children, as is commonly done today by several Tehillim groups in Israel, because the pictures may come to be treated disrespectfully, thereby causing the children of Israel to stumble. However, the common custom is to be lenient in this matter. In any case, it is preferable to give children large pictures of tzaddikim and great Torah leaders, so they can hang them in their homes and thereby fulfill the verse, “And your eyes shall behold your teachers.”

See the footnote there regarding the range of opinions on "gedolim pictures."

title: Repentance vs Intercession
content:
# Repentance vs Intercession ## Frage

I know (from grok) that The Eleh Ezkerah is a powerful liturgical text that recounts the martyrdom of ten sages, framing their deaths as a Kiddush Hashem with atoning significance for the Jewish people. Its poetic narrative, celestial dialogue, and concluding plea for mercy underscore the themes of sacrifice, righteousness, and communal redemption central to Yom Kippur. By invoking the martyrs’ merit, the text bridges historical suffering with the present-day pursuit of atonement.

If God forgives people for the dying of a righteous person/persons why there is Repentance? is not Repentance alone enough? How do Jews balance between Repentance and Intercession?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The answer is that Repentance alone still leaves behind an aftereffect of the sin, which still needs to be purified. As explained in the classic work "Gates of Repentance":

And behold that there are many levels of repentance. It is true that you will find forgiveness for any repentance. However the soul will only find complete purification - to be as if the iniquities never had been - when a person purifies his heart and prepares his spirit, as will be explained. And so is it written (Psalms 32:2), "Happy is the man whom the Lord does not hold guilty, and in whose spirit there is no deceit." And it is like the matter of a garment that needs washing: For a little washing will be effective to remove its soiling. However, it will [only] whiten according to the amount of washing. And so is it written there (Psalms 51:4), "Wash me thoroughly of my iniquity."

In fact the entire fourth part of the work focuses on this topic. It begins:

In the same way as the body has sicknesses and ailments, so too does the soul. And the ailments of the soul and its diseases are its evil traits and its sins. But when an evildoer repents from his evil path, God, may He be blessed, heals the soul of the sinner - as it is stated (Psalms 41:5), “O Lord, have mercy on me, heal my soul, for I have sinned against You.” And it is [also] stated (Isaiah 6:10), “and repent and save itself.” And in the way that it is sometimes found with the sicknesses of the body that the sickness lightens itself from upon one, as does the length of most of the ailments, but the body is not cleansed of it without drinking a bitter drink and suffering further by afflicting his soul from [eating] all desirable food; so too is it with the soul sick from great iniquity: And even though most of the sickness is healed, and most parts of the punishment are removed after the repentance - and God, may He be blessed, has gone away from His anger - the soul will not yet be cleansed from the sickness and its sin will not be atoned until the sinner is made to suffer with afflictions, purified with pain and with bad and difficult things that happen to him.

So in the prayer Eleh Ezkerah and many others like it we beseech G-d to recognize our suffering and count it towards our full atonement.

title: When did the Rebbe say "his soul is in me"?
content:
# When did the Rebbe say "his soul is in me"? ## Frage

B"H

One of the arguments that the Chabad messianic group makes for the Rebbe allegedly being the Messiah is that they claim he said that his predecessor, Rabbi Yosef Yitzchak Shneurson, (זי"ע), was the Messiah, and "his soul is in me".

Right now, I'm searching for the source where he allegedly said "his soul is in me". Maybe he was saying his soul is in every Jew, or some other context, I would like clarification

This is different from the general questions on here which ask if he says he's moshiach or not etc., because I'm only looking for this one specific source.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

B"H

Here's is the OCR of the text from purim 5711, as was mentioned by shmosel in the comments

The quotes are based on what people claim to have heard, but they are not edited and checked by the Rebbe himself

כט. כ"ק אדמו"ר שליט'יא התחיל לדבר על עצמו (בהמשך להנ"ל ע"ד הצורך לצאת ממציאותו), והמשיך לדבר אודות ענין הנשיאות, ובין הדברים בכה ואמר: "מי אני ומה אני", "איך ווייס גיט פאַרוואָס מאַטערט מען מיר, פּאַרוואָס האָט מען אַייך פאַרבונדן צו מיר און מיר צו אַייך"...

בין הדברים פנה לא' מזקני החסידים ואמר לו: בנוגע לחנוכת בית שני מצינו*' ש""הזקנים אשר ראו את הבית הראשון .. בוכים". -- אתם, שהייתם אצל כ"ק אדנ'יע ואצל כ"ק מו"ח אדמו"ר, ה"ז גבורה מצדכם שאינכם בוכים... בשלמא אצל כ"יק אדנ"יע, הי' בנו יחידו ממלא מקומו, אבל עכשיו?!..,

[כמה מזקני החסידים ניגשו אל כ"ק אדמו"ר שליט"א ואמרו שחסידים אינם רוצים לשמוע דיבורים כאלה, וא' הכריז: "איר זייט דער רבי, עס איז איין המשך און איין שלשלת פון דעם אַלטן רביץ'""י, וביקש משקה מכ"ק אדמו"ר שליט"א, באמרו, שרוצה לקבל משקה "פון דעם אַלטן רביץ"! -- כ"ק אדמו"ר שליט'"א חייך, ונתן לו משקה].

בהמשך הדברים היו גם כמה ביטויים ע"ד ההתקשרות אליו, ומהם:

כנראה, אין לכם ברירה אחרת, וגם לי אין ברירה אחרת... "איך זאְג זיך ניט אֶפ"... "איך בין נאֶר א צינור", "מקושר דארף מען זיין צום רביץ, איך בין א ממלא מקום נאָר אין איין פרט".

בין הדברים אמר:

לאחר הסתלקות כ"ק אדנ'יע אמר פעם כ"ק מו"ח אדמו"רי*י שאינו אומר אודות אביו "נשמתו עדן", שכן, לשם מה לומר "נשמתו עדן" כשנקל וטוב יותר לומר "נשמתו בי".

(וסיים כ"ק אדמו"ר שליט'"א:) כך גם על הרבי -- אינני אומר ינשמתו עדן", אלא "נשמתו בי"!...

ל. [כ'יק אדמו"ר שליט"א צוה לנגן ניגון ד' הבבות לאדמו"ר הזקן, והניגון "ניע זשוריצי כלאֶפצי". ואח"כ אמר:]

Free translation:

The Rebbe, may he live and be well, began to speak about himself (continuing from what he had said earlier about the need to go out of one’s own self), and continued speaking about the matter of Nesius (leadership). In the middle of his words, he cried and said:

“Who am I, and what am I?” “I don’t know why they bother me — why have you been connected to me, and I to you...?”

In the middle of his words, he turned to one of the elder Chassidim and said to him:

“Regarding the dedication of the Second Beis HaMikdash, we find that ‘the elders who had seen the First House… were crying.’ You, who were by my father-in-law the Rebbe, and even by the Rebbe Rashab — it’s a show of strength from you that you’re not crying… It’s understandable by the Rebbe Rashab, because his only son succeeded him — but now?!...”

[Some of the elder Chassidim then came up to the Rebbe and said that Chassidim don’t want to hear such talk. One of them called out: “You are the Rebbe — it’s one continuation, one chain from the Alter Rebbe!” And he asked for mashke (a drink) from the Rebbe, saying he wanted to receive it “from the Alter Rebbe!” The Rebbe smiled and gave him mashke.]

As he continued speaking, he also said several things about hiskashrus (connection to the Rebbe), including:

“Apparently, you have no other choice — and I also have no other choice... I don’t say of myself anything... I’m just a conduit (tziner). One must be connected to the Rebbe — I’m only a successor in one specific aspect.”

In the middle of his words he said:

After the passing of the Rebbe Rashab, my father-in-law the Rebbe once said that he doesn’t say about his father ‘Nishmaso Eden’ (‘his soul in Eden’), because — why say ‘his soul in Eden’ when it’s easier and truer to say ‘his soul is within me’?”

(The Rebbe concluded:) “So too regarding the Rebbe — I don’t say ‘his soul in Eden,’ rather ‘his soul is within me!’”

Then the Rebbe instructed to sing the Niggun Daled Bavos (the Four Stanzas of the Alter Rebbe) and the niggun Nyet Zhurnitsi Klaptsi (“We Won’t Bow Down”).

title: Is it halachically valid to rebuild the Beit HaMikdash if we have doubts about the line of Kohanim?
content:
# Is it halachically valid to rebuild the Beit HaMikdash if we have doubts about the line of Kohanim? ## Frage

The Kohanim managed the day to day responsibilities of the temple and their line was preserved and protected through stringent practice.

But since the exile - while I do trust the community has managed to maintain the validity of Kohanim lines - we don't have the same "guarantee" that our ancestors did when it came to the Kohanim of ancient Israel. The fact we all lived in one place and could manage those issues prevented doubt. Galut changed all of that as while we still have Kohanim, all documentation and facts stop beyond a specific point. No Kohan alive today (as far as I know) can truly validate their line that far back.

This leads to my question.

There are groups which wish to rebuild the Beit HaMikdash. They believe it is the responsibility of the Jewish people to restart temple processes in an effort to more fully connect with God and redeem Klal Yisrael.

While I fully endorse the end goal and the hope for a third temple, my question is whether this goal is a violation in and of itself due to the Kohanim issue.

What I mean is if we don't have a guarantee about the priesthood's status anymore, we run the risk of inviting a population of people in to manage the temple who have no business managing the temple. Not due to their character but due to the restrictions around lineage. They literally would not be allowed to stand where they'd need to be. What I'm asking is does the very act of restarting temple processes in a questionable way overrule the benefits to the Jewish people if we did so in a wrong way?

I know that the Rabbinate of Israel formally bans Jews from the Temple Mount in part because they are concerned some Jews may go in beyond the archway and violate the sanctity of the location. This makes me wonder if that same rule would apply if we had the opportunity to rebuild the temple.

Would Hashem recognize we are trying and relax his standards due to the circumstances of galut or would he be displeased with the temple restarting if it was done in an incorrect way? The fact we managed this long without it makes me wonder if we'd be forcing something we ultimately shouldn't.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

There are essays on this topic (in Hebrew) here and here, with numerous sources cited. Some relevant points:

  • There are in fact Acharonim (R. Yaakov Emden, R. Kook, etc.) who say that even nowadays there are Kohanim who have family trees that establish their yichus. So according to them the question is obviated.

  • The Mabit, the Bach, R. Chaim Ozer, etc., hold that Kohanei Chazakah are perfectly valid for the avodah.

  • The Chasam Sofer, the Chazon Ish, etc., say somewhat differently: while indeed we should have Kohanim with established yichus to do the avodah, the ones with chazakah can fill in until then.

title: Taking something without permission
content:
# Taking something without permission ## Frage

I teach in a yeshiva and found a cheese danish in a shopping bag under my desk. I tried to locate the Rebbi who uses the classroom in the morning, but I was told he already left for the day. I started thinking that the sandwich would get hard overnight, so I gave a kid a piece and ate the rest.

In hindsight, I should not have done this.

I saw the Rebbi a few days later and he said it belonged to him. He said he had left and boarded a plane for a Simcha. He wanted to text me to take it, as it would otherwise go to garage; but he’s forgotten to text me.

Being that, in retrospect, he wanted to give it to me, did I do anything wrong by taking it? Do I need to do teshuvah for this?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

I'm not a posek, please ask your LOR

There seems to be a machloket in this matter:

  1. Tosfoat Bava Metzia 22a ד״ה מר זוטרא לא אכל, Hagahot Ashri, and Hagahot Mordechai brought down by the Shach Choshen Mishpat Siman 358 Seif Katan 1 say that one is not allowed to eat without the owners knowing, even if one knows that the בעלים will be happy that the person ate it (see the Ketzot Siman 109:5 and 262:1 and Shulchan Aruch Harav Hilchot Metzia Upikadon Seif 4).
  2. Shach Choshen Mishpat Siman 358 Seif Katan 1 says that if the owners would be happy that the person took it to eat, one can eat it even if the owner doesn't know (see שו״ת נודע ביהודה תנינא אבע״ז סימן עז, נתיבות המשפט סימן רמד סק״א).

Conclusion: It would seem that in this case, since you didn't know if the Rebbi would have wanted you to eat the cheese danish or not, since he could have come back the next day (you didn't know he was flying to a simcha) according to everybody then it would not be allowed to eat it or distribute to other talmidim and would be gneiva. In order to prevent food from rotting, you could have put it in a fridge or freezer and then return it when the Rebbi would have come back so as to prevent the issur of בל תשחית. We don't look at thing retroactively in cases of gneiva or gzeila.

With regards to teshuvah: if the Rebbi is מוחל then you're all good. If not, then you need to pay him back the amount it cost and do teshuvah on it, and learn the halachot of גניבה so it doesn't happen again.

title: Phraseology of teaching Torah as both "making" and "giving birth"
content:
# Phraseology of teaching Torah as both "making" and "giving birth" ## Frage

The Gemara in Sanhedrin 99b writes:

אָמַר רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ: כׇּל הַמְלַמֵּד אֶת בֶּן חֲבֵירוֹ תּוֹרָה, מַעֲלֶה עָלָיו הַכָּתוּב כְּאִילּוּ עֲשָׂאוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְאֵת הַנֶּפֶשׁ אֲשֶׁר עָשׂוּ בְחָרָן״.

Reish Lokish said: With regard to anyone who teaches Torah to the son of another, the verse ascribes him credit as though he made that student, as it is stated: “And Avram took Sarai his wife…and the souls that they formed in Charan” (Genesis 12:5). They are given credit for forming the students to whom they taught Torah.

The Maharsha explains this is because a person can only exist when he has Torah and therefore supplying him with Torah makes him able to be created. Furthermore, the Gemara in Avoda Zara 9a says that the two thousand years of Torah in the world start from Avraham when he taught Torah.

However, the Gemara in Sanhedrin 19b says the same idea, but changes the phraseology to:

אָמַר רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר נַחְמָנִי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹנָתָן: כׇּל הַמְלַמֵּד בֶּן חֲבֵירוֹ תּוֹרָה, מַעֲלֶה עָלָיו הַכָּתוּב כְּאִילּוּ יְלָדוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְאֵלֶּה תּוֹלְדֹת אַהֲרֹן וּמֹשֶׁה״, וּכְתִיב: ״וְאֵלֶּה שְׁמוֹת בְּנֵי אַהֲרֹן״. לוֹמַר לָךְ: אַהֲרֹן יָלַד וּמֹשֶׁה לִימֵּד, לְפִיכָךְ נִקְרְאוּ עַל שְׁמוֹ.

Rabbi Shmuel bar Nacḥmani says that Rabbi Yonasan says: Anyone who teaches another person’s son Torah, the verse ascribes him credit as if he gave birth to him, as it is stated: “Now these are the generations of Aharon and Moshe” (Numbers 3:1), and it is written immediately afterward: “And these are the names of the sons of Aharon: Nadav the firstborn and Avihu, Elazar, and Isamar” (Numbers 3:2), but it does not mention the names of Moshe’s children. This serves to say to you that Aharon sired his children, but Moshe taught them Torah. Therefore, the children were also called by his name.

  1. So we see that the Gemara switches from "making" to "giving birth", does anyone pick up on this change in phraseology? I know the easy answer is that we can say it is quoting different Amoraim but wondered if there is anything more to say?

  2. And perhaps we can say further, that there is a question on the second Gemara on 19b because the whole posuk says:

וְאֵלֶּה תּוֹלְדֹת אַהֲרֹן וּמֹשֶׁה בְּיוֹם דִּבֶּר ה’ אֶת מֹשֶׁה בְּהַר סִינָי

In other words, it describes when Moshe learnt from Hashem, so how could the Gemara say that Moshe teaching was as if he gave birth if the posuk was only discussing Moshe learning. It must be that when Moshe was already learning and possessed that yearning to give it over, already from then it’s considered as if he gave birth to them?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

So I asked this question to someone and they made the following suggestion:

The only difference in the two Gemaras is the word "את".

The Gemara on 99b says:

כל המלמד את בן חבירו תורה

while the one on 19b merely says

כל המלמד בן חבירו תורה (without the את).

So perhaps we can explain the difference between creating and giving birth. When someone is giving over only to a specific person as conveyed with the word את, then it’s merely a level of creating that person which the person possesses full control over just like creating a certain object.

However, if someone just has כל המלמד בן חבירו תורה without anyone in specific and he is open to teach everyone, as we find by Moshe that already from the time he was learning he had in mind to teach anyone, then he gets the higher level of actually giving birth to them which we know a person has no direct control over.

In the Seder Hachalitza as found in the back of Shulchan Oruch Even Ha’ezer, the Mechaber writes that:

Sefaria Link

מצאתי כתוב בסדר אשכנז וכשיעמדו יאמר הרב בא"י אמ"ה אקב"ו במצות וחוקים של אברהם אבינו והטעם מדאמרינן בפרק כיסוי דם בשכר שאמר אברהם ועד שרוך נעל זכו בניו למנעל של חליצה ויש לאומרו בלא הזכרת שם ומלכות:

translation: I found it written in an Ashkenazi order of service: When they stand, the rabbi should say: "Blessed are You, Hashem, our God, King of the Universe, Who has sanctified us with the commandments and statutes of Avraham our father." And the reason is that we say (in Tractate Chullin, Chapter Kisuy HaDam) that in reward for Avraham saying “from a thread to a sandal strap” (Bereishit 14:23), his descendants merited the shoe used in the act of chalitzah. So far as I can tell, however, the gemara in Chullin (89a; and this is also in Sota 17a) says that זכו בניו לשתי מצות לחוט של תכלת ורצועה של תפילין ("his children merited two mitzvot, the thread blue in tsitsis and the strap of tefillin") but there is nothing there about חליצה.

title: Why did these gedolim seemingly regularly not daven with minyan for sake of focused intense learning?
content:
# Why did these gedolim seemingly regularly not daven with minyan for sake of focused intense learning? ## Frage

I know of two Gedolim who apparently went into "seclusion mode" in their youth in order to learn Torah. Interestingly, they both went to a hut by a river.

  • The first is the Arizal, who did so when he started learning the Zohar and developing his system (source: Wikipedia). He only came home for Shabbat.

  • The second is the Bava Sali z'tl (I think! Maybe it was HaRav Kaduri z'tl), who also did this when he was younger. I can't remember which biography I saw this in.

I am assuming they both missed minyan during the week at those times. There are other examples of Gedolim missing minyan regularly:

  • The Chafetz Chaim z'tl would sometimes miss minyan (mincha and/or maariv) when writing his sefarim. See here: Chafetz Chaim and Maariv (thanks @JoelK)

  • The Lubavitcher Rebbe z'tl would daven Shacharis alone in his room throughout the year. See this Derher edition, first page. (Thanks @TheTargum)

Can someone explain the circumstances that they were seemingly able to do this? Was this halachically sound, and if so how? What is the precedent and how can one know if and when one should do the same?

Note: I'd prefer to avoid halachic politics. If some say they had precedent for this, and others say actually no, they had no precedent and those who say so are wrong, I'd rather not get into that. I'd rather hear from those who say they had precedent and how. We can ask another question about whether that's legitimate or not.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Three possible theories:

  1. Rabbeinu Yonah on the Rif Berachot 4a brings the opinion of the rabbonim of France that one need not leave one's place of learning in order to pray in a minyan because it is better to pray alone in a place designated for the study of Torah day and night than to pray in a shul in a minyan. So maybe that’s what the Arizal and others relied on.

  2. The Rema Orach Chaim Siman 90:18 (quoting Rishonim) says that someone for whom תורתו אומנתו (whose learning is his “occupation”), meaning that one does not waste any time not learning except for the absolutely necessary activities, may daven without being part of a minyan; however, nowadays this is discouraged. So perhaps the Arizal and others also relied on this.

  3. Piskei Teshuvot O.C 90:9 quotes the Pri Megadim Siman 101 Mishbetzot Zahav Seif Katan 1, and also brought in the Biur Halacha that says one is permitted to daven by himself if he is, גדול הדור ומפורסם שכל מעשיו לשם שמים, which could be someone like the Arizal and Baba Sali. In the Mishmeret Shalom 10:4 he says that those who want to have the kavvanot of the Arizal (which are long and require lots of concentration and no distractions) may daven themselves, so this may also explain the practice of the Arizal and Baba Sali (who was also a very big kabbalist).

title: Permissible Hefsek while reading The Megillah
content:
# Permissible Hefsek while reading The Megillah ## Frage

I wish to present a halachic inquiry regarding the reading of the Megillah, specifically regarding the practice of making certain verbal additions during the kriyah itself.

Specifically, I am curious whether there is room to permit the inclusion of the phrase “חרבונה זכור לטוב” within the reading, as mentioned by Rav Pinchas and others. We find this concept already in the Yerushalmi (Megillah 3:7), which describes that Rabbi Yonasan, upon reaching the verse mentioning Nevuchadnezzar, would pause and declare: “נבוכדנצר שחיק עצמות.”

The Gemara proceeds to ask why this was not similarly done when reading Nevuchadnezzar’s name in Yirmiyahu — clarifying that such an addition was made during the reading itself and not afterward.

This theme reappears in Bereishis Rabbah (49): רַבִּי בֶּרֶכְיָה וְרַבִּי חֶלְבּוֹ מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר נַחְמָן וְרַבִּי יוֹנָתָן... רַב כִּי הֲוָה מָטֵי לְהָמָן בְּפוּרִים, אָמַר אָרוּר הָמָן וַאֲרוּרִים בָּנָיו... אָמַר רַבִּי פִּינְחָס חַרְבוֹנָה זָכוּר לַטּוֹב.

The Matnas Kehunah there explains explicitly that Rav Pinchas made this declaration as he reached the verse mentioning Charvonah during his reading of the megillah: א"ר פנחס... בפורים כשהגיע לפסוק ויאמר חרבונה.

The Maharzu suggests alternatively that perhaps these expressions were said after the completion of the Megillah, to avoid any appearance of a hefsek between the berachos and the mitzvah of reading: ...אך במס' סופרים איתא בהדיא שרב אמר כן אחר קריאת המגילה... אפשר שהטעם משום הפסק הברכה והמ"ע יקיים אחר הקריאה.

Moving forward in time, the Shulchan Aruch (O.C. 690:16) codifies that one should say: צריך שיאמר ארור המן ברוך מרדכי... וצריך שיאמר וגם חרבונה זכור לטוב,

which seems to legitimize such additions as part of the reading experience itself.

Nevertheless, later authorities such as Peninei Halacha — and this appears to reflect the common custom — specify that these statements are recited after the Megillah reading: צריך לומר אחר הקריאה... וגם חרבונא זכור לטוב.

However, it would seem from other sources — including Shulchan Aruch O.C. 690:13, Yerushalmi Megillah 2:2, and Mishnah Berurah 690:19 — that a brief verbal interjection of this nature would not constitute a hefsek invalidating the reading. These sources indicate that not every interruption or reaction during the reading rises to the level of a prohibited hefsek, especially where it is derech kavod or derech mitzvah, as would be the case here.

Having reviewed these sources, my main question is as follows:

Is it halachically permissible, in principle, to make such additions during the reading of the Megillah itself — such as saying “חרבונה זכור לטוב” aloud upon reaching that verse — or would this nonetheless be considered an invalidating hefsek? Additionally, if this is permissible, would the same apply equally to a private reading (for oneself or one’s family) as to a public congregational reading?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

There is a discussion in the poskim with regards to saying ושם רשעים ירקב (pasuk in Mishlei 10:7) when getting to המן, which we would then apply to all other phrases mentioned in Masechet Sofrim 14:6 and other places.

The Magen Avraham 690:21 citing the Levush, the Shalmei Tzibur page 328, Chemdat Yamim Purim Perek 3, Hagahot Uminhagim Purim אות נה, permit to say ושם רשעים ירקב (Mishlei 10:7).

In Sefer Shenot Chaim Siman 32 footnote 16, Kaf Hachaim 690:11, Chazon Ovadia Purim page 93 forbid saying it.

What's the possible reason for both sides?

Side that permits it: Sha'ar hatziun 690:57 writes that it's not a hefsek based on Shulchan Aruch O.C 690:13; however there could be a big problem where if people start saying ושם רשעים ירקב every time Haman is mentioned, there will be many who won't be able to hear the words before or after Haman, which is a big problem. However, Rav Moshe in Igrot Moshe Orach Chaim 1:192 says that even if we use this Shulchan Aruch to permit saying ושם רשעים ירקב after every Haman, this is not a lechatchila thing to do, even though it's technically valid, since maybe in the case of the Shulchan Aruch, the guy never said a bracha before the meggilah reading. And the Tosfoat in Brachot 13a in the name of the Yerushalmi says that Brachot are not מעכב, and Tosfoat Brachot 14a says that by Hallel for Rosh Chodesh, if one doesn't say a bracha, it's not שייך to say that there is a הפסק. Furthermore, that Yerushalmi Meggilah 3:7 that Rebbi Yonatan said נבוכדנצר שחיק עצמות might have been during the reading itself, therefore the Yerushalmi says there is no הפסק, if you learn like that. Furthermore, maybe based on the Midrash in Yalkut Parashat Vayera, 82, it says that anyone who mentions a bad guy and doesn't curse him goes over a לאו. The proofs that one should do this even while reading the meggilah would be from the Midrashim (Ester Rabah פרשה י, Beresheit Rabah Vayeira פרשה מט, and Yerushalmi meggilah 3:7.

Side that doesn't permit it: Rav Moshe then concludes that the Rosh Meggilah 1:8 says that this saying was after kriat hameggilah, and Rebbi Yonatan just did it as he was learning the meggilah in depth. Therefore, because of a safek it is better not to say the phrase. In Chazon Ovadia Purim page 93 he brings in the argument that people might still not be able to hear the words before and after Haman which be very problematic.

Conclusion: From the Rav Moshe and Rav Ovadia in Chazon Ovadia Purim Page 93 and others, it seems that this should not be done lechatchilah (even though its technically permissible according to halacha) mainly because people might miss the words of the meggilah thus causing people to not fulfill the mitzvah.

I would think that even if the meggilah is being read for ones family it would still be a problem based on the reason that people might still not be able to hear the words before and after Haman, however if someone is reading it to themselves, then there would be no problem seemingly.

title: Is G.od the exclusive creator of life?
content:
# Is G.od the exclusive creator of life? ## Frage

In “The Religious Implications of Extraterrestrial Life” (first published in Tradition 7/8 [1965–66] and reprinted in Challenge, p. 396 n.31), Rabbi Norman Lamm suggests that Judaism does not require belief in God as the exclusive Creator of life.

Lamm (pp. 36 - 42), discussing the scientific possibility of lab made life states that the creation of life ex materia is not a contradiction to Judaism:

There is no fundamental of the Jewish faith that for its own dogmatic integrity, requires or implies the belief that God is the exclusive Creator of life.

Is Lamm correct in implying that Jewish faith does not necessitate belief in God as the exclusive Creator of life?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: -2)

The Ramban clearly believes that God has partners in creation. Commentary to Genesis 1:26

The correct explanation of na’aseh (let us make) [which is in the plural form when it should have been in the singular] is as follows: It has been shown to you that G-d created something from nothing only on the first day, and afterwards He formed and made things from those created elements. Thus when He gave the waters the power of bringing forth a living soul, the command concerning them was Let the waters swarm. The command concerning cattle was Let the earth bring forth. But in the case of man He said, Let us make, that is, I and the aforementioned earth, let us make man, the earth to bring forth the body from its elements as it did with cattle and beasts, as it is written, And the Eternal G-d formed man of the dust of the ground, and He, blessed be He, to give the spirit from His mouth, the Supreme One, as it is written, And He breathed into his nostrils the breath of life. And He said, In our image, and after our likeness, as man will then be similar to both. In the capacity of his body, he will be similar to the earth from which he was taken, and in spirit he will be similar to the higher beings, because it [the spirit] is not a body and will not die. In the second verse, He says, In the image of G-d He created him, in order to relate the distinction by which man is distinguished from the rest of created beings. The explanation of this verse I have found ascribed to Rabbi Joseph the Kimchite, and is the most acceptable of all interpretations that have been advanced concerning it.

title: Kayin, Hevel, Yaval, Yuval, Tuval-Kayin & Keinan
content:
# Kayin, Hevel, Yaval, Yuval, Tuval-Kayin & Keinan ## Frage

I find interesting that in the aftermath of Hevel's murder by Kayin, several characters in Bereshit perek 4 and 5 seem to share either partially, fully or a combination of Hevel or Kayin's names.

Do Yaval, Yuval and Tuval share the same root name as Hevel? If yes, what would be the significance of it?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

Rabbi Ahron Marcus in his commentary on Tanach (of which only the beginning of Beresheet was printed and hence survived the Holocaust), Keset Ha'Sofer, Beresheet 4:20 (new edition, p. 212; can be found on Otzar Hachochmah]) stated that the name "Hevel" means "son",1 and that all three of Lemech's sons' names - Yaval, Yuval, Tuval-Kayin - are connected to that root.

Regarding the significance of the similarities between the names, Ariel Feiglin, "For the Secret of Man (Adam) and Land (Adamah) - Between Adam & Kayin and the Commandments of the First Fruits and the Decapitated Calf" (בסוד אדם ואדמה - בין אדם וקין למצוות ביכורים ועגלה ערופה), Asif 5 (5778), p. 111 suggested that Kayin and his family attempted to make amends for the murder of Hevel via two fronts: Kayin built a city - Chanoch - which intended to fix the socio-international aspect of the world (building instead of destroying/killing), while his descendant Lemech named his sons after Hevel - intended to fix the personal-familial aspect of the world. Lemech also preserved Hevel's memory by marrying two women, as according to a midrash that one daughter was born with Kayin and two with Hevel.

Each of the three sons went on to amend Hevel's death in his own way: Yaval took up Hevel's mantle as a shepherd, and Yuval created music which is connected to the same pastoral lifestyle, and is also connected to Ruach Hakodesh (see Melachim 2:3:15), reflecting Hevel's closeness to Hashem. Tuval-Kayin is more complicated. He reflects a merge of Hevel and Kayin - he is named after Hevel like his brothers, but also after Kayin. He invented metal weapons that could be used to kill - detrimental to the world's development.2 His actions led to the killing of Kayin by Lemech (see Rashi on Beresheet 4:24). This necessitated the killing of Tuval-Kayin by Lemech, as justice. This reflects the completion of the seven-generations-long justice process for Hevel's murder.

Regarding Keinan, Rabbi Marcus, Keset, p. 220 suggested that it is an unrelated name that comes from Hebrew קינה, referring to the tragic event that took place during his father (Enosh)'s lifetime: The double flooding of the world (Beresheet Rabbah 23:7).

1 In his book on the development of the Hebrew language, Barzilai (Hebrew translation, can be found on Otzar Hachochmah), pp. 126-127, Rabbi Marcus clarified that "Hevel" comes from a Mesopotamian word, the Akkadian ablu, which had been proposed as a possible etymology for Hevel in the 19th century.

2 "Kayin" is a word that is also related to metallurgy. See some sources here. This was also noted by Rabbi Marcus in Keset, p. 212.

title: Numbers mi yodeya - how do we look at numbers in the Torah?
content:
# Numbers mi yodeya - how do we look at numbers in the Torah? ## Frage

I recently disagreed with a friend on the following question. I wonder if others can bring evidence.

Assumed: For various numbers the Torah seems to treat the number as being significant. (See the Mi Yodeya series here on every number you've ever heard of.) For example, there are many "threes" (Avraham, Yitzchak, and Yaakov; Pesach, Shavuos, Sukkos; Moshe, Aharon, Miriam;...) We seem to understand that there is some underlying idea that these "threes" share. The same is true for many examples of "fours", many examples of "tens", "forties", etc. Each number represents something shared by its examples; see the Maharal and many others who discuss what the underlying ideas are.

Question: Do we think that all the cases of "threes", say, should be matched up in a specific one-to-one way? So (as a Midrash says), Pesach is Avraham Avinu, Shavuos is Yitzchak, Sukkos is Yaakov. Or the Ten Makos in Mitzrayim match up with the Asarah Maamaros that created the world: see the Maharal who puts them in reverse order, and some Achronim who switch the order... As the examples show, sometimes that is a good idea. Is it always true?
Of course, it maybe be difficult or impractical to do it, above our level. But in theory, yes, you should be able to match up each "ten" one-to-one, and each "seventy", etc. That was my friend's position and he claimed his rabbeim would agree with him.

I thought that was absurd. לשבר את האוזן, just because something is a three-dimensional system, say, doesn't mean that there's only one way to choose the axes. Depending on where you're standing on the earth, Up/Down, Forward/Back, Left/Right can be completely different directions - all perfectly acceptable and all very different and independent. My "up" can be equal to a sum of parts of your "up, back, and left". Why should Moshe, Aharon, and Miriam have to represent the same three sides as Avraham, Yitzchak, and Yaakov do? Maybe they're three different kinds of side.
Do you really think that the seventy souls who went down to Mitzrayim, just because they correspond to the seventy nations, have to match up one by one? Which one is Kush and which one gets to be Peleg? Which of the seventy nations is from the side of Leah, and which from the side of Rachel or Bilhah? I'm not saying it's hard to decide. I'm asking why you're so sure that exactly one of them corresponds to exactly one of the other group. Maybe it's just the aspect of "seventy" that they share, along with the Sanhedrin, along with the Parim on Sukkos, but they represent very different ways of looking at that aspect.

Anyhow, does someone discuss this?

title: What part of liturgy is this line from?
content:

title: Meaning of הקריב in Bereshis 12:11
content:
# Meaning of הקריב in Bereshis 12:11 ## Frage

Rashi on Shemos 14:10 is troubled by the dikduk of ופרעה הקריב. If it meant that Pharaoh drew near, it would say קרב. The Hiphil form הקריב indicates that he caused someone to draw near. Rashi answers that he caused himself to draw near, that is, he pushed himself to lead the charge. (Elsewhere it's explained that he caused the Jews to become closer to Hashem.)

Bereshis 12:11, speaking of Avram's journey, seems to use a similar grammatical construction: ויהי כאשר הקריב לבוא מצרימה. Why doesn't Rashi take issue with the dikduk here? Shouldn't it say כאשר קרב?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Refer to the Perush Maharzu on Bereishis Rabbah 40:6

ויהי כאשר הקריב. פסוק זה מדבר בפרעה וזה צ"ע. שהרי עיקר הכוונה לדמות מעשה ישראל למעשה אברהם אך לא למעשה פרעה. אך לשון חכמים מרפא ומלמדנו דעת עומק הענינים. שהוקשה לחז"ל שהיל"ל כאשר קרב. על כן דורש אא"ע על קרבת המקום ת"ע על קרבת הלב שהרי לקיחת שרה לפרעה הוא אחד מיו"ד נסיונות. שאברם הבין וידע שתלקח שרה והקריב לבו ולבה להש"י על ידי פרעה ומצרים לבטוח בה' לעמוד בנסיון וזה סימן לישראל שנתקרבו ג"כ אל הש"י ע"י פרעה ומצרים אצל הים כמ"ש ופרעה הקריב ודרשו בשמ"ר פר' כ"א סימן ד' שהקריב לבן של ישראל לתשובה וזהו באמת הדמיון שאצל ישראל כתוב ופרעה הקריב ואצל אברהם כתוב כאשר הקריב. אחר זמן רב מצאתי כל זה מפורש בזוהר על פסוק זה כאשר הקריב ושמחתי כי כוונתי בדעת המדרש לאמתה של תורה. וז"ל הזוהר אר"א כאשר הקריב כאשר קרב מבעי ליה מאי כאשר הקריב אלא כדכתיב ופרעה הקריב דאיהו אקריב להו לישראל לתיובתא אוף הכי דאקריב גרמיה להקב"ה וכו': \nובישראל כתוב כל הבן. וס"ד וכל הבת תחיון: \nוייטב אלהים למילדות. והטובה היה מ"ש בסיפא וירב העם ויעצמו מאד הרי שהטובה לישראל: \nואברם כבד מאד במקנה. בכסף ובזהב לקמן פר' מ"א סוף סימן ב': \nויצו עליו פרעה. אנשים וישלחו אותו ובישראל כתיב ותחזק מצרים על העם למהר לשלחם מן הארץ ואין שילוח אלא לשון לויה כמ"ש במכילתא ריש בשלח ובשמ"ר פרשה כ

“And it came to pass, as he drew near…” – This verse speaks of Pharaoh, and this raises a question. For the primary intention is to compare the actions of Israel to those of Abraham, not to those of Pharaoh. However, the language of the Sages brings healing and teaches us the depth of matters.

The Sages were puzzled by the fact that the verse does not say “as he approached” (כַּאֲשֶׁר קָרַב), and therefore they interpreted it as referring to drawing near to the Omnipresent (God) – that is, drawing near with the heart. For the taking of Sarah by Pharaoh is one of the ten trials of Abraham. Abraham understood and knew that Sarah would be taken, and he offered his heart and hers to the Holy One, blessed be He, through Pharaoh and Egypt – to place their trust in God and withstand the test.

This serves as a sign for Israel, who also drew near to the Holy One, blessed be He, through Pharaoh and Egypt at the sea, as it is written: “And Pharaoh drew near” (וּפַרְעֹה הִקְרִיב). This is interpreted in Shemot Rabbah, Parashat 21, Section 4, to mean that Pharaoh brought the hearts of Israel closer to repentance.

This is the true parallel: in the case of Israel, it is written “And Pharaoh drew near,” and in the case of Abraham, it is written “as he drew near.”

After a long time, I found this very idea explicitly stated in the Zohar on this verse “as he drew near,” and I rejoiced, for my understanding of the Midrash aligned with the truth of the Torah.

And these are the words of the Zohar: Rabbi Elazar said, “‘As he drew near’ – it should have said ‘as he approached.’ Why does it say ‘as he drew near’? Rather, as it is written, ‘And Pharaoh drew near,’ meaning that he brought Israel near to repentance. So too, here, he brought himself closer to the Holy One, blessed be He,” etc.

title: What does Rashi mean "taryag mitzvos shamarti"?
content:
# What does Rashi mean "taryag mitzvos shamarti"? ## Frage

In his message to Eisav in Bereishis 32:5, Yaakov says "עם לבן גרתי - I lived with Lavan," upon which Rashi famously says "עם לבן גרתי ותריג מצוות שמרתי - I lived with Lavan and I fulfilled the 613 mitzvos."

What does this mean? Best case scenario, he didn't fulfill all 613 mitzvos because no individual can, as many are designed for kohanim in the Bais Hamikdash. Furthermore, he married two sisters in direct violation of the Torah - and even if you argue that he wasn't obligated to keep the Torah because he was in Chutz La'aretz, he's still claiming to have done so!

title: Sephardic Tefillin: One or Two Mitzvot?
content:
# Sephardic Tefillin: One or Two Mitzvot? ## Frage

For Sephardic Jews, is the arm and head Tefillin considered a single mitzvah or two separate mitzvot? They recite one blessing for both, while Ashkenazi Jews recite a separate blessing for each Tefillin, from what I understand.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The number of mitzvos do not change because someone made one or 2 blessings on tefilin. The source for making only one bracha to cover both is found in the talmud menachos 35b where it is explained you only make a second bracha on the shel rosh if one interrupted and spoke after putting on the shel yad. This is also brought down in the rambam hilchos tefilin chapter 4 halachos 4 and 5.

title: Jew without Brit Milá: Can they wear Tefillin?
content:
# Jew without Brit Milá: Can they wear Tefillin? ## Frage

Can a Jew born to a Jewish mother, who has not yet undergone Brit Milá (circumcision), put on Tefillin?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

As mentioned in the comments, Teffilin is not one of the mitzvot that an uncircumcised person cannot fulfill. The following is the list of mitzvot that an uncircumcised person cannot fulfill (teffilin not being there):

  1. Korban Pesach- see Shemot 12:48

  2. Terumah- see Gemera in Yevamot 70a.

  3. Kodshim- see Rambam Maseh Korbanot 10:9

  4. Avodah in Beit Hamikdash- See Zevachim 22b

  5. Circumcising others- If the person didn't want to get a brit milah on purpose, then he can't circumcise others, see Yoreah Deah 2:7.

  6. Korban ראיה- see Chagigah 4b, and Rambam Hilchot Chagigah 2:1 (although this might be a bit different since it says פטור and not אסור).

7. Uncircumcised Kohen for Birkat Kohanim- see Bach O.C 128:44, שיירי כנסת הגדולה סימן קכח:כד, Pri Chadash 128:39, Pri Megadim 128 Eshel Avraham Seif Katan 54, Eliyah Rabah 128:69, and others.

8. Getting an aliyah- In the Minchat Yitzchak 4:10 he says not to give an uncircumcised person an aliyah; however, the Sridei Eish I:11 and Igrot Moshe 2:33 say it's allowed.

If I missed any please let me know, but the idea behind doing this is to show all the examples that an uncircumcised person cannot fulfill and how teffilin is not on the list.

title: Origins of the Perizi
content:
# Origins of the Perizi ## Frage

Do we know the origins of the people known as the Perizi people who are mentioned in Parashath Lech Lecha, Sefer Bereishith 13:7?
Who was their ancestor going back towards Noach?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

Ibn Ezra (Shemos 3:8) says that they are from צידון, the son of כנען (see Bereishis 10:15).

### Antwort 2 (Score: 4)

Following Ibn Ezra's suggestion as brought in @S. Dixler's answer, various supercommentaries on Ibn Ezra attempted to explain the rationale behind the identification. The best explanation I've seen was brought in Rabbi Yitzchak Meller's Ezra Le'Havin on Shemot 3:8:

"צידון. שהרי מצינו גבי אברהם והכנעני והפריזי אז וגו' הרי שהוציא את הפריזי לחשבו לבד. לז"א (=לפיכך זאת אומרת) שהפריזי הוא צידון בכור כנען. שהיה גבולו לבד מהכנעני כמ"ש (=כמו שכתוב) ויהי גבול הכנעני מצידון. ונקרא הפריזי כמ"ש בשופטים אל עם שוקט ובוטח כמשפט צידונים. משמע שהיו יושבים בערי הפרזות."

"Tzidon. For we find regarding Avraham "and the Canaanite and the Perizzite were at the time etc", for we find that the Perizzites were viewed as separate. Therefore, that means that the Perizzite is Tzidon, Canaan's eldest. For his territory 's boundaries were separate from that of the Canaanite, as it is written: "The Canaanite territory extended from Tzidon". And they were called Perizzite, as it is written in Shoftim "to...a tranquil and unsuspecting people", "after the manner of the Tzidonim". Meaning, that they lived in unwalled cities.

In other words, the suggested rationale behind the Ibn Ezra's statement is thus: During the time of Avraham, the Perizzites were apparently a prominent enough people to be described as separate from the rest of the Canaanites. Elsewhere, in the description of the Canaanite families in Parashat Noach, Tzidon (Sidon) is also described as distinct from the other families, as all of the families were included in the territory of Canaan, while Tzidon was described as having a separate territory. As for why the Tzidonim were known as Perizzites, this question is clarified in a verse in Shoftim which describes people from Tzidon (or at least closely connected to them) living tranquil lives, which appears to indicate they lived in unwalled cities - not fearing any enemy attacks.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 1)

From the hebrew wiki entry on פריזי

The Perizzite are never mentioned anywhere separately from the other Canaanite nations. In fact, they aren't t even mentioned in the list of the sons of Canaan:

"וּכְנַעַן, יָלַד אֶת-צִידֹן בְּכֹרוֹ וְאֶת-חֵת: וְאֶת-הַיְבוּסִי, וְאֶת-הָאֱמֹרִי, וְאֵת הַגִּרְגָּשִׁי:" — Book of Genesis, Chapter 10, verses 15–16

Arel Segal Halevi writes that it is possible that the term “Perizzite” is merely a designation given to a portion of Canaan’s descendants (perhaps among the sons of Canaan who did not become separate nations — such as the Arkite, the Sinite, the Arvadite, etc.), possibly because they lived in villages and unwalled towns (arei perazot), as it is written:

"וְעַכְבְּרֵי הַזָּהָב מִסְפַּר כָּל עָרֵי פְלִשְׁתִּים לַחֲמֵשֶׁת הַסְּרָנִים מֵעִיר מִבְצָר וְעַד כֹּפֶר הַפְּרָזִי..." (Book of Samuel I, Chapter 6, verse 18). And Rashi explains: "כפר הפרזי" — a village without a wall.

Also written in Ezekiel: "וְאָמַרְתָּ אֶעֱלֶה עַל אֶרֶץ פְּרָזוֹת אָבוֹא הַשֹּׁקְטִים יֹשְׁבֵי לָבֶטַח כֻּלָּם יֹשְׁבִים בְּאֵין חוֹמָה וּבְרִיחַ וּדְלָתַיִם אֵין לָהֶם" (Book of Ezekiel, Chapter 38, verse 11).

It may be inferred that peoples who lived in unwalled towns were peaceful nations engaged in trade rather than war. Accordingly, the Perizzite was also a quiet and tranquil people — perhaps even more so than the Canaanite.

Ibn Ezra, in his commentary on the Torah, associates the nation of the Perizzite with “Sidon,” the firstborn son of Canaan.

title: What's the source of this story about pronouncing letters in the Talmud?
content:
# What's the source of this story about pronouncing letters in the Talmud? ## Frage

I remember reading a story in the Talmud about a Rabbi, who was seemingly being made fun of for his voice by another Rabbi. Someone else, maybe his father, told him to reply that the second person was constantly saying heresy whenever he prayed, because he pronounced Chet like Heh. (I think this referred to the root ch-l-l ("profane"), which he pronounced like h-l-l ("praise"), which reversed the meaning of whatever verse was under discussion.)

Where in the Talmud is this story found?

(Note: AI was used to make sure this was grammatical and clear)

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

It’s in Megillah 24b

אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַבִּי חִיָּיא לְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בַּר רַבִּי: אִלְמָלֵי אַתָּה לֵוִי — פָּסוּל אַתָּה מִן הַדּוּכָן, מִשּׁוּם דַּעֲבֵי קָלָךְ. אֲתָא אֲמַר לֵיהּ לַאֲבוּהּ. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: זִיל אֵימָא לֵיהּ: כְּשֶׁאַתָּה מַגִּיעַ אֵצֶל ״וְחִכִּיתִי לַה׳״, לֹא נִמְצֵאת מְחָרֵף וּמְגַדֵּף?

The Gemara relates that Rabbi Ḥiyya once said to Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi: If you were a Levite, you would be disqualified from singing on the platform in the Temple courtyard because your voice is thick. Rabbi Shimon went and told his father, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, what Rabbi Ḥiyya had said. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi said to him: Go and say to him: When you study and reach the verse: “And I will wait upon [veḥikkiti] the Lord” (Isaiah 8:17), will you not be a maligner and a blasphemer? Rabbi Ḥiyya, who was from Babylonia, was unable to differentiate between the letters ḥet and heh, and he would therefore pronounce the word veḥikkiti as vehikkiti, which means: And I will strike.

title: Sperm will die anyway - why is wasting seed a sin?
content:
# Sperm will die anyway - why is wasting seed a sin? ## Frage

From the Cleveland clinic:

Unejaculated sperm can stay alive in your testicles for about 2.5 months. Around this time, sperm cells die, and your body reabsorbs them.

The reabsorbtion does not contribute to the making of new sperm in any significant way but is repurposed throughout the body.

On this premise, why is the sin of wasting seed so bad, or really bad at all, if the sperm will be wasted anyway if not ejaculated?

title: Where in Tanach do we find a jewel as a source of light
content:
# Where in Tanach do we find a jewel as a source of light ## Frage

I am trying to find where in Tanach, other than in Noah's ark, is there a jewel as a source of light. I have checked the chumash in reference to light from the basket Moses was placed in and I believe there might have been some kind of jewel as light in the fish that swallowed Jonah.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

As per @DoubleAA's comment above, I don't know if you are specifically after sources direct in Tanach or also the commentaries, but if the latter, there is an incredibly insightful piece from Rabbeinu Bachya when detailing the choshen (in Parshas Teruma 28:15) and the various precious stones that were used.

When describing the stone that was used for Shevet Levi, it writes:

לוי היה מפותח על ברקת והוא הקרבונקל"א נקראת ברקת על שם שנוצצת כברק ומאירה כנר וכן תרגום ברקן, והוא אבן שתלה נח בתיבה ממה שכתוב (בראשית ו׳:ט״ז) צהר תעשה לתיבה והנביא קראה אקדח שנאמר (ישעיהו נ״ד:י״ב) ושעריך לאבני אקדח על שם שקודח כגחלת והוא מלשון (שם נ) קודחי אש, ונתנה ללוי מפני ששבט לוי היו מאירין בתורה כענין שנאמר (דברים ל״ג:י׳) יורו משפטיך ליעקב ותורתך לישראל, וכן משה שהיה משבט לוי כשנולד נתמלא כל הבית אורה ונאמר בו כי קרן עור פניו וכתיב (קהלת ח׳:א׳) חכמת אדם תאיר פניו, וסגולת האבן הזאת שהיא מחכימת פתי ומאירת העינים מלבד שמשתמשין בעצם גופה כמו שמשתמשין באור הנר...

The stone which bore the name of Levi was the ברקת, known popularly as carbuncle (a rounded gemstone without facets). It is so called as it flashes just like a bolt of lightning, ברק. It illuminates like a lamp. Onkelos also translates it as ברקן, a flashing stone. This was the gemstone Noach hung in the ark to provide him with light. The Torah referred to this light in Genesis 6,15 צהר תעשה לתבה. Isaiah refers to it as אקדח, in Isaiah 54,12 where, speaking of the future of Israel he writes: ”I will make your battlements rubies and your gates of precious stones, i.e. לאבני אקדח.” The name is justified as it appears glowing like red-hot coals. A similar expression occurs also in Isaiah 50,11: “kindlers of fire.” The reason this stone was chosen to symbolise Levi was that the Levites illuminate the people by teaching them spiritual illumination, i.e. Torah, as we know from Deut. 33,10 יורו משפטיך ליעקב ותורתך לישראל, “they teach Your judgments to Yaakov and Your Torah to Israel.” We also know of Moses, who was of the tribe of Levi, that the whole house was filled with light when he was born as the Midrash (Shemot Rabbah 1,24) interpreted the words in Exodus there (Exodus 2,2) that “she (his mother) saw that he was good.” Furthermore, when Moses returned from Mount Sinai with the second sets of Tablets the Torah testified that the skin of his face emitted rays of light (Exodus 34,29). We have another verse (Kohelet 8,1) “a man’s wisdom lights up his face.” The positive value of this gemstone is that it is apt to enlighten the foolish, providing him with insights he never had. This is in addition to the general usefulness of that jewel in providing light just as does a lamp.
