title: Why are there two different versions of the vowels in lekh-lekha?
content:
# Why are there two different versions of the vowels in lekh-lekha? ## Frage

Preparing to leyn next week, I noticed that a word in Bereshit 12:3 appears very slightly differently in different versions. On the version on Sefaria (JPS's Contemporary Torah) and tikkun.io, it's מְבָ֣רְכֶ֔יךָ , while in my the weekday readings section of my Artscroll and my Koren, as well as Chabad's version, it's מְבָ֣רֲכֶ֔יךָ . In particular, under the resh, there's a shva (na) in the former and a khataf patakh in the latter.

The difference in pronunciation is minor in my pronunciation, but I'd like to leyn the "right" pronunciation. I'd also like to understand what's going on. Is this a typo in one? Are there multiple versions of the Masoretic text? Do different groups use different versions? Is there a list of variations somewhere so I know when to be aware of this?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

See the comments and answers at DoubleAA’s link.

In the Masoretic era, Shva was pronounced exactly like chataf-Patach by default. So many Masoretes would replace certain instances of Shva naʿ with a chataf-Patach, in order to clarify that the Shva should be pronounced in that situation.

Nowadays, most Jews pronounce Shva naʿ like Segol, so the Masoretic trick to disambiguate Shva naʿ doesn’t apply to us. (The modern equivalent is printing Shva naʿ in a bold font.)

Several modern tiḳḳūnīm have unfortunately failed to understand this, and attempt to “fix” the vocalization of the Chumash by replacing Shva with chataf-Patach and claiming the vowel should be pronounced as such, as opposed to Shva naʿ. This is historically mistaken. In all such words, the essential vowel is a simple Shva naʿ. That’s the vowel that was intended by the Masoretes, and that’s the vowel we’re meant to pronounce.

In short, the Shva’s right.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

I will not address the pronunciation part of the question, which has already been ably addressed above. But will address this part of the question:

Are there multiple versions of the Masoretic text? Do different groups use different versions? Is there a list of variations somewhere so I know when to be aware of this?

Edit: the answer I originally gave (preserved below) is for the wrong word. The correct word, i.e. the word asked about in the original question, does not have חטף פתח on its ר in the authoritative manuscripts, but does have חטף פתח on its ר in the printed tradition, stemming back, as it often does, to the 2nd Venice MG (see comment below).

==== original, flawed answer appears below ====

MAM's decision was to have simple shewa, where that shewa is supplemented by varika in some editions. (MAM restricts the use of חטף shewa to gutturals but if one or more manuscripts of interest use חטף shewa on a non-guttural, it notes this with a varika.) To understand MAM's decision, and to see where notable manuscripts "land" on this issue, see an edition of MAM that shows its documentation, such as "MAM with doc."

Just to have it right here, here is how the documentation currently reads:

title: What is the Chabad tradition for starting the day as a Jew alone in the morning?
content:
# What is the Chabad tradition for starting the day as a Jew alone in the morning? ## Frage

I understand Chabad as having a unique style of Chassidism, emphasizing an awareness of the mystical aspects of Jewish practices while following Jewish tradition with orthodox rigor and zeal. I am not an orthodox Jew and don't know how the day usually starts for followers of the Chabad traditions. When I try to look it up, I mostly find prayers that are meant to be said during a service with a minyan.

How do Jews following Chabad start their days when they're alone and not able to go to a morning service? What are the rituals and prayers said?

More broadly I'd love to learn this answer for the whole day, how one structures their day, but even just understanding morning routines would be helpful. For example, I know the Modeh Ani prayer is said when one first opens their eyes in the morning, and then comes washing one's hands. Then at some point, laying tefillin facing east and saying some prayers. But I am missing lots of details and clarity, especially on what prayers are said when alone vs. in a communal service.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 6)
  1. The Modeh Ani (see source for the positioning).
  2. Washing Negel Vaaser.
  3. Dressing, going to a Mikva (ritual bath) if there's one in the area (some may even use a pool).
  4. Morning Prayers, Shema.
  5. Mezonot (pastries), coffee / tea to taste.
  6. Learn Chabad Chassidus.
  7. Shacharis. Whether or not you're praying with a minyan, preparing for prayer is the same: Start at Hareinu Mekabel, until Eizehu Mekomon at this point we lay the Talit (if applicable) and Teffilin. Recite Eizehu Mekoimon. After the Yehi Ratzon if you were praying with a minyan, the Chazzan would say Kaddish Derabbanan. Continue on to Hodu through Yishtabach. By a minyan, the Chazan would say Half Kaddish. Continue on to Yoitzer Or through after the Amida. By a minyan, at this point, the chazan would recite the repetition of the Amida. Continue on to Viduy (if applicable), through Oleinu (there are three Kaddeshim a Chazzan would do in between, and on Monday and Thursday there's the Torah reading). After the conclusion of prayer (Al Tirah), we say the Rebbe's Kapital (Psalms Chapter 124), and the Rebbitzins (125). Then Psalms Chapter 20, your own Chapter (the year of age you're entering, e.g. if you turned 30, you entered your 31st year - Chapter 31). Then the Daily Tehillim. After which, a Chazzan who is mourning would say Mourner's Kaddish. We remove our Rashi Teffilin and lay Rabbeinu Tam and (Shema, Vehaya etc). Then the Seven Remembrances.
  8. Study the Chitas and Rambam. This is done at a certain point during the day; many do this in the morning.

Mincha and Mariv follow; many set a time to learn a portion of Nigla at a certain point.

There are thousands of Chabad Chassidim away from the regular community element, hundreds not even having a Minyan to attend. That is because they are Shluchim, emissaries of the Rebbe, spreading Judaism in the most central regions to the far flung areas.

Praying, in our general view, isn't just a time we request our personal physical-spiritual needs from G-d, rather a format of connection to Him. It's not magical, though. To get there we learn about Him (learning Chabad Chassidus before praying), and contemplate about Him (using what we learned). To enhance the spirituality, we make our physicality most able - by eating some sort of Pastry, hence nourishing our bodies to be nourished by our soul.

With that foundation laid, the day is set on its proper path: renewal of energy and commitment to the service of G-d.

# Abarbanel's Timeline of Shoftim and Shmuel ## Frage

Does anyone have any resources on Abarbanel's timeline in Shmuel 1 Ch. 13?

Ideally, a timeline map, with lifespans and events according to Abarbanel's opinion throughout.

Anything would help tremendously.

My real question: After Abarbanel states his opinion of the timeline, he states two results that pertain to that chapter. In the first one, he states that Shmuel was judge from Eli's death to Shaul's Coronation [20 years], adding that that includes the 20 years that the Aron was in Kiryas Yearim before Klal Yisroel did Teshuva, and then 5 or 6 years before Shaul's coronation. That would mean that from Eli's death to Shaul's coronation is 25-26 years, not 20 as he mentioned in the timeline! Any thoughts?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Here's a timeline I made (click on the picture to enlarge it; the spaces between points on the timeline are a rough estimate and not intended to be accurate). The Abarbanel preferred including Shamgar's reign within the 80 years between Ehud and Yavin, but noted a variant option for Shamgar, having him rule for one year. This would shift all dates forward by one year until Shmuel's time, and then cutting down Shmuel's reign as judge by one year (19 years total instead of 20). Abarbanel assumed that all dates were accurate except for the "300 years" that had passed since the Israelite conquest of the Amorite (ex-Ammonite) territory in the 40th year from the Exodus, stated by Yiftach in his speech to the king of Ammon. title: Does Earth having a second moon affect halacha?
content:
# Does Earth having a second moon affect halacha? ## Frage

Apparently according to NASA Earth currently has a second moon, until the year 2083. I never considered the possibility that the Earth could gain additional moons. Whether or not the current asteroid is halachically classified as a moon, I would like to know if in the event that the Earth were to gain a natural satellite that would be halachically defined as a moon, would this impact Judaism in any way?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The "moon" is actually misnamed as such, and much of the media around it is a bit overhyped. The new asteroid is not orbiting Earth, but conducting an orbit around the sun that is close to Earth's. As such, it is not a "moon" but a space rock that happens to be close to us, and will dissapear in 2083 because it is not in a stable orbit around Earth.

Also, like @RabbiKaii and @shmosel said, halachically "moon" refers to Earth's current moon, the rounded object you can see in the sky.

If halachically a "moon" were any object orbiting the earth that you could see, than we could celebrate Rosh Chodesh every 90 minutes because the ISS could be considered a moon.

If earth really did have a second moon that was astronomically defined as one, I still think that halachically only our moon that we already are familiar with would count for calendar purposes.

As for the premise of the question, I think it is valid, since technically the question actually also includes the question inside a question of "what is halachically defined as a moon?"

title: Is this pronunciation of ה acceptable?
content:
# Is this pronunciation of ה acceptable? ## Frage

I have a friend who’s often the ש״ץ of a casual Minyan.

I’ve noticed that he occasionally pronounces ה very emphatically, such that it becomes strongly pharyngealized, and thus identical to the Mizrahi pronunciation of ח (henceforth “ħ”). He does this apparently at random.

It’s known that one should be careful not to mix up certain letters, since doing so can radically alter the meaning of certain words. One example found in the Talmud is accidentally pronouncing a ה like ח, regarding the roots ה־ל־ל and ח־ל־ל. The former means “praise”, while the latter means “desecrate”; so it’s important to pronounce the ה correctly in words derived from ה־ל־ל.

If my friend normally pronounced ח as “ħ”, this would obviously be problematic. Thing is, he pronounces ח the same way as כ, like Ashkenazim.

Is “ħ” considered a pronunciation of ח for my friend, even though that he doesn’t use it for ח? In other words, does “ħ” have an objective status as a pronunciation of ח?
(Does “ħ” being the original pronunciation make a difference? What about the fact that a portion of the minyan does use “ħ” for ח?)

If not, is “ħ” considered a valid free allophone of ה for my friend? Or is it still halachically undesirable for whatever reason?

In short, should he be more careful how he pronounces ה?

title: Connection between steps of Beis HaMikdash, Shir Hamaalos, and Mabul above mountains
content:
# Connection between steps of Beis HaMikdash, Shir Hamaalos, and Mabul above mountains ## Frage

There are 15 Shir Hamaalos in Tehillim (120–134), 15 steps in the Beis Hamikdash where the Levi'im sang, and 15 amos of water above the highest mountains by the Mabul. What is the connection?

(There are many more 15s, but I'll limit for now.)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

So look, the steps of the Beis HaMikdash - specifically these fifteen ma'alos that go up from the Ezras Nashim to the Ezras Yisrael - they have a very deep connection, mamash, to the fifteen "Shir HaMa'alos" in Tehillim, you know what I mean? These pesukim, the Levi'im were singing them on these very steps, and it represents, like, an aliyah - an ascent - in ruchniyus and kedushah. And the number fifteen itself, chamesh-esrei, is very significant, ken? Because it's connected to Hashem's Name - yud-hei (י-ה) - which shows us there's a kesher, a connection, between the physical aliyah and the Shechina, the divine presence, davka. Now, regarding the Mabul, the flood - the Torah tells us explicitly that the water rose fifteen amos above the highest mountains, right there in Bereishis 7:20. This number could symbolize, in a symbolic way, the koach of HaKadosh Baruch Hu that encompasses everything - both in destruction and also in protection of the briyah, the creation. So mamash, the number fifteen in these contexts - it connects the whole inyan of aliyah, of divine presence, and of Hashem's all-encompassing power, you see?

# Zera Yisrael 50% jewish is patrilineal Jewish,? ## Frage

I am a Soler Mater es Quadam 50 % Jewish and not raised jewish, is there a way to be Jewish then my biological father is American Jewish whom i dont know he was a Vietnam veteran. I even have dreams of shechita, it is hard to understand i have a non Jewish mother and non Jewish father. A childhood dentist told me once i am a descendant of the hebrew.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

"Zera Yisrael", is a term that rings with a Jewish flavor. Nevertheless, Jewish religious law articulates quite clearly, that a child who is born to a Jewish father and a non-Jewish mother is considered to be a non-Jew.

title: What is the discussion around the hashgacha behind our mesorah?
content:
# What is the discussion around the hashgacha behind our mesorah? ## Frage

In the SeforimChatter podcast episode on Talmud Reclaimed, around minute 1:05:00, R' Shmuel Phillips mentions the idea that our mesorah is guided by hashgachah min hashomayim, and he quotes the Chazon Ish as saying such. In the next sentence he mentions other gedolim of the time who took a very different, more proactive approach of attempting to analyze kisvei yad, etc.

Can anyone detail this machlokes - the two positions and those who held them, as well as how they have played out in the century that has followed - i.e. how is this machlokes viewed in different camps nowadays? For example, I've heard that Briskers reject the shinuyei nuscha'os of the Rambam that Frankel produced.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Several scholars have discussed this topic in detail. For an excellent summary, I recommend Yaakov Spiegel's book עמודים בתולדות הספר העברי: הגהות ומגיהים (can be found in Otzar Hachochmah and Kotar). This volume, part of a series on the history of the Jewish book, is dedicated to examining sources from throughout Jewish history on the topic of hagahot (annotations) and manuscript variations. In chapter 15 he discussed views on the topic from the late Enlightenment period (end of the 18th century) and the early modern era (19-20th centuries). As he cited, several prior scholars have written regarding Chazon Ish's views regarding the role of manuscripts in the field of Torah study and halacha, including: Zvi A. Yehuda, 'Hazon Ish on Textual Criticism and Halakhah', Tradition 18 (1980), pp. 172-180; Rabbi Shnayer Z. Leiman, 'Hazon Ish on Textual Criticism and Halakhah - a Rejoinder', Tradition 19 (1981), pp. 301-310; Rabbi Moshe Bleich, 'The Role of Manuscripts in Halakhic Decision-Making: Hazon Ish, His Precursors and Contemporaries', Tradition 27 (1993), pp. 22-55, and more.

Zvi A. Yehuda began his discussion by stating that he was once asked by the eminent Orthodox scholar Rabbi Dr. Binyamin Menashe Levine to ask the Chazon Ish - whom Yehuda knew personally - why yeshiva students (and the yeshiva world at large) don't use his then-newly-published Otzar Ha'Geonim, a work he had toiled upon for years and which he believed would have greatly enriched the study of yeshiva students. According to Yehuda, Chazon Ish responded:

"The old material, we have; the new, we don't need. The sources already printed are found in the works of the Rishonim, organically within the context in which they are quoted and the way they are discussed and treated; the sources now printed for the first time from Geniza manuscripts, whatever their importance may be for academic study, are irrelevant for halakhic consideration."

In other words, usage of material - minute as it may be - that was not known to earlier generations, those whose works form the basis of the modern halachic corpus - is extremely problematic, as it is not contained within said corpus. As such, this material did not undergo generations of refinement within the rabbinic crucible and is therefore irrelevant for current discussions of halacha.

Elsewhere, Chazon Ish noted regarding the nusach of the Munich manuscript of the Talmud (Ms. Munich 95), which is the only manuscript we have today of the entire Bavli, and which formed the basis for Rabbi Refael Natan Neta Rabinovicz's Dikdukei Sofrim. In response to seeing its usage within halachic discussions, Chazon Ish wrote (קובץ אגרות מאת חזון איש, vol. 1, no. 33 [cited by Spiegel, p. 544]):

"...ולהגיה בגמ' עפ"י כת"י מינכן, וכי כל חכמי הדור מזמן הראשונים עד עכשיו כולם לא עמדו על האמת, מפני שסופר אחד טעה והוסיף דברים בגמ' מלבו, והכשיל את כל החכמים. ואני לא מהם ולא מהמונם, וכת"י שהיה ביד הראשונים מסרו נפשם עליהם, והשגחתו ית' שלא תשתכח תורה מישראל הגינה עליהם, וכשהחלו להדפיס את הגמ' מסרו חכמי הדור נפשם על זיקוקו והגהתו. ואם אמנם לפעמים נהנים מהכת"י לנקות השיבושים המתהוים בהמשך הזמן, אבל דבר שיצא מיד כל רבותנו בלי שום פקפוק - חלילה להרוס. הגע בעצמך, בשעה שיש שלשה כת"י לפנינו ושניהם שוין, אנו לוקחים את השנים ומניחים את האחד, ומאן לימא לאן דכת"י מינכן אינו מאותו שנתבטל ברוב בזמנו, ומאן לימא לן שלא היה ידוע לבעלי מדוקדק, ובכל אופן הוא בטל כחרס הנשבר נגד הגרסא המקובלת, וכי מני שהסופר טעה והשמיט איזה תיבות [...] נבנה מגדלים, ואולי כן שהסופר השמיטם ולא מיד חכמים הוא, אבל כשאנו סומכים על הקבלה, תורת רש"י ותוספות וכל החכמים, ודאי היא התורה, וכמעט שלא ראיתי תועלת להגיע אל האמת ע"י הגירסאות שמחפשים מהגניזות, רק כולם תועלת לעוות משפט ולעקם את האמת, וראוי היה לגונזם, שההפסד יתר על השכר."

"...And to make corrections in the talmud according to Ms. Munich, and [should we think] that all of the sages of past generations did not uncover the truth, all because one scribe made a mistake and added things to the gemara from his mind, and caused all of the sages to stumble. And I am not of them and their kind, and manuscripts that were in the hands of the Rishonim they gave their lives over them, and the Blessed One's providence that the Torah shall not be forgotten from Yisrael protected them, and when the gemara began to be printed, the sages of the generation gave their lives to purifying and correcting it (=the nusach). And even though sometimes we enjoy from fixing errors formed over time within manuscripts, but something that undoubtedly came from the hands of our rabbis - God forbid that we destroy. See for yourself, when we have three manuscripts before us and two are equal, we take the two and leave the third, and who told you that Ms. Munich was not one of those that was canceled out in time, and how do you know that it (Ms. Munich) was not known to the annotating sages, and in any case, it (Ms. Munich) is canceled out like a broken pottery sherd in the face of the accepted (widespread) version, should we build towers from a version where the scribe made a mistake and left out some words, and perhaps the scribe is the one who left out the words and not sages, but when we rely on tradition, the Torah of Rashi and Tosfot and all of the sages, it is certainly the Torah, and I hardly saw any usage for reaching the truth based on versions pulled out from genizot, their entire usage is to simply distort the law and bend the truth, and it is appropriate to bury them, for the loss is greater than the gain."

In short, according to the Chazon Ish, widespread versions of sources are more trustworthy than ancient manuscripts, because we must believe that the popular versions were ones that were checked out, properly corrected and purified by earlier sages, and that Hashem's providence led to our possession of these popular versions. Chazon Ish also produced arguments specifically against Ms. Munich: It may well be that this manuscript was already known at the time of its production to be of poor quality in terms of its content. In the end, we really do not know what Jews of the past thought of its nusach. In other words, old and complete isn't necessarily better.

That's not to say that the Chazon Ish would have been entirely against the usage of manuscripts, as he himself noted that sometimes scribal errors may creep into manuscript traditions that had passed under the hands of sages. Rabbi Bleich in his article (pp. 38-39) noted a case where Rabbi Wosner ruled in favor of a version of Ra'avad cited by the Rosh and the Shulchan Aruch against the Chatam Sofer's interpretation of the Ra'avad, as a version of Ra'avad based on newly-discovered manuscripts proved that the former poskim's versions were more accurate than Chatam Sofer's, thereby rendering the latter's interpretation irrelevant. Such a case conforms with the Chazon Ish's view, according to Rabbi Bleich.

Rabbi Moshe Feinstein agreed with the Chazon Ish's position to some extent. His main criticism of critical editions of Jewish works was that they were often produced by academics and not men truly learned in Torah, which would often lead to severe mistakes in their reasoning. See a summary of his view in Rabbi Bleich's article, pp. 37-38. Rabbi Shlomo Zevin, who was part of the team that worked on Dikdukei Sofrim Ha'Shalem, agreed that manuscripts may only be used if they are in agreement with a textual tradition that can be found among the Rishonim. His rationale was that we today do not have the ability to discern correct textual versions and must trust the judgement of the giants of previous generations (Dikdukei Sofrim Ha'Shalem, vol. 5: Ketubot, pt. 1, p. 12; mentioned also by Rabbi Bleich, p. 42).

But the Chazon Ish also had some opponents on the issue. Rabbi Yechiel Yaakov Weinberg (author of Shu"t Seridei Esh), for example, noted on one hand that there is no reason to assume that a unique textual tradition found in the work of a rishon was necessarily flawed. The reverse may be true: That that book preserves the true, correct version. Therefore, Rabbi Weinberg wholeheartedly supported the publication of critical editions. See a summary of his view in Rabbi Bleich's article, pp. 35-37.

Another of the Chazon Ish's opponents on the matter was Rabbi Menachem Mendel Kasher (most well-know for his Torah Shelemah compendium), who began publishing the Gemara Shelemah, a critical edition of the Talmud based on multiple manuscripts. On the occasion of the publication of two volumes from a separate project, Yad Ha'Rav Herzog's Mishna Zeraim and Masechet Ketubot of Mif'al Ha'Shas Ha'Shalem, Rabbi Kasher published an essay on the importance of using manuscripts in the study of gemara ("להופעת שני כרכים ממפעל הש"ס השלם", Noam 16 [5733/1973], § Halachah, pp. 165-182). This essay was prefaced by an essay written by Rabbi Yisrael Rosen on the importance of Rabbi Kasher's work in the field of talmudic manuscripts ("להופעת שני כרכים ממפעל הש"ס השלם", ibid., pp. 156-165), and included copies of letters Rabbi Weinberg sent Rabbi Kasher (and herein we see the differences between the Chazon Ish and Rabbi Weingarten). Among other things, Rabbi Kasher responded to the Chazon Ish (simply referring to him as a "gadol ha'dor" without explicitly stating who he was speaking about. However, he quotes the above passage from Igrot, vol. 1):

Rabbi Kasher opened by expressing surprise at the Chazon Ish's wholesale rejection of manuscripts simply due to one scribal error in Ms. Munich, which led another contemporaneous rabbi to reach a faulty conclusion regarding that specific passage. He then noted the importance of Ms. Munich:

  • It is the only complete Shas manuscript that has survived to this day.
  • It was used by the author of the Korban Netanel.
  • Several prominent rabbis welcomed Rabbi Rabinovicz's publication of Dikdukei Sofrim, based on Ms. Munich. Rabbi Yosef Natansohn (author of Shoel U'Meshiv) in particular greatly valued the book and heaped praises on it. Other gedolim who praised the publication include Rabbi Yitzchak Elchanan Spektor, Rabbi Yaakov Ettlinger, and Rabbi Shlomo Kluger.

Rabbi Kasher then noted the flaws in the Chazon Ish's arguments:

  • The process of preserving two manuscripts against a third is only relevant for Written Torah (Tanach). The poskim never argued that the same rule applied to manuscript variants of Oral Torah works.
  • The reverse is actually true: There were poskim who argued that a manuscript with a unique textual tradition must also be taken into account (חוששין לו).
  • Many gedolim over the ages used variant manuscripts and textual traditions as a basis for their arguments.
  • The claim that "when the gemara began to be printed, the sages of the generation gave their lives to purifying and correcting it (=the nusach)" is simply incorrect - studies of the history of the printing of the Talmud shows that no gedolim were involved in correcting the nusach of the printed Shas. Again, the reverse is true - when gedolim began studying printed gemaras, they marked down the vast number of mistakes found in these editions.

It is therefore evident, noted Rabbi Kasher, that the many mistakes in the printed editions necessitate a critical study of the textual tradition of the Talmud, to discern what is the most correct text. Rabbi Kasher finished off this section of the essay by noting that the same (regarding using manuscripts and variant textual traditions to discern the correct text) should be argued regarding other Jewish works, from the time of the Geonim and onwards.

Where we are today: Rabbi Kasher had opened his essay by noting that it's clear to him that not every person has the intellectual capability to sift through textual variations and to properly understand how each variation arose, but he hoped that other talmidei chachamim (Yechidei Segulah as he referred to them) will join him, perhaps via Yad Ha'Rav Herzog, in working on producing a critical edition of the Shas and other important Jewish works, and that these editions will be welcomed by the yeshiva world. Nowadays, however, to my knowledge, it seems that for the general gemara (and other works)-studying public, the old printed editions largely remain triumphant, while the study of manuscript variants is mainly limited to the halls of academia, though can also be found among some individuals in the Torah/yeshiva world. Some yeshivas and Torah-background-type institutes publish on occasion new critical editions of Jewish books, typically the result of a joint effort between members of the institutions and more academically-leaning scholars. Sometimes such editions merit general popularity and sometimes they remain obscure.1 It's not entirely clear to me whether there are prominent "camps" today as there were back then (last century). Perhaps someone else can shed light on the matter.

1 Anecdotally, there's such an institute that's connected to my yeshiva (it was essentially founded by alumni and is situated near the yeshiva; note that I am otherwise unaffiliated with this institute) that published, among other books, a new edition of the S'fat Emet. I've heard that the Gerrer Rebbe keeps this edition on his desk.

title: Chacham Hillel Vs. Chassidic Kabbalah
content:
# Chacham Hillel Vs. Chassidic Kabbalah ## Frage

I heard from my friend Rabbi Botton that Chacham Hillel Shlita has a philosophical difference regarding the way of studying Kabbalah, with the Chassidim. He heard it in a class from a young Chacham but that's all he can tell me.

I don't know exactly what was said but the following do seem to apply:

  1. He wasn't saying that Chassidic learning is fundamentally wrong in and of itself
  2. He was framing it as a preference
  3. It isn't anything to do with the controversy regarding the Baal Shem Tov's use of "non-Vitalian sources".

I don't dare to misquote him, so please understand that this is just third hand "hearsay" and is only provided to help someone who might know respond, but it was something along the lines of him not liking the more philosophical, expansive way of explaining Kabbalah, with lots of deep connections between matters, bechina of this and bechina of that etc, e.g. the way HaRav Morgenstern Shlita teaches.

Can someone please confirm what he thinks about it more precisely, as well as explain it in more detail? Why doesn't he like what he claims to not like? What does he find wrong with it and what does he see value in his method over it? What precisely is his method in contradistinction to the "Chassidic" method? The more detail and clarity, the better.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Fascinating question.

I preface this answer by openly stating this is not an area of expertise, but I was intrigued by the question and therefore did some digging...

So, firstly some background as to the Chassidish approach.

It writes here:

Chassidut is inwardly based upon the ancient doctrinal tradition of Kabbalah. Outwardly it gives new emphasis to the simple and joyful service of God, particularly through prayer and acts of loving-kindness. In Chassidic thought, the abstract and often impenetrable formulae of classical Kabbalah are recast into the psychological terms of human experience.

By using the individual’s own inner experience as an allegorical model for understanding the deepest mysteries of the universe, Chassidut both elevates the consciousness of the ordinary Jew as well as expands the conceptual territory of Kabbalistic thought. Indeed, the classical tradition of Kabbalah can be considered superficial relative to that of Chassidut. By focusing upon immediate experience, Chassidut identifies aspects of Divinity that the highly formal and abstract system of Kabbalistic induction leaves unexplored.

Another way of explaining the differing emphases of Kabbalah and Chassidut is to say that Kabbalah focuses on the "vessels" (kelim) of Creation while Chassidut deals with the "lights"(orot) that fill these vessels. This distinction is apparent even in the names attached to these two mystical traditions: The word Kabbalah in Hebrew is derived from the root kabal, "to serve as a receptacle or vessel," while the word Chassidut is constructed from the root chesed, "lovingkindness," an attribute often referred to symbolically as the light of day...

For more about detail about the specifics of the Chassidish approach to Kabbalah see here1. And also look at the 4th chapter of Mevo HaShearim by the Piaseczna Rebbe that deals exactly with this topic at length.

It would seem that this extra dimension, of "recasting" Kabbalah is what Chacham Hillel takes issue with.

I found this academic piece entitled The Boundaries of the Kabbalah: R. Yaakov Moshe Hillel and the Kabbalah in Jerusalem, Kabbalah and Contemporary Spiritual Revival, ed. Boaz Huss, Beer Sheva 2011, pp. 163-180 (English).

It is a good read and one of the things that it notes is how Chacham Hillel critiques the popularization of Kabbalah, warning against superficial interpretations and public display. As far as the chassidish approach, it is this 'deeper', discernment of the inner meaning of Kabbalah that he takes issue with. Or, in other words, whether the chassidish approach has both the capacity or right to explain it.

On page 69, footnote 42 it writes:

Since Lurianic Kabbalah rarely reveals the inner meaning (nimshal) of any one of its symbols (mashalim), it is a matter of controversy whether it is possible for anyone to discern it. The prevailing view among Sefardic Kabbalists (in Teiman, Iraq and North Africa) is that the nimshal is not available to us; we must simply learn Kabbalah as it has been revealed, as a sacred wisdom. As contemporary author Rabbi Ya’akov Moshe Hillel writes, summarizing the position of the leading Sefardic Kabbalist, Rabbi Shalom Sharabi (1720–1777): “There is no possibility whatsoever to grasp the inner ‘nimshal’ hidden in the text and its symbols. Ask yourself: Is it possible to interpret a riddle without first knowing the whole of the riddle itself, in all its detail? That is why our master Rabbi Shalom Sharabi—and following him, the works of most early and later Kabbalists—set their primary goal to study the teachings of Arizal, to know with as much clarity as possible, the stated symbolism (mashal hachitzon).... This is our primary task” [Rabbi Yaakov Moshe Hillel, Ahavas Shalom (Jerusalem, 2002), p. 124].

It also writes here in footnote 26 the following:

R. Yaakov Moshe Hillel writes about the conditions and methods for Zohar study in his Vayeshev HaYam, Part 3, Siman 32, sect. 11, which includes the following statement (the original Hebrew is followed by its translation and analysis):

… ובפרט יש להודיע ולהזהיר, לגבי אותם הקטעים שבזוהר העוסקים על דרך הסוד, שאיסור חמור הוא לתרגם אותם, כי אין בהם שייכות עם הפשט, והם סודות מופשטים ונעלמים, ורק שהלבישום במשלים גשמיים, אבל אין להם שום דמיון עם המשל החיצוני לפי האמת. ולכן אין בתרגומם שום תועלת כלל, כי הרי אין הדברים כפשטן כלל. ואדרבא הוא מזיק מאד, שמגשים בתכלית את הסודות. (ופשוט דגם ללשון הקודש אין נכון לתרגם לשונות כאלו). וכבר האריך בזה בתשובה רבינו הרי”ח טוב ז”ל בשו”ת רב פעלים (חלק א’ חלק יו”ד סימן נ”ו), וגזר חרם ושמתא על אדם אחד על שתרגם שיר השירים והאדרות וספר שומר אמונים ללשון ערבי המדוברת בין היהודים (באותיות עבריות). ואסר בכל תוקף לתרגם סודות התורה, עי”ש באורך.

“It should specifically be made known and the caution given, that there is a severe prohibition to translate those passages of the Zohar that relate to Kabbalistic secrets, as they do not have any associated literal meaning. They are abstracted and concealed secrets expressed using physical analogies. However, in truth, they are not comparable with the external analogy. Therefore, there is no purpose in translating them at all, as these matters are not like their literal meaning at all. On the contrary, it is very damaging, as it absolutely physicalizes the secret concepts. (It is obvious that it is also improper to translate these expressions [from Aramaic] into Hebrew.) This has already been elaborated upon by R. Yosef Chaim in a responsum in Rav Pe’alim (Part 1, Yoreh De’ah, Question 56). He decreed the excommunication of an individual who translated Shir Hashirim, the Idrot [Rabba and Zuta] and the work Shomer Emunim into Arabic that was spoken by the Jews (using Hebrew letters). He forbade, in the strongest terms, the translation of the secrets of the Torah. Refer there at length.”

So at least tentatively, we can suggest that he does not like the approach that Chassidish-based kabbalah takes where it probes and suggests meaning in the words of the Zohar and the like which, traditional sefardi mekubalim do not think anyone has license to do.

1 In short, Chassidish thought reinterprets Lurianic Kabbalah through the inner life of the human soul, rather than as a description of cosmic, metaphysical processes. Whereas classical Kabbalah, especially the Lurianic system, focused on the structure of the divine realms, the emanations (sefiros), and the dynamics of creation, contraction (tzimtzum), and repair (tikkun) in the supernal worlds, Chasidism internalised these doctrines, seeing them as psychological and spiritual processes within man.

title: Do Nedarim Help Overcome the Yetzer Hara or Simply Avoid It?
content:
# Do Nedarim Help Overcome the Yetzer Hara or Simply Avoid It? ## Frage

If the goal is to overcome the yetzer hara, why do Chazal sometimes teach us to make nedarim (vows) as a strategy? Once something becomes forbidden like eating pork, isn’t that just avoiding the challenge rather than overcoming it?

title: Nedarim for Overcoming Challenges
content:
# Nedarim for Overcoming Challenges ## Frage

Like many others, I struggle with the yetzer hara. In the past, I used to make nedarim (vows), and this approach worked very well for me—once I made a neder, whatever I vowed about became completely forbidden to me, just like eating pork, and it really helped me overcome the nisayon (challenge).

However, someone later warned me very strongly not to make any more nedarim, saying it’s dangerous and that people can end up suffering their whole lives because of them.

I’ve heard about the practice of saying “bli neder,” where you make a commitment without it having the full halachic weight of a vow. My question is: Is there something in between—something like a “neder-bli-neder”—where the commitment is stronger than a regular promise, but doesn’t carry the severe consequences of an actual neder? Has anyone heard of such a concept or practice?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

Doing a commendable practice three times without specifying bli-neder is an intermediate level -- somewhat like a neder, but probably not a full Torah-level vow. "כעין בל יחל"

.ר"ן נדרים דף 81 ד"ה משום שנאמר

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

This might not be what you are looking for, but you can make a time-limited Neder. For example, "I hereby make a Neder (or shevua...) that I will not go online on an unfiltered internet device for the next 2 weeks".

Part of the danger of creating Nedarim is that they bind you permanently, and they are pretty serious transgressions. Getting a neder rescinded is not a simple or comfortable process. Having a Neder time-fenced reduces the risk and challenge of ensuring it is not transgressed.

If the Neder was successfully upheld for the duration of its lifetime, you can then create a new one.

(I believe I saw this hint in a guardyoureyes handbook some time ago. For the record, they generally do not recommend Nedarim alone as a method for restraint.)

title: How do you type trope marks (te'amim) on a computer keyboard?
content:
# How do you type trope marks (te'amim) on a computer keyboard? ## Frage

Suppose you need to type Hebrew text with trope marks on your computer, for whatever reason. As far as I can tell, the normal Hebrew keyboard layouts on Windows/Mac don't include trope marks.

I am aware of the SBL Biblical Hebrew keyboard layouts but I don't know how widely used these are.

Of course it's also possible to enter trope marks by the Unicode codepoint, but this seems like a hassle if you're doing more than a small handful.

What is the generally used method? The SBL keyboard layouts? Unicode codepoints? Something else?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

I'm not aware of a generally used method but you can try one the following.

1 - You can try out the virtual keyboard available at (my own) basehasefer.com which will work well for the most commonly used trop:

  • click the keyboard icon from the search bar
  • click/type in your Hebrew letters
  • click the virtual keyboard on the relevant trop mark after the letter where you want that trop to appear (must be after the letter due to cantillation marks being combining characters in Unicode)
  • copy the resulting text from the search bar and paste wherever you want

2 - You will also get some resources with similar functionality by searching the internet for one of the following:

  • virtual cantillation keyboard (among the hits will be Lexilogos)
  • מקלדת טעמי המקרא

True that using a virtual keyboard with a copy/paste can be a bit cumbersome, but this is what is available AFAIK and shouldn't be an issue if you don't need to type so many at a time eg. for educational and demonstration purposes.

If one does need a guide to typing in the Unicode directly from the Alt-key, etc., here's a good guide: https://tarboot.wordpress.com/2020/12/24/teamim/

title: Pronunciation tradition in the Sephardic old ישוב
content:
# Pronunciation tradition in the Sephardic old ישוב ## Frage

Many resources about several מזרחי pronunciation traditions of Hebrew can quite easily be found, from the entries in Khan's Encyclopedia of Hebrew Language and Linguistics covering the pronunciation used among the Jews of Morocco, Iraq, Tunisia and Syria, to Aïm's article about the pronunciation used in Algeria, to Katz's comprehensive works on the Aleppo and Jerba traditions.

However, I cannot find anything specifically about the traditional pronunciation used in the מוסתערבי and Sephardic old ישוב in Galilee (Safed, פקיעין, Tiberias...) and Jerusalem.

Do we know how it sounded? Was it like the Syrian pronunciation, or was it different? If it was different, what were the differences? In particular, were ב ,ג ,ד, and ת‎ pronounced the same with and without דגש? Was צ an emphatic /sˤ/ or /ts/? Was ק‎ a uvular /q/ or /k/? Was ט‎ ‎emphatic?

title: Anything wrong with trading card games?
content:
# Anything wrong with trading card games? ## Frage

Magic: the Gathering, Yugioh, Pokemon, Lorcana, etc. These are games where the cards cost money and people buy, trade, and collect them in order to play with them. I played Magic: the Gathering for a while and it ended in addiction. When playing the game I felt like I was in another world. Nothing mattered, just the game. And then the tournaments where there were prizes to compete for. It was like gambling. But it's not always gambling, sometimes I would play with friends for fun. But there was something about the culture, it felt antithetical to Judaism but I never understood why. Does anyone understand it? I know it's not healthy for me to play, but if there was a reason why I would find it easier to stop.

# Connection between Mezuzah, Tzitzis, Kiddush and Candles ## Frage

The Gemara in Shabbos writes (Davidson Edition translation):

אָמַר רַב הוּנָא: הָרָגִיל בְּנֵר הָוְיִין לֵיהּ בָּנִים תַּלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים. הַזָּהִיר בִּמְזוּזָה — זוֹכֶה לְדִירָה נָאָה. הַזָּהִיר בְּצִיצִית — זוֹכֶה לְטַלִּית נָאָה. הַזָּהִיר בְּקִידּוּשׁ הַיּוֹם — זוֹכֶה וּמְמַלֵּא גַּרְבֵי יַיִן.

Rav Huna said: One who is accustomed to kindle lights on Shabbat and Hanukkah will be rewarded and have children who are Torah scholars, who will disseminate the light of Torah. One who is meticulous in performing the mitzva of mezuza merits a beautiful house on which to affix his mezuza. One who is meticulous in performing the mitzva of ritual fringes merits a beautiful garment. One who is meticulous in performing the mitzva of kiddush of the day merits and fills jugs of wine.

The Gemara chooses 4 seemingly random Mitzvos (see the title) that receive special reward. While Chanukah/Shabbat candles are the topic of conversation, the others are not. What is the connection between these 4 (or at least the remaining 3) Mitzvos that are chosen here by the Gemara? Please provide sources for any answer.

title: How did earlier yeshivos differ from Volozhen?
content:
# How did earlier yeshivos differ from Volozhen? ## Frage

The yeshiva in Volozhin is often referred to as "the mother of yeshivos" due to its influence in style and structure. According to the Jewish History website,

Until then, the system of learning in Eastern Europe was that boys went to cheder (literally “a room,” but more broadly an elementary school) from about the time they turned three until about bar mitzvah. Some stopped at 11 or 12. Most young Jewish men were working by the time they were bar mitzvah. The elite — those who showed promise in their Talmudic studies, or who came from the upper classes, or from rabbinic homes — continued their education into their adolescent years and beyond, usually by studying with the rabbi of the town in which they lived. That was part of the task of the rabbi, to conduct the study sessions with whoever came to learn. If the young man showed particular promise, then he was sent out of town to the cities of noted rabbinical scholars, where he would learn with that rabbinic scholar for a period of time. Then, finally, when he attained sufficient knowledge he would be ordained, usually by a number of rabbis.

Now, this doesn't sound like there had been any particular structure prior to Volozhin for advanced study beyond essentially a chavrusah with greater and greater rabbonim as one progressed. But I was reading the wiki of the Rash miSens, where it references yeshiva learning that he did:

...for ten years, together with his older brother R. Yitzhak (known as the "Ritzba"), attended the Yeshiva of Rabbi Isaac ben Samuel ha-Zaken (the Ri) of Dampierre, after whose death he took charge of the yeshiva of Sens.

This sounds like a more structured design than the history of Volozhin would suggest. What is known about these earlier yeshivos, around the period of the Tosafists? What was their design, and how Volozhin differ from them such that it became known as the mother of yeshivos?

title: When did we begin to distinguish Rishonim from Acharonim in the way that now seems widely assumed?
content:
# When did we begin to distinguish Rishonim from Acharonim in the way that now seems widely assumed? ## Frage

I think that today, we take for granted some sort of important distinction between (on the one hand) Rashi, Rambam and Ramban, who are "Rishonim," and (on the other hand) some more recent figures, who are "Acharonim."

I am not totally sure what that distinction is, but perhaps the idea is that when Acharonim consider a question debated by Rishonim, Acharonim should confine themselves to weighing the strengths of the approaches of the Rishonim, without ever suggesting that they are free to differ with all Rishonim and propose solutions which no major Rishonim ever adopted.

Have I got this distinction basically correct? How did this view arise? Who were the first people who announced it? If you are thinking of telling me that Rav Moshe would sometimes disregard this respect for Rishonim, is he the exception proving the rule, famous for doing this because almost nobody did this? And would such a person, who felt free to differ with all Rishonim and Acharonim, still have any use for the distinction?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

Like user55402's answer, I would say the trigger was a historical event. But not directly.

It took a while for the Shulchan Arukh to get accepted. MichoelR's answer quotes the Yam Shel Shelomo's opposition. The Maharsha also objected. (Chiddushei Aggados, Sota 22a) And the Bach (responsum #80).

The Maharal (Nesivos Shalom, Nesiv haTorah) proves that the Mechaber didn't intend the Shulchan Arukh [SA] as a stand-alone code, to be used without his commentary on the Tur that brings in previous discussion, the Beis Yoseif. There is a whole article by R' Ari Storch in Hakira vol. 33 on the topic of the original intent behind the SA, "Was the Shulchan Aruch Intended to Be a Code of Jewish Law?"

What brought common acceptance to the SA was when the standardized page included commentary from the first generations after its writing -- the Shakh, the Taz, the Magein Avraham, the Beis Shemu'el / Chelqas Mechoqeiq), Be'er Heiteiv, etc..

This, combined with the Beis Yoseif, made it clear that the SA was a landmark in the conversation, and not entirely separate from it. The SA draws on previous conversation, and usually you could turn to the Beis Yoseif to see how, and it is published with the start of the contination of that conversation.

This takes care of the Maharshal's et al's objection to the reliance on codes. In ways the Rambam's Mishnah Torah and the Tur do not. (While the Rambam tells the layman to just go straight to his book, he too didn't expect Rabbis to make decisions without looking at the same primary sources he did. But still, the text is very closed, and subsequent commentary didn't save it.)

Same thing happened before:

The Mishnah divides tannaim from amoraim. The Bavli - amoraim from ge'onim.

The Rif tried to sum up after the ge'onim, but it didn't get that level of acceptance. And sure enough, rishonim have no problem arguing with ge'onim.

And in those cases there was a reason to summarize just then: Hadrian motivated Rebbe to write the Mishnah. The end of the Sanhedrin was followed up with the Talmud Bavli.

The Rif lived right after the great relocation of Jewish communities that led to Ashkenaz and Sepharad. But there is no real split in authority -- Rishonim have no problem arguing with Geonim -- because not enough people started following the Rif's code, giving the gemara's conclusions (as he saw them).

The Mechaber lived among people expelled from Spain. So he too had reason to feel that the state of halakhah, his Beis Yoseif, needed a summary.

So nowadays, if you want to hold differently than the SA, you need to bring a justification. An Acharon can be defined as a Rav who needs to justify a differing opinion, a Rishon as a potential source they could use for that justification.

Parallel to the gemara concluding like a beraisa over a mishnah. Or like a rishon holding like a Yerushalmi or Tosefta despite the Talmud Bavli.

And I mentioned the Holocaust and our subsequent gravitating to new codes.

Our children or grandchildren will see if the Holocaust ended the Acharonim. It will take more than a historical event. If the Mishnah Berurah ends up being the Ashkenazi go-to summarizing text then we would be in a weird place where contemporary rabbis can't argue with acharonim on Orach Chaim, but they could in most other topics?! (Even though most Ashkenazi Rashei Yeshiva at the time would have pointed you to the Arukh haShulchan. R Aharon Kotler and the Chazon Ish won over the majority.)

Whereas Sepharadim lean on the Ben Ish Chai and/or R' Ovadiah Yosef's writings and would not have that problem.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 4)

Beis Yosef, in his Introduction to the Tur:

ועלה בדעתי שאחר כל הדברים אפסוק הלכה ואכריע בין הסברות כי זהו התכלית להיות לנו תורה אחת ומשפט אחד. וראיתי שאם באנו לומר שנכריע דין בין הפוסקים בטענות וראיות תלמודיות הנה התוספות וחידושי הרמב"ן והרשב"א והר"ן ז"ל מלאים טענות וראיות לכל אחת מהדיעות. ומי זה אשר יערב לבו לגשת להוסיף טענות וראיות. ואיזהו אשר ימלאהו לבו להכניס ראשו בין ההרים הררי אל להכריע ביניהם על פי טענות וראיות לסתור מה שביררו הם או להכריע במה שלא הכריעו הם. כי בעונותינו הרבים קצר מצע שכלינו להבין דבריהם כל שכן להתחכם עליהם. ולא עוד אלא שאפילו היה אפשר לנו לדרוך דרך זה לא היה ראוי להחזיק בה לפי שהיא דרך ארוכה ביותר:
ולכן הסכמתי בדעתי כי להיות שלשת עמודי ההוראה אשר הבית בית ישראל נשען עליהם בהוראותיהם הלא המה הרי"ף והרמב"ם והרא"ש ז"ל אמרתי אל לבי שבמקום ששנים מהם מסכימים לדעת אחת נפסוק הלכה כמותם אם לא במקצת מקומות שכל חכמי ישראל או רובם חולקין על הדעת ההוא ולכן פשט המנהג בהיפך:
ומקום שאחד מן הג' העמודים הנזכרים לא גילה דעתו בדין ההוא והשני עמודים הנשארין חולקין בדבר הנה הרמב"ן והרשב"א והר"ן והמרדכי וסמ"ג ז"ל לפנינו אל מקום אשר יהיה שמה הרוח רוח אלהי"ן קדישין ללכת נלך כי אל הדעת אשר יטו רובן כן נפסוק הלכה:
ובמקום שלא גילה דעתו שום אחד מן הג' עמודים הנזכרים נפסוק כדברי החכמים המפורסמים שכתבו דעתם בדין ההוא. ודרך זו דרך המלך נכונה וקרובה אל הדעת להרים מכשול:

tl;dr: The Beis Yosef thought to try to work out all the sugyos, with all the proofs, and rule. But he decided that there was enough discussion in the Rishonim and he was going to quote much of it, and not add (much) more of his own. Then he would rule like two out of three of the main Rishonim: Rif, Rambam, Rosh. And where one of them didn't rule and the other two disagreed, or none of them ruled, he'd add on other Rishonim to decide.

In the Yam shel Shlomo (see Hakdamah to Bava Kamma and to Chullin), his contemporary the Maharshal disagreed strongly with this approach. He held that it was his obligation to study the sugya of the gemara, read and ponder what earlier authorities said about it, and then decide himself. He said (again, if I remember correctly) that the Beis Yosef was abdicating his responsibility by just letting the Rishonim "vote" on it.
Here is an article bringing Rav Ovadia Yosef's discussion on the subject: https://nleresources.com/2014/09/guest-post-to-begin-to-appreciate-rav-ovadia-yosefs-derech/

So roughly speaking, the Beis Yosef was taking the attitude you describe, that we could or should just work with the opinions of Rishonim, and the Maharshal didn't agree. Later authorities seem to mostly be following the approach of the Beis Yosef. And indeed they have great respect for the Maharshal himself, but usually won't accept his opinion over the usual Rishonim.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 2)

My personal impression is that Rishonim tend to comment directly on the Gemara (or Rif), whereas Acharonim comment on the Gemara and commentaries of Rishonim, primarily Rashi and Tosafos. In other words, there is one group of commentaries that forms the starting point for a second group of commentaries. We call the former Rishonim and the latter Acharonim.

The Acharonim feel duty-bound to try to justify the approaches of the Rishonim, although they will disagree if they feel compelled to do so by powerful arguments. Rishonim OTOH will disagree with each other much more freely. Some Acharonim are more confident in their willingness to argue with Rishonim, but they still feel obligated to refer to the Rishonim and demonstrate their reasons for arguing, as opposed to Rishonim who much more frequently just state their opinion without mentioning whom they disagree with.

title: Esther and the end of Miracles
content:
# Esther and the end of Miracles ## Frage

Shalom,

According to b.Yoma 29a, queen Esther is compared to the end of the night (dawn), which represents the end of supernatural miracles. אָמַר רַבִּי אַסִּי: לָמָּה נִמְשְׁלָה אֶסְתֵּר לְשַׁחַר — לוֹמַר לָךְ: מָה שַׁחַר סוֹף כׇּל הַלַּיְלָה, אַף אֶסְתֵּר סוֹף כׇּל הַנִּסִּים.

If supernatural miracles ended with Purim, how is the oil miracle of Hanukka to be understood?

Thanks!

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Continue reading the passage in Yoma:

"וְהָא אִיכָּא חֲנוּכָּה! נִיתְּנָה לִכְתּוֹב קָא אָמְרִינַן."

The Gemara asks this same question regarding Chanukah (and this question, it should be noted, is also relevant for other miracles that occurred over the millennia) and explains that the phrase "סוף כל הנסים", the end of miracles, means "the end of miracles that were allowed to be written in the biblical canon". In other words, all later miracles, even if written down, were not to be included in the biblical canon.

title: May a child set the pace for Shema from his seat and essentially lead Shema instead of the Shaliach Tzibbur?
content:
# May a child set the pace for Shema from his seat and essentially lead Shema instead of the Shaliach Tzibbur? ## Frage

Can anyone provide me with a source permitting the following situation that occurred this morning?

Context: An Israeli Ashke-Sephard Minyan (meaning Nusach Sefard and Edot HaMizrach with Ashkenaz being a barely tolerated minority).

When the Minyan in question reached Shema this morning, a child around age 9-10 took over for the Chazzan from the end of “הבוחר בעמו ישראל באהבה” until the end of Shema (ה׳ אלוקיכם אמת). Said child did not go up to the Amud, he simply raised his voice from his seat and set the pace for Shema, reciting the whole thing as loudly as he possibly could.

It was explained to me that it was: (1) Bar Mitzvah preparation for said child and (2) it encourages children to stay in shul and actually daven.

I am well aware that most Sephardic Minyanim do a “round robin” of sorts with Pesukei De-Zimra with different people reading the various sections of Tehillim. That happens weekly at said Minyan. I used to lead Pesukei De-Zimra at more than one Ashkenazi shul when I was that same age (I also used to lead the end of the davening as well, as is normal in most shuls). I am also well aware that there many parts of davening that children may lead and I am aware of the various Hilchos Kriyas HaTorah allowing children to receive Aliyot and read for the Kahal under certain circumstances.

I have never seen anyone, anywhere, allow a child to set the pace for Shema in the middle of Shacharis, especially for the purposes stated above, and also possibly giving the impression that a child is leading Shema.

title: Who are R' Avner and R' Chanoch Parsah?
content:
# Who are R' Avner and R' Chanoch Parsah? ## Frage

The Abarbanel in Yehoshua 10 (in his lengthy stance against extreme rationalism of miracles) lists Rishonim who were apparently extreme rationalists:

ר׳ אבנר, ר׳ יהושע הנרבוני, אבן כספי, ר׳ יצחק אלבלג, ר׳ חנוך פרסה

Who are R' Avner and R' Chanoch Parsah?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

Well, diving into this was fascinating.

Rabbi Chanoch:

Examining older printings of the Abarbanel's commentary on Yehoshua revealed that in what appears to be the editio princeps (original printing) of his commentary on the Early Prophets (Pesaro, 1512?), the wording of this passage was thus (no pagination, in the NLI's scanned document's pagination it's p. 46):

"ר' אבנר ר' יהושע הנרבוני אבן כספי ר' יצחק אלבלג ר' חנוך סרסה ורבי' אחרי'"

This wording is significant for two reasons:

  1. There are no commas between the names.
  2. It means that פרסה (Parsa) is a later printer's error of סרסה (Sarsa).1

Given that no ר' חנוך סרסה is known to us, the lack of commas shows that the division of the names with commas in modern printings is probably mistaken with regards to "ר' חנוך סרסה". It's likely supposed to be ר' חנוך, סרסה. "Sarsa" refers to Ibn Zarza (common Hebrew variants included אבן סרסא, אבן סרסה, אבן צרצא, אבן צרצה) - this is Rabbi Shmuel Ibn Zarza, a well-known Sefardic philosopher from the 14th century. Ibn Zarza was also sometimes simply known as R' Shmuel Zarza (/Sarsa, סרסא, e.g. Shalshelet Hakabbalah), so it seems that Abarbanel just wrote his surname.

One source (R' Yochanan Lederman, Midrash Abarbanel [in Hebrew], p. 7 [can be found on Otzar Hachochmah]) appeared to suppose that "Chanoch" is also a printing error and that the original name was "Shmuel" (ר' שמואל סרסא in his words). However, there's another possibility, that Abarbanel did in fact mean, as I suggested above, that there were two people: ר' חנוך and סרסה. There are a few places in his works where Abarbanel listed philosophically-minded individuals who held views that Abarbanel deemed to be extreme and problematic. To identify Rabbi Chanoch, we turn to Abarbanel's list in Yeshuot Meshicho, pt. 2 (here, p. 51), where he mentioned:

"וכבר נמצא בזה...וגם בדברי הרלב"ג ורבי חנוך אלקוסטאנטינא ורבי שמואל מוטוט ורבי לוי בן רבי אברהם..."

I would guess that this Rabbi Chanoch Alkostantina (in some editions "Alkonstantina" [אלקונסטאנטינא]) is the one Abarbanel referred to in his commentary. It seems likely that this Rabbi Chanoch should be identified with Rabbi Chanoch Saporta (ר' חנוך ספורטה/צפורטא/צפורתא/other variants). The only explicit mention we have of him is in a responsum by Rabbi Eliyahu Mizrachi (the Re'em), where he stated that Rabbi Mordechai Comtino, who was born in Constantinople, told him (Rabbi Mizrachi) that his rabbi, Rabbi Chanoch Saporta, had a tradition from other Sephardic rabbis that it was allowed to teach Karaites Torah. The bit we know of Rabbi Chanoch is that he originally lived in Catalonia ca. the late 14th-early 15th centuries and apparently eventually moved to Christian Byzantium (which is likely where Rabbi Mordechai met him).2 Rabbi Mordechai, his student, was known as being philosophically-minded. It's likely he received his views from his rabbi, Rabbi Chanoch. For these reasons I believe Rabbi Chanoch Alkostantina should be identified with Rabbi Chanoch Saporta. Rabbi Chanoch Saporta was likely also mentioned by the Karaite Avraham Bali (Gurland, Ginzei Yisrael in St. Petersburg, vol. 3, p. 32; the identification was suggested by Jean-Christophe Attias, Le Commentaire Biblique Mordekhai Komtino ou l’herméneutique du dialogue, Hebrew translation, p. 69).

Rabbi Avner:

This case is less clear. Given that these individuals were looked upon by the Abarbanel in disdain, I think it may be proposed that he was referring to Avner of Burgos. Avner was originally a rabbi in Castille ca. the late 13th-mid-14th centuries, who eventually converted to Christianity. He was also known to being philosophically-minded, both before and after his conversion. Shalshelet Hakabbalah brings a legend about Avner having been a student of Ramban and what led him to apostasy. However, Avner was about 10 years old when Ramban died, and anyway the latter was already long living in Eretz Yisrael by that time, so the legend is impossible (at best, Avner may have been inspired by Ramban's writings, or perhaps was a student of a student). Most significant to us is Ibn Yechiya's wording of the story: He refers to Avner as ר' אבנר, which demonstrates that even after his apostasy, some later writers referred to him as ר' אבנר. This raises the likelihood that Abarbanel was indeed referring to Avner of Burgos.

As a side-note, it should be mentioned that ר' יהושע הנרבוני is also problematic. A famous philosopher of Narbonne was Rabbi Moshe Ha'Narboni. His father's name is debatable (see a summary in this footnote in his Hebrew Wiki entry), it was either Meir or Yehoshua. If Yehoshua is the correct version, perhaps the Abarbanel originally wrote בן יהושע הנרבוני, and ר' יהושע הנרבוני is a mistake already in the 1512 printing. If not, perhaps again it should be separated thus: "ר' יהושע, הנרבוני", with Narboni being one person - Rabbi Moshe Ha'Narboni - and Rabbi Yehoshua being another (though I don't know who).3

1 This was still the wording in the Leipzig 1681 edition and the Hamburg 1687 edition.

2 This rationale seems to be the basis for the assertion made in this article that Rabbi Chanoch Saporta was a rabbi in Constantinople. And see also the assertion made here.

3 A wild guess may be Rabbi Yehoshua Ibn Shuaib, though I'm not sure if he was considered a philosopher.

title: What would Chabad-Lubavitch look like today if they had gone with R' Gurary instead of R' Schneerson as seventh Rebbe?
content:
# What would Chabad-Lubavitch look like today if they had gone with R' Gurary instead of R' Schneerson as seventh Rebbe? ## Frage

After the passing of the sixth Lubavitcher Rebbe, there was some dispute which son-in-law would succeed him -- R' Menachem Mendel Schneerson zt'l (who ultimately did), or R' Shmaryahu Gurary zt'l.

Any sense on what the latter's vision/approach/style was? And therefore where he might have taken Chabad-Lubavitch? Would shlichus have looked the same, with its globe-spanning, outward-looking approach? What would relationships have looked like vis-a-vis, for example, "ChaGaS" Chassidim, Agudas Harabbonim, R' Moshe Feinstein zt'l, and R' Yosef Dov Soloveitchik zt'l?

(As Gurary did have a son, presumably that son would have been named the eighth rebbe ...)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

I agree this question is too opinion based to answer directly, but there are some facts that provide an indirect answer, which is to state what was unique about the 7th Rebbe compared to the rest.

Here is Rabbi Manis Friedman explaining it: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XqT2l2lzmTM

Summary:

  • The first 3 Rebbeim worked on cultivating Chassidim who had phenomenal levels of penimius.

  • The next 3 focused on cultivating mesirus nefesh.

  • The 7th Rebbe shifted to "Shabbos", changing the target of avodah: stop trying to "fix the person" (taking the bad from the good); focus on fulfilling what Hashem wants from the world now (taking the good from the bad; Shabbos). Dirah Betachtonim in practice:

    You are needed, it's not about your needs!

It's interesting to note, from what I've heard, that the 6th Rebbe did say that he liked Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneersohn z'tl because he appreciated his vision*. Indeed, it is this vision that produced unique direction that he took Chabad in, and informed many of the resulting actions he took (and from this we can also presume Rabbi Shmaryahu Gurary z'tl would not have taken them, at least to this extent):

  1. Shlichut - just go, you are needed. Don't wait until you are "on the madregah", it's Shabbos now.
  2. Kiruv - Hashem needs all His Jews back, don't abandon them, like many were doing in the post-war generation. They are all Jewish in their hearts, someone needs to bring them their Torah and Mitzvot!
  3. Tefillin - do the mitzvah even if the person is far from "ideal" (tattoos, no mikveh, shaky beliefs) — e.g., put on tefillin on the street. Earlier eras would protest "bizayon hamitzvah"; the Rebbe argued that in this era, this is the right move.
  4. Education - stop with the negative pressure, "What will be with you!". Reframe in objective-mission language "Can you do something for Hashem?".
  5. De-narcissize avodah - don't focus on you "becoming a tzaddik", the goal is not about you, but about Hashem. Don't fix the Jew, deploy him!
  6. Lectures - Chabad Rebbeim put out more material than all other Chassidic groups combined, and arguably all other groups - it's hard to imagine which modern dynasty comes even close. Weekly lectures and essays penned or delivered by the Rebbeim themselves for 7 generations. If you thought that was a lot, the 7th Rebbe opened the floodgates, putting out 3 generations of Chassidus in one generation, making sure every last detail of penimius haTorah was explained as thoroughly, clearly and down to earth-ly as possible. The Dirah Betachton.

This would also inform his other famous, rather unique practises - telling teenagers that they are fine, just get on with doing something useful. His "hesech hada'as" policy on inappropriate gazing. Tznius isn't about your image, but just like everything, it's for Hashem. Davening should primarily be filled with d'vekut and connection to Hashem etc.

* I've heard this orally - the Rebbe said that he had an "eye that sees further".

title: What should an Ashkenazi expect from a Sefaradi Hoshana Rabbah?
content:
# What should an Ashkenazi expect from a Sefaradi Hoshana Rabbah? ## Frage

I am Ashkenazi and will be davening at a Sefaradi shul for Hoshana Rabbah. (I don't know more precisely what minhag they follow.) I've occasionally been to Sefaradi shuls during the week or Shabbat, but never on Sukkot.

What should I expect that is different from what I'm used to (i.e. artscroll)? I'm particularly interested in hoshanot, and in things that will not be obvious from following along in the siddur and could be distracting if I don't know about them in advance.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

This was a separate minyan for a brit in the basement of a Sefaradi shul of some variety. The baalei simcha are Syrian and ran the minyan, so it's probably following those minhagim.

These are my observations:

  • No tefillin
  • Pesukei Dezimra
    • Same as a regular weekday, as far as I could tell. At least it didn't seem to be longer. If you're planning to say the Shabbos Pesukei Dezimra as per the Ashkenazi custom, you should start early.
  • Hallel
    • This is where I was caught most off guard
    • I think Sefaradim say לגמור את ההלל but wasn't paying enough attention to notice.
    • They did not say הודו or אנא responsively, which surprised me. (If anything I was expecting everyone to be yotzei the first four pesukim with the chazzan instead of also repeating them as Artscroll says.) Instead everyone said the pesukim together, turning in unison and waving the lulavim.
    • The order of the 6 directions of waving was different than I'm used to.
    • They waved for the first הודו and the first time saying הודו at the end. I'm fairly certain they did not wave for the repetition of הודו but did wave for both times אנא ה' הושיעה נא.
    • For אנא ה', they waved one direction per syllable instead of two per word. This makes נא a lot less unwieldy.
  • Hoshanot
    • Totally different than the Ashkenazi custom, but very easy to follow as long as you have a machzor.
    • After Hallel, not after Musaf.
    • Each hakafa had a similar structure: piyutim interspersed with responsive tefillot that were reminiscent of Avinu Malkeinu and selichot.
    • Each time a different person was chosen to be the leader. The leader reads the piyutim and leads the responsive parts. The responses are either אמן or simple lines like וחוסה על ישראל עמך.
    • We started each hakafa's prayers while walking around the bimah, but that finished pretty quickly. After everyone completed 360 degrees we just stood in place to finish that hakafa, then started walking again when we got to the next one.
    • After the 7 hakafot are tefillot that are kind of like the Ashkenazi ones. A lot of the lines that are bolded in Artscroll (e.g. אנא אל נא הושענא והושיעה נא and קול מבשר מבשר ואומר) are still there, sometimes with slight variations, but the piyutim afterwards are different. Sometimes they have similar structure. For example the piyut that goes with אני והוּ הושיעה נא (also note different vowels) still has each stanza starting with כהושעת.
  • Leining
    • The aliyot were days 6, 7, 7, 6+7. (As opposed to Ashkenazi 5, 6, 7, 6+7.)
    • (As DoubleAA points out, this is not specific to Hoshana Rabba. They follow a similar sequence every day. For example the previous day was 5, 6, 6, 5+6.)
  • Musaf
    • Kedusha was the same as the Sefaradi minhag for Chol Hamoed and Rosh Chodesh. The intro was כתר, but there were just the short joining verses (לעמתם משבחים ואומרים) and no Shema.
  • Arava
    • They hit the aravot all the way after davening, not after hoshanot, and were makpid to go outside to hit it on dirt as opposed to the floor of the shul. (Even though it was raining - the seudat mitzvah was inside.) I didn't see it because I didn't know what was happening until they came back in.

title: Istanis and negative commandments
content:
# Istanis and negative commandments ## Frage

This article says that the status of istanis can sometimes justify exemption from a positive biblical commandment (e.g. if one is too sensitive to put on tefillin), but can never justify exemption from a negative commandment.

This seems illogical: someone might equally have a sensitivity that prevents their complying with a negative commandment (e.g. if they have a mental health condition that would be exacerbated by the change of diet that comes with the chametz prohibition at Pesach).

So: do any poskim or responsa address exemption from negative biblical commandments in such circumstances? Not so extreme as the shoteh but still a genuine involuntary sensitivity.

title: Story about Rav Soloveitchik and Simchat Torah
content:
# Story about Rav Soloveitchik and Simchat Torah ## Frage

Some years ago I heard in a shiur from my late rosh yeshiva, Rabbi Chaim Druckman zt"l, a story regarding Rabbi Soloveitchik (I believe it was about Rabbi Yosef Ber, but I may be mistaken) taking a walk after the meal on the night of Simchat Torah. Unfortunately, though I've tried a number of times over the years, I haven't managed to find that story and I currently don't have access to the notebook where I might have written down the story during that particular class. Is anyone aware of a source for this story?

title: Torah Reading On Sukkot
content:
# Torah Reading On Sukkot ## Frage

In Eretz Yisroel, where there is no Sefeka Deyoma, for the krias hatorah we just read the day 4 times - ie, uv'ayom hashishi is read for all four olim. In Chutz La'aretz, we read the present day, the following day, the day after and then finally the first and second day again for the 4th oleh - why dont we simply read the sefeka deyoma 4 times in C'L?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: -1)

The only aliyah that has to be the correct day is the fourth, because that is the one added for Chol Hamoed. So we make sure that is the correct day by reading both. For the other three, it doesn't matter.

title: Persian Custom of giving Apples during a Brit
content:
# Persian Custom of giving Apples during a Brit ## Frage

A classmate mentioned to me today that her family comes from Mashhad, Iran, and Mashhadi Jews have a custom of giving out apples during Brit Milah ceremonies, as a segulah for fertility. She's trying to track down sources that address this custom. I did a few quick online searches but didn't find anything. Is anyone familiar with sources for this custom?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

So it writes on the Chabad website as follows:

At Persian circumcisions, a large tray of apples is placed on the table and young couples are encouraged to partake. Assumedly, this custom is based on the Midrash that explains how, when Pharaoh ordered the midwives to kill all newborn Jewish males, the Jewish women hid in the apple orchards. There Heavenly emissaries assisted them with the birth and subsequent care of the baby. This is alluded to in the verse, “Under the apple tree I begot you.”1 Thus, apples are propitious for easy labor and delivery.

1 Song of Songs 8:5; Rashi to Sotah 11b.
