title: Who are these Rishonim
content:
# Who are these Rishonim ## Frage

If anyone knows more about these three Rishonim, please provide the information. I have included what I know about them below. Thank you!

Rabbi Yitzchak Ibn Shaprut
I do know that he was the father of Rav Chisdai Ibn Shaprut.

Rabbi Dosa ben Saadia
His father was the great Rav Saadia Gaon of Sura. He even wrote a bio at the behest of Rav Chisdai Ibn Shaprut.

Rav Yechiel
I know that he was the father of Rav Nosson ben Yechiel, author of the Aruch, and I think he was the rosh yeshiva in Rome.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Rabbi Yitzchak ben Ezra Ibn Shaprut:

Some basic information can be found in the Wiki entry linked by @rosends. To this I'll add some info from Eliyahu Ashtor, The Jews in Moslem Spain (Hebrew edition), Vol. 1 p. 111 (can be found on Otzar Hachochmah). He was born in the Spanish city of Jaén (an important city in Eastern Al-Andalus) sometime during the second half of the 9th century CE. At some point he moved to Cordoba. He was a wealthy and righteous man. He built a synagogue in Cordoba and financially supported tamidei chachamim. His son Chasdai was born around 910 CE.

Rabbi Dosa ben Saadya:

The two linked Wiki entries (in Hebrew and English) are pretty rich (especially the Hebrew one) (though there's at least one discrepancy between them), so I'll summarize their info along with a bit of added info. Rav Dosa is thought to have been born around 930 CE, to Rav Saadayah Gaon. The family was originally from Fayum in Egypt, hence their last name "Al-Fayumi". Rasag was the first "outsider" (non-Babylonian) elected to position of Gaon (head of the yeshiva) in the Babylonian yeshivas of the period. Dosa was about 12 when his father died (ca. 942 CE). Dosa waited about 71 years (!) before being called upon to succeed his father as Gaon, stepping into the role at the ripe old age of 83 (ca. 1013), and holding office until his death four years later, ca. 1017/8. He succeeded Rav Shmuel ben Chofni Gaon, and was in turn succeeded by Rav Yisrael ben Rav Shmuel ben Chofni Gaon, who had previously served as scribe of the yeshiva under Rav Shmuel his father and then under Rav Dosa. Rav Dosa's advanced age was a matter of note, as indicated by a Genizah letter from the summer of 1015 CE mentioning him with added wishes for good health to be given to him (see its publication with a Hebrew translation here).

Rabbi Yechiel:

The following information is from Avraham Fraenkel, The Piyyutim of R. Yechiel bar Avraham of Rome - Father of R. Natan, Author of the 'Aruch' (in Hebrew), Introduction, pp. 1-4. Not much is known about Rabbi Yechiel. He lived in Rome and was the son of one R' Avraham, who was the son of one R' Yoav. All three were members of a Judeo-Italian family known in Hebrew as the "Anavim" (ענוים, humble), and in Italian Piatelli or Delli Mansi. A certain historical document describes an anti-Jewish decree from the year 1007 CE commanded by Robert II of France and mentions that Rabbi Yaakov ben Yekutiel, one of the leaders of the Jews of Rome, sought an audience with the pope to try to overturn the decree, and afterwards he met with other leaders of the community, among them one Rabbi Avraham. This might be Rabbi Yechiel's father.

Rabbi Yechiel lived ca. the first half of the 11th century, and according to a responsa from the Rokeach (preserved in Or Zarua, Hilchot Rosh Hashanah, § 275), he headed the yeshiva of Rome, and had studied under the previous head of the Roman beit midrash, Rabbi Yaakov Gaon. For this reason, Rabbi Yechiel was also referred to as "Gaon" in the responsa. It has been speculated that he died when his son Rabbi Natan was fairly young, and so the latter had not studied much under his father, and that Rabbi Yechiel was no longer alive when his son wrote the Aruch. He was known for writing various piyyutim and selichot (published by Fraenkel). He had three sons: Rabbi Daniel, Rabbi Natan and Rabbi Avraham (all are mentioned in another responsa in the Or Zarua, Hilchot Shabbat, § 52). Another prominent Roman rabbi who lived during Rabbi Yechiel's time was Rabbi Shabtai ben Moshe, a fellow paytan and a "rosh kallah" (a certain position in the Roman beit midrash, subordinate to the rosh yeshiva). Rabbi Shabtai's sons were Rabbi Moshe ben Shabtai and Rabbi Kalonymos of Rome, prominent figures as well (Rabbi Kalonymos eventually moved to Worms, Germany, and headed the yeshiva there. He is often thought as one of the "missing links" between Italian Jewry and Ashkenazic Jewry).

It should be noted that Rabbi Yechiel lived during what were arguably the final decades of the Geonic period, so really all three of these figures should be considered as being from the Geonic period, not the Rishonic period.

title: Were there any Hasidic Rebbes under Nazi occupation whose writings or sermons from that time were published besides the Piaseczner Rebbe?
content:
# Were there any Hasidic Rebbes under Nazi occupation whose writings or sermons from that time were published besides the Piaseczner Rebbe? ## Frage

Were there any Hasidic Rebbes during the Holocaust, living under Nazi occupation, whose writings or sermons from that time were published - besides the Piaseczner Rebbe?

If so, what are the names of the works in which those writings or sermons were collected?

EDIT:
Following comments - I’d like to clarify that in this question, my focus is on the survival or publishing of writings or sermons rather than the survival of the Rebbes themselves. So regardless of whether a particular Rebbe survived the Holocaust or not, as long as his writings or sermons from the Nazi occupation period have survived or were later published, that would qualify.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 8)


Rabbi Shlomo Chanoch Hakohen Rabinowicz H'yd
Fourth and last Rebbe of the Radomsk Chassidim.
His teachings were compiled into Shivchei Kohen, with other Rebbeim and Rabbonim of his dynasty. Some were delivered during the war.
He was murdered in the Warsaw Ghetto in 1943 with his family.


Rabbi Dovid Bornsztain H'yd
Third Rebbe of the Sochatchover dynasty.
Most of his works were burned, but some of his Chiddushim on the Haggadah were published in Chasdei David, and were saved by his talmidim who survived, so it seems like some of this is likely to have been actually delivered/innovated and recorded during the war. He was murdered in the Warsaw Ghetto in 1943 with his family.


Rabbi Yitzchak Menachem Mendel Dancyger H'yd
Second Rebbe of Alexander.
Author of Akeidat Yitzchak, which includes sermons delivered in the Ghetto.
He was murdered in Treblinka along with his family in 1942.


Rabbi Yekutiel Yehuda (Zalmen Leib) Teitelbaum H'yd
Second Sigheter Rebbe.
He was murdered in Auschwitz with his wife and daughters in 1944.
Some of his responsa are collected in Yad Yekutiel, and it is plausible that some of these were recorded during the war.


Rabbi Yitzchok Breiter H'yd
A leading teacher of Breslov Chassidus (not a formal “Rebbe”).
He was murdered in Treblinka, yet many of his seforim remain beloved, including
Seder HaYom, Sheva Amudei Emunah, Chilukei HaNachal, and Sh’erit Yitzchak. These were all composed before the war, and during it he was focussed on giving chizuk to his community, but he did compose a poem, Shir Yedidut, expressing his attachment to Rebbe Nachman.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

Given the change in the question with a specific mention of any published works, there are several other options that can be added to the list...

HaRav Menachem Mendel Taub zt”l, the Kaliver Rebbe famously was sadly experimented on by Mengele ym"sh, but survived the war.

He published a 13-volume work on the Torah and Yomim Tovim entitled Kol Menachem. Also, particularly pertinent to the question, published Shema Yisroel - a two-volume treatise on the Holocaust.

There is also HaRav Yekusiel Yehudah Halberstam zt"l the Klausenberger Rebbe who likewise survived the war and was a prolific author. His monumental series Shefa Chaim on the Torah and Moadim etc. is fully accessible on Hebrewbooks.org. In addition his series of Divrei Yatziv on halacha is also downloadable there.

The Bluzhever Rebbe, Rabbi Yisroel Spira zt"l survived the war, and whilst he did not publish any official works his experiences during the Holocaust were told over to the Holocaust researcher Yaffa Eliach. These stories would later become the basis for her book Hasidic Tales of the Holocaust.

In 2005, the Rebbe's grandson, Rabbi Yoseph Spira, compiled two volumes of his grandfather's Torah thoughts, called Shufra Deyisroel. He also wrote a biography called L'Eid Bivnei Yisroel.

title: Why is the word Shabbat broken up here?
content:
# Why is the word Shabbat broken up here? ## Frage

This is a package for bread, a fancier pita. The words לכבוד שבת seem out-of-place, unless this is a roundabout way of saying "you can use this for challa." (It is not a special package pulled out for use only once a week.)

I think the explanation is this: It is similar the markings on grape juice saying that "ברכתו הגפן גם לדעת מרן הבית יוסף" yet since they are not addressing any real halachic issues, they write it in this cryptic way. Is that right?

But why is the word ש-ב-ת broken up? I have seen packets if toilet tissues that say שומר שביעי (i.e., the factory keeps Shabbat). I guess they do this to keep the holy word שבת away from something unholy.

title: Simchas Beis HaShoevah; when was the libation?
content:
# Simchas Beis HaShoevah; when was the libation? ## Frage

By Simchas beis Hashoevah, when did they draw the water and when was the libation?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Based on the Rambam in Hilchos Temdim U'Musafim perek 10:Halachos 6-10.

Halachos that pertain to Nisuch Hamayim (all info from the Rambam,but organized by AI for easier read):

Sukkot Water Libation Overview

Performed on all seven days of the Sukkot festival.

Halachah given to Moses on Mount Sinai.

Water libation poured separately alongside the morning wine libation.

Libation Details and Procedure

Water and wine can be poured mixed or separately; either way fulfills the obligation.

Libation may be poured before the daily sacrifice or even at night.

Location: Southwest corner above the altar’s midpoint, water flows down to the shittin.

Water is taken from the Shiloach stream in a golden vessel holding three lugin.

At the Water Gate, trumpet blasts of tekiah, teruah, and tekiah signal the pouring.

Priest ascends ramp, turns left, and pours water into the western silver cup; wine poured into eastern silver cup.

Both cups have two small holes; the water cup’s hole is narrower to time the flow properly.

Ritual Etiquette and Precautions

Priests are instructed to “Lift up your hands” before pouring.

One priest was stoned for pouring water on his feet, seen as denying the water libation (Sadducee accusation).

Sabbath Practices

Water libation on the Sabbath is performed exactly as during the week.

On Friday, a non-sacrificial golden jug is filled with water and left overnight.

The next day, the libation pitcher is filled from this jug.

Handling Mistakes

If water is spilled or uncovered, the pitcher is refilled from the basin before pouring the libation.

title: Beating the willow branches on the ground on Hoshanah Rabba and Moshe striking the rock
content:
# Beating the willow branches on the ground on Hoshanah Rabba and Moshe striking the rock ## Frage

In his book "Rendezvous with God", chapter 5, footnote 45, Rabbi Natan Laufer suggests that the ritual of beating the hoshanah bundles on the ground on Hoshanah Rabba is reminiscent of G-d's instruction to Moshe to strike the rock to draw forth its waters in the desert (Shemos 17:6, Bamidbar 20:7-11). In my opinion, it is an interesting connection, since Hoshanah Rabba is the day when G-d seals his annual judgement for water. There is actually reference to Moshe's striking the rock in the prayer תענה אמונים, when some people put their lulav down and take the willow twigs:

לְמַעַן נֶאֱמַן בַּיִת מַסְפִּיק לָעָם מַיִם. סֶלַע הָךְ וַיָּזוּבוּ מַיִם וְהַצְלִיחָה נָּא וְהוֹשִׁיעֵנוּ אֵל מָעֻזֵּנוּ:

in the merit of [Moshe] the most trusted of the household, who supplied people with water, who struck the rock and there flowed water, and bring success now and save us, G-d, our Fortress.

Is there any discussion of such a connection elsewhere?

title: Why do we say פטום הקטורת twice during Shacharis?
content:
# Why do we say פטום הקטורת twice during Shacharis? ## Frage

During Shacharis, we say the פטום הקטורת twice, once during korbanos and once right after "ein kelokeinu." Seemingly, we already fulfilled the purpose that we had with this prayer the first time we said it? And why do we specifically say it after "ein kelokeinu"?

Please give two separate answers, one using regular commentators and one using Chassidic sources, but if not, it is fine, thank you.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

Shaar Hakollel (3:12) discusses this at length. The gist of his answer is that the second recital, after Ein Keilokeinu, is the primary one, since just as the ketores was offered in the Beis Hamikdash after the morning Tamid, so do we first say Shemoneh Esrei (paralleling the Tamid) and afterwards the Ketores. The earlier time, in the Korbanos section, is more because of the power of the Ketores (and the recital of it) for purification, to get rid of negative spiritual forces, etc.

title: Answering a smartphone on Yom Tov
content:
# Answering a smartphone on Yom Tov ## Frage

On Yom Tov one may light a fire from a preexisting flame. I am wondering if that concept can translate to answering a call or a message on a smartphone.

Normally the screen of an iPhone or Motorola phone, for example, would light up when a call or message is received. In that case it could be said that the screen would be analogous to a preexisting flame. Now that being said, would swiping the screen to answer the call or message be analogous to increasing the flame?

On the other hand, the way a touchscreen work is that when one touches the screen the user’s finger causes a disruption of the electrical field and based on the disruption the controller determines the action of the user. In which case, it should be analogous to extinguishing a flame. Based on this reasoning, should the use of the touchscreen be considered a forbidden action and therefore one may not answer a smartphone on Yom Tov?

title: Sephardic Siddur without Mysticism
content:
# Sephardic Siddur without Mysticism ## Frage

As the title suggests, I am looking for a Siddur that has no references to the Kabbalistic Mysticism, such as Gilgul.

I actually used Sefaria but both the Ashkenazi and the Sephardi has the Mystic elements of Gilgul in them.

I want a Traditional Sephardic Siddur without any of those.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

I don't think you can find a modern Sephardic siddur without any mysticism. But you can come close.

The sidurrim of the Spanish Portuguese Jews of England have very little Kabbalistic influence. The same can be said of much older Sephardic siddurs of Amram and Saadia Gaon but these are not easily available to buy in print.

There is a Rambam Siddur that will be missing mysticism, but that's a recent publication and it's not based on an actual siddur, but based on various rulings and manuscripts

You will get recommendations for Yemenite siddurim as they tend to base their tiklal/siddur on the Rambam. My personal favorite is the Siah Yerushalayim series by Moreh Kafih.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

According to this question and its answers, there is the Adeni Siddur Sim Shalom (not to be confused with the Conservative Siddur of the same name).

Here is a link to read it online: https://tablet.otzar.org/#/book/196528/p/-1/t/1/fs/0/start/0/end/0/c. You will need access with Otzar which I do not have.

From what I understand, the Adenim did not incorporate many, if any, changes from Kabbalah, being in proximity to the Temanim who follow the Mishneh Torah, which is a Halachic Codex that was written before the advent of Kabbalistic changes to Tefilla.

As an Adeni myself, I am ashamed to admit that I do not own an Adeni Siddur, and use regular Sefardi/Edot Mizrachi Siddurim, and therefore have not confirmed the extent to which this is true, but I do believe I am not completely wrong.

To be even safer, you could consider getting a regular Temani Siddur (Shami or Balaadi, such as this Shami Siddur Zechor LeAvraham: http://www.nosachteiman.co.il/?CategoryID=580&ArticleID=532), but I believe Adeni Siddurim will be closer to "Sefardi" as you know it.

If neither of these please you, I'd suggest that you keep looking because regular Sefardi Siddurim, without Kabbalistic changes, certainly existed not too long ago and it shouldn't be too hard to find one. If you do, don't forget to post it as an answer here for us to see too! Hatzlacha.

title: Which direction to face when shaking the Lulav (not the order in which we shake)
content:
# Which direction to face when shaking the Lulav (not the order in which we shake) ## Frage

According to the Minhag to keep one’s body still while waving, which direction does one face?

I’ve read several times that one should face east, but no clear makor or reason was given. When I lived in America, I assumed it was to face Yerushalayim; however, since moving to eretz Yisrael, I notice that people are still facing east. When I asked for an explanation I was unable to get one.

To my knowledge, in the times of the Beis Hamikdash, Jews wave their lulavim and esrogim in the beis hamikdash. We continue to do this today during Succos.

Had the Jews in the Beis HaMikdash faced east for some kabbalistic reason, then in the beis hamikdash the entire klal would be turning their backs to the kadosh kadoshim and the shechinah to their west, which is very hard for me to understand.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: -3)

I've received some corrections from AI, and made corrections on it:

They circled the altar and the ceremonies thus facing all directions. Facing one direction is a modern adaptation anticipating the return to Jerusalem.

Did participants in the Temple's Sukkot lulav ritual face east, based on Mishnah Sukkah 4:5?

The Mishnah Sukkah 4:5 describes the Sukkot Hakafot (circumambulations) around the Temple altar, where priests, Levites, and the crowd waved the lulav and performed the aravah ritual:

Each day they would circle the altar one time and say: “Lord, please save us. Lord, please grant us success” (Psalms 118:25). Rabbi Yehuda says that they would say: Ani vaho, please save us..

The question is whether this implies they faced east while waving, as some modern customs suggest.

Answer

The mishnah describes the crowd standing facing the altar, waving lulavim in sync with the priests circling counterclockwise (Mishnah Sukkah 4:5; Talmud Sukkah 38b). The focus is on facing the dynamic procession, not a fixed cardinal direction like east. Classical sources (Rashi, Tosafot on Sukkah 51a; Rambam Hilchot Lulav 7:13) emphasize ritual unity, not orientation.

In contrast, post-Temple customs (e.g., Shulchan Aruch OC 651:8; Arizal) prescribe facing east during lulav waving, symbolizing the return to Jerusalem. This is a rabbinic innovation, not a Temple practice. The Temple ritual prioritized encircling the altar and communal participation, with waving in all directions to signify God's universal presence (Talmud Sukkah 37b).

Summary Table

Context Standing Direction of Wavers Source
Temple (Sukkot Hakafot) Dynamic, facing the counterclockwise procession (all sides of altar) Mishnah Sukkah 4:5; Talmud Sukkah 51a
Modern Custom Static, often facing east (symbolic) Shulchan Aruch OC 651:8; Arizal

Thus, the Temple practice does not support an east-facing orientation for lulav wavers.

Sources: Sefaria (Mishnah Sukkah, Talmud Sukkah); Rambam Hilchot Lulav; Shulchan Aruch OC 651.

My previous thoughts are below. Maybe they should be deleted, or maybe they're useful in understanding modern customs.

One faces east because even the kh"k, which contains the luchot haBrit, has their back on this, on the inyan of the Tzaddik who is the Berit who is in principle facing east (think Yossef haTzaddik or ..) and it's to him we are binding, and the klal is it's all Zekher Liysiyat Misrayim which was to the east, and Qriyat Yam Souf was in his merit, right?

These are no longer space dimensions, because Binah is discernment, past (Chokhma is foresight, future) and Malkhut is "the No Good" or counter-dimension to Keter per Sefer Yetzira. In the womb you have no direction. So maybe during Sukkot there's a less regard for directions. And if the Sukkah represents the Clouds of the Kavod, well in a cloud can you tell direction?

There's a story about a Tzaddik, an apparent hunchback beggar, who told about a conversation where ... eventually they want to get to this Tree that's above space. He tells this group, "Why argue about which side to get to the Tree? First ask who is worthy to get to that Tree! (He that attains the attributes of the Tree; its roots are faith, fear, and humility, and truth is the Tree's body). I believe this illustrates the level of the Spirit dimension (Keter-Malchus) over the other Sfirot namely time-space; by humility (contraction of Malkhut to Keter?) they're all Nothing. title: Why do we shake the lulav?
content:
# Why do we shake the lulav? ## Frage

I am familiar with the mystical meaning behind the directions that we shake the lulav, and of the commandment to assemble the Arba Minim in Vayikra, but there seems to be no place that discusses why we shake them.

Sukkot 3:9 mentions they shook them in the Beit Hamikdash, and is cited as the source of the mitzvah; but why did they shake them in the first place?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

The gemara in sukka 37b offers two reasons.

  1. Praise - praising HaShem Whom all directions are His.

  2. Request - a request from HaShem to stop bad winds and rains

Text of gemara:

"Rabbi Yoḥanan said: He moves them to and fro to dedicate them to He Whom the four directions are His. He raises and lowers them to He Whom the heavens and earth are His. In the West, Eretz Yisrael, they taught it as follows. Rabbi Ḥama bar Ukva said that Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said: He moves them to and fro in order to request a halt to harmful winds, storms and tempests that come from all directions; he raises and lowers them in order to halt harmful dews and rains that come from above "

title: Why the frequency of וימן in Yonah
content:
# Why the frequency of וימן in Yonah ## Frage

Anyone reading Yonah will notice that the word וימן appears a bunch of times. And after a quick search, it seems this word is used 5 times in Tanach, with 4 of those times being here in Yonah (link). Do any commentaries discuss this?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Rabbi Ahron Marcus in his book Barzilai (ברזילי) on the development of Hebrew over the ages, with an emphasis on Tanachic Hebrew), discussed (pp. 205-208) the unique aspects of Yonah's Hebrew within a wider discussion of the unique linguistic aspects of each of the main prophets. Among other things, he wrote:

"עם הקמת בית המקדש נוספו לשפה העברית מונחי בנין רבים, בהשפעתם של אדריכלים ואמני בנייה סוריים...בעקבות הקרע לשתי ממלכות, יהודה וישראל, נוצר מצב, שאחת גובלת בעמים המדברים בניב שמי דרומי, ולשניה שכנים דוברי ניב שמי צפוני...בממלכת ישראל, בין אוכלוסיה מרוחקת מהמקור החי של שפת תהלים אשר בירושלים, מופיעים הנביאים הקדומים - אחיה, אליהו ואלישע. הם נסוגים לבדידות המדבר וההרים מפני המלכים הנמשכים אחרי פולחנים נכריים...עד שסוף סוף, פולחן הבעל נעקר על ידי יהוא וממלכת ישראל מתקרבת לירושלים. התקרבות הזאת באה לידי בטוי אצל תלמידו של אלישע, יונה בן אמתי, אשר מגת החפר. עיר מולדתו, גת חפר, היתה בשבט זבולון, לא רחוק מצידון, והיתה מוקפת בתחום השפה הפיניקית, אשר השפעתה מצויה בשפע בדברי נביא זה. אבל לפי המסורת, קיבל יונה הנביא את השראת נבואתו בשעת עליתו לרגל ירושלימה. בהתאם לכך, תפילתו חוזרת על מזמורים הסדורים בכל חמשת ספרי תהלים..."

"With the construction of the Beit Hamikdash many architectural terms were added to the Hebrew language, influenced by Syrian architects and artisans...following the split into two kingdoms, Yehudah and Yisrael, a situation was born whereby one bordered nations speaking southern Semitic dialects, and the other had neighbors speaking northern Semitic dialects...in the Kingdom of Yisrael, among a population distant from the living source of the language of Tehillim in Yerushalayim, appeared the ancient prophets - Achiyah, Eliyahu and Elisha. They escaped to the solitude of the wilderness and mountains in the face of kings who were drawn after foreign worship...until finally, the worship of Ba'al was uprooted by Yehu and the Kingdom of Yisrael began moving closer to Yerushalayim. This process was manifested in Elisha's student, Yonah ben Amitai from Gath-Chefer. His birth town, Gath-Chefer, was in the Tribe of Zevulun, not far from Sidon, and was surrounded by the region of the Phoenician language, whose influence is clearly visible in the language of this prophet. However, according to tradition, the prophet Yonah received his prophetic inspiration while making pilgrimage (aliyah) to Yerushalayim. Following that, his prayers return to the standard psalms in all five books of Tehillim..."

Rabbi Marcus then listed the unique or almost-unique words used by Yonah and noted where the uncommon phrases appeared elsewhere in the Tanach, as well as showing where Yonah used phrases from Tehillim. One of the words he noted was וימן, as well as several other words and phrases.

The gist of this idea is that Yonah's usage of this word, as well as other terms, reflects his own unique linguistic background, as a person who came from the northern Zebulonite town of Gath-Chepher in a heavily Phoenician-influenced region, while at the same time being drawn to Judahite Hebrew as he picked it up while visiting Yerushalayim. This is demonstrative of the statement the gemara in Sanhedrin 89a put in the mouth of King Yehoshafat:

"כָּךְ מְקוּבְּלַנִי מִבֵּית אֲבִי אַבָּא: סִיגְנוֹן אֶחָד עוֹלֶה לְכַמָּה נְבִיאִים, וְאֵין שְׁנֵי נְבִיאִים מִתְנַבְּאִים בְּסִיגְנוֹן אֶחָד."

"This is the tradition that I received from the house of the father of my father: A prophetic vision relating to one and the same subject matter may appear to several prophets, but two prophets do not prophesy employing one and the same style of expression."

title: Why take three hadasim if symbolize two eyes?
content:
# Why take three hadasim if symbolize two eyes? ## Frage

The Midrash Vayikra Rabbah (30:14) writes:

רַבִּי מָנֵי פָּתַח (תהלים לה, י): כָּל עַצְמֹתַי תֹּאמַרְנָה ה' מִי כָמוֹךָ, לֹא נֶאֱמַר פָּסוּק זֶה אֶלָּא בִּשְׁבִיל לוּלָב, הַשִּׁדְרָה שֶׁל לוּלָב דּוֹמָה לַשִּׁדְרָה שֶׁל אָדָם, וְהַהֲדַס דּוֹמֶה לָעַיִן, וַעֲרָבָה דּוֹמָה לַפֶּה, וְהָאֶתְרוֹג דּוֹמֶה לַלֵּב, אָמַר דָּוִד אֵין בְּכָל הָאֵיבָרִים גָּדוֹל מֵאֵלּוּ, שֶׁהֵן שְׁקוּלִין כְּנֶגֶד כָּל הַגּוּף, הֱוֵי: כָּל עַצְמוֹתַי תֹּאמַרְנָה - Rabbi Mani began: “All my bones will say: Lord, who is comparable to You” (Psalms 35:10) – this verse is stated only for the sake of the palm branch. The spine of the palm branch resembles the spine of a person, the myrtle resembles the eye, the willow resembles the mouth, and the citron resembles the heart.

The Shulchan Aruch OC (651:1) paskens: מצות ד' מינים שיטול כל אחד לולב א' וב' ערבות וג' הדסים - we we take one lulav (one spine), one esrog (one heart), two aravos (two lips), and...three hadasim (two eyes).

Why do we take three rather than two hadasim to parallel our two eyes?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The Shemen HaTov answers that we view the world through three lenses: the past, present, and future, as Pirkei Avos (3:1) writes:

עֲקַבְיָא בֶן מַהֲלַלְאֵל אוֹמֵר, הִסְתַּכֵּל בִּשְׁלשָׁה דְבָרִים וְאִי אַתָּה בָא לִידֵי עֲבֵרָה. דַּע מֵאַיִן בָּאתָ, וּלְאָן אַתָּה הוֹלֵךְ, וְלִפְנֵי מִי אַתָּה עָתִיד לִתֵּן דִּין וְחֶשְׁבּוֹן. מֵאַיִן בָּאתָ, מִטִּפָּה סְרוּחָה, וּלְאָן אַתָּה הוֹלֵךְ, לִמְקוֹם עָפָר רִמָּה וְתוֹלֵעָה. וְלִפְנֵי מִי אַתָּה עָתִיד לִתֵּן דִּין וְחֶשְׁבּוֹן, לִפְנֵי מֶלֶךְ מַלְכֵי הַמְּלָכִים הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא: Akabyah ben Mahalalel said: mark well three things and you will not come into the power of sin: know from where you come, and where you are going, and before whom you are destined to give an account and reckoning. From where do you come? From a putrid drop. Where are you going? To a place of dust, of worm and of maggot. Before whom you are destined to give an account and reckoning? Before the King of the kings of kings, the Holy One, blessed be He.

We must know our past, recognize the present, and anticipate the future, and the three hadasim symbolize those three perspectives.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

The reason the hadasim resemble the eyes is due to its leaf shapes as explained by Eitz Yosef on Vayikra Rabba 30:14

ההדס דומה לעין. שדומה בתבניתה רחבה באמצע ומתקצרת בצדו כעין ממש. ועוד בזה דומה לעין מפני שהבד מכוסה בעלין עד שאין רואין אותו כל עיקר כמו שאין העין ניכר בשעה שהוא עצום:

The myrtle resembles an eye. It resembles it in its shape, wide in the middle and shortened at the sides, like a real eye. Moreover, it resembles an eye because the stem (branch) is covered with leaves until it is not visible at all, just as the eye is not visible when it is closed:

One can answer why we take 3 hadasim branches in the bundle from Vayikra Rabba 30:11:

דָּבָר אַחֵר, פְּרִי עֵץ הָדָר, זוֹ סַנְהֶדְרֵי גְדוֹלָה שֶׁל יִשְׂרָאֵל שֶׁהִדְּרָם הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא בְּשֵׂיבָה טוֹבָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר (ויקרא יט, לב): מִפְּנֵי שֵׂיבָה תָּקוּם. כַּפֹּת תְּמָרִים, אֵלּוּ תַּלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים שֶׁכּוֹפִין אֶת עַצְמָן לִלְמֹד תּוֹרָה אֵלּוּ מֵאֵלּוּ. וַעֲנַף עֵץ עָבֹת, אֵלּוּ שָׁלשׁ שׁוּרוֹת שֶׁל תַּלְמִידִים שֶׁיּוֹשְׁבִין לִפְנֵיהֶם. וְעַרְבֵי נָחַל, אֵלּוּ שְׁנֵי סוֹפְרִים שֶׁל דַּיָּנִין שֶׁעוֹמְדִים לִפְנֵיהֶם וְכוֹתְבִין דִּבְרֵי הַמְזַכִּים וְדִבְרֵי הַמְחַיְּבִין.

Another matter: “The fruit of a pleasant [hadar] tree” – this is the Great Sanhedrin of Israel, whom the Holy One blessed be He glorified [shehideram] with good old age, as it is stated: “You shall rise before the elderly [and show deference [vehadarta] to the old]” (Leviticus 19:32) 1. “Branches of [kapot] date palms” – these are Torah scholars, who humble [shekofin] themselves to learn from one another. “A bough of a leafy tree” – these are the three rows of students who sit before them.2 “Willows of the brook” – these are the two judges’ scribes who stand before them and record the words of those who acquit and the words of those who convict.

1 “The old [zaken]” is interpreted by the Sages as one who has acquired wisdom [zeh shekana ḥokhma], in this case, a reference to the elders of the Great Sanhedrin.

2Three rows of students would sit before the Great Sanhedrin when they deliberated a case. The allusion here is based on the three Hebrew words in the phrase “a bough of a leafy tree [anaf etz avot].”

Why connection it has to the eyes? That's because the judgements of the great Sanhedrin must be watched and witnessed by the students who make up 3 rows of eyes.

A stronger similar question would be, why does the hadas should be ideally triple leaved, i.e. it should look like a row of triple leaves, each triple growing at the same level? The question can be answered, that the talmidim witness the testimonies of the 2 sides corresponding to each of 2 eyes, but they ultimately have to figure out the truth, as G-d would view the matter (3rd eye). This idea can be connected to several mishnayos in Pirkei Avos.

Additionally, one can say that, in parallel, in the eye one can see 3 parts: the white (sclera), the iris, and the pupil.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 0)

The Mishnah in Sukkah 3:4 says :

רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל אוֹמֵר, שְׁלשָׁה הֲדַסִּים וּשְׁתֵּי עֲרָבוֹת, לוּלָב אֶחָד וְאֶתְרוֹג אֶחָד, אֲפִלּוּ שְׁנַיִם קְטוּמִים וְאֶחָד אֵינוֹ קָטוּם. רַבִּי טַרְפוֹן אוֹמֵר, אֲפִלּוּ שְׁלָשְׁתָּן קְטוּמִים. רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר, כְּשֵׁם שֶׁלּוּלָב אֶחָד וְאֶתְרוֹג אֶחָד, כָּךְ הֲדַס אֶחָד וַעֲרָבָה אֶחָת

Rabbi Yishmael says: The mitzva of the four species is to take three myrtle branches, and two willow branches, one lulav, and one etrog. With regard to the myrtle branches, even if the tops of two are severed and the top of one is not severed, it is fit. Rabbi Tarfon says: Even if the tops of all three are severed, it is fit. Rabbi Akiva says with regard to the number of each of the species: Just as there is one lulav and one etrog, so too there is one myrtle branch and one willow branch.

And the Rambam to comment: ר' ישמעאל אומר ג' הדסים ושתי ערבות וכו': דע כי שיעור ערבה והדס באורך ג' טפחים מן הטפחים הידועים שהן ד' אצבעות בגודל. והלכה כר' ישמעאל וכר' טרפון: And know that the length of the myrtle and the willow is three handbreadths from the handbreadths that are known which are four [fingers] in size (see Tractate Sukkah 32b and the Laws of Lulav, Chapter 7, Halakha 8) and the Halakha is according to Rabbi Yishmael and according to Rabbi Tarfon.

It seems you are referring to the case that is brought in the Binyan Tzyion 154 where a women is "coerced" to have relations with a man claiming to be Eliyahu and promising the Mashiach will come forth and this is the divine plan. title: How do we reconcile the well known idea that fish are immune to the ayin hara with the fact that their eyes are always wide open & visually prominent
content:
# How do we reconcile the well known idea that fish are immune to the ayin hara with the fact that their eyes are always wide open & visually prominent ## Frage

The idea that fish protect us from ayin hara is one of the themes of Rosh Hashanah. That’s why Ashkenazim use a fish head at the meal, and why we do tashlich in rivers, which have fish. The common explanation is that fish are hidden from view, and so too, we ask to be hidden from the eyes of our enemies—from their jealousy, their judgment, their negativity.

But something about that feels off to me. Fish might be hidden, yes—but they also have strange, prominent eyes. In a physical sense, they actually do have what you could call a “bad eye.” So how exactly are they the symbol of protection from ayin hara, when they seem to embody it in the most literal way?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

Maybe fish do have an ayin hara—but it’s empty. Their eyes might look harsh, but there’s no thought or intent behind them. They’re just staring. So maybe we actually want that kind of ayin hara—one that checks the box but doesn’t do any damage. A budget version. Because kabbalists say: most people are carrying some kind of ayin hara already. Might as well get it from a fish.

title: קבע in Torah versus Tefila

# קבע in Torah versus Tefila ## Frage

Our תפילה is not supposed to be קבע- e.g.:

ברכות ד ד. רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר, הָעוֹשֶׂה תְפִלָּתוֹ קֶבַע, אֵין תְּפִלָּתוֹ תַּחֲנוּנִים.

אבות ב יג. רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן (בן נתנאל) אוֹמֵר, הֱוֵי זָהִיר בִּקְרִיאַת שְׁמַע וּבַתְּפִלָּה. וּכְשֶׁאַתָּה מִתְפַּלֵּל, אַל תַּעַשׂ תְּפִלָּתְךָ קֶבַע, אֶלָּא רַחֲמִים וְתַחֲנוּנִים לִפְנֵי הַמָּקוֹם בָּרוּךְ הוּא, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר (יואל ב יג) כִּי חַנּוּן וְרַחוּם הוּא אֶרֶךְ אַפַּיִם וְרַב חֶסֶד וְנִחָם עַל הָרָעָה. וְאַל תְּהִי רָשָׁע בִּפְנֵי עַצְמְךָ:

On the other hand, our תורה is supposed to be קבע, e.g.:

אבות א טו. שַׁמַּאי אוֹמֵר, עֲשֵׂה תוֹרָתְךָ קֶבַע. אֱמֹר מְעַט וַעֲשֵׂה הַרְבֵּה, וֶהֱוֵי מְקַבֵּל אֶת כָּל הָאָדָם בְּסֵבֶר פָּנִים יָפוֹת:

שבת לא. אָמַר רָבָא: בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁמַּכְנִיסִין אָדָם לְדִין, אוֹמְרִים לוֹ: נָשָׂאתָ וְנָתַתָּ בָּאֱמוּנָה? קָבַעְתָּ עִתִּים לַתּוֹרָה?

Is there anyone who explains this dichotomy explicitly?

title: Dvora from Genesis and Dvora from Judges: Reincarnation?
content:
# Dvora from Genesis and Dvora from Judges: Reincarnation? ## Frage

It is written in the book of Judges (4:4-5):

Deborah, wife of Lappidoth, was a prophet; she led Israel at that time.
She used to sit under the Palm of Deborah, between Ramah and Bethel in the hill country of Ephraim, and the Israelites would come to her for decisions.

And in the book Genesis (35:8):

Deborah, Rebekah’s nurse, died, and was buried under the oak below Bethel; so it was named Allon-bacuth

Same name, a tree and Beth El are mentioned. Any sources that Deborah from Judges is the Gilgul of Deborah from Genesis ?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

It's a highly interesting observation, but after intensive searching I .have not found anyone suggesting it. It is, however, extremely widely quoted that דבורה הנביאה was a גלגול of צפורה who didn't sing the שירה after קריעת ים סוף due to the fact that she only joined her husband משה afterwards. That's why she, as דבורה, sang שירת דבורה. See for example ילקוט ראוביני פרשת שמות. It is also brought widely that דבורה also was a גלגול of תמר who put herself into a situation of יחוד with יהודה which is why דבורה sat in an open place, תַּחַת־תֹּמֶר דְּבוֹרָה (with the word תומר written as תמר). See ספר גלגולי נשמות להרמ"ע מפאנו. After having written this I did find some connection between the two Devorahs. See דעת זקנים בראשית לה-ח who writes that the תומר דבורה were דבורה הנביאה sat was the spot where דברה מינקת יעקב was buried.

title: Stretching Torah Letters to Make the Column "Beautifully Justified" - How to know if the rules are correctly applied?
content:
# Stretching Torah Letters to Make the Column "Beautifully Justified" - How to know if the rules are correctly applied? ## Frage

I was privileged to receive an aliyah this Shabbat Ha'azinu. I was looking at how the Sofer who wrote the Sefer Torah stretched the letters and there was indeed a lot of stretching. The double-columns themselves were indeed beautifully justified, but the letters did look a bit weird. I understand that's subjective so I decided to do a bit of research as this is not my area of expertise.

I had a look at לשכת הסופר י״ד. It gives guidelines on stretching letters, and basically says a few things:

  1. One may not stretch or shrink the width/height of the letter in a way that changes its normal form.

  2. One may make small, aesthetic adjustments, particularly at the end of a line, in order to make the column justified.

  3. Excessive stretching is not allowed, if it changes the letter's shape (e.g. turning a ר into something that looks like a ו).

  4. The following letters can be stretched: Only those letters that have natural room for widening or lengthening without deforming: א, ד, ה, ל, ק, ר, ת, and sometimes מ סתומה.

How exactly can we know if they have been applied properly? They are a bit subjective, especially 2. I was seeing letters stretched to 3 or 4 times their normal length?

Bonus question: which verses in the Torah are "notoriously hard to justify" due to a lack of "beautiful letters"? Any soferim here care to share their safrut woes, whether it be for a Sefer Torah, Mezuzah, Tefillin etc.?

title: What does "zeh mayesh" (זה מה יש) mean?

title: Why did Nineveh repent?
content:
# Why did Nineveh repent? ## Frage

In the story of Jonah we read earlier today in shul, God tells Jonah to go to Nineveh, capital of Assyria, and tell the people to repent or He will destroy them. After many twists and turns, Jonah warns Nineveh and they repent, so God spares them.

Why did Nineveh repent? They were a warlike superpower, guilty of the worst atrocities you can imagine, and idolatrous to the hilt. Then they see a little guy they never heard of showing up from afar and telling them (halfheartedly) to "repent" or "God" will destroy them. They never heard of Jonah or his god, or see him perform miracles. Why would they repent? You would think they would laugh in his face, then kill him. But they immediately "believe God", go on a fast, put on sackcloth and sit in ashes [Jonah 3:5-6], then "turn back from their evil ways" [Jonah 3:8], so God does not destroy them. Did they even know what is "evil"? Who told them?

There's got to be more to this story. What?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Per the Midrash (see here), Nineveh's king was Pharaoh, so he had a thing or two to tell this city about the King of the World.

According to the Midrash, it was because the king of Nineveh had been the king of Egypt, many moons ago. Apparently his memory had yet to fail him, and he knew that God meant business. He had learned his lesson long ago, and made sure that the next time God came calling, if He came calling, He would back down immediately and comply with the divine will.

Or, if the original Pharaoh had already died, he made sure that his descendants learned the lesson and applied it when they were king. Either way, Pharaoh had changed his ways after losing everything at the splitting of the sea. And Moshe, anticipating this, could tell Pharaoh back in Egypt, “You’re right, the next time we meet you will not be the same Pharaoh.”

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

This is an excellent question, one which bothered Yonah himself, according to the midrashim. Ultimately, he concluded that there was a strong chance they would do teshuva, which lead him to make the final decision to flee from God.

Many have given the answer that it was the King that encouraged/pressured the people to do teshuva - something Yonah no doubt considered given that he knew it was King Pharaoh. Here are a couple more reasons:

  1. According to Radak on Yonah 1:3 they were more likely to repent than the Jewish people. Netzach Yisrael 14 says that this is because the Jewish people are more stubborn than pagans.
  2. According to Rav Tzadok HaKohen, Pri Tzaddik, Vayelech 17, and Dover Tzedek, Achrei Mot; Chatam Sofer, Tehillim 147:6; Kochvei Ohr; Radal, note 7, on Pirkei d'Rabbi Eliezer 10: the decision to repent would not have the same profound implications for pagans as it does for Jews, and is therefore an easier decision to make. When Jews repent, they have to utterly eradicate sin from their hearts and return to Hashem with love and inspiration, which is a very difficult process. Pagans only have to desist from sin (of which they have less to worry about), and this can be achieved by simple fear of punishment.

Based on research of Yosef Deutsch, Let My Nation Be Warned. Note: I have not verified these sources, and potentially misinterpreted which idea fell on which footnote. I have also had an example where I could not find something he said. I just say this to avoid anyone going on a wild goose chase. If anyone verifies these sources please let me know and I can remove this note, and will try to do so myself if I find the time.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 1)

This is discussed in Pirkei d'Rabbi Eliezer chapter 43. It says there as follows:

רַבִּי נְחוּנְיָא בֶּן הַקָּנָה אוֹמֵר: תֵּדַע לְךָ כֹּחַ הַתְּשׁוּבָה. בֹּא וּרְאֵה מִפַּרְעֹה מֶלֶךְ מִצְרַיִם שֶׁמָּרַד בְּצוּר עֶלְיוֹן הַרְבֵּה מְאֹד, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״מִי ה' אֲשֶׁר אֶשְׁמַע בְּקוֹלוֹ״. וּבַלָּשׁוֹן שֶׁחָטָא בּוֹ בַּלָּשׁוֹן עָשָׂה תְשׁוּבָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״מִי כָמֹכָה בָּאֵלִם ה', מִי כָּמֹכָה נֶאְדָּר בַּקֹּדֶשׁ״. וְהִצִּילוֹ הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא בֵּין הַמֵּתִים. מִנַּיִן שֶׁלֹּא מֵת? שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״כִּי עַתָּה שָׁלַחְתִּי אֶת יָדִי וָאַךְ אוֹתְךָ, וְאוּלָם בַּעֲבוּר זֹאת הֶעֱמַדְתִּיךָ״ וְכוּ'. וְהָלַךְ וּמָלַךְ בְּנִינְוֵה. וְהָיוּ אַנְשֵׁי נִינְוֵה כּוֹתְבִים מִכְתְּבֵי עָמָל וְגוֹזְלִים אִישׁ אֶת רֵעֵהוּ, וּבָאִים אִישׁ עַל רֵעֵהוּ בְּמִשְׁכַּב זָכוּר. וּבָא אֶצְלוֹ מַעֲשֵׂיהֶם הָרָעִים. וּכְשֶׁשָּׁלַח הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא לְיוֹנָה לְהִנָּבֵא עָלֶיהָ לְהַחֲרִיבָהּ, שָׁמַע פַּרְעֹה וְעָמַד מִכִּסְאוֹ וְקָרַע בְּגָדָיו וְלָבַשׁ שַׂק וָאֵפֶר, וְהִכְרִיז בְּכָל עַמּוֹ שֶׁיָּצוּמוּ כָּל הָעָם שְׁנֵי יָמִים, וְכָל מִי שֶׁיַּעֲשֶׂה אֶת הַדְּבָרִים הַלָּלוּ יִשָּׂרֵף בָּאֵשׁ.

Rabbi Nechunia, son of Haḳḳanah, said: Know thou the power of repentance. Come and see from Pharaoh, king of Egypt, who rebelled most grievously against the Rock, the Most High, as it is said, "Who is the Lord, that I should hearken unto his voice?" (Ex. 5:2). In the same terms of speech in which he sinned, he repented, as it is said "Who is like thee, O Lord, among the mighty?" (Ex. 15:11). The Holy One, blessed be He, delivered him from amongst the dead. Whence (do we know) that he died? Because it is said, "For now I had put forth my hand, and smitten thee" (Ex. 9:15). He went and ruled in Nineveh. The men of Nineveh were writing fraudulent deeds, and everyone robbed his neighbour, and they committed sodomy, and such-like wicked actions. When the Holy One, blessed be He, sent for Jonah, to prophesy against (the city) its destruction, Pharaoh hearkened and arose from his throne, rent his garments and clothed himself in sackcloth and ashes, and had a proclamation made to all his people, that all the people should fast for two days, and all who did these (wicked) things should be burnt by fire.

In other words,the king knew what it meant when a prophet showed up warning him that Hashem would destroy his people.

title: Is it permissible to look at women if one is not seeking beauty?
content:
# Is it permissible to look at women if one is not seeking beauty? ## Frage

I find it difficult to always avoid looking at women in public spaces, especially when I am not intentionally seeking beauty or looking with desire. Is it permissible according to Halacha to look at women in such situations, as long as the intention is not for pleasure or attraction?

Please include sources in your answer.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Ask your Local Orthodox Rabbi for practical p'sak to your individual situation. My answer is:

yes, so long as they are dressed appropriately

...but do not follow that as p'sak. Here's my justification:

General case for men looking at women

There are 3 types of looking for our purposes1:

  1. Leer: Looking lustfully.
  2. Gaze: Looking to enjoy beauty.
  3. Glance: Looking without either of the above. Just looking.

One is not allowed to even glance (3) at the normally-covered parts of a woman's body (which is the basic halachic definition of "erva"/"nakedness", and includes also the hair of a married/widowed/divorced woman, and a woman's singing voice), even if one isn't trying to derive enjoyment from the glance2.

If the looking is "leering" or "gazing" (1 or 2) i.e. deliberate watching/staring, and the woman is forbidden to him, then it is forbidden even if she is appropriately dressed (if he knows her, then even if one isn't looking at her, but just looking at her clothes!)3.

With regards to all of this, known as "shemirat enayim" (guarding one's eyes), the consensus is it is d'oraita4. See the Sefer HaMitzvot Negative Mitzvah 475. All the more so if she is inappropriately dressed.

It is based off of Bamidbar 15:39:

ולא תתורו אחרי לבבכם ואחרי עיניכם אשר אתם זונים אחריהם

Do not follow your heart and eyes after which you are going astray.

Rambam says in Hilchot Teshuva 4:4:

Someone who looks at forbidden women will think that there is no problem, since he will say: “Did I have intercourse or draw close to her?” But he does not know that looking is a great sin.

Exceptions

  • It is permissible to look (3) at a woman when talking to her, if he does not do so for the purposes of enjoying her appearance2, and certainly he must not look at ervah. Following the advice of Rabbeinu Yonah in Sefer HaYira (starting from Vayetze mibeit hakneset), as a precaution one should minimise the looking to avoid improper thoughts coming against one's will.
  • It is permissible for a male doctor to look (3) at a female patient, even her normally covered parts, as part of his examination and treatment - he is totally absorbed in his work and therefore the authorities permitted it6.
  • We are less strict about gazing (2) at one's mother, daughter and sister, as well as any Jewish girl under the age of 11, although of course lustful thoughts are completely forbidden even here7.
  • A man looking to marry may look at (2) and intentionally examine the beauty of his suitors, in order to determine if he finds them attractive. This is not only permitted, but fitting, as one is not allowed to marry someone he is not attracted to. Once this is determined he may continue looking at her while they continue to meet before marriage, but he must avoid deriving pleasure from her beauty8.
  • One may look at one's wife (2) during the time of Niddah9, as she will become permissible to him soon so we are not worried about anything improper. However, he may not look at her nakedness i.e. parts that are normally covered, including her hair.

1 - Following Lift Up Your Eyes - R' S. Wagshal
2 - במ״ב סי׳ ע״ה ס״ק ז. See footnote 7 pp. 17 of Lift Up Your Eyes for full explanation and discussion.
3 - See Sefer Chareidim 2:4, Shulchan Aruch Even HaEzer 21:1. Be'er Hetev there brings Rabbeinu Yonah citing this is d'oraita, and Rambam as an example saying it is d'rabbanan. Note Rambam and others apparently derive it from Ketubot 46a, and Devarim 23:10 וְּנִשְׁמַרְתָּ מִכֹּל דָּבָר רָע. See Issurei Beiah 21:21
4 - Ritva and a few others hold it is d'rabbanan. Either way it is completely forbidden.
5 - Also, there are additional laws about not reciting berachot and studying Torah in front of nudity, even if one isn't looking (but is facing the nudity), which are completely off topic here but be aware they exist and look them up!
6 - See Shach on SH Y'D 195 s'k 20
7 - See footnote 13 of pp.22 in Lift Up Your Eyes for full discussion and explanation.
8 - SH E'H 21:3
9 - SH Y'D 195:7

title: Source for Burnout
content:
# Source for Burnout ## Frage

Is there a source that one should let go of limud hatorah when burning out?

How about letting go of other stuff, like kavana by prayer?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

When you notice burnout in learning, kavana, and your other devotions, how about a break?

Breslov and Na Nach on Burnout in Torah Study and Prayer

By "burnout" perhaps you mean yi'uf (exhaustion, Isaiah 40:30) or atzvut (sadness/depression [this is not a medical answer; maybe it's better!]). Rebbe Nachman of Breslov, the Tzaddik haEmet, teaches that forcing limud Torah or kavana during fatigue risks spiritual alienation. Instead, temporarily lighten intensity or pause, using hitbodedut (private meditation and prayer) or simcha (joy) to restore connection to Hashem. Don't fight the burnout; observe it, accept it as a benevolent messenger from your Shadow (see Carl Jung, the Tao, Buddhism, Alan Watts etc.) The Na Nach chant—“Na Nach Nachma Nachman MeUman”—lifts despair, reigniting passion! (Saba). Below are some citations from Sifre Breslev and suggested applications for those facing burnout.

1. Burning Out in Learning? Take a break!

Ease study to preserve spiritual vitality.

Source Quote Application
Likutei Moharan I:8 “When a person sighs over the (whatever thing is) lacking and extends his ruach, he draws the ruach-of-life to that which he is lacking.” Yi'uf tiring study? Sigh in hitbodedut—shift to simple Torah (e.g., Psalms) or rest. Your breath sparks renewal!
Likutei Moharan II:24 “It is a great mitzvah to always be happy [mitzvah gedolah lihyot b’simcha tamid].” Atzvut halting Torah? Release intensity; find joy in small acts (a simple mitzva,; a sip of coffee; watch the birds). Na Nach: Chant to dispel the yetzer hara.

See also Rabbi Nachman's wonderous advices regarding various types of "sleep" to renew your Enumah, in your other related question.

2. Letting Go of Kavana in Prayer When Exhausted

Raw effort trumps forced focus in fatigue.

Source Quote Application
Likutei Moharan II:25 If at times you find yourself unable to speak to God or even open your mouth, the very fact that you are there before Him wanting and yearning to speak is itself very good. You can even turn your very inability to speak into a prayer. Tell God that you feel so far away that you cannot even speak to Him! Ask Him to have mercy on you and open your mouth to tell Him what you need. No kavana from yi'uf? Drop elaborate intent; groans suffice. Your raw cry thrills Hashem!
Likutei Etzot - Hitchazkut 26. When a person falls from his level, he should know that it is from Heaven, for distance is the ultimate means of drawing closer... He should continue to search and seek until he finds within himself some other good thing, and through this, he discovers some merit and goodness. Through this, one can truly move from the scale of obligation to the scale of merit, and one can truly turn to God. Through this, one can revive oneself, strengthen oneself, and find joy in whatever situation he is in, and then he can pray, sing, and give thanks to God. (L. Moharan 282 "Azamra") Tired? Core blessings only ("say one word in truth"); hitbodedut clears atzvut. Na Nach: Chant lifts prayer effortlessly.

Conclusion

Burning out -- Yi'uf/atzvut -- is a forge for ascent. Rebbe Nachman urges: “The big mitzva is -- Be happy always!”.

In addition, Likutei Etzot has entire sections on "Truth and Faith" - Hitbodedut - Hitchazkut - "Fear and Devotions" - Patience - "Desire and Aspiration" - Refuah - Simcha - Shalom - Talmud Torah - Tefilah - and more; see there.

Read biographies or watch videos or recordings like those of Sabba Yisrael Dov Ber Odesser z"l (book: ישראל סבא - Saba Yisrael). "Ribono shel Oilom! I can't learn. I can't pray. Have compassion on me! You are the Compassionate One -- have pity on me! [laughs] ... Na Nach, Nachma Nachman meUman! [laughs]"

Myself, I have greatly benefited from these new AI videos on Youtube a la Joe Dispenza, Carl Jung, Alan Watts, J.S. Bach, etc. -- which have helped me go deeper into internalizing Breslev and Nanach ways and advices. Let go. Be yourself. Accept. Don't fight burnout -- recognize and accept it, then be born anew. Know yourself; don't do what's not in alignment with your Self; then be assured with faith, that the right learning and avodah that is tune with you, will follow.

title: Nechamiah ben Chushiel and Serayah ben Dan
content:
# Nechamiah ben Chushiel and Serayah ben Dan ## Frage

tl;dr: What is the reason for calling Mashiach ben Yosef specifically "Nechemiah ben Chushiel" and his righthand man "Serayah ben Dan"?

If I'm not mistaken, starting from the ca. 7th-8th century pseudepigraphic apocalyptic work Sefer Zerubavel (and contemporary or near-contemporary works such as piyutim that were likely based on Zerubavel) and going forward, a significant number of Jewish sources state that the name of Mashiach ben Yosef is/will be Nechamiah ben Chushiel (נחמיה בן חושיאל) (link to one relevant passage in Zerubavel; another example in Hechalot Rabbati; Bnei Yissaschar, etc.). Many modern scholars have proposed identifying Nechemiah ben Chushiel with an actual figure (i.e., that this was the real name of a historic figure), the nameless leader of the Jews in Eretz Yisrael in the early 7th century CE, circa the Sassanian (Persian)-Byzantine War of 602-628 CE (whence Yerushalayim was captured by the Persians in 614),1 and later borrowed by Jews and repurposed as the name of Mashiach ben Yosef, based on historical memories of the greatness of the original namesake.

I myself am skeptical that this was ever the name of an actual past historical figure. It seems more like a symbolical name, like the name Menachem ben Chizkiyah (מנחם בן חזקיה), the name of Mashiach ben David according to Chazalic sources, later transformed into Menachem ben Amiel (מנחם בן עמיאל). Menachem is well-known as one of the symbolic names of the Mashiach (Sanhedrin 98b; Yerushalmi Brachot 2:4; Eicha Rabbah 1:51; etc), and Chizkiyah was the name of one of the most righteous kings of Am Yisrael, who was supposed to have been the Mashiach himself at one point (Sanhedrin 94a).2 Nechemiah has the same connotation as Menachem: Comfort, consolation (נחמה). And Chushiel reminds me of the phrase "בְּעִתָּהּ אֲחִישֶׁנָּה" (Yeshayahu 60:22) - a request from Hashem to speed up the redemption.

Another figure mentioned in sources starting from the Zohar and later is Serayah ben Dan (שריה בן דן), who is supposed to be Mashiach ben Yosef's Chief of War (שר צבא, presumably meaning his righthand man) (e.g., Zohar Balak 194:2; Kol Ha'Tor 1:28). Here, too, there are some messianic connotations in the "ben Dan" part. Already Chazal present a notion of a kind of "Mashiach ben Dan", so to speak (Shimshon was thought to be the Mashiach - Beresheet Rabbah 98:14;3 according to Bamidbar Rabbah 10:5 the Mashiach is a descendant of Dan on his mother's side, etc). My assumption is that also in the case of Serayah ben Dan, this was not the name of a real historic figure, but is symbolic (and unlike the prior two figures, I have not found suggestions to the contrary).

Following that assumption, I was wondering whether there were any sources that explain the reasoning behind naming Mashiach ben Yosef and his assistant specifically these names. I mentioned some possible reasons for Nechemiah ben Chushiel, but these are just my own thoughts. Was "Nechamiah" chosen specifically to compliment "Menachem", or is there another reason? And why "Chushiel"? I also have no idea why specifically "Serayah" for the Danite. And do the two names (Nechamiah ben Chushiel and Serayah ben Dan) compliment each other somehow?

1 This theory is so popular nowadays that it is presented as fact in the linked Wikipedia entry. However, the relevant historical sources that describe the period and mention the Jews of the time never actually refer to this person by that name (or any other name).

2 However, like in the case of Nechemiah, scholars have proposed that the name Menachem ben Chizkiyah was also borrowed from a historic figure. Some propose Menachem ben Yehudah ben Chizkiyah the Galilean zealot of the 1st century CE (e.g., Yosef Klausner, The History of the Second Temple Period, vol. 5 [in Hebrew], pp. 148-149), and others propose a hypothetical son of Chizkiyah, Resh Galuta ca. the time of the Great Revolt (e.g., Yehuda Even Shmuel, Midrashei Geulah [in Hebrew], pp. 47-49).

3 It's been noted that this passage bears some similarities to Rabbi Akiva's pronouncement of Bar Kochva as the Mashiach. See e.g., here, pp. 85-86).

title: Why are selichos Erev Yom Kippur so short?
content:
# Why are selichos Erev Yom Kippur so short? ## Frage

Every day of the Aseres Yemei Teshuvah there is an extensive selichos regime. The selichos have at the beginning שמע תפילה, followed by a פתיחה, then after several standard selichos there is a שלמונית then an עקידה sandwiching the פזמון. There is a long זכור לנו paragraph, multiple וידוי, and several paragraphs of א-ל רחום שמך/עננו/מי שענה. Erev Yom Kippur, however, has absolutely none of this - in fact, it's deliberately shorter than any selichos throughout the entire process, including before Rosh Hashanah. What's the reason we say so few selichos Erev Yom Kippur?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

Rema (in his glosses to Shulchan Arukh: Orach Chayim 604:2) says:

גם אין אומרים קודם עלות השחר הרבה סליחות ויש מקומות נוהגים להרבות בסליחות והכל לפי המנהג

Also they do not say before dawn many seliḥot (prayers of forgiveness), but there are places where it is customary to increase seliḥot. All (this should be done) according to the (local) custom.

R. Eliezer Melamed (in Peninei Halakhah: Days of Awe 5:10 "Erev Yom Kippur Customs") says:

יש נוהגים להרבות בסליחות בערב יום הכיפורים, ויש נוהגים לקצר (רמ"א תרד, ב). בדורות האחרונים נהגו באשכנז לקצר באמירת סליחות, וכפי דעת הסוברים שגם בליל יום הכיפורים יש מצווה להרבות באכילה ושתייה, וממילא הוא קצת יום טוב ונכון למעט אז באמירת סליחות (של"ה)

Some communities recite extra Seliḥot on Erev Yom Kippur, while others recite fewer (Rema 604:2). Ashkenazic practice for the past few centuries has been to recite fewer Seliḥot, in accordance with the opinion that there is a mitzva to eat and drink at night as well, which implies that it is a quasi-holiday on which Seliḥot should be kept to a minimum (Shlah).

title: Teshuva and Sacrifices in Vayikra
content:
# Teshuva and Sacrifices in Vayikra ## Frage

Shalom Chaverim,

I was wondering why the concept of Teshuva does not appear at all in the description of the Yom Kippur sacrifices in Vayikra 16. On the contrary, when reading Vayikra 16, I get the impression that only the sacrifices atone for sins. This is uncomfortable because in the Mishna, the theme of Teshuva is going to be introduced as an essential part to achieve atonement. Why then Teshuva is not be clearly mentioned as an essential part of Yom Kippur?

Thanks!

Gmar Chatima Tova

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

This is 1 (logic based) reason [If someone has more they can edit this answer and add it in at the end]:

  1. There is not (specific/extra) mitzvah in the Torah to do Teshuvah on Yom Kippur, as the mitzvah is to do Teshuvah the whole year. Though Korbanos, there are sacrifices which you only have a mitzvah to do on Yom Kippur (This is evident by the Pesukim you mentioned). The mishnayos mention Teshuvah, because the Korbanos mean nothing unless you did Teshuvah (while it is not a mitzvah) i.e the Torah's Korbanot and the sanctity of the day only atone for intentional sins if they are preceded by Teshuvah.

title: extent of kedusha in birchot shema
content:
# extent of kedusha in birchot shema ## Frage

According to those (e.g., Rambam) who hold that an individual praying alone omits kedushah from the first blessing on the morning Shema, what is the full extent of the omitted portion of the blessing, beyond the actual verse "kadosh kadosh kadosh..."?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Rav Saadia Gaon has an extremely short version of the first blessing before Shema to be recited by one praying alone:

ברוך אתה ה' אלקינו מלך העולם יוצר אור ובורא חושך עושה שלום ובורא את הכל המאיר לארץ ולדרין עליה ברחמים רבים וטובו מחדש בכל יום תמיד מעשה בראשית ברוך אתה ה' יוצר המאורות

Contrast this his much longer version to be recited by a congregation, including the verses of kedusha.

On the other hand, Magen Avraham 59:3 writes that according to this opinion one praying alone would essentially say the entirety of the text of the blessing as found in the siddur today, simply abbreviating the kedusha verses to their respective initial words as follows:

ואומרים ביראה קדוש והאופנים וכו' ואומרים ברוך

In a similar vein, the Baladi Tichlal says that one praying alone simply replaces the first verse of kedusha as follows:

קְדֻשַּׁת ה' צְבָקוֹת מְלֹא כָל הָאָרֶץ כְּבוֹדוֹ

(It's not totally clear to me what an individual does with the second verse in this rite, but I think it's recited as normal.)

title: Which commentary says this
content:
# Which commentary says this ## Frage

There is a commentary who says, and I am paraphrasing, on Shabbos 23b, that the reason why the Gemara there says "One who is careful to fulfill Mezuzah properly will merit to have a nice dwelling; one who is careful about Tzitzis will merit to have a nice garment; One who is careful about Kidush ha'Yom will merit to have much wine" is that these mitzvos are not mechuyav on a person, one can choose to live in a camper or something that doesn't require a mezuzah, one can wear a non-four-cornered garment and not have to put on tzitzis, one can make kiddush on bread rather than wine. So midah k'neged midah, Hashem rewards him with extra things because he himself did more than was required. Which commentary says this?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

It's the Meiri there:

לעולם יהא אדם זריז לקיים את המצות ובקלה כבחמורה שאינו יודע מתן שכרן של מצות ומ"מ יהא לבו סמוך שאין השם מקפח שכר כל בריה ושמדתו לשלם מדה כנגד מדה דרך הערה אמרו הרגיל בנר חנוכה דרך חבוב מצוה ובהערה מפורסמת הויין לו בנים תלמידי חכמים לקיים עליו נר מצוה ותורה אור הרגיל במזוזה זוכה לדירה נאה הזהיר בציצית זוכה לטלית נאה הזהיר בקידוש היום זוכה וממלא גרבי יין וכל אלו מדה כנגד מדה וכל עוד שמרבה במצות שכרו מתרבה דרך הערה אמרו ובאחד מגדוליהם שראה באחד והיה רגיל בשתי נרות ר"ל של חנכה ושל שבת בהדור ודרך חבוב ואמר גברי רברבי נפקי מהכא וראה באחד שהיה רגיל באחת בהידור ובחיבוב ואמר גברא רבא נפיק מהכא וכאשר פתר כן היה:

A person should always be careful to perform the mitzvos - treating the light ones like important ones - because he doesn't know the reward for mitzvos, and nevertheless his hert should always rely upon the fact that Hashem doesn't deprive His creations from reward and His nature is to reward middah k'neged middah. As an example: They said "one who regularly performs ner Chanukah in a loving and public way will have children who are Torah scholars," to fulfill in him the idea of "the mitzvos are a candle and Torah is a light." [They say further that] "one who regularly performs mezuzah will merit a beautiful home and one who is careful in tzitzis will merit a beautiful tali's and one who is careful in kiddush with merit to fill jugs of wine" - all of these are middah k'neged middah. And the more one increases his mitzvos the more his reward increases. As an example, they said "and one of them saw someone who would regularly use two candles" - that is to say, for Shabbos and Chanukah - "in a beautifying and loving way and said 'two great men will emerge from here.' And they saw someone who was did one [candle] in a beautifying and loving way and they said 'one great man will emerge from here.'" And so it was.

Although the gemara doesn't only discuss voluntary mitzvos so I think that component of your paraphrase is fundamentally mistaken.

title: Burnout in Judaism
content:
# Burnout in Judaism ## Frage

Where can I find the Torah talking about over-exertion? And how is it that I see gedoilim who learned 18 hours a day and didn't have a breakdown?

See What's the גדר for ביטול תורה?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: -2)

Great question. What is burnout? What is over-exertion?
Let's say it's yi'uf (עיף), tiredness, or mit'yagea, hit'yagea, yegiyyut? (יגע), exhausted, spent.

How about

Isa. 40

הֲל֨וֹא יָדַ֜עְתָּ אִם־לֹ֣א שָׁמַ֗עְתָּ אֱלֹהֵ֨י עוֹלָ֤ם ׀ יְהֹוָה֙ בּוֹרֵא֙ קְצ֣וֹת הָאָ֔רֶץ לֹ֥א יִיעַ֖ף וְלֹ֣א יִיגָ֑ע אֵ֥ין חֵ֖קֶר לִתְבוּנָתֽוֹ׃

Do you not know? Have you not heard? The ETERNAL is God from of old, Creator of the earth from end to end, Who never grows faint or weary, Whose wisdom cannot be fathomed—

נֹתֵ֥ן לַיָּעֵ֖ף כֹּ֑חַ וּלְאֵ֥ין אוֹנִ֖ים עׇצְמָ֥ה יַרְבֶּֽה׃

Who gives strength to the weary, Fresh vigor to the spent. |Rashi: "Who gives the tired strength": And Who will eventually renew strength for your tiredness.

And aren't we blessed to have this Brokho in Morning Blessings? And I've seen "Barukh ha-noten leyya'ef koach," like a great sigh and prayer, placed by the composers at the end of many sefarim such as Breslev.

וְיִעֲפ֥וּ נְעָרִ֖ים וְיִגָ֑עוּ וּבַחוּרִ֖ים כָּשׁ֥וֹל יִכָּשֵֽׁלוּ׃

Youths may grow faint and weary, And young men stumble and fall; |Rashi: "Now youths shall become tired Heb. נְעָרִים." The might of your enemies who are devoid (מְנֹעָרִים) of commandments, shall become faint..."

וְקוֹיֵ֤ יְהֹוָה֙ יַחֲלִ֣יפוּ כֹ֔חַ יַעֲל֥וּ אֵ֖בֶר כַּנְּשָׁרִ֑ים יָר֙וּצוּ֙ וְלֹ֣א יִיגָ֔עוּ יֵלְכ֖וּ וְלֹ֥א יִיעָֽפוּ׃ {ס}

But they who trust in GOD shall renew their strength As eagles grow new plumes: They shall run and not grow weary, They shall march and not grow faint.

and

Likutei Etzot - Da'at

  1. Sleep revitalizes the Sekhel, mind, and thus the Neshama, soul. Because when the Mochin, brain, are tired (מִתְיַגְּעִים) then sleep recharges them.** During sleep the Mochin, mind, and hence the Neshama, soul, enters into Emunah, faith, as in (Job 3:23), "New (chadashim) to the morning - great is Thy faith! (L. Moharan 35:3)

  2. There's many kinds of sleep. There's physical sleep which is good for the Mochin, brains. Some Torah learning is also a sleep relative to Dveikut (cleaving, communion) with the Blessed One, and that's learning Pashtei Oraita, basic levels of Torah. So someone that's constantly wrapped up in devotions to the Creator and his Mochin are tired due to so much Dveikut, he should study Pashtei Oraita. There's also sleep found in Masa uMatan b'Emunah (lit. commerce in faith) - when doing Masa uMatan b'Emunah then his Mochin i.e. his Neshama enters in Emunah and gets revitalized there and refreshed from its exhaustion, and he draws a new Sekhel, mind, from the Ohr haPanim, Light of the Face. The main point and the purpose is to carefully guard the Emunah. So when his Mochin, mind, is tired he needs to revive it in the Emunah through some kind of sleep, whether it's simple physical sleep which is when the Mochin are renewed as we can see tangibly, but again the main point and purpose is the Emunah, so before sleeping you need to attach yourself to the Emunah which this is the aspect of Kriat Shma She'al haMita that we recite before sleep. You need to read it with Kavana, intent, in order to hook up your Neshama and insert it inside the Emunah during sleep, and then your Nehsama will be revitalized in there, as in "New to the morning, great is Thy faith!" as mentioned. By sleeping you'll be able to get a new Sekhel, mind, and new Neshama, soul, from the Ohr haPanim. Likewise whoever has some kind of Dveikut and it has made his Moach tired, he needs to then occupy himself in Pashtei Oraita (simple Torah) and enter inside the Emunah while doing so. Meaning, since his Moach starts to get confused and he's no longer able to cleave to Hashem Yitbarakh in the aspect of Daat and Mochin, by way of mind and brain, mentally, then he needs to just remove his Daat and Mochin entirely and hook himself up to the Emunah in Pshitut and occupy himself in Pashtei Oraita in Temimut, simplicity, and Emunah Sheleimah. Because actually whenever you're maintaining your Mochin in Dveikut or any kind of level, even then the main thing that sustains the mind is Emunah, for "you cannot rely on Sekhel, mind, alone" [like we've explained above in #15]. But when the mind goes away you need to enter into the Emunah alone, through some kind of sleep as mentioned. Similarly, doing commerce is sometimes a kind of sleep that can renew his Moach, as mentioned, and there too the main point and purpose is the Emunah, when he's doing commerce "in Emunah;" then his Neshama which is his Sekhel, mind, enters inside the Emunah and gets revitalized there as mentioned (Ibid. 4, 6).

Saying Na Nach Nachma Nachman MeUman

Saying Rebbe Nachman's new name NNNNM, and blasting Nanach music and dancing, can only help and can't hurt, per Saba.

title: Why am I studying the torah
content:
# Why am I studying the torah ## Frage

Why am I studying the Torah? I want to know what is the motivation for a person to do so, and continue growing and working on themselves.

I used to think that it is because I want to get rewarded (שכר) but then I realized that if that's the case why don't I keep on my tefillin for an hour after davening.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Torah is Hashem telling us about Himself, so we learn Torah to get to know Him. See also Berachot 8b "From the day that the Holy Temple was destroyed, the Holy One blessed be He has nothing in His world except the dalet amot of halacha."

He wants and needs us to get to know Him, so we do it for Him (although who wouldn't want to get to know Him? 😊). See Avot 6:1. See this ma'amar, parts 1-4 and this Sfat Emet making the same point.

This is not all there is to say, but this is in many ways a foundational answer (indeed, those, like OP, who complain about answers that centre around reward often prefer this answer. See Avot 1:3 and Rambam there. See Mesilat Yesharim 18 onwards.)

title: Why only Erev Yom Kippur we worry that one will choke
content:
# Why only Erev Yom Kippur we worry that one will choke ## Frage

It says that you should say viduy before the meal because maybe you will choke. Why don't we worry all year round for this?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

If you look inside at the Mishnah Berurah 607:1 it is clear:

קודם סעודה המפסקת - שמא יארע לו דבר קלקלה בסעודה שיחנק או שתטרף דעתו ולא יוכל להתודות אח"כ ויש פוסקים שסוברין שצריך להתודות גם אחר אכילה קודם חשיכה וראוי להחמיר כדעה זו (של"ה) וכן נהגו בזמנינו שאומרים אז תפלה זכה

Before the concluding meal (Seudah HaMafseket) – Lest something harmful occur to him during the meal, such as that he might choke, or his mind might become disturbed, and he would then be unable to confess afterward.

And there are halachic authorities who hold that one must also confess after eating, before nightfall. And it is proper to be stringent in accordance with this opinion (this is the view of the Shelah).

And so too, the custom in our times is to recite then Tefillah Zakkah (‘Pure Prayer’).

In other words, it is Erev Yom Kippur where we are about to go into a day where our year ahead will be decided. We are in a state where our very existence is "hanging in the balance"1. If G-d forbid a person were to choke etc. they would not have had the chance to confess their sins and help bring about a proper teshuva, and as such it is more significant than an every day scenario.

1 As per the wording of Rosh Hashanah 16b:

אָמַר רַבִּי כְּרוּסְפָּדַאי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: שְׁלֹשָׁה סְפָרִים נִפְתָּחִין בְּרֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה, אֶחָד שֶׁל רְשָׁעִים גְּמוּרִין, וְאֶחָד שֶׁל צַדִּיקִים גְּמוּרִין, וְאֶחָד שֶׁל בֵּינוֹנִיִּים. צַדִּיקִים גְּמוּרִין — נִכְתָּבִין וְנֶחְתָּמִין לְאַלְתַּר לְחַיִּים, רְשָׁעִים גְּמוּרִין — נִכְתָּבִין וְנֶחְתָּמִין לְאַלְתַּר לְמִיתָה, בֵּינוֹנִיִּים — תְּלוּיִין וְעוֹמְדִין מֵרֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה וְעַד יוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים, זָכוּ — נִכְתָּבִין לְחַיִּים, לֹא זָכוּ — נִכְתָּבִין לְמִיתָה.

Rabbi Kruspedai said that Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Three books are opened on Rosh HaShana before the Holy One, Blessed be He: One of wholly wicked people, and one of wholly righteous people, and one of middling people whose good and bad deeds are equally balanced. Wholly righteous people are immediately written and sealed for life; wholly wicked people are immediately written and sealed for death; and middling people are left with their judgment suspended from Rosh HaShana until Yom Kippur, their fate remaining undecided. If they merit, through the good deeds and mitzvot that they perform during this period, they are written for life; if they do not so merit, they are written for death. (William Davidson translation and notation).

title: Is one permitted to daven only in socks and not in shoes on Yom Kippur?
content:
# Is one permitted to daven only in socks and not in shoes on Yom Kippur? ## Frage

I don't know the sugya surrounding this topic well, so I was wondering if there would be an issue with wearing only socks as opposed to crocs or other non-leather shoes during Yom Kippur, especially while davening. Is there an issue of a lack of kavod for Hashem? Also, is there an issue of appearing as if in aveilus when the day is a happy day?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

It really depends on who you follow. The gemara in Yerushalmi Yoma 6:1 says that two teachers had an argument if you could wear socks, and Rav Chisda explain that the one that said you could go out, was talking about normal socks, and the other one was talking about leather socks. The main thing is you wear that something that doesn't protect from the elements.

Mishnah Berura 614:5 מ"מ מי שאפשר לו נכון להחמיר בזה ולילך באנפלאות של בגד כנהוג Nevertheless, if it is possible for him (if he is able) it is correct to act stringently and walk in socks of cloth, as is the custom.

Here we see that it is actually better to wear socks and slippers etc. The mishna Berura 91:11 allows to Daven with socks, and it is not considered "barefoot"

title: Seeking source from the Satmar Rav on Yom Kippur
content:
# Seeking source from the Satmar Rav on Yom Kippur ## Frage

I vaguely remember in the name of the Satmar Rav, that there is an idea that, on Yom Kippur, there would be police-officers in Yerushalayim that would hold people back killing the goat that was sent to Azazel.

The Rebbe explained that the people eagerly wanted their sins to be forgiven, so instead of waiting for the goat to be pushed off the cliff, they would hasten the process themselves.

Does anyone know where this can be found in the writings of the Satmar Rav? I only know that it is in Divrei Yoel

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

With a huge thanks to @JoelK for bringing the Mishnah the Rebbe quotes, here is the original piece (Divrei Yoel Al HaMoadim, Motzaei Yom Kippur, p. 431, paragraph 87):

It seems that one must understand: for at that time in the Temple, there were officers of the Kingdom of Israel, and it was to supervise that they should not [push it off from the gate]

As Rashi explained: they would say to it, “Pull quickly and go out,”

למי שהי הבבליים וצא קיים וכבש עשו לו מפני וצא טול הי לו טול אח השעיר לעזאזל ואומרים בידם להעמיד שוטרים ולמה הוצרכו לכך לעשות כדת ב מ שנ ה פ"ו דיומא מ"ד מוליך בשערו מתלשים מלכות ישראל שהיו ונר לכאורה יש להבין דהרי בזמן שביהמ"ק והי הי להשגיח שלא יתלשו בשערו כבש עבורו מה שהיו תולשין בשערו הרי הי מפני וכפירש"י ע"א שהיו אומרין לו טול מהר וצא זה מדרך היו לבם אדם ואע"פ שאין כואב והנה הצה"ק חיי עמ"ש בכל פ עוד לפי שהי זכרון בס דיעות שלעולם ילך אי אבל כואב לבם על עונות ישראל ס"ו ונראה ה דף דהנ שהי ביומא ואל תשהה עונותינו אצלינו מ"מ לתלוש בשערו ואומרים לו טול וצא עול וצא זאת כתב בהלכות הממוצע שזה אינו אלא אחר שהאדם הממוצע לדרך זלה"ה ז"ל אק עושים כן מלובלין בדרך הרמב"ם מדותיו נטה תחלה בעבודתו עד הקצה האחרון רק אח"כ יוכל אפשר להתחיל ולבוא יל בנידון להם מאד על עס השעיר כואב את יעיי"ש הי הממוצע דרך על לחזור בדרך הממוצע כי אז לא ימלט שלא יעזוב ממנה אגל יוכל אס מתחלה הוא מתגבר עצמו מאוד עד הקצה אז וכמרכ ישראל בפניהם לבס של וע"כ כשהוליכו דהנה העונות להשאר דידן

title: Poetic License Suspended
content:
# Poetic License Suspended ## Frage

In my Chabad Machzor, toward the end of the repetition of Musaf on each day of Rosh Hashanah, there’s a Piyut that begins Hayom Te’amtzeinu. I can’t find any online image of the page, but this Youtube video contains a comparable image.

You can see something in this image which is also true of my Machzor. Each line begins Hayom, followed by a word that begins with a Tav. From one line to the next, the Tav is followed by letters that (at first) suggest an alphabetical progress. The first four lines follow Hayom with Te’amtzeinu (Aleph), Tevarcheinu (Beis), Tegadleinu (Gimel) and Tidresheinu (Dalet). But the next lines in my Machzor follow Hayom with Tishma (Shin), Tekabeil (Kuf) and Tismecheinu (Sav), letters near the end of the alphabet but not consecutive in the alphabet. I would assume that this reflects an original, properly alphabetical Piyut that was somehow transmogrified to this.

The trouble is, there’s something similar in the daily prayers.

Each morning, just before the Shema, my Chabad siddur contains the line Kulam Ahuvim, Kulam Berurim, Kulam Giborim, Kulam Kedoshim, Vechulam Osim… Vechulam Poschim… This quoted passage begins on the fourth line of type in the following image. Once again, there’s a gesture toward alphabetical progress that fizzles into letters late in the alphabet but not consecutive: Aleph, Beis, Gimel, Kuf, Ayin, Peh. (Again, this image is one I found online for a fairly close depiction of my Siddur.)

What explains these halfhearted devices?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

See the comentary on artscroll's machzor. Some machzorim do have all 22 lines with all the aleph beis, but no one says them. Look at this comment on this post:

According to the Birnbaum Machzor, היום תאמצנו is the remainder of a complete alphabetical acrostic which must have consisted of at least 22 lines – J. W. Tanner
