title: Should we strive to mimic God and animal behavior or not?
content:
# Should we strive to mimic God and animal behavior or not? ## Frage

We're instructed to emulate God's ways.

We're also told that had the Torah not been given we could have learned proper behavior from animals.

However, God is also described as jealous and vengeful and as exacting excruciatingly painful justice.

Animal predators inflict enormous suffering.

How are we supposed to base our morals and ethics on God and nature? If taken to an extreme, doing so would result in a society not in consonance with the Torah's ideal. Where do we draw the line?

Only following traits that we consider admirable doesn't seem to be copying God or nature, but rather cherry-picking the behaviors that resonate with our conscience.

title: Why do most masechtos end with a pasuk/Aggadah?
content:
# Why do most masechtos end with a pasuk/Aggadah? ## Frage

I researched the end of every Masechta in Shas, and found that 24 out of 39 Masechtos ended with a Pasuk or an Aggadah (with a few only ending at the last half of the last amud). The other 15 didn't. I also saw that 4/15 Masechtos I checked in Yerushalmi ended with a Pasuk (and Aggadah). Is there a reason for this?

To make a Kaddish d'Rabbonon after learning, you must learn at least one piece of Aggada [On Shabbos Minchah you say after a Perek of Pirkei Avos the last Mishnah of Makkos, which is pure Aggada.], in order to say Kaddish]. Could this be the reason a Masechta ends with a Pasuk (or something Aggadic)? Then how can you say Kaddish on the other Masechtos?

So, does anyone know if there is a reason for doing this, or does it just happen to be that 24 times out of 39 a Masechta ends with a Pasuk, even though Pesukim in Shas are generally rare [*in some Masechtos. But even a Masechta that has 3+ Pasukim/Daf, why would the last Amud on the last line contain a Pasuk/Aggadah].

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

See Agaddos Maharsha at the very end of Bava Kamma, I think the point is more to end on a positive note. So they throw in an inspirational Agadda or Passuk. [Edit: See also Tosfos to the end of Kesubos, Daf 112b]

title: Bowing to "Yihyu leratzon" in Amidah
content:
# Bowing to "Yihyu leratzon" in Amidah ## Frage

I was watching YouTube videos of enthusiasts who pray Amidah with prostrations, and I noticed that they bow after Birkat Sim Shalom to "Amen. Yihyu leratzon imrei fi…."

What is the origin of this custom?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

According to the Talmud, you only bow at the first and last parts of the 1st and 2nd last brochos.

Yerushalmi Brochos (Perek 1:5):

אלו ברכות ששוחחין בהן בראשונה תחילה וסוף ובמודים תחילה וסוף השוחח על כל ברכה וברכה מלמדין אותו שלא ישוח

To summarize, you only bow at the beginning and end of both Avos and Modim. The Yerushalmi does not mention bowing at the end of Sim Shalom (unless one is a king or kohen gadol).

See Bavli Brochos 34 (both עמודים) for a longer discussion about bowing. Also see Tosefta Brochos 1:10.

You also bow at Oseh Shalom:

Bavli Yoma 53b (paraphrased):

A braisa says that at the conclusion of Shmoneh Esrei, one takes three steps back and recites Oseh Shalom. And they said in the name of Shemaya that one recites Oseh Shalom, (bows) to the right, and then to the left.

title: Does the Mishna or Gemara ever explicitly mention the second day of Shavuot?
content:
# Does the Mishna or Gemara ever explicitly mention the second day of Shavuot? ## Frage

I have been searching for a source to demonstrate that the Talmud held a second day of Shavuot like Succot Pesach, however I have not found a single specific reference. There are references to the concept of a second day but they are always either ambiguous or in reference to Succot and Pesach, not Shavuot.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

Megillah 31a:

בָּעֲצֶרֶת ״שִׁבְעָה שָׁבוּעוֹת״, וּמַפְטִירִין בַּחֲבַקּוּק. אֲחֵרִים אוֹמְרִים: ״בַּחֹדֶשׁ הַשְּׁלִישִׁי״, וּמַפְטִירִין בַּמֶּרְכָּבָה. וְהָאִידָּנָא דְּאִיכָּא תְּרֵי יוֹמֵי, עָבְדִינַן כְּתַרְוַיְיהוּ וְאִיפְכָּא.‏

On Shavuot they read the portion of “Seven weeks,” and they read as the haftara from Habakkuk. Others say: They read the portion of “In the third month” (Exodus 19:1–20:23), and they read as the haftara from the account of the Divine Chariot (Ezekiel 1). And nowadays, when there are two days [of Shavuot], we act in accordance with both opinions, but in the reverse order.

"and shalt return unto the LORD thy God, and hearken to His voice according to all that I command thee this day, thou and thy children, with all thy heart, and with all thy soul that then the LORD thy God will turn thy captivity, and have compassion upon thee, and will return and gather thee from all the peoples, whither the LORD thy God hath scattered thee."

title: Who is a part of Israel?
content:
# Who is a part of Israel? ## Frage

There are many sections in the Torah where it reads to me like the umbrella of who God accepts as part of Israel is bigger than we are comfortable with. For example on Shabbat we learn that not only can we not work, but our slaves, maidservants, animals, etc. Most of the commentators frame this as instructing Israel to give other groups time off or to emulate God. Whereas to me it reads like slaves and animals become part of Israel by living with us and therefore they are entitled to similar rights such as not working on Shabbat. Just as one example: An animal example is God claims the right to the firstborn of Israel, whether human or animal. Could it be considered that the animal is now a part of Klal Yisrael?

The Gemara also brings down in Berakhot 2a:

צְרִיכִי, דְּאִי תְּנָא לוֹקֵחַ — הֲוָה אָמֵינָא מִשּׁוּם דְּקָא מַיְיתֵי לַהּ לִקְדוּשָּׁה, אֲבָל מוֹכֵר דְּקָא מַפְקַע לַהּ מִקְּדוּשָּׁה — אֵימָא לִיקְנְסֵיהּ, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן. The Gemara explains: All of these examples are necessary. As, had the tanna taught that a donkey is exempt from the obligations of firstborn status only in the case where a Jew purchases a fetus from a gentile, I would say that this is because the Jew brings it to a state of sanctity in that it will not be worked on Shabbat. But in the case where a Jew sells the fetus of his donkey to a gentile, where he abrogates its state of sanctity, I would say that the Sages should penalize him [likneseih] for his actions by rendering the fetus subject to the obligations of firstborn status. Therefore, the mishna teaches us that it is exempt from these obligations.

Rashi comments

גמ' מייתי לה לקדושה – “The Gemara brings it to holiness” – meaning: that the animal is brought under a category of sanctity,

שתהא שובתת בשבת – “that it should rest on Shabbat.”

וכיון דמצוה עביד – “And since he is performing a mitzvah (by ensuring the animal rests on Shabbat),”

ליכא למיקנסיה – “there is no reason to penalize him.”

A human example is the longstanding custom to convert your slaves, who often then practice Judaism upon being freed. Were they a part of Israel even while slaves? Is that why they receive Shabbat off?

title: Does anybody know from which tribe were Queen Shlomtziyon and her brother Shimon ben Shetach?
content:
# Does anybody know from which tribe were Queen Shlomtziyon and her brother Shimon ben Shetach? ## Frage

Does anybody know from which tribe were Queen Shlomtziyon and her brother Shimon ben Shetach?

I have heard that perhaps they were from the Kehunah, but no one seems to know for sure, it seems more common that the Nasi Hador would be from Yehuda.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Abarbanel on Beresheet 49:8 wrote:

"יהודה אתה יודוך אחיך [...] לא יסור שבט מיהודה [...] כי ביהודה בחר לנגיד [...] וגם בזמן בית שני עם היות החשמונים מולכים ללחום מלחמות י"י תמיד היה בירושלים נגיד מיהודה והוא היה ראש לסנהדרין לקיים מה שנא' לא יסור שבט מיהודה וכמו שכתב יוסף בן גוריון. [...]"

""You, O Judah, your brothers shall praise" [...] "The scepter shall not depart from Judah" [...] for Judah was chosen to be chief/ruler (נגיד) [...] and also during the time of the Second Temple despite that the Chashmonaim ruled to battle Hashem's wars, there was always in Yerushalayim a chief (נגיד) from Yehudah and he was the head of the Sanhedrin to fulfill that which is stated "the scepter shall not depart from Judah", and as Yosef ben Gurion wrote as well. [...]"

This would seem to indicate that at least during the time of the Chashmonaim, the head of the Sanhedrin was always from the tribe of Yehudah, and this would include Shimon ben Shetach (at least according to the opinion of the sages in Tosefta Chagigah 2:4, Bavli Chagigah 16b and elsewhere, that Shimon ben Shetach was the Nasi, and not his zug Yehudah ben Tabbai).

This seems to have been Rabbi Uri Landman (the fourth Rebbi of the Strelisk Chassidut)'s rationale when he wrote explicitly that Shimon ben Shetach was from Yehudah, and he noted that two times the word רגל in gematria equals Shimon (שמעון), which hints at Shimon ben Shetach's connection to the verse "ומחוקק מבין רגליו" (twice רגל equals רגליו, i.e., two legs).1

Following this view, it seems that Shimon ben Shetach and Shlomtzion were from the tribe of Yehudah.

1 Though it should be noted that this same gematria is cited by other sources with regards to other sages named Rabbi Shimon.

title: Can you make a hadran with kaddish on tractate Kallah Rabbasi, and are there Perushim on it?
content:
# Can you make a hadran with kaddish on tractate Kallah Rabbasi, and are there Perushim on it? ## Frage

מסכת כלה רבתי is a masechta ketana (It's a braisa not Mishna) found after eduyos in some Gemaras. It contains tractate Kallah but also contains 8 other perakim, and has Gemara [Talmud Bavli] on 8 of them. Is it considered enough of a masechta to make a hadran (With Kaddish) on? And are there any Perushim on it that you can find online on it from anywhere in the world.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

While himself not a posek, R' Itche Meir Morgenstern in the sefer Bayam Darkecha - Darkei Avodah L'maaseh (note 68) says as follows:

אך לגבי מסכת גמ' בבלי או ירושלמי, כתב, שאפילו אם למד במיוחד כדי לעשות סיום, מותר מדינא לעשות סיום בערב פסח. ובזה אשכחן חידוש בספר 'פתחא זוטא' בשם ספר 'הדרת קודש', שכותב שמסכתות קטנות נמי דינם הכי. ויכולים ללמדם במיוחד, כדי לעשות עליהם סיום. ובתנאי שיבין את לימודו ולא בקריאה בעלמא.

But regarding mesechtos in Bavli or Yerushalmi, [R' Shlomo Kluger] writes, that even if one learned in order to make a siyum, one is permitted m'dina to make a siyum on Erev Pesach. And with this we find a chiddush in the sefer 'Pischa Zuta' in the name of the sefer 'Hadras Kodesh', who writes that mesechtos ketanos have a similar din. And you're able to learn them specifically, in order to make a siyum on them. Upon the condition that you understand your learning and you're not just reading.

He recommends making a siyum on Maseches Tzitzis (which is also a mesechta ketanah) to easily elevate a meal to a status of seudas mitzvah (page 46):

ובזה יש עצה נפלאה לקדושת האכילה, והיא - לעשות ביום מסכת ציצית בסעודה. כי מסכת זו היא קצרה ביותר, והיא עצה טובה ונכונה, למי שרוצה שתהיה סעודתו סעודת מצוה.

...And with this there is an amazing idea for the holiness of eating, and that is - to make a siyum on Maseches Tzitzis during your meal. Because this Maseches is the shortest, and it's a good and proper idea, for one who wants his meal to be a seudas mitzvah.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

Rav Chaim Kanievsky wrote a perush available on hebrewbooks (he writes in his intro that theres a sefer מעין גנים on Kallah, also i found this there). Also you can work backwards by looking at the sources (available on sefaria) and looking at perushim on the source.

Regarding a Hadran, you can make a hadran on anything, for example sfardim have a hadran on the torah printed after tikkun leil shavuot and the Lubavitcher Rebbe would make on the Rambam.

title: Meshech Chochmah's question regarding Teshuvah
content:
# Meshech Chochmah's question regarding Teshuvah ## Frage

R. Meir Simcha HaKohen m'Dvinsk asks the following ingenious question regarding the nature of Teshuvah:

And let us reflect: since the very term teshuvah (repentance) indicates what it means, how can it be counted as a commandment — that a person should return from his folly and sin no more? Behold, even without this commandment, he is already commanded and obligated not to transgress the commandments of the Blessed One! Could it enter your mind that because he has sinned and repeated the sin it should thereby become permitted to him?! Indeed, the original prohibition, which restrained him from sinning before he sinned, restrains him as well from sinning after he has sinned.

(He uses it to explain Rambam's omission of Azivas HaChet; I'm putting it out there for other potential answers)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

My rebbe wrote a long piece about the question here on p. 29.

The tl;dr:

Rambam defines teshuva as azivas hachet, therefore teshuva alone cannot be a mitzvah, as one is already obligated to stop doing the chet. Rabbeinu Yonah and others define teshuva as primarily charata al haavar, therefore the question of the Meshech Chochmah does not start. Besides stopping to sin, teshuva creates an additional commandment to repent from having sinned in the past.

title: Self-naming in Torah
content:
# Self-naming in Torah ## Frage

I am looking to learn more about the subject of "giving oneself a name", through a Torah lens. Specifically, I am hoping to gain a bit of insight into what the Torah might say about the modern world, where everyone has an "online persona" that they themselves come up with*.

Generally speaking the norm for humanity until recently has been generally that a person is named by their parents or community at birth. If a person wants titles on their name, they need to earn them. Excluding some interesting exceptions, it's highly unusual for a person to give themself a name and enter spaces where that name is exclusively used. More than that, they might create an image for others to know them by (e.g. a profile picture or avatar that is not a photo of them), and perhaps even a full on personality/persona.

I believe the Torah is likely to have plenty of material that would be relevant to helping me understand what sort of effects this may have had on the collective human psyche. There may even be some useful halachic discussions, or interesting Kabbalah/Mussar discussions on the topic of names that is relevant. For instance, there's a question here about the custom of naming Rabbonim after their most popular Sefer. That topic might be relevant?

My guess is that giving ourselves names is overall not the greatest thing because it can feed narcissism, or at least self-absorption, and destroy bittul and anivut. Still, I reckon we can do much better and so if anyone knows of anything relevant or fancies giving a fuller analysis of their own based on Torah sources, I'd be grateful. I usually express my gratitude with bounties, especially when it's obvious a lot of effort has gone in to the answer :)

* Indeed, my real name is not Kaii (although I didn't invent my qualification), which I have used for a degree of anonymity. I made it up a long time ago and have used it in various contexts relevant to this question although this is not a personal question by any means.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

One thing that comes to mind is an example from Tanach where someone suggests a name change for themselves. In מגילת רות, Naomi (with a name indicating sweetness) tells people to call her Mara (indicating bitterness) due to her new bitter life.

(רות א:כ) ותאמר אליהן אל תקראנה לי נעמי קראן לי מרא כי המר שדי לי מאד

For a different angle on self-naming, see the following gemara (ראש השנה טז עמ' ב):

וְאָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק: אַרְבָּעָה דְּבָרִים מְקָרְעִין גְּזַר דִּינוֹ שֶׁל אָדָם, אֵלּוּ הֵן: צְדָקָה, צְעָקָה, שִׁינּוּי הַשֵּׁם, וְשִׁינּוּי מַעֲשֶׂה.

...and R. Yitzchak said: There are four things that will tear up the bad decree of a person - these are: charity, crying out in prayer, a name change, a change in one's actions

title: How to understand the aggada of non-Jews testifying that the Jewish people kept the whole Torah?
content:
# How to understand the aggada of non-Jews testifying that the Jewish people kept the whole Torah? ## Frage

In Avoda Zara 3a there is an aggadic tale wherein God calls on representatives of the non-Jewish nations to testify that the Jewish people have kept the whole Torah. The relevants parts are excerpted here

אֶלָּא כָּךְ אוֹמְרִים הַגּוֹיִם לִפְנֵי הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא: רִבּוֹנוֹ שֶׁל עוֹלָם, יִשְׂרָאֵל שֶׁקִּיבְּלוּהָ הֵיכָן קִיְּימוּהָ? ... אָמַר לָהֶם הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא: מִכֶּם יָבֹאוּ וְיָעִידוּ בָּהֶן בְּיִשְׂרָאֵל שֶׁקִּיְּימוּ אֶת הַתּוֹרָה כּוּלָּהּ, יָבֹא נִמְרוֹד וְיָעִיד בְּאַבְרָהָם שֶׁלֹּא עָבַד עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה, יָבֹא לָבָן וְיָעִיד בְּיַעֲקֹב שֶׁלֹּא נֶחְשַׁד עַל הַגָּזֵל, תָּבֹא אֵשֶׁת פּוֹטִיפֶרַע וְתָעִיד בְּיוֹסֵף שֶׁלֹּא נֶחְשַׁד עַל הָעֲבֵירָה. יָבֹא נְבוּכַדְנֶצַּר וְיָעִיד בַּחֲנַנְיָה מִישָׁאֵל וַעֲזַרְיָה שֶׁלֹּא הִשְׁתַּחֲווּ לַצֶּלֶם, יָבֹא דָּרְיָוֶשׁ וְיָעִיד בְּדָנִיֵּאל שֶׁלֹּא בִּיטֵּל אֶת הַתְּפִלָּה, יָבֹא בִּלְדַּד הַשּׁוּחִי וְצוֹפַר הַנַּעֲמָתִי וֶאֱלִיפַז הַתֵּימָנִי וֶאֱלִיהוּ בֶּן בַּרַכְאֵל הַבּוּזִי וְיָעִידוּ בָּהֶם בְּיִשְׂרָאֵל שֶׁקִּיְּימוּ אֶת כָּל הַתּוֹרָה כּוּלָּהּ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״יִתְּנוּ עֵדֵיהֶם וְיִצְדָּקוּ״

The upshot of this discussion is that certain non-Jews can be expected to testify that they knew of certain Jews who kept certain mitzvot. I would like to understand the logic of this argument which seems to have the following issues

  1. The issue at stake is that the entirety of the Jewish people possibly did not keep the Torah they accepted and thus the non-Jews deserve a chance to receive the Torah as well. None of the testimony offered is about the Jewish nation as a whole, rather it is about select individuals. I don't see how such testimony bears on the discussion at all
  2. How does the testimony of Nimrod, Lavan or the wife of Potiphar have any bearing on the discussion when all of the incidents in question took place before the giving of the Torah?
  3. Even granting all of the testimony is relevant and compelling, could not the nations of the world offer a strong rebuttal that the prophets themselves constantly berate the Jewish nation for failure to keep the Torah, including statements from prophets like Ezekiel which indicate that the leaders of the people who may themselves be righteous are held accountable for not exerting more influence on the general populous to repent and adhere to the Torah?
  4. How are we to understand the reference to Iyov's friends? Even assuming Iyov was Jewish (itself a disagreement in the Talmud) Iyov's friends actually spend their time accusing Iyov of sinning in some capacity as an explanation for his suffering. Furthermore the quote in the aggada does not come from them (or even from the book of Iyov!).
  5. Lastly, the logic of this overall argument could be used in reverse, the nations of the world could say that they have individuals over the course of history who have in fact kept the 7 Noahide laws, which if that is the only criteria necessary, would entitle them to receive the Torah as well.

Given what appears to me to be extensive issues with the internal logic of this aggadah I would like to know if any commentaries or scholars address any of these issues or offer a way to read this story that removes these problems.

title: Why does Onkelos translate הַשִּׁירָ֖ה to תּוּשְׁבַּחְתָּא instead of שִׁירָתָא?
content:
# Why does Onkelos translate הַשִּׁירָ֖ה to תּוּשְׁבַּחְתָּא instead of שִׁירָתָא? ## Frage

At the end of the parashas Vayelekh, Devarim 31:30, Moshe Rabbeinu refers to the song הַשִּׁירָ֖ה, which is the song Haazinu starting in the next verse Devarim 32:1. Onkelos translates the word הַשִּׁירָ֖ה as תּוּשְׁבַּחְתָּא in Aramaic. While according to Jastrow, תּוּשְׁבַּחְתָּא has also a meaning song, it is not the main meaning of the word which also means praise, glory. We also see this difference in the well-known line of kadish that has both words:

לְעֵלָּא מִן כָּל בִּרְכָתָא וְשִׁירָתָא תֻּשְׁבְּחָתָא וְנֶחֱמָתָא דַּאֲמִירָן בְּעָלְמָא.

Above every blessing and song, praise and consolation that are said in this world.

As noted by @DoubleAA, the same translation occurs also in Shemos 15:1 -2 and Bamidbar 21:17. Why does Onkelos translate הַשִּׁירָ֖ה to תּוּשְׁבַּחְתָּא instead of שִׁירָתָא, given that it's not seemingly the best translation? Is there a midrashic source for this translation?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Lechem V'Simlah on Onkelos, Shemot 15:1 wrote:

"שבח - כל שיר ורנה והלל תרגומם שוה בלשון שבח, ובעברית הוא רק ל' הלול וכן ושפתי ישבחונך כמו ישבחו אותך ולא ביחס שאליו ישבחו לך, וכן השם שירה מתורגם גם באונקלוס ותושבחתא ומה שנמצא בל' הקדיש שירתא תושבחתא נראה כי הוא מושאל מלשון העברי אשר בו הם שמות נרדפים שיר ושבחה וכן בתיוב"ע בזה ית שבח שירתא."

"Shevach - every song, joy and praise are equally translated as "Shevach" (praise), and in Hebrew it only means "praise", and it is similarly written "(and) My lips declare Your praise" like they will praise You and not towards You who they will praise, and so the term "Shirah" (song) is also translated in Onkelos as "V'Tushbechata", and that which we find in the Kaddish "Shirata v'Tushbechata" it seems that this is a borrowing from the Hebrew language, where the synonyms "Shir" (song) and "Shevacha" (praise) are found, and so too in Targum Yonatan ben Uziel (=Pseudo-Jonathan) "Yat Shevach Shiratah" (This praise-song)."

Following Lechem V'Simlah, Rabbi Binyamin Posen wrote in Parshegen on Shemot 15:1, p. 257, § 5 that the many different words meaning "song" in Hebrew were consistently translated in Aramaic as "Shevach" because of the lack of relevant synonyms in Aramaic (מחמת דלות הלשון הארמית). He agreed that the Kaddish phrase is a borrowing from Hebrew.

title: Why did the Jews in the Diaspora keep the Feast of Trumpets on the first two days of the month?
content:
# Why did the Jews in the Diaspora keep the Feast of Trumpets on the first two days of the month? ## Frage

I understand the Jews in the Diaspora want to keep the Feast of Trumpets on the correct day, so they celebrate the Day of Trumpets on the first two days of the seventh month. I have little understanding of Judaism, but how does keeping the first two days of the first month ensure they kept the right day?

Say you're a Jew in Babylon on the 29th day of month. It is also the 29th day of the month in Jerusalem. You don't know if the first day of the next month is tomorrow or the day after tomorrow. If the spotters in Jerusalem spotted the new moon on the evening of the 29th, then the next day would be Tishri 1. But the Jews in Babylon wouldn't know that the 29th day was the last day of the month, so they would consider the next day the 30th of the month and not celebrate Trumpets until the day afterward (Tishri 2 in Jerusalem).

How does keeping the Feast of Trumpets two days in Babylon make them keep the day correctly?

If I understand correctly,

If it was Nisan 29 in both Babylon and Jerusalem the same day, would the Jews in Babylon celebrate the next day as Iyar 1? If the spotters in Jerualem spotted the crescent on the evening of Nisan 29, then the next day would be Iyar 1. Is that how it works?

Meanwhile, the Jews in Babylon, would celebrate Nisan 30 as the first day of the month and the next day Iyar 1 and in effect they would have celebrated the first of the month would be celebrated two days in a row, right? Later, when word from Jerusalem reached Babylon, they would then “correct” with the right day of the month. Is this correct?

Unlike actual Shacharis, differences between major Ashkenazi minhagim of selichos is minimal. title: Explanation for the BeShT insulting his disciples?
content:
# Explanation for the BeShT insulting his disciples? ## Frage

During studying towards the upcoming holy days, I encountered two stories about the BeShT insulting his disciples.

The first story is from שבחי הבעש"ט ט"ו:

פ"א ביום הכיפורים בהשכמה לא בא הבעש"ט לבית המדרש כפי המנהג ביה"כ להתפלל בהשכמה. והיה שוהה עד בוש על היום והמתינו עליו מלהתפלל ואח"כ בא וישב על מקומו והיה ראשו על הסטענדר מקים ראשו ומניח ראשו מקים ומניח כמה פעמים. ואח"כ רמז שילכו להתפלל לפני התיבה ובא ר' דוד הנ"ל להתפלל כי הוא היה מתפלל בימים נוראים וכשבא סמוך לתיבה התחיל הבעש"ט לבזותו בפני כל עם ועדה ואמר בזה הלשון. זקן אשמאי היכן אתה הולך וביזה וגינה אותו ערך חצי שעה והיה רוצה לחזור ולילך מן העמוד כי היטב חרה עד מאוד כי אמר שמא ח"ו ראה בי דבר מגונה. וגער עליו ואמר. עמוד והתחיל להתפלל ובכה ולא היה יודע מה שהוא מדבר רק שצעק ובכה כי שבר לבו מאוד. ואח"כ במוצאי יה"כ הלך ר' דוד מ"מ ז"ל אל הבעש"ט ואמר לו רבינו מה ראית בי דבר מגונה ח"ו ענה ואמר ח"ו לא ראיתי בך כלום רק באשמורת ראיתי להס"ס על הדרך מקום שהתפילות הולכים לקבל כל התפילות ח"ו. ואמרתי בלבי למה אלך להתפלל ולמסור לו התפילות ח"ו וע"כ שהיתי מלהתפלל. ות"ל פניתי דרך אחד שילכו התפלות בזו הדרך ולא יוכל לאחוז בהם וע"כ יראתי פן ח"ו יכנוס בלבך ויקלקל ח"ו הדבר ושברתי את לבך בכדי שלא יהיה בך שום מחשב זרה בלבך ואח"כ צויתי לך להתפלל:

The second story is from a much less reputable source, called שופרא דיעקב, עמ' תרי (the source can be found in Otzar HaHochma):

פעם בראש חודש אלול נתוועדו יחד חמשה מתלמידי הבעש״ט ה"ה ר׳ אליעזר כהנא מקארלין, ר׳ דוד ממיקלאיוב, ר׳ דוד פירקוס, ר׳ דוד מקאלימייא, ור' דוד לייקעס, והחליטו ביניהם לפעול יחד כל החדש אלול ועשרת ימי תשובה בפרישות וקדושה בתעניות ותפילות ביחודי שמות הק' המיוחדים לקרב קץ הגאולה, וגמר העבודה תהיה בעבודת יום הכיפורים על פי כוונות יחודים הערוכות על פי ח"ן המסוגלים לביאת המשיח, ויהיו מסורים לבעל המוסף ר׳ אליעזר מקארלין שהיתה לו חזקה לתפילת המוסף בבית המדרש של הבעש״ט, וכל אלו ההכנות היו נעשות בהסתר גדול שאפילו מלאכי מעלה לא ידעו מהן. ובהגיע יום הכיפורים אחרי קריאת התורה עלה ר׳ אליעזר כדרכו מאז לקחת הספר תורה ולומר יהללו, אז קרא אליו הבעש״ט ממקומו ויאמר איך זה ירהיב איש לגשת ולעבור לפני התיבה לפני קהל קדוש כזה, מה יתרון ראה בעצמו ומה מצא בקרבו להיות ראוי לכך, ואם גם הוא מלא מסתרים איך יגבה להיות שליח ציבור כזה. ר׳ אליעזר התפחד לקול מורו ורבו והתחיל לסגת אחור ולרדת מן הבימה ברוב דיכוי הנפש ושבר לב, אך אז קרא אליו הבעש״ט ואמר לו: ועתה שוב וקח הספר הק׳ ועבור לפני התיבה לתפלת המוסף. ר׳ אליעזר עשה כן, ברם נלקחה ממנו כל גדלות המוחין שלו והתפלל בלי כל הכוונות שהכין לו, ובאותה השנה נפטר ר׳ אליעזר.

The two stories have a moral justification, by which the disciple ego had to be broken, not because it was full of pride, but because its ideal state is humility.

However, what is the justification to violate the prohibition of מלבין פני חברו ברבים as well as אונאת דברים?

title: Do we need to stand up for a great rav, if a greater rav is already sitting down in the room?
content:
# Do we need to stand up for a great rav, if a greater rav is already sitting down in the room? ## Frage

B"H

There's a halacha that if one's own Rav walks in a room, or even if any Torah scholar (to the point where one can ask him anything I'm halacha and he can answer it immediately) enters a room, one should stand up if one is sitting.

What if there's a greater rav in the room where the lesser Rav entered, does the greater rav himself need to stand, and if not, do at least the other people in the room need to stand for the lesser Rav?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The SA in YD 244:8 says that two rabbis don’t have to stand up for each other, but they should still try to make a gesture of standing up a bit:

שני חכמים ושני זקנים אין אחד צריך לקום מפני חבירו אלא יעשה לו הידור (ואפי' הרב לתלמידו יעשה לו הידור קצת) (מהגהת מיימוני פ"ה דת"ת בשם רמ"ך)

When two sages or two elderly men encounter one another, neither is required to stand for the other, but each should show some form of respect. (Even a teacher should show a bit of honor to his student) (from Hagahot Maimoniyot ch. 5 of Talmud Torah in the name of RaMaḥ).

The Tur in YD 244 explains the reason for this, because since everyone else must show honor to both of them, it isn’t proper for them to give full honor to someone else. It seems apparent from this, that everyone else is supposed to stand up for both of them:

ואפשר שלא אמר שא"צ לעמוד לפני הזקן מלא קומתו אלא ילד חכם שכיון שצריכין לנהוג בו ג"כ כבוד אין לו להתבזות לקום מפני הזקן אלא שיעשה לו הידור אבל כל אדם צריך לקום מפני הזקן מלא קומתו והכי מסתבר נמי בשני חכמים או בשני זקנים שאין אחד צריך לקום מפני חבירו אלא יעשה לו הידור

title: Might you have to check dried fruit, even if it already has a hechsher?
content:
# Might you have to check dried fruit, even if it already has a hechsher? ## Frage

Plenty of dried fruit products have a hechsher (kosher certification logo) on the package.

title: Looking for source and reason for the Psak that one is not required to interrupt his learning to recite Birkat Hatorah?
content:
# Looking for source and reason for the Psak that one is not required to interrupt his learning to recite Birkat Hatorah? ## Frage

I’ve heard that there are those who hold that if one is awake all night learning, he may continue learning even after it became morning, and he is not required to interrupt his learning in order to recite or hear Birkat Hatorah, and he would only be required to recite/hear it once he has interrupted his learning.

Does anyone know where this is brought down, and what is the reason behind this Psak? Also, is there anyone who disagrees?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

According to the Rosh and most of the Rishonim, one who was awake all night, as on Shavuot night, may not recite Birkot HaTorah before Shacharit, because as long as he did not interrupt by sleeping, the previous day’s Birkot HaTorah still apply. That is how many eminent Acharonim rule (Pri Chadash, Gra, Chayei Adam). According to Rabbeinu Tam, however, he must recite Birkot HaTorah before Shacharit. Since Birkot HaTorah are intended to last for a 24-hour period, even if he did not sleep at all during that whole day, when the time arrives to recite Shacharit the next day, he must recite Birkot HaTorah again. That is what is said in the name of the Arizal, and that is the minhag of the Sephardim (Birkei Yosef 46:12; Ben Ish Chai, Berachah 3; Kaf HaChaim 47:26).

In order to avoid uncertainty, it is preferable that someone who did not sleep at night hear someone else recite Birkot HaTorah, thereby fulfilling his obligation according to all opinions.

If he cannot find someone who needs to recite Birkot HaTorah, according to the minhag of the Sephardim and some of the Ashkenazim, he should recite Birkot HaTorah himself. According to the minhag of the majority of Ashkenazim, he should have kavanah to fulfill the obligation of Birkot HaTorah in Ahavah Rabbah before Shema (Mishnah Berurah 47:28), for we have already learned (in halachah 2) that this berachah is considered like Birkot HaTorah. After praying he must learn a verse of scripture or a Mishnah in order to adjoin his learning to the berachah.[8]

Regarding that same person who stayed awake all night, if he slept a regular sleep during the day prior to that, according to all opinions he must recite Birkot HaTorah before reciting Shacharit.[9] (See earlier in this book 9:6 for a summary of the laws concerning one who was awake all night.)

Link to source

title: Do animals have 10 Sefiros
content:
# Do animals have 10 Sefiros ## Frage

B"H

We say that only humans are creatures in the image of Elokim, and therefore have 10 Sefiros (corresponding to Adam HaElyon, the image that Elokim made for Himself to use to create the universes).

But do animals also have chochmah, bina, daas, chesed through malchus? Usually we say that the animal soul of a person has those 10 faculties, but do animals themselves have them? If not, do they at least have some?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Yes and no, see the following sources:

  1. Likkutei Torah Emor (ביאור ע״פ והניף הכהן אותם)
  2. Derech Mitzvotecha Pru Urvu
  3. ר״ה 5656

Basically animals and angels are created one way, and Neshamot another:

  • Angels and animals have 10 Sefirot in Tohu-like configuration
  • Neshamot have 10 Sefirot of Tikkun

Neshamot have a fully integrated 10 Sefirot in what's known as a Partzuf (Adam). Each of their Sefirot is their own; a personal aspect of their life, their personality, their conscious experience. This is Tikkun. All of their Sefirot are penimi: inward, personal, them.

Animals on the other hand, lacking personalised Da'at*, originate in source from Tohu (Nekudim), where the Sefirot do not (or barely) inter-include. Therefore they are generally made from a single Sefira. However, all the worlds are created from the 10 Sefirot and life can't exist without all 10, so they receive an external radiance of the other Sefirot, in a concealed way. These Sefirot all serve their primary Sefira, so a raven, being "cruel", will still have intellect (mochin), but it's intellect instinctively seeks ways to be "cruel", and nothing else.

* it is functional but not integrating (called an acquired da'at, da'at hanikne, and thus they do not have a sensation of intellect). Angels thus only have a single mission.

title: The veracity of the Torah
content:
# The veracity of the Torah ## Frage

How do we know that the Torah - both shebiksav and shebal'peh - is true (here simply meaning true in an abstract, general sense, not from a historical standpoint - e.g. Jews should abstain from pork)? If it cannot be proven to be true, do any mekorot discuss why we observe it at all? Sources would be appreciated.

Although I've seen many proofs for the reliability of the Oral Torah, none of them seem to me to prove that it accurately transmits the teaching of Moshe Rabeinu beyond a reasonable doubt. As for the Written Torah, while it is demonstrably quite accurate about many historical details, that doesn't bear on why Jews think it's the truth, as any religious text from that period could've been just as accurate. The Kuzari's argument that so many Jews saw the miracles wrought by Hashem that it would be irrational for them to not believe in Him certainly applies to the dor ha'midbar, but no Jews are alive today who can recall those events, and the idea that our ancestors practiced the Torah for thousands of years is not proof of its veracity, either, as many other groups have maintained their religion for a long duration of time (such as the Mandeans and Syriac Christians).

So what logical proofs are there for the Torah's truth, and what rational reasons does this generation have for needing to continue its observance?

title: How do we know whether a young bird is a Tumtum or not?
content:
# How do we know whether a young bird is a Tumtum or not? ## Frage

The Rambam (Hil. Pesulei Hamukdashin 7:4) writes that a bird that is a Tumtum is not kosher to be brought as a sacrifice.

The Radbaz (ad loc) asks how it’s possible to know whether a bird is a Tumtum, since a Tumtum is a person or animal who’s reproductive organs are blocked by skin, and by birds those organs are concealed either way?

The Radbaz then answers that the way to know that a bird is a Tumtum is if we see that it never mates with another bird, which indicates that its reproductive organs are indeed blocked and not just concealed.

My question is: there are two types of birds that are kosher to be brought as a sacrifice - בני יונה (young pigeons) and תורים (turtledoves), and the Talmud (Chulin 22a) says that pigeons are only kosher for sacrifices when they are young i.e. before they begin to mature.

Based on that, how would the Radbaz explain how it’s possible to know whether a young pigeon is a Tumtum, since according him, the way to tell if a bird is a Tumtum is if it doesn’t mate - but a young pigeon that has not yet matured wouldn’t be mating either way?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Pigeons pair up a couple of months before they mature and actually begin mating, playing house if you will. Perhaps, the Radbaz would say that they will not even perform the pre-mating courtship, which gives you about a two month window.

title: What binds Jews to the Torah?
content:
# What binds Jews to the Torah? ## Frage

A few times in the Torah the Jews accepted the Torah. The Talmud refers to it as being bound by the oath that they took at Sinai.

Why did they have to keep their word? Ostensibly because the Torah says that they must.

But isn’t that circular? The Jews at Har Sinai were obligated to abide by their word as the Torah says so which they accepted…

Is it that natural morality undergirds all of Torah?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

R. Avraham Bornstein poses this question in his Responsa Avnei Neizer (here, 16-17) and posits that one's word is binding as a matter of morality and does not need to be based on the Torah or the 7 noahide laws:

ונראה דהנה נתקשה ה'משנה למלך' פ"י מהל' מלכים (ה"ז) בשבועות שקודם מתן תורה, אברהם ויצחק לאבימלך, עשו ליעקב, אליעזר לאברהם, הלא שבועה אינה מז' מצוות שנצטוו בני נח, ולי קשה עוד על שבועת הר סיני שהוא יסוד קבלת התורה, והרי כל זמן שלא קיבלו התורה לא נצטוו על השבועה, ועוד שאפילו היו מצווים, מכל מקום כל כח השבועה משום שמצוה 'לא יחל דברו', ומה יותר אזהרה זו משאר אזהרות שבתורה, ומה יוסיף כח השבועה באזהרות שבתורה, כיון שהשבועה גם כן אינה רק אזהרה. אשר על כן נראה ברורן של דברים, דודאי מי שנשבע לאחר, זה הסברא מכרעת שמחויב לקיים, ואין צורך לזה שום אזהרה, והיינו שבועת אברהם ויצחק ואליעזר כו', והוא הדין הנשבע להקב"ה

And it seems reasonable to say: the Mishneh LaMelekh (Chapter 10, Laws of Kings, Halakha 7) was troubled by the oaths sworn before the Giving of the Torah: Abraham and Isaac to Avimelekh, Esau to Jacob, and Eliezer to Abraham. The perplexity lies in the fact that the commandment of an oath is not one of the Seven Noahide Laws. I find this even more difficult regarding the oath at Mount Sinai, which is the very foundation of accepting the Torah. After all, as long as they had not yet received the Torah, they were not commanded concerning oaths. Furthermore, even if they had been commanded, the power of an oath stems from the commandment "He shall not profane his word." How is this warning any different from other warnings in the Torah? And what power does the oath add to the Torah's warnings, given that the oath itself is also merely a warning? Therefore, it seems clear that when one swears to another, this is a compelling reason to fulfill it, and no [additional] warning is needed. This applies to the oaths of Abraham, Isaac, and Eliezer, and similarly to one who swears to the Holy One, blessed be He.

R Elazar Moshe Horowitz already waxed poetic about it in his Responsa Ohel Moshe 138.

title: How were true prophets recognized during the time of prophecy?
content:
# How were true prophets recognized during the time of prophecy? ## Frage

The Torah gives some instructions for recognizing false prophets, but how were true prophets recognized? Who had the authority to label a particular prophet as kosher?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

This is how Rambam lays it out in the last chapter of Yesodei haTorah:

Any prophet who arises and tells us that God has sent him does not have to prove himself by performing wonders like those performed by Moses, our teacher, or like the wonders of Elijah or Elisha, which altered the natural order. Rather, the sign of the truth of his prophecy will be the fulfillment of his prediction of future events, as implied by Deuteronomy 18:21: “How shall we recognize that a prophecy was not spoken by God?...” Therefore, if a person whose progress in the service of God makes him fit for prophecy arises and claims to be a prophet — if he does not intend to add to or diminish the Torah, but rather to serve God through the mitzvot of the Torah — we do not tell him: “Split the sea for us, revive the dead, or the like, and then we will believe in you.” Instead, we tell him, “If you are a prophet, tell us what will happen in the future.” He makes his statements, and we wait to see whether his prophecy comes to fruition or not. Should even a minute particular of his prophecy not materialize, he is surely a false prophet. If his entire prophecy materializes, we should consider him a true prophet. We should test him many times. If all of his statements prove true, he should be considered to be a true prophet, as I Samuel 3:20 states concerning Samuel, “And all of Israel, from Dan to Beersheba, knew that Samuel had been proven to be a prophet unto God.”

title: Does the segol change to a tsere when there is a yod after it?
content:
# Does the segol change to a tsere when there is a yod after it? ## Frage

Does the segol change into a tsere sound? Example: the word אליך there being a segol under the lamed and no niqqud under the yod does the segol sound stay the same or is it changed to a tsere vowel sound? If it does, is it safe to assume this is the same change when you have a dagesh hazak (hazak is the doubling of the consonant right? Or is it dagesh col)?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

No.

When the early Tiberian Masoretes vocalized Tanakh with niqqud, they did so according to their pronunciation tradition.

This means that every vowel symbol corresponded to a single pronounced vowel. The vowel pronounced [ɛ] was marked with Segol, and the vowel pronounced [eː] was marked with Tzereh.

So when they vocalized אֵלֶיךָ with a Segol on the ל and nothing on the י, they were recording the fact that the word was actually pronounced as [ʔeː.ˈlɛː.χɔː], with a Segol sound after the ל and an unpronounced י.

# Explanation of Rebbe (R Yehuda HaNasi) making kiddish after his passing ## Frage

B"H

There's a famous Mishnas Chassidim commentary that says that after Rebbe passed away, he would still make kiddish for his family, and they fulfilled their obligation by listening to him, because "the righteous are still obligated in mitzvos " after their passing

Is they any kind of explanation for how this can be? Is the physical body of Rebbe somehow climbing out of it's grave to go make kiddish, or is his soul making kiddish?

title: Chashmonaic Authorship of Al Ha'Nissim of Chanukah
content:
# Chashmonaic Authorship of Al Ha'Nissim of Chanukah ## Frage

Very related. Slightly related (link, link).

I'm looking for Rishonim (or earlier authorities) that state that the author or authors of Al Ha'Nissim for Chanukah was/were Yochanan Kohen Gadol and/or other members of the same family/group (the Chashmonaim). So far I've found that this is stated by the Rokeach (Hilchot Chanukah, § 225), the Kol Bo, and an anonymous student of Rabbi Yehudah Ha'Chassid (Sodei Chumash ve'Sha'ar, p. 49, § 50 [can be found on Otzar Hachochmah]). Are there any others?1

1 I also found it in Rabbeinu Ephraim's commentary on the Torah (Parashat Miketz), however, contrary to later (modern) mistaken references to that commentary, it appears in a section that was explicitly defined in the manuscript as additional commentaries from mainly later sages, and is therefore not attributed to Rabbienu Ephraim himself. In this case, it appears to be quoted out of the Rokeach.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

In Orchos Chaim (Chanukah seif 22), Rav Aharon m'Lunil says:

... מזכירין בהודאה על הניסים ויש בו קכ"ד תיבות כמנין יוחנן שתיקנו... ואין אומרים בו וחשמונאי ובניו כי יוחנן הוא חשמונאי כמו שאומר בספר יוסיפון

We mention in Modim "Al Hanisim", and it has 124 letters, like the Gematria of Yochanan who wrote it... And we don't say "and Hasmonean and his sons" because Yochanan was a Hasmonean, as it says in Josephus

In siddur Harash m'Garmaiza he says the same thing, quoting the Rokeach. He also says:

וי"א כמניין כהנים תיבות יש בברכה זו ופי' חשמונאי ובניו יסדוהו

And there are those that say that the are as many words (in Al Hanisim) as the Gematria of Kohanim (125), meaning that the Hasmonean and his sons established it.

Also Shabbos (21b) says

לשנה אחרת קבעום ועשאום ימים טובים בהלל והודאה

And rashi explains:

ה"ג ועשאום ימים טובים בהלל והודאה: לא שאסורים במלאכה, שלא נקבעו אלא לקרות הלל ולומר על הניסים בהודאה

They made them holidays of praise and thanks: not to prohibit melacha, since they were only established to read hallel and to say Al Hanisim in thanks.

At least one way of understanding לשנה אחרת is that it means "the next year" (for example, Ritva ad loc). If Rashi agrees with this reading, that would means he holds that hallel and Al Hanisim were decreed the next year, which would likely mean it was written by one of the Hasmoneans.

title: Are the traditions of the Karaim considered legitimate by other more mainstream sects of Judaism (ie Chasidism other rabbinic schools)?
content:
# Are the traditions of the Karaim considered legitimate by other more mainstream sects of Judaism (ie Chasidism other rabbinic schools)? ## Frage

I'm curious if the traditions of the Karaim (Karaite Jews) are considered legitimate by other Jewish groups. Maybe they are seen as legitimate by some groups but not others.

I'm NOT asking if the Karaim are seen as Jews, but if their traditions of only doing commands in the Bible without extensive rabbinic commentary is seen as a legitimate expression of Judaism.

Also, corrections are welcome regarding any misunderstanding on my part of the Karaim, their traditions, or of any Jewish group.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

No. Rabbinic theology is based on a number of factors, such as:

  • Leading sages have legal authority according to scripture, and violating their legal interpretations and enactments is forbidden.
  • Many aspects of the Oral Law were received along with scripture, and were preserved by the sages of each generation; so a number of laws from the oral tradition are as strong as scriptural law.

The Karaites violate both: They reject Rabbinic authority, and reject the authenticity of our oral tradition. They believe that each person’s subjective interpretation of scripture is entirely valid, whether literalist or otherwise. Thus, their practices and theology are not a valid form of Rabbinic Judaism (and therefore not considered Judaism at all by Rabbinates).

title: Halachot of Animals with Tzaraat
content:
# Halachot of Animals with Tzaraat ## Frage

If an animal has tzaraat are there any halachot which appertain to them? I realize that technically an animal is not considered a metzora, but if the animal clearly has signs which would be considered tzaraat on a person (or clothing or home) do we treat the animal differently in any way?

Can they be ridden? If they are slaughtered while they have tzaraat can they be eaten? Can you keep them in your home? Etc.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

Living animals are never subject to any sort of Tumah, so there is no reason they anything would be forbidden while alive.

Theoretically the Tzaraat might be a problem after the animal dies. But Tzaraat is not listed as a Treifa that would render it forbidden for eating.

One practical possibility is that the Tzaraas might be considered a blemish that makes an animal Pasul for a Korban, just as a Kohen who has a non-Tamei form of Tzaraat cannot serve in the Beit Hamikdash (Bechorot Mishna 7:6). I have not seen anything indicating that Tzaraas is a pasul in animals though.

On a more practical note, no form of Tzaraas can exist where normal hair is present. So it seems unlikely that any animal would have Tzaraas unless it loses its hair. I don’t know if lost hair is considered a blemish on its own.

title: Why do the best of doctors go to Gehinnom? Looking for more answers (especially less well known ones)
content:
# Why do the best of doctors go to Gehinnom? Looking for more answers (especially less well known ones) ## Frage

Why do the best of doctors go to Gehinnom?

Kiddushin 82a:

טוב שברופאים לגיהנם

The best of doctors go to Gehinnom

I am looking for an out of the box answer, and even one that somehow puts the doctors in a good light. I've heard the following already:

  1. The most common: Doctors gain pride, hubris or some lack of emuna in Hashem. They start to believe in their own power, and less in Hashem's (e.g. Rashi, Ben Yehoyada, Maharsha, Maharal).
  2. Doctors inevitably make mistakes, bad decisions, or similar and thus are responsible for a lot of bloodshed (Meiri)
  3. Medicine is a dangerous practice, and this statement isn't necessarily against doctors but against the profession (Ramban)

But I've also heard the occasional "positive" interpretation:

  1. It's not talking about practising doctors, but rather people who could be doctors but don't do so, and thus lose out on the great Mitzva of healing (Tur)
  2. It's not a practical statement but rather a meditation - every doctor should imagine that each one of his patients risks him going to Gehinnom if he messes up. This will ensure he tries his best (Shevet Yehuda)

Are there any very different interpretations (especially positive ones) that might be a bit more obscure? Any that are very clever and satisfying? Especially with regards to the "kasha of the heart" that many people seem to have about this: we generally see doctors as particularly engaged in Mitzvot and trying to make the world a better place - people we should be very grateful to, and in awe of. Why such a seemingly harsh statement?

[I know the latter is opinion based, but it's not me'akev - just a hint at what I would find the most interesting. The main question is I want more explanations of this difficult Chazal.]

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

טוב שברופאים לגהינום means those doctors who say only 17 (טוב) of the 18 Brachos of Shmoneh Esrei, omitting the brochah of רפאנו -- since they believe that healing is in their hands -- go to גהינום

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

I think the Rasbha says -if not him a different early Torah source- that it is because they make you come back for follow up visits when you really don't need to so that they can make money off you.

A more positive explanation alleged to be said by Rav Yosef Chaim Sonnenfeld is because when patients tell them that it is too difficult for them to take important measures for their, they are too empathic instead of insisting that they do so.

Rashi on the mishna says an additional reason to the one quoted here. He should have healed poor people for free

### Antwort 3 (Score: 1)

Rabbi Akiva Eiger explains the it to mean the best of doctors will lead others to gehenom. Meaning the good traits of doctors. Sometimes they have to give painful treatment, or amputate limbs to save the person. But a regular person who does these things will go to gehenom.

title: If the 6 days of creation followed by a day of rest aren't meant to be taken literally then what is Shabbos based on?
content:
# If the 6 days of creation followed by a day of rest aren't meant to be taken literally then what is Shabbos based on? ## Frage

The rationale for Shabbos is presented differently in the two sets of luchos.

In Sefer Shemos it is about six days of God's creation of the universe and rest which sanctifies the day and which we are to mimic whereas in Devarim it is about not overworking the people and animals that are in our control as we know what it was like to be overworked in Egypt.

According to the first reason Shabbos has a unique character as the actual day God rested which stamps it with Kedusha and Bracha, it is about emulating God and recognizing creation.

According to the second reason that isn't necessary but rather every seven days is when humans and animals require repose.

Traditionally they're understood complimentarily with the seventh day of necessary rest happily coinciding with the actual seventh day of creation.

Rashbam even asserts (Bereishis 1:1) that the creation story was written as an etiology for the mitzvah:

גם כל הפרשה הזאת של מלאכת ששה ימים הקדימו משה רבינו לפרש לך מה שאמר הקב״ה בשעת מתן תורה: זכור את יום השבת לקדשו {וגו׳} כי ששת ימים עשה י״י את השמים ואת הארץ את הים ואת כל אשר בם וינח ביום השביעי (שמות כ׳:ז׳-י׳). וזהו שכתוב: ויהי ערב ויהי בקר יום הששי (בראשית א׳:ל״א) – אותו ששי שהוא גמר ששה ימים שאמר הקב״ה במתן תורה.

Even this entire portion concerning the six days of labor, Moses our teacher preceded to explain to you what the Holy One, blessed be He, said at the time of the giving of the Torah: “Remember the Sabbath day to sanctify it…” (Exodus 20:8–11), for in six days the Lord made the heavens and the earth, the sea, and all that is in them, and He rested on the seventh day. And this is what is written: “And there was evening, and there was morning, the sixth day” (Genesis 1:31) — that very “sixth” day is the completion of the six days that the Holy One, blessed be He, mentioned at the giving of the Torah.

Rambam famously writes that he is able and willing to reinterpret the creation story to cohere with Aristotle's eternal universe were he to have proved it but being that he did has not he is going to adopt creation from nothing.

In an eternal universe there aren't any first or seventh days (or any other days).

(Also if one doesn't take the six days of creation literally even if one accepts a created universe which again may be Rambam's position, [as opposed to say Ramban (Bereishis 1:3) who takes them literally:

ודע, כי הימים הנזכרים במעשה בראשית היו בבריאת השמים והארץ ימים ממש, מחוברים משעות ורגעים, והיו ששה כששת ימי המעשה, כפשוטו של מקרא.

Know that the days mentioned in the account of Creation were actual days in the creation of the heavens and the earth, measured by hours and moments, and there were six of them, like the six days of the work, according to the plain meaning of the Scripture.]

although it may be less of an issue as there were actual first and seventh days to get the ball rolling)

If the six days of creation followed by a day of rest aren't meant to be taken literally is Shabbos then "merely" a day adopted by God who knows the nature of man and animals and their rest needs and commanded rest every seventh day (the Devarim model), which He blessed and sanctified, the seven day week either being generated by the Jews based on God's instruction (which in turn begs the question of when He chose to start the week exactly?) or Shabbos being patterned off of a preexisting seven day week already around before the Jews with the creation story a religious "myth" (the Shemos Model) to imbue it with more ontological and metaphysical meaning and significance than the relatively more utilitarian true reason which is less inspiring?

title: Is it OK to pray at breakneck speed?
content:
# Is it OK to pray at breakneck speed? ## Frage

Some people pray at breakneck speed, even if they are leading the service. Let's assume they enunciate every word, as required, and claim they feel kavanah. Still, one can argue it is not seemly, because they appear to just want to get the service over with as fast as possible, and that one should pray at normal conversational speed.

My question is: Are there halakhic guidelines on the speed of delivery in praying?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 10)

Aside from the general concerns of having proper intention (1:4) and properly pronouncing words (61:22), a few citations from Shulchan Arukh come to mind:

58:8

אין אומרים הזמירות במרוצה כי אם בנחת
We do not say the Psalms [in Pesukei Dizimra] quickly but rather gently.

61:1

יקרא קריאת שמע בכוונה באימה ביראה ברתת וזיע
He should read the Shema with intent, fear, awe, trembling, and sweat.

98:3

יתפלל דרך תחנונים כרש המבקש בפתח ובנחת ושלא תראה עליו כמשא ומבקש ליפטר ממנה
He should pray in a supplicative manner, as a pauper begs at a doorway, and gently, and so that it not seem as a burden which one wants to be done with.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 3)

Yalkut Yosef (Tefilla B, 124:6) discusses a potential halakhic problem with praying fast: preventing the community from properly hearing and responding to a blessing. Here is the issue:

מנהג יפה לומר על כל ברכה שאדם שומע, אחר הזכרת שם ה' ''ברוך הוא וברוך שמו'... ולכן על השליח צבור כשמסיים הברכות בתפלת החזרה, ואומר ברוך אתה ה', להמתין ולשהות קצת, כדי שיספיקו השומעים לענות ''ברוך הוא וברוך שמו'', ורק לאחר מכן יחתום הברכה, ויענו אחריו אמן. אך אם השליח צבור ממהר מאוד בתפלתו, ואחר שאומר ברוך אתה ה' מסיים תיכף ומיד חתימת הברכה, שאז קיים חשש שהשומעים שעונים ''ברוך הוא וברוך שמו'' לא ישמעו חתימת הברכה כראוי, מוטב לא לענות ''ברוך הוא וברוך שמו'', שעיקרו מתורת מנהג, כדי להעדיף שמיעת חתימת הברכה כראוי, ויענו אחריו אמן, שענייתו חובה גמורה מן הדין.

For every blessing that one hears, it is a beautiful custom to say, "Barukh Hu u-Barukh Shemo" [Blessed be He and blessed be His name] after hearing the name of God...Therefore, when the prayer leader concludes the blessing in the repetition of the Amida, and says, "Blessed are you, O God," he must wait and linger a little, so that those who hear him have time to respond, "Barukh Hu u-Barukh Shemo," and only then conclude the blessing, so that they can respond with "Amen." However, if the prayer leader is very hasty in his prayer, and after saying "Barukh ata Hashem," he immediately concludes the blessing, there is then a concern that those who hear him respond, "Barukh Hu u-Barukh Shemo," and will not hear the conclusion of the blessing properly. It is better not to respond, "Barukh Hu u-Barukh Shemo," which is essentially a custom, in order to prefer hearing the conclusion of the blessing properly, and respond with "Amen," a response absolutely obligatory by law.

The footnote to the Yalkut Yosef cites the Ben Ish Hai (Terumah #12) that:

שאם הש"צ ממהר ולא ענו הצבור ב"ה וב"ש, כדי לענות אמן, העונש עליו

If the prayer leader ​​rushes and the congregation does not answer "Barukh Hu u-Barukh Shemo" in order to answer Amen, the punishment is on him.

title: Who were the members of Beit Hillel
content:
# Who were the members of Beit Hillel ## Frage

Similar to this question Who were members of Beth Shammai? - who were the members of Beit Hillel?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

As previously noted here, a certain version of Seder Tannaim ve'Amoraim contains lists of sages who belonged to Beit Hillel and Beit Shammai. Here are the names of sages stated to belong to Beit Hillel (MS British Library Add. 11639, fols. 680r-v; Marx edition, p. XIV):

  • Rabban Gamliel (unclear which one)
  • Rabbi Akiva
  • Rabbi Shimon ben Yehudah
  • Rabbi Chanina ben Dosa
  • Rabbi Yosi Ha'Glili
  • Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel
  • Rabbi Yehudah Ha'Nasi
  • Rabbi Shimon ben Nanas
  • Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar
  • Rabbi Shimon ben Akshyah (a scribal error for Rabbi Chananyah ben Akashyah?)
  • Rabb Eliezer ben Yaakov
  • Rabbi Dostai bar Yannai
  • Rabbi Natan
  • Rabbi Yochanan Ha'Sandlar
  • Rabbi Yochanan ben Elazar Ha'Kapar
  • Rabbi Shimon Kohen Gadol
  • Rabbi Tarfon
  • Rashbi
  • Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi
  • Rabbi Dosa ben Harkinas
  • Rabbi Yochanan
  • Reish Lakish
  • Rabbi Chutzpit
  • Rabbi Shimon ben Azzai
  • Rabbi Shimon ben Netanel
  • Rabbi Yehoshua ben Chananyah
  • Rabbi Elazar ben Azaryah
  • Rabbi Nechunyah ben Hakanah
  • Rabbi Yochanan ben Brokah
  • Rabbi Yosi Ha'Kohen
  • Rabbi Elazar ben Yehudah

The list also includes the earlier Rabbi Shimon ben Shetach. As in the case of the Beit Shammai list, this may be a scribal error, but it may also suggest that he is considered part of the same school of thought, as a kind of precursor of Beit Hillel, and was therefore included in the list. Notably, some sages named here also appear in the Beit Shammai list, such as Rebbi. Another notable point is that the three explicitly named students of Hillel are missing: Yonatan ben Uziel, Rabbi Yochanan ben Zakkai (who does appear in the Beit Shammai list; and indeed was a student of both), and [Rabban] Shimon ben Hillel.1

So, to this list should be added the above-three sages.

1 Some medieval sources refer to Hillel's son Shimon by the title rabban, though he does not appear with that title in Chazalic sources.

The Chida famously wrote:

כתבו הספרים שבלילה קודם השינה נכון לאדם שיפשפש במעשיו שעשה כל היום ואם ימצא שעשה עבירה יתודה עליה ויקבל ע"ע שלא לעשותה עוד ובפרט בעונות המצויים כגון חניפות שקרים ליצנות לשה"ר וכן עון בטול תורה צריכים בדיקה ביותר. גם ראוי למחול לכל מי שחטא כנגדו וציערו ובזכות זה האדם מאריך ימים

title: time for starting evening shema (Yehoshua, Berakhot 2b)
content:
# time for starting evening shema (Yehoshua, Berakhot 2b) ## Frage

In Berakhot 2b the Gemara debates whether the starting time for Shema is determined by the priest (when he may eat his teruma) or by the poor person (when he eats his evening meal).

Among the various baraitot (e.g. of Rabbi Meir, Rabbi Yehuda, Rabbi Ḥanina), Rabbi Yehoshua states: “From the time when the priests are eligible to partake of their teruma.”

From what I understand, Rabbi Yehoshua sets the latest possible starting time (among these views). The emergence of stars, after completely setting of sun.

But in the Steinsaltz commentary I see the line:

“As if you say that the poor person is earlier, it would be impossible to establish a time earlier than that established by Rabbi Yehoshua.”

My confusion: Why would it be “impossible to establish an earlier time” than Rabbi Yehoshua, if Rabbi Yehoshua is actually giving the latest time?

The whole text:

And is the time of the poor person and the priest the same? The Gemara raises a contradiction to this approach from another baraita, in which other opinions regarding the time for the recitation of the evening Shema are cited. From when does one begin to recite the evening Shema?

From the time when the day becomes sanctified on the eve of Shabbat. This is the statement of Rabbi Eliezer, who established an earlier time for Shema. Rabbi Yehoshua, like our mishna, says: from the time when the priests are eligible to partake of their teruma. Rabbi Meir says: the time for the recitation of Shema begins before the priests were purified, from when the priests immerse themselves in order to partake of their teruma.

Rabbi Yehuda said to Rabbi Meir: How is it possible that the time for the recitation of the evening Shema corresponds to the time of the priests’ immersion? Do the priests not immerse themselves during the day, so that with nightfall and the onset of a new day they will be purified? If so, how can that time be called night?

Rabbi Ḥanina says that the time for the recitation of the evening Shema begins when the poor person eats his bread with salt. But Rabbi Aḥai, and some say Rabbi Aḥa, says: from the time when most people recline at their meal during the week.

The preceding was the text of the baraita. Returning to our question, if you say that the time of the poor person and the priest are one and the same, then the opinion of Rabbi Ḥanina is identical to that of Rabbi Yehoshua. However, the fact that they are cited together indicates that they are not, in fact, the same. Rather, must one not conclude from this that the time for the poor person is separate and the time for the priest is separate? Since no objection is raised, the Gemara concedes: indeed, conclude from this.

Having established that the time of the poor person and that of the priest are different, the Gemara seeks to determine: which one is later? The Gemara suggests that it is reasonable to conclude that the time of the poor person is later. As if you say that the poor person is earlier, it would be impossible to establish a time earlier than that established by Rabbi Yehoshua, unless we hold that night begins with sunset, in which case the opinion of Rabbi Ḥanina is identical to that of Rabbi Eliezer. Rather, must one not conclude from this that the poor person is later? The Gemara notes: indeed, conclude from this.

title: Understanding this Yismach Moshe on bikkurim
content:
# Understanding this Yismach Moshe on bikkurim ## Frage

The Torah in Parshas Ki Savo says:

[...] that thou shalt take of the first of all the fruit of the earth, which thou shalt bring of thy land that the L-rd thy G-d gives thee, and shalt put it in a basket, and shalt go to the place which the L-rd thy G-d shall choose to place his name there. (Devarim 26:2)

Background/Context:

The Yismach Moshe (Parshas Ki Savo, sv. והיה כי תבא) explains the words "and shalt put it in a basket" to mean the following:

ושמת בטנא, ר"ל שאתה צריך לשום בסל, ר"ל להשפיע לך פרנסה ופירות מעשיך הטובים

And you shall put in the basket, meaning that you must place in the basket, meaning to cause sustenance and the fruits of your good deeds to flow for you.

He also says this:

you come to the priest — meaning an important and righteous person to guide you in the ways of repentance

I have trouble understanding the mitzvah of bringing bikkurim in light of what the Yismach Moshe says. He says that going to the priest, will guide a person in the ways of repentance. However, the mitzvah of bringing bikkurim (which are a present to G-d, as per the Sforno) is given to us as a remembrance that it is G-d who sustains us.

Rabbi Immanuel Bernstein explains the mitzvah of bikkurim as follows:

By bringing the first fruits to the Temple, one is acknowledging Hashem as the Source of his sustenance, as the One who guided the agricultural cycle and provided the harvest.

Question

My question is this: According to the Yismach Moshe, the fruits represent the good deeds of a person, and going to the kohen will guide one to do teshuvah. How can this all be deduced from these pesukim? The bikkurim remind a person that it is G-d who sustains us; what has that to do with teshuvah?

title: Once reason is admissible where is the line drawn—if indeed it is—between the literal and non-literal interpretation of Tanach?
content:
# Once reason is admissible where is the line drawn—if indeed it is—between the literal and non-literal interpretation of Tanach? ## Frage

Unless a verse in Tanach is clearly poetic, rhetorical, or a literary flourish (like “the mountains skipped” or “the trees clap their hands”), how do we determine when to read it literally versus non-literally?

For example, Onkelos already read anthropomorphisms non-literally, but then later science forced us to reinterpret things like the firmament and the “windows of heaven”, (and angels for some), items which were taken literally according to earlier conceptions of cosmology (and angelology).

R. Avraham ben David (Ra’avad) already criticized Rambam for enlarging the scope of heresy, noting that the plain meaning of the verses about God’s body misled people “greater than [Rambam] himself” (Hasagos HaRa’avad to Hilchos Teshuvah 3:7).

From R. Saadia Gaon through Gersonides the rationalist tradition got ever bolder in what it took non-literally, with the trend eventually moving away from medieval rationalism.

Since even rejecting anthropomorphism relies on reason (Greek thought if we're being honest), how do we decide how far reason and science should guide us in reading the Torah non-literally, and where do we draw the line, if there is one (Maimonides was famously open to accepting an eternal universe if it were proven by reason)?

Nowadays some Orthodox Jews will—based on modern science and archeology—accept a very old universe along with some form of evolution, reinterpreting Tanach as they go along. (Although admittedly some of that has to do with actual scientific evidence and finds, in other words the sense test of R Saadia Gaon vs the logical test.)

Is it that these explanations were always embedded in the text with progress in thought and science merely uncovering the "true" meaning of Tanach (till the next discovery comes along)?

In a word, once reason and science are admitted as valid (re-)interpreters of Tanach, where do we draw the line, if we do?
