title: How can the Mitzvah of Torah study sometimes override the Mitzva of "be fruitful and multiply"?
content:
# How can the Mitzvah of Torah study sometimes override the Mitzva of "be fruitful and multiply"? ## Frage

Surrounding Shulchan Aruch Even HaEzer 1:3, there seems to be a discussion about delaying marriage (and therefore having children) for the sake of learning Torah. The Beit Shmuel (5) explains that, based on the Rambam, there is seemingly no limit on this (based on the case of Ben Azzai). He mentions that the Rosh disagrees, and says surely there must be a limit to this delay, but no limit is provided. The Chochmat Shlomo (starting ומיהו אם) gives practical advice to those who wish to not have children for the sake of Torah learning, including finding a wife who cannot have children and even extends it to an umdena - if someone feels he wouldn't be a good father, he can find a wife who cannot bear children (no mention of Torah study!)

So, how do we understand this? How do we go discussing delaying a bit for Torah, and discussing one's yetzer, to suddenly saying one can delay having children all one's life for Torah and more?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Rambam says that the dispensation is based upon עוסק במצוה פטור מן המצוה.

The problem is that that פטור is typically limited to when others can do the mitzvah for you, unless one says that Rambam only uses it for delaying.

However, he does say that there is no sin if one follows Ben Azai provided one doesn't have lustful thoughts.

Maimonides rules that if one had children when he was a non-Jew, and subsequently converts, one isn't obligated in the mitzvah.

Evidently this mitzvah isn't about performance per se but rather about leaving progeny and populating the world.

Perhaps the leap can be made that it is called אפשר למצוה להעשות על ידי אחרים being that it is about populating the world which although לכתחילה devolves upon all adult men but ultimately can be pawned off to others in pressing circumstances.

Likewise, if it is about populating the world and continuity, then one can also posit that it is about raising healthy children who themselves can participate in society and raise their own children.

Prior to the later teenage years perhaps one isn't emotionally developed enough to father healthy children.

That may explain the opinion that one who knows he won't make a good father is able to skate.

Perhaps the dispensation of Ben Azai itself can be explained as such, namely, that if one is truly attached to learning one wouldn't make an ideal dad.

title: Timeline and circumstances of "Rabbi as leader"
content:
# Timeline and circumstances of "Rabbi as leader" ## Frage

In our community we sometimes discuss not only who should be the Rabbi, but also whether we should have a Rabbi at all.

I would like to better understand the role of the Rabbi as a leader, and how that role has evolved over time. For example, in Second Temple times, the national leadership was the Sanhedrin — but were there also local sages (the forerunners of the 'Rabbis') who served in leadership roles within individual communities? If so, what did their leadership look like?

In later periods, especially in Europe, it was common for a town or region to have a Rabbi as the Mara d’Atra — the communal halachic authority and leader — but not necessarily for an individual synagogue to have its own Rabbi. Rather, the Rabbi’s role was to adjudicate disputes, issue rulings, supervise communal standards, and represent the Jewish community to the outside world.

So my question is: What is the historical development of the role of the Rabbi as a communal or local leader, from the time of the Second Temple through the medieval European model, and how did that evolve into today’s more synagogue-centered model of Rabbinic leadership?

title: What does it mean that the nefesh'guf resides in the liver?
content:
# What does it mean that the nefesh'guf resides in the liver? ## Frage

According to the Gra and others, the nefesh which is the guf resides in the liver. What does it mean that the guf resides in the liver?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

I'll answer according to the Vilna Ga'on's contemporary (and disputant, but probably not on this), the Alter Rebbe (R' Schnuer Zalman of Liadi).

This statement is explained in Likkutei Torah Pinchas (3rd Ma'amar) as follows:

The statement in the Torah "the life is in the blood" (Devarim 12:23 "הַדָּם הוּא הַנָּפֶשׁ"; see also Vayikra 17:11, 14) is taken straightforwardly in Kabbalah due to the principle of "the order of links in a chain" (Seder Hishtalshelut). I.e. the body and soul exist on many planes of existence, like links in a chain, each one "beyond" the other.

Note, that chain links pass through the adjacent links, and this is why they are used as the analogy here - in order for each part of the soul to connect to the parts above it and below it, there has to be a similarity/cross over between them. I'll give an example, and then show how it relates to the Nefesh and the blood, and then finally we can bring in the liver.

Example: the soul has emotions and intellect. They seem worlds apart! Yet we also know that they are directly connected - our emotions are born in our intellect. So, what is the similarity? Well, the highest aspect of emotion is "like/don't like" (Chesed and Gevura). The lowest part of the intellect is "yes, or no?" (Da'at). Thus, there is a similarity: yes = like, no = don't like. When the Da'at concludes yes, our heart is moved to like it. When it concludes no, our heart is opposed to it.

That's how intellect overlaps with emotion! Da'at overlaps with Chesed and Gevura (as we know from the 4 pronged Shin on the Tefillin Shel Rosh - see Derech Mitzvotecha Mitzvat Tefillin).

Da'at itself is below Binah, which is our left-brain analysis. This has a mode of "agree, disagree", and that's how Da'at "overlaps" with Binah. And so on.

So, when it comes to the body and soul connection, we need something similar*. The lowest part of the soul is called the Nefesh, and it's the most "physical" aspect of the soul (it is described this way in the sources, as being a part of the physical world - see Derech Hashem 3). It needs to connect with the most "spiritual" part of the body, which is the heat of the blood (you can't see heat, only feel it, similar to a soul).

So, finally we can explain why it is in the liver specifically. According to the sources, this is because the liver cleans and refines the blood. Blood gets its vitality from the food the body eats, but the food is not all useful for the vitality of creating this heat, so the liver is one of the final stages in the refinement of the blood, where it becomes purified to supply the rest of the body with vitality. Therefore it is the seat of the Nefesh, where the Nefesh first connects.

* it should be noted, as per the Rema on Orach Chayim 6:1, and Derech Mitzvotecha Shoresh Mitzvat HaTefilla 39, the leap from spiritual to physical is a truly wonderous miracle, far more of a leap than any other "leaps" in the Seder Hishtalshelut.

title: 1st, 2nd and 3rd generations of Zohar authorship?
content:
# 1st, 2nd and 3rd generations of Zohar authorship? ## Frage

On the Talk page of the Idra on Wikipedia I noted the following. The page doesn't get much views and I'm curious about it so I thought I'd bring attention to it here. Please feel free to also post responses there in addition.

First, Second, Third Generations of Zoharic Literature?

  1. "Contemporary scholars believe the Idra dates to the third generation of Zoharic literature, which also produced the two anonymous or collective works of the Tikunei haZohar and Ra'aya Mehemna "Faithful Shephard" as well as other Zoharic material. The main body of the Zohar dates to the second generation of Zoharic material."

-- This is the first time I've seen these terms of first, second etc. generations of Zoharic literature. Looking at Zohar#Modern_critical_views, it says:

  1. "According to Scholem, the Zohar can be divided into 21 types of content, of which the first 18 (a.–s.) are the work of the original author (probably de Leon) and the final 3 (t.–v.) are the work of a later imitator."

My rav told me that yes there are parts of the Zohar that were added later, as those contain future events and future linguistics after Rashbi's time.

Mapping the common academic and "many achronim" as some say, view, that deLeon is "the author," to the view that Rashbi and friends are the original and initial author, I gather this framework:

  • 1a. Rashbi and friends, Zohar.
  • 1b. Tikunei Zohar, Rashbi and Eliyahu, like the text says.
    1. Moshe de Leon and/or earlier pseudepigraphists.
    1. Moshe de Leon and/or later epigraphists.

This makes sense for me.

I would just like to hear and bring attention to, and for various views to lay out their positions of, what are "1st, 2nd and 3rd gen." In particular because that wiki page didn't refer to what's the 1st generation nor cite the source of its view.

And regarding that R' Yitzchak b' Shmuel of Akko (whom the Chida identifies as as a talmid of the Ramba"n) says that he visited the widow of Moshe de León to enquire about the manuscripts from which Moshe copied the Zohar and she admitted that he wrote it page by page as a way to support his family -- I'm aware of that, and also of the view that she might have been embarrassed later for selling the sheets to get by and that's why she said that.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

Arthur Green, A Guide to The Zohar, pp. 166-167 wrote:

"Contemporary scholarship on the Zohar (here we are indebted especially to the pioneering work of Yehuda Liebes and its more recent development by Ronit Meroz) has parted company with Scholem on the question of single authorship.1 While it is tacitly accepted that De Leon did either write or edit long sections of the Zohar [...] he is not thought to be the only writer involved. Multiple layers of literary creativity can be discerned within the text. It may be that the Zohar should be seen as the product of a school of mystical practictioners and writers, one that could have existed even before 1270 and continued into the early years of the fourteenth century. Certain texts, including the Midrash ha-Ne'elam [...] belong to the oldest stratum of writing. The main part of the Zohar [...] were indeed composed in the decades claimed by Scholem.2 Work on the Zohar did not cease, however, with the turn of the fourteenth dentury or the passing of Moses de Leon. In fact, the author of the Tiqqunei Zohar and the Ra'ya Meheimna, see by Scholem as "later" addenda to the Zohar corpus, may represent the third "generation" of this ongoing school [...]"

But, it should be emphasized, as Green later noted himself (pp. 167-168), that this "school" of Zohar authors is purely hypothetical, based on literary analysis of the Zoharic texts.

1 I.e., that the Zohar was composed solely by Rabbi Moshe de Leon (Ramdal).

2 Ca. the time of Ramdal.

title: What does Maimonides mean when he denies a reason for creation and assigns it to God's will/wisdom?
content:
# What does Maimonides mean when he denies a reason for creation and assigns it to God's will/wisdom? ## Frage

In the guide 3:13 Rambam is at pains to emphasize that it isn't possible to assign a reason or purpose to creation but rather that it is the manifestation of God's will/wisdom.

Some excepts:

Even if the Universe existed for man's sake and man existed for the purpose of serving God, as has been mentioned, the question remains, What is the end of serving God? He does not become more perfect if all His creatures serve Him and comprehend Him as far as possible; nor would He lose anything if nothing existed beside Him. It might perhaps be replied that the service of God is not intended for God's perfection; it is intended for our own perfection,--it is good for us, it makes us perfect. But then the question might be repeated, What is the object of our being perfect? We must in continuing the inquiry as to the purpose of the creation at last arrive at the answer, It was the Will of God, or His Wisdom decreed it; and this is the correct answer. . . We remain firm in our belief that the whole Universe was created in accordance with the will of God, and we do not inquire for any other cause or object. just as we do not ask what is the purpose of God's existence, so we do not ask what was the object of His will, which is the cause of the existence of all things with their present properties, both those that have been created and those that will be created. . . This must be our belief when we have a correct knowledge of our own self, and comprehend the true nature of everything; we must be content, and not trouble our mind with seeking a certain final cause for things that have none, or have no other final cause but their own existence, which depends on the Will of God, or, if you prefer, on the Divine Wisdom.

For Rambam all of nature and Torah has purpose (ibid 2:20, 3:20,25,26).

God surely doesn't do anything for no reason or point so surely the universe has a reason for God bringing it into existence.

What does Rambam mean when he asserts that creation is only the function of God's will and/or wisdom but that it doesn't have a purpose or point?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

If it has a purpose, then why does He see value in that purpose? And why does He see value in the value of that purpose? And why does He see value in the value in the value... Uh oh.

Therefore: I guess, this is what He wants, not for anything further - i.e exactly what Rambam is saying. His Will alone.

  • This is why we can't ask any further - there's no further.

Second uh oh: there's a purpose and value Hashem finds in something, outside of Himself?! He is drawn to something?! He is influenced by something?! Impossible.

Therefore: It must be something about Him, not something about the creation. Again, exactly what the Rambam is saying: His Will alone.

  • This is why we can't understand it; just as much as we can't understand Him.

Read the whole of section 3. If you want to go further than that, then read the philosophy of Chabad Chassidut on these matters, which are very respectful to the Rambam here.

title: How do you pronounce this word in Devarim 22:1
content:
# How do you pronounce this word in Devarim 22:1 ## Frage

The word in that pasuk that translates as "his sheep," do you pronounce it "seyo," enunciating the yud, or would you pronounce it "sei-o," without enunciating the yud?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

In Biblical Hebrew, vowels can't exist without a preceding consonant. For example, Cholam can’t come immediately after Tzereh. There must be a consonant before the Cholam.

That means that in this case, the Yud is pronounced (sē-yō). Otherwise, there would be two adjacent vowels, which isn’t possible in Hebrew.

title: List of cities that are considered Safek Mukaf Choma?
content:
# List of cities that are considered Safek Mukaf Choma? ## Frage

I'm wondering if anyone can provide a list of cities that have the status of "Mukaf Choma" or "Safek Mukaf Choma".

I know only Yerushalayim is considered a Mukaf Choma city.

So far, the cities that I know of that are safek mukaf choma are:

  1. Baghdad
  2. Gaza
  3. Ramot (but it's status changed when they connected it to Yerushalayim)
  4. Teveria (I think)

I know there are many other cities in Israel with the status, but I was wondering if anyone had a concrete list.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Hebron residents keep two days of Purim for this reason.

I believe I heard this about Aleppo as well, but no source to back it up.

Related thread:

Walled cities for Purim other than Jerusalem

### ✅ Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

You're absolutely right that Yerushalayim is the only city we know for sure was walled back in the time of Yehoshua bin Nun. According to Peninei Halakhah (Zemanim 17:3), here's the list of cities with safek (uncertain) status when it comes to Purim:

In Eretz Yisrael:

Tiberias (Teveria)

Hebron

Shechem

Jaffa

Lod

Gaza

Tzefat

Akko

Haifa

Some people also add:

Beit She'an

Jericho

Beersheba

Ramla

Outside of Israel:

Tyre

Sidon

Damascus

Izmir

Baghdad

In most of these safek cities, people follow the lenient opinion and only celebrate Purim on the 14th of Adar. But in places where it's more likely they really were walled cities - especially Tiberias and Hebron - many people read the Megillah on the 15th as well. Some even do all the Purim mitzvot on both days in these cities. The uncertainty comes from two things: either we don't know if the city actually had a wall in Yehoshua's time (or if the wall was built after the houses), or we're not sure if the modern city is in the exact same spot as the ancient one. And yeah, you're spot on about Ramot, once they connected it to Yerushalayim, its status changed since it became part of the city.

title: Secularism in Judaism
content:
# Secularism in Judaism ## Frage

I was wondering if there are any aspects of life which Judaism considers not holy but secular (e.g. politics today)?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

I suspect a lot of this is a bit of a semantic question and can't truly be answered. With that out of the way, here's my answer to this question:

The Shulchan Aruch in Orach Chaim 231:1 lists several actions that one does throughout the course of the day that could switch between positive, negative, or neutral depending on one's thoughts and intentions. The implication being that the actions themselves are not inherently holy, but how one does them could turn it into a holy act, or leave it as a purely secular act (or even a negative one).

Here's a small sample of the text (it gives multiple examples, but for the sake of brevity only quoting one. Loose translation is my own):

וכל צרכי גופך יהיו כולם לעבודת בוראך או לדבר הגורם עבודתו שאפילו היה צמא ורעב אם אכל ושתה להנאתו אינו משובח אלא יתכוין שיאכל וישתה כפי חיותו לעבוד את בוראו

And all bodily needs should be done in furtherance of serving G-D. For example, even if someone was hungry and thirsty, if he ate with the sole intent of having enjoyment in the food, that is not praiseworthy. Rather, he should have the intention that the food and drink should give him strength to enable him to serve his Creator.

Regarding your specific example (politics), that would probably most closely parallel the example the Shulchan Aruch gives regarding "לישב בסוד ישרים" - sitting amongst the righteous. The parallel being one can sit and discuss/philosophize any topic with a group of people, and can either turn it into a productive discussion session or a non-productive one. Of course, even without an exact parallel to one of the examples listed in the Shulchan Aruch, the idea remains true for all actions.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

From Wikipedia:

Rav S.R. Hirsch:

Judaism is not a mere adjunct to life: it comprises all of life. To be a Jew is not a mere part, it is the sum total of our task in life. To be a Jew in the synagogue and the kitchen, in the field and the warehouse, in the office and the pulpit ... with the needle and the graving-tool, with the pen and the chisel—that is what it means to be a Jew.

And from Wikipedia regarding study of so-called secular topics:

הגר"א, למשל, דיבר על נחיצותן של שבע החכמות החיצוניות. בהשראתו של רמב"ם, טען הגר"א כי ידיעת כל החכמות מסייעת לתורה: "כפי שיחסר לאדם ידיעות משארי חוכמות, לעומת זה יחסר לו מאה ידות בחוכמת התורה, כי התורה והחוכמה נצמדים יחד" "כל החוכמות נצרכות לתורתנו", כך שלימודי החול יכולים להוות חלק מתלמוד התורה. אך לפי פרשנותו של הרב יוסף קאפח על תפיסת רמב"ם בעניין זה לא קיים ביהדות כלל מושג "לימודי חול" מול "לימודי קודש", אלא "לימוד מועיל" מול "לימודי סרק" כאשר "לימוד מועיל" אלה לימודי תורה ומדעי טבע ו"לימודי סרק" הם פחות או יותר

The Vilna Gaon, for example, spoke of the necessity of the seven external sciences. Inspired by Maimonides, the Vilna Gaon maintained that knowledge of all the sciences assists in the study of Torah: “To the extent that a person lacks knowledge of other sciences, by that same measure he will lack a hundredfold in the wisdom of the Torah, for Torah and wisdom are bound together”; “All the sciences are necessary for our Torah”. Accordingly, secular studies can constitute a component of Torah study. However, according to Rabbi Yosef Qafih’s interpretation of Maimonides’ position on this matter, within Judaism there is no concept at all of “secular studies” versus “sacred studies,” but rather of “useful study” versus “vain study.” “Useful study” refers to Torah study and the natural sciences, while “vain study” is more or less…

title: Rashi on Genesis 4:16 קדמת עדן
content:
# Rashi on Genesis 4:16 קדמת עדן ## Frage

I am learning with the Jaffa Hebrew Chumash Rashi right now, and I encountered when reading the commentary to Genesis 4:16 on קדמת עדן the expression לשמור את שמירת דרך מבוא לגן .

I don't understand what it is saying. "To guard the guarding of the road bringing towards the garden"??? I can't get it. No sifsei chachamim on this phrase either.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

It looks clunky in English but its idiomatic in Hebrew. For example, my favourite "don't translate me hyper-literally" phrase from Torah is:

אשר לא־עלה עליה על

"Which hasn't upped on upon it an up-on-er [i.e. a yoke which goes up on the neck]" [Bamidbar 19:2]

So it's not "to guard the guarding", it's just "to guard", and is fully rendered

"to guard the way that leads to the Garden"

See how this Rashi is translated by various translators here: it's all roughly the same.

We do this in English too sometimes:

They fought a fight = they fought
She lived her life = she lived
He dreamed a dream = he dreamed

But generally it sounds weird - not so in Hebrew. "He guarded a guard" is perfectly normal.

title: Practices that were adopted to support the rabbinic oral tradition against those that denied it
content:
# Practices that were adopted to support the rabbinic oral tradition against those that denied it ## Frage

I'm interested in halacha or minhag that developed to counter the deniers in the rabbinic Torah shebaal peh

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

title: Why on Rosh Hashono do we focus on the acknowledgement of the nations? Let us rather proclaim G-d's universal Kingship
content:
# Why on Rosh Hashono do we focus on the acknowledgement of the nations? Let us rather proclaim G-d's universal Kingship ## Frage

The “Kingship” section of the Musaf Amidah for Rosh Hashono conclude with these tow verses:

And it is said: “And Adonoy will be King over the whole earth; on that day Adonoy will be One and His Name One.”

And in Your Torah it is written: “Hear, Yisrael: Adonoy is our God Adonoy is One!”

Both of these verses refer to the future time when G-d's kingship will be acknowledged by all nations and not as now when only the Jewish people acknowledges this.

The fact is that G-d is the universal King even now. Why when we proclaim His Kingship do we focus on the acknowledgement of the nations of the world? Let us proclaim G-d's universal Kingship.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

It is a well known principle that Hashem doesn't want to be King by coercion:

אמרו לפני מלכיות כדי שתמליכוני עליכם

Say before me verses of Malchut in order to make me King over you [Rosh Hashana 16a, 34b]

(see also any Chassidus on Rosh Hashana will bring up this principle as well, this is the principle of Binyan Malchut, e.g. Yom Tov Shel Rosh Hashana 5666; Sfat Emet on Pesach. Generally speaking, the fact that Hashem gave us the choice to serve Him with free will is a logical and obvious proof that this is what He prefers, e.g. אם שמוע תשמעו... והייתם לי, ובחרת בחיים, אֵין הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא בָּא בִּטְרוּנְיָא עִם בְּרִיּוֹתָיו, כֹּל בִּידֵי שָׁמַיִם חוּץ מִיִּרְאַת שָׁמַיִם, הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא לִיבָּא בָּעֵי, etc.)

...and indeed it's questionable if such a ruler could be called "King". Kings are crowned and accepted by the people:

כִּי תָבֹא... וְאָמַרְתָּ אָשִׂימָה עָלַי מֶלֶךְ... שׂוֹם תָּשִׂים עָלֶיךָ מֶלֶךְ

When you come to the land... and you say: "I will set a king over me"... you shall surely set a king over yourself. [Devarim 17:14-15]

נחדש שם המלוכה... וימליכו שם את שאול לפני ה׳...

Let us go to Gilgal and renew the monarchy... and they made Saul king there before Hashem. [Shmuel 1:11:14-15]

כי יש הבדל בין מלך ומושל, שהמלך הוא בהסכמת העם ובבחירתם כי ראוי לכך, והמושל הוא ביד חזקה

There's a difference between a King and a Ruler; a King rules with the acceptance and free will of the people, while a Ruler rules by force [Malbim on תהלים כב:כח];

(see also Rabbeinu Bachya, Bamidbar 22:2, 2 for a long exposition on this concept; Ibn Ezra on Vayeshev 37:8; Gur Aryeh for Lech Lecha 17:1)

So it makes perfect sense that we cannot declare Hashem as King of the nations when they have yet to accept Him.

title: If Yom Kippur marks the arrival of the second set of luchos why isn't it mentioned at all in the whole of the davening?
content:
# If Yom Kippur marks the arrival of the second set of luchos why isn't it mentioned at all in the whole of the davening? ## Frage

I heard the following question from Rav Yehoshua Hartman shlita, who, in turn, asked Rav Schachter, who didn't have an answer.

We know that the first set of luchos didn't go down so well (Shemos 32:19) and it has ramifications until today. What was meant to be the most joyous of days is marked as shiva asar b'tammuz each year (refer to Mishnah Taanis 4:6 amongst other sources).

The second set of luchos followed and were brought down from Har Sinai on the day of Yom Kippur (refer to Rashi - Shemos 34:29).

Rabbi Hartman asked, this was a watershed moment in the history of klal yisroel, and yet it is not marked anywhere throughout the entire liturgy of Yom Kippur(!)

Are there any sources that discuss why?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

It is a very good question and can only suggest an answer, which is that we do not mention them because of the Midrashic principle that the reason why the second tablets endured is due to the fact that they were not given with "public spectacle", but quietly and without fanfare (see Midrash Tanchuma, Ki Tisa 31:2). The first Luchot were subject to the "evil eye", but the second not (Rashi).

Therefore, we follow this principle, which is associated with modesty, by only hinting at the tablets. How do we hint at them?

  1. All forgiveness comes from the second tablets, so the whole day is a testament to the "power" of the second giving of the Torah. See Sfat Emet on Yom Kippur.

  2. The second tablets were given with the 13 Middot Rachamim, which we say repeatedly on Yom Kippur. The Arizal notes that saying them invokes the original mercies of the Second Tablets at their giving. See Pri Etz Chaim, Sha'ar HaSelichot ch. 1. See also Rosh Hashana 17b:

    אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: אִלְמָלֵא מִקְרָא כָּתוּב אִי אֶפְשָׁר לְאוֹמְרוֹ. מְלַמֵּד שֶׁנִּתְעַטֵּף הַקָּב״ה כְּשְׁלִיחַ צִבּוּר וְהֶרְאָה לוֹ לְמשֶׁה סֵדֶר תְּפִלָּה. אָמַר לוֹ: כָּל זְמַן שֶׁיִּשְׂרָאֵל חוֹטְאִין, יַעֲשׂוּ לְפָנַי כַּסֵּדֶר הַזֶּה, וַאֲנִי מוֹחֵל לָהֶם

    Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Were it not explicitly written in the verse, it would be impossible to say this, as it would be insulting to God’s honor. The verse teaches that the Holy One, Blessed be He, wrapped Himself in a prayer shawl like a prayer leader and showed Moses the structure of the order of the prayer. He said to him: Whenever the Jewish people sin, let them act before Me in accordance with this order. Let the prayer leader wrap himself in a prayer shawl and publicly recite the thirteen attributes of mercy, and I will forgive them. [Steinsaltz annotated translation/commentary]

  3. We do note in our Mishna that Yom Kippur's joy is associated with the second giving of the Tablets and the meal we have on Erev Yom Kippur is directly associated with them. See Taanit 30:

    אָמַר רַבָּן שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן גַּמְלִיאֵל: לֹא הָיוּ יָמִים טוֹבִים לְיִשְׂרָאֵל כַּחֲמִשָּׁה עָשָׂר בְּאָב וּכְיוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים. בִּשְׁלָמָא יוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים — מִשּׁוּם דְּאִית בֵּיהּ סְלִיחָה וּמְחִילָה, יוֹם שֶׁנִּיתְּנוּ בּוֹ לוּחוֹת הָאַחֲרוֹנוֹת

    § The mishna taught that Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: There were no days as happy for the Jewish people as the fifteenth of Av and as Yom Kippur. The Gemara asks: Granted, Yom Kippur is a day of joy because it has the elements of pardon and forgiveness, and moreover, it is the day on which the last pair of tablets were given. [Steinsaltz annotated translation/commentary]

tl;dr: They are only implicitly mentioned due to the principle of the importance of modesty, which is how they were given. Despite their giving being a monumental event, nonetheless the Giving of the Torah in general is celebrated on Shavuot, and here the theme is actually forgiveness and atonement, and this power does indeed come from their giving.

title: Who is the servant in Isaiah 49:5?
content:
# Who is the servant in Isaiah 49:5? ## Frage

Isaiah 49:1-6:

שִׁמְע֤וּ אִיִּים֙ אֵלַ֔י וְהַקְשִׁ֥יבוּ לְאֻמִּ֖ים מֵרָח֑וֹק יְהֹוָה֙ מִבֶּ֣טֶן קְרָאָ֔נִי מִמְּעֵ֥י אִמִּ֖י הִזְכִּ֥יר שְׁמִֽי׃

Listen, O coastlands, to me, And give heed, O nations afar: GOD appointed me before I was born, Naming me while I was in my mother’s womb.

וַיָּ֤שֶׂם פִּי֙ כְּחֶ֣רֶב חַדָּ֔ה בְּצֵ֥ל יָד֖וֹ הֶחְבִּיאָ֑נִי וַיְשִׂימֵ֙נִי֙ לְחֵ֣ץ בָּר֔וּר בְּאַשְׁפָּת֖וֹ הִסְתִּירָֽנִי׃

My mouth was made to be like a sharpened blade, While I was hidden in the shadow of a divine hand, So that I was like a polished arrow— Concealed in God’s quiver.

וַיֹּ֥אמֶר לִ֖י עַבְדִּי־אָ֑תָּה יִשְׂרָאֵ֕ל אֲשֶׁר־בְּךָ֖ אֶתְפָּאָֽר׃

And [God] said to me, “You are My servant, Israel in whom I glory.”

וַאֲנִ֤י אָמַ֙רְתִּי֙ לְרִ֣יק יָגַ֔עְתִּי לְתֹ֥הוּ וְהֶ֖בֶל כֹּחִ֣י כִלֵּ֑יתִי אָכֵן֙ מִשְׁפָּטִ֣י אֶת־יְהֹוָ֔ה וּפְעֻלָּתִ֖י אֶת־אֱלֹהָֽי׃ {ס}

I thought, “I have labored in vain, I have spent my strength for empty breath.” But my case rested with GOD, My recompense was in the hands of my God.

וְעַתָּ֣ה ׀ אָמַ֣ר יְהֹוָ֗ה יֽוֹצְרִ֤י מִבֶּ֙טֶן֙ לְעֶ֣בֶד ל֔וֹ לְשׁוֹבֵ֤ב יַֽעֲקֹב֙ אֵלָ֔יו וְיִשְׂרָאֵ֖ל (לא) [ל֣וֹ] יֵאָסֵ֑ף וְאֶכָּבֵד֙ בְּעֵינֵ֣י יְהֹוָ֔ה וֵאלֹהַ֖י הָיָ֥ה עֻזִּֽי׃

And now GOD has resolved— The One who formed me in the womb to be of service— To bring back Jacob And restore Israel. And I have been honored in the sight of GOD, My God has been my strength.

וַיֹּ֗אמֶר נָקֵ֨ל מִֽהְיוֹתְךָ֥ לִי֙ עֶ֔בֶד לְהָקִים֙ אֶת־שִׁבְטֵ֣י יַעֲקֹ֔ב (ונצירי) [וּנְצוּרֵ֥י] יִשְׂרָאֵ֖ל לְהָשִׁ֑יב וּנְתַתִּ֙יךָ֙ לְא֣וֹר גּוֹיִ֔ם לִהְי֥וֹת יְשׁוּעָתִ֖י עַד־קְצֵ֥ה הָאָֽרֶץ׃ {ס}

And [God] has said: “It is too little that you should be My servant In that I raise up the tribes of Jacob And restore the survivors of Israel: I will also make you a light of nations, That My salvation may reach the ends of the earth.”

כֹּ֣ה אָֽמַר־יְהֹוָה֩ גֹּאֵ֨ל יִשְׂרָאֵ֜ל קְדוֹשׁ֗וֹ לִבְזֹה־נֶ֜פֶשׁ לִמְתָ֤עֵֽב גּוֹי֙ לְעֶ֣בֶד מֹשְׁלִ֔ים מְלָכִים֙ יִרְא֣וּ וָקָ֔מוּ שָׂרִ֖ים וְיִֽשְׁתַּחֲו֑וּ לְמַ֤עַן יְהֹוָה֙ אֲשֶׁ֣ר נֶאֱמָ֔ן קְדֹ֥שׁ יִשְׂרָאֵ֖ל וַיִּבְחָרֶֽךָּ׃ {ס}

Thus said GOD, The Redeemer of Israel, his Holy One, To the despised one, To the abhorred nations, To the slave of rulers: Kings shall see and stand up; Nobles, and they shall prostrate themselves— To the honor of GOD, who is faithful, To the Holy One of Israel who chose you.

I’m having trouble with this passage.

Isaiah 49:1-2 seems to be speaking about Isaiah, who was called by Hashem.

In Isaiah 49:3, Israel is called Hashem’s servant.

Isaiah 49:4-5 seems to fit Isaiah when it says he was called as a servant to bring back Israel.

But then there’s the second part of 49:5 that goes on to say that whoever the “servant” is in 49:5, they are “a light to the nations”. And then 49:6 talks about the nations bowing down to Hashem, possibly bowing to Israel. Is 49:5 talking about Isaiah? I don’t see how he was a light to the nations. It doesn’t seem to be Israel, because whoever it is “restores the survivors of Israel”. 49:6 seems to continue the thought from 49:5, and it almost seems to fit the future Messianic age where the nations bow to Israel. Is 49:5 talking about Moshiach?

This is very confusing because both Israel and Isaiah are called servant here.

Any commentaries on this would be greatly appreciated.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The Malbim explains that the prophet Yeshaya is reflecting on the mission given to him by G-d, which was initially to bring Israel to repentance, a task that appeared unsuccessful. Despite this, he finds consolation in the fact that G-d honoured his effort and recognized the sincerity and effort he put into his mission.

ועתה, מתחיל לבאר איך סבב ה' את פני הדבר שיהיה תועלת ושכר לפעולתו, אומר, ה' אמר לי, ה' אשר יצר אתי מבטן לעבד לו לשובב יעקב אליו, ר"ל הגם שהתכלית אשר בעבורו יצר אותי ה' מבטן לעבד לו, היה מיוחד רק לדבר פרטי ועבודה מיוחדת, שהוא לשובב יעקב אליו בתשובה, וישראל שהם הגדולים שבהם שא"צ להחזירם בתשובה לו יאסף אפעול בתוכחה שיתאספו לו לעבוד אותו באגודה אחת שכם אחד, זה היה עקר עבודתי שיחד ה' לי מעת יצירתי, ובעבודה הזאת אמרתי כי לריק יגעתי כי לא השלמתיה כי ישראל לא שבו אל ה' ולא שמעו לתוכחתי, מ"מ אחר כי ואכבד בעיני ה', אחר שנכבדתי בעיני ה' ע"י שראה רוב ההשתדלות והיגיעה שהיה לי, ואלהי היה עזי על ידי מעשי הטובים

Now, he begins to explain how Hashem orchestrated the outcome of the matter so that there would be benefit and reward for his actions. He says, "Hashem said to me, the Lord who formed me from the womb to be His servant, to bring Jacob back to Him."

This means that although the purpose for which G-d formed me from the womb to serve Him was specifically for a particular task - a unique work, which was to bring back Jacob to Him in repentance - Israel, who are the great ones among them, do not require such repentance. He will gather them together through rebuke, so that they will unite to serve Him in one assembly, with one heart.

This was the essential work that Hashem assigned to me from the moment of my creation. And regarding this task, I said that I had labored in vain, because I did not complete it, as Israel did not return to G-d and did not listen to my rebuke.

Nevertheless, after being honoured in the eyes of Hashem, after He saw the great effort and toil I had put forth, my G-d became my strength through my good deeds.

Similarly, note the Metzudos Dovid there:

ועתה אמר ה׳ וכו׳. ר״ל ה׳ אשר מבטן יצר אותי להיות לו לעבד ללכת בשליחותו אמר לי עתה להשיב אליו את יעקב בתשובה ובעבור זה אהיה נכבד בעיני ה׳ ואף היה חזקי לבל יוכלו הרשעים להרע לי וכאומר כאשר חשב באחרונה כן אמר לי ה׳ שאף אם לא אועיל אהיה נכבד בעיניו וכן היה לי למעוז ולחוזק

"And now, says G-d...": This means that Hashem, who formed me from the womb to be His servant and to carry out His mission, now tells me to return Jacob to Him through repentance. Because of this mission, I will be honoured in the eyes of G-d. Moreover, He will strengthen me so that the wicked will not be able to harm me.

In other words, even if I do not succeed in my mission, Hashem tells me that I will still be honoured in His eyes. And indeed, He became my refuge and strength.

title: Conjoined animals in halacha
content:
# Conjoined animals in halacha ## Frage

Are there any special halachot for conjoined animals? For examples slaughtering a kosher animal which has 2 heads and necks, is it possible? If so, how can it be done correctly according to halacha? May a siamese calf be used for eglah arufa?

Are there any general parameters for dealing with conjoined animals in halacha?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

I came across this piece here from Rabbi Reuven Chaim Klein which explores principally the notion of Siamese twins as it pertains to marriage.

On page 266 he introduces psakim from Rabbi Yisrael Yaakov Chagiz. On page 267 he brings the case of conjoined chickens...

QUESTION: In Verona, they showed two chicks that were attached from the side. It appears that they came from two different egg yolks. They had two heads, two necks, four feet, and both heads were able to eat. What is [the halachic status of this chicken (i.e. may it be eaten and how)]?

ANSWER: It is a creature from the Six Days of Creation. According to the opinion that Adam was created thusly35 [i.e. Adam and his partner originally formed one back-to-back person], the other animals of creation were also possibly created so.36 If they [the chickens] live for twelve months, you may37 slaughter both heads like one (so as not to [invalidate the slaughtering by way of] waiting [in the middle of slaughtering]) [and the chicks may be eaten].38

35 Eruvin 18a

36 R. Yosef Engel (Gilyonei ha-Shas to Berachot 61a) cites the commentary of Chizkuni (to Gen. 2:23) who explicitly writes that only man was created thusly, while other animals were not. In R. Engel’s assessment, this passage offsets R. Chagiz’s supposition.

37 See Shut Shaar ha-Zekenim, Beit Milo §19 who disagrees with R. Chagiz and rules that an animal with two heads is considered a treifah and may not be eaten. See also Darkei Teshuvah (Yoreh Deah §50:16) regarding such an animal.

38 Halachot Ketanot (vol. 1, §249)

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

in the simla chadasha and in SA it says an animal with 2 spines is a treifa. SA YD 13:6

SA YD 13:6

השוחט את הבהמה ומצא בה בריה שיש לה שני גבין ושני שדראות אסור:

Seif 6 If after slaughtering an animal we find (a fetus) that has two backs and two spines it is not permitted.

title: Why is a Jewish man not allowed to marry his ex-wife after she was married to somebody else and divorced from the second person?
content:
# Why is a Jewish man not allowed to marry his ex-wife after she was married to somebody else and divorced from the second person? ## Frage

Why is a Jewish man not allowed to marry his ex-wife after she was married to somebody else and divorced from the second person- while, at the same time, if she had liaisons with other men without the benefit of marriage it seems that she can remarry her husband?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

The Sforno explains that this would basically allow the practice of wife swapping so the Torah prohibits it:

כי תועבה היא. כי זה דרך מבוא לנאוף שיגרש איש את אשתו לבקשת הנואף שיקחנה לאיזה זמן וישוב בעלה הראשון לקחתה

because this is a sure recipe leading to legalised adultery, people marrying for short periods of time, and then legally swapping wives by going through phony but legally correct divorce procedures

It would seem that the main reason for the prohibition is the legality of it, when a divorced woman has illicit relations without marriage, that isn’t legal and isn’t included in this prohibition.

title: Who is Rabbi Chizkiya in the Beginning of the Zohar?
content:
# Who is Rabbi Chizkiya in the Beginning of the Zohar? ## Frage

BH

In the beginning of the Zohar there is a rabbi mentioned named Rabbi Chizkiya 1. Who is he? Is this the same Chizkiya who is mentioned inside this Introduction to the Talmud book by Art Scroll here? If not who is he?

Sources 1 Zohar רִבִּי חִזְקִיָּה פָּתַח, כְּתִיב, (שיר השירים ב׳:ב׳) (פנחס רלג, ופ' תשא קפט) כְּשׁוֹשַׁנָּה בֵּין הַחוֹחִים. מָאן שׁוֹשַׁנָּה, דָּא כְּנֶסֶת יִשְׂרָאֵל.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

That Artscroll Talmud volume specifically focuses on a subset of Tannaim and Amoraim who appear in Talmud Bavli, but there are other such Sages.

A good resource for Tannaitic / Amoraic biography, Toledot Tannaim veAmoraim by Rav Aharon Hyman, which is available at HebrewBooks, or now mostly digitized online (with a few OCR errors here and there). Looking for Chizkiya (or, rather, searching in Hebrew on Google for חזקיא תולדות תנאים ואמוראים, we are brought to the main Chizkiyah entry. This Sage is the son of the transitional Tanna/Amora, Rabbi Chiyya, and does not have the title "Rabbi", so say that he is approximately a first-generation Amora.

As a separate entry, he has Rabbi Chizkiyah (note the rabbinic title) of the Zohar. Other entries for the name Chizkiyah follow, of later scholastic generations. Namely, there is a Rabbi Chizkiyah who is a fourth-generation Amora of the Land of Israel, Chizkiyah Ish Ikesh in Tannaitic times who testified before the later Rabban Gamliel of Yavneh about the practices of Rabban Gamliel the Elder, Chizkiyah the brother of Hillel the Nasi, Chizkiyah bar Biltoi who spoke before the Amora Rabbi Abahu, Chizkiyah ben Guryon, and the list goes on and on.

In the Rabbi Chizkiyah of the Zohar entry, we might be able to intuit why Rav Hyman did not just say that these first two Sages were the same person. He collects interactions with other Sages. So, for instance, Chizkiyah of the Zohar has to travel with the fifth-generation Tanna Rabbi Yehuda (elsewhere, Rabbi Yossi) to visit the fifth generation Tanna Rabbi Shimon. He also learned from Rav Yeiva Sava (the Tanna), who is a different entry than the Talmudic Rav Yeiva Sava (the Amora). These Zoharic interactions might not be consistent with the interactions we would see for the Talmudic Sage, so we might assume that we are either speaking about a different Sage.

title: A coherent view of Adam and the Serpent
content:
# A coherent view of Adam and the Serpent ## Frage

I was debating with Biblical literalists, and I struggled to present a coherent view of Genesis 3.

  1. It starts with "וְהַנָּחָשׁ הָיָה עָרוּם מִכֹּל חַיַּת הַשָּׂדֶה" ("And the serpent was the shrewdest of all the wild beasts), meaning that it was one of its species.
  2. Adam named all the field animals, knowing their nature.
  3. According to Yevamos 63a, Adam knew all [kinds of] animals intimately.
  4. Ergo, Adam met the Serpent and knew its nature.

I was confused here — if Adam had known the Serpent's evil intentions, I suppose he would have acted accordingly. Since he didn't, and given the sages' respect for his wisdom, I can only think that, in fact, the Serpent's nature was to tell the truth:

"And the serpent said to the woman, 'You are not going to die, but God knows that as soon as you eat of it your eyes will be opened and you will be like divine beings who know good and bad.'”

Is there a source that reconciles the Biblical verses with rabbinic Midrashim in a non-contradicting way?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

At face value, Adam may have known all the animals and their nature, but we have no evidence that Chava had any of this knowledge. The Serpent convinced/tricked Chava who in turn caused Adam to sin. There is no indication that Adam had any interaction with the Serpent during this episode.

Bereishis Rabbah 19:3 discusses Adam's whereabouts during this episode

וַתֹּאמֶר הָאִשָּׁה אֶל הַנָּחָשׁ (בראשית ג, ב), וְהֵיכָן הָיָה אָדָם בְּאוֹתָהּ שָׁעָה, אַבָּא בַּר קוֹרְיָיה אָמַר נִתְעַסֵּק בְּדֶרֶךְ אֶרֶץ וְיָשַׁן לוֹ. רַבָּנָן אַמְרֵי נְטָלוֹ הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא וְהֶחֱזִירוֹ בְּכָל הָעוֹלָם כֻּלּוֹ, אָמַר לוֹ כָּאן בֵּית נֶטַע, כָּאן בֵּית זֶרַע, הֲדָא הוּא דִכְתִיב (ירמיה ב, ו): בְּאֶרֶץ לֹא עָבַר בָּהּ אִישׁ וְלֹא יָשַׁב אָדָם שָׁם, לֹא יָשַׁב אָדָם הָרִאשׁוֹן שָׁם.

“The woman said to the serpent: From the fruit of the trees of the garden we may eat” (Genesis 3:2). “The woman said to the serpent” – where was Adam at that time? Abba bar Korya said: He had engaged in the way of nature and he was sleeping. The Rabbis say: The Holy One blessed be He was taking him and circulating throughout the entire world [telling him]: ‘This is a good place to plant, this is a good place to sow.’ That is what is written: “In a land that no man has ever crossed, and where no person [adam] has ever dwelled” (Jeremiah 2:6) – Adam the first man did not dwell there.

Pirkei DeRebbi Eliezer 13:5 dicusses the Serpents plan

דָּן דִּין נָחָשׁ בֵּינוֹ לְבֵין עַצְמוֹ וְאָמַר: אִם הוֹלֵךְ אֲנִי וְאוֹמֵר לְאָדָם, יוֹדֵעַ אֲנִי שֶׁאֵינוֹ שׁוֹמֵעַ לִי, שֶׁהָאִישׁ לְעוֹלָם קָשֶׁה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְהָאִישׁ רַע מַעֲלָלִים״. אֶלָּא הוֹלֵךְ אֲנִי וְאוֹמֵר לְחַוָּה, שֶׁהָאִשָּׁה שֶׁאֲנִי יוֹדֵעַ שֶׁהִיא שׁוֹמַעַת לִי, שֶׁהַנָּשִׁים נִשְׁמָעוֹת לְכָל הַבְּרִיּוֹת, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״פְּתַיּוּת וּבַל יָדְעָה מָּה״.

The serpent argued with itself, saying: If I go and speak to Adam, I know that he will not listen to me, for a man is always hard (to be persuaded), as it is said, "For a man is churlish and evil in his doings" (1 Sam. 25:3); but behold I will speak to Eve, for I know that she will listen to me; for women listen to all creatures, as it is said, "She is simple and knoweth nothing" (Prov. 9:18).

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

The problem with most interpretations is that they don't ask the questions the text asks. Such as: How does the snake know what the tree of knowledge will do to Eve?

I think most people accept the idea of the snake being Satan because it kind of answers that question by writing it off as secret knowledge by the adversary. This answer is not very satisfying.

I believe the only way to understand this story is to read it literally and without putting any religious notions on it whether you are Jewish, Christian, or Muslim. I think we often make the mistake of not letting the Torah worldbuild because we're too preoccupied looking for lofty spiritual answers. I think if you let the logic of the text flow then the story is quite understandable but possibly not religiously satisfying to anyone.

Josephus and Jubilees both state that all animals spoke one language with humans in the beginning. Jubilees makes the claim this ability was lost after Adam ate from the Tree. Abarbanel in his commentary to Genesis 3:1 says that the snake never spoke. Because the Torah lists punishments and taking away speech was not listed and it's the only one really worth mentioning. His answer seems to be addressing and defeating Jubilees and Josephus. But a rare book of tosafot collections called Moshav Zekenim says that the universal language that all life spoke was lost when all languages were confused in the Tower of Babel story. Which means that all animals spoke in the garden of eden story, the noahs ark story (I mean just logistically doesn't that story make so much more sense if all the animals and humans could talk to each other?), all the way up til the tower of Babel. This also explains why the Bible doesn't say God had to open the mouth of the snake to talk, but had to open the mouth of the donkey because it happens after the tower of Babel.

We don't know if Abarbanel knew of this opinion from Moshav Zekeinim but he offers a fascinating alternative to talking animals that I argue answers the question of how the snake knows what the fruit does.

According to Abarbanel Eve saw the serpent eat from the tree of knowledge day after day and it wasn't dying, which is what God told Adam would happen. From there the Torah is basically reflecting her inner monologue and she convinces herself the fruit looks good to eat. But Abarbanel still doesn't answer how the Serpent or Eve know what the tree does because God never says what it does, only that on the day the human eats of it he will surely die.

I think Abarbanel is correct, the snake does eat the fruit day after day, and that's why the snake knows what the fruit does: because it did it to him. This also explains why there's wordplay with Arum/Nakedness happening.

Genesis 2:25-3:8 (Abridged)

וַיִּֽהְי֤וּ שְׁנֵיהֶם֙ עֲרוּמִּ֔ים הָֽאָדָ֖ם וְאִשְׁתּ֑וֹ וְלֹ֖א יִתְבֹּשָֽׁשׁוּ׃

The two of them were naked/arumim, the Human and his wife,

yet they felt no shame.

וְהַנָּחָשׁ֙ הָיָ֣ה עָר֔וּם מִכֹּל֙ חַיַּ֣ת הַשָּׂדֶ֔ה אֲשֶׁ֥ר עָשָׂ֖ה יְהֹוָ֣ה אֱלֹהִ֑ים וַיֹּ֙אמֶר֙ אֶל־הָ֣אִשָּׁ֔ה אַ֚ף כִּֽי־אָמַ֣ר אֱלֹהִ֔ים לֹ֣א תֹֽאכְל֔וּ מִכֹּ֖ל עֵ֥ץ הַגָּֽן׃

Now the serpent was the shrewdest/arum of all the wild beasts that God יהוה had made. It said to the woman, “Did God really say: You shall not eat of any tree of the garden?”

.... וַתִּפָּקַ֙חְנָה֙ עֵינֵ֣י שְׁנֵיהֶ֔ם וַיֵּ֣דְע֔וּ כִּ֥י עֵֽירֻמִּ֖ם הֵ֑ם וַֽיִּתְפְּרוּ֙ עֲלֵ֣ה תְאֵנָ֔ה וַיַּעֲשׂ֥וּ

לָהֶ֖ם חֲגֹרֹֽת׃

Then the eyes of both of them were opened and they perceived that they were naked/arum; and they sewed together fig leaves and made themselves loincloths.

The serpent knowing good from evil helps explain why he's Arum/Naked just like Adam and Eve become at the end of the story. It also explains how it was able to have the moral nuance to sway Eve with a single question and be punished by God as if an animal can be held morally responsible. It also explains how the donkey was able to plead a moral case against Balaam for striking her instead of knowing her better from a shared history together.

I think the deeper message of the story is that the tree of knowledge makes you believe you know right from wrong. This knowledge is apparently allowed to God and animals, but not to humans. Something apparently really bad will happen if we believe we know right from wrong. Narratively it's not a shock when the next story is brothers killing each other and God has to wipe out humanity less than 10 chapters later. It seems the Torah was spot on: us believing we know right from wrong made really bad things happen.

All this to say, the story is really about a snake who wanted to lead Eve astray. And it really just talked to her. And the story is more about how unified all life was, how the tree of life was offered to everyone unless humans ate from the tree of knowledge. Because can you imagine if the generation of Noah, the generation God had to wipe out, could live forever?

title: What happened to Jephthah's daughter?
content:
# What happened to Jephthah's daughter? ## Frage

You know the story. Jephthah, before going into battle, promises to God as a burnt offering the first thing that comes out of his house to meet him. God gives him victory, he comes home, his only daughter runs out to meet him, and... what?

I'm aware of two interpretations (in Christian circles):

  • "burnt offering" means that something is dedicated in entirety to God. Jephthah's daughter was dedicated to serving God and remained a virgin.
  • Jephthah made a foolish vow and foolishly carried it out. He should have gone to a priest to be released from his vow. Instead, he committed the crime of human sacrifice.

The question: what do Jewish sources say on the topic? Is there a debate between the two versions above (or a third option?) among Jewish commentators, and which (if either) is generally accepted?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Ibn Ezra and the Radak suggest that Jephthah meant that the first thing to come out the door would be sacrificed only if it was an “appropriate” creature. But if so, why were Jephthah and his daughter so worked up about the vow? Because, if a sacrifice wasn’t “appropriate”, the creature would still have to be consecrated to God. So the daughter had to seclude herself in a house outside the city, in nun-like fashion.

Later medieval commentators (such as Abravanel, Gersonides, or Malbim) agreed that Jephthah only consecrated his daughter to God as a virgin. Indeed, the Bible says: “And he did to her as he had vowed. She had never known a man.” Why add that last comment? It must be because it is relevant. However, asceticism and lifelong virginity are not encouraged in Judaism.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

Ramban says that he made a mistake and sacrificed her. He also quotes ibn Ezra that he dedicated her to God and never allowed her to marry or mingle with people, censuring it.

And this was the mistake that Jephthah made with his daughter. For he thought that just as a cheirem ["doomed" object] of the chief of Israel is valid and takes effect to put [certain] people to death, and [also] anyone who transgresses it is liable to the death-penalty, so [Jephthah thought] that if he uttered a vow at a time of war, to make an offering of a certain person or persons, the vow is valid; but he did not know that a cheirem declared by the king and Sanhedrin is valid [only] regarding the destruction of rebels, or against one who transgresses their decrees and ordinances. But that a vow should take effect to make a burnt-offering of something not appropriate for G-d, [as Jephthah thought] — Heaven forbid! Therefore the Rabbis have said in Bereshith Rabbah that [Jephthah] was not even obliged to pay the price of her market-value to the Temple treasury [as his vow was totally invalid], and he was punished for her [innocent] blood!

Now do not let yourself be misled by Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra's empty words, when he says that the meaning of the expression and I will offer it up for a burnt-offering is "or I will offer it up," as if to say: "if that which comes forth of the doors of my house be a man or woman, that person shall be holy to G-d, inasmuch as he will abstain from the ways of the world, to stand to minister in the Name of the Eternal in prayer and thanksgiving to G-d; but if it be something fit for an offering, I will make it a burnt-offering." Accordingly [Ibn Ezra's interpretation continues, since Jephthah's daughter was the first to come out to meet her father], he built her a house outside the city where she resided in seclusion, and he provided her with sustenance all her days, and no man knew her, so that his daughter remained shut away [from the world all her life].

All this are words of emptiness. For if he vowed that [whatsoever comes forth of the door of his house] shall be the Eternal's, this does not mean that he should be a recluse [from the world], but instead he is to be like Samuel, of whom his mother said, and I shall give him unto the Eternal, and he was a servant in the House of G-d, not a recluse. And according to the ordinances of the Torah, no man can utter a vow which will bind the persons who come out of the door of his house to live thereafter in seclusion, just as he cannot bring them as an offering. And if the matter be so [as Ibn Ezra put it] then Jephthah's daughter would be bewailing her virginity with her companions with her, like harlots enhancing their hire! Heaven forbid that this be a custom in Israel, to lament the daughter of Jephthah the Gileadite four days in a year because she did not marry and she worshipped G-d in purity! Rather, this whole subject is to be understood in its plain meaning [that Jephthah actually brought her as an offering], and his mistake was as I have explained.

title: The practice of Jews keeping dogs
content:
# The practice of Jews keeping dogs ## Frage

Do the verses (Ex 11.7) "But not a dog shall snarl at any of the Israelites, at human or beast..." and (Ex 22.30) "you must not eat flesh torn by beasts in the field; you shall cast it to the dogs..." imply that the Jews in Egypt owned/kept dogs?

What do Jewish sources tell us about the use or domestication of dogs in Biblical or rabbinic times? How common was the practice?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

There are many laws about dogs, such as feeding them the meat of dead animals. Dogs eating human fecal matter on the Sabbath. How and when dangerous dogs must be chained, how to deal with guard dogs and much more. So it seems fairly common as an almost work animal, but as a pet, they seem to dissuade raising non Kosher animals. There is also talk of a dogs dedication to man and Ben Yehoyada notes in the name of the sages that Kelev is a contraction of Kuloi Lev = All heart.(Horayot 13a)

An interesting tidbit is in Talmud Eruvin 81a where it mentions the Amorah Shmuel feeding Ezekiel bread to HIS dog, not A dog.

אָמַר רַב חִיָּיא בַּר אָבִין אָמַר רַב: מְעָרְבִין בְּפַת עֲדָשִׁים. אִינִי?! וְהָא הָהִיא דַּהֲוַאי בִּשְׁנֵי דְּמָר שְׁמוּאֵל, וְשַׁדְיַיהּ לְכַלְבֵּיהּ וְלָא אַכְלַהּ!
Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin said that Rav said: One may establish an eiruv with lentil bread. The Gemara raises a difficulty: Is that so? Is such bread edible? But there was that lentil bread in the days of Mar Shmuel, which he threw to his dog, and even it would not eat it. Clearly, lentil bread is not fit for human consumption.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

It is related that when Dovid HaMelech was niftar on a hot Shabbos day that dogs which he owned were locked up to protect him from them. I know that I read this- but perhaps someone can bring the source as I don't remember it.

title: Are soulmates in a relationship that lasts forever
content:
# Are soulmates in a relationship that lasts forever ## Frage

Is a soulmate just a helper for this life, or does the Kabbalah or the Zohar etc. say the union is bound together even in heaven, meaning a relationship that lasts forever?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Soulmates are two halves (or parts) of the same soul, and are absolutely formed in heaven, and indeed, remain together post-resurrection in Olam Haba (unless they divorce of course). This fact is recognised in Kabbalah and even some areas of Halacha:

Kabbalah sources:

Quotes from Zohar chapters 30 & 32, I 91a onwards:

All the figures of souls that are to be born stand before God in pairs.

When their time of marriage arrives... God... joins them as at first, and proclaims their union. Thus when they are joined they become one body and one soul, right and left in unison, and in this way 'there is nothing new under the sun'.

Happy are the righteous whose souls are beatified before the Holy King before they come into this world... all souls are formed into pairs of male and female, and thus united.

When God sends souls into the world they are formed into pairs of male and female, and thus united... After that they are separated, and subsequently taken down among mankind … When their time of marriage arrives... He joins them as at first.

See this answer: https://judaism.stackexchange.com/a/149861/31534

Chesed LeAvraham 2:65 discusses the ins and outs of destined matches and how they can be "lost forever" and what to do to avoid that, so they can indeed be forever.

See this Torah.org page which brings practically the entire teachings of the Arizal on soul mates: https://torah.org/torah-portion/perceptions-5765-chayeisarah/

Halacha sources:

Moed Katan 18b discusses halachot related to zivugim, although it doesn't explicitly discuss them being eternal. It does frame them as set in heaven before birth, which as we know from above is because they are two halves of the same soul.

The following halachot discuss who a wife will reunite with if her first husband dies and she remarries, after resurrection:

Hagahot Yad Sha’ul (YD 366:3) – “a woman will reunite with her second husband after the resurrection.”

Zera Emet, YD 146, etc. – if she had children with both, she reunites with her first husband in Heaven.

Piskei Teshuva 124 (per Rav Aviner’s reading) – a wife is reunited with the first husband, unless the second marriage was more distinctly successful.

Chatam Sofer – second marriage can nullify the prior bond (post-resurrection).

See this question and its sources: Soul mates, death and remarriage - who will we spend eternity with?

(I partially utilised ChatGPT to check the answers that I quoted to distil the information from them, and then proofed it before posting this answer)

### ✅ Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

וְהָאָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: אַרְבָּעִים יוֹם קוֹדֶם יְצִירַת הַוָּלָד, בַּת קוֹל יוֹצֵאת וְאוֹמֶרֶת ״בַּת פְּלוֹנִי לִפְלוֹנִי״

title: Medieval criticism of Rambam's program of providing reasons for the commandments
content:
# Medieval criticism of Rambam's program of providing reasons for the commandments ## Frage

Rambam spends a large part of the third section of the guide giving reasons for the commandments in line with his rationalist outlook.

There are Rishonim that weren't pleased with some of the reasons given (e.g., for korbanos).

I'm not looking for that.

Should it exist, as I seem to recall it does, I'm looking for explicit criticism by rishonim of his entire project of rationalizing the mitzvos.

Specifically, that anchoring them in human reason may lead to their neglect should people decide that a given mitzvah's reason isn't applicable to them or should societal norms change rendering a given mitzvah irrelevant based on Maimonides' rationale.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

As far as I know, there is no criticism of the concept of giving reasons for the commandments as such, but there are views that are arguably opposed to details of the Rambam's program. As in the view that it's better to accept the mitzvot without investigating the reasons, and discovering the reasons is only the second best option (Kuzari 2:26). Or the view that the mitzvot are intended to bring about a spiritual benefit (הענין האלהי) rather than a worldly benefit (Ran, Derashot 11). Or the tendency to offer symbolic reasons instead of practical ones (as far as I can tell this is a tendency, not that anyone has actually claimed all the mitzvot are explicable only by mystical reasons and none by rational reasons; the Rambam also sometimes gives symbolic reasons, e.g. More Nevuchim 3:46).

As far as I know, the view that there are no reasons for the commandments doesn't exist among the Rishonim. This has been claimed, so it might be worth explaining the reason why I don't think it's correct. Lorberbaum believes that there was opposition to giving reasons for the commandments in the Rambam's time, based on his description in More Nevuchim 3:31 of people who would prefer that there would be no reason at all for the mitzvot (והטוב אצלם שלא יושכל למצוה ולאזהרה ענין כלל). This seems to me to be a misreading, because firstly, the Rambam is describing a feeling or tendency, but not an articulated theory (חלי שימצאוהו בנפשם ולא יוכלו להגות בו ולא ידעו לומר אותו). Secondly, the Rambam says that the view that the mitzvot have a reason is the opinion of all Jews (More Nevuchim 3:31). Apparently then this view is insignificant enough to be excluded from "all Jews," if he meant it was a Jewish view at all. However, he also quotes the Rambam's commentators, such as Narboni, who identify this view with that of "religious people" (תוריים), which is more likely to be an actual Jewish view, but apparently not a view that has come down to us from a proponent.

Lorberbaum also wants to identify this view that the mitzvot are unknowable with that of the Tur, and suggests that the Tur is possibly concerned that offering reasons for the commandments based on historical context (as the Rambam does in this case) would lead to disrespect towards the prohibitions (p. 40). Again both claims seem to me to be a misreading, since (1) the Tur, in one particular context, razing the beard, doesn't accept the Rambam's speculative reason that this was an idolatrous practice, and falls back to saying we don't need to know the reason, and no epistemological or pragmatic claim is being made at all. (2) If any general criticism is intended, then rather than speculatively positing a hitherto-unknown anti-reason community, it would be much more straightforward to identify the Tur's brief rejection with some known criticism of historical reasons, as that of the Ramban (a big influence on the Tur) in his commentary. (3) The Tur himself, in his (long) Torah commentary, does offer a practical reason. (4) This is also, as Fred notes in the comments to the question, the kind of thing that the Rambam himself says (Hilchot Meila 8:8, Hilchot Temura 4:13), and isn't expressing general opposition to finding reasons for commandments. If anything it should be read as an affirmation of the Rambam's approach, which he's only repeating as a commonplace.

There was very fierce controversy surrounding the Rambam in the generation after his death (even leading up to some of his books being burned). Some of the controversy involved the character of the mitzvot (it's not clear to me whether this was an issue of obligatoriness or merely of classification, i.e. that the mitzvot are in the same category of things as secular laws). However, as far as I know, none of those involved in the controversy took issue with the Rambam's views on the matter (or if they did they didn't leave behind writings). Typically they took the Rambam as being on their own side and took issue with his interpreters (see for instance קבוצת מכתבים בעניני המחלוקת... letter 7).

title: How come Adam didn't know he's a different species?
content:
# How come Adam didn't know he's a different species? ## Frage

In Bereishit 2:19–20, Adam names all the animals, and Chazal describe this as a display of his wisdom and insight.

At the same time, Sanhedrin 38b and Bereishit Rabbah 18:4 says that Adam even sought a mate among the animals and even attempted relations with them (Yevamot 63a) — until Hashem created Chavah.

If Adam was wise enough to perceive the essence of each creature to name them, why did he not recognize from the beginning that he was fundamentally a different species, requiring a partner of his own kind?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 8)

Like many questions on this site, this is predicated on a misunderstanding of sources, and then asking a question about it. Perhaps part of this is hastiness in not looking at sources, and blindly trusting ChatGPT output.

As far as I can tell:

  • Sanhedrin 38b merely says Adam named the animals
  • Bereishit Rabbah 18:4 (actually, an error for Bereishit Rabba 17:4) merely says that, aside from naming the animals, he saw that the animals were brought in pairs, and then wondered where his pair was.

Neither says that he sought a mate among the animals. (Did ChatGPT 5 hallucinate that these sources said this?)

Yes, one Tanna or Amora in Yevamot 63a, Rabbi Eleazar, interprets a verse that in his (perhaps subsequent) search for a mate, he had intercourse with every animal. The question then becomes -- "I have this specific view of how the world should work, and how an interpretation should be, but -- gasp! -- this Tanna or Amora has a different way of thinking about it. Isn't that strange? Now please account for it, either by acknowledging how wrong he was, or by reinterpreting it to conform with my framework". Sometimes this approach is legitimate, when the premise is readily acceptable. And sometimes is it not so legitimate. Regardless, it leads to dozens of questions being placed in short order, because they are so easy to devise.

Possible answers:

  1. Indeed, Rabbi Eleazar (ben Pedat) or Rabbi Eleazar (ben Shamua) was being silly. What nonsense!
  2. Rabbi Eleazar did not agree with the premise being read into the text that the naming reflected a deep understanding of the essence of each creature. Where do Chazal say this, and is Rabbi Eleazar among those who say it? Not all of Chazal need to agree.
  3. Grouped as it is in Yevamot among a corpus of Rabbi Eleazar statements, and other statements by others, where the theme is the relationship between a husband and wife, that was the import of Rabbi Eleazar's statement. He intended it as a derasha, homiletically, rather than a historical reading of the text.

title: Importance of Adam naming animals
content:
# Importance of Adam naming animals ## Frage

In Bereishit 2:19–20, Adam names the animals. Rashi (to v. 20) notes that he recognized their essence and named them accordingly.

As a simple answer to a child’s “Why is a cow called a cow?”, one might say: “Because Adam named it.” But from a more serious perspective:

  1. What would be the long-standing significance if Adam had chosen different names (e.g., calling a dog מַלְב instead of כֶּלֶב)?
  2. Could Adam have used names already found elsewhere in the Torah (assuming, per midrash, that the Torah pre-existed Creation)?

How would such scenarios affect our understanding of language, Torah, and creation?

title: Suicide or abortion
content:
# Suicide or abortion ## Frage

What is the halacha if (chalilah) a woman who is pregnant threatens suicide if she is not able to have an abortion? Do we allow (or mandate) an abortion? Do we ignore her statement? Another course of action? If the stage of development is a factor in the answer please indicate the differences.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

From Aish:

Judaism recognizes psychiatric as well as physical factors in evaluating the potential threat that the fetus poses to the mother. The degree of mental illness that must be present to justify termination of a pregnancy has been widely debated by rabbinic scholars, without a clear consensus of opinion regarding the exact criteria for permitting abortion in such instances. Nevertheless, all agree that were a pregnancy to cause a woman to become suicidal, there would be grounds for abortion.

title: Knowledge of God in Olam Haba/Olam HaNeshamot
content:
# Knowledge of God in Olam Haba/Olam HaNeshamot ## Frage

In this world, there is room for doubt about the existence of God; it is at least conceivable (chas v’shalom) that there might not be a God. Many classical “proofs” for God — such as Rambam’s mechuyav ha-metziut (Necessary Being), or similar arguments in the Sefer HaIkkarim and in Chassidut — insist that the very concept of God is a logical imperative (notwithstanding the loose use of the word "logical" here, given that Hashem is beyond logic etc.).

My question is: In the future, when the veils of doubt are lifted and God is revealed without question, will that certainty come only from direct experience of His presence, or will it also include the intellectual clarity that His existence is logically necessary?

I think the latter is clearly the case, but I would be glad if there were some explicit source saying so - I'd find it interesting! Please share if you know of one.

(note, I used ChatGPT to copy-edit this question because I found it hard to express clearly)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

From ספר המאמרים תרפ"ה, pg 127 (הבאים ישרש יעקב יציץ ופרח ישראל כו׳):

וזהו ההפרש בחושי הנשמה עצמה בין קודם התלבשותה בגוף לאחר ירידתה והתלבשותה בגוף, דכאשר עודנה למעלה האלקות היא בפשיטות והעולמות הם בהתחדשות, ובירידתה למטה ונתפסת בגוף הנה העולמות הם בפשיטות ואלקות הוא בהתחדשות, ומובן שאינו בערך כלל לכמו שהיתה השגתה תחלה

And this is the difference in the faculties of sensation of the soul itself between before its enclothing in the body and after its descent and enclothing in the body: for when it is still above, Elokus is in peshitus [utter simplicity and obviousness] and the worlds are in his­chadshus [novelty], and in its descent below and its being seized by the body, behold, the worlds are in peshitus and Divinity is in his­chadshus. And it is understood that this is in no comparison at all to how its comprehension originally was.

To the soul's intellectual perception, Hashem's reality is obvious.

title: 14th-18th Centuries Commentaries on Eicha Rabbah
content:
# 14th-18th Centuries Commentaries on Eicha Rabbah ## Frage

I'm looking for commentaries on Eicha Rabbah from the 14th-18th centuries (in print or manuscripts, preferably accessible online). I'm already familiar with Rabbi Shmuel Ashkenazi's Yefeh Anaf, Chida's Kikar La'aden, Rabbi Yissachar Katz's Matnot Kehunah, and Rabbi Naftali Hirtz's commentary (titled simply "פירוש למדרש חמש מגילות"). Are there any others?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

This edition of Eicha Rabbah contains several mefarshim (including all those you mention).

One of those commentaries that fits your timespan is Rabbi Eliyahu Hakohen Itamari the author of Shevet Mussar. He has a commentary entitled V'lo Od Elah. In the standalone sefer (which I have linked) the entry on Eicha Rabbah is not particularly extensive see here, and it would seem that it only focuses on the midrashic instances of the expression "V'lo Od Elah" (hence the title name).

The same sefer above also features the Mishnas Rebbi Eliezer authored by Rabbi Eliezer Yehuda of Pintshov (Pinsk) who lived in the late 17th - early 18th century. (See number 9 on the list of commentaries inside the sefer - on p.2)

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

Adding another commentary: Rabbi Shabtai of Rashkov wrote a relatively concise commentary on Eicha Rabbah (as well as the rest of Midrash Rabbah) called אסיפת אמרים. Rabbi Shabtai lived during the 17th-18th centuries (exact dates unclear; he died in 1765). The commentary was first printed in an edition of Eicha Rabbah published in Mahilyow, ca. 1808-1809 (link), and published again in an edition printed in Lviv, 1849 (link). It is largely (and explicitly so) based on past commentaries.

title: Why did Hashem try killing Moses on his way to Egypt?
content:
# Why did Hashem try killing Moses on his way to Egypt? ## Frage

In Exodus Chapter 4:24, Hashem apparently tries to kill Moses. Why? I am ignorant of how the Israelites would have understood this event, and I want to understand it from the Jewish perspective.

(I apologize if my wording is offensive; it is not my intention to offend anyone with my question.)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

It's complicated. The Mekhilta tells us that Moses promised his father-in-law Jethro that his first son would become an idolater. [Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 18:3] Why? The Midrash says that Jethro first worshipped all existing idols and concluded only God was real [Midrash Tanḥuma, Yitro 7] Rabbi Shim'on Schwab concludes that Jethro wanted a grandson to do as he did: Worship all existing idols and conclude only God was real. This would give him a better appreciation of monotheism. [Mayan Bet Hashoeva on Yitro 18, 4] So Moses at first did not circumcize Gershom, and God threatened to kill him as a result, and his wife Zipporah had to do it in his stead. [Ex. 4:24-26] Moses intentionally did not want Gershom circumcised because of his promise to Jethro.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

Of interest is Rashbam's relevant comments. On the verse in question:

ויפגשהו ה' - המלאך - כי היה מתעצל בהליכתו ומוליך אשתו ובניו.

The LORD encountered him -- [i.e., His] angel -- since Moses was meandered in going, and that he had brought his wife and children along.

The suggestion local to the verse is that Moses' lack of urgency was the cause. However, Rashbam presents a more complex picture elsewhere. Returning to the scene at the bush (Ex. 4:14), he comments

ויחר אף ה' במשה - וחרון אף עשה רושם לפי הפשט כאמור לפנינו: ויפגשהו ה' ויבקש המיתו - כדפירשתי אצל יעקב כשנעשה צולע על יריכו.

The LORD's anger kindled against Moses -- According to the peshat, [God's] anger produces a manifestation as stated later: "Hashem encountered him and sought his death" as I have explained regarding Jacob when his thigh was injured.

Rashbam is implicitly responding to a statement in b. Zevachim 102a (cited by Rashi on our verse) of Rabbi Yehoshua:

רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן קׇרְחָה אוֹמֵר: כׇּל חֲרוֹן אַף שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה נֶאֱמַר בּוֹ רוֹשֶׁם, וְזֶה לֹא נֶאֱמַר בּוֹ רוֹשֶׁם

Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korcha said: For each instance of [God's] anger in the Torah there is recorded a manifestation, but this instance has no such manifestation.

This is challenged by Rabbi Shimon Bar Yochai (in the Bavli, although Rashi quotes Rabbi Yose), who objects:

אַף זֶה נֶאֱמַר בּוֹ רוֹשֶׁם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״הֲלֹא אַהֲרֹן אָחִיךָ הַלֵּוִי״ – וַהֲלֹא כֹּהֵן הוּא! הָכִי קָאָמַר: אֲנִי אָמַרְתִּי אַתָּה כֹּהֵן וְהוּא לֵוִי, עַכְשָׁיו הוּא כֹּהֵן וְאַתָּה לֵוִי.

This, too, has a manifestation, for it says: "Is there not Aaron your brother, the Levite?" but in fact he is a priest! [the Bavli clarifies:] That is to say: I intended you will be the priest and he will be the Levite, now he will be the priest and you will be the Levite.

We see that Rashbam rejects the opinion of both the tanna and Rashi and suggests simply that the "manifestation" of God's anger is delayed until later, at the inn. This is distinct from, but thematically agrees with, Rashbam's local comment in the original verse. The consistent position is that Moses' reticence to return to Egypt and accept his mission provokes God's anger. This position is clarified and distilled when we refer back to the episode of Jacob's injury. There (Gen. 32:29), we find:

וַיֹּ֗אמֶר לֹ֤א יַעֲקֹב֙ יֵאָמֵ֥ר עוֹד֙ שִׁמְךָ֔ כִּ֖י אִם־יִשְׂרָאֵ֑ל כִּֽי־שָׂרִ֧יתָ עִם־אֱלֹהִ֛ים וְעִם־אֲנָשִׁ֖ים וַתּוּכָֽל׃

He [the man] said to him: Your name shall no longer be called Jacob but Israel, for you have striven with God and men and have prevailed.

Rashbam's relevant excerpt:

ומה שלקה יעקב ונצלע, לפי שהקב"ה הבטיחו והוא היה בורח. וכן מצינו בכל ההולכים בדרך שלא ברצון הקב"ה, או ממאנים ללכת שנענשו. במשה כתיב: שלח נא ביד תשלח ויחר אף ה' במשה. ולפי הדרש, אף על פי שאמרו חכמים בכל מקום חרון אף עושה רושם וכאן מה רושם יש? הלא אהרן אחיך הלוי עתיד הוא להיות לוי ואתה כהן ועכשיו הוא יהיה כהן ואתה לוי. אך לפי הפשט: לפי שהיה מתעצל ללכת כתיב: ויהי בדרך במלון ויפגשהו ה' ויבקש המיתו.

The reason that he injured Jacob is that the Holy One promised him [safety], but he had fled [from confronting Esau]. Similarly we find all who travel against the will of the Holy One, or refuse to travel, are punished. Regarding Moses, it is written: "[Moses said,] 'Please, send the one You will send,' and the LORD's anger kindled against Moses." In derash, the Sages said that every instance of [God's] anger has a manifestation, but what manifestation is here? 'Is there not Aaron your brother, the Levite' who would only be a Levite while you become the priest? Now, he will be priest and you will be but the Levite." Nevertheless, in peshat, since Moses was reluctant to go, it is written, "It was on the way in the inn, the LORD encountered him and sought his death".

I want to note that this investigation is prototypical Rashbam. He proposes his own principle, "God punishes those who journey/do not journey against His will", and demonstrates its consistency with many textual examples. In service of this principle, he resolves to his satisfaction a claim of the Sages (all instances of God's anger entail a physical manifestation) that ostensibly fails in one textual instance. But in doing so, he rejects the midrashic interpretation of his grandfather and tannaim themselves! This is quite radical, especially for a rishon.

Nevertheless, I do find this explanation of the inn episode compelling. It neatly resolves the mystery by connecting it to the broader narrative while exposing an important characterization of Moses (and God) in these scenes.

### Antwort 3 (Score: -2)

Completely rational question. Moses had two sons Gershom and Eliezer. Circumcision was done on the 8th day and since Gershom was already born in exodus 2 but no mention of Eliezer. This baby must be Eliezer. God commanded Moses to circumcise his son on the 8th day and Tzipporah refused.

Exodus 4.25 Then Zipporah took a flint, and cut off the foreskin of her son, and cast it at his feet; and she said: 'Surely a bridegroom of blood art thou to me.'26 So He let him alone. Then she said: 'A bridegroom of blood in regard of the circumcision.'

Here we see clearly she was against it. This is the reason they got divorced. So why did God almost kill Moses? I would argue God almost killed the baby to scare Tzipporah because she was against it, where as Moses was all for it. This explains why they got divorced also. And we know the Midianites believed in other gods according to numbers 25.

Exodus 18.11 Now I know that the LORD is greater than all gods; yea, for that they dealt proudly against them.'

Now i know meaning i didn't know before since he worshiped many gods before. Now tzipporah clearly didn't accept the God of Moses as we can tell by her language " a bride groom of blood" .

There is another secret here reguarding the identity of Eliezer and how he became Joshua son of Nun, Moses being Nun. Lets leave that for another discussion.
