title: Were Samson's Women his Metaphorical Jawbones?
content:
# Were Samson's Women his Metaphorical Jawbones? ## Frage

The Talmud in Sota 9b states:

״וַיִּבְקַע אֱלֹהִים אֶת הַמַּכְתֵּשׁ אֲשֶׁר בַּלֶּחִי״. אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק דְּבֵי רַבִּי אַמֵּי: הוּא אִיוָּה לְדָבָר טָמֵא — לְפִיכָךְ נִתְלוּ חַיָּיו בְּדָבָר טָמֵא. After Samson smote one thousand Philistines with the jawbone of a donkey, he called the place Lehi, and God miraculously granted him to drink, as he was dying of thirst. The verse states: “But God cleaved the hollow place that is in Lehi, and out of there came water; and when he had drunk, his spirit came back, and he revived” (Judges 15:19). Rabbi Yitzḥak of the school of Rabbi Ami says: He desired something unclean, as he was driven by lust to Philistine women. Therefore, the saving of his life was dependent on something unclean, the jawbone of a donkey.

Is the above Talmudic piece suggesting that Samson's women were his metaphorical jawbones? In other words, in the same way that he could have fought the Plishtim bare handed with full trust in God, but, instead, chose to sully himself and rely on a dubious externality (a donkey jawbone), he also could have generally fought the Plishtim in another manner (rather than via connecting with various Plishti women)?

I think the Yerushalmi actually suggests this (Sota First Chapter)

וְאָבִיו וְאִמּוֹ לֹא יָדְעוּ כִּי מֵיי הִיא כִּי תוֹאָנָה הוּא מְבַקֵּשׁ מִפְּלִשְׁתִּים. אָמַר רִבִּי לָעְזָר. בְּשִׁבְעָה מְקוֹמוֹת כְּתִיב לֹא תִּתְחַתֵּן בָּם. אָמַר רִבִּי אָבִין. לֶאֱסוֹר שִׁבְעָה עַמָּמִין. וְהָכָא הוּא אָמַר הָכֵין. אָמַר רִבִּי יִצְחָק אִם לַלֵּצִים הוּא יָלִיץ. “And his father and mother did not know that this was from the Eternal, that he was looking for a pretext from the Philistines.” Rebbi Eleazar said, In seven places it is written: “Do not contract marriage with them.” Rebbi Abun said, to prohibit seven peoples. And here, it says so? Rebbi Isaac said, “if he scoffs about the scoffers.”

The Pnei Moshe Explains:

ואת אמר הכין. כי מה' הוא בתמיה: And you say such? That (marrying the Plishti woman) it was from God! (read in astonishment). (Rather the answer is:) אם ללצים הוא יליץ. כתיב דבדרך שאדם רוצה לילך מוליכין אותו: 'With scoffers, He scoffs' it is written. for in the way that a man wants to go, he is led (by God).

Notice it is Rabbi Yitzchak who makes the comment in both Talmuds

title: Devarim vs mitzvot
content:
# Devarim vs mitzvot ## Frage

I am a newcomer to Judaism. When I was younger, it was always emphasised to me that I needed to follow the 10 commandments. But, I've learned that "commandments" in Deut 4/13 may be too strong of a word and, that it's better rendered as sayings/words.

For someone coming from Christendom, what is the difference between the devarim and mitzvot? If I observe the 10 (strictly speaking 7) devarim, does that automatically mean I am also observing the 613 mitzvot?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Welcome to Judaism! Let's clear this up step by step:

Are the 10 Commandments actually the 10 Sayings? What's the difference?

Yes, but they are also commandments. In Hebrew, the word for "commandment" is Mitzva. The reason you heard that they are actually the 10 Sayings is because the name given to the 10 Mitzvas given at Mount Sinai are referred to, in Hebrew, as the 10 Devarim (sometimes referred to as Eser HaDiberot). Devarim = "Sayings/Statements" (and this is generally because we heard them spoken by Hashem and Moses during the Sinai Event). That does not mean that they are not also commandments - they are. They are 10 out of the full 613.

That being said there is interesting discussion regarding the word Mitzva (and even Devarim) in our sources and whether "commandment" is the correct translation. If I were to summarise those discussions in a nutshell, Mitzvas are indeed obligations, but they are also ways of connecting to Hashem (the root of the word Mitzva is both Tzav = command as well as Tzavta = connection). Therefore we should view them as more "obligations in a relationship", similar to all relationships. Every relationship carries with it obligations on both sides, but those obligations should be kept lovingly, and with the intention that they are there to bring the participants in the relationship closer.

If I observe the 10 (strictly speaking 7) does that automatically mean I am also observing the 613 Mitzvot?

I can answer for the 10 but I am not sure about the 7. When it comes to the 10, we say that the 10 Devarim contain all of the other Mitzvot within them (see here: 613 mitzvos in the aseres hadibbros), homiletically. In fact we even say that the 10 Devarim are contained in the first, and in fact, in the first word of the first, and in fact, the first letter of the first. This is, as I said, homiletics. One should not stick to the 10 Devarim and ignore the rest, practically. This homiletical teaching is beautiful and contains many secrets, but practically speaking it just means that if one truly internalises the 10 Devarim, that will lead to them keeping the rest as well, and in some deep way they are all connected to the 10.

That being said, this applies to a Jew. To a Noahide, I am not sure what there is to be said about keeping the 7. We generally hold that the non-Jew is not obligated to keep the 613 (and actually forbidden from keeping some, such as Shabbat - which is included in the 10), and I am unaware of any homiletical interpretations that keeping the 7 is equivalent to keeping the 613, but could be. The 7 bring the non-Jew closer to God and fulfil his obligations to Him, and they do so on their own.

I have provided quite a few links to a reputable, authentic resource for questions on Judaism, to back up and expand on what I've been saying - Chabad.org, who are on top of their game generally speaking. Here are a few others about the Noahide Laws for you to read up on.

https://www.chabad.org/library/article_cdo/aid/62221/jewish/The-7-Noahide-Laws.htm

https://www.chabad.org/library/article_cdo/aid/5559665/jewish/The-Seven-Laws-of-Noah.htm

https://www.chabad.org/library/article_cdo/aid/4157474/jewish/Seven-Laws-for-a-Beautiful-Planet.htm

https://www.chabad.org/kabbalah/article_cdo/aid/380332/jewish/The-Mitzvot-of-Non-Jews.htm

title: Does reading the Judges of Caesarea's formulas as area-based fit the Gemara's flow in Sukkah 8b?
content:
# Does reading the Judges of Caesarea's formulas as area-based fit the Gemara's flow in Sukkah 8b? ## Frage

In Sukkah 8b, the Gemara cites the “Judges of Caesarea” who said: A circle inscribed in a square is one-quarter, a square inscribed in a circle is one-half.

Typically, this is read as a statement about perimeters, but Tosafot already notes difficulties with this reading. So, I was exploring whether perhaps they meant for us to calculate the areas, not the perimeters:

The inscribed circle is ~25% smaller in area than its square (actual value ≈ 21.46%). The inscribed square of that circle is exactly 50% smaller in area than its circumscribing square.

A circle inscribed in a square is [approximately] one-quarter [less than the area of the circumscribing square. While the area of] a square inscribed in a circle is [exactly] one-half [less than the circumscribing square of the circle].

If so, the Gemara could be read as first offering an approximate formula of the Judges (like Rabbi Yochanan’s method) that is “good enough” when it leads to a stringency, alongside their precise one for calculating the area of the internal square of a round sukkah to complement Rabbi Yochanan's imprecise method that utilizes circumference; or even the Gemara's own use of a circle's diameter to calculate the perimeter of the internal square of a round sukkah, Sukkah 8b.

It seems the Gemara may have brought the first saying of the Judges of Caesarea in support of Rabbi Yochanan right after the discussion about how his formula was an acceptable method even though it was imprecise, so long as it resulted in a stringency. It supported him by showing that even the Judges of Caesarea stated that a circle inscribed in a square has an area which is one-quarter less than the area of the external square when it is actually 21.46% less.

That said, the Gemara ends the discussion with bringing the second part of the sayings of the Judges of Caesarea to teach us how to more simply calculate the area of a square inside a circle (round sukkah) without having to use the formulas for circumference or the diagonal of a square for calculating its perimeter. And their formula is also exactly precise.

For example, if you wanted to know if a round sukkah is valid all you need to do is draw a square on the outside of the round sukkah and then measure the length of one side and square it. Afterwards, you know that the area of the square inside the circle is exactly half the area of the external square of that same circle. So, if one side of the external square is 6 amos then the total area of the external square would be 36 amos and the round sukkah would contain an internal square of 18 amos, exactly 50% the external square.

I want to read Gemara 8a like this: This is where R Yochanan was imprecise in his measurement, and his imprecision results in a stringency. [The Gemara then notes for the reader how it knows that an imprecision resulting in a stringency is an acceptable practice and that it had indeed arrived at the proper understanding of R Yochanan’s formula by bringing the following proof:] The Rabbis of Caesarea and some say the Judges of Caesarea… A circle inscribed in a square is one-quarter less… But this [formula also] is not so [exact] for we see that it is not that great [resulting in a stringency].

Therefore, the Judges of Caesarea were correct and the Gemara knew why it was bringing their formulas.

My question: Does this reinterpretation fit the logical flow of the Gemara — or am I forcing the text?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

This is a very niche question as one needs to have learned the sugya in depth to understand it. I happen to have just done so - which attracted me to your question. Your suggestion is mathematically correct, but how does this help R Yochanan? R Yochanan is interested in placing people all across the circumference of the circle - or even if you say he is interested in placing them inside the circle, he would want to fill all of the circle.

In any case, as Tosfot notes, the statement of the Judges of Caesarea don't really help us because they are incorrect, at least as it relates to the circumference of the Sukkah.

What is interesting to note is that the area of the circle going around a 4x4 sukkah is exactly 24 ! If anything, that might have been what R Yochanan meant (problem is the gemara doesn't seem to think this way, but the fact Rashi and Tosfot both allude to areas - while the gemara only speak of circumference - might mean they also explored this)

title: Why is Nedarim in Nashim?
content:
# Why is Nedarim in Nashim? ## Frage

Simple question surprised not asked yet, but why is tractate Nedarim in order Nashim? I am not presuming it has anywhere better to be, but I don't see how it directly connects with Nashim more than other orders.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 8)

The Gemara in Sota 2A mentions this question and gives an answer that it continues from the seventh perek in Kesubos that discusses Nedarim:

וְלִיתְנֵי סוֹטָה, וַהֲדַר לִיתְנֵי נָזִיר! אַיְּידֵי דִּתְנָא כְּתוּבּוֹת וּתְנָא ״הַמַּדִּיר״, תְּנָא נְדָרִים. וְאַיְּידֵי דִּתְנָא נְדָרִים — תְּנָא נָזִיר, דְּדָמֵי לִנְדָרִים. וְקָתָנֵי סוֹטָה, כִּדְרַבִּי.

The Gemara asks: But if so, let him teach tractate Sota first and then let him teach tractate Nazir, which is the way these topics are ordered in the Torah, and also accords better with the statement of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi. The Gemara answers: Since the tanna taught tractate Ketubot, and in that tractate he taught a chapter that begins: One who vows, in which there are several mishnayot concerning vows between husbands and wives, he then taught tractate Nedarim, whose subject is the halakhot of vows. And since he taught tractate Nedarim, he then taught tractate Nazir, which is similar to tractate Nedarim in that one becomes a nazirite by taking a vow. And he then teaches tractate Sota, in accordance with the statement of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi

### Antwort 2 (Score: 3)

As I discuss in this article, Nashim is perhaps not the most accurate title for the Seder. Yes, it captures an aspect of many of the masechtot therein. Yet if that were the sole grouping principle, I would have expected e.g. Niddah in that grouping.

If I had to give the Seder a name / grouping principle, I would have labeled it Kinyanim and Kabbalot, Acquisitions and Acceptances. Kiddushin is not actually about betrothal but, as the perakim continue, about all sorts of kinyanim.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 2)

Nedarim appears in the Torah primarily with regard to women.

The sole pasuk (3) dealing with men's utterances functions more as an introduction to those of women (4-17)

When the parsha wraps up it doesn't even mention those of a man (17)

וַיְדַבֵּ֤ר מֹשֶׁה֙ אֶל־רָאשֵׁ֣י הַמַּטּ֔וֹת לִבְנֵ֥י יִשְׂרָאֵ֖ל לֵאמֹ֑ר זֶ֣ה הַדָּבָ֔ר אֲשֶׁ֖ר צִוָּ֥ה יְ־הֹוָֽה׃ (ג) אִישׁ֩ כִּֽי־יִדֹּ֨ר נֶ֜דֶר לַֽי־הֹוָ֗ה אֽוֹ־הִשָּׁ֤בַע שְׁבֻעָה֙ לֶאְסֹ֤ר אִסָּר֙ עַל־נַפְשׁ֔וֹ לֹ֥א יַחֵ֖ל דְּבָר֑וֹ כְּכׇל־הַיֹּצֵ֥א מִפִּ֖יו יַעֲשֶֽׂה׃ (ד) וְאִשָּׁ֕ה כִּֽי־תִדֹּ֥ר נֶ֖דֶר לַי־הֹוָ֑ה וְאָסְרָ֥ה אִסָּ֛ר בְּבֵ֥ית אָבִ֖יהָ בִּנְעֻרֶֽיהָ׃ (ה) וְשָׁמַ֨ע אָבִ֜יהָ אֶת־נִדְרָ֗הּ וֶֽאֱסָרָהּ֙ אֲשֶׁ֣ר אָֽסְרָ֣ה עַל־נַפְשָׁ֔הּ וְהֶחֱרִ֥ישׁ לָ֖הּ אָבִ֑יהָ וְקָ֙מוּ֙ כׇּל־נְדָרֶ֔יהָ וְכׇל־אִסָּ֛ר אֲשֶׁר־אָסְרָ֥ה עַל־נַפְשָׁ֖הּ יָקֽוּם׃ (ו) וְאִם־הֵנִ֨יא אָבִ֣יהָ אֹתָהּ֮ בְּי֣וֹם שׇׁמְעוֹ֒ כׇּל־נְדָרֶ֗יהָ וֶֽאֱסָרֶ֛יהָ אֲשֶׁר־אָסְרָ֥ה עַל־נַפְשָׁ֖הּ לֹ֣א יָק֑וּם וַֽי־הֹוָה֙ יִֽסְלַח־לָ֔הּ כִּי־הֵנִ֥יא אָבִ֖יהָ אֹתָֽהּ׃ (ז) וְאִם־הָי֤וֹ תִֽהְיֶה֙ לְאִ֔ישׁ וּנְדָרֶ֖יהָ עָלֶ֑יהָ א֚וֹ מִבְטָ֣א שְׂפָתֶ֔יהָ אֲשֶׁ֥ר אָסְרָ֖ה עַל־נַפְשָֽׁהּ׃ (ח) וְשָׁמַ֥ע אִישָׁ֛הּ בְּי֥וֹם שׇׁמְע֖וֹ וְהֶחֱרִ֣ישׁ לָ֑הּ וְקָ֣מוּ נְדָרֶ֗יהָ וֶֽאֱסָרֶ֛הָ אֲשֶׁר־אָסְרָ֥ה עַל־נַפְשָׁ֖הּ יָקֻֽמוּ׃ (ט) וְ֠אִ֠ם בְּי֨וֹם שְׁמֹ֣עַ אִישָׁהּ֮ יָנִ֣יא אוֹתָהּ֒ וְהֵפֵ֗ר אֶת־נִדְרָהּ֙ אֲשֶׁ֣ר עָלֶ֔יהָ וְאֵת֙ מִבְטָ֣א שְׂפָתֶ֔יהָ אֲשֶׁ֥ר אָסְרָ֖ה עַל־נַפְשָׁ֑הּ וַי־הֹוָ֖ה יִֽסְלַֽח־לָֽהּ׃ (י) וְנֵ֥דֶר אַלְמָנָ֖ה וּגְרוּשָׁ֑ה כֹּ֛ל אֲשֶׁר־אָסְרָ֥ה עַל־נַפְשָׁ֖הּ יָק֥וּם עָלֶֽיהָ׃ (יא) וְאִם־בֵּ֥ית אִישָׁ֖הּ נָדָ֑רָה אֽוֹ־אָסְרָ֥ה אִסָּ֛ר עַל־נַפְשָׁ֖הּ בִּשְׁבֻעָֽה׃ (יב) וְשָׁמַ֤ע אִישָׁהּ֙ וְהֶחֱרִ֣שׁ לָ֔הּ לֹ֥א הֵנִ֖יא אֹתָ֑הּ וְקָ֙מוּ֙ כׇּל־נְדָרֶ֔יהָ וְכׇל־אִסָּ֛ר אֲשֶׁר־אָסְרָ֥ה עַל־נַפְשָׁ֖הּ יָקֽוּם׃ (יג) וְאִם־הָפֵר֩ יָפֵ֨ר אֹתָ֥ם ׀ אִישָׁהּ֮ בְּי֣וֹם שׇׁמְעוֹ֒ כׇּל־מוֹצָ֨א שְׂפָתֶ֧יהָ לִנְדָרֶ֛יהָ וּלְאִסַּ֥ר נַפְשָׁ֖הּ לֹ֣א יָק֑וּם אִישָׁ֣הּ הֲפֵרָ֔ם וַי־הֹוָ֖ה יִֽסְלַֽח־לָֽהּ׃ (יד) כׇּל־נֵ֛דֶר וְכׇל־שְׁבֻעַ֥ת אִסָּ֖ר לְעַנֹּ֣ת נָ֑פֶשׁ אִישָׁ֥הּ יְקִימֶ֖נּוּ וְאִישָׁ֥הּ יְפֵרֶֽנּוּ׃ (טו) וְאִם־הַחֲרֵשׁ֩ יַחֲרִ֨ישׁ לָ֥הּ אִישָׁהּ֮ מִיּ֣וֹם אֶל־יוֹם֒ וְהֵקִים֙ אֶת־כׇּל־נְדָרֶ֔יהָ א֥וֹ אֶת־כׇּל־אֱסָרֶ֖יהָ אֲשֶׁ֣ר עָלֶ֑יהָ הֵקִ֣ים אֹתָ֔ם כִּי־הֶחֱרִ֥שׁ לָ֖הּ בְּי֥וֹם שׇׁמְעֽוֹ׃ (טז) וְאִם־הָפֵ֥ר יָפֵ֛ר אֹתָ֖ם אַחֲרֵ֣י שׇׁמְע֑וֹ וְנָשָׂ֖א אֶת־עֲוֺנָֽהּ׃ (יז) אֵ֣לֶּה הַֽחֻקִּ֗ים אֲשֶׁ֨ר צִוָּ֤ה יְ־הֹוָה֙ אֶת־מֹשֶׁ֔ה בֵּ֥ין אִ֖ישׁ לְאִשְׁתּ֑וֹ בֵּֽין־אָ֣ב לְבִתּ֔וֹ בִּנְעֻרֶ֖יהָ בֵּ֥ית אָבִֽיהָ׃

title: Does Isaiah 47:2’s use of showq refer to the thigh or shin?
content:
# Does Isaiah 47:2’s use of showq refer to the thigh or shin? ## Frage

Isaiah 47:1–3 has the “virgin daughter of Babylon” uncovering the showq, and her ‘ervah is uncovered. It seems to me at first glance that the reason her ‘ervah is uncovered is simply because she removed her skirt. But if this passage teaches that the showq is ‘ervah, then we better know what showq means. I’ve seen translations render it “thigh,” but some lexicons say the word actually refers to the “shin” when referencing humans.

What specifically does showq mean in Isaiah 47:2? Do women with knee‐length clothing expose ‘ervah according to this passage?

title: Why does 1 Samuel 16:10-11 say Jesse had 8 sons, while 1 Chronicles 2:13-15 mentions 7?
content:
# Why does 1 Samuel 16:10-11 say Jesse had 8 sons, while 1 Chronicles 2:13-15 mentions 7? ## Frage

Curious what the meaning behind this is and/or if any early Jewish commentators address this.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

As Metzudat David on Samuel 1:16:10 noted, it's possible that there indeed was an eighth brother, Elihu, mentioned only in Chronicles 1:27:18. According to Tanchuma Vayera 25 (mentioned by the Metzudah), Elihu was the only sibling who survived the king of Moab's killing of David's family. Other commentators (e.g. Radak, Ralbag, Rabbi Steinsaltz) however, have argued that Elihu was either a second name of one of David's other brothers (Ralbag and Rabbi Steinsaltz suggested specifically Elihu, likely due to the similarities between the names, and the logic behind promoting David's eldest brother to an important administratorial position), or the name of a nephew (and therefore not a "brother" in the regular sense, but a kinsman).

So why were only seven sons mentioned in the beginning of Chronicles? A few commentators have addressed the issue:

The commentary by the anonymous Student of Rasag on Chronicles 1:2:15 suggested:

"דויד השביעי – ואעפ"י שעוד אליהו שמיני כדכתיב בדברי הימים: ליהודה אליהו מאחי דויד (דברי הימים א כ"ז:י"ח), ותימה לבני אדם למה אמר דויד השביעי, ואומר ודוד הוא הקטן (שמואל א י"ז:י"ד), דע לך כי אליהו היה באותה שעה קטן ומוטל בעריסה בחיק אומנתו ולפיכך לא מנה אותו בחלק הבנים, ומניין אתה יודע שכן הוא הדבר, כי בשעה שברח דוד מפני שאול הנהיג עמו אחיו ובית אביו כדכתיב וינחם את פני מלך מואב (שמואל א כ"ב:ד') וכשהלך מאתו קם מלך מואב והרגן כולם ולא נשתייר מהם אלא אליהו שהיה קטן ותטמנהו אומנתו, ולפי שקטן היה לא העלהו כאן בחשבון הבנים, וכן דרשו חכמים (ילקוט שמעוני שמואל קמ"ז). ויהודה בן קורייש פירש כי לאליאב היה בן גדול והעבירו ישי לפני שמואל, ועוד נשאר הקטן הוא דוד, ולכך אומר ויעבר ישי שבעת בניו (שמואל א ט"ז:י') ודוד הוא שמיני, כי בן אליאב חשוב בבנים..."

"David the seventh - and even though Elihu was the remaining eighth, as it is written in Chronicles: "Of Judah, Elihu from the brothers of David" (Chronicles 1:27:18), and it is therefore strange why it is written that David is the seventh (and no more), and it is also stated that "and David was the youngest" (Samuel 1:17:14), know that Elihu at the time was young and lay in the crib by his nurse and therefore was not counted among the sons, and how do you know that this was the case? Because when David fled from Shaul he led his brothers and the house of his father, as it is written "So he led them to the king of Moab" (Samuel 1:22:4), and when he left, the king of Moab rose and killed all of them, and none remained but Elihu who was small and hidden by his nurse, and since he was small, he was not counted among the sons, and the sages also taught (Yalkut Shimoni Samuel 147). And Yehudah Kuraish explained that Eliav had a grownup son who was passed by Yishai before Shmuel, and "another remains, the youngest, David", and for this reason it is stated that Yishai passed his seven sons (Samuel 1:16:10), and David was the eigthth, because Eliav's son was counted among the sons..."

Pseudo-Rashi on the verse in Chronicles 1:2:15 suggested:

"דויד השבעי – מלא יו"ד מפני כבודו של דוד ועתה מצא המרגלית לפיכך לא מנה השמיני אליהו."

"David the seventh - written fully with a Yod1 in honor of David, as he (i.e., the author of the text) now came across the gemstone and therefore did not name the eighth, Elihu."

Malbim on Chronicles 1:2:15:

"דויד השביעי – וזה סותר למה שבשמואל (א' טז, י; י"ז:י"ב) חושב לישי שמונה בנים ודוד הוא הקטן. ודעת חז"ל במדרש שהשמיני הוא אליהו הנזכר בין הנגידים שהקים דוד על יהודה, אליהו אחי דוד (לקמן כ"ז:י"ח), והוא היה קטן מדוד, וקרא לדוד קטן על שהיה מקטין א״ע, וכן פרש"י. וראב"ע ורד"ק פירשו שאליהו היה אח מן האב ולא מן האם, ולכן לא חשבו פה מפני שאומר ואחיותיהם צרויה ואביגיל, והם היו אחיות מן האם ולא מן האב, וא"כ לא היו אחיות לאליהו לא מן האב ולא מן האם, וכדבריהם נראה ממ״ש (שמואל ב י"ז:כ"ה) ועמשא בן איש ושמו יתרא הישראלי אשר בא אל אביגיל בת נחש אחות צרויה אם יואב, מבואר (לפי הפשט, והדרש ידוע) שאביגיל היתה בת נחש לא בת ישי, וא״כ היתה אחותם רק מן האם, לכן אמר אחות צרויה ולא אמר אחות דוד, מפני שאחות צרויה היתה מן האב ומן האם שגם צרויה היתה בת נחש, ואמם נשאת לישי באלמנותה."

"David the seventh - and this contradicts what is said in Samuel (1:16:10, 17:12) that Yishai was thought to have eight sons and David was the youngest. And our sages' opinion in the midrash is that the eighth was Elihu, mentioned among the princes that David raised "Of Judah, Elihu from the brothers of David" (ibid. 27:18), and he was younger than David, but the text called David the youngest because he made himself small (i.e., he was humble), and so explained Rashi. And Ibn Ezra and Radak explained that Elihu was a brother from the paternal side but not from the maternal side, and therefore he was not counted here, as it is said "and their sisters Tzeruyah and Avigail", and they were sisters on the maternal side and not the paternal side, and therefore were not sisters of Elihu not from the father and not from the mother, and their arguments appear to be proven from what is written (Samuel 2:17:25), "And Amassah was the son of a man named Yitra the Israelite who cohabited with Avigail daughter of Nachash" - not the daughter of Yishai, and therefore was only their sister from the maternal side, and therefore it is written "sister of Tzruyah", not "sister of David", since she was the sister of Tzruyah from father and mother, since Tzruyah was also the daughter of Nachash, and their mother married Yishai during her widowhood."

1 Unclear to me whether he meant that David was written with a Yod (דויד) or that he had before him seventh written with two Yods (שביעי) rather than what we have (שבעי).

title: Punishments that "never happened and could never happen" - weakens the perceived authority/seriousness of the Torah?
content:
# Punishments that "never happened and could never happen" - weakens the perceived authority/seriousness of the Torah? ## Frage

I think the title is bad but I am having a "bad articulation day" - feel free to edit.

What I am trying to ask is this: if we have some punishment-involving-Mitzvot that are recognised as being "impossible" and "will never happen", such as the ones recorded here, based on Sanhedrin 71a: Why would the Torah give us mitzvot that will never actually happen?

  • Ben Sorer u'Morer (wayward son)
  • Ir HaNidachat (idolatrous city)
  • Bet HaMenuga (leprous house)
  • Sotah (suspected wife) (this probably did happen, but there is an opinion that it didn't)

... then the question is, how does this not weaken the authority of the Torah, at least in the minds of some? If a parent threatens a consequence to an action, and the child performs the action repeatedly but never receives the consequence (the parent always find a loophole, as did the courts for these Mitzvot), the child eventually starts to lose respect for the parent's authority, right? Or wrong? Maybe the opposite is true.

I am not looking for site users' own opinions on this, but actual sources that ask the question that I ask, and answer it. I admit, it's not the world's greatest question, and there are some obvious answers but I want to see them from the pen of a generational scholar.

For the record, I don't personally think the Torah's authority should be or is weakened by this, but I still would like to know if it's dealt with because it is a valid question, and a serious one to some degree - it's well known that by their inclusion in the Torah, non-Jewish/non-"Rabbinic" bible followers, such as Christians, did "keep" them with horrific consequences.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Even though the OP sounds interesting, its basic setup is completely flawed to begin with. Therefore, there is no special response needed. We must merely identify the false pretense.

A. These mitzvos certainly do happen.

B. There is no lack or weakening of authority at all.

  1. The "wayward son", way before he faces a question of execution, is given 39 lashes with a fierce whip by the Court, for his "first offense" of stealing his father's funds and eating and drinking with the stolen funds. This itself (the lashes), could kill and is not covered by the Talmudic guarantee that there will never be such a case.

The case that will never be is direct execution when the son commits a highly defined act of theft of his father's funds and eating meat and wine in a glutenous fashion purchased from those funds under peculiar circumstances, a "second time" within 3 months.

wayward sons also suffer public humiliation etc.

The OP forgets that these sins do get punished, just not punished in the most extreme way possible due to technicalities of the law.

  1. Idolaters that convert or pervert their neighbors are likewise killed by Torah Law all the time. The question is if an entire town in certain extreme ways could all become classified as such extreme idolaters as to have the town burned down by the Court etc.

  2. People who practice evil speech and gossip (among some other sins) are punished in Torah Law. They usually contract white skin blotches which cause them to dwell outside the camp and call out "unclean" to passersby until a Cohen says they are cured.

This really did happen.

What might not happen is that the entire family has to demolish their impure house due to such levels of gossip that the "walls have ears" and the walls couldn't take it anymore. However the Cohen does come to inspect the house and colored blotches did appear on houses.

  1. People who act lewdly within marriage and risk the sanctity of their marriage certainly existed and were punished via forced divorce, ruined reputations and humiliations etc., and yes, execution if applicable.

The Sotah procedures did occur in the Temple. Women did go through it and some ended up being punished. The question is did a woman actually need to publicly rot and explode miraculously as a curse among her people under very technical rules and events?

All these people face punishment and loss for their bad deeds.

No one is escaping justice.

All of these mitzvos still apply to us.

The Rambam codifies the wayward son as a mitzvah that we not eat like gluttons which could lead towards becoming like a classic wayward son.

Likewise the Torah commands us not to commit idolatry and not to preach idolatrty as well as to avoid evil gossip and to avoid adulterous activity and flirtations.

And yes, there are smaller and greater punishments along these paths so that no one would assume the authority of the Torah is weakening.

The OP makes it sound like these special mitzvos are completely irrational, non-existent theory, and never punishable, and not practiced or taught. It obviously is not the case.

Saying that the Torah's authority is "weakening" because of technicalities in extreme cases, would be like claiming that murderers are flocking from Florida to Texas because they realized they could merely receive lethal injection if caught in Texas, vs. the electric chair back in Florida.

Maybe the OP should restart and ask why these extreme cases are taught when we already have a Torah framework for their sins, and what lessons they teach if they will never come to pass?

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

The answer to your question is simply "Yes". These cases will cause some people to question the authority of the Torah and weaken its validity in their eyes. But that's not a "Torah" problem. That's a "That Guy" problem.

The Passuk in Hosea 14:10 says:

מִ֤י חָכָם֙ וְיָ֣בֵֽן אֵ֔לֶּה נָב֖וֹן וְיֵדָעֵ֑ם כִּֽי־יְשָׁרִ֞ים דַּרְכֵ֣י יְהֹוָ֗ה וְצַדִּקִים֙ יֵ֣לְכוּ בָ֔ם וּפֹשְׁעִ֖ים יִכָּ֥שְׁלוּ בָֽם׃

The wise will consider these words,

The prudent will take note of them.

For the paths of GOD are smooth;

The righteous can walk on them,

While sinners stumble on them.

People ultimately have free will and can interpret anything they want however they want. That doesn't mean they are interpreting it correctly, and it also doesn't mean that the One making the statement is giving it over incorrectly.

Hashem wrote the Torah in a specific way, meant to be interpreted through the Oral Torah and the commentaries. There will always be people who misread things (whether willfully or mistakenly), and the onus is on them to correct themselves, not to bend the Torah to fit their philosophy.

The Torah is right, it's up to us to realize it.

title: Shlosh Meyos Chamishim V'Chameish (355) - mi yodeya?
content:
# Shlosh Meyos Chamishim V'Chameish (355) - mi yodeya? ## Frage

Who knows three hundred fifty-five? Besides the obvious, שנה, year/change/repeat/review/digest, unless you can expand on that one.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

1 - I noticed an observation in נחלת אבות - ספר שופטים (אברהם בלוי, תשמ"ה) on p. 26 (p. 42 in Otzar and past the free 40 page limit) that the period of the שופטים lasted 355 years. This begins with the passing of יהושע in the year 2,516 and ends with the passing of עלי הכהן in the year 2,871.

This way to define the שופטים period seems to be in line with the words of the Meiri at the beginning of Pirkei Avos:

ואמר שיהושע בעת מותו מסרה לאותם הזקנים ועתניאל בן קנז היה מראשוניהם ועלי הכהן מאחרוניהם עד זמן החרבן שהשופטים אף הם בכלל הזקנים כמו שביארנו בפתיחה ומהם נמסרה לנביאים שהרי שמואל מראשוניהם

See below for the full excerpt from the sefer:

2 - If you want a bit of a stretch, we see a multiple of 355 in the Torah with the count in במדבר having 3,550 men over and above the number 600,000. Those 3,550 had a meaningful impact in the silver donated to the משכן for the collection of the half-shekel. The 300,000 shekalim corresponding to the 600,000 men were used for the silver אדנים of the משכן and the remaining 1,775 (corresponding to the 3,550 men) were used specifically for the silver hooks, coatings and wrappings of the posts of the courtyard.

(שמות לח:כח) וְאֶת הָאֶ֜לֶף וּשְׁבַ֤ע הַמֵּאוֹת֙ וַחֲמִשָּׁ֣ה וְשִׁבְעִ֔ים עָשָׂ֥ה וָוִ֖ים לָעַמּוּדִ֑ים וְצִפָּ֥ה רָאשֵׁיהֶ֖ם וְחִשַּׁ֥ק אֹתָֽם

One can also consider that 3,550 as 355 עדות of men (where a minyan is 10).

3 - As implied in the original question, if you search around there are many who comment on the gematria of שנה = 355 in various ways as that's by far the most frequent occurrence of a word with a value of 355 in Tanach. Indeed the longest non-leap year in the current Jewish calendar is 355 days. There are also many who comment on פרעה which is by far the 2nd most frequent occurrence of 355 in Tanach. I will leave it up to others who desire to expand upon these.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

355 is Gematria

פצפצי"ה

Which is one of the names seventy names of the MT"T according to Alef Bet of R Akiva.

This name occurs in the Petek, at the end of the ninth line.

It is also

נ נח נחמ נחמן

with the addition of 1 kollel. This name is on the seventh line of the Petek.

# Transliterated Sephardic siddur ## Frage

I'm looking for an Edot HaMizrach Siddur with a Latin-script transliteration.

I know Artscroll has a very good one, but that is Nusach Ashkenaz.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

You might want to try the Siddur Ner Tamid:

Introducing the exquisite Siddur Ner Tamid: Sephardic Jewish Siddur, a meticulously crafted prayerbook designed to unite and inspire worshippers across the globe. This exceptional volume is thoughtfully divided into two parts, catering to both Shabbat and Weekday prayers, making it a versatile companion for spiritual seekers. Masterfully transliterated, it provides an inclusive experience for individuals from all backgrounds, empowering them to join in with other communities and strengthen the bonds of faith. This remarkable Siddur has garnered international acclaim, with copies cherished by devotees in the U.S., Israel, Spain, the U.K., Germany, France, Poland, and India. Embrace this treasured prayerbook and revel in the unity it brings to the diverse tapestry of Sephardic Jewish communities worldwide.

Here is a sample page posted on the Amazon page:

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

In addition to Siddur Ner Tamid, which is indeed what I would recommend seeing as you prefer Latin-script transliteration, there is also Siddur Lev Eliezer, available from Eichler's, Seforim Center, and others. Lev Eliezer seems to follow the customs of Syrian Jews, and while I purchased it, I found the formatting and transliteration choices personally difficult to use (אֵי- transliterated as -íye, for example).

I am unaware of any other English-transliterated siddurim. I am aware of a French-transliterated siddur from the Patah Eliyahou series. However, Patah Eliyahou I believe follows more closely to North African customs and the Livorno nusach.

(I assume OP is aware of Siddur Tefilat Azaria, which is a Bukharian siddur, but transliterated using Cyrillic script, given that OP specified Latin-script transliteration.)

title: Why are red tzitzit assur to Ashkenazi?
content:
# Why are red tzitzit assur to Ashkenazi? ## Frage

First question so pardon me. Will try to follow the rules.

Recently moved and got to a mostly ashkenazi shul and am sephardic. I understand Ashkenazim only wear white tzitzit as their minhag but I heard that specifically red is also additionally assur.

I am curious of the logic and am not able to find any reason for the custom. I even asked my rabbi and he was unaware beyond ashkenazi wear only white.

I myself have tzitzit in a few other colors to match a tallit gadol and katan and see where Rambam states if a garment is red it ought have red tzitzit.

If helpful, I do have my rabbis permission to wear my non white tzitzit which are black and green.

Thanks for any insight.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

According to Ashkenazi custom, as cited by the Rema (YD 178:1), wearing red clothes is forbidden as an aspect of avoiding the emulation of immodest gentile practices.

The congregants/rabbi you spoke with were likely referring to this, as red strands would presumably only be worn by you with a dominantly red garment (per the Rambam in H. Sisith 2:8).

title: Is there a comprehensive sefer on the Jecke pronunciation of Hebrew?
content:
# Is there a comprehensive sefer on the Jecke pronunciation of Hebrew? ## Frage

Is there a comprehensive sefer on the Jecke pronunciation of Hebrew?

I’d prefer one in English, but Hebrew one/s is fine.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

While several poskim address pronunciation, there is no comprehensive work on the subject of German havoroh (pronunciation).

  • R' Binyomin Shlomo Hamburger devotes a chapter in his Shorshei Minhag Ashkenaz to the pronunciation of the chaulom/cholom vowel (Vol. 1, Ch. 9) although my friend, Dr. Gabriel Wasserman, questions the validity of some of his assertions, since the phonology of Western Yiddish had a long /O/, whereas German does not, the development of the distinctive chaulom had more to do with language shifts over the 19th century than regional pronunciation, as R' Hamburger asserts.

  • The Yosef Ometz (R' Josef Hahn, a dayan under the Sheloh) and the Pnei Yehoshua' (R' Jakob Jehoschua-Falk, R' Dovid Schiff Londoner's rov) both complain about the loss of certain phonemic distinctions in their respective time periods, namely the loss of ח–כֿ and א–ע distinctions, which indicates that, at least in Frankfurt, these values were preserved at a fairly late date, relative to other Ashkenazi communities.

The best source for [late] Jekkisch havoroh is in the numerous recordings of Shoah survivors, including Messrs. Benno Weis and Moshe Schnerb, along with Chazzan Robert Frankel זכרונם לברכה. Herr Weis, in particular, left a large legacy, including complete Tauroh, haftoroh, Esther, and Eichoh leinen for the entire year, the seder, and nuschaos for most special tefillos, as they were sung in Frankfurt.

Sources:

Hamburger, R' Binyomin Shlomo. Shorshei Minhag Ashkenaz Cheilek I (Bnei Brak).

Wasserman, Dr. Gabriel. Personal communications with the author.

Strauß, R' Sidney. Personal communications with the author. 2019

Recordings:

Chazzan Frankel: Khal Adath Jeshurun, Washington Heights

Herr Schnerb: Khal Adath Jeshurun, Washington Heights

Herr Weis: KAJ, Zemiros Ashkenaz, Dartmouth Jewish Sound Archive

title: Requirements for Washing Hands
content:
# Requirements for Washing Hands ## Frage

When do you need to wash hands 3 times and with a vessel? It is my understanding that waking up in the morning requires 3 times and from a vessel. But what about:

  1. After using a restroom
  2. Touching your nose or face
  3. Grabbing something from the floor
  4. Touching the floor

I ask about these because I do these during the work day and I can't wash my hands with a vessel at work.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

In the Shulchan Aruch Orach Chaim (4:18), there is a list of things from which you need to wash your hands. The Magen Avraham quotes earlier sources who says that those things (including after using the restroom, but not the rest) do not require three times.

However, there are others, mentioned in the Shaarei Teshuva, that do hold of washing three times. The Ben Ish Chai as well holds this way, and even that you need to switch back and forth just as in the morning.

And so, being that the Mishnah Berurah frames the Magen Avraham as the final word on this, you wouldn't need to wash three times for the restroom. But this would ultimately come down to community's customs.

All this is about the amount of times and whether or not you need to wash in a right-left pattern. As for using a vessel, it would likely depend on the reason. Those things that are because of cleanliness, you can wash any way you'd like. This goes for the second item on your list. As for the restroom, since there is an element of Ruach Ra, or evil spirit, it does seem that a vessel is required for that, but you don't need to worry about where you wash into: it can be spilled anywhere.

However, on this too, there are those who say that any washing is fine, these days, since our restrooms are not similar to those of which the sages have spoken of.

title: Per Rashi, Why was Samson Able to Kill the Lion Using Only his Hands?
content:
# Per Rashi, Why was Samson Able to Kill the Lion Using Only his Hands? ## Frage

The psukim state ;

וַיֵּ֧רֶד שִׁמְשׁ֛וֹן וְאָבִ֥יו וְאִמּ֖וֹ תִּמְנָ֑תָה וַיָּבֹ֙אוּ֙ עַד־כַּרְמֵ֣י תִמְנָ֔תָה וְהִנֵּה֙ כְּפִ֣יר אֲרָי֔וֹת שֹׁאֵ֖ג לִקְרָאתֽוֹ׃ So Samson and his father and mother went down to Timnah. When he came to the vineyards of Timnah [for the first time], a full-grown lion came roaring at him.
וַתִּצְלַ֨ח עָלָ֜יו ר֣וּחַ יְהֹוָ֗ה וַֽיְשַׁסְּעֵ֙הוּ֙ כְּשַׁסַּ֣ע הַגְּדִ֔י וּמְא֖וּמָה אֵ֣ין בְּיָד֑וֹ וְלֹ֤א הִגִּיד֙ לְאָבִ֣יו וּלְאִמּ֔וֹ אֵ֖ת אֲשֶׁ֥ר עָשָֽׂה׃ The spirit of GOD gripped him, and he tore him asunder with his bare hands as one might tear a kid asunder; but he did not tell his father and mother what he had done.

Eventually, however, he was unable to survive on his own and he needed an impure thing to live:

הוּא־בָ֣א עַד־לֶ֔חִי וּפְלִשְׁתִּ֖ים הֵרִ֣יעוּ לִקְרָאת֑וֹ וַתִּצְלַ֨ח עָלָ֜יו ר֣וּחַ יְהֹוָ֗ה וַתִּהְיֶ֨ינָה הָעֲבֹתִ֜ים אֲשֶׁ֣ר עַל־זְרוֹעוֹתָ֗יו כַּפִּשְׁתִּים֙ אֲשֶׁ֣ר בָּעֲר֣וּ בָאֵ֔שׁ וַיִּמַּ֥סּוּ אֱסוּרָ֖יו מֵעַ֥ל יָדָֽיו׃ When he reached Lehi, the Philistines came shouting to meet him. Thereupon the spirit of GOD gripped him, and the ropes on his arms became like flax that catches fire; the bonds melted off his hands.
וַיִּמְצָ֥א לְחִי־חֲמ֖וֹר טְרִיָּ֑ה וַיִּשְׁלַ֤ח יָדוֹ֙ וַיִּקָּחֶ֔הָ וַיַּךְ־בָּ֖הּ אֶ֥לֶף אִֽישׁ׃ He came upon a fresh jawbone of a donkey and he picked it up; and with it he killed a thousand men.

He then almost dies of thirst and the jawbone provides water.

The Talmud explains in Sota 9b:

״וַיִּבְקַע אֱלֹהִים אֶת הַמַּכְתֵּשׁ אֲשֶׁר בַּלֶּחִי״. אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק דְּבֵי רַבִּי אַמֵּי: הוּא אִיוָּה לְדָבָר טָמֵא — לְפִיכָךְ נִתְלוּ חַיָּיו בְּדָבָר טָמֵא. After Samson smote one thousand Philistines with the jawbone of a donkey, he called the place Lehi, and God miraculously granted him to drink, as he was dying of thirst. The verse states: “But God cleaved the hollow place that is in Lehi, and out of there came water; and when he had drunk, his spirit came back, and he revived” (Judges 15:19). Rabbi Yitzḥak of the school of Rabbi Ami says: He desired something unclean, as he was driven by lust to Philistine women. Therefore, the saving of his life was dependent on something unclean, the jawbone of a donkey.

Rashi explains that the meaning of desires an unclean thing means that he wanted to marry the daughters of gentiles.

But he had this desire from The get go - before the lion. Why was he able to not need a Taamei thing to save him during his earlier battles - lion and fights with philistines?

title: The Ramban on the pasuk of Lo Sossur says the Sanhedrin doesn’t err. However, there is a Par Halem Davar brought where they do make a mistake?
content:
# The Ramban on the pasuk of Lo Sossur says the Sanhedrin doesn’t err. However, there is a Par Halem Davar brought where they do make a mistake? ## Frage

The Ramban says on the pasuk of Lo Sossor that you must always listen to the Sanhedrin as they do not mistakes. However, we know there is a concept of Par Halem Davar that is brought in a situation where the Sanhedrin makes a mistake?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Here is the operative language:

וְכָל שֶׁכֵּן שֶׁיֵּשׁ לְךָ לַחְשֹׁב שֶׁהֵם אוֹמְרִים עַל יָמִין שֶׁהוּא יָמִין, כִּי רוּחַ הַשֵּׁם עַל מְשָׁרְתֵי מִקְדָּשׁוֹ וְלֹא יַעֲזֹב אֶת חֲסִידָיו לְעוֹלָם נִשְׁמָרוּ מִן הַטָּעוּת וּמִן הַמִּכְשׁוֹל.

He is not saying that they can't make a mistake. He is saying that people cannot view them as making a mistake.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

Presumably it's a rhetorical flourish leaning on a verse in psalms as earlier in the piece he explicitly says that we're to follow them even if we think they've erred.

Here's the whole passage with the relevant parts bolded:

וענינו: אפילו תחשב בלבך שהם טועים, והדבר פשוט בעיניך כאשר אתה יודע בין ימינך לשמאלך, תעשה כמצותם, ואל תאמר: איך אוכל החלב הגמור הזה או אהרוג האיש הנקי הזה, אבל תאמר: כך צוה אותי האדון המצוה על המצות שאעשה בכל מצותיו ככל אשר יורוני העומדים לפניו במקום אשר יבחר, ועל משמעות דעתם נתן לי התורה אפילו יטעו. וזה כענין רבי יהושע עם רבן גמליאל ביום הכפורים שחל להיות בחשבונו (בבלי ר"ה כ"ה.). והצורך במצוה הזאת גדול מאד כי התורה נתנה לנו בכתב, וידוע הוא שלא ישתוו הדעות בכל הדברים הנולדים, והנה ירבו המחלוקות ותעשה התורה כמה תורות. וחתך הכתוב לנו הדין שנשמע לבית דין הגדול העומד לפני השם במקום אשר יבחר בכל מה שיאמרו לנו בפירוש התורה, בין שקבלו פירושו עד מפי משה מפי הגבורה, או שיאמרו כן לפי משמעות התורה או כונתה, כי על הדעת שלהם הוא נותן לנו התורה, אפילו יהו בעיניך כמחליף הימין בשמאל. וכל שכן שיש לך לחשוב שהם אומרים על ימין שהוא ימין, כי רוח השם על משרתי מקדשו ולא יעזוב את חסידיו, לעולם נשמרו (תהלים ל"ז:כ"ח) מן הטעות ומן המכשול. ולשון סיפרי (ספרי דברים י"ז:י"א): אפילו מראין בעיניך על ימין שהוא שמאל ועל שמאל שהוא ימין שמע להם.

The purport thereof is that even if you think in your heart that they are mistaken, and the matter is simple in your eyes just as you know [the difference] between your right hand and your left hand, you must still do as they command you. You are not to say: "How can I [permit myself to] eat this real forbidden fat, or execute this innocent man;" instead you are to say, "The Lord Who enjoined the commandments commanded that I perform all His commandments in accordance with all that they, who stand before Him in the place that He shall choose, teach me to do. He gave me the Torah as taught by them, even if they were to err." Such was the case of Rabbi Yehoshua and Rabban Gamaliel [Rabbi Yehoshua being instructed by Rabban Gamaliel to come before him with his walking stick] on the Day of Atonement that occurred according to his reckoning. Now the need for this commandment is very great, for the Torah was given to us in written form and it is known that not all opinions concur on newly arising matters. Disagreements would thus increase and the one Torah would become many Torahs. Scripture, therefore, defined the law that we are to obey the Great Court that stands before G-d in the place that He chose in whatever they tell us with respect to the interpretation of the Torah, whether they received its interpretation by means of witness from witness until Moses [who heard it] from the mouth of the Almighty, or whether they said so based on the implication [of the written words] of the Torah or its intent. For it was subject to their judgment that He gave them the Torah even if it [the judgment] appears to you to exchange right for left. And surely you are obligated to think that they say "right" what is truly right, because G-d's spirit is upon the ministers of His Sanctuary, and He forsaketh not His saints; they are preserved forever from error and stumbling. In the language of the Sifre: "Even if they show you before your own eyes that right is left and that left is right — obey them!"

title: What is the halachic basis for Machon Shilo?
content:
# What is the halachic basis for Machon Shilo? ## Frage

In many places but labeled as such here, Rabbi David Bar-Hayyim of Machon Shilo declares that the organization's mission is to

be in touch with the true, authentic Torah of Eretz Yisrael, without any deviation and without all manner of foreign ideas and accretions. The Torah, as it is, does not require any embellishment - תורת ה' תמימה משיבת נפש as it is. All you have to do is to live according to the Torah.

Elsewhere on their website, they state that

Until the time of the First Crusade, the Jewish communities of the Land of Israel maintained the ancient traditions: they followed the Halakhic rulings of the Jerusalem Talmud (as opposed to its Babylonian counterpart) and prayed according to the liturgy used in Erets Yisrael from time immemorial. Even outside the Land, certain communities, notably in Egypt, used the Land of Israel liturgy and followed the ancient customs of Erets Yisrael as recently as two generations ago. In general, the nusah of Erets Yisrael had receded into the mist of history ... Machon Shilo - and its rabbinical court Beth haWa’adh, led by HaRav David Bar-Hayim-believe that the Return of Jews to Erets Yisrael must be complemented by a return to the authentic teachings and religious practices of Erets Yisrael in order to “renew our days as of old”.

However, the Rambam in his introduction to the Mishnah Torah, places authority with the Talmud Bavli:

כָּל הַדְּבָרִים שֶׁבַּתַּלְמוּד הַבַּבְלִי, חַיָּבִין כָּל בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל לָלֶכֶת בָּהֶם; וְכוֹפִין כָּל עִיר וְעִיר וְכָל מְדִינָה וּמְדִינָה לִנְהֹג בְּכָל הַמִּנְהָגוֹת שֶׁנָּהֲגוּ חֲכָמִים שֶׁבַּתַּלְמוּד, וְלִגְזֹר גְּזֵרוֹתָם וְלָלֶכֶת בְּתַקָּנוֹתָם.

all the matters mentioned by the Babylonian Talmud are incumbent on the entire Jewish people to follow. We must compel each and every city and each country to accept all the customs that were put into practice by the Sages of the Talmud, to pass decrees parallelling their decrees, and to observe their ordinances, since all the matters in the Babylonian Talmud were accepted by the entire Jewish people.

Is there a halachic basis for establishing a halachic framework around Toras Eretz Yisrael - one that requires us to abandon various community mesoros - rooted in Chazal/rishonim/acharonim, or is it more just an attitude of "we're here now so we gotta do things different"?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

I don't totally agree with Harel. Machon Shiloh as much as it talks about Torath Eres Yriroel, it still abides for the most part on rulings of Bavli, Rambam and Gra. It definitely takes a position aligned with Yerushalmi, but as we know there's no Yerushalmi in everything. Yes, they do put Tefilin during cholo shel moed as one would take Vadii Yerushalmi over. Safek Bavli. They make a beracha when taking off Tefilin, but it is not like it was not mentioned in the Bavli. They do pray in-line with Nusach Eres Yiaroel, so that is maybe the most Minhag Eres Yriroel Machon Shiloh is. However, the concept of Machon Shiloh is to approach Torah with rationale, unlike the rote minhagim that the masses follow blindly without understanding what they are or not doing. Everyone is supposed to be learned and be able to carry a conversation and debate with our community leaders. It does a disservice when there is no discussion and you are told this is how we always did things, thereby shutting down dialogue. This creates a lack of learning. Regardless, you can do you, I can do me as long as we are all in the boundaries of Torah. I strongly disagree with the person mentioning something along the lines that Machon Shiloh is proposing new minhagim. It is quite the opposite, the Sepharadim and Ashkenazim of today that have been so kabbalistically infused that one would argue these groups have been introducing Chadash into their respective communities.

title: תורמוס in Hilchos Nidah
content:
# תורמוס in Hilchos Nidah ## Frage

According to the gemara, and Shulchan Aruch Yoreh Deah 190(7)

אם הרגה פשפש או הריחה ריחו תולה בו עד כתורמוס (פירוש מין ממיני הקטניות שהוא מר ובלע"ז לופינ"ו):
If she killed or smelled a פשפש [bedbug, I heard?], [and finds a stain on her clothing] she can assume it is from the פשפש until it's as big as a תורמוס [lupine?].

The Taz there says that's רחב כמעה קטנה, as wide as a small מעה coin [sigh]. How big is that?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

It seems this size is shrouded in mystery!

The Toras Hashlomim (SA YD 190:10) offers another reference for this size:

אם הרגה פשפש. (שקורין בל"א וואנץ) או הריחה לריחו תולה בו עד כתורמס ופי' של תורמס מבואר בביצה דף כ"ה בפי' רש"י מין קטנית עגול כמין עדשה ורחב כמעה קטנה ושמעתי מלועז א' שהוא מה שקורין טורמיזין בלע"ז והוא רחב כמו מטבע שקורין במדינתנו בל"א הלבין פצין וכתב הט"ז והש"ך דבמקומות שהפשפש והרחש מצוי תולין בה עד כתורמס אע"פ שלא הרגה כי בכתמים שומעין להקל ועיין עוד דבריהם באורך:

But you're not alone, the Aruch HaShulchan (SA YD 190:33) was just as lost!

שיעור התורמוס לא נתברר לנו דבש"ע כתוב מין ממיני הקטניות הוא מר ובלע"ז לופינ"ו עכ"ל ולא נודע לנו וכ"כ רש"י בביצה [כ"ה ב ד"ה תורמוס] וז"ל מין קטניות עגול כמין עדשה ורחב כמעה קטנה והוא מר מאד עד וכו' עכ"ל וראיתי פתרונו בלשון אשכנז פייגבאהנע"ן ופתרונו פול של תאינים וגם זה נעלם מאתנו ובתוי"ט פ"א דטבול יום משנה ד' מבואר שהוא גדול הרבה ע"ש ויש מי שכתב שהוא כמטבע חצי פצי"ן [מנ"י וס"ט סקט"ו] ומטבע זו ג"כ לא נודע לנו וכ"ש דמעה שכתב רש"י אינו ידוע עתה [ומ"ש המנ"י כסלע וודאי תמוה כמ"ש הס"ט שם] ולכן אני משער תמיד כפי ראות עיני [וגם החכ"א כתב חצי פ"ץ ונעלם ממני מטבע זו ואין לי קבלה בשיעור זה]:

title: Why did Hashem create animals with such different lifespans?
content:
# Why did Hashem create animals with such different lifespans? ## Frage

In Jewish sources, we find that some animals live only a short while — for example, certain insects die within days — while others (like elephants or humans) live many decades.

Are there classical Jewish explanations (Midrash, Talmud, commentators, etc.) that address why Hashem created such wide variation in animal lifespans? Is this tied to their role in creation, moral lessons for us, or other purposes?

EDIT: Since Hashem's blessings often include a long life, could animal lifespan reflect their merits, like some sharks and whales, which live over 200 years?

I’m interested in sources that go beyond scientific explanations and instead discuss the theological or ethical significance of these differences.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Commentaries on Genesis 1:22:

Ramban:

AND G-D BLESSED THEM SAYING. He decreed the blessing on them and said of them that they should be fruitful and multiply, meaning that they should bring forth abundantly, that one creature should bring forth many like itself. The purport of the blessing is procreation, even as it says, And I will bless her, and she shall be a mother of nations. In connection with plants also, the term “blessing” applies: Then I will command My blessing upon you in the sixth year. However, it does not say so on the third day [when the plants and trees were created] because all created living beings were only a single pair, male and female, according to their kind, and therefore they were in need of a blessing to bring forth abundantly; but in the case of plants, they sprang up over the face of the entire earth in great abundance, just as they exist today. Nor did He mention a blessing on the sixth day for cattle and beasts because in the decree of abundancy which He decreed for the moving souls in the waters there were included the moving souls on the earth, as all living souls that do not speak are in the same class of creation. And our Rabbis have said that they [the fish and fowl] were in need of a blessing because people hunt them and eat them.

Rashi:

AND HE BLESSED THEM — Because people decreased their number, hunting them and eating them, they needed a blessing (Genesis Rabbah 11:2); it is true that beasts also were in need of a blessing, but on account of the serpent that was to be cursed in the future, He did not bless them, in order that it might not be included in the blessing.

These commentaries note that there was a blessing on the fish and fowl because they were hunted as food, but there was no blessing on the land animals. Fish and fowl that are hunted for food commonly have short lifespans. This may be a hint that longer lifespans for animals are not indications of blessing, because the fish and fowl were blessed because we eat them, and the fish and fowl we eat are typically young. Nobody eats those old sharks and whales.

title: Torah Scholars not having Torah Scholar Children because they call people "Donkeys". Why specifically a Donkey?
content:
# Torah Scholars not having Torah Scholar Children because they call people "Donkeys". Why specifically a Donkey? ## Frage

I saw a statement in a ma'amar (Rosh Hashana 5656)

וכמארז״ל מפני מה בניהם של ת״ח אינן ת״ח משום דקרו לאינשי חמרא

And as our Sages of blessed memory said: why are the children of Torah scholars not [always] Torah scholars? Because they call people "donkey"

The source for this seems to be Nedarim 81a. I would like to know why specifically "donkey"? I can see there is rich commentary on this concept and many beautiful ideas, but I have yet to see any that directly explain why Chazal chose the word "donkey".

I have seen some allusions in the Chassidic commentaries, such as a donkey is a specific klipa of Ishmael: lust etc; or that חומר is similar to "darkness" and lack of refinement, but that just pushes the question back - why does that specific "insult" and attitude lead to Torah scholars not having Torah-scholar children?

I am basically looking for a deep, well reasoned explanation for this gemara.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Refer to the Maharsha there in his Chiddushei Aggados:

דקרו לאנשי חמרי כו' משום דקרו להו חמרי. כאילו הם בטבע הבריאה אינן ראוים לחכמה כבריאת החמור הזה וע"כ אין בניהם ת"ח דאילו לפי דעתם ולפי טבע הבריאה המוליד מוליד בדומה וכיון שהם ת"ח אמאי אין בניהם ת"ח וק"ל

"[The children of Torah scholars are not [always] Torah scholars] because they call people 'donkey'..." – Meaning, because they (the Torah scholars) refer to others as 'donkeys,' it is as if they view them by nature of their creation as inherently unfit for wisdom, just like the creation of a donkey [which lacks intellect].

Therefore, their own children do not become Torah scholars. For, according to their view, based on the laws of nature, a being gives birth to one like itself. So if they themselves are Torah scholars, why then are their children not Torah scholars?

Why though a donkey?

Because a donkey, more than any other animal is known for its ignorance / complete lack of intellect.

Rav Tzadok of Lublin in his Pri Tzadik, chapt. 11 brings this out, drawing on several maamarei chazal etc.

He notes there that the donkey is associated with the klipah of Yishmael, which represents the foolishness of indulgence and lack of intellect. The relevant point there reads:

וגם כל בעל תאוה עושה מעשה שטות ואיתא (מ"ר בלק) על אתונו של בלעם שזו הטפשות שבבהמה וכו' ע"ש וכן הלשון בגמרא (ב"ב עד.) כל אבא חמרא ופירשב"ם שוטה כחמור. וכן איתא (נדרים פא.) שאין מצויין לצאת ת"ח מבניהן משום דקרו לאינשי חמרי היינו שמתגאים על הציבור בחכמתם להחשיב הכל כטפשים. וחמור הטיפש שבבהמה כנ"ל. ותאוה מעשה שטות כמ"ש (סנהדרין קו.) שטים שנתעסקו בדברי שטות וכן איתא (סוטה ג.) אין אדם עובר עבירה אלא אם כן נכנס בו רוח שטות שנ' כי תשטה אשתו. כי אין שטות גדול מזה כי הוא דבר מאוס כמ"ש (שבת קנב.) אשה חמת מלא צואה וכו' ושוטה זה מאבד עולמו בשביל רגע א' דתאוה מנוולת ועל כן נקרא קליפת ישמעאל דתאוה חמור.

Furthermore, anyone driven by lust performs acts of foolishness. As it is written in Midrash Rabbah on Parshas Balak, regarding Bilam’s donkey, it is said: “This is the foolishness of the animal”. Similarly, in Bava Basra (74a), it says: “Until all the fathers became donkeys,” and Rashbam explains that a fool is like a donkey. It is also said in Nedarim 81a that Torah scholars are not often found among the children of Torah scholars because they call people “donkeys”, meaning they are arrogant toward the public, considering everyone to be foolish, and the donkey is the most foolish of animals, as mentioned earlier. Desire leads to acts of foolishness, as the Gemara in Sanhedrin 106a says: “The Israelites engaged in foolishness,” and in Sotah 3a: “No person commits a sin unless a spirit of foolishness enters him,” as it is written: “If a wife goes astray...” (Bamidbar 5:12).

This is the greatest foolishness, for it is a repulsive thing, as the Gemara in Shabbos 152a says: “A wife who is angry, full of excrement...”. This fool loses his world for a moment’s desire, and therefore Ishmael is called the klipah of desire, likened to a donkey.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

R. Yechiel Michel Stern in Sefer "Leshon Limudim", p. 187-8 notes based on Rabbeinu Bachya that this is play on the animal name חמור (donkey) - חומר (chomer measure [of barley], also raw matter). Here's the full translation:

The donkey carries his load longer than any other animal, that's why people use it to transport heavy cargo of wheat. Explained Rabbeinu Bachya on Bereshis 2:19, reason (2), that's why the donkey's name in Hebrew is חמור (chamOr), which is derived from the meaning חומר שעורים (chomer measure of barley):

When it came to naming the donkey, Adam called it חמור. Adam had recognised that that (1) animal was extremely dull-witted, more foolish than all the other animals. This is why he chose a name which is closely related to the word חומר, i.e. “matter, material.” (2) An additional reason for that name is the fact that the donkey is a beast of burden employed to carry sacks of grain. Grain is measured in terms of a weight called חומר, as we find in Hoseah 3:2 חֹ֥מֶר שְׂעֹרִ֖ים “a chomer of barley.”

In other words, the donkey appears to be more absorbed in physicality compared to any other animal as it is even capable to rest with the load on his back. (Btw. that's why the symbol of Yissachar is donkey, for just like a donkey can rest with a load on its back so does ben Yissachar with the Torah scroll).

As noted by @Dov with other sources, R. Stern continues explaining reason (1) in Rabbeinu Bachya:

The nature of donkey is gullible, foolish, and more burdensome from other animals, as they say in midrash Tanchuma Balak 9 (at the end of the paragraph): שֶׁזֹּה הַטִּפְּשִׁית שֶׁבַּבְּהֵמוֹת - the donkey is the silliest of animals. Also Rabbeinu Bachya in the quote above. The donkey's Hebrew name is חמור (chamor), since it is driven after its physical desires (התאוות) which is derived from חומר - physicality, as pulled towards materiality (חומריות). That is why the nations with culture driven by physicality are called a nation like a donkey. Also a human being at the time of one's youth who pursues physical pleasures is compared to a donkey that brays (חמור נוער, see B'rachos 3a for usage of the phrase, also a play on the word נער - youth).

Based on these sources, one could interpret the gemara as follows. The children of rabbis that do not grow to be Torah scholars is a punishment of the rabbis themselves, who, in moments of frustration, may call ordinary people donkeys. Why donkeys? Either because the ordinary people did not develop intellect, or because they are fully engrossed in materiality, or in pursuit of physical desires.

The punishment is spelled in the gemara, since naturally children seek to test the boundaries of the permitted set by their parents. It is especially true after age 7 and in their teen years as they develop independence, as the source above compares them to a donkey that brays, when they get more adversarial. Such a youth, when seeing the parent-rabbi frustration with ordinary people, may not appreciate reasons for frustration, but rather use it as a weapon to continue frustrating the parent. At the end he, חו"ש, develop dislike for the profession of the parent.

title: Staying in Torah class below one's level
content:
# Staying in Torah class below one's level ## Frage

Just wondering if we have any useful/helpful facts (halachot, recorded advice and/or ma'asim from Rabbonim, etc.) on the situation where one has ended up in a class below his level.

I have personally had this situation in the past, and you might say "why not just leave", but sometimes it is more complicated than that. For example, it might be a shiur established by your kehilla and your attendance is important to the community; Sometimes the person giving the class is a friend or someone who might get upset if you were to leave; Sometimes it's a very small shiur and if you were to leave, it might shut down, or cause others to leave leading to it shutting down; People might view you as arrogant or aloof if you leave.

Therefore, it can sometimes be tricky to leave such a shiur. That's why I ask - what information do we have in our sources about this situation? Examples:

  1. It is bittul zman to stay in a shiur below one's level and that takes precedence
  2. If there are good, extraneous reasons to stay, like the one's listed above, then one should stay, all else being equal (if so, what factors could override this?)
  3. This is a complete non-issue. It's never a bittul to learn Torah, even Torah below one's level, as there's always something new to learn, chazara to do, and your own input that can be provided to the class etc.
  4. Leaving might be bittul Torah, or otherwise generally the wrong thing to do, unless one has another Torah class to swap it with etc.

On the other hand, being in a class that's below one's level can be frustrating, off putting, and can indeed feel like bittul zman, or time taken away from work, family or other important matters.

title: Is charging money to attend Rosh Hashanah/Yom Kippur services a violation of ahavat Yisrael
content:
# Is charging money to attend Rosh Hashanah/Yom Kippur services a violation of ahavat Yisrael ## Frage

I’m curious, is the minhag of some synagogues to charge money for people (especially non members) to attend their Rosh Hashanah and/or Yom Kippur services a violation of any ethical or halachic principles related to Ahavat Yisrael? The reason I hypothesize this is because many Jews only attend Shul on Yamim Noraim and so it might deter them from coming closer to Hashem if they have to pay to daven with the community.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Halachically Speaking Volume 5 Issue 1 discusses the issue of buying seats but not specifically for Yomim Neroim.

Page 5:

"The custom is that one buys a seat to sit in while davening in a shul."

The corresponding footnote number 35 states

Refer to Rashba 1:319, Rosh klal 5:3, Radvaz 2:628, Chasam Sofer O.C. 29, see Igros Moshe C.M. 1:40, Divrei Yatziv C.M. 51. Some poskim are of the opinion that if there is a custom to buy seats then one has a right to tell someone else not to sit there. (Refer to Halacha Berurah 153:page 436:footnote 35, see Biur Halacha 153 ein adom).

title: Using illness to get close to Hashem
content:
# Using illness to get close to Hashem ## Frage

Do Chazal or any commentaries or contemporary rabbis have any thoughts on how a sick person can use their illness to connect with Hashem, or the correct mindset a sick person should have?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

A commonly quoted Chazal from Berachos 5a doesn't specifically mention sickness but it is definitely applicable:

Berachos 5a

אָמַר רָבָא, וְאִיתֵּימָא רַב חִסְדָּא: אִם רוֹאֶה אָדָם שֶׁיִּסּוּרִין בָּאִין עָלָיו — יְפַשְׁפֵּשׁ בְּמַעֲשָׂיו, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״נַחְפְּשָׂה דְרָכֵינוּ וְנַחְקֹרָה וְנָשׁוּבָה עַד ה׳״.

Rava, and some say Rav Ḥisda, said: If a person sees that suffering has befallen him, he should examine his actions. Generally, suffering comes about as punishment for one’s transgressions, as it is stated: “We will search and examine our ways, and return to God” (Lamentations 3:40). [Steinsaltz annotated translation and commentary]

title: The root of the word תשכנו in Rashi to Genesis 3:15 ואתה תשופנו עקב
content:
# The root of the word תשכנו in Rashi to Genesis 3:15 ואתה תשופנו עקב ## Frage

I was learning Rashi in Hebrew and came across the word תשכנו in his perush to Genesis 3:15. The word is translated as "biting", but I cannot find its root nor locate this meaning of biting in all the dictionaries provided by Sefaria.

May I ask of you guys to help me?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

The root is נשך, meaning to bite. The prefix ת means “you will”. The suffix נו means “him”. The נ of the root drops out, and there’s a דגש in the ש. Besides the examples given in the comment by DoubleAA (Numbers 21:6 or Kohelet 10:8), the root נשך can be seen in Deuteronomy 23:20-21 (with and without the נ), where it means to charge interest.

### Antwort 2 (Score: -5)

Can mean to settle or live. Or as a nown neighbours

Genesis 25.יח וַיִּשְׁכְּנוּ מֵחֲוִילָה עַד-שׁוּר, אֲשֶׁר עַל-פְּנֵי מִצְרַיִם, בֹּאֲכָה, אַשּׁוּרָה; עַל-פְּנֵי כָל-אֶחָיו, נָפָל. {פ} 18 And they dwelt from Havilah unto Shur that is before Egypt, as thou goest toward Asshur: over against all his brethren he did settle.

תשכנו means you plural will settle. ישכבו they settled past. Same root word. שכנ

Genesis 3.כד וַיְגָרֶשׁ, אֶת-הָאָדָם; וַיַּשְׁכֵּן מִקֶּדֶם לְגַן-עֵדֶן אֶת-הַכְּרֻבִים, וְאֵת לַהַט הַחֶרֶב הַמִּתְהַפֶּכֶת, לִשְׁמֹר, אֶת-דֶּרֶךְ עֵץ הַחַיִּים. {ס} 24 So He drove out the man; and He placed at the east of the garden of Eden the cherubim, and the flaming sword which turned every way, to keep the way to the tree of life.

The other word ישופך means to pour out. So it could be translated you will pour out his head. Probably referring to the clipa

Exodus 29.12 And thou shalt take of the blood of the bullock, and put it upon the horns of the altar with thy finger; and thou shalt pour out all the remaining blood at the base of the altar.

תשפך

title: Why didn't Jews pray from siddurim earlier in Jewish history?
content:
# Why didn't Jews pray from siddurim earlier in Jewish history? ## Frage

It seems that tefilah was recited by heart for a long part of our history.

This generated many halachos related to concerns about getting confused during davening.

See, e.g., here and here ff (and perhaps here as well) with the poskim saying that praying from a siddur would do away with the issues.

Rambam writes that the nusach hatefilah was already fixed from the time of Ezra.

That being so, why does it seem that tefilah was recited by heart for a long stretch of our history, not being read from a siddur (which generated related Halacha, to the extent that even the biblical mitzvah of Birchas Kohanim was skipped when the shatz was the sole Kohen and not confident about not getting confused, as opposed to requiring that the prayers be said from a siddur, unless one claims that these halachos were formulated as siddurim were rare or in a case where they weren't available which doesn't seem likely)?

Was there some issue with writing down Shemoneh Esrei, similar to the oral law, which was later overrode?

Does it have to do with keeping ones eyes closed during davening?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

Because until recently in our history, the printing press didn’t exist.

Handwritten books are very expensive, and take a very long time to compose. Both were even more true before modern paper and ink production methods.

Until relatively recently in human history, it would be almost impossible for each person in a congregation to have his own סדור. For that to happen, there would have to be a large number of scribes willing to take the time and expense to write a סדור (because it would take years, if not decades, for a single scribe to finish a congregation’s-worth of סִדורים). For that to happen, there would have to be a lot of demand from people willing to pay a fortune (and for that demand to remain for the years it takes to find and train multiple scribes). That, in turn, would require multiple congregations of rich people, and who to feel that it’s better to lose a significant amount of money than to just memorize the liturgy.

All of which was extremely unlikely, considering most people were moderately poor by today’s standards—not to mention illiterate, so a סִדור probably wouldn’t be of any use to a good portion of Jews at the time.

In short, it was just not worth it. Too expensive for the consumer, and too much trouble for the scribe.

title: How does a wife bring blessing to a home? Understanding the derasha of Yevamot 62b
content:
# How does a wife bring blessing to a home? Understanding the derasha of Yevamot 62b ## Frage

In Yevamot 62b Rabbi Tanchum makes the following claim

אָמַר רַבִּי תַּנְחוּם אָמַר רַבִּי חֲנִילַאי: כׇּל אָדָם שֶׁאֵין לוֹ אִשָּׁה — שָׁרוּי בְּלֹא שִׂמְחָה, בְּלֹא בְּרָכָה, בְּלֹא טוֹבָה. בְּלֹא שִׂמְחָה, דִּכְתִיב: ״וְשָׂמַחְתָּ אַתָּה וּבֵיתֶךָ״. בְּלֹא בְּרָכָה, דִּכְתִיב: ״לְהָנִיחַ בְּרָכָה אֶל בֵּיתֶךָ״. בְּלֹא טוֹבָה, דִּכְתִיב: ״לֹא טוֹב הֱיוֹת הָאָדָם לְבַדּוֹ״.
Rabbi Tanḥum said that Rabbi Ḥanilai said: Any man who does not have a wife is left without joy, without blessing, without goodness. He proceeds to quote verses to support each part of his statement. He is without joy, as it is written: “And you shall rejoice, you and your household” (Deuteronomy 14:26), which indicates that a man is in a joyful state only when he is with his household, i.e., his wife. He is without blessing, as it is written: “To cause a blessing to rest in your house” (Ezekiel 44:30), which indicates that blessing comes through one’s house, i.e., one’s wife. He is without goodness, as it is written: “It is not good that man should be alone” (Genesis 2:18), i.e., without a wife.

I would like to understand the derasha from Ezekiel 44:30. The context there seems to be that giving terumah and various gifts to the kohen will result in a blessing on the giver's home. I do not see any indication of a connection to marriage or having a wife. R' Steinsaltz's commentary that the blessing will apply to the home, ie the person's wife does not seem to accord with the simple meaning of the verse (would a widower who gives terumah not receive the blessing?).

Please cite sources which explain R' Tanchum's derasha or how the verse in Ezekiel can be understood as relating to marriage.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

The connection to marriage is the word "home". As Rabbi Yosei says in Gittin 52a and Shabbat 118b, he referred to his wife as his "home":

אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי: מִיָּמַי לֹא קָרִיתִי לְאִשְׁתִּי ״אִשְׁתִּי״ וּלְשׁוֹרִי ״שׁוֹרִי״, אֶלָּא לְאִשְׁתִּי — ״בֵּיתִי״, וּלְשׁוֹרִי — ״שָׂדִי״.

Furthermore, Rabbi Yosei said that he always spoke euphemistically: In all my days, I did not call my wife, my wife, nor my ox, my ox. Rather, I called my wife, my home, because she is the essence of the home, and my ox, my field, because it is the primary force in the fields. [Steinsaltz translation and inter-commentary]

As Rashi confirms in the quoted sugya from Yevamot, the operating principle in the first two of these proofs is this very principle - the wife is called the home, which is utilised throughout shas. Hence, the verse from Yechezkel, which says the word "home", is darshened to mean about a "wife".

The standard principle that the wife is the ikar bayit is the lived reality of Torah and therefore this principle is very general. However, if you ask why Yechezkel's specific use of the word bayit is darshened as wife, the Chiddushei Aggadot answers that this is because this blessing is specifically regarding challa (the pasuk says ראשית עריסותיכם, "the first of your dough" i.e. challa [Malbim]), and challa is a mitzva devolved principally upon women (Shabbat 31b).

title: Was King David from the tribe of Ephraim?
content:
# Was King David from the tribe of Ephraim? ## Frage

Samuel 17.12 Now David was the son of that Ephrathite of Beth-lehem in Judah, whose name was Jesse; and he had eight sons; and the man was an old man in the days of Saul, stricken in years among men.

The Hebrew word used is אפרתי. This word appears only 5 times in the whole Bible.

Judges 12.5 And the Gileadites took the fords of the Jordan against the Ephraimites; and it was so, that when any of the fugitives of Ephraim said: ‘Let me go over,’ the men of Gilead said unto him: ‘Art thou an Ephraimite?’ If he said: ‘Nay’;

Samuel 1.1 Now there was a certain man of Ramathaim-zophim, of the hill-country of Ephraim, and his name was Elkanah, the son of Jeroham, the son of Elihu, the son of Tohu, the son of Zuph, an Ephraimite.

Kings 1.11.26 And Jeroboam the son of Nebat, an Ephraimite of Zeredah, a servant of Solomon, whose mother’s name was Zeruah, a widow, he also lifted up his hand against the king.

Ruth 1.2 And the name of the man was Elimelech, and the name of his wife Naomi, and the name of his two sons Mahlon and Chilion, Ephrathites of Beth-lehem in Judah. And they came into the field of Moab, and continued there.

As you can see in all these examples אפרתי means Ephraimites. For some reason Ephraimites moved to Bet Lehem. It was maybe because their mother Rachel was buried there.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Ephratite is a bit of a tricky term, but there's no other concrete evidence to suggest David was from Ephraim. His full lineage up to Yehudah is listed twice in Tanach (Ruth 4:18-22 and Chronicles 1:2:9-15). The gemara in Sotah 11b suggests that David was called "the son of an Ephratite" because he was descended on the maternal side from Ephrat, wife of Kalev ben Chetzron, also identified by the Talmud with Miriam and Puah the midwife.1 Indeed, Beit Lechem is also called Ephrat/Ephratah in Beresheet (35:16, 19; 48:7), Micha 5:1 and Ruth 4:11.

Another possibilty for the meaning of Ephrati is that it means "nobleman" in Hebrew, and is therefore used as an honorific for prominent Israelite families, not necessarily members of the tribe of Ephraim (Ruth Rabbah 2).

1 Likewise, Shmuel's full lineage all the way to Levi in e.g., Chronicles 1:6:18-23 shows that the term Ephratite in reference to his father Elkanah (or one of their ancestors) did not mean they were members of Ephraim. Given that they were Kehatites living in Ramah/Ramatayim Tzofim, in a territory called "Eretz Tzuf" (both eponymously named for their ancestor Tzuf), it seems that Tzuf was a Levite who had to leave his original territory, likely due to monetary issues. He was therefore called an Ephratite for his original home in the area of Ephrat/Beit Lechem, and was later called "of Mt. Ephraim" after having moved there. The seemingly duplicate term indicates that Ephratite does not necessarily mean "of Ephraim". For more information, see: Yoel Elitzur, "The First Verse in the Book of Samuel: Geography, History and Meaning" (הפסוק הראשון בספר שמואל: גאוגרפיה, היסטוריה ומשמעות), in: Yisrael Rosenson and Yossi Spanier (eds.), Minchat Sapir, Elkanah-Rechovot 5773/2013, pp. 51-63.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

In a word, no. David's lineage is explicitly traced to Peretz, the son of Yehuda, in Rut 4:18-22:

וְאֵ֙לֶּה֙ תּוֹלְד֣וֹת פָּ֔רֶץ פֶּ֖רֶץ הוֹלִ֥יד אֶת־חֶצְרֽוֹן: וְחֶצְרוֹן֙ הוֹלִ֣יד אֶת־רָ֔ם וְרָ֖ם הוֹלִ֥יד אֶת־עַמִּינָדָֽב׃ וְעַמִּֽינָדָב֙ הוֹלִ֣יד אֶת־נַחְשׁ֔וֹן וְנַחְשׁ֖וֹן הוֹלִ֥יד אֶת־שַׂלְמָֽה׃ וְשַׂלְמוֹן֙ הוֹלִ֣יד אֶת־בֹּ֔עַז וּבֹ֖עַז הוֹלִ֥יד אֶת־עוֹבֵֽד׃ וְעֹבֵד֙ הוֹלִ֣יד אֶת־יִשָׁ֔י וְיִשַׁ֖י הוֹלִ֥יד אֶת־דָּוִֽד׃

This is the line of Perez: Perez begot Hezron, Hezron begot Ram, Ram begot Amminadab, Amminadab begot Nahshon, Nahshon begot Salmon, Salmon begot Boaz, Boaz begot Obed, Obed begot Jesse, and Jesse begot David.

title: How come the Baraita/Gemara didn't derive the meaning from the subsequent verse just like its second example?
content:
# How come the Baraita/Gemara didn't derive the meaning from the subsequent verse just like its second example? ## Frage

The following is from Sanhedrin 86a:

תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״לֹא תִגְנֹב״ – בְּגוֹנֵב נְפָשׁוֹת הַכָּתוּב מְדַבֵּר. אַתָּה אוֹמֵר בְּגוֹנֵב נְפָשׁוֹת, אוֹ אֵינוֹ אֶלָּא בְּגוֹנֵב מָמוֹן? אָמַרְתָּ: צֵא וּלְמַד מִשְּׁלֹשׁ עֶשְׂרֵה מִדּוֹת שֶׁהַתּוֹרָה נִדְרֶשֶׁת בָּהֶן, דָּבָר הַלָּמֵד מֵעִנְיָינוֹ. בְּמָה הַכָּתוּב מְדַבֵּר? בִּנְפָשׁוֹת. אַף כָּאן בִּנְפָשׁוֹת.

The Sages taught in a baraita: “You shall not steal” (Exodus 20:13), and it is with regard to one who abducts people that the verse is speaking. Do you say that the verse is speaking with regard to one who abducts people, or perhaps the verse is speaking only with regard to one who steals property? You say: Go out and learn from one of the thirteen hermeneutical principles: A matter derived from its context. With regard to what context are the adjacent prohibitions “You shall not kill; you shall not commit adultery” in the verse speaking? They are speaking with regard to capital cases. So too here, the prohibition is speaking with regard to a capital case of abduction.

תַּנְיָא אִידַּךְ: ״לֹא תִגְנֹבוּ״ – בְּגוֹנֵב מָמוֹן הַכָּתוּב מְדַבֵּר. אַתָּה אוֹמֵר בְּגוֹנֵב מָמוֹן, אוֹ אֵינוֹ אֶלָּא בְּגוֹנֵב נְפָשׁוֹת? אָמַרְתָּ: צֵא וּלְמַד מִשְּׁלֹשׁ עֶשְׂרֵה מִדּוֹת שֶׁהַתּוֹרָה נִדְרֶשֶׁת בָּהֶן, דָּבָר הַלָּמֵד מֵעִנְיָנוֹ. בְּמָה הַכָּתוּב מְדַבֵּר? בְּמָמוֹן. אַף כָּאן בְּמָמוֹן.

It is taught in another baraita: “You shall not steal” (Leviticus 19:11), and it is with regard to one who steals property that the verse is speaking. Do you say that the verse is speaking with regard to one who steals property, or perhaps the verse is speaking only with regard to one who abducts people? You say: Go out and learn from one of the thirteen hermeneutical principles: A matter derived from its context. With regard to what context is the subsequent verse: “You shall neither exploit your neighbor nor rob him” (Leviticus 19:13), speaking? It is speaking with regard to property. So too here, the verse is speaking with regard to property.

The question is how come the Baraita/Gemara didn't derive the meaning from the subsequent verse just like its second example? Why not derive “You shall not steal” (Exodus 20:13) from "You shall not covet your neighbor’s house" (Exodus 20:14)?
