title: What is the nature of the Oath we made before coming into the world vs The one we made on mount Sinai
content:
# What is the nature of the Oath we made before coming into the world vs The one we made on mount Sinai ## Frage

BH

The start of the Tanya Likutei Amarim/Sefer Shel Beinonim says in the beginning, quoting from Massekhet Nidah, that a Malach made us swear that we will be a tzaddik and not a rasha; however, I heard from other people that we also made an oath on Mount Sinai for keeping the mitzvot.

Is this true? If yes, what is the nature of this oath to keep the mitzvot? Is it different from the one we made before we came to the world? Also was this oath always made before, even before Mount Sinai? Or only after Sinai did this oath come into the world and stay happening until now, and, if yes, also what was the point of having the oath done at Mount Sinai or we had to make this oath only after the oath at Mount Sinai?

In short, is it the same two oaths or different? If not different, what is the purpose of the two oaths?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

The Chida offers one difference. He brings a Gemara in Niddah 30b that says that we all make a shevua in the womb to be a Tzadik and not a Rosha. Rashi explains that this is a Shevua to keep the whole Torah. The Shevua at Har Sinai was on all Nefashos present and future, in the womb however, we make a 2nd Shevua with Guf and Nefesh together. See sources below.

Another potential difference is that the Shevua at Har Sinai was made under duress, as Hashem held a mountain over our heads like a barrel. The Shevua made in the womb is seemingly made willingly.

Another potential difference based on the Maharsha on Shavuos 29a is that the Shevua at Har Sinai was the communal acceptance of the Torah onto the Jewish people, effectively making its laws binding. The Shevua in the womb on the other hand, would just be an oath to actually do that which we are bound to do by that original oath.

In a similar vein, the Chazon Ish on Shulchan Aruch Yoreh Deah 119:8 explains that the Shevua at Har Sinai was actually a Bris - covenant - unlike the Shevua in the womb.

Edit: Adding more sources about the Shevua made at Har Sinai

Sources:

Chidah – In his sefer Maharis Ayin on Nedarim

והלא מושבע ועומד מהר סיני וכו'. בפ"ג דנדה אמרו דמשביעין לילד בבטן אמו. ונראה דשבועת הר סיני היתה לנפשות העתידות שהיו הכל בהר סיני כדכתיב את אשר ישנו פה ואשר איננו. וזו השבועה היתה לנפשות לבד. ואח"כ בבטן היא שבועה לגוף ונפש כאחד. ומ"מ רגיל הש"ס לומר מושבע ועומד מהר סיני כי היתה השבועה הראשונה וגם היתה לכוללות ישראל:

Niddah 30b

ואינו יוצא משם עד שמשביעין אותו שנאמר (ישעיהו מה, כג) כי לי תכרע כל ברך תשבע כל לשון כי לי תכרע כל ברך זה יום המיתה שנאמר (תהלים כב, ל) לפניו יכרעו כל יורדי עפר תשבע כל לשון זה יום הלידה שנאמר (תהלים כד, ד) נקי כפים ובר לבב אשר לא נשא לשוא נפשו ולא נשבע למרמה ומה היא השבועה שמשביעין אותו תהי צדיק ואל תהי רשע ואפילו כל העולם כולו אומרים לך צדיק אתה היה בעיניך כרשע והוי יודע שהקב"ה טהור ומשרתיו טהורים ונשמה שנתן בך טהורה היא אם אתה משמרה בטהרה מוטב ואם לאו הריני נוטלה ממך

Rashi (ibid.)

ולא נשבע למרמה - שקיים שבועתו לשמור את התורה דאי בשבועה בעלמא אטו משום דלא נשבע למרמה חשיב להו בעולין בהר ה':

Tosfos Shavuos 29a

כשהשביע משה את ישראל. קצת קשה מה היתה מועלת השבועה כמו שהיה ירא שיעבדו עבודת כוכבים כמו כן היה לירא פן יעברו השבועה:?

Maharsha (ibid.)

כשהשביע משה את ישראל. כתבו התוס' ק"ק מה היתה מועלת השבועה כמו שהיה ירא שיעבדו את ע"ז כו' עכ"ל ונראה דלק"מ דהשבועה עצמה היא קבלת התורה ואי לאו השבועה בדיבורא בעלמא ליכא קיבול ולא היו נענשים אם יעברו עליה וכן מוכיח המקרא דכתיב לעברך בברית ה' אלהיך ובאלתו וגו' והרבה כמוהו וק"ל:

Chazon Ish - SA YD 119:8

Additional Sources about the Shevua made at Har Sinai:

Gemara Nedarim 8a - Source for Shevua made at Har Sinai

וְאָמַר רַב גִּידֵּל אָמַר רַב: מִנַּיִן שֶׁנִּשְׁבָּעִין לְקַיֵּים אֶת הַמִּצְוָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״נִשְׁבַּעְתִּי וָאֲקַיֵּמָה לִשְׁמֹר מִשְׁפְּטֵי צִדְקֶךָ״. וַהֲלֹא מוּשְׁבָּע וְעוֹמֵד מֵהַר סִינַי הוּא. אֶלָּא הָא קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן דְּשָׁרֵי לֵיהּ לְאִינִישׁ לְזָרוֹזֵי נַפְשֵׁיהּ

Devarim 28:69 – Bris at Har Grizim and Har Eival

אֵלֶּה דִבְרֵי הַבְּרִית אֲשֶׁר־צִוָּה יְהֹוָה אֶת־מֹשֶׁה לִכְרֹת אֶת־בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל בְּאֶרֶץ מוֹאָב מִלְּבַד הַבְּרִית אֲשֶׁר־כָּרַת אִתָּם בְּחֹרֵב׃

These are the statements of the covenant that Hashem commanded Moshe to ratify with Bnei Yisroel in the land of Moav, beside the covenant that he had made with them at Choreiv.

Rashi (ibid.) - This Bris at Choreiv/Har Sinai was a Shevua

לכרת את בני ישראל. שֶׁיְּקַבְּלוּ עֲלֵיהֶם אֶת הַתּוֹרָה בְּאָלָה וּבִשְׁבוּעָה:

Medrash Rabbah Parshas Naso - The Source for Rashi

וּמִנַּיִן שֶׁבְּסִינַי לָקְחוּ שְׁבוּעַת הָאָלָה, שֶׁכֵּן כְּתִיב (דברים כח, סט): אֵלֶּה דִבְרֵי הַבְּרִית וגו' מִלְּבַד הַבְּרִית אֲשֶׁר כָּרַת אִתָּם בְּחֹרֵב, הִקִּישׁ בְּרִית חוֹרֵב לִבְרִית אֶרֶץ מוֹאָב, מַה לְּהַלָּן בְּאָלָה אַף כָּאן בְּאָלָה. אֵי זֶהוּ בְּרִית שֶׁל חוֹרֵב, (ויקרא כו, יד): וְאִם־לֹא תִשְׁמְעוּ לִי וְלֹא תַעֲשׂוּ אֵת כׇּל־הַמִּצְוֺת הָאֵלֶּה.

title: Requesting miracles in birkat kohanim
content:
# Requesting miracles in birkat kohanim ## Frage

The Yehi Ratzon supplication at the end of birkat kohanim in the ashkenaz rite reads:

וְתַעֲשֶׂה עִמִּי נִפְלָאוֹת וְנִסִּים

In the singular form, requesting miracles.

How can we request personal miracles? (I cant seem to find where i know this concept, though i did find the gemara taanit 20 & rashi on 24b which says to distance oneself from miracles) Should the language be changed to plural?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The Mishna in Brachos 9:3 says that if one whose wife is expecting prays that the child shall be/become a male, that is a wasted prayer, for it is too late. The Gemara in Brachos 60a mentions that the matriarch Leah did indeed pray thus, and she was answered. The Gemara responds to this that you can't bring up miracles. And so, we see from that Mishna that you should not indeed pray for a miracle. It is considered silly.

Similarly, we find the Gemara in Taanis 24b saying that one should not take from the product of miracles. (Rashi implies that it uses up your merits.)

On the other hand, we find instances of miracles such as in Taanis 25a where Rebbi Chanina ben Dosa caused vinegar to burn like oil. The Gemara (in Me'ila 17b) also describes Rebbi Shimon bar Yochai as a miracle worker. And obviously, we have all the instances of the prophets performing miracles.

Therefore, a distinction must be drawn, where you'd say that it depends on whether you are a "miracle person" who lives a life above his nature or a regular person or is steeped in the physical world.

With that in the background, we find that the Rema wrote in Shulchan Aruch 682 that if one forgot to say AL Hanissim then he should say, at the end of Birchas Hamazon, הרחמן הוא יעשה עמנו נסים כמו שעשית לאבותינו בימים ההם בזמן הזה: The Merciful one, He should bring upon us miracles, as He did for our fathers in those days in this time.

The same question applies here: how can you pray for a miracle? One answer is that you may pray for everyone but just not for yourself alone. This align well with the answer differentiating prophets and holy people from the rest.

But also, in essence, you aren't actually asking 'for a miracle'. You are asking to merit a relationship with G-d in which He will show His closeness by doing miracles. This is something that Moshe prayed for.

### Antwort 2 (Score: -2)

Permissible and even desired, however, is to ask for divine help and miracles within the natural order; this is what we constantly do in the Amidah: for example, "רפאנו" (Heal us) – even if medicine has given up on us, we may hope for HaSchem's hidden miracles; such prayers are not a "test" of HaSchem, but an expression of our faith in His omnipotence within His creation; even when the situation seems hopeless – "אפילו חרב חדה מונחת על צווארו של אדם אל ימנע עצמו מן הרחמים" – "even if the sword is already on a person's neck, he should not withhold himself from mercy (prayer)" (Talmud, Berachot 10a); for HaShem can still save in natural ways, such as through circumstances we do not foresee; hoping for such miracles is part of our Bitachon (trust); the Chazon Ish teaches in Emunah u’Bitachon that true trust in HaSchem does not mean being certain that a miracle will happen, but knowing that nothing is beyond HaSchem's power and He does what is best – sometimes through wondrous providence.

Communal prayers for miracles for the entire people (or for the public sanctification of HaSchem's name) are permitted; thus, we may ask for the final redemption with great miracles, as in the Amidah: "May the offspring of David... quickly flourish," which according to the prophets will only happen with great miracles (etzion.org.il). Our prayers on Chanukah or Purim ("In the days of Mordechai and Esther") or Passover ("Who performed miracles for our ancestors" in Al HaNissim) remind HaSchem of past miracles and plead for similar acts of His grace. This is permissible according to the Poskim because it either (a) comes in the form of thanks/remembrance and not as a demanding new request, and (b) concerns the welfare of all Israel and the honor of HaSchem (halachayomit.co.il). Here, the principle of "the prayer of the many" applies: HaSchem graciously accepts the unified prayer of many. Nevertheless, even here, the Rema cautiously uses "perform miracles for us" (etzion.org.il), in the plural, to make it clear: We ask for miracles as once, for all of us.

For the Yehi Ratzon after Birkat Kohanim, it follows: One should preferably say (or think) "ועשה עמנו נפלאות וניסים" instead of "עמי", thereby transforming the request into a collective one. As shown above, this change is well supported by (Summary of the laws of deriving benefit from a miracle page 3 at bottom). However, if someone reads "עמי" from their Siddur, they need not be alarmed – they have not committed a sin. For in context, "with me" also refers to the supplicant as part of the community of Israel, not as an isolated individual. Additionally, one can interpret "perform wonders for me" as "work wonders upon me so that others may see and be inspired by You, HaShem" – analogous to David's "עשה עמי אות לטובה ויראו שונאי ויבושו" (Ps. 86:17) judaism.stackexchange.com. Either way, there is no real Tefilat Shav, as we do not dictate to HaSchem how He should help. We ask for His kindness; whether through ordinary means or astonishing miracles, we leave to Him.

Practical recommendation: In printed siddurim for communal use, it would be desirable to print the plural version to avoid misunderstandings—just as is customary in the table prayer on Chanukah. Anyone who wants to be personally devout (ba’al nefesh) can already adjust the wording for themselves. The main thing, however, is the inner attitude: earnestly ask HaShem for blessing, for help "from the heavens," and trust in Him—but do not expect "miracles on demand." Halacha and Aggadah teach us humility: "The one to whom a miracle happens often does not recognize it (as such)" (Ein ba'al ha-nes makir b'niso). Often, miracles work in secret. Therefore, most communities conclude with Birkat Kohanim with the threefold assurance of peace and blessing (Sim Shalom), nothing more is needed. If it is HaSchem's will to show us open miracles, we will thank Him for it—but until then, we walk in grateful humility and ask for "wonders and consolations" (niflaot v'nechamot) for the entire people.

title: How to make the gaps in tzitzit knots according to BIH
content:
# How to make the gaps in tzitzit knots according to BIH ## Frage

Is there a clear authoritative source that discusses how exactly to tie the tzitzit according to the Ben Ish Hai?

He says to tie them 7, 8, 11, 13, and to make gaps between every three wraps.

I haven't been able to find a clear source for the knotting each wrap that Sefaradim do. It seems to be just an oral mesorah from what I can tell. Is there anywhere that clearly discusses this and any halachic/kabbalistic impact of it?

Also, there seem to be two ways to go about the gaps the BIH says to make every three wraps:

  1. Just make a space and hope it doesn't close. Constantly adjust the wraps for the lifetime of the tzitzit.
  2. Put the shamash string in between the two sides (of 4 and 3 strings) at each gap. This forces the gap to stay. I saw this brought in a note at the back of the Ish Matzliach Mishna Berura (I don't remember which sefer he quoted). But he didn't say with confidence that this is the right way.

Are there any sources that discuss this?

Thank you.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The BIH is just quoting the Shaar hakavanot (tzitzit 6).

The Kaf Hachaim (11:47 (3)) writes to do this as 3 space 3 space 1, 2/3/3,3/3/3/2, 1/3/3/3/3.

The Brit Kehuna (90:1) writes to take the long string and put it thru in between each 3 so itll stay separate.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

The emphasis is on the blue. Not so much how many knots. The blue reminds us of the priests and the temple and the presence of God at Sinai. Sapir stone blue.

Isaiah 28.4 And the fading flower of his glorious beauty, which is on the head of the fat valley, shall be as the first-ripe fig before the summer, which when one looketh upon it, while it is yet in his hand he eateth it up.

The hebrew word is ציצת also. Wonder if there is a connection between a type of flower and the knots

Ezekial 8.3 And the form of a hand was put forth, and I was taken by a lock of my head;

Here tzit tzit is translated as locks of the hair. Similar idea.

title: Changing pronouncing some things to the Tiberian tradition?
content:
# Changing pronouncing some things to the Tiberian tradition? ## Frage

I understand that adopting the Tiberian pronunciation tradition might be problematic altogether because no existing Jewish community continue using it; and as far as I know, it is mainly based on scholarly reconstruction.

Assuming it’s okay in the first place, is there room for adopting a mixed pronunciation, with traits from both the Tiberian pronunciation and from existing pronunciation minhagim? (This would also greatly aid a learner of Hebrew in memorizing correct spelling, avoiding confusion of letters which have the same pronunciation.)

For example, the following:

  • using the Tiberian Resh (to distinguish few cases when it has dagesh).
  • using waw for letter ו as distinguished from ב in line with Iraqi minhag.
  • pronouncing shwa na as a "uh" as done by Ashkenazim.
  • pronouncing צ as ṣ or "saw" sound as done by Sepharadim, and not as tz as Ashkenazim.
  • pronouncing hiriq yod as a long -ee sound as in see.
  • doubling letters with daghesh hazak

In what context (personal learning, public reading, etc.) are such chages permitted? May any other changes also be adopted?

title: What Jewish sources address the shape of the Earth?
content:
# What Jewish sources address the shape of the Earth? ## Frage

What are the explicit statements in Jewish literature—from Tanach, Talmud, Midrash, Kabbalah, Jewish Thought, Rishonim or Acharonim—that describe the shape of the Earth?

  1. How is a spherical model reconciled with the language of Genesis 1, which uses terms like רָקִיעַ, firmament, and phrases that to a plain reader might suggest a flat earth with a dome overhead?

  2. Were there opposing views? Did any significant authorities maintain a different model (like a flat earth) based on their reading of the Torah or other sources?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: -1)

"The corners of the earth" described by Job 38:13 appears to falsify the globe theory. As to the Greeks, there's plenty of problems relying on Greek philosophers including the fact that the Alexandria library burned up circa 48 bc. Plus there are documents of numerous Greek philosophers (who argued for flat planets such as Anaximander, Anaximenes, Xenophanes, etc. A number of ancient Chinese philosophers also argued for flat earth. Isaiah 11:12 appears to corroborate "the four corners of the earth" and that's not really a round earth. 1Chronicles 16:30 implies a stationary planet: "The world stands firm; it cannot be shaken." Standing firm is a Flat Earth premise and antithetical to a twirling Globe. Psalms 104:5 does not support a twirling globe either: "He established the earth on its foundations". What did Hashem say through prophet Isaiah in 45:12? "My own hands stretched out the heavens..." If you've ever pitched a tent you may recall that the ground cloth fabric is laid first and on flat ground not a curve. What did Hashem tell Isaiah in 40:22? He seems to have "spread out" the planet "like a tent". Point is - Judaic scripture seems to support the Flat Earth Theory and may falsify the Globe Theory.

### Antwort 2 (Score: -2)

An explicit testimony of the Flat Earth approach is demonstrated in the Talmud (Psachim 94a), between the 3rd and the 5th centuries CE:

"The Jewish Sages say that during the day the sun travels beneath the firmament and is therefore visible, and at night it travels above the firmament.
And the sages of the nations of the world (the Roman philosophers) say that during the day the sun travels beneath the firmament, and at night it travels beneath the earth and around to the other side of the world.
Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi said: And the statement of the sages of the nations of the world appears to be more accurate than our statement. A proof of this is that during the day, springs that originate deep in the ground are cold, and during the night they are hot compared to the air temperature, which supports the theory that these springs are warmed by the sun as it travels beneath the earth."

Interestingly, it appears that one of the most distinguished rabbis of the 16th century (!), Rabbi Yossef Karo, agrees with Rabbi Judah that at night the sun warms the springs from beneath (Beit_Yosef Orach_Chayim 455.1.1):

אך נראה לי הטעם לפי שהחמה מהלכת בלילה תחת הקרקע
כחכמי א"ה בפרק מי שהיה טמא (פסחים צד:) וא"ר נראים דבריהם

title: Why isn't there a complete prohibition against working on the Sabbath?
content:
# Why isn't there a complete prohibition against working on the Sabbath? ## Frage

Following "babysitting-on-shabbos".

Regardless of how a Jew is paid Kosherly for a job they perform for another Jew on the Sabbath, the Talmudic (Nedarim 37a) and Halachic discussion is ALL about the payment (see Peninei Halakha) and not the fact that a Jew is working on the Sabbath.

Unless a person's job requires rest, even if someone does not perform any forbidden Melachah, any work would directly contradict the core idea of having a full day of rest, because a person's focus would necessarily be on the job and not on resting on the Holy Day (based on Isaiah 58.13 "אִם־תָּשִׁיב מִשַּׁבָּת רַגְלֶךָ עֲשׂוֹת חֲפָצֶךָ בְּיוֹם קׇדְשִׁי וְקָרָאתָ לַשַּׁבָּת עֹנֶג לִקְדוֹשׁ יְהֹוָה מְכֻבָּד וְכִבַּדְתּוֹ מֵעֲשׂוֹת דְּרָכֶיךָ מִמְּצוֹא חֶפְצְךָ וְדַבֵּר דָּבָר׃").

Similarly, [if the employer is Jewish] he would be "guilty" of causing another Jew to desecrate the Sabbath.

Why isn't there a complete Halachic prohibition against working on the Sabbath?

title: Wearing a Tallis by Mincha
content:
# Wearing a Tallis by Mincha ## Frage

The Shulchan Aruch writes that one of the requirements to folding clothes on shabbos is that it be needed for that day. The Mishna Berura says therefore, one may not fold a tallis on shabbos unless he’s in a place where people wear a tallis by mincha:

(יג) ללבשם בו ביום - ולכן אסור לקפל הטלית אע"פ שמצות ציצית כל היום ויכול להתעטף בו מ"מ כיון שאין בדעתו להתעטף בו אסור אם לא במקום שנהגו להתעטף בטליתות במנחה:

Does the Mishan Berura write this just to extrapolate and show how situations can change things, or is there an actual demographic or community that he’s referencing that indeed wore or wears their tallis by mincha?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Some Yemenites wear a tallis at Shabbos Mincha.

title: When and why did Judaism shift away from naming a boy at birth to at the bris?
content:
# When and why did Judaism shift away from naming a boy at birth to at the bris? ## Frage

In Tanach boys are named at birth (even Yitzchak himself).

Binyamin is explicitly named at birth.

There's no mention of boys being named at their bris in either the Talmud or Rambam's Mishneh Torah, and if anything Tur seems to indicate that it preceded the bris.

R. Yehuda HaChasid (12th century) casually mentions that boys were named when they were (initially) placed in their crib (Sefer Chasidim 1140).

When and why did the custom change to delay the naming until the bris?

(See here, with my comment, that ostensibly provides an early source for the custom.)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

Chesed Le Avraham, Even Shetiya, Maayan 2 52:6 kabbalistically addresses why but not the when:

והנה בנפש ורוח יש אחיזה לחצונים קצת, והטעם כי שורש הדינין יניקתן מן התפארת והמלכות שהם סוד הרוח והנפש, אמנם מן הבינה ולמעלה אין להם אחיזה כלל, ובזה יובן הטעם למה הלבושים של נפש רוח נשמה הם בסוד אהי"ה כנזכר, והוא לפי ששם אהי"ה הוא סוד הבינה שממנה בורחים החיצונים, ולזה כל עוד שיש לו אחיזה לערלה והטומאה באדם אי אפשר שיחול עליו הנשמה ולזה אי אפשר שיקרא בשם ישראל, ולזה נהגו שלא יקראו לו שם רק אחר המילה שמאחר שכבר נסתלקה הערלה והטומאה אז ודאי תחול עליו סוד הנשמה, ר"ל נשמה של הנפש, ובזה יקרא בשם אדם ישראלי שמעון וראובן וכיוצא, א"כ נתבאר כי הסיבה שנקרא אדם הוא על ידי מצות המילה. וזמש"ל:

And behold, in the soul and spirit, there is some hold for the external forces. The reason is that the root of judgment derives from the attributes of beauty and sovereignty, which are the mysteries of spirit and soul. However, from understanding and above, they have no hold at all. In this, one can understand the reason why the garments of the soul, spirit, and breath are in the secret of Ehyeh, as mentioned. This is because the name Ehyeh is the mystery of understanding from which the external forces flee. Therefore, as long as there is a hold for uncircumcision and impurity in a person, it is impossible for the soul to rest upon him, and thus, he cannot be called by the name Israel. Therefore, it is customary not to call him by that name until after the circumcision, for once the uncircumcision and impurity have been removed, the mystery of the soul will certainly take effect upon him—meaning, the soul of the lower aspect. In this case, he will be called by the name of an Israelite, like Shimon, Reuben, and the like. Thus, it becomes clear that the reason he is called 'Adam' is through the commandment of circumcision. This is the essence of the matter.

title: Requirement for Hechsher in an open kitchen
content:
# Requirement for Hechsher in an open kitchen ## Frage

The Takana of the "Va'ad Arba Arotzot" (see here) requires that all food sold for profit requires a Hechsher.

Is the requirement necessary if the entire kitchen operation is on public display, from opening sealed packages bearing a hechsher to cooking and serving?

For example, a street food cart, or kids selling lemonade?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The Takana of the "Va'ad Arba Arotzot" provides no exception or leniency due to the public visibility of a kitchen's operations as long as the food is being sold.

R' Chaim Bleier in his publication Chukai Chaim offers, in my opinion, the best English explanation of the Takana and provides sources. (In particular paragraphs 10-14).

Although the application of the Takana to a publicly visible kitchen or stall might be purely due to the concept of "Lo Plug", there are still logical reasons why it might apply. Even the most simple operation, like a lemonade stand could have a plethora of Shailos which could be negated by even a low level Hashgacha. I will name a few here and invite commenters to provide more:

  1. Kashrus of the lemons (are they from Israel with all relevant complications)
  2. Lemon peels cleaned for Scale Insects?
  3. Kashrus of Knife, Chopping Board, Squeezing Utensil, Pitchers (complications could arise due to the fact lemons are a Davar Charif)
  4. Were relevant keilim Toiveled? (not a kashrus issue per se)
  5. Is the stall open on Shabbos?
  6. Kashrus of sugars, flavorings and additives if applicable.

title: What aspect of Hashem is ado-nai?
content:
# What aspect of Hashem is ado-nai? ## Frage

If the 4-letter name YHWH indicates mercy and the word "Elokim" points to the quality of justice, then what does the word אֲדֹנָ֖י mean when used on its own? Is it, in meaning, associated with the 4-letter name which is replaced by it, or is it a distinct name with separate attributes?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Sorry, I don't know how to answer this without "essay" format. It's a very good question, but to properly answer it, there is a lot to get through. I have done my best to not condense it too much, and I welcome questions, and suggest reading up the citations for further study.

The Name of Adnut, Lordship, should be taken to mean that Hashem is the absolute Master of nature. He created it and is creating it every moment, from absolute and utter nothingness, and is therefore in complete control. This is true Lordship (see many places, e.g. Sefer Maamarim 5659 Sukkot Night 2).

This is why it is sometimes also associated with the aspect of "din" (it contains those letters in it - see R' Yosef Chayyim's Aderet Eliyahu on Parashat Shoftim; See also the Baalei Berit Avram on Parashat Shoftim), because "natural law" appears to be "logical". "Survival of the fittest", "one must earn one's bread with the sweat of one's brow" etc. Justice is cold, harsh, but fair - but certainly not "compassionate". If you combine the Name with "E-l", you get the same gematria as "tzav", which the Arizal associates with idolatry. In this world, we can look around, and say "where's the compassion?" and make a mistake and think that there's no Hashem, and this is the essence of idolatry (see Derech Mitzvotecha Mitzvat Korban Pesach).

However, there is a famous combination of the Names Adnut and Havaya, which is taken to mean that we restore this seeming schism when we look closely and see that everything actually is Hashem's compassion - Havaya is all there is. Shem Adnut also has the same gematria as "Heichal", i.e. the Beit Hamikdash, the seat of Hashem's righteous judges, who issue righteous judgements, and this creates this very combination of the Names, in a "higher unification" (Chomat Anach on Shoftim 2:18 - see what I wrote here for more). Interestingly, the Beit Hamikdash is the one place where we pronounce Hashem's Name, instead of pronouncing it b'Shem Adnut!

By studying Hashem's Laws (i.e. His righteousness and justice), we see the compassion. It's only right that if I have more money than I need, and someone else has less than they need, that I should give him some of my money. It's fair (tzeddaka = tzedek), but it's also a clear demonstration of how when we follow Hashem's laws, we are producing compassion*. Another example are the laws of slavery, i.e. treat your slave like a mentsch. It's only fair, but it shows the deep compassion we should have for every human being.

See Hemshech Samech Vav, especially the later ma'amarim for extensive coverage on this concept of how halacha reveals Hashem. See also Likkutei Torah of the Alter Rebbe on Parashat Bechukotai.

If you want to get specific, and go deeper (as your question and comments indicate), this Name is the name of Malchut of Atzilut. Much of what we said above is very similar to other vertlach about Elokim. I.e. when we see through the "mask" of the world, that all is Him, we are "shown to know, that Hashem is Elokim... Ein Old Milvado" (Devarim 4:39). So what's the similarity with Elokim and Adnut?

Well, they both pertain to the obscuring, the "tzimtzum" Hashem creates in order for there to be this world. Elokim is His Name of Gevura, which represents His power of restriction and limitation. He uses it in order to restrict His Light so that the world, paradoxically, can be revealed. A nice mashal used is that of the sun. If the earth were inside the sun, we would not be able to see it, as it would be totally outshined by the sun's light. Therefore, the earth is at a distance from the sun, and only lit up by "rays" that have left the sun and travelled a long way, and now we can see the earth (see Derech Mitzvotecha Haamanut Elokut 6). This is another way of saying that if we saw just how good and compassionate Hashem is, we would lose our free will in that we would choose Him without a second thought, but because He "hides behind cold, harsh nature", we have an opportunity to choose Him from our own free will.

So, Elokim is like a "shield" to Havaya (see Tanya Shaar Hayichud VehaEmuna), restricting our perception so we are not blinded and nullified by Hashem. This is where Shem Adnut comes in.

Hashem's Malchut is His power of Speech - He speaks the world into creation. In order for there to be a world that is, so to speak, "separate" from Him, He needs to use His power of Gevura - as above - and condense His Light and Being into letters, speaking words, as it is written in Sefer Maamarim 5659 Sukkot Night 2:

וז״ש כבוד מלכותך כו׳ וגבורתך ידברו, דבכדי שיהיו האותיות דמלכות בבחי׳ יש, שיוכל להיות מקור להוות עולמות בי״ע, זהו ע״י וגבורתך דוקא, בחי׳ גבורה דז״א, לצמצם את האור, ועי״ז דוקא נעשו האותיות בבחי׳ יש כו׳

And this is the meaning of what is written: "The glory of Your kingship... and Your might they will speak." For in order that the letters of Malchut should be in the category of "somethingness", such that they can be the source for the coming into being of the worlds of Creation (BiYA), this is specifically through "Your Might," the aspect of Gevura of Ze'ir Anpin, to contract the light. And specifically through this the letters become in the category of "somethingness", etc.

Why? Well, words are very superficial and external in comparison to the concepts they are representing - like a mashal. They are "just" words, and therefore this is a great contraction and restriction of Hashem's Light. It is through these words that He creates the world we live in, i.e. the world of nature that I spoke about above.

The fact that He is speaking the world into creation is indeed why He is the absolute and utter Master and Lord of the world (it's His story!), hence the Name Adnut.

For a bit more detail - the power of Malchut is the most external power of Hashem's Being. The world of Atzilut is not a "mashal", it is genuinely His very Being, although it has being somewhat restricted and limited by Gevura. What this means is that He identifies with Atzilut, He speaks in the first person. "My Chochma", "My Gevura", "My Malchut". Still, the worlds created by His Malchut are from Him, but He considers them "external" to Him - we are separate from Him. Therefore there is a transition point and this happens in Malchut of Atzilut, part of which actually becomes the highest point of the created worlds.

This is Shem Adnut, and is also referred to as the Shechina, the Kise HaKavod, Mimaaleh Kol Almin, and the parsa/parochet. It is where Hashem "puts on His mask" as it were (hester panim; see Worldmask by R' Tatz), and hides behind nature. We must know though that nature is a perfect mashal of Him (i.e. the words He speaks to create the mashal are all about Him, the Nimshal, authentically), and therefore if we study it through the lens of Torah, and particularly, study His Laws (as we we wrote above), we will see through the mashal, and create gilui panim; this Yichud Elyon cited by Chomat Anach above.

tl;dr:

Havaya - Hashem's Name that is utterly beyond. Pertains to "being", but also pertains to His lofty goodness and compassion.

Elokim - Hashem's power of Gevura - restriction and limitation.

Adnut - Hashem's Name that is associated with His power of action and creation (Malchut), where, after He limits Himself by hiding behind nature, His Kingship is revealed as His being utterly in charge of nature - Lording over it.

Our job is to realise that Hashem's goodness is still here in the world of nature, and is only hidden in order to allow free will. We study His Torah, and realise that the Master of Nature is actually one and the same as Havaya, the Infinite, Transcendent Havaya, Who is Good and Compassionate. Nature only exists due to His immense power of Gevura that gives us this impression, but in truth, He is Elokim, and the Master of Nature - all is One.

For a thoroughly clear, comprehensive treatment of this topic, please see this Torat Chaim by the Mittler Rebbe, of blessed and righteous memory: בעז״ה תורת אדמו״ר הרב ר׳ דובער פרשה וארא באברוסק שנת תקפ״ד יום א - הוא אהרן ומשה. You'll find he doesn't mention din at all, and focuses primarily on Hashem's Kingship and the concept of the unification with Havaya, through Pesukei Dezimra and the first two verses of Shema.

* There's an amazing Chida (Rosh David, Vayachel, quoting Parashat Derachim) that explains how this fulfils Hashem's "first thought" to create the world with din, instead of "combining" it with mercy. We actually transform the din into mercy, so the world is no longer a "combination", but actually made out of din, like He always wanted!

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

  1. ADNY corresponds to Malkhut-Mouth, as in (Ps. 51:51) "Adonai open my lips; and my mouth shall show forth thy praise." There's a writeup on the 10 Sfirot and the associated 10 names here. These names are printed in Siddur Avodat Hashem, along with more detail like the Eyes, Nose, etc.

  2. Yes it's associated with the Tetragrammaton; it's the Tetragrammaton's pronunciation in this world. We see it written YKWK and pronounce it ADNY. Siddurim like Avodat Hashem have ADNY inside the last Hei of YKWK and it means "Lord of all."

  3. ADNY is the "sheath" of the sword YKWK (the tip, blade, and two edges):

    T. Zohar 54b:

    דרישא דחרבא איהי י', גופא דחרבא ו', תרין פיפיות דילה ה"ה, נרתקא דילה אדנ"י, (וחרבא יקו"ק), וכד איהי יקו"ק בר משכינתיה, איהו דין דחתיך מכל סטרא, כד עאל בנרתקה אתעביד רחמי ולא חתיך דינין, ורזא דחרבא בנרתקה, יאקדונק"י הכי ודאי:

    "The head of the sword is the Yod (י), the body of the sword is the Vav (ו), and its two edges are the two Hehs (ה ה). Its sheath is Adonai (אדנ"י), and the sword is YHVH (יקו"ק). And when it is YHVH without its Shekhinah (Divine Presence), it is judgment that cuts from every side. But when it enters its sheath, it becomes mercy and does not cut judgments. And the secret of the sword in its sheath is certainly Yakdonki (יאקדונק"י)."

  4. In the verse that you link Ex. 15:17 Hashem corresponds to the upper Jerusalem and ADNY to the lower Jerusalem; the word Mikdash is even interposed between the two names. H' will cause the upper to descend on the lower, uniting them, hubrah yachdaw, bb"a.

תְּבִאֵ֗מוֹ וְתִטָּעֵ֙מוֹ֙ בְּהַ֣ר נַחֲלָֽתְךָ֔        מָכ֧וֹן לְשִׁבְתְּךָ֛ פָּעַ֖לְתָּ יְהֹוָ֑ה        מִקְּדָ֕שׁ אֲדֹנָ֖י כּוֹנְנ֥וּ יָדֶֽיךָ׃        
You will bring them and plant them in Your own mountain, The place You made to dwell in, יהוה, The sanctuary, O my lord, which Your hands established.

Zohar, Vayeshev 9:100 According to our teachers, God fashioned the lower Jerusalem on the model of the heavenly Jerusalem, the one exactly facing the other, as it is written: “the place, O Lord, which thou hast made for thee to dwell in, the Sanctuary, O Lord, which thy hands have established” (Ex. 15, 17). The expression “that art builded” indicates that God will in time to come cause the upper Jerusalem to descend below; this is further proved by the phrase “as a city that is compact (she-hubrah) together”, where the term hubrah (lit. she is joined), written in the singular, indicates that the Mother has joined the Daughter and the two are become as one.

  1. There are 169 occurrence of ADNY in T. Zohar.

  • Its Yud represents Malkhut

    ואי תמרון אמאי צריכין למהוי תרוייהו בכל בר נש בכל יומא, בגין דלא תשתכח שכינתא דאיהו יו"ד מן אדנ"י, יחידה בלא קודשא בריך הוא דאיהו יו"ד מן יקו"ק, וצריך בר נש דלא ישתכח בכל יומא פחות מתרוייהו,

  • It is the Shekhina and speech in relation to "the voice riding in your mouth" YKWK and you pair them and the hint is "ADNY open my lips" etc.

    ובעל כנפים יגיד דבר, דא צלותא, דמטי לה עד צדיק חי עלמין, כליל ח"י ברכאן, דאתמר בהון וברכות לראש צדיק חי העולמים, וצלותא איהו דבור דרכיבת עליה, ואיהו מרכבה לגבה ביומין דחול, ודא שכינתא ודא אדנ"י, קול רכיב בפומוי דא יקו"ק, ורזא דדבור אדנ"י שפתי תפתח וגומר, ואיהו מרכבה לתרוייהו כגוונא דא יאקדונק"י, והכי סליק מלא"ך כחושבן תרין שמהן כחדא

    דבכל אזכרה דיפוק מפומוי בכל אתר ובכל ממלל, צריך לכוונא דיבור באדנ"י קול ביקו"ק, ולייחדא לון כחדא, ביחודא דאיהו יחיד נעלם

  • Y from ADNY is the arm knot of the tefilin, and ADNY is the four compartments.

    כל קשר איהו מסטרא דאת י', ותרין קשרין אינון, דאינון קשר דרישא קשר דדרועא שמאלא, ואינון ה' מן יאקדונק"י, יקו"ק ארבע פרשיין דתפלי, וראו כל עמי הארץ כי שם ה' וכו', אדנ"י ארבע בתי דתפלי, אקי"ק אשר אקי"ק מלגאו דתפלי

  • Its Yud is the "calm quiet voice [praising God]" in the appearance to Elijah, appearing afterwards, fourth in Ezekiel's vision, because "Hashem was not in the fire," but rather HWH was riding on the triplet "storm wind from the north, huge cloud, and flashing fire" -- then the Yud appears which is the Y' of Hashem and of Adn"y; there enters the King which is Hashem.

In Tanya, Shaar Hayichud vihaemunah chapter 7, the Alter Rebbe contrasts the names Adnus and Havayah, saying that the former is how Hashem is manifested within the division of space and time (malchis, kingship), while Havayah refers to how He creates all past, present and future as one essential point:

Chapter 7 פרק ז The Alter Rebbe explained in the previous chapters that the Scriptural statement that “in the heavens above and upon the earth below, there is none other” is not intended to negate the existence of another god. Rather, it tells us that Divine Unity is such that there is no true existence other than G‑d, for all created beings are completely nullified in relation to Him and are united with Him. This is not perceived by them nor manifest in them only because of the tzimtzum which conceals the Divine life-force that continuously brings about their existence ex nihilo. Being unable to perceive this life-force, they consider themselves to be independently existing entities.

This concealment, of course, applies only to created beings but not to their Creator. From the Divine perspective, there is no concealment whatsoever, inasmuch as Havayah and Elokim are truly one: the concealment effected by Elokim thus does not act as a concealment for Havayah.

The Alter Rebbe will now explain how the above enables us to understand the teaching of the Zohar that Shema Yisrael is “higher-level Unity” and Baruch shem is “lower-level Unity.”

Were Divine Unity merely to signify the existence of one G‑d, it would be impossible to speak of higher and lower levels of Unity. According to the above explanation, however, that Divine Unity means the nullity of created beings and their unity with G‑d, it is indeed possible to speak of two diverse levels of Unity.

In this sense, “higher-level Unity” refers to the Divine faculty of creative speech (otherwise known as malchut), considered at the stage in which it is still found within its source. By way of analogy, the seminal letters of a person’s speech are first encapsulated within his thought and emotions, which will ultimately be responsible for his subsequent speech. (The Rebbe notes that “this was explained in Part I, chs. 20-21.”)

The same is true Above: When supernal creative speech is at the stage in which it is still included within the supernal attributes—which, being infinite, are too lofty to serve as a source of creation, for it is inherently limited to space and time—creation as it exists in its source is united with G‑d at the higher level of Unity. Its manner of nullification is then similar to the nullification of the sun’s rays as they are found within the sun-globe.

When, however, the Divine creative power of speech (or malchut), after undergoing a process of tzimtzumim, descends to a level at which it is able to serve as a source for creation, then the term “lower-level Unity” applies. Created beings at this level cannot be said to be completely and utterly nullified. For inasmuch as this level becomes the actual source of created beings, they must perforce have some measure of identity in relation to it.

Although this level, too, is pervaded by the Ein Sof-light which unites with the Divine faculty of creative speech, this unification is nevertheless one of “lower-level Unity,” wherein created beings are seen to have some measure of existence—albeit a nullified form of existence, but existence nonetheless.

With the above in mind, we may now understand the statement in the holy Zohar that the verse Shema Yisrael is yichuda ilaah (“higher-level Unity”) and that the verse Baruch shem kvod malchuto leolam vaed is yichuda tataah (“lower-level Unity”).

וּבָזֶה יוּבַן מַה שֶּׁכָּתוּב בַּזֹּהַר הַקָּדוֹשׁ, דְּפָסוּק "שְׁמַע יִשְׂרָאֵל" – הוּא "יִחוּדָא עִילָּאָה", וּ"בָרוּךְ שֵׁם כְּבוֹד מַלְכוּתוֹ לְעוֹלָם וָעֶד" – הוּא "יִחוּדָא תַּתָּאָה",

The connection between the last mentioned verse and Divine Unity is now explained:

For1 vaed is equivalent to echad through the substitution of letters.2

כִּי "וָעֶד" הוּא "אֶחָד" בְּחִלּוּפֵי אַתְוָון.

The alef of echad interchanges with the vav of vaed since both letters belong to the same group of letters, viz., alef, hey, vav, yud (which, the Rebbe notes, are known as otiyot hahemshech, the “connective letters”). The chet of echad interchanges with the ayin of vaed since they share the same source (motza) in the organs of speech and thus both belong to the category of “guttural letters,” viz., alef, hey, chet, ayin. Finally, the large daled of echad transposes into the small daled of vaed.

The cause and reason for this tzimtzum and concealment with which the Holy One, blessed be He, obscured and hid the life force of the world, making it appear as an independently existing entity [is as follows]:

כִּי הִנֵּה, סִיבַּת וְטַעַם הַצִּמְצוּם וְהַהֶסְתֵּר הַזֶּה, שֶׁהִסְתִּיר וְהֶעֱלִים הַקָּדוֹשׁ־בָּרוּךְ־הוּא אֶת הַחַיּוּת שֶׁל הָעוֹלָם כְּדֵי שֶׁיִּהְיֶה הָעוֹלָם נִרְאֶה דָּבָר נִפְרָד בִּפְנֵי עַצְמוֹ,

I.e., the Alter Rebbe is asking why it is indeed necessary for the world to appear as an independently existing entity. What would be lacking if the world would be perceived in its true state—as an entity wholly nullified in relation to its source? The reason for this is as follows:

הִנֵּה הוּא יָדוּעַ לַכֹּל, כִּי תַּכְלִית בְּרִיאַת הָעוֹלָם הוּא בִּשְׁבִיל הִתְגַּלּוּת מַלְכוּתוֹ יִתְבָּרֵךְ,

for “there is no king without a nation.”3

דְּ"אֵין מֶלֶךְ בְּלֹא עָם",

The word עָם (“nation”) is related etymologically to the word עוֹמְמוֹת (“dimmed, extinguished”), as in the expression גְחָלִים עוֹמְמוֹת (Rashi on Judges 5:14), describing coals in which the fire is not to be seen. In terms of the relationship of a king and his subjects, the word עָם thus signifies those whose relationship with the king is not readily apparent,

פֵּירוּשׁ "עָם" – מִלְּשׁוֹן "עוֹמְמוֹת",

for they—the subjects who comprise a nation—are separate entities, distinct and distant from the level of the king; only upon them does the king reign as a result of their nullifying themselves to him.

שֶׁהֵם דְּבָרִים נִפְרָדִים וְזָרִים וּרְחוֹקִים מִמַּעֲלַת הַמֶּלֶךְ,

For even if he had very many children, the term “kingship” would not apply to them, inasmuch as the king’s children are part of the king himself,

כִּי אִילּוּ אֲפִילוּ הָיוּ לוֹ בָּנִים רַבִּים מְאֹד – לֹא שַׁיָּיךְ שֵׁם "מְלוּכָה" עֲלֵיהֶם,

nor is it possible for a king to reign even over nobles alone.

וְכֵן אֲפִילוּ עַל שָׂרִים לְבַדָּם,

Although they—unlike a king’s children—are not part of him, nevertheless, since their position puts them in constant and close contact with him, thereby lending them some of the aspects of kingship, the king cannot reign over nobles alone.

Only “in a numerous nation is the glory of the king.”4

רַק "בְּרוֹב עָם" – דַּוְוקָא – "הַדְרַת מֶלֶךְ".

Only upon strangers can sovereignty apply. The same is true Above: The ultimate intent of the revelation of Divine Kingship finds expression in His reigning over lowly created beings, who perceive themselves as existing independently of Him—so that they, too, should humble and nullify themselves before Him.

The Name that indicates the attribute of G‑d’s malchut (“kingship”) is the Name of Adnut (“Lordship”), for His kingship lies in the fact that He is L-rd of the whole universe.

וְשֵׁם הַמּוֹרֶה עַל מִדַּת מַלְכוּתוֹ יִתְבָּרֵךְ, הוּא שֵׁם אַדְנוּת, כִּי הוּא אֲדוֹן כָּל הָאָרֶץ.

Thus, it is this attribute (viz., malchut) and this Name (viz., the Name of Adnut, signifying lordship) which bring the world into existence and sustain it so that it should be as it is now—

וְנִמְצָא, כִּי מִדָּה זוֹ וְשֵׁם זֶה – הֵן הַמְּהַוִּין וּמְקַיְּימִין הָעוֹלָם, לִהְיוֹת עוֹלָם כְּמוֹת שֶׁהוּא עַכְשָׁיו,

a completely independent and separate entity, and not absolutely nullified,

יֵשׁ גָּמוּר וְדָבָר נִפְרָד בִּפְנֵי עַצְמוֹ וְאֵינוֹ בָּטֵל בִּמְצִיאוּת מַמָּשׁ,

for with the withdrawal of this attribute and this Name from the world, G‑d forbid, the world would revert to its source in the ‘‘word of G‑d” and the “breath of His mouth,” where it would be completely nullified, and the name “world” could not be applied to it at all.

כִּי בְּהִסְתַּלְּקוּת מִדָּה זוֹ וְשֵׁם זֶה חַס וְשָׁלוֹם, הָיָה הָעוֹלָם חוֹזֵר לִמְקוֹרוֹ בִּדְבַר ה' וְרוּחַ פִּיו יִתְבָּרֵךְ, וּבָטֵל שָׁם בִּמְצִיאוּת מַמָּשׁ, וְלֹא הָיָה שֵׁם "עוֹלָם" עָלָיו כְּלָל.

Inherent in the name “world” is being and limitation. However, in the state in which the world finds itself within its source, it would have no “being” and would not be limited.

The term “world” can be applied solely to [that which possesses] the dimensions of space and time,

וְהִנֵּה, גֶּדֶר וּבְחִינַת שֵׁם "עוֹלָם" נוֹפֵל עַל בְּחִינַת מָקוֹם וּבְחִינַת זְמַן דַּוְקָא.

“space” referring to east, west, north, and south, upward and downward,

בְּחִינַת מָקוֹם – הוּא: מִזְרָח וּמַעֲרָב, צָפוֹן, דָּרוֹם, מַעְלָה וּמַטָּה.

and “time” referring to past, present, and future.

בְּחִינַת זְמַן – עָבָר, הֹוֶה וְעָתִיד.

Only with regard to entities that are subject to the limitations of space and time can the term “world” be applied.

All these dimensions of space and time have no relation to the holy supernal attributes of the World of Atzilut because those attributes are infinite.

וְהִנֵּה, כָּל בְּחִינוֹת אֵלּוּ אֵין לָהֶן שַׁיָּיכוּת בַּמִּדּוֹת הַקְּדוֹשׁוֹת הָעֶלְיוֹנוֹת,

As explained earlier, the attribute of chesed is infinite; so, too, are the other attributes in the World of Atzilut. Hence, by definition, they are not at all subject to the limitations of space and time.

Only concerning the attribute of [G‑d’s] malchut is it possible to say that He is King “Above without end and below without limit” and likewise in all four directions.

כִּי אִם בְּמִדַּת מַלְכוּתוֹ יִתְבָּרֵךְ לְבַדָּהּ, שַׁיָּיךְ לוֹמַר שֶׁהוּא יִתְבָּרֵךְ מֶלֶךְ לְמַעְלָה עַד אֵין קֵץ וּלְמַטָּה עַד אֵין תַּכְלִית, וְכֵן לְד' סִטְרִין,

This means to say that G‑d is King of all creatures, from the very highest to the very lowest. Thus, when speaking of malchut, it is in order to use terminology that has some relationship to space, such as “higher” and “lower.” This indicates that malchut itself has some relationship to the aspects of time and space.

The same is true concerning the dimension of time, i.e., that the attribute of malchut is in some small measure related to time, as it is written:

וְכֵן בִּבְחִינַת זְמַן –

“G‑d reigns, G‑d has reigned, G‑d will reign.”5

"ה' מֶלֶךְ, ה' מָלָךְ, ה' יִמְלוֹךְ"

I.e., G‑d’s reign is related to present, past, and future—the dimension of time.

Thus, the life-force of space, and likewise of time, and their coming into being from nothingness, and their existence as long as they shall exist, are from [G‑d’s] attribute of malchut and from the Name of Adnut.

וְנִמְצָא, שֶׁחַיּוּת הַמָּקוֹם וְכֵן חַיּוּת הַזְּמַן, וְהִתְהַוּוּתָם מֵאַיִן לְיֵשׁ, וְקִיּוּמָם כָּל זְמַן קִיּוּמָם, הוּא מִמִּדַּת מַלְכוּתוֹ יִתְבָּרֵךְ וְשֵׁם אַדְנוּת בָּרוּךְ־הוּא.

Now, since [G‑d’s] attribute of malchut is united with His Essence and Being in an absolute union, as will be explained,

וּלְפִי שֶׁמִּדַּת מַלְכוּתוֹ יִתְבָּרֵךְ מְיוּחֶדֶת בְּמַהוּתוֹ וְעַצְמוּתוֹ יִתְבָּרֵךְ בְּתַכְלִית הַיִּחוּד, כְּמוֹ שֶׁיִּתְבָּאֵר,

space and time which are created from malchut are therefore also completely nullified in relation to [G‑d’s] Essence and Being, just as sunlight whilst it is still within the orb of the sun is nullified in the sun.

הִלְכָּךְ, גַּם בְּחִינַת הַמָּקוֹם וְהַזְּמַן בְּטֵילִים בִּמְצִיאוּת מַמָּשׁ לְגַבֵּי מַהוּתוֹ וְעַצְמוּתוֹ יִתְבָּרֵךְ, כְּבִיטּוּל אוֹר הַשֶּׁמֶשׁ בַּשֶּׁמֶשׁ.

This means to say: As long as malchut still exists in a state of complete union with G‑d’s Essence and Being, space and time—the source of worlds—as found within the attribute of malchut are utterly nullified relative to G‑d.

This state is called “higher-level Unity.” It exists only before the descent of malchut through various tzimtzumim in order to vest itself in the lower worlds, thereby creating them and providing them with life. It is then that the worlds enjoy the state of “higher-level Unity” because from the perspective of the pristine source of malchut and Adnut, which brings about their existence, their actual creation is as yet inconceivable, inasmuch as malchut and Adnut are still in a state of inclusion within their source. Consequently, space and time “exist” there in the same manner as the light of the sun “exists” within the sun in a state of complete nullity.

And this is the [meaning of the] alternation of the [letters of the] Name of Adnut with the [letters of the] Name Havayah.

וְזֶהוּ שִׁילּוּב שֵׁם אַדְנוּת בְּשֵׁם הֲוָיָ"ה,

When the letters of one Divine Name are alternated with the letters of another, the Name whose initial letter appears first is the dominant one, the second Name being intertwined and encompassed by it. If, for example, the first letter is the initial of the Divine Name that designates chesed and the second letter is the initial of the Divine Name that designates gevurah, the revelation of chesed will predominate.

One speaks of “the alternation of the [letters of the] Name of Adnut with the [letters of the] Name Havayah” when referring to malchut and Adnut while they are still united with G‑d’s Essence and Being, which are too lofty to serve as a source for created beings.

The eventual source of the existence of created beings is malchut and Adnut. Nevertheless, since the Divine Name Havayah is dominant—i.e., since Adnut is submerged within Havayah—all “existence” is completely nullified in relation to G‑d’s Essence and Being, just as sunlight is devoid of all identity within the sun.

The Name Havayah indicates that He transcends time, that “He was, is, and will be—all at the same instant,”

כִּי שֵׁם הֲוָיָ"ה מוֹרֶה שֶׁהוּא לְמַעְלָה מִן הַזְּמַן, שֶׁהוּא הָיָה הֹוֶה וְיִהְיֶה בְּרֶגַע אֶחָד

Past, present and future meld into one within the Name Havayah, indicating that Havayah transcends time,

as is stated (6in Raaya Mehemna on Parashat Pinchas),

כְּמוֹ שֶׁכָּתוּב [בְּרַעְיָא מְהֵימְנָא פָּרָשַׁת פִּנְחָס],

and likewise, [the Name Havayah] transcends space, for [Havayah] continuously brings into existence the whole dimension of space, from the uppermost level [of space] to the lowermost level [of space] and in the four directions.

וְכֵן לְמַעְלָה מִבְּחִינַת מָקוֹם, כִּי הוּא מְהַוֶּה תָּמִיד אֶת כָּל בְּחִינַת הַמָּקוֹם כּוּלּוֹ מִלְמַעְלָה עַד לְמַטָּה וּלְד' סִטְרִין.

Clearly, the Divine Name Havayah transcends time and space.

Malchut and Adnut, however, do bear some relation to time and space. Nevertheless, since the letters of the Name of Adnut are interspaced within the letters of the Name Havayah, the dimensions of time and space are completely nullified in relation to G‑d. This is the state called yichuda ilaah, or “higher-level Unity.”

Now, although G‑d transcends space and time, He is nevertheless also found below, within space and time—even as space and time, i.e., the dimensions that constitute the world, exist (in their own eyes) as independent entities,

וְהִנֵּה, אַף־עַל־פִּי שֶׁהוּא יִתְבָּרֵךְ לְמַעְלָה מֵהַמָּקוֹם וְהַזְּמַן, אַף־עַל־פִּי־כֵן – הוּא נִמְצָא גַּם לְמַטָּה בְּמָקוֹם וּזְמַן,

that is, He unites with His attribute of malchut, from which space and time are derived and come into existence.

דְּהַיְינוּ, שֶׁמִּתְיַיחֵד בְּמִדַּת מַלְכוּתוֹ שֶׁמִּמֶּנָּה נִמְשָׁךְ וְנִתְהַוֶּוה הַמָּקוֹם וְהַזְּמַן,

This refers to malchut after its descent through the various tzimtzumim. However, even this level of malchut is united with G‑d. Thus, G‑d Who transcends time and space is also found within time and space.

The reason created beings are unable to perceive Him is that malchut conceals His Presence; they thus regard themselves as possessing independent existence subject to the limitations and divisions of time and space.

And this is yichuda tataah, or “lower-level Unity,”

וְזֶהוּ יִחוּדָא תַּתָּאָה

In this state, created beings are not totally nullified in relation to their source, the attribute of malchut, inasmuch as it allows them to be aware of their own existence.

(7[meaning] the intertwining of [the letters of the Name] Havayah within [the letters of the Name of] Adnut). In this instance, the Divine Name Havayah is intertwined and vested within the Name of Adnut; i.e., Havayah is concealed and submerged while Adnut is revealed and predominant, allowing for the creation of time and space.

[שִׁילּוּב הֲוָיָ"ה בְּאַדְנוּת בָּרוּךְ־הוּא],

I.e., His Essence and Being, which is called by the Name Ein Sof, “the Infinite One,” completely fills the whole earth temporally and spatially.

דְּהַיְינוּ, שֶׁמַּהוּתוֹ וְעַצְמוּתוֹ יִתְבָּרֵךְ, הַנִּקְרָא בְּשֵׁם "אֵין־סוֹף" בָּרוּךְ־הוּא – מָלֵא אֶת כָּל הָאָרֶץ מַמָּשׁ בִּזְמַן וּמָקוֹם,

For in the heavens above and on the earth [below] and in the four directions, everything is equally permeated with the Ein Sof-light, for [G‑d] is to be found on the earth below exactly as in the heavens above,

כִּי בַּשָּׁמַיִם מִמַּעַל וּבָאָרֶץ וּלְד' סִטְרִין, הַכֹּל מָלֵא מֵאוֹר־אֵין־סוֹף בָּרוּךְ־הוּא בְּשָׁוֶה מַמָּשׁ, כִּי כָּךְ הוּא בָּאָרֶץ מִתַּחַת כְּמוֹ בַּשָּׁמַיִם מִמַּעַל מַמָּשׁ,

for everything—including both heaven and earth—is within the dimension of space, which is utterly nullified in the Ein Sof-light,

כִּי הַכֹּל הוּא בְּחִינַת מָקוֹם – הַבָּטֵל בִּמְצִיאוּת בְּאוֹר־אֵין־סוֹף בָּרוּךְ־הוּא,

which clothes itself in it through [G‑d’s] attribute of malchut that is united with Him.

הַמִּתְלַבֵּשׁ בּוֹ עַל יְדֵי מִדַּת מַלְכוּתוֹ הַמְיוּחֶדֶת בּוֹ יִתְבָּרֵךְ.

In relation to the Ein Sof-light, which totally transcends time and space, there exists no difference between heaven and earth; G‑d is found equally in heaven and upon the earth. This being so, why are time and space not totally nullified?

[They are not nullified] because [G‑d’s] attribute of malchut is the attribute of tzimtzum and concealment, [whose function is] to hide the Ein Sof-light so that it will not be perceived by created beings,

רַק, שֶׁמִּדַּת מַלְכוּתוֹ הִיא מִדַּת הַצִּמְצוּם וְהַהֶסְתֵּר, לְהַסְתִּיר אוֹר־אֵין־סוֹף בָּרוּךְ־הוּא,

so that the existence of time and space should not be completely nullified, and there will be no dimensions of time and space whatsoever, even for the lower worlds.

שֶׁלֹּא יִבָּטְלוּ הַזְּמַן וְהַמָּקוֹם מִמְּצִיאוּתָם לְגַמְרֵי, וְלֹא יִהְיֶה שׁוּם בְּחִינַת זְמַן וּמָקוֹם בִּמְצִיאוּת אֲפִילוּ לַתַּחְתּוֹנִים.

I.e., it is only because of the concealment effected by malchut that time and space exist for created beings

title: How can a babysitter get paid for babysitting on Shabbos?
content:
# How can a babysitter get paid for babysitting on Shabbos? ## Frage

We know there is a concept in Halacha called Schar Shabbos. This means that you can’t get paid for work done on Shabbos.

So if I have a family Simcha, and I hire someone to babysit my children, how can the babysitter get paid? Is she earning money from work done on Shabbos?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

See here. The trick is to pay for work done on a weekday at the same time or to give a guft --- as the article says:

Can We Pay For Shabbat Babysitting?

It is forbidden for a Jew to be paid for work performed exclusively on Shabbat. So how do you compensate someone who watches your kids on Shabbat?

Combine with Weekday Work: Arrange for the babysitter to do additional work during the week, and pay them for both Shabbat and weekday tasks as one combined payment.16 Some hold that this extra work must not just be a perfunctory task but should be significant enough to warrant payment on its own.17

Inflated Fee for Preparations: Alternatively, some allow paying an inflated fee for preparations done before Shabbat, such as travel or setup, which includes the Shababat work.18

Give a Gift: Instead of payment, give the babysitter a gift.19 This may be in cash, so long as the rate of pay was not pre-negotiated,20 and both parties must understand it as a genuine gift.21

title: What is the SMA"K's case of רק שנהנה בהסתכלה?
content:
# What is the SMA"K's case of רק שנהנה בהסתכלה? ## Frage

The SMA"K in Mitzva 30 states:

שלא לתור אחר העין דכתיב (במדבר טו) אחרי עיניכ'. ודרשו רבותינו זהו זנו' שלא יסתכל בנשי' לשם זנו': אע"ג דבספ"ק דעכו"ם מפיק הסתכלו' נשי' מקרא דונשמרת' מכל דבר רע: ההוא הסתכלו' נשים שלא לשם זנות רק שנהנה בהסתכלה: Not to stray after the eye as it says 'after your eyes.' Our rabbis expound this (to mean) - promiscuity. He is not stare at women for the sake of promiscuity. Even though at the end of the first chapter of Avoda Zara it derives the prohibition of staring at women from (the verse) 'and preserve yourselves from all evil,' this is a reference to staring at women NOT for the sake of promiscuity but to simply derive pleasure in the looking.

This is very subtle - what is this case? A man looks at a woman and feels that he is glad she possesses a certain figure and form, but has no licentious thoughts - is that possible? Common?

title: How is Hashem said to be in specific places, if He is everywhere?
content:
# How is Hashem said to be in specific places, if He is everywhere? ## Frage

Hashem is said to be in certain places: In a flame of fire in the burning bush (Exodus 3), in the pillar of fire and cloud (Exodus 13:21), in the Most Holy Place (Exodus 25:22), upon a throne in heaven (Isaiah 6), "in the midst of Israel" (Joel 2:27), and "in Israel" (1 Samuel 17:46).

Hashem is also everywhere (Jeremiah 23:24, Psalm 139).

How is He said to be in those specific places in a different manner than He is everywhere else?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Hashem's presence is everywhere, however its intensity in our perception is filtered. In those specific references it refers to a less filtered presence. Then there is also the anthropomorphisms used to imply a strength, love or passion.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

When someone else asked the same question in this Midrash:

"וַיי הֹלֵךְ לִפְנֵיהֶם יוֹמָם". אֵי אֶפְשָׁר לוֹמַר כֵּן. וַהֲלֹא כְבָר נֶאֱמַר: (ירמיה כג,כד) "הֲלוֹא אֶת הַשָּׁמַיִם וְאֶת הָאָרֶץ אֲנִי מָלֵא נְאֻם יי". וְאוֹמֵר: (ישעיה ו,ג) "וְקָרָא זֶה אֶל זֶה וְאָמַר: קָדוֹשׁ, קָדוֹשׁ, קָדוֹשׁ יי צְבָאוֹת, מְלֹא כָל הָאָרֶץ כְּבוֹדוֹ." וְאוֹמֵר: (יחזקאל מג,ב) "וְהִנֵּה כְּבוֹד אֱלֹהֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל בָּא מִדֶּרֶךְ הַקָּדִים וְקוֹלוֹ כְּקוֹל מַיִם רַבִּים וְהָאָרֶץ הֵאִירָה מִכְּבֹדוֹ", וּמַה תִּלְמֹד לוֹמַר "וַיי הֹלֵךְ לִפְנֵיהֶם יוֹמָם"? (Exodus 13:21) "And the L–rd went before them by day": Can this be said? Is it not written (Jeremiah 23:22) "'Do I not fill the heavens and the earth?' says the L–rd"? and (Isaiah 6:3) "One (seraph) called to the other 'Holy, Holy, Holy is the L–rd of hosts — the earth is full of His glory'"? and (Ezekiel 43:2) "And, behold, the glory of the G–d of Israel came from the east, His voice like the voice of many waters, the earth shining in His glory"? How, then, am I to understand "And the L–rd went before them by day"?

Here was the answer:

אָמַר רַבִּי: אַנְטוֹנִינוּס, פְּעָמִים שֶׁהוּא דָן עַל בֵּמָה וּמַחְשִׁיךְ, וְהָיוּ בָנָיו מַחְשִׁיכִין אֶצְלוֹ. אַחַר שֶׁנִּפְטַר מִן הַבֵּמָה, הָיָה נוֹטֵל אֶת הַפָּנָס וּמֵאִיר לִפְנֵי בָנָיו. וְהָיוּ גְּדוֹלֵי מַלְכוּת קְרֵבִין אֶצְלוֹ וְאוֹמְרִין לוֹ: אָנוּ נוֹטְלִין אֶת הַפָּנָס וְנָאִיר לִפְנֵי בָנֶיךָ! וְהוּא אוֹמֵר לָהֶם: לָאו מִפְּנֵי שֶׁאֵין לִי מִי שֶׁיִּטֹּל אֶת הַפָּנָס וְיָאִיר לִפְנֵי בָנַי, אֶלָּא הֲרֵי אֲנִי מוֹדִיעַ לָכֶם חִבָּתָן שֶׁלְּבָנַי, שֶׁתִּהְיוּ נוֹהֲגִים עִמָּהֶן בְּכָבוֹד! וְכָךְ הוֹדִיעַ הַמָּקוֹם חִבָּתָם שֶׁלְּיִשְׂרָאֵל לְאֻמּוֹת הָעוֹלָם, שֶׁתְּהוּ נוֹהֲגִין עִמָּהֶם בְּכָבוֹד. Rebbi said: An analogy: The emperor Antoninus was presiding at the dais when it got dark, his sons remaining there. After he was finished, he took the lantern and lit (the way) for his sons — whereupon the nobles close to him said: Let us take the lantern and light (the way) for your sons. At this, he said: It is not that I have no one to take the lantern and light (the way) for my sons; but I want to impress upon you my love for my sons, that you treat them honorably.
כָּךְ הוֹדִיעַ הַקֹּדֶשׁ חִבָּתָן שֶׁלְּיִשְׂרָאֵל לִפְנֵי כָל אֻמּוֹת הָעוֹלָם, שֶׁיְּהוּ נוֹהֲגִין עִמָּהֶן בְּכָבוֹד. וְאֵינָן נוֹהֲגִין עִמָּהֶן בְּכָבוֹד, אֶלָּא מְמִיתִין אוֹתָן מִיתוֹת חֲמוּרוֹת, מִיתוֹת מְשֻׁנּוֹת זוֹ מִזּוֹ! וּלְעִנְיַן כָּךְ הוּא אוֹמֵר: (יואל ד,ב) "וְקִבַּצְתִּי אֶת כָּל הַגּוֹיִם, וְהוֹרַדְתִּים אֶל עֵמֶק יְהוֹשָׁפָט". יָכֹל עַל עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה, וְעַל גִּלּוּי עֲרָיוֹת וְעַל שְׁפִיכוּת דָּמִים? תִּלְמֹד לוֹמַר: "עַל עַמִּי וְנַחֲלָתִי יִשְׂרָאֵל, אֲשֶׁר פִּזְּרוּ בַגּוֹיִם וְאֶת אַרְצִי חִלֵּקוּ." וְאוֹמֵר: (יואל ד,יט) "מִצְרַיִם לִשְׁמָמָה תִהְיֶה, וֶאֱדוֹם לְמִדְבַּר שְׁמָמָה תִּהְיֶה". מִפְּנֵי מָה? "מֵחֲמַס בְּנֵי יְהוּדָה, אֲשֶׁר שָׁפְכוּ דָם נָקִיא בְּאַרְצָם." בְּאוֹתָהּ שָׁעָה: (יואל ד,כ) "וִיהוּדָה לְעוֹלָם תֵּשֵׁב, וִירוּשָׁלִַם לְדוֹר וָדוֹר." וְאוֹמֵר: (יואל ד,כא) "וְנִקֵּיתִי דָּמָם לֹא נִקֵּיתִי, וַיי שֹׁכֵן בְּצִיּוֹן". And thus did the Holy One Blessed be He impress upon the nations of the world His love of Israel — He Himself walking before them, so that they (learn to) treat them honorably. And let alone that they do not do so, but they kill them with all kinds of sore, strange deaths, one unlike the other. Of this it is written (Joel 4:2) "And I will gather all the nations and I will bring them down to the valley of Yehoshafat, and I will contend with them there over My people and My inheritance, Israel, that they have scattered among the nations, and over My land that they have divided." I might think that He will contend with them) over (their being guilty of) idolatry, illicit relations, and the spilling of blood. It is, therefore, written "over My people and My inheritance, Israel." And (Ibid. 19) "Egypt shall be a wasteland, and Edom, a desolate desert because of the sons of Judah, in whose land they have spilled innocent blood." At that time (Ibid. 10) "Judah will endure forever, and Jerusalem, from generation to generation," and (Ibid. 21) "And absolve them of their blood, I will not absolve them." When? When the L–rd dwells in Zion. (Exodus 13:22)

If that “analogy” was a good enough answer then, it is good enough for me.

Thanks to everyone who commented, I wouldn’t have found this without your help.

title: Did Samson suffer a different fate from the original snake because he violated ולא תתורו but not לא תחמד?
content:
# Did Samson suffer a different fate from the original snake because he violated ולא תתורו but not לא תחמד? ## Frage

The SMA"K (19) defines לא תחמד and states:

ונראה דלא תחמוד ולא תתאוה הכל אחד הוא

it appears that לא תחמד and do not desire are the same thing ...

Then he quotes the Gemara in Sota which lists the original snake, Sotas, and Cain, Bilaam, and Haman and others as those who place(d)their eyes upon things that were not theirs and who thus suffer(ed) the fate of losing all of those things and more.

It appears per the Smak that דלא תחמוד ולא תתאוה and שנתנו עיניהם במה שאינו שלהם are all the same.

How is this different than ולא תתורו?

The Smak describes (30) that as desirous looking.

The Mishna in Sota (9b) does not group Samson with those who placed their eyes on something not theirs but instead describes him as 'following ' his eyes. He suffered a different fate - blinding.

Is ולא תתורו a more superficial staring/impulse without the internal desire and machinations? Is ולא תחמד more of an off camera outside of the field of vision plotting and yearning? If Samson violated the former and not the latter, does this explain why he was blinded but not stripped of what he had and what he wished for? Or did he suffer that fate too?
