title: What is the breakdown of the 13 attributes of divine Mercy?
content:
# What is the breakdown of the 13 attributes of divine Mercy? ## Frage

B"H

How are the 13 Attributes divided?

I would think they are as follows:

  1. ה׳
  2. ה׳
  3. אל
  4. רחום
  5. וחנון
  6. ארך אפים
  7. ורב חסד
  8. ואמת
  9. נצר חסד לאלפים
  10. נשא עון
  11. ופשע
  12. וחטאה
  13. ונקה

However, I just read a maamar (אני לדודי 5726, meluket) that references sources discussing how the first attribute, which is the source of all of the other ones, is "El". That implies that the first two references to Hashem's name are not counted as part of the 13.

If so, how would the attributes after El be divided up to still arrive at 13?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

According to סדור עבודת ה׳, they are divided as follows:

  1. אל
  2. רחום
  3. וחנון
  4. ארך
  5. אפים
  6. ורב חסד
  7. ואמת
  8. נצר חסד
  9. לאלפים
  10. נשא עון
  11. ופשע
  12. וחטאה
  13. ונקה

According to this, a couple of clauses are split into separate attributes, which obviously contradicts the verse’s syntax. I assume there’s some Kabbalistic basis for this method of division; yours seems to be the פשט.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

B"H

I recently found an article on chabad.org that describes some of the possible differences:

The kabbalists take the following approach to the words that are counted as an attribute.6

The 13 Attributes of Mercy according to Kabbalah:

א-ל / G‑d — mighty in compassion to give all creatures according to their need;

רַחוּם / rachum — merciful, that humankind may not be distressed;

וְחַנּוּן / ve’chanun — and gracious if humankind is already in distress;

אֶרֶךְ אַפַּיִם / erech apayim — slow to anger; (once, to the righteous)

אֶרֶךְ אַפַּיִם / erech apayim — slow to anger; (repeated again for the wicked)

וְרַב-חֶסֶד / ve’rav chesed — and plenteous in kindness;

וֶאֱמֶת / ve’emet — and truth;

נֹצֵר חֶסֶד / notzer chesed — keeping kindness

לָאֲלָפִים / laalafim — unto thousands;

נֹשֵׂא עָוֹן / noseh avon — forgiving iniquity;

וָפֶשַׁע / vafeshah — and transgression;

וְחַטָּאָה / vechata'ah — and sin;

וְנַקֵּה / venakeh — and pardoning.

However, others argue and offer a different approach to the words that count as an attribute.7 For example, they believe that the first two names of G‑d are attributes themselves. In contrast, the Kabbalistic approach did not include the first two names of G‑d, instead, it regards them as introductory notes - as the source for the thirteen attributes of mercy.

י-ה-ו-ה / Hashem — compassion before a person sins;

י-ה-ו-ה / Hashem — compassion after a person has sinned;

א-ל / G‑d — mighty in compassion, to give all creatures according to their need;8

רַחוּם / rachum — merciful, that humankind may not be distressed;

וְחַנּוּן / ve’chanun — and gracious if humankind is already in distress;

אֶרֶךְ אַפַּיִם / erech apayim — slow to anger;

וְרַב-חֶסֶד / ve’rav chesed — and plenteous in kindness;

וֶאֱמֶת / ve’emet — and truth;

נֹצֵר חֶסֶד לָאֲלָפִים / notzer chesed laalafim — keeping kindness unto thousands;

נֹשֵׂא עָוֹן / noseh avon — forgiving iniquity;

וָפֶשַׁע / vafeshah — and transgression;

וְחַטָּאָה / VeChata'ah — and sin;

וְנַקֵּה / VeNakeh — and pardoning.

The consensus amongst the Rabbinic authorities leans towards the kabbalistic approach. One of the reasons given for this is because in halachik analysis, when Torah is discussing a matter which has strong ties to Kabbalah, then the kabbalistic approach is the accepted opinion.

So in the first way, "long to anger" is counted twice, once for righteous ppl and once for wicked, and "for thousands" is counted as separate for "he guards kindness".

I'm still not sure what the meaning of "for thousands" is alone, when counted by itself.

It references:

  1. Idra Raba 131b, Etz Chayim - Shaar Erech Anpin Chp.11. See Likkutei Sichot, vol. 4, p.1348 for further discussion on the topic.

  2. Rosh Hashanah 17b, Tosafot, ad loc. Ramban, Rosh and Ibn Ezra also take this view. There are many other opinions regarding the order, some of which are mentioned in Likkutei Sichot in the previous footnote

  3. These first three attributes are also names of G‑d that are associated with His mercy, and are therefore not pronounced as written.

  4. See Likkutei Sichot, vol. 4, p.1348 for more answers, why the Kabbalisitc approach is the accepted one.

Likkutei Sichos says there:

B”H

...

הנה ד' שיטות בהתחלת מנין י"ג מדות (הוזכרו בקרבן נתנאל ספ"א דר"ה ועי' ג"כ בחיי פ' תשא):

שם הוי' הא' (פסיקתא רבתי, שוחר"ט צ"ג. חכמי צרפת הובאו באבודרהם פי' נעילה דתענית וכנראה הם הם ר"ת בתוס' דיה שלש עשרה מדות ר"ה (יז, ב). הראב"ע עה"ת, רא"ש ועוד).

שם הוי' השני (ר"ג בתוס' שם, גאון הובא בראב"ע שם. ועפ"י הקדמת הראב"ע לפירושו הוא ר' סעדי' גאון. וכ"מ קצת לפי' אחד בספר הליקוטים להאריז"ל פ' כי תשא).

א"ל (זח"ג קל"א, ב. עה"ש שער א"א פי"א. פע"ח שער הסליחות פ"ד. ספר הכוונות דרושי ויעבור דרוש ג' ואילך. משנת חסידים מסכת שארית האצילות פ"י ואילך).

אל רחום (ספר חסידים סי' רי"ג. מהר"ל מפראג בס' נתיבות עולם נתיב התשובה פ"ו. ומש"ש ראיה לדבריו מזח"ג הנ"ל ומהש"ס — לא זכיתי להבין כי אדרבה משם מוכח כדעת האריז"ל).

והחלטה בעניני סתרי תורה — הרי צ"ל עפ"י הכרעת חכמי הקבלה, ובפרט שהם ראו גם דברי התוס' ור"ג וכו'. ובכ"ז התליטו כנ"ל. וכבר כתב האזולאי בפי' לסידור השל"ה שם וז"ל: רבינו והתוס' בפ"ק דר"ה חקרו למנות י"ג מדות מפני שבימיהם ז"ל לא נתגלה ספר הזהר הקדוש. ושם ובכתבי רבינו האריז"ל גילו לנו מנינם וסודם, עכ"ל.

וע"פ נגלה י"ל דתלוי בהגרסא בש"ס. דהנה גרסת הרי"ף והרא"ש היא אשר דרשת ר' יוחנן שם דברית כרותה לי"ג מדות כו' באה תיכף אחרי הדרשה על "הוי' הוי'". ולכן אפשר לומר דוהוא התחלת י"ג מדות — וביאור ע"ד שייכות הרא"ש ובעלי התוס' (אשר ר"ת מראשיהם). וכז"ע ע"ד שייכות הרי"ף והגאונים.

משא"כ לגרסא בש"ס שנתפשטה ונתקבלה אצלינו — הדרשה דברית כרותה לי"ג מדות מקדים לה הש"ס התיבות "א"ל רחום וכו'" (ועי' ג"כ גרסת הע"י). ה"ז ראיה מכרעת דהתחלת המנין היא "א"ל" — וכמ"ש המהר"ל שם ראיה זו ובמו"א הובא בעץ יוסף. (ובדקדוקי סופרים לא הביא שינוי גרסא זו).

והנה ברא"ש שם הקשה דאם לא תימא כשיטת ר"ת למה פשט המנהג דהצבור כשחוזרין י"ג מדות בקול רם מתחילין מהתיבות "הוי' הוי'"?

והתירוץ מובן עפמ"ש בכתבי האריז"ל שם. דשני שמות הוי' אלו הם מקור כל י"ג מדות. ומובן עפ"י דא"ח עפמ"ש בלקו"ת ד"ה "והיה ביום ההוא יתקע בשופר", ובתו"א מקץ סוף הביאור לד"ה "כי אתה נרי". ועפ"ז יש לתרץ בפשיטות הפסיקתא ושוחר"ט לדעת האריז"ל). או אין פטט ווערטער: הצבור אומרים: (אתה) הוי' הוי' (אנו מבקשים שתהי') א"ל רחום וכו'.

מה שהקשה שם עוד ברא"ש ד"נוצר חסד לאלפים" צ"ל מדה אחת — כבר מתורץ בתוס' שם.

ודוגמת הסבר זה הלכה כרב באיסורי וכשמואל בדיני (ראה ריש בבא קמא כז, ב. ועי' ג"כ שו"ע אדה"ז סי' רס"ח סע"ב. שער הכולל. בתהילתו).

B"H

Free translation:

Behold, there are four approaches to the beginning of the count of the Thirteen Attributes of Mercy (these were mentioned in Korban Nesanel, at the beginning of tractate Rosh HaShanah, and also the Bechayei on Parashas Ki Tisa):

  1. The first Name of Havayah — (as in Pesikta Rabbasi, Shocher Tov 93; the sages of France brought in Avudraham in the commentary to the Neilah prayer of Yom Kippur; and it seems they are also the “Rabbenu Tam” cited in Tosafos, Rosh HaShanah 17b, “the thirteen attributes”; see also Ibn Ezra on the Torah, Rosh, and others).

  2. The second Name of Havayah — (as in Rabbeinu Gershom in Tosafos there; a Gaon brought in Ibn Ezra there, and according to the introduction of Ibn Ezra to his commentary it is Rav Saadia Gaon; and it is also found somewhat in one commentary in Sefer HaLikutim of the Arizal, Parashas Ki Tisa).

  3. “E-l” (G-d) — (as in Zohar III 131b; see Shaar HaArich Anpin chapter 11; Pri Etz Chaim, Shaar HaSelichos chapter 4; Sefer HaKavanot, discourses on Vaya’avor, from the third discourse onward; Mishnas Chassidim, tractate She’eiris HaAtzilus chapter 10 and onwards, and more. And what is explained in Derech Emes on Zohar I 2a, section 4, in the first opinion, requires further analysis. And were I not afraid, I would say it is not from Rav Chaim Vital, since it is the opposite of what is explicitly explained everywhere in the writings of the Arizal, and it has already been written that several notes from Imrei Binah were mixed in by mistake of printers in Derech Emes).

  4. “El Rachum” (Merciful G-d) — (as in Sefer Chassidim §213; Maharal of Prague in Netivos Olam, Netiv HaTeshuvah chapter 6; and what is cited there as proof from Zohar III and from the Talmud—I have not merited to understand, for on the contrary, it proves like the opinion of the Arizal).

And the decision in matters of esoteric Torah — must follow the ruling of the sages of Kabbalah, particularly since they also considered the words of Tosafos, Rabbeinu Gershom, and others. And nevertheless they concluded as above. And already the Chida wrote in his commentary to the Siddur HaShelah there, as follows: “Our master (the Arizal) and Tosafos in Rosh HaShanah investigated how to count the Thirteen Attributes, because in their days the holy Zohar had not yet been revealed. And in the Zohar and in the writings of our master the Arizal their order and their secret were revealed to us.”

And according to the revealed Torah one may say it depends on the textual version of the Talmud. For the version of the Rif and the Rosh is that the teaching of Rabbi Yochanan—‘a covenant is established with the Thirteen Attributes’—comes immediately after the teaching on ‘Havayah, Havayah.’ Therefore one can say that this is the beginning of the Thirteen Attributes, and this explains the connection of the Rosh and the Tosafists (whose heads were Rabbenu Tam, etc.). Similarly with the Rif and the Geonim.

However, according to the version of the Talmud that has spread and been accepted by us, the teaching of ‘a covenant is established with the Thirteen Attributes’ is preceded in the Talmud with the words E-l, Rachum, etc. (and so too is the version in the Ein Yaakov). This is therefore a decisive proof that the beginning of the count is E-l, as Maharal writes there, and as also brought in Etz Yosef. (And in Dikdukei Sofrim no change of version was brought here).

Now, the Rosh asks there: if not according to Rabbenu Tam’s opinion, why is the custom that when the congregation recites the Thirteen Attributes aloud, they begin from the words Havayah, Havayah?

And the answer is clear according to what is written in the Arizal’s works: these two Names of Havayah are the source of all the Thirteen Attributes. And this is also understood according to Chassidus from what is written in Likkutei Torah, discourse “Vehayah bayom hahu yitaka,” and in Torah Or, Parashas Miketz, at the end of the discourse “Ki Atah Neri.” And according to this one can also explain simply the words of the Pesikta and Shocher Tov, according to the Arizal. The words of the congregation are thus: “(You) Havayah, Havayah (we request that You be) E-l Rachum, etc.”

As for the further question of the Rosh, that “Notzer chesed la’alafim” (“preserving kindness for thousands”) should count as one attribute—this is already resolved in Tosafos there.

And this resembles the principle: the halacha follows Rav in prohibitions, and Shmuel in civil law (see Rosh, Bava Kama 27b; see also Shulchan Aruch of the Alter Rebbe, Orach Chaim 268, Sefer Shaar HaKolel, and his Tehillato).

title: If doubt in Torah was intentionally made, then why is it moral to sanction the kofer?
content:
# If doubt in Torah was intentionally made, then why is it moral to sanction the kofer? ## Frage

I see Rabbi's saying Hashem cannot reveal himself, because then everyone would have emunah, and then there is no room to misbehave. Therefore how is it moral to sanction people for being a Kofer BaTorah? For example, there are cases, that if someone becomes secular, then their family will not speak to them anymore.

I am not asking why hashem does not make someone explode if they light a match on shabbos, that does take away free will. But simply revealing himself is different, someone can know the truth, have emunah and still choose to violate it, there are people in yeshiva right now who pray 3 times a day put tefillin believe in hashem yet still choose to waste seed. They aren't saying in that moment "I disbelieve in Hashem" They are sinning while still believing. Therefore I don't think this argument that hashem cannot reveal himself as that removes free choice is a valid one. There is no downside, it would only make it fair to sanction those who do not follow the laws of Torah as there wouldn't be doubt of torah's divinity yes? And if you are going to say we can't have no doubt of the divinity of the torah then how can a family shame, think bad of and put them in cherem over a maybe I don't get that part.

title: The verbs uses for different Jewish "prayers"
content:
# The verbs uses for different Jewish "prayers" ## Frage

In both Yiddish and Hebrew there is a distinction between those "prayers" which one SAYS (Yiddish zogn) and those which one PRAYS (Yiddish davenen).

So one davens the three (on certain days four or five) prayer sets at the synagogue as well as the key component of these (Amida = Shemone-Esre) but one zag's most of the other components not to mention the prayers that are said at home.

I have heard a theory that the ones one PRAYS involve asking the Almighty for things, while the others praise him or thank him, but I am not sure that this is correct.

title: Is the Church of the Subgenius Avodah Zarah?
content:
# Is the Church of the Subgenius Avodah Zarah? ## Frage

The Church of the Subgenius (wiki) is a so-called religion, intended as a parody or satire of religion and popular culture.

The Church of the SubGenius is a parody religion that satirizes better-known belief systems. It teaches a complex philosophy that focuses on J. R. "Bob" Dobbs, purportedly a salesman from the 1950s, who is revered as a prophet by the Church. SubGenius leaders have developed detailed narratives about Dobbs and his relationship to various gods and conspiracies.

Their central deity, Jehovah 1, is accompanied by other gods drawn from ancient myth and popular fiction. SubGenius literature describes a grand conspiracy that seeks to brainwash the world and oppress Dobbs's followers. In its narratives, the Church presents a blend of cultural references in an elaborate remix of the sources.

Although it is clearly played as a joke, some people do take it seriously. Anyone can join the Church for a one-time fee, and all members are automatically ordained ministers.

Is this Avodah Zera? Any halachic problem with a Jew joining the Church? Is it relevant that it is intended as a parody? Or that a member becomes an ordained minister?

title: Meaning of Deut. 26:5
content:
# Meaning of Deut. 26:5 ## Frage

In Deuteronomy/Dvarim 26:5, the phrase "ארמי א(ו)בד אבי", which is usually translated as something like "my father was a wandering Aramaean", appears. If that translation is correct, why does Rashi refer to this verse as being a reference to Laban pursuing (i.e. attempting to destroy) Yaakov/Israel?

Ibn Ezra, Chizkuni, etc all seem to agree that this verse isn't refering to Laban. Ibn Ezra himself gives some reasons as to why this verse can't (contextually and grammatically) be referring to Laban pursuing Jacob. So why does Rashi seem to think the opposite? Was it just a mistake he made or something else?

title: Why do people follow the Zohar in bending their knees before bowing in Shemoneh Esrei when it directly conflicts with the Talmud?
content:
# Why do people follow the Zohar in bending their knees before bowing in Shemoneh Esrei when it directly conflicts with the Talmud? ## Frage

See When was the bending of the knees in bowing introduced? with the answer there which essentially state that the minhag is based on the Zohar as cited in Magen Avraham.

The Talmud and all the standard codes, including SA, clearly say to bow at ברוך and straighten at the Name.

The well known rule, which Magen Avraham himself quotes, is that when there's a clash between the Talmud and the Zohar the Talmud prevails.

However, in this case, bending the knees at ברוך and not bowing until אתה, or perhaps even bending the knees at all, conflicts head on with Talmudic law (which is presumably why SA doesn't codify it).

How then can Magen Avraham, who himself quotes and abides by this rule, cite the Zohar with regard to bending the knees?

And by extension, how can folks follow it (also cited in MB), against the Talmud and all the codes?

title: Why do people mention a sick person's name when praying for them?
content:
# Why do people mention a sick person's name when praying for them? ## Frage

In light of this gemara:

אֲמַר רִבִּי יַעֲקֹב אֲמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: כָּל הַמְּבַקֵּשׁ רַחֲמִים עַל חֲבֵירוֹ, אֵין צָרִיךְ לְהַזְכִּיר שְׁמוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: אֵל נָא רְפָא נָא לָהּ. וְלָא קָמַדְכַּר שְׁמַהּ דְּמִרְיָם.

Rabbi Yaakov said in the name of Rav Chisda: Anyone who requests mercy on behalf of his fellow does not need to mention his name, as it is said: ‘Please, God, heal her, please’ (Numbers 12:13) — and he (Moses) did not mention Miriam’s name.

why are folks particular about mentioning an ill person's name?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

The Magen Avrohom qualifies the Gemara as follows:

המבקש רחמים על חבירו א"צ להזכיר שמו (ברכות דף ל"ד) וה"מ בפניו אבל כשמתפלל שלא בפניו צריך להזכיר שמו (מהרי"ל):

If one is seeking mercy on someone he does not need to mention his name (Mesechta Berachot). However this is only if the person (your praying for) is before you. If he isn't before you, you do need to mention his name (Mahril).

Hence when one is not praying in front of the person one must mention the name.

title: Non Mevushal Wine and a Convert
content:
# Non Mevushal Wine and a Convert ## Frage

I was reading this answer and I thought of a hypothetical scenario.

Let's say a non-Jew who has been on the road to conversion for a couple of years is getting ready for his big day. The morning of, he opens a bottle of non-mevushal wine and puts it on the table to air out, preparing for his post conversion l'chaim.

When he comes home later, a full fledged Jew, can he drink his own wine? He knows hat there was no thought of A"Z when he put it on the table, already opened, and he isn't concerned about the bottle's leading to intermarriage.

Is that bottle still forbidden to him or is it acceptable because we can be sure that the reasons that we would forbid it don't apply.

title: Question regarding Mishnah Berachos 1:2
content:
# Question regarding Mishnah Berachos 1:2 ## Frage

In Mishnah Berachos 1:2, R’ Yehoshua says (or seems to me to say) that one ‘loses nothing’ by reciting the Shema late in the morning.

I do not understand this. If the halacha is to say it on time, how can the reward be the same if one does not say it on time? What is R’ Yehoshua saying here?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

He's not saying you don't lose the reward for saying it on time - you do. He is saying you don't lose anything further than that.

It's a nice way of saying "it couldn't hurt"; there's no punishment for saying it then - in fact, there's pretty much always a zechus for saying words of Torah and Tefilla (minor exceptions like Tisha B'Av come to mind) - so why not say it? (see Rambam there)

See Bartenura there, following the gemara - saying more specifically that what he is not losing are the berachot he can say with Shema, he can still say them.

title: "Good vs. Evil?" rather ask "Berakha and Klala" / "Life vs. Death?"
content:
# "Good vs. Evil?" rather ask "Berakha and Klala" / "Life vs. Death?" ## Frage

Shalom all,

I was wondering now that this week's Parasha is Re'eh, whether the question between "Good & Evil" does not really play such a relevant role in the Torah than for example differentiating between "Berakha & Klala" or between "Life & Death". It seems the whole world is obssessed defining what's "good" and what's "Evil". Should we rather be asking "is it Berakha /Life rather than Klala/Death"? An additional question I have is how to differentiate between the two concepts "Good" and "Berakha".

Thanks & Shabbat Shalom!

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The question is based on a false assumption. While it does not mention good or evil in this parshah, it is mentioned directly later on in Deuteronomy 30:15

רְאֵ֨ה נָתַ֤תִּי לְפָנֶ֙יךָ֙ הַיּ֔וֹם אֶת־הַֽחַיִּ֖ים וְאֶת־הַטּ֑וֹב וְאֶת־הַמָּ֖וֶת וְאֶת־הָרָֽע׃
See, I have set before thee this day life and good, and death and evil;

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

No, that’s a false parallelism.

פרשת ראה discusses life and blessing as a reward for good behavior; and conversely, it discusses death and curses as a punishment for evil behavior.

Good and evil are not synonymous with blessing and curses, nor with life and death. For example, evil people can live and receive blessing, which is a curse on the world.

The Torah only discusses blessing and curse in the context of reward and punishment for good and evil behavior. The only reason the words טוב and רע are (usually) not explicitly written, is because they can be inferred: Hashem clearly wants us to do what’s good, and to avoid what’s evil. When He tells us what to do and avoid, it’s clear that He’s telling us what’s good and evil. Explicitly saying so would be a waste of ink.

title: Are the five pathways from Atzilut to Briah, given they’re the outlets to speech, correlated to the five families of letters?
content:
# Are the five pathways from Atzilut to Briah, given they’re the outlets to speech, correlated to the five families of letters? ## Frage

Based on @RabbiKaii ́s comment on this current bounty question:

…This is referring to the pathways from the Chesed and Gevura through Netzach and Hod to the Peh (Malchut/Nukva)[,] which has 5 parts/articulators, so to speak, for speaking the world into creation…

Are these correlated to the 5 families of Osiyos as brought in Sefer Yetzirah, namely:

אחה"ע בגרון גיכ"ק בחיך דטלנ"ת בלשון זסשר"ץ בשינים בומ"ף בשפתים:

?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

See Idra Rabba, Parashat Naso, page 141b; Etz Chayim, Sha'ar HaKlalim, chapter 10. The passage I quoted there (Likkutei Torah Kedoshim 1 וכי תבואו אל הארץ ונטעתם כל עץ מאכל כו׳) explains that indeed these are referring to the ה׳ מוצאות of the mouth, which as we know correspond to:

גרוניות (g’roniyot) – gutturals (throat letters א ה ח ע)

חיכיות (chikiyot) – palatals (palate letters ג י כ ק)

לשוניות (leshoniyot) – linguals (tongue letters ד ט ל נ ת)

שיניות / שיניים (shinuyot / shinayim) – dentals (teeth letters ז ס ש ר צ)

שפתיות (sifiyot) – labials (lips letters ב ו מ פ)

For more information about what this is all about, see what is written in Derech Mitzvotecha (מצות נטילת ידים לסעודה), where he writes:

והנה ענין ה' אצבעות שביד הם בחי' ה"ג המחלקים ומפרידים את כח פעולת העשי' שבעצם היד כדי שיהי' פעולת דבר פרטי כמו ציור וכתיבה או נתינה לזולתו שאם לא האצבעות אע"פ שכל כח הפעולה היה ביד בשלימות אבל לא הי' שום נפעל ממנה בפרטות כי כח היד אחד הוא והאצבעות הם הגורמים התחלקות לפרטי' שונים וכענין הידוע בהבל הדבור שמתחלק ע"י ה' מוצאות שהם ג"כ ה"ג המפרידות ההבל ובלעדם הי' הבל א' פשוט ולא הי' התחלקות צירופי האותיות

The five fingers of the hand correspond to the five Gevurot (restrictive forces), which divide and separate the power of action contained in the hand itself. This enables it to perform specific actions, such as drawing, writing, or giving to another.

For if not for the fingers, even though the full power of action would be present in the hand, it would not be able to bring about any specific effect, since the force of the hand is singular and undivided. The fingers are what cause the division into particular details.

This parallels the known concept regarding the breath of speech, which is divided through the five articulatory organs, which likewise correspond to the five Gevurot that separate the breath. Without these divisions, speech would remain a simple, undifferentiated breath, with no distinct combinations of letters.

Of course, this is just an analogy. See what he writes in מצות הקרבת וספירת העומר א׳ to help understand the Nimshal:

והנה בחי' דיבורו ית' מתחלק לה' מוצאות שכמו עד"מ באדם הבל הדבור מתחלק בה' מוצאות כן בחי' מל' ורוח פיו ית' הנק' ה' מתחלק לה' מוצאות שהוא ענין התחלקות האור והחיות הכללי למדריגות ובחי' שונות ומובדלות זו מזו וזהו ענין ד' חיות שבמרכבת יחזקאל הם ד' מחנות שכינה שהם מחנה מיכאל מחנה גבריאל כו' שהם בחי' שונות לפי שכל א' מקבל ממוצא מיוחד נבדל מזולתו

And behold, the aspect of His blessed speech is divided into the five articulations (motza'ot), for just as, by way of analogy, in a human being, the breath of speech is divided into five sources of articulation, so too, the aspect of Malchut and the breath of His mouth, may He be blessed, which is called the letter Hei, is divided into five articulations.

This represents the division of the general light and vitality into different levels and distinct aspects.

And this is the concept of the four Chayot in the Chariot of Ezekiel, which correspond to the four camps of the Shechinah: the camp of Michael, the camp of Gavriel, etc. These represent different aspects, for each one receives from a distinct and separate articulation source.

However, the way you are trying to correlate the 5 motza'ot to the Sefirot is incorrect. He goes on to say:

אך מה שאינן אלא ד' ולא חמש הוא לפי שמוצא החמישי אינו מכלל המוצאות הנמשכות לנבראים כמו ד' מוצאות הנשארים אלא הוא מקור הכוללם יחד שממנו יתחלקו אח"כ בפרט לבחי' שונות הגם שממנו נמצאים אותיות גיכ"ק והיינו מפני שנאמר חכו ממתקים (שה"ש ה' ט"ז)

However, the reason they are only four and not five is because the fifth articulation is not part of those that extend to the created beings like the remaining four. Rather, it is the source that encompasses them all together, from which they subsequently divide into distinct aspects.

Even though from it emerge the letters Gimel, Yud, Chaf, Kuf (Gichak, letters pronounced in the palate), nevertheless, this is because it is written: "His palate is sweetness" (Song of Songs 5:16).

He goes on to explain that letters from the palate, Gichak, corresponds to spiritual delight and understanding, Chochma (and Keter), and thus the source of all the letters. Gichak thus encompasses the other four motza'ot beneat it, which create, through combinations of letters listed in Sefer Yetzira, the four "Camps of the Shechina", i.e. the four angelic camps listed in Midrash Rabba:

  • Micha'el (Chesed)
  • Gavriel (Gevura)
  • Raphael (Tiferet)
  • Uriel (Malchut)

and that all camps have many myriads of angels, from which arise all the combinations of the Sefirot that Hashem creates through this articulating His Divine breath; His Divine speech.

The source of the letters are much higher. To get an introduction to this, study להבין מ"ש באוצ"ח in the hosafot to the Alter Rebbe's Likkutei Torah. The letters we are currently talking about stem from the lowest aspect of Chochma, representing the waste product of Chochma. Our souls are made of letters, and our Chochma, wherein dwells the Ohr Ein Sof, must crystallise/clump together into letters in order to reveal itself. These letters of machshava become letters of dibbur. Notably, this process happens in higher realms too, all the way to the Ohr Ein Sof Himself, where are hidden the 231 Gates (unordered 2-distinct-letter pairings) in the Tiharu Ila'ah, which are revealed in the Reshimu. These act as "horses" to bring their Master - Hashem's Ohr, exalted far beyond the realm of hishtalshelut - into the lower realms, clothed as letters of Torah.

This of course is just to whet the appetite for those who wish to learn these amazing ma'amarim. All will make a lot more sense and be explained in far more depth and clarity, and makes for a truly beautiful lesson. It will also deepen one's understanding of tzimtzum.

See also אני ישנה ולבי ער קול דודי דופק פתחי לי כו׳

אֲמַר לְהֹן: בְּיַמָּא יָאֵי לְמֵידַר, אוֹ בְּיַבִּשְׁתָּא יָאֵי לְמֵידַר? אֲמַרוּ לֵיהּ: בְּיַבִּשְׁתָּא יָאֵי לְמֵידַר, דְּהָא כֹּל נָחוֹתֵי יַמָּא לָא מִיַּתְּבָא דַּעְתֵּיהוֹן עַד דְּסָלְקִין לְיַבִּשְׁתָּא.

title: Which animal’s blood is prohibited to consume?
content:
# Which animal’s blood is prohibited to consume? ## Frage

As I am reading the Torah I find myself confused by specific verses. In some instances it seems like God is saying the blood of land animals and birds is prohibited & in other verses it seems like the blood of every creature is prohibited. Can anyone clarify?

  1. this verse shows only land animals and birds: Moreover, you shall eat no blood whatever, whether of fowl or of animal, in any of your dwelling places. 27 Whoever eats any blood, that person shall be cut off from his people."

  2. this verse says blood of every creature! "Any one also of the people of Israel, or of the strangers who sojourn among them, who takes in hunting any beast or bird that may be eaten shall pour out its blood and cover it with earth. "For the life of every creature? is its blood: its blood is its life. Therefore I have said to the people of Israel, You shall not eat the blood of any creature, for the life of every creature is its blood. Whoever eats it shall be cut off.

So I wonder can we really eat fish, lobster, shrimp since they all have blood (maybe not like human blood but it says there every creatures blood)!

Can someone give us some info why Jewish people believe they can have fish blood? But not birds & lands animals?!

Anywhere we can understand how they understood the 2nd verses to still mean land animals & birds blood is prohibited!

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The Gemara - our Oral Torah, makes an exegesis from the verse you mention:

Refer to the gemara in Kerisus 20b:

תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״כָּל דָּם לֹא תֹאכְלוּ״, שׁוֹמֵעַ אֲנִי אֲפִילּוּ דַּם מְהַלְּכֵי שְׁתַּיִם, דַּם בֵּיצִים, דַּם חֲגָבִים, דַּם דָּגִים, הַכֹּל בַּכְּלָל? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״לְעוֹף וְלִבְהֵמָה״

The Sages taught in a baraita: The verse states: “And you shall consume no manner of blood” (Leviticus 7:26). I would derive from here that even with regard to the blood of bipeds, i.e., human beings, and the blood of eggs, the blood of grasshoppers, and the blood of fish, all these are included in the prohibition against consuming blood. Therefore, the verse states: “Whether it is of bird or of animal” (Leviticus 7:26).

The gemara continues and explains as follows:

מָה עוֹף וּבְהֵמָה מְיוּחָדִין, שֶׁיֵּשׁ בָּהֶן טוּמְאָה קַלָּה וְטוּמְאָה חֲמוּרָה, וְיֵשׁ בָּהֶן אִיסּוּר וְהֶיתֵּר, וְהֵן מִין בָּשָׂר – אַף כֹּל שֶׁיֵּשׁ בָּהֶן טוּמְאָה קַלָּה. אוֹצִיא דַּם מְהַלְּכֵי שְׁתַּיִם – שֶׁיֵּשׁ בָּהֶן טוּמְאָה חֲמוּרָה, וְאֵין בָּהֶן טוּמְאָה קַלָּה. אוֹצִיא דַּם שְׁרָצִים – שֶׁאֵין בָּהֶם טוּמְאָה חֲמוּרָה. אוֹצִיא דַּם בֵּיצִים – שֶׁאֵין מִין בָּשָׂר, דַּם דָּגִים דַּם חֲגָבִים – שֶׁכּוּלּוֹ הֶיתֵּר

The baraita explains the derivation from the verse: Just as birds and animals are unique in that they have the capacity for both a light form of ritual impurity, if they become impure after they are slaughtered, in which case they are considered impure food, and a severe form of impurity, if they die without valid ritual slaughter, and they have the possibility of being forbidden or permitted, and they are a type of meat, so too, everything that has the capacity for both a light form of impurity and a severe form of ritual impurity, and has the possibility of being forbidden or permitted, and is a type of meat, is included in the prohibition. I will therefore exclude the blood of bipeds, as they have the capacity for a severe form of ritual impurity, i.e., the impurity of a corpse, but they do not have the capacity for a light form of ritual impurity, since the halakhot of the impurity of food do not apply to the human body. I will likewise exclude the blood of creeping animals, which do not have a severe form of ritual impurity. Impurity transmitted to a person by the carcass of a creeping animal does not render clothing impure, whereas impurity transmitted by the carcass of an animal or bird does render one’s clothing impure. I will also exclude the blood of eggs, as they are not a type of meat, and finally I will exclude the blood of fish and the blood of grasshoppers, as they are entirely permitted, as explained on 21b. (William Davidson translation & notation)

As far as the second verse you bring from Vayikra 17:14 note the Netziv in his Ha'amek Davar commentary:

כי נפש כל בשר. היינו של חיה ועוף מה שהוא פראי

For the soul of all flesh — meaning of wild animals and birds, that which is untamed (wild).

In other words, despite it saying "the life of all flesh" - it is still only referring to birds and wild animals.

title: How come Hebrew/Judaism doesn't have a distinctive noun for God?
content:
# How come Hebrew/Judaism doesn't have a distinctive noun for God? ## Frage

Correct me if I'm missing something here, but I wonder why the Holy Language, the heart of a truly monotheistic religion, does not have a unique noun for God. (I don't mean His proper name, YHWH, but a noun like Θεός (Theos) in Greek, or “God” in English.)

How come אל/אלוהים is used for God (YHWH), god (foreign), angels, divine beings, idols, human kings/judges, and more, and there is no dedicated noun for the only God?

How did God envision writing a foundational book where it is impossible to distinguish between all of them without sufficient context?

I’m looking for Rabbinic sources dealing with this conundrum.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Depends what you are talking about. God is just a word that means "creator and ruler", and we do call God "HaBoreh", and "Adonai", both terms in Lashon HaKodesh.

However, the Rabbis have long taught us that these are just descriptions, similar to "job" descriptions. He is beyond all appellation and description, beyond pronouns, language, reference, definition, limitation, category, species or relation. His Essence and Being precede all of those, and therefore there is no "essential" description of Him. Therefore, all we have is His Name, and His "job descriptions" as provided in the Torah.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

From the comments, it seems you’re asking this from the perspective that the lack of a unique noun for the One God of monotheism indicates that there was no such concept in the Biblical period.

This reasoning is deeply flawed:

  1. English doesn’t have one either. The only way English differentiates between a polytheistic god and a monotheistic God, is through capitalization. In the spoken language, they remain the same word. Despite this, there are plenty of English-speaking monotheists (such as yourself, I presume). Furthermore, almost every English speaker is perfectly capable of determining what any given speaker means when he says “god”, purely from semantic and pragmatic context.

  2. It’s a general rule in colloquial human languages that when a new concept is introduced, people don’t just arbitrarily invent a new noun. Rather, they use a meaningful description, which often (but not always) becomes specialized over time.

    To illustrate, when pianos were invented, Italians didn’t name it an arbitrary sequence of sounds like “kuptarol” or something. Instead, they referred to it as “piano-forte” (gentle-strong), referencing its ability to play various degrees of volume. This description later became considered a noun in its own right. Furthermore, even in Italy, the word is occasionally clipped to just “piano”, which still means “gentle”. Obviously, that doesn’t indicate that Italians don’t distinguish between the concepts of gentleness and piano-ness. That would be absurd.

    There’s no reason to assume that the Hebrew word for God would be an exception. Rather, the Hebrews used the existing Canaanite word for a powerful being—אל(הים)—as a description of Hashem (cf. the Kuzari. That description became considered a Name, in addition to retaining its older, more general meaning of a powerful and exalted being.

In short, there is no “conundrum” to be discussed. The absence of a unique noun for a given concept, can’t be taken to indicate that no such concept exists in the minds of the language’s speakers.

### Antwort 3 (Score: -1)

My understanding is that we can't have a full grasp of understanding H'. That being the case, we can't have a word that fully encapsulates His being. All we can do is refer to him in the ways we comprehend him interacting with us, hence us using what you might call "borrowed" words.

At the same time, note that seeing as H' is the one who created everything, including lashon hakodesh (and any language for that matter), this means that He wants us to call Him as he relates to us. So really we know Him as he chooses to relate to us and in the names He chooses for us to use for Him.

Since we relate to H' based on how He allows us to perceive His interaction with us, the names we use for Him are, by definition, going to need to have other meanings in order to have that depth.

title: Who was Rav Abun of Narbonne
content:
# Who was Rav Abun of Narbonne ## Frage

In an entry for one of the Rishonim, the sefer "The Rishonim" mentioned someone named R' Abun who was the first rosh yeshiva in Narbonne Province. It also mentions that he is the great-great-grandfather of R. Moshe Hadarshan. He sounds like an interesting talmid chochom. If someone knows anything about him, please say something.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 8)

Welcome to Mi Yodeya.

Unfortunately, Rabbi Abun lived during a murky period in Ashkenazi history, and we have little information regarding the various figures of the time. I don't know which book you're referring, but Raavad (Rabbi Avraham Ibn Daud)'s Sefer Hakabbalah is the main source we have for Rabbi Moshe Ha'Darshan's lineage. There he stated:

"והיו בנרבונה חכמים גדולים ראשי ישיבה...הראשון הידוע לנו בקבלותינו ר' יעקב הנביא גאון בר' משה בר' אבון. והרב ר' יהודה בר' משה הנקרא דשא דונזילה וקבל מרבינו גרשום ורבץ תורה בנרבונה והעמיד תלמידים..."

"And there were in Narbonne great sages, heads of yeshivas...the first who is known to us in our traditions is R. Yaakov the Prophet, son of R. Moshe, son of Rabbi Abun. And Rabbi Yehudah, son of R. Moshe who is known as de sa Donçela (of the damsel), and he received from Rabbeinu Gershom and taught Torah in Narbonne and taught students..."

So really the first known Rosh Yeshiva of Narbonne was Rabbi Yaakov the Prophet (on this title, see for example here). It was conjectured by modern historians (e.g., Avraham Grossman, Chananel Mack) that Rabbi Yehudah b. Rabbi Moshe Ha'Darshan refers to Rabbi Moshe Ha'Darshan's son, and that the previous figure, Rabbi Yaakov, is also related to the same family, perhaps being Rabbi Moshe's father. That would make Rabbi Abun Rabbi Moshe Ha'Darshan's great-grandfather.

Both Grossman and Mack also proposed that this Rabbi Abun may be identified with Rabbi Abun the Great (רבי אבון הגדול), or a descendant of his. Rabbi Abun the Great lived ca. the early 10th century CE, and was a descendant of Rabbi Shimon of Le Mans in France, as well as a member of the Kalonymos family. Helpfully enough, on Hebrew Wikipedia there's a family tree for the Kalonymos family (an English version can also be found, but it does not include Rabbi Abun). Per that tree, which is based on a variety of sources, Rabbi Abun was a great-grandson of Rabbi Moshe ben Kalonymos, who is known to have received Kabbalistic teachings from Abu Aharon ben Rav Shmuel the Babylonian. The oldest known ancestor of the family is the ca. 8th century CE Rabbeinu Meshulam.

Other prominent descendants of Rabbi Abun include: Rabbi Shimon the Great of Mainz (in turn an ancestor of several prominent rabbis, such the family of Rabbi Moshe of Londres [London]), and the Chassid family: Rabbi Kalonymos Ha'Chassid, Rabbi Shmuel Ha'Chassid and Rabbi Yehudah Ha'Chassid. It is believed that Rashi may have also been a descendant of Rabbi Abun (see here).

To my knowledge, no teachings of Rabbi Abun have been preserved, but perhaps some may yet turn up in the future (B"H new-old materials pop up every now and then).

To sum up what we know about Rabbi Abun: He came from the prominent Kalonymos family, specifically from a French branch that at one point settled in Le Mans, France. Descendants of his eventually moved to Narbonne (it's not known whether he himself also lived there; considering other descendants lived in Mainz and elsewhere, it doesn't appear necessary to assume this). He had many prominent descendants, among them perhaps Rabbi Moshe Ha'Darshan and perhaps also Rashi.

For more general information, see for example: Hannanel Mack, The Mystery of Rabbi Moshe Hadarshan (Hebrew), Jerusalem 5770/2010, pp. 65-66; Asher Frishman, The Early Ashkenazi Jews: Since Their Settlement in North-West Europe to the First Crusade (Hebrew), Tel Aviv 2008, pp. 121, 405-408.

title: What's With Snakes and Philistines?
content:
# What's With Snakes and Philistines? ## Frage

Samson defeated the Philistine lords (see Judges 16). He is blessed by Jacob to wage war as a snake (Genesis 49:17 per Rashi).

Isaiah foretells the downfall of the Philistines (Isaiah 14:29).

אַֽל־תִּשְׂמְחִ֤י פְלֶ֙שֶׁת֙ כֻּלֵּ֔ךְ כִּ֥י נִשְׁבַּ֖ר שֵׁ֣בֶט מַכֵּ֑ךְ כִּֽי־מִשֹּׁ֤רֶשׁ נָחָשׁ֙ יֵ֣צֵא צֶ֔פַע וּפִרְי֖וֹ שָׂרָ֥ף מְעוֹפֵֽף׃

Rejoice not, all Philistia, Because the staff of him that beat you is broken. For from the stock of a snake there sprouts an asp, A flying seraph branches out from it.

The Metzudot Dovid states:

כי משורש נחש. ר״ל מגזע המלכים המכים בך מאז יצא מלך מולך הדומה לצפע והוא חזקיה שירבה להכות בו: for from the stock of snake - from the race of kings that beat you before will issue a king similar to an asp, which is Hezekiah, who will greatly beat with it ...

This means that the Davidic kings who attacked the Philistines were known as snakes.

Why are Davidic Kings and Samson framed in terms of snakes vis a vis the Philistines?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The Kli Yakar writes on the verse you quote from Sefer Bereishis:

ומה שמצינו, שמשה המשיל את דן לגור אריה ויעקב המשילו לנחש, רמז שכל דיין יש לו מלחמה פנים ואחור יש מעיזים בפניו לומר לו מוסיף אני עליך דיינים, כמ״ש (דברים א יב) טרחכם ומשאכם וריבכם. ויש מרנן אחריו אבל לא בפניו, ע״כ צריך להיות בעל כח ואמיץ רוח ללחום פנים ואחור, ולא יתן את לבו לכל הדברים אשר ידברו בין בפניו בין אחוריו, אלא יהיה כאריה ונחש זה כחו באחוריו וזה כחו בפניו וזה רמז נכון.

And regarding what we find that Moshe compared Dan to a young lion, while Yaakov compared him to a snake — this is a hint that every judge has battles both ‘from the front’ and ‘from behind.’ There are those who brazenly confront him to his face, saying: ‘We will add judges over you,’ as it is written (Devarim 1:12), ‘Your troubles, your burdens, and your quarrels.’ And there are those who murmur about him behind his back, but not in his presence. Therefore he must be strong and courageous of spirit, to fight both from the front and from the back, and he should not set his heart on all the words that people speak — whether before him or behind him. Rather, he should be like a lion and a snake: the lion’s strength is in facing forward, and the snake’s strength is from behind. And this is a fitting allusion.

So possibly, they were just more savvy to the way of conflict and had an heightened awareness to the mumblings "behind" them, and thus the snake reference is the ability to also retaliate from the back.

Alternatively, note the Rabbeinu Bachya:

דן ידין עמו. זה שמשון שהיה משבט דן והיה שופט ישראל ועל כן הזכיר ידין כי היה שופט לא מלך, כאחד שבטי ישראל כמיוחד שבשבטים זה יהודה שכתוב בו ידך בערף אויביך גם השופט הזה יגבר על אויביו וינצחם

דן ידין עמו, “Dan will judge his people.” This is a reference to Samson the judge who was a member of the tribe of Dan. The reason Yaakov said ידין “he will judge,” is because Samson was only a judge and not a king. כאחד שבטי ישראל, “uniting the tribes of Israel.” The word כאחד is to be understood as כמיוחד, “like the unique one amongst the tribes,” like Yehudah of whom it is said that his hands were at the nape of his enemies. The judge Samson from the tribe of Dan would display similar strength when vanquishing his enemies.

In other words, Shimshon like the kings who came from Yehuda were similar in the fact that they were unique in the level of strength they demonstrated when fighting their enemies. Indeed the Malbim notes that the reference of snake in the posuk in Yeshaya that you brought is alluding to a viper, a more harmful serpent rather than a "regular" snake.

The Tur Ha'Aruch makes a similar assessment:

כאחד. פי' כמיוחד שבשבטים דהיינו יהודה. אי נמי פי' ידין עמו כאחד שדן לכל ישראל כאחד ודימה שמשון לנחש שלא הי' מקבץ חיל לבוא עליהם אלא הוא לבדו יוצא אליהם כמו הצפעוני היוצא ממאורה על הולכי הדרך

כאחד, “similar to the “one,” i.e. the tribe of Yehudah who normally played the role of saviour of his people. The meaning could also be that Shimshon, from the tribe of Dan, would be the only judge who would rule over the entire people, something that otherwise would be the prerogative of the tribe of Yehudah. Yaakov likened Shimshon the Danite to a snake, as just like a snake he acted on his own, without the support of an army. He acted aggressively just as certain types of snakes who attack unsuspecting travelers without warning.

title: Trop for reading Torah on Leil Rosh Hashanah
content:
# Trop for reading Torah on Leil Rosh Hashanah ## Frage

During the Arvit service on Leil Rosh Hashanah, after the sh'ma and the amidah, in Machzor Lev Shalem (common in Conservative congregations) there's a section called "Kiddush Hashanah" for the dedication of the new year. (Mostly piyyutim, and an announcement of the year.)

In my machzor, this section begins with Torah: B'reishit 1:1–5. (You're not getting out a sefer Torah for a whole torah service here – just reading a few verses from the machzor.) Is it traditional to read these verses, or chant them? If you chant, do you use the special torah trop for high holy days, or the more common one that we use on Shabbat/Monday/Thursday?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

This is not well-sourced, but based on usual Conservative practice, if you read from the Torah scroll, then you use the appropriate trope for the occasion, and on Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur, that would be the High Holiday trope or stubentrop as it is traditionally called in minhag ashkenaz.

If however, you are not performing an actual kriat Torah from the scroll (which you would not be for this little pious interlude in the evening between Aleinu and Kiddush), but are instead just reading Torah verses similar to how one does in birchot ha-shachar, then the congregation or Ba'al/Ba'alat Tefillah has wide latitude in choosing how to intone the verses. They could choose to read it in trope, similar to how many congregations execute Shema, they could choose to read it in English or spoken Hebrew, or they could choose to use any appropriate tune. There is not a set tradition for it, so one must use judgement as to what is appropriate in the setting.

title: Beracha on Popcorn
content:
# Beracha on Popcorn ## Frage

Which beracha should be made on popcorn? Is the fact that some corn is planted for the purpose of making popcorn factor in the halacha. I have heard some people say that this would make a difference.

If so, can one assume that all popcorn is made from such crop?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

OU and brachos.org both mention the initial blessing is ha-adama and the final blessing borei nefashot.

dinonline explains

According to most authorities, the berachah for popcorn is ha'adama.

Rav Moshe Feinstein explains (Torah Vehora'ah 5733) that this is because although the form has changed, it has not been mashed or ground, and a change of form other than mashing or grinding does not alter the blessing to shehakol. See also Birkas Hanehenin (p. 113), Vezos Haberachah (p. 102), and others.

Note that according to Rav Mordechai Eliyahu, the berachah for most communities (other than Yemenites) would be shehakol.

title: Jewish sources linking Caleb & Rachav to King David
content:
# Jewish sources linking Caleb & Rachav to King David ## Frage

The opening of the book of Chronicles is a bit of a muddle, particularly the part around Caleb. He has several sets of descendants and seems to be married to Miriam, Pharaoh's Daughter (midrash). I had "known" until now that he was married to Rahav but just discovered that Megilla 14b says Joshua married Rahav.

Anyway, the Christian Bible's book of Matthew says Rahav married Salmon/Salma (Nachshon's son) and was Boaz's mother.

In Chronicles, there are two Salmas. One is Nachshon's son, one is Caleb's son (2:51 and 54). This son of Caleb is the "father of Beit Lehem (Bethlehem?) and the next sentence mentions someone from בֵֽית־רֵכָֽב. (Different spelling from Rahav). One of Caleb's wives is called Efrat, which is also Beit Lehem.

It would make sense that Rahav is the ancestor of the Messiah to add another questionable woman to Lot's daughters, Tamar, and Batsheva's club. And it would be cool to have David descended from Caleb because he's such an interesting character inserted into the lives of several other prominent characters. Is there a Jewish source for Caleb and Rahav being connected to David?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

I'm not aware of a connection between Rachav and David. Eliyahu Zuta 22 states:

"ראב"י אומר למה נקרא שמה רחב משום שהיא נעשית רחבה בזכיות וזכתה שיצאו ממנה (שבעה מלכים) ושמונה נביאים."
"Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov said: Why was she called Rachav? Because she would become wide (Rechava) with merits, and she merited that (seven kings) and eight prophets were descended from her."

Other sources name the exact prophets descended from her, all long post-dating David. The section in ellipses appears in the text but many editions put in ellipses because it's thought to be a scribal error.1

Kalev is an entire different story. Kalev, particularly in modern Tanach studies (I don't mean academic), is thought to have been, or represented, an ideological and political rival to the royal lineage from the family of Ram (the father of Nachshon). A good essay on the matter is Rabbi Yaakov Medan's ""Nabal said in his heart: There is no God", "Ha! He who builds his house with unfairness and his upper chambers with injustice who makes his neighbors work without pay and does not give them their wages"" (Hebrew), Megadim 4 (1988/5748), pp. 23-54.

The gist of the idea is thus: Peretz, Yehudah's eldest from Tamar, had Chetzron, his eldest. Chetzron in his youth2 had three children: Yerachmeel, Ram and Kalev/Kaluvi. The latter is most likely, from a p'shat perspective, not Kalev ben Yefuneh.3 Each of the three lines vied for the position of fulfiller of Yaakov's prophecy of "The scepter shall not depart from Judah, nor the ruler’s staff from between his feet" (Genesis 49:10). Yerachmeel, we are told (Yerushalmi Sanhedrin 2:3), married a foreign woman, and so was essentially cut off from the game. That left two lines: Ram and Kaluvi.

Various prominent figures were descended from Kaluvi: Chur, one of the assistants of Moshe (along with Aharon and Yehoshua), Betzalel (architect of the tabernacle), Kalev ben Yefuneh (see n. 3 below). Their prominence strengthened Kaluvi's claim to the throne. Another of Kaluvi's descendants was Naval the Carmelite. This is both stated by the sages (Yerushalmi ibid., held by multiple commentators, and makes sense from a p'shat level (Naval is called "Kalibi" and the region is called "Negev of Kalev"). Naval represents the epitome of disrespecting David (and by extension that of the House of Ram)'s claim to the monarchy. According to the above-linked Yerushalmi, Naval argued that both Yerachmeel and Ram lost their claims to the crown for marrying foreign wives: Yerachmeel married Atarah and Boaz, Ram's descendant, married Ruth the Moabitess. We see in the text in Shmuel that Naval greatly disrespects David - but not out of loyalty to Shaul, as was the case of the Ziphites (Shmuel 1:26:1). It was because he believed he should rule after Shaul, not David.

Rabbi Medan then noted that by Chazal Miriam is identified with Efrat, as well as with Puah, who was promised to be the matriarch of kings (Sotah 11b). Miriam/Efrat seemingly lost out on the blessing by marrying Kalev ben Chur/Yefuneh, who was not the father of the royal lineage, yet the same passage in the Talmud states that David was a descendant of Miriam. Rav Medan also noted the fact that Salma of Beit Lechem, who would have made more sense to be identified with Salmon, whose descendants lived in Beit Lechem, is one of the sons of Kalev and Efrat, and Beit Lechem is called Efrat. He suggests that the solution to these problems would be identifying Salma with Salmon, and not a direct son of Kalev and Efrat, but rather: a male-line descendant of Ram and a female-line descendant of Kalev and Efrat. The joining of these two rival lines brought David. He finds some further basis for this suggestion in the verse stated by David: "I am a stranger to my brothers, an alien to my mother's children" (Psalms 69:9) - relatives from David's mother's side (or perhaps Salma's mother's side) alienated David for being descended from a Moabite woman; Naval, one of these extended relatives, actively disrespected David.

But, as mentioned above, it was the unity between the two rival lines that brought about David, and thus both lines merited to be ancestors of the Judahite monarchy. Naval died from heartbreak when Avigail chose to recognize David's right to the crown (Shmuel 1:25:36-38). That was the end of the male-line Kalebites' attempts of challenging the crown.4

1 I have not seen clarifications on the matter, but my guess would be that even if we take Rachav to have been the ancestor of all of the Ephraimite kings (since Yehoshua was from Ephraim), we would still end up with more than seven, given that Omri and Achav were also ancestors of the Judahites kings, having given daughters to wed them.

2 In his old age, Chetzron remarried and one of their descendants was Yair ben Menashe (Chronicles 1:2:21-23). Yair was adopted into the tribe of his mother, Menashe, and thus essentially got a get-out-of-jail-free-card from the Judahite political tensions of his siblings and their descendants.

3 The issue was also noted by Rav Medan, but he declined to discuss it further. I don't know what his opinion on the matter is, but personally, I favor Rabbi Ze'ev Yaavetz's position (Toldot Yisrael vol. 1, p. 195, nn. 1-2) that Kalev ben Yefuneh should be identified with Kalev ben Chur, the latter being, in turn, a son of Kalev ben Chetzron.

4 Rabbi Medan also argued for the possibility that Kilav the son of David from Avigail was actually fathered by Naval, and adopted by David. If correct, this would represent another aspect of the unification of and political truce called between the two lines (Ram and Kaluvi).

title: Why isn't the shortened version of chazaras hashatz utilized for shacharis?
content:
# Why isn't the shortened version of chazaras hashatz utilized for shacharis? ## Frage

At mincha there's a technique to do away with most of the chazzan's repetition, ending it after Kedusha.

I've never seen it employed by morning prayers.

Why is that?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: -2)

It seems likely that as it would do away with Birchas Kohanim (where it is said daily), which is said toward the end of chazaras hashatz, it became customary not to truncate shacharis, which then spilled over to places where Birchas Kohanim isn't recited daily.

By Mincha however, where Birchas Kohanim isn't recited, owing to concerns of wine by lunch, no such issue arose, paving the way for a shortened chazaras hashatz to get off the ground.

title: Would the phrase "blessings!" be considered bad form in responding to a pregnancy announcement?
content:
# Would the phrase "blessings!" be considered bad form in responding to a pregnancy announcement? ## Frage

I know that when someone announces they are pregnant, the correct response is to say b'shaah tovah (In a good hour) - meaning "may this blessing come to fulfillment." The reason I was taught is that it's a practice of caution where you don't want to assume a blessing is a given before it arrives due to the common issues some have with pregnancy.

I say "blessings!" a lot. It tends to be my go-to phrase in life other than mazel tov when any good thing happens or is going to happen. No idea when I started but it's just something I say a lot. I always felt it just really emphasizes "good things are coming, good things are happening, and may good things continue to happen." Just a general expression of the blessing of the moment.

My question is does that word carry with it a problematic connotation of saying "Mazel Tov/Congratulations" to a pregnant woman or is it multifaceted enough a word in that one could assume it also means "Blessings" (May you have this blessing)

I try to be conscious of the way I talk because I wasn't raised observant and I've come to realize I carried over a lot of secular speaking conventions that might unintentionally send someone the wrong message. So I'm just trying to understand if what I'm doing is a problem and if I should make an effort to change?

title: Did Samson Fulfill חִ֣יל אָחַ֔ז יֹשְׁבֵ֖י פְּלָֽשֶׁת?
content:
# Did Samson Fulfill חִ֣יל אָחַ֔ז יֹשְׁבֵ֖י פְּלָֽשֶׁת? ## Frage

The Targum Yonatan on Exodus 15:14 reads in part:

דְּחִילָא אֲחָדַת יַת כָּל עַמּוּדֵי דַיְירֵי אַרְעֲהוֹן דִּפְּלִשְׁתָּאֵי
terror will seize all the pillars of the inhabitants of the Philistine land.

We have 1) seize, 2) pillars, and 3) Philistines.

("Pillars" is likely a reference to Philistine lords).

Cf. the Targum to Judges 16:29:

וַאֲחַד שִׁמְשׁוֹן יַת תְּרֵין עַמוּדֵי מְצִיעָאֵי דְבֵיתָא מַתְקַן עִלַוֵיהוֹן
He (Samson) seized the two middle pillars that the temple rested upon.

We know that Samson killed all of the Philistine lords ("pillars") when he brought the house down. Moreover, the Mechilta states on חִ֣יל אָחַ֔ז יֹשְׁבֵ֖י פְּלָֽשֶׁת:

אָמְרוּ: אֵין לָהֶם דֶּרֶךְ מִכָּל מָקוֹם אֶלָּא עָלֵינוּ, וְעַכְשָׁו הֵן בָּאִין וּבוֹזְזִין אֶת נְכָסֵינוּ, וּמַחְרִיבִין אֶת אַרְצֵנוּ!
they (the dwellers of Plasheth) said They have no other way (to enter the land) but by way of our land, and now they will come and rob us and lay waste our land.

Samson is expressly identified as the one who lays waste to their land -

Judges 16:25:

וַיִּרְא֤וּ אֹתוֹ֙ הָעָ֔ם וַֽיְהַלְל֖וּ אֶת־אֱלֹהֵיהֶ֑ם כִּ֣י אָמְר֗וּ נָתַ֨ן אֱלֹהֵ֤ינוּ בְיָדֵ֙נוּ֙ אֶת־א֣וֹיְבֵ֔נוּ וְאֵת֙ מַחֲרִ֣יב אַרְצֵ֔נוּ וַאֲשֶׁ֥ר הִרְבָּ֖ה אֶת־חֲלָלֵֽינוּ׃
When the people saw him, they sang praises to their god, chanting, “Our god has delivered into our hands The enemy who lay waste to our land, And who slew so many of us.”

*Do, thus, the biblical words חִ֣יל אָחַ֔ז יֹשְׁבֵ֖י פְּלָֽשֶׁת (also) refer to

  • the pillars that Samson would seize

&

  • the concomitant fear that the Philistine lords/pillars would be seized with

as Samson brought the house down?*

title: What is today's punishment for murder?
content:
# What is today's punishment for murder? ## Frage

The Torah mandates the death penalty for intentional murderers. But no Jewish court has issued a death verdict since the year 40 or so, because the rabbis demanded high levels of proof. Since then, I believe only secular courts have handled murder. The State of Israel punishes murder (intentional or not) by up to life in prison, but the President routinely commutes that to 20 years or less, except for terrorists.

Is this the extent of the halakha for murder today? Are there any Jewish laws for monetary compensation to the survivors (as there are for causing harm that does not result in death)?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

There is a well documented history of as late as the Vaad Arba Haratzos and perhaps even later of Jewish courts meting out corporal punishments such as amputation, prison and I believe death too. Mostly done with permission of the secular courts and often to retain their independence.

title: What does it mean to be a "Father"?
content:
# What does it mean to be a "Father"? ## Frage

Expanding upon my earlier question about what it means to be "God," I am interested in better understanding what it means for YHWH to be "Father" and for Israel to be His (firstborn) "son". I'm especially interested in any theological works that expand upon these titles in a technical way.

People will often say something like "God is the Father of all" in the sense that He is the Creator of all. However, this doesn't seem to be the sense in which scripture uses the term. After all, Israel was not the first people on earth; thus it would not make sense to declare them them the "firstborn son" if this was what was meant by YHWH being their "Father" - nor would it explain why Israel is declared to be a "son" but Egypt is not.

It is also interesting to note that YHWH declares Israel to be His firstborn son BEFORE he saves them and establishes himself as their God; and they His People.

My current thought is that the basis for this Father-son relationship is none other than the Abrahamic Covenant and the tradition of circumcision. Circumcision of the flesh - which is symbolic of circumcision of the heart - is what establishes the Father-son relationship, and it proceeds the God-people relationship. This is reflected in the promise of the New Covenant wherein YHWH writing the His Law upon our hearts and mind proceeds Him being Israel's God and they His People.

Jeremiah 31:33 (Revised JPS, 2023)

But such is the covenant I will make with the House of Israel after these days—declares GOD: I will put My Teaching into their inmost being and inscribe it upon their hearts. Then I will be their God, and they shall be My people.

Albeit, the use of "then" here may or may not be accurate. Not all translations use it.

Are there any good resources that explore this Father-son relationship?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Understanding Hashem as our Father means recognizing that our relationship with God is based on a covenantal bond like in a family; Israel is not only a subject of an almighty Creator but a child of the eternal Father; this father-child relationship was established in the covenant with Abraham and sealed through the Brit Mila; every Jew enters this familial relationship with God unconditionally and irrevocably at birth (or entry into the covenant); whether Israel behaves appropriately or not, Hashem continues to call it "My child" (sefaria.org), even if He must sometimes correct or punish it; no misconduct can erase the fundamental identity as God's son – bein kach u’bein kach kruyin banim laMakom; this understanding should give people confidence and dignity: we remain children of the King; "Chamol al Ma’asecha" – God ultimately has mercy on us "like a father over sons," therefore there is always a way back into His arms through Teshuva.

Simultaneously, the sonship of Israel brings obligations with it. Just as a son honors the father, so we owe God kavod and obedience. "Banim atem la’Hashem Elokechem" – precisely because you are children of the Eternal, "lo titgodedu" – do not be disloyal or rebellious, but trust Him (Ibn Ezra on Deut. 14:1 sefaria.org). The covenant in the flesh and in the heart demands that we live differently from nations that do not know God – "lo ta’asu kema’aseihem … ki am kadosh atah" (Ibn Ezra ibid.). A child of the king must prove worthy of their status. In modern language: Our identity as children of God should be an incentive for moral greatness and holiness. For the Shem haAv (Name of the Father) is upon us – "banim atem la-Hashem Elokeichem" is both an honor and an obligation. The Halacha teaches us in every area: From dietary laws to mourning rites – we behave differently "for we are children of the King". In practice, this also means that we should see each other as siblings. All Jews – indeed, all people – are ultimately children of ONE Father in heaven; therefore, the Chachamim prohibit excessive resentment or vengeance among brothers, "lo tisna et achikha bilvavekha" (Lev. 19:17) – "do not hate your brother in your heart" –, for "ma yomar avikhem shebashamayim?" – "what would your Father in heaven say to this?".

Finally, the sources strengthen us that the fatherhood of God is a source of hope: Just as a loving father always opens the door to his lost son, so Hashem waits for Israel's return. Prophecy promises that full reconciliation will one day come: "You will be called sons of the living God" (Hosea 2:1), without blemish and alienation. In the age of Ge'ulah (redemption), the ideal "ben yakir" – "a dear son" (Jeremiah 31:20) – will be completely fulfilled. Every Jew and convert who partakes in the covenant can be certain of this love. No other faith has this intimate concept: God, the King of the universe, is also our loving Father, who educates us and never rejects us. This should ignite in us Ahavat Hashem (love of God), but also Yir'at Hashem (awe) not to dishonor the name of our Father. As it says in the Aseret Hadibrot: "I am the Lord, your God" – that is the paternal closeness; and at the same time "You shall have no other gods" – that is the exclusive loyalty a child owes to his father.

Pidyon haBen (Redemption of the Firstborn): A notable legal implementation of the idea "Israel is God's firstborn" is found in the commandment to "redeem" all firstborn sons to the Kohen (God's representative); in Bamidbar 3:13, God says, „Kol bekhor bnei Yisrael li hu … li yihyu“ – "Every firstborn of the children of Israel is Mine... they shall be Mine," as a consequence of God sparing the Israelite firstborns in Egypt.

Human parents vs. God: Our duties towards earthly parents (Kibbud Av waEm) also have a connection to the relationship with God. The Gemara says: "Shlosha shutafin yesh ba’adam: HaKadosh Baruch Hu, aviv ve’imo" – "Three partners are involved in a person: God, his father, and his mother" (Kiddushin 30b). Whoever honors their parents is considered as if they honor God.

Prayer and Address: In Tefilla, we often address God as "Avinu" (Our Father) – for example, in Avinu Malkenu (Our Father, our King) or in the daily Berachot "Avinu haAv harachaman" (Our merciful Father). The Mishna (Ta’anit 2:2) teaches that on Yom Kippur, the Kohen Gadol pronounced the Shem HaMeforash, and the people prayed: "Baruch shem kevod malchuto" etc., because Israel was allowed to plead with God as children. In the "Prayer for the Peace of the State", we speak of "Avinu shebashamayim" (Our Father in Heaven). These liturgical forms stem from the awareness that we are legitimately allowed to call God 'Father' because He Himself has called it so. The Bracha "Avinu Malkeinu" illustrates: God is not only a distant King but also a close Father – there is both reverence (Malchut) and love/intimacy (Av). Judaism allows – unlike some ancient philosophies – a very intimate address to God; yet reverence remains (we do not casually say "Papa" to God, but rather "Avinu" with a mix of love and reverence).

Avinu shebashamayim, ten belibeinu bina lehavin u’lehaskil, lishmoa, lilmod u’lelameid, lishmor u’la’asot u’lekayem et kol divrei Talmud Toratekha b’ahavah

Yehi ratzon shenizkeh kulanu lachush tamid et ahavat Avinu Malkeinu, velashuv biteshuvah shleimah elav, bimherah beyameinu, amen.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

In Kabbalah/Chassidut, the Father-son relationship is explain to mean that we fulfil Hashem's will in the same way that a child fulfils a father's will:

וביאור הענין בד״פ. הנה בחי׳ הנשמה המלובשת בגוף שנק׳ רגל שנת״ל הטעם מה שנק׳ רגל מפני שהיא בחי׳ אחרונה שבנשמה דהיינו הארה לבד שנמשכה להחיות את הגוף ומתלבשת בפנימיותו כו׳, הנה עוד זאת מורה שם רגל ע״ו שהוא בבחי׳ ביטול לאלקות, וכמו ביטול הרגל לגבי הראש שהוא בטל בתכלית כנראה לעין כל דלכל אשר יחפץ יטנו בתנועה אנה ואנה, ואין לו רצון וחפץ אחר לשנות המעשה מצד עצמו כלל כו׳. כמו״כ הוא מה שהנשמה נק׳ רגל והוא בחי׳ יעקב יו״ד עקב הוא להורות על הביטול שיש בנשמות לאלקות שבטלים בתכלית וכמא׳ ברא כרעא דאבוה, דמה שנק׳ כרעא דאבוה הוא מפני שיש בהבן ביטול גדול אל האב, וכמו שאנו רואין שמה שיעלה ברצון האב יעשה הבן תומ״י בלי שום מניעה ועיכוב ובלי שום רצון אחר כו׳. וכמו״כ בנש״י שיש להם התקשרות וביטול לאלקות להיות בטל רצונך מפני רצונו ית׳ ולקיים רצה״ע בקיום התו״מ בקעומ״ש לא מצד איזה טעם ושכל, כ״א מצד הביטול שלו שבטל לאלקות בבחי׳ קעומ״ש ה״ה מקיים רצונו ית׳ בקיום התומ״צ כו׳. וביטול הזה אינו בהנה״א לבד, כ״א גם בהגוף והנה״ט שלו

And to explain the matter more precisely: the aspect of the soul that is enclothed in the body, which is called "foot" - as explained above, that it is called "foot" because it is the last level of the soul, that is, only a radiance which extends to give life to the body and enclothes itself inwardly within it, this too is indicated by the term "foot," for the foot is in a state of bitul (self-nullification) to the head. For the nullification of the foot to the head is absolute, as is visible to the eye: wherever the head desires, it immediately directs the foot to move, without any will or desire of its own to alter the action at all.

So too is it with the soul being called "foot": this is the aspect of Yaakov i.e. yud ekev ("heel"), to indicate the bitul which is in souls, that they are utterly nullified to G-dliness. As it is said, "a son is the leg of his father", meaning that the son is so called because of his great bitul to the father. For as we see, whatever arises in the father's will, the son does immediately, without delay or hindrance, and without any other will of his own.

So too with Israel: they have a connection and bitul to G-dliness, to nullify their own will before His will, and to fulfil His will in the observance of Torah and mitzvot, and in accepting the yoke of Heaven, not because of any reason or intellect, but because of their bitul, that by being nullified to G-dliness, they fulfill His will in observing Torah and mitzvot. And this bitul is not only in the Divine soul, but also in the body and in the animal soul.

I.e. our soul reaches all the way up beyond the creation, right unto Hashem's very essence, higher than angels, but at its "foot", it is enclothed in an animal soul and physical body. Our being Hashem's "children" implies that despite the coarseness of the physical body and its lusts, temptations and strong, selfish will, it is still ultimately obedient to the levels above - the Godly levels that are wholly obedient and yearning for Hashem, just like a child is to his father.

The way to think about it is like this: when someone finds out that someone else is his father, then there is a natural force that comes over him of bitul; a sense of humility, deference, desire to please and serve the father. Israel have this bitul in their souls for Hashem, Torah and mitzvot, and it extends into their very bodies. It doesn't come from logic or convincing, it's just there.

This ma'amar gets a bit more technical. In what way are we higher than angels? We are made in Hashem's image, which specifically means that we are quite literally His children. Children are born from their parents, and as such take on their parents likeness, in every sense: they are human, but more than that, they look like their parents, they think like their parents and they have the same general personality and inclinations as their parents.

In Kabbalah, the child is born from the Chochma (the intellectual sphere) of the parent, and humans (and more specifically, Israel) are born from Hashem's Chochma. Chochma contains within it the entirety of the "humanity" of a person, and thus the child inherits the whole spiritual DNA of the parent.

Angels are not so - they not "born" in this way. They are specific - some are created from Hashem's Kindness, some from His Might, some from His Tiferet etc. They are more akin to "students" to a teacher: a student doesn't inherit the very essence of the intellect of the teacher, but rather just receives some external intellectual light from the teacher - a specific lesson. So too, angels receive more external light from Hashem, whereas souls are truly "born" from the inwardness of the light, i.e. as we said, similar to how a child doesn't just receive lessons from the father, but actually inherits the fathers very faculty of intellect, and thus all the other traits.

Deep stuff, but explained exquisitely by the Rebbe Rashab in Hemshech 5656, Rosh Hashana, where the above quote is from.

title: How can the diversity of Minhag (מנהג) and Nusach (נוסח) be reconciled with the prohibition "lo titgodedu" (לא תתגודדו)?
content:
# How can the diversity of Minhag (מנהג) and Nusach (נוסח) be reconciled with the prohibition "lo titgodedu" (לא תתגודדו)? ## Frage

As derived in Yevamot 13b–14a from lo titgodedu (לא תתגודדו) that within a community or a Beit Din, two different Halachot on the same matter should not be practiced, how can the current diversity of Minhagim (מנהגים) and Nuschaot (נוסחאות) within the same synagogue or community be justified? Are these differences considered "separate communities" in the halachic sense (like two Batei Din בעיר אחת), or do they represent a prohibited division within a Kehilla?

Is the existence of Ashkenazi and Sephardi traditions a violation of "Lo Titgodedu"?

The claim that Sephardim/Ashkenazim were "traditionally" separated by city is misleading halachically—it concerns separate Kehillot/Batei Din, not geography.

The blanket permission to publicly continue one's own Minhag in any foreign community ignores Minhag ha-Makom and the lo-titgodedu guideline within a Kehilla.

title: Animal cruelty in the Gemara
content:
# Animal cruelty in the Gemara ## Frage

In Masechet Avoda Zara 13b it is written

And what constitutes destroying? He locks the door before it, and the animal dies on its own (ואיזהו עיקור נועל דלת בפניה היא מתה)

How does the Gemara instruct to kill an animal in such a way even though it committed idolatry? After all the animal is not guilty! And what about animal cruelty? Is that not important?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

The very same gemara brings the answer to your question, a few lines before your quote

אָמַר מָר: בְּהֵמָה תֵּיעָקֵר. וְהָא אִיכָּא צַעַר בַּעֲלֵי חַיִּים! אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: אָמַר רַחֲמָנָא ״אֶת סוּסֵיהֶם תְּעַקֵּר״.

The Gemara returns to discuss the baraita that cited the opinion of Rabbi Natan. The Master said above: Any animal that one bought there should be destroyed. The Gemara asks: But isn’t there a requirement to prevent suffering to animals? Abaye said: Although there is an enjoinder against causing suffering to a living creature, it is permitted when necessary, as the Merciful One states to Joshua: “You shall destroy their horses” (Joshua 11:6).

In other words, there are priorities. Not causing suffering to animals is important (and the gemara in Baba Metzia 32b discusses whether it a rabbinic or Torah-level prohibition), but avoda zara is more important (something we see all over masechet AZ: there are lots of humrot which are specific to avoda zara).
