title: Did Rambam contemplate Maaseh Bereishit and/or Maaseh Merkavah in the bathroom?
content:
# Did Rambam contemplate Maaseh Bereishit and/or Maaseh Merkavah in the bathroom? ## Frage

The first two chapters in Mishneh Torah are dedicated to metaphysics, which Rambam identifies as Maaseh Merkavah (Yesodei_HaTorah 2.11). The next two explicate physics, which Rambam fingers as Maaseh Bereishit (ibid 4.10).

He terms them both Pardes (4.13) and even includes them in the definition of Talmud (Talmud_Torah 1.12).

They are placed higher (Yesodei_HaTorah 4.13) than typical Torah study.

It is forbidden to even think about Torah (Keriat Shema 3.4) in the bathroom. One would think that it is certainly forbidden to contemplate Pardes in the bathroom.

However, his language וְלֹא קְרִיַּת שְׁמַע בִּלְבַד, אֶלָּא כָּל עִנְיָן שֶׁהוּא מִדִּבְרֵי קֹדֶשׁ would seem to preclude physics and metaphysics.

(Compare with what kind of study necessitates Birchas haTorah (Tefillah 7.10)

In a word, did Rambam contemplate Maaseh Bereishit and/or Maaseh Merkavah in the bathroom?

(Sparked by this explanation of Rabbeinu Manoach)

title: What does it mean to be one's "God"?
content:
# What does it mean to be one's "God"? ## Frage

Often times, I feel, we use the term "God" like a personal identifier for the LORD. This is to be expected since in Judaism there is only one proper "God" (although angels and men like Moses have been referred to as God as well). In fact, it appears that out of reverence for God's name, it is even common practice amongst Jews to write "G-d" instead of "God".

Nevertheless, the scriptures would appear to use the term more properly as a title that reflects the LORD's relationship to Israel. In fact, unless I'm reading the scriptures incorrectly, the LORD was not always "God". Rather, the LORD established himself as "God" simultaneously when he made Israel his "people."

Exodus 6:7 [The Contemporary Torah, 2006]

And I will take you to be My people, and I will be your God. And you shall know that I, יהוה, am your God who freed you from the labors of the Egyptians.

Leviticus 26:12 [The Contemporary Torah, 2006]

I will be ever present in your midst: I will be your God, and you shall be My people.

Jeremiah 31:33 [The Contemporary Torah, 2006]

But such is the covenant I will make with the House of Israel after these days—declares GOD: I will put My Teaching into their inmost being and inscribe it upon their hearts. Then I will be their God, and they shall be My people.

It would seem, therefore, that the biblical understanding of a "god" is one side of a relationship and the other side is the "people" who serve and follow that god. Abstractly speaking, the precise nature of this relationship may differ between different "gods" and "peoples" - but in the case of the LORD he established this relationship via the Covenant(s), Prophets, and the Law. And when people turn away from the LORD, he in turn rejects them and even ceases to serve as their "God."

Judges 10:13-14 [The Contemporary Torah, 2006]

Yet you have forsaken Me and have served other gods. No, I will not deliver you again.
Go cry to the gods you have chosen; let them deliver you in your time of distress!”

I am curious about how well defined a concept the term "god" is in Judaism and the "god"/"people" relationship. I expect the focus will be on the LORD and Israel specifically, of course. But I am curious if there are any Jewish Rabbis or works that go into depth on this topic and explore what it means for the LORD to become "God."

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

"To be 'G-d' in Jewish understanding means not only omnipotence in an abstract sense, but to be G-d for us – a counterpart that loves, demands, protects, and has made a covenant with us; Hashem has linked His identity with the history of Israel through revelation and redemption, which is why He is always invoked in our prayers as 'our G-d and G-d of our fathers'; this divine self-commitment to a specific people is unique, yet it does not make G-d's essence dependent on humans, but rather reveals His grace: He, the Infinite, wants to be 'the G-d' of a finite people to bring ethics and salvation to the world; Israel serves Him as Mamlechet Kohanim (kingdom of priests) and Goj Kadosch (holy nation); thus, rabbinic sources define the G-d–people relationship as an eternal covenant with mutual recognition; the Eternal is our G-d – we are His people; this formula is the essence of Judaism; may Israel always walk in the height of this calling so that 'Hashem Echad u’Schmo Echad' – G-d is recognized as the only King and His name is one in the world through His people (Zechariah 14:9)."

The destiny of Israel to be a "light for the nations" (אוֹר לַגּוֹיִם) emphasizes from the beginning an ethical and universal mission; already the prophet Isaiah promises Israel a role as a model and teacher for all peoples, as it is said: "וְנָתַתִּיךָ לְאוֹר גּוֹיִם לִהְיוֹת יְשׁוּעָתִי עַד קְצֵה הָאָרֶץ" – "I will make you a light for the nations, that my salvation may reach to the end of the earth" he.wikipedia.org; this ideal is to be understood ethically-universalistically: Israel's task is to bring God's morality and justice closer to the world, not through coercion, but through exemplary effect; the Torah emphasizes that the nations should recognize Israel's wisdom and legal culture: "These commandments are your wisdom and insight in the eyes of the nations," so that they exclaim: "Truly, a wise and understanding people!" (cf. Devarim/Deut 4:6-8); this is connected with the concept of Tikkun Olam (תיקון עולם), the improvement and healing of the world in accordance with the divine order; already in the ancient Hebrew Aleinu prayer, Jews pray for the world to be healed under God's kingship – "לתקן עולם במלכות שדי" –, expressing the universal hope that ultimately all people will call upon God's one name schechter.ac.il.

This universal calling is inseparably linked with high ethical demands. The Talmud even explains that God scattered Israel among the nations "only so that righteous people from the nations might join them" – thus gaining Gerim (converts to Judaism) daf-yomi.com. This makes it clear: Israel is to be a light by inspiring people to find goodness and turn to God. At the same time, rabbinic tradition admonishes absolute integrity in dealing with non-Jews: Rabbi Moshe of Coucy (13th century) emphasizes in Sefer Mitzvot Gadol that the long diaspora should prompt Israel to "stay away from vain things, hold fast to God's seal – the truth – and deceive neither Jews nor non-Jews." For if the Jews behaved dishonestly, "who would join them?" daf-yomi.com. Only morally exemplary behavior – truthfulness, charity, and justice – makes it possible to truly be a light for the nations. This ideal also corresponds to the kabbalistic idea that Israel, through its Mitzvot, redeems hidden sparks in creation and thus purifies the entire structure of the world – a cosmic Tikkun Olam, from which ultimately all creatures should benefit.

The Zohar and later Kabbalists see Israel as the spiritual center of the world: The Jewish soul carries a unique divine spark within it, which helps redeem all creation through the fulfillment of the commandments. The Ari (Rabbi Yitzchak Luria) taught that each mitzvah elevates the scattered sparks of light (ניצוצות) from the material world – ultimately a process from which the whole world spiritually benefits. Chabad Chassidism speaks of Israel being called to "transform the world's darkness into light" by filling the surroundings with God-consciousness. Thus, the Lubavitcher Rebbe said: "As 'a light unto the nations'... it is Israel's duty to lead the whole world to faith in the One God" hechabadorg.clhosting.org. This "being a light" is, according to Kabbalistic understanding, not a claim to mastery, but a selfless service: Israel lights the lights of truth so that ultimately "the knowledge of God fills the earth as the waters cover the sea."

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

Every effect has a cause; that cause, in and of itself, is the effect of another cause. To be G-d is to be the Causer of all causes, for which there is no other cause. When we call G-d עליון it means just that, grammatically: עילת העילות, Causer of causes. This is explored in depth in kabbalistic literature.

title: In Isa. 46:9 why is וְאֵין עוֹד אֱלֹהִים not translated "and there are no other gods?"
content:
# In Isa. 46:9 why is וְאֵין עוֹד אֱלֹהִים not translated "and there are no other gods?" ## Frage

I already asked this question at Biblical Hermeneutics, but to answer this needs someone knowing Hebrew better than that group, probably someone who recites this passage in Hebrew during worship.

Isa. 46:9: "זִכְרוּ רִאשֹׁנוֹת מֵעוֹלָם כִּי אָנֹכִי אֵל וְאֵין עוֹד אֱלֹהִים וְאֶפֶס כָּמוֹנִי׃"
JPS1985: "For I am God, and there is none else, I am divine, and there is none like Me".
JPSofA1917: "that I am God, and there is none else; I am God, and there is none like Me".
LXX: "ὅτι ἐγώ εἰμι ὁ θεός, καὶ οὐκ ἔστιν ἔτι πλὴν ἐμοῦ"

The literal translation of וְאֵ֣ין עֹ֔וד אֱלֹהִ֖ים seems to be "and [there are] no more gods."

I could find no translation of the Bible translating it this way, and I could not find in the Hebrew grammars or lexicons why I could not.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 10)

If you look closely, you’ll notice cantillation marks on each word.

Cantillation marks have two functions: They indicate tunes for liturgical recitation, and they mark syntax.

The cantillation mark over the word עוֹד (“other”) is called zāqēf qāṭōn, and indicates a disjunction similar to a comma. Therefore, עוֹד cannot form a phrase with the following word אֱלוֹהִים (“God(s)”). This makes the reading “no other gods” impossible.

This isn’t too unusual: The verse exhibits elliptical parallelism, which is a common device in scriptural poetry.

title: How can Rambam cite the prayer to angels said before entering the bathroom?
content:
# How can Rambam cite the prayer to angels said before entering the bathroom? ## Frage

Rambam doesn't allow prayer to angels, nor does he believe in angels in the traditional sense.

Rambam has no issue ignoring explicit and uncontested Talmudic laws when they are based upon belief in sheidim, ruchot, etc, which Maimonides doesn't believe in (see here, 'הערה ה).

This all so, why and how can he cite the Talmudic prayer said to the angels that accompany a person prior to entering the bathroom.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Rabbeinu Manoach interprets it as an instruction to your intellectual faculties to stand by while you take care of business:

המלאכים הם הכוחות השכליות. התכבדו מכובדים, הערה שאינו רוצה להשתמש בהן באותו זמן. שמרוני שמרוני, כלומר, שאינו מניח אותן לגמרי, אמנם אפילו באותו זמן דעתו עליהם להשתמש בהם אחר המעשה, כמו שכתוב שויתי ה׳ לנגדי תמיד. ואלו הכוחות נקראו מלאכי השרת על דרך משל.‏

This paper suggests Rambam deviates from the original text to avoid implying that it's a request for assistance. See there for further discussion.

title: Did the Jews wander in the desert for forty years as a punishment or as a test?
content:
# Did the Jews wander in the desert for forty years as a punishment or as a test? ## Frage

Bamidbar (14:26 ff) asserts that the Jews spent forty years in the desert as a punishment for the spying episode; one year for each of the forty days spent spying.

Otoh, Devarim (8:2 ff) posits that it was to test their faith.

How to reconcile?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

It seems from the particular language of the respective passages that the core forty year delay was indeed a punishment so that the generation that doubted God would die out and not enter the land whereas the way they were led on (Ramban) and/or manner they were dealt with (Ralbag) during said forty years was for educative purposes for the younger generation that would enter the land.

Ramban:

למען ענותך לנסותך לדעת את אשר בלבבך התשמור מצותיו אם לא, כי היה נסיון גדול להם שלא ידעו עצה לנפשם, ויכנסו במדבר הגדול לא מקום לחם, ואין בידם כלום מן המן, אבל ירד דבר יום ביומו וחם השמש ונמס (שמות ט״ז:כ״א), וירעבו אליו מאד, וכל זה עשו לשמור מצות השם ללכת כאשר יצוה. והשם היה יכול להוליכם בדרך הערים אשר סביבותיהם, אבל הביאם בנסיון הזה כי ממנו יודע שישמרו מצותיו לעולם.

…in order to afflict you, to test you, to know what was in your heart — whether you would keep His commandments or not — for it was a great trial for them, that they knew of no plan for themselves, and entered the great wilderness, a place without bread, and had nothing of the manna in hand; rather, it came down each day in its daily amount, and when the sun grew hot it melted (Exodus 16:21), and they greatly hungered for it. And all this they did in order to keep the commandment of the Lord, to go wherever He would command. And the Lord could have led them by way of the cities that were around them, but He brought them into this trial, for from it would be known that they would keep His commandments forever.

Ralbag:

התועלת השביעי הוא להודיע עומק מחשבות השם יתעלה שעם היות ישראל מתאחרים במדבר ארבעים שנה על צד העונש השתמש בזה לתועלת הוא לנסותם אם ישמרו מצות השם יתעלה אם לא כדי לעמוד על העת שיהיו ראויים בו לירושת הארץ ולזאת הסבה גם כן יסרם שם תכף מרותם מה שאינו ממנהג השם יתעלה כי הוא ארך אפים אבל להשגחת כל ישראל עשה זה כדי שישמרו מחטוא לי"י ולזה גם כן ענם והרעיבם במדבר ארבעים שנה להראות לישראל נפלאות השם יתעלה כדי שיחזקו לשמור מצותיו.

The seventh benefit is to make known the depth of the thoughts of the Exalted God: that although the Israelites tarried in the wilderness for forty years as a form of punishment, He utilized this for a beneficial purpose — namely, to test them, whether they would keep the commandments of the Exalted God or not, in order to determine the time at which they would be worthy of inheriting the land. For this reason, He also immediately restrained their rebelliousness there — something not in keeping with the usual manner of the Exalted God, for He is slow to anger — but for the sake of His providence over all Israel, He did this so that they would guard themselves from sinning against the Lord. For this reason as well, He afflicted them and caused them to hunger in the wilderness for forty years, to show Israel the wonders of the Exalted God, so that they would be strengthened to keep His commandments.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

The forty years in the desert were both punishment and trial. In the language of our sages: "פורענות ודיסציפלינה גם יחד" – a punishment that already contained within itself an educational discipline and purification.

As a punishment, the forty years fulfilled the just verdict over the sinful generation: "יִשְּׂאוּ אֶת־עֲוֹנֹתֵיכֶם אַרְבָּעִים שָׁנָה" – "They should bear their sins for forty years" chabad.org. The generation of the Exodus, which had tested God ten times and ultimately openly rebelled, was not allowed to enter the promised land. This verdict was harsh but necessary to preserve the holiness of the land for a faithful generation.

As a test and training, the forty years were a conscious transitional period in which HaShem elevated the people to a higher level of faith. "לְמַעַן עַנֹּתְךָ לְנַסֹּתְךָ" – "to humble you and to test you" chabad.org: God subjected Israel to challenges in the desert but also unfolded constant miracles, so that the people learned humility, recognized their complete dependence on the heavenly will, and could build a deep trust relationship with HaShem. The test was therefore successful: The succeeding generation – nourished by the manna, guided by the pillar of cloud, taught by Moshe Rabbenu – finally entered the land of Canaan purified and remained faithful to HaShem (as seen in the Book of Joshua).

There is no contradiction, but rather unity in duality: The punishment itself was conceived as an educational act. Or with a beautiful wordplay of the Chachamim: "ארבעים שנה במדבר – דור נענש ומתנסה כאחד" – "Forty years in the desert – a generation is punished and tested as one." Exactly this is expressed in Devarim 8:5: God was Israel's judge and loving educator in the desert, like a father who punishes his child to bring him on the right path chabad.org.

Both verses are simultaneously true. HaShem punished the generation of the desert wanderings for their lack of Emuna, and through this very wandering, tested, educated, and strengthened the people of Israel for the future. There is no contradiction, but a holistic plan: עונש שהוא נסיון, ונסיון שבא מתוך העונש – "a punishment that is also a test, and a test that arises from the punishment." Thus, we can understand the forty-year period with the words of the prophet Hosea (2:16): „וְנִסְּרְתִּיהָ לִי שָׁם“ – "I drew her strictly to me there" – God held Israel accountable in the desert to bind them back to Him.

title: Wasting onions and not leaving them overnight - practical considerations
content:
# Wasting onions and not leaving them overnight - practical considerations ## Frage

Someone asked if it's bal tashchis (prohibition on wasting) to throw out an onion because it was left overnight*. The answer given is that this is a prohibition due to health concerns, and wasting our body is worse than wasting food.

Gershon Gold brought this in his answer to a related question (as did many others). This was the source: https://halachafortodaycom.blogspot.com/2012/04/q-page-5.html

My follow up question - yes, according to those opinions, we should throw out an onion once it has been peeled and left overnight and it's not bal tashchis to do so. What about before hand?

  1. Should we make sure to buy small onions for those situations where we really only need a little?
  2. Should we have some sort of metric to decide "how much we really need" part of an onion, before we use it, knowing that we will inevitably have to throw out the rest? E.g. Can we justify adding onion to a tuna or egg mayo, if all we have is an onion twice the size that we really need?
  3. What about genuinely impoverished people, who haven't got the luxury to afford different sized onions (larger onions have less peel, so are better value for money), or to throw out food on the regular (so they'd have to choose to eat less instead)?

These are some questions I can think of but generally speaking, I would be happy to hear about any sources that give practical, real-life advice about dealing with onions in terms of this halacha.

* See this OU page on this inyan:

Regarding the source:

The Gemara (Nidah 17) cites an extremely strong statement by Rabbi Shimon Bar Yochai. He states that one who eats a peeled onion, egg or garlic that has been left sitting out overnight is literally endangering his life, and will be ultimately judged as a person who took his own life.1 The cause of this prohibition is a “ruach ra’ah,” a type of ‘spirit of impurity’ or spiritual contamination that rests upon these three foods when peeled and left overnight.

Regarding the opinions that hold this is halacha:

Astoundingly, there is absolutely no mention of this proscription in any of the works of the the Rambam, Rif, Tur, nor Shulchan Aruch. Yet, many later authorities, including the Pri Chadash (Y.D. 116:9), Shulchan Aruch HaRav(Shmeiras Haguf 7), Chida (Birkei Yosef Y.D. 116:10), Ben Ish Chai (Year 2 Pinchas 14), Chofetz Chaim (Likutei Halachos note 9) and Aruch Hashulchan (Y.D. 116:22), all do cite the Gemara’s statement, and consequently rule that eating a peeled egg, onion or garlic that sat overnight is strictly forbidden.

Regarding if it's possible to avoid this with modern health and safety advances:

The assumption amongst the poskim is that this danger of “ruach ra’ah” is a spiritual danger and not a danger that a doctor would warn against. (see Shevet Halevi 3:169)

Regarding what to do with overnight peeled onions:

According to most authorities if the food was left overnight (b’dieved) it must be discarded. (Chida ibid. and Shemiras Haguf V’nefesh 3:6. See also Minchas Yitzchak 9:28)

See the page for a detailed response on whether this halacha still applies today.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

The Ben Ish Chai in Pinchas (year 2) clarifies the gemara:

ואם נשאר מעט מקליפתם מותר

If you leave part of the peel, it is mutar

The question remains in cases where this is not possible but it solves the majority of cases, seemingly.

title: Why do scholars believe the name YHWH means “He causes to be”? (Grammar question)
content:
# Why do scholars believe the name YHWH means “He causes to be”? (Grammar question) ## Frage

Most scholars believe the divine name is pronounced יַהְוֶה, which means “He causes to be”.

How can this be? Throughout scripture, יהוה has prepositions, such as ל,ב,מ etc. If the scholars are correct, then this would lead to very unusual forms with the masculine singular prefix י, which we don’t find with any other root.

Am I missing something? Can a ל preposition with י prefix occur in Biblical Hebrew?

Is it possible for multiple prefixes to be attached to a root (other than י & ו), such as a י & ל?

Here is a link to the Wiktionary article on YHWH.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

While the name is based on the word for being (see Rashbam to Exodus 3:15), at the end of the day it is a proper name, and follows all the rules for proper names, including using prefixes. A similar example is the name of our forefather Yitzchok. It literally means "he will laugh" and begins with a "yud" prefix, but after it became his name, it became a proper noun. A quick Sefaria search shows 21 times in Tanach that we have the word ליצחק. (I got 47 results for ליעקב, which is the same.)

As to pronunciation, we don't know the so-called proper pronunciation. Kabbalists use lots of different vowelizations for different purposes. I personally don't know why, but you can see in some Sephardic siddurim different vowelizations for different blessings in Shmoneh Esrei. (They are not pronounced, because instead we say "Adonoi").

title: How is the concept of Belial (בליעל) understood in the context of Geulah, and what do our sources say about it?
content:
# How is the concept of Belial (בליעל) understood in the context of Geulah, and what do our sources say about it? ## Frage

I want to know how the term "Belial" (בליעל), b’nei Belial (בני בליעל) is understood in Jewish tradition; it appears in Tanach and rabbinic texts, but what is its exact meaning and etymology, and are there halachic implications—practical legal consequences—that arise from the use of this term, particularly whether people or actions are classified as "Belial" and what that means legally (e.g., for testimonial capacity, community status, etc.)

What is the meaning of "Belial" in the time before the coming of the Mashiach?

Sources:

And I will also make the “prophets” and the impure spirit vanish from the land. Zechariah 13

Evil Inclination

A variation of the term "evil inclination" – yetzer hara in Hebrew – is first found in the book of Genesis, as God acknowledges the evil impulse within people. In rabbinic literature, the evil inclination is often discussed in contrast to its opposite, the good inclination (yetzer hatov in Hebrew). In some sources, the force is presented as an internal drive within people, while other texts depict the yetzer hara as an external figure that can tempt people toward bad choices.

Adam Belijaal worthless man And this refers to Samael, the worthless man (adam b’liya’al), the man of iniquity

ואית אחרא מסטרא דמסאבו דאיהו אדם בליעל איש און יצר הרע See Zohar Chadash (33b): And not only this, but there are three [types of] Man — the Man of Beriah, the Man of Yetzirah, [and] the Man of Asiyah — from the side of purity; and there is another from the side of defilement, who is the Worthless Man (Adam Belial), the man of iniquity, the evil inclination. [By contrast,] the good man is the good inclination. Thus the ancients explained the verse: “Also the one opposite the other God has made”

Amalek Sitra Achra Amalek personifies the full force of the Sitra Achra, the Other Side. He marshals his strength to cast down the spiritually weak among the Jews by making it seem to them as if they no longer have hope, no good points, chas ve-shalom. An example of this can be found in the Torah’s account of Amalek’s attack on the fledgling Israelite nation, which relates, “He cut off among you all the weaklings … when you were faint and exhausted.” Amalek seeks to cut off the “weaklings,” namely those lacking spiritual strength, by convincing them that they are far from HaShem, and then using their despair to bring them down, chas ve-shalom. This is the meaning of “he cut off among you.” But when a person merits finding a good point inside himself even while falling, Amalek is thereby defeated.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Regarding the etymology of Belial, Jastrow has it similar to as you rendered, "worthless man, wicked":

‎בליעל ‎m. ‎(Biblical Hebrew) ‎availing ‎nothing, ‎wickedness. ‎

And the same in Rashbam on Deut. 15:9

השמר לך פן יהיה דבר עם לבבך - דבר בליעל כלומר, דבר שהוא של רֶשַׁע כמו: דבר בליעל יצוק בו. שפתרונו כך.
השמר לך פן יהיה עם לבבך דבר בליעל,

"Be on guard lest there be a davar/thing with your heart" -- in other words a davar belial/evil thing, a 'thing' of evil, as in (Ps. 41:9) דבר בליעל יצוק בו "something baneful has settled in him," which we have clarified the same way, "Be on guard lest there be in your heart an belial/evil thing.

Regarding your question "..., community status, etc.) What is the meaning of "Belial" in the time before the coming of the Mashiach?" -- I found the following in Tikunei Zohar:

  1. Choosing bad thoughts makes a man Belial:
daf 63a

וכל קרבנין אלין רמיזין בגופא דבר נש, מוח"א וליב"א וריא"ה, אינון ארי"ה שו"ר נש"ר, קטרוגא דלהון כלב חמור נץ, טחו"ל מר"ה וכב"ד, דאינון משחי"ת א"ף וחמ"ה, מחשבה דא אדם, אית מחשבה טבא דחיוון טבין, ואית מחשבה בישא דחיון בישין, ומחשבא טבא איהו אדם טוב, ומחשבה בישא דא אדם רע בליעל, אדם להבל דמה:

"And all these sacrifices correspond to the human body: the brain, the heart, and the lungs. They are symbolized by the lion, the ox, and the eagle. Their accusers (opposing forces) are the dog, the donkey, and the hawk. The spleen, the gallbladder, and the liver—these are the destroyers of anger and wrath. Thought is what defines a person. There is good thought, which gives rise to good living beings, and there is evil thought, which gives rise to evil beings. A person with good thought is a good person. A person with evil thought is a wicked, worthless person, (Ps. 144:4) 'a man like a fleeting vapor.'"

  1. And on daf 98a, the larger context of what you cited. Belial are considered dead in their lifetime and are not to mingle with decent people:
אדהכי הא סבא חד אזדמן ליה, ואמר רבי רבי, הא חזינא קרא דאמר באורייתא (במדבר י"ט) אדם כי ימות באהל, והא אורייתא קדם דאתברי עלמא הות, וחזינא דעלמא אקדים לאדם, דכל עלמא וצרכוי אתבריאו קדם דאתברי אדם, אי הכי מאי תקנתא אית הכא, אמר ליה סבא והא כתיב דנשמתין דצדיקיא אתבריאו קדם דאתברי עלמא, כמה דאת אמר בראשית ברא אלקי"ם, ולית ראשית אלא נשמה, דאתמר ביה נר ה' נשמת אדם, איהי נשמתא דאדם דלעילא, אלא אית אדם ואית אדם, אית אדם דאיהו אדם דנשמתא, ואית אדם דגופא, דאתמר ביה אדם להבל דמה, ועליה אתמר אדם כי ימות באהל, ועליה אתמר ארור הגבר אשר יבטח:

 
תיקוני זהר דף צח/ב

באדם ושם בשר זרועו, ודא סמא"ל אדם בליעל איש און, ואית ליה תרין נוקבין בישין, ועלייהו אתמר על כל נפשות מת לא יבא, לאביו ולאמו לא יטמא, ולית אביו אלא קודשא בריך הוא, ולית אמו אלא שכינתא, וכי לא אתמר בקודשא בריך הוא ובשכינתיה הלא כה דברי כאש נאם ה', מה אש אינו מקבל טומאה הכי איהו לא מקבל טומאה, אמר ליה והא כתיב (במדבר י"ט) את מקדש ה' טמא ודא שכינתיה, אמר ליה ודאי דקודשא בריך הוא ושכינתא לא מקבל טומאה, אבל כל מאן דסאיב אתר דאיהי שריא ביה, אתחשיב ליה כאלו עביד ליה, ובגין דא לאביו ולאמו לא יטמא, ולית אביו אלא קודשא בריך הוא, ולית אמו אלא שכינתא, ודא איהו רזא מאן דאעיל מרשות הרבים לרשות היחיד, ובגין דא אמר ולא תחללו את שם קדשי, ודא אדנ"י, דאיהו רשות היחיד דאיהו יקו"ק יחידו דעלמא, ודא איהו אדם:

(ובגין דא לאביו ולאמו לא יטמא, ודא איהו רזא מאן דאעיל מרשות הרבים לרשות היחיד, ובגין דא אמר) אדם כי ימות באהל, דא אדם בליעל, ומסטרא דא בר נש רשע קרוי מת מעיקרא מקמי דאתברי עלמא, אבל לא אתמר על אדם דאיהו מסטרא דקודשא, וכמה טפשין אינון בעלמא דאמרין הא קודשא בריך הוא גזר על בר נש דימות, הדא הוא דכתיב אדם כי ימות, ואיך אמרין דלא יהא מיתה מיניה, וי לון דטב לון דלא אתבריאו בעלמא, דאלין אינון דשוין לון, שוין לאדם דאתקרי ישראל ולאדם בליעל, ואמרין כאדם טוב כחוטא כלהון שוין, יהיו כמוץ לפני רוח אלין חייביא דאמרי הכי, ומלאך ה' דוחה מנייהו:

דאית אדם דאיהו ישראל, ואית אדם דאיהו מלאך ודא מטטרו"ן, ואית אדם בדיוקנא דקודשא בריך הוא דאיהו אצילותיה, ודא יו"ד ק"א וא"ו ק"א, ולית ליה בריאה ויצירה ועשיה אלא אצילותא, ובאתר דא לית חטא ולא מות, הדא הוא דכתיב לא יגורך רע, ועל האי אדם בליעל מני קודשא בריך הוא דלא למיכל מניה, ודלא לערבא ליה עם טוב, דהאי איהו כמאן דעריב כספא עם עופרת, ודא גרים בלבולא בפמליא דלעילא, וערב חשוכא בנהורא מה דאפריש קודשא בריך הוא, כמה דאת אמר ויבדל אלקי"ם בין האור ובין החושך:

While this was happening, an old man (saba) appeared before him and said: "Rabbi, Rabbi! I have seen a verse in the Torah (Numbers 19): ‘If a man dies in a tent…’ But the Torah existed before the world was created. And I see that the world was created before man, for the entire world and all its needs were created before man was created. If so, what is the meaning of this verse?" The old man replied: "But it is written that the souls of the righteous were created before the world was created, as it says: ‘In the beginning God created…’ And there is no ‘beginning’ except for the soul, as it is said: ‘The soul of man is the lamp of the Lord.’ This refers to the supernal soul of man. There is ‘man’ and there is ‘man’: one is the man of the soul, and one is the man of the body, as it is said: ‘Man is like a breath.’ It is about this latter that it is written: ‘If a man dies in a tent,’ and also: ‘Cursed is the man who trusts…"

(Tikkunei Zohar 98b continues):

“…in man and makes flesh his strength.” This refers to Samael, the worthless man (adam beliya’al), a man of iniquity. He has two evil female counterparts. About them it is said: ‘He shall not come near any soul, neither his father nor mother shall he defile.' There is no ‘father’ but the Holy One, blessed be He, and no ‘mother’ but the Shekhinah. And is it not said of them: ‘Is not My word like fire?’ says the Lord. Just as fire does not become impure, so too they do not become impure. He said to him: But it is written (Numbers 19): ‘He has defiled the sanctuary of the Lord,’ and this refers to the Shekhinah. He replied: Indeed, the Holy One and His Shekhinah do not become impure. But anyone who defiles the place where She dwells is considered as if he defiled Them. Therefore, it is said: ‘He shall not defile himself for his father or mother.’ This is the secret of one who moves from the public domain to the private domain. Therefore it is said: ‘Do not profane My holy name,’ and this refers to Adonai, which is the private domain, which is YKWK, the Unique One of the world. And this is the ‘man.’ And therefore it is said: ‘He shall not defile himself for his father or mother’ — this is the secret of one who enters from the public to the private domain. And thus it is said: ‘If a man dies in a tent’ — this refers to the worthless man (adam beliya’al). From this side, a wicked person is called ‘dead’ even before the world was created. But it was not said about the man who is from the side of holiness. How foolish are those in the world who say: "The Holy One, blessed be He, decreed that man should die. This is what is written: ‘If a man dies…’ How can they say that death does not come from Him?" Woe to them! It would have been better had they not been created in the world. For they equate the man called Israel with the worthless man, and say: "As the good man, so the sinner — they are all the same." They shall be like chaff before the wind," these wicked ones who say such things. The angel of the Lord drive them away. There is a ‘man’ who is Israel, and there is a ‘man’ who is an angel — and this is Metatron. And there is a ‘man’ in the image of the Holy One, blessed be He —this is His emanation (Atzilut). This is the divine name Yod–He–Vav–He (YKWK), and He has no connection to Beriah (Creation), Yetzirah (Formation), or Asiyah (Action), but only to Atzilut (Emanation). In that realm, there is no sin and no death, as it is written: ‘Evil shall not dwell with You.’ And regarding the worthless man (adam beliya’al), the Holy One, blessed be He, warned not to partake of him, and not to mix him with the good. For he is like one who mixes silver with lead, and this causes confusion in the heavenly hosts. It is like mixing darkness with light—something the Holy One, blessed be He, separated, as it is written: ‘And God separated between the light and the darkness.’”

  1. He that rules over his yetzer hara will ride on and rule over men of Belial:

ועם כל דא זכאה נשמתא דשליט עליה ורכיב עליה, כבר נש דרכיב על סוסיא או על חמריה, ווי ליה למאן דחוויא שליט עליה, האי אתקרי רשע גמור, ומאן דאיהו שליט עליה איהו אתקרי צדיק גמור, ועליה אתמר ואתן אדם תחתך, אדם בליעל איש און, ולאומים תחת נפשך, דכד בר נש איהו שליט על יצריה, הכי איהו שליט על כל שנאוי, ואם יצריה שליט עליה שנאוי שלטין עליה:

"And despite all this, fortunate is the soul that rules over and rides upon [the body], like a person who rides upon his horse or donkey. Woe to the one over whom the serpent rules— this one is called a complete evildoer (rasha gamur). But the one who rules over [the soul] is called a complete righteous one (tzaddik gamur). And about him it is said: 'I will give men in exchange for you, a base man, a man of iniquity, and nations for your soul.' For when a person rules over his inclination (yetzer), he also rules over all that is hateful. But if his inclination rules over him, then all that is hateful rules over him."

Regarding "what that means legally (e.g., for testimonial capacity," -- idk.

title: Why did the Yemenites curse Ezra haSofer?
content:
# Why did the Yemenites curse Ezra haSofer? ## Frage

Why did the Yemenites place curses on Ezra haSofer? What made them go beyond simply refusing his call to return?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

According to Rabbi Yaakov Sapir, the famous 19th century Shadar (money-collecting emissary) and visitor to Yemen, Ezra cursed the Jews of Yemen because they refused to return to the Land of Israel when summoned. In turn, they cursed him that he should not be buried in the Land of Israel after his passing. According to Yemenite tradition, both curses came true: The Yemenite Jews suffered greatly in Yemen, and Ezra did not merit to be buried in Israel. And as further revenge, Yemenite Jews do not name their children Ezra (Sefer Masah Teiman, chapter 29, cited on Wikipedia here; the full text can be found e.g. here).

So, in short, it was an act of revenge.

title: Difference in attitudes towards bitochen and hishtadlus when it comes to Ruchnius
content:
# Difference in attitudes towards bitochen and hishtadlus when it comes to Ruchnius ## Frage

Why is it that even those who say that the more Bitochen someone has the more protection they will receive from Hashem, to the extent that it would be possible for someone with enough Bitochen to just sit home and all his needs will come to him only seem to apply this approach when it comes to gashmius?

For example. The Novarodekers went from town to building Yeshivas without a dime to their name or any foreseeable way of supporting that Yeshiva gave no thought as to how they will support it. They were confident that their Bitochen alone would take care of all material needs the Yeshiva would have .(as indeed usually happened) On the flip side they did not think that anyone was coming to learn in that Yeshiva based on their bitochen. The very actively went from town to town recruiting students. What principle of Bitochen caused them to think that their Bitochen would send them financial supporters but not Talmidim?

Novaradak may be a more extreme example but the mindset of “we do not need to make hishtadlus for material areas because of bitochen but do need to make hishtadlus so that external issues that directly pertain to ruchnuis should work out” seems common among those who are very into stressing the power of Bitochen. (Even though AFAIK it is never explicitly spoken).

What is it based on?

If you disagree with those groups in general please don't use this question as a place to voice that opinion.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

I can't speak for Nevardok specifically, but in general, I believe this principle is based on this gemara (Megilla 6b):

אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק, אִם יֹאמַר לְךָ אָדָם: יָגַעְתִּי וְלֹא מָצָאתִי — אַל תַּאֲמֵן. לֹא יָגַעְתִּי וּמָצָאתִי — אַל תַּאֲמֵן. יָגַעְתִּי וּמָצָאתִי — תַּאֲמֵן.

§ Rabbi Yitzḥak said in the style of a previous passage: If a person says to you: I have labored and not found success, do not believe him. Similarly, if he says to you: I have not labored but nevertheless I have found success, do not believe him. If, however, he says to you: I have labored and I have found success, believe him.*

So, there is a clear principle here that we only gain success if we put in effort.

However, the gemara then continues:

הָנֵי מִילֵּי בְּדִבְרֵי תוֹרָה, אֲבָל בְּמַשָּׂא וּמַתָּן — סִיַּיעְתָּא הוּא מִן שְׁמַיָּא. וּלְדִבְרֵי תוֹרָה לָא אֲמַרַן אֶלָּא לְחַדּוֹדֵי, אֲבָל לְאוֹקֹמֵי גִּירְסָא — סִיַּיעְתָּא מִן שְׁמַיָּא הִיא.

The Gemara comments: This applies only to matters of Torah, as success with respect to Torah study is in accordance with the toil and effort invested. But with regard to success in business, it all depends upon assistance from Heaven, as there is no correlation between success and effort. And even with regard to matters of Torah, we said this only with regard to sharpening one’s understanding of Torah, as the more one labors, the deeper the understanding of the material he achieves. However, to preserve what one has learned, it is dependent upon assistance from Heaven. Not everyone achieves this, even with much effort.*

The previous gemara only applies to Torah study (i.e. ruchnius), but not business (i.e. gashmius). When it comes to ruchnius, we are meant to make as much effort as we can and not strive to do less through increased bitachon.

* Steinsaltz translation (including inter-commentary)

title: Meaning of Rambam's ideal motivation for performing mitzvot
content:
# Meaning of Rambam's ideal motivation for performing mitzvot ## Frage

Rambam writes in Mishneh Torah (Teshuvah 10:2) as follows:

הָעוֹבֵד מֵאַהֲבָה - עוֹסֵק בַּתּוֹרָה וּבַמִּצְווֹת וְהוֹלֵךְ בִּנְתִיבוֹת הַחָכְמָה לֹא מִפְּנֵי דָּבָר בָּעוֹלָם, לֹא מִפְּנֵי יִרְאַת הָרָעָה וְלֹא כְּדֵי לִירַשׁ הַטּוֹבָה, אֶלָּא עוֹשֶׂה הָאֱמֶת מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהוּא אֱמֶת, וְסוֹף הַטּוֹבָה לָבוֹא בִּכְלָל.

One who serves [God] out of love — engages in the Torah and the commandments and walks in the paths of wisdom, not because of anything in the world, not out of fear of evil, and not in order to inherit the good, but rather does the truth because it is the truth, and in the end the good will come as a matter of course.

What does Rambam mean with "doing the truth because it is the truth"?

To elaborate:

Rambam writes (MN 3:27) that the purpose of all mitzvos are either to inculcate us with correct metaphysical opinions or to contribute to good social relations.

The purpose of the entire Torah is two things: the perfection of the soul and the perfection of the body. Know that of these two purposes, one is without doubt greater in its importance—namely, the perfection of the soul, that is, the imparting of correct beliefs. The second comes first in nature and in time—namely, the perfection of the body, meaning the ordering of the state and the proper regulation of the circumstances of all its people to the extent possible.

So does he mean that in performing the mitzvos we are to have in mind those intrinsic ends (as opposed to external reward and punishment)?

Or does he mean something else?

title: Might the Torah’s spelling have changed?
content:
# Might the Torah’s spelling have changed? ## Frage

There’s some evidence, and a high probability, that all Hebrew writing in Biblical times was חסר, such that every letter represented a consonant.

I understand that it is generally taken as a given that the Torah’s spelling has never changed. However, is this due to fundamental Jewish theology explicitly forbidding such a notion (e.g. a scriptural proof against it, some halachah forbidding it, etc.)? Or is this just the mainstream opinion, and it’s technically possible within Jewish theology for the Torah’s spelling to have changed?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Definitely. The gemara (Qiddushin 30a) concludes, "ינְהוּ בְּקִיאִי בַּחֲסֵירוֹת וִיתֵרוֹת, אֲנַן לָא בְּקִיאִינַן - they [the Soferim of the early Bayis Sheini era] were experts in full and defective [spellings]; we are not experts." And this is their answer why the "ו" of "גחון" is no longer the middle letter of the Torah. (Nowadays the difference is about 5,000 letters.)

Then there is the story of how the spelling was reconstructed in the days of Ezra, meaning what the aforementioned Soferim were experts in and Yerushalmi Taanit 20b:

שלשה ספרים מצאו בעזרה: ספר "מעוני", וספר "זעטוטי" ", וספר "היא". באחד מצאו כתוב "מעון א-להי קדש", ובשנים כתיב (דברים ל״ג:כ״ז) "מענה א-להי קדם", וקיימו שנים וביטלו אחד. באחד מצאו כתוב "וישלח את זעטוטי בני ישראל", ובשנים כתוב (שמות כ״ד:ה׳) "וישלח את נערי בני ישראל", וקיימו שנים וביטלו אחד. באחד מצאו כתוב "תשע היא" ובשנים כתיב "אחד עשר היא", וקיימו שנים ובטלו אחד.

Three scrolls were found in the Temple court: The Me'onei scroll and the Za'atutei scroll and the Hi' scroll. In one they found written "the eternal God is Me'on" and in two it was written "the eternal God is Me'onah (a dwelling place)", so they adopted the reading of the two scrolls and discarded that of the one scroll. In one they found written "And he sent the za‘atutei (nobles) of the children of Israel", and in the other two they found written And he sent na‘arei (the young men of) the children of Israel", so they retained the reading of the two and abandoned that of the one. In one of the scrolls hi’ was written nine times, but in the other two hi’ was written eleven times, so they adopted the reading of the two and discarded that of the one.

(Translation from this question, which should be reviewed for more detail.)

So we now have a Torah unlike any of those they found from the First Beis haMiqdash.

Also there are spelling differences today. Interestingly, none change the meaning of the pasuq. But Ashkenazic, Sepharadic and Yemenite Sifrei Torah have spelling differences. @DoubleAa lists them in an answer here.

In my humble opinion, and no one else has to agree - this is from logic, not sources: it is like the famous Tanur shel Akhnai story. Hashem wants us to follow the kelalei pesaq, rules of halachic decision making He gave us. The holy text is thus the reconstruction, not the original. Just as we don't listen to voices from heaven, we wouldn't follow a Sefer Torah found by archeologists. Even if it could be proven to be the original that Moshe Rabbeinu put in or next to the Aron. Halakhah is a legal process, not a truth finding one. Or / and, if the halachically mandatory spelling changes, Hashem wanted that change. After all, pesaq comes with siyata diShmaya, assistance from heaven.

### Antwort 2 (Score: -1)

Yes, Kiddushin 30a (Koren-Steinsaltz translation and interpretation) clearly demonstrates that in the Amoraic period, Rabbis' Torah scrolls were way off (e.g., in our scrolls, the Vav of Gachon is off by some 5'000 letters):

"אמר ליה: ניתי ספר תורה ואימנינהו, מי לא אמר רבה בר בר חנה לא זזו משם עד שהביאו ספר תורה ומנאום? אמר ליה: אינהו בקיאי בחסירות ויתרות, אנן לא בקיאינן." "Therefore, because they devoted so much time to the Bible, the first Sages were called soferim (Those who count), because they would count all the letters in the Torah. They would say that the letter vav in the word “belly [gaḥon]” (Leviticus 11:42) is the midpoint of the letters in a Torah scroll...
Rav Yosef raises a dilemma: Does the vav of the word “belly [gaḥon]” belong to this side or to this side? Is it part of the first or second half of the Torah?
The Sages said to him: Let us bring a Torah scroll and count the letters. Didn’t Rabba bar bar Ḥana say with regard to a different issue: They did not move from there until they brought a Torah scroll and counted the letters? Therefore, we can do the same. Rav Yosef said to them: They were experts in the deficient and plene forms of words and therefore could count the letters precisely. We are not experts in this regard, and therefore we would be unable to resolve the question even if we were to count the letters.

The Mishna in Sofrim provides another evidence of not having a standard formula:

"R. Simeon b. Laḳish said: Three scrolls of the Torah were found in the Temple court: the Ma‘on scroll, the Za’aṭuṭë scroll, and the Hu’ scroll. In one of these they found the expression of ma‘on, and in the other two it was written, The eternal God is me‘onah (a dwelling place), so they adopted the reading of the two scrolls and discarded that of the one scroll. In another of the scrolls they found it written, And he sent the za‘aṭuṭë (nobles) of the children of Israel, and in the other two they found written And he sent na‘arë (the young men of) the children of Israel, so they retained the reading of the two and abandoned that of the one. In one of the scrolls hu’ was written eleven times, but in the other two hi’ was written eleven times, so they adopted the reading of the two and discarded that of the one."

And the final, and probably most valid, argument is that the entire Mishna (see Maseches Sofrim) does not mention the importance of precision in the Torah scrolls.

# Sources about - the angel of destruction obtains authorisation to destroy, does not discriminate between innocent and guilty ## Frage

For when the angel of destruction obtains authorisation to destroy, he does not discriminate between innocent and guilty. It is for this reason that when punishment falls upon a town a man should flee from thence before he is overtaken.

Zohar 113b WAJERA

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Rashi Shmot 22:5, from M'chilta

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

See also Ramban, who quotes Rashi that @Mordechai brings:

The purport thereof is to state that Scripture warned the Israelites in Egypt not to go out of the door of their homes on that night because the Holy One, blessed be He, was passing through Egypt like a king who passes from one place to another and whose guardsmen go before him so that people should neither meet him nor see him. This is similar to that which is said, And the Eternal my G-d shall come, and all the holy ones with Thee; and also, And it shall come to pass, while My glory passeth by, that I will put thee in a cleft of the rock, i.e., to protect him [Moses] from the seraphim and the heavenly agencies. And since we find that once permission is given to the destroying angel he does not discriminate between righteous and wicked, therefore a person has no right to change from the customary way of the world and leave at night-time, since it is the time of the wild beasts when they go out for prey, and there is no way [for them] to distinguish between righteous and wicked. (emphasis mine).

Similary, the Eitz Yosef in his commentary to the Midrash in Bereishis Rabbah 49:8 writes:

משניתנה רשות למשחית אינו מבחין בין צדיק לרשע כי הוא מצד תוקף הדין - When permission is given to the Destroyer, he does not distinguish between righteous and wicked, because he acts by the force of judgment

title: Search for sources about - Violation against a provision of the divine law, by a prophet already proven as a נביא אמת
content:
# Search for sources about - Violation against a provision of the divine law, by a prophet already proven as a נביא אמת ## Frage

I am looking for Talmudic, Midrash, Aggadah, Zohar, Responsa, as well as modern Poskim, sources that support the following.

Kiyum mikzat u'vittul mikzat d'she'ar mitzvot - Partial fulfillment and partial nullification of other commandments, only a temporary, momentary transgression against a precept of the divine law in the interest of the law - Hora'at sha'ah, a temporary ruling, is legally possible through a prophet already proven as a true prophet (Ot U'Mofet - signs and wonders) with the exception of the idolatry laws - avodah zarah.

The question is based on Elijah on Mount Carmel (I Kings 18) Sanhedrin.90a

The dispute is with regard to a prophet who prophesies to abolish the essence of the prohibition of idol worship, or a prophet who espouses fulfillment of part of the prohibition and nullification of part of the prohibition of idol worship, asserting that idol worship is permitted in certain circumstances, as the Merciful One says: “And that prophet…shall be put to death; because he has spoken perversion against the Lord…to divert you from the way on which the Lord your God commanded you to walk” (Deuteronomy 13:6). It may be inferred from this verse: If he diverts you even from part of the way. In these cases, Rabbi Shimon holds that he is executed by strangulation, and the Rabbis hold that he is executed by stoning.

But if a prophet abolishes the essence of the rest of the mitzvot, everyone agrees that he is executed by strangulation. And if the prophet espouses fulfillment of part and nullification of part of other mitzvot, everyone agrees that he is exempt from punishment. If a true prophet espouses temporary nullification of a specific mitzva, one must heed his words.

But if the prophet espouses fulfillment of part and nullification of part of other mitzvot, everyone agrees that he is exempt from punishment, as that is within the prophet’s mandate.

The purpose of the question is to find out how to deal with a person who acts similarly to Elijah the Prophet (Elijah on Mount Carmel) Therefore, what other sources are there, where is this topic referenced, discussed...

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Here's Sifri:

אליו תשמעון – אפילו אומר לך עבור על אחת מן המצות האמורות בתורה כאליהו בהר הכרמל לפי שעה שמע לו.

"to him shall you hearken": even if he tells you to transgress (temporarily) one of the mitzvoth of the Torah, as in the instance of Eliyahu on Mount Carmel, if (in his judgment) the time requires it, listen to him.

You'd do well checking out Mishneh Torah (Yesodei haTorah 9:3-5) with the commentaries, they cite the relevant primary sources.

Here's some of it:

וְכֵן אִם יֹאמַר לָנוּ הַנָּבִיא שֶׁנּוֹדַע לָנוּ שֶׁהוּא נָבִיא, לַעֲבֹר עַל אַחַת מִכָּל מִצְווֹת הָאֲמוּרוֹת בַּתּוֹרָה, אוֹ עַל מִצְווֹת הַרְבֵּה, בֵּין קַלּוֹת בֵּין חֲמוּרוֹת, לְפִי שָׁעָה - מִצְוָה לִשְׁמֹעַ לוֹ. וְכֵן לָמַדְנוּ מֵחֲכָמִים הָרִאשׁוֹנִים מִפִּי הַשְּׁמוּעָה: בַּכֹּל, אִם יֹאמַר לְךָ נָבִיא: עֲבֹר עַל דִּבְרֵי תּוֹרָה, כְּאֵלִיָּהוּ בְּהַר הַכַּרְמֶל - שְׁמַע לוֹ, חוּץ מֵעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה; וְהוּא שֶׁיִּהְיֶה הַדָּבָר לְפִי שָׁעָה, כְּגוֹן אֵלִיָּהוּ בְּהַר הַכַּרְמֶל, שֶׁהִקְרִיב עוֹלָה בַּחוּץ, וִירוּשָׁלַיִם נִבְחֲרָה, וְהַמַּקְרִיב בַּחוּץ חַיָּב כָּרֵת. וּמִפְּנֵי שֶׁהוּא נָבִיא - מִצְוָה לִשְׁמֹעַ לוֹ. וְגַם בָּזֶה נֶאֱמַר: ״אֵלָיו תִּשְׁמָעוּן״ (דברים יח,טו). וְאִלּוּ שָׁאֲלוּ אֶת אֵלִיָּהוּ וְאָמְרוּ לוֹ ׳הֵיאַךְ נַעֲקֹר מַה שֶּׁכָּתוּב בַּתּוֹרָה: ״פֶּן תַּעֲלֶה עֹלֹתֶיךָ בְּכָל מָקוֹם״ (שם יב,יג)?׳, הָיָה אוֹמֵר ׳לֹא, אֶלָּא הַמַּקְרִיב בַּחוּץ - לְעוֹלָם חַיָּב כָּרֵת, כְּמוֹ שֶׁצִּוָּה מֹשֶׁה; אֲבָל אֲנִי אַקְרִיב הַיּוֹם בַּחוּץ בִּדְבַר יי, כְּדֵי לְהַכְחִישׁ נְבִיאֵי הַבַּעַל׳. וְעַל הַדֶּרֶךְ הַזֹּאת, אִם צִוּוּ כָּל הַנְּבִיאִים לַעֲבֹר לְפִי שָׁעָה - מִצְוָה לִשְׁמֹעַ לָהֶן. וְאִם אָמְרוּ שֶׁהַדָּבָר נֶעֱקַר לְעוֹלָם - מִיתָתָן בְּחֶנֶק, שֶׁהַתּוֹרָה אָמְרָה: ״לָנוּ וּלְבָנֵינוּ עַד עוֹלָם״ (שם כט,כח). . .

And likewise, if a prophet who is known to us as a true prophet tells us to transgress one of the commandments stated in the Torah, or many commandments—whether light or severe—because at that time it is a commandment to listen to him, we must listen to him. And so we have learned from the early Sages from the very announcement (the prophecy): in everything, if a prophet says to you, “transgress the words of the Torah,” like Elijah on Mount Carmel, listen to him—except for idolatry; and this matter will be according to the circumstance, like Elijah on Mount Carmel, who brought an offering outside the Temple, and Jerusalem was chosen, and the one who offered outside is liable to kareth (spiritual excision). And because he is a prophet, it is a commandment to listen to him. And also concerning this it is said: “To him you shall listen” (Deuteronomy 18:15). And if they asked Elijah and said to him, “How can we uproot what is written in the Torah: ‘Take heed to yourself that you do not offer your burnt offerings in every place’?” (Deuteronomy 12:13), he would say, “No; only the one who offers outside is always liable to kareth, as Moses commanded; but today I offer outside by the word of the Lord, in order to refute the prophets of Baal.” And in this way, if all the prophets commanded to act according to the circumstance, it is a commandment to listen to them. And if they said that the matter is uprooted forever, their death would be by strangulation, for the Torah says: “To us and to our children forever” (Deuteronomy 29:28).

title: Is the name/word “Dalia” connected to the “branch of Jesse” in Jewish tradition?
content:
# Is the name/word “Dalia” connected to the “branch of Jesse” in Jewish tradition? ## Frage

I am considering the Hebrew name Dalia (דַּלְיָה) for my daughter, who is due in a few months.

I’ve read that Dalia can mean a branch, shoot, or hanging bough. But does דַּלְיָה refer to the same type of “branch” (נֵצֶר) mentioned in Isaiah 11:1, or is it a completely unrelated word?

"And there shall come forth a shoot out of the stock of Jesse, and a branch shall grow out of his roots."

I'd be curious whether דַּלְיָה has this connection either historically, etymologically, or just within the Jewish tradition.

My father's name was Michael Jesse (ז״ל), and I was thinking of Dalia as a way to honor him, symbolizing continuity of the family line. Sources, linguistic background, or rabbinic commentary would be very helpful.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

דליה is a family name mentioned in Ezra (2:60), Nechemiah (6:10 and 7:62) and Divrei Hayomim (I-3:24). Outside of several name-references, they seem unremarkable - I don't see any discussion about the name itself or the family in any of the major commentaries. NOTE: The pronunciation of the name in all of these verses is "D'laya," not "Daliah."

If I can offer a creative alternative: The verse you presented is generally perceived as Messianic in nature, i.e. referring to the Moshiach, who will restore the Davidic line. Moshiach is referred to as the "son of David," or even as David himself, due to this connection. I propose naming your daughter Davida Malka (דוידה מלכה) to honor this connection directly to this verse. Davida is the feminine form of David, and Malka means "queen." The names together sound very similar to "David Hamelech" (דוד המלך), "David the King" and would connect your daughter to the idea of being a "shoot from Jesse."

נ נח נחמ נחמן מאומן is 491. This gematria is noted by and notable amongst those who study the (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hebrew_language)[Nanach Petek]. Some have observed:

Amazingly, in 1922 and after the passing of R' Nathan, the Petek was revealed with נ נח נחמ נחמן מאומן (491) and saying "the sign is, 17 Tammuz they'll say you're not fasting."
  • שם אלהים אדני is 491. This brought in (https://www.nanach.org/books/likutay-nanach.pdf)[Sefer Likutay Nanach] #470 (and see the wondrous discussion and kavana there).
  • תהלים (485) with +5 and +1 for its letters and a kollel is 491. (ibid. #940.1)
  • Vedibarta bam - bam spelled out is בית מם, 492, which is נ נח נחמ נחמן מאומן with the kollel. (ibid. .15)

title: Were non Jewish slaves made to convert to accept the covenant?
content:
# Were non Jewish slaves made to convert to accept the covenant? ## Frage

Was the non Jewish slave made a convert thus gaining the rights and protections of a citizen?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

He is given the option to convert. If he rejects it he must be sold to a non Jew. If stipulated at purchase that he will only accept the noahide laws then that is fine. If he either converts or becomes a ger toshav he may reside in Israel. Otherwise, he may not.

Rambam writes as follows in Mishneh Torah (Issurei Biah 14:9):

הָעֶבֶד הַנִּלְקָח מִן הָעַכּוּ״ם אֵין אוֹמְרִין לוֹ מָה רָאִיתָ שֶׁבָּאתָ. אֶלָּא אוֹמְרִים לוֹ רְצוֹנְךָ שֶׁתִּכָּנֵס לִכְלַל עַבְדֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל וְתִהְיֶה מִן הַכְּשֵׁרִים אוֹ לֹא. אִם רָצָה מוֹדִיעִין לוֹ עִקְּרֵי הַדָּת וּמִקְצָת מִצְוֹת קַלּוֹת וַחֲמוּרוֹת וְעָנְשָׁן וּשְׂכָרָן כְּמוֹ שֶׁמּוֹדִיעִין אֶת הַגֵּר וּמַטְבִּילִין אוֹתוֹ כְּגֵר. וּמוֹדִיעִין אוֹתוֹ כְּשֶׁהוּא בַּמַּיִם. וְאִם לֹא רָצָה לְקַבֵּל מְגַלְגְּלִין עָלָיו כׇּל שְׁנֵים עָשָׂר חֹדֶשׁ וּמוֹכְרוֹ לְעַכּוּ״ם. וְאָסוּר לְקַיְּמוֹ יוֹתֵר עַל כֵּן. וְאִם הִתְנָה עָלָיו מִתְּחִלָּה שֶׁלֹּא יָמוּל וְלֹא יִטְבֹּל אֶלָּא יִהְיֶה גֵּר תּוֹשָׁב מֻתָּר לְקַיְּמוֹ בַּעֲבוֹדָתוֹ כְּשֶׁהוּא גֵּר תּוֹשָׁב. וְאֵין מְקַיְּמִין עֶבֶד כָּזֶה אֶלָּא בִּזְמַן הַיּוֹבֵל:

A slave acquired from the gentiles is not asked, 'What did you see that made you come [to join the Israelites]?' Rather, he is asked, 'Do you desire to enter into the community of the slaves of Israel and be among the fit ones or not?' If he desires [to do so], he is informed of the fundamentals of the religion and some of the minor and major commandments, along with their punishments and rewards—just as is done when informing a [prospective] convert. He is then immersed [in a mikveh] as a convert, and he is informed [of this] while he is in the water. If he does not desire to accept [this], we persist in trying with him for twelve months. If [after that] he still refuses, he is sold back to the gentiles, and it is forbidden to retain him longer than that. However, if a condition was made at the outset that he would neither be circumcised nor immersed, but rather would be a resident alien (ger toshav), it is permitted to retain him in his labor as a ger toshav. Yet a slave of this kind is only permitted to be retained during the time when the Jubilee [year] is observed.

title: What is the correct procedure when one awakens around midnight?
content:
# What is the correct procedure when one awakens around midnight? ## Frage

What is the correct procedure of morning rituals when one awakens around midnight, and doesn’t intend to go back to sleep?

For example, if one awakens slightly after midnight, when should one:

  • Do נטילת ידיִם?
  • Say בִרכות הַתּורה?
  • Say ברכות השּׁחר?
  • Say the morning אשר יצר—what if he uses the bathroom upon awakening? What if he doesn’t need to, so he waits until morning?

And so on.

What about when someone awakens slightly before midnight?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

The Shulchan Aruch in Orach Chaim 47:13 states:

המשכים קודם אור היום ללמוד מברך ברכ' התור' ואינו צריך לחזור ולברך כשילך לבית הכנסת המשכים קודם אור היום מברך כל סדר הברכות חוץ מברכת הנותן לשכוי בינה ופרשת התמיד [ע"ל סי' א' סעיף ו'] שימתין מלאומרם עד שיאור היום: הגה ולכתחלה יטול ידיו קודם שיברך ללמוד ואם לא היה לו מים יכול ללמוד ולברך בלא נטילה כמו בשאר ברכות שמברך קודם נטילה כדלעיל סימן מ"ו [אגור]:

Those who wake early, before the light of day, to study, bless the Blessings of the Torah; and there is no need to go back and bless [again] when one goes to the synagogue. Those who wake early before the light of day bless the entire order of blessings other than the blessing of "who gives the rooster understanding" and the section of the daily offering [see above, Chapter 1, Section 6]; in that, one waits to say them until the light of day. (Gloss: ab initio, one washes one's hands prior to blessing for study, but if one did not have water, one can learn and bless without washing as with the rest of blessing that one blesses before washing as above, Chapter 46 [Agur].)

title: Can a frum, charedi woman wear tzitzit privately? What do major poskim say?
content:
# Can a frum, charedi woman wear tzitzit privately? What do major poskim say? ## Frage

I’m asking this question sincerely, from a place of deep yirat Shamayim and a desire to grow closer to Hashem. This is not coming from a liberal or feminist place — chas v’shalom — but from a heart that wants to get closer to Hashem.

Lately, I’ve been learning about the mitzvah of tzitzit and all the beautiful things Chazal say about it. I was especially moved by what the Chazon Ish said — that wearing tzitzit is like tying a permanent knot with Hashem — and also by the story of the Gaon of Vilna, who longed to stay in this world just to keep doing mitzvot through tzitzit. All of this made me wish I could have something like that too.

So I wanted to ask:

  1. What do the gedolim— like the Chafetz Chaim, Chazon Ish, Rav Moshe Feinstein, Rav Elyashiv, Rav Chaim Kanievsky, Rav Ovadia Yosef, Rav Ben Tzion Abba Shaul — say about a woman wearing tzitzit privately?
  2. If she is allowed to wear tzitzit, would it also be considered a mitzvah — or would it just be seen as another garment for her?

I’m not looking to make a statement or change anything. I just want to understand if this is something a woman can quietly do to deepen her avodat Hashem within the framework of halacha.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

A story is being brought (see e.g., here) regarding R Soloveitchik when asked this same question. I am not suggesting you are like the person described in the story - but it provides an interesting framework to think of your issue.

R. Soloveitchik believed he had good reason to doubt that greater fulfillment of mitsvot motivated many of these women, as illustrated in the following story, related to us by R. Yehuda Kelemer, former Rabbi of the Young Israel of Brookline, Massachusetts.

During the mid-1970’s, one of R. Kelemer’s woman congregants at the Young Israel of Brookline was interested in wearing a tallit and tsitsit during the prayer services. After R. Kelemer had expressed to her his hesitations about the matter, she approached R. Soloveitchik — who lived in Brookline — on the matter. The Rav explained that in light of the novelty of the action, it needed to be adopted gradually.

Accordingly, he suggested that she first try wearing a talit without tsitsit (which is, of course, allowed for women.) The Rav asked the woman to return to him after three months, at which time they would discuss the matter further. When the two met once again, she described to R. Soloveitchik the magnificent nature of her religious experience in wearing the tallit. The Rav pointed out to the woman that wearing a tallit without tsitsit lacked any halakhically authentic element of mitsvah. It was obvious, therefore, that what generated her sense of “religious high” was not an enhanced kiyyum hamitsvah, but something else.

Under such circumstances, the Rav maintained, wearing a tallit was an inappropriate use of the mitsvah. Consequently, the Rav forbade the woman from wearing a tallit with tsitsit. [Rabbi Aryeh A. Frimer & Rabbi Dov I. Frimer, “Women’s Prayer Services – Theory and Practice I” Tradition, 32:2, pp. 5-118 (Winter 1998) at page 41.]

title: Why haAres instead of haEres
content:
# Why haAres instead of haEres ## Frage

Rabbi ovadia yosef writes that the correct text of the berakha is hagEfen and not hagAfen, because hagefen isnt the last word, “amen” is, and therefore gefen doesnt need to be in the pasual form. However, if this is the case, why do we not say hamosi lehem min haEres? Why do we say haAres, but not hagAfen?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

הארץ, the definite form of ארץ, is always pronounced hā'āreṣ (your “haAres”). We don’t say hā'ereṣ (your “haEres”), because the word hā'ereṣ doesn’t exist.

The following is taken from the accepted answer here, with the addition of background information:

In Biblical times, the word ארץ was pronounced 'arṣ. The definite form, הארץ, was pronounced ha''arṣ.

Eventually, א was no longer allowed to be geminated (which is why it can’t have a Dagesh Chazzak like most letters can). To preserve the prosody of the word, the vowel of the definite article was lengthened; ergo, hā'arṣ.

According to most linguists, א was later elided between certain vowels in certain situations, including this one. So at some point, the word was pronounced hārṣ (possibly with an extra-long vowel).

Eventually, the א was added back in formal readings (by analogy with almost everywhere else in Tanakh, where א is pronounced). The ā vowel was perceived as part of the noun; in other words, people parsed הארץ as hā and 'ārṣ, the latter with the long vowel.

Eventually, hāʔārṣ underwent segolation and became hāʔāreṣ. This is what we have today.

(Something similar likely happened to other definite nouns starting with hā'ā-; for example, hāʔārôn (הָאָרוֹן).)

title: Rav Huna and Rav Yirmiya in Bereshit Rabbah
content:
# Rav Huna and Rav Yirmiya in Bereshit Rabbah ## Frage

I'm trying to find out who were the Rav Huna and Rav Yirmiya cited in Bereshit Rabbah 1:4:

"Rabbi Huna and Rabbi Yirmeya said in the name of Rabbi Shmuel bar Rabbi Yitzḥak: The contemplation about [creating] Israel preceded all other things".

I know who Rabbi Shmuel bar R. Yitzhak is, but there are too many amoraim named Huna or Yirmiya to say who they were. I've tried Sefer Seder HaDorot and AI, but no much luck.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

This Rabbi Yirmiyah seems to be the famous one, "stam Rabbi Yirmiyah", so to speak. Rabbi Aharon Heiman noted in Seder Tannaim v'Amoraim, vol. 3, pp. 1139-1140 that Rabbi Yirmiyah brought teachings in his name a few times, and even asked Rav Zeira - who was one of Rabbi Yirmiyah's rabbis - a question by Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzchak's funeral wake (Yerushalmi Brachot 3:1 = Yerushalmi Nazir 7:1).

The case of this Rav Huna is less clear, as already noted in Seder Ha'Dorot:

"רב הונא ור' ירמיה בשמו מדרש ריש פתיחתא דאיכה וכ"ה בירושלמי פ"א דחגיגה הלכה ז'. וצ"ע שר"ה יאמר בשם תלמידו, וראיתי בילקוט ירמיה סי' ט' רמז רפ"ב ענין זה ר"ה ור' ירמיה ור' שמואל ברב יצחק. ואולי הגיה כן מטעם שכתבתי."

"Rav Huna and R. Yirmiyah said in [the name of Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzchak] in the midrash, the head of Petichta of Eicha, as well as in the Yerushalmi, Chagigah 1:7. And this necessitates further examination that Rav Huna would say in the name of his student, and I saw in the Yalkut [Shimoni] of Yirmiyah, § 9, remez 282 it stated thus: "Rav Huna and Rabbi Yirmiyah and Rav Shmuel b'Rav Yitzhak". And perhaps he corrected for the reason that I brought."

So according to S"H, it seems that this Rav Huna should be "stam Rav Huna", however Rav Huna was the rabbi of Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzchak, so it's strange that he would bring teachings in the name of his student. He notes a version of one of the statements brought in Yalkut Shimoni, where it seems that all three made the statement, and not two in the name of Rav Shmuel. But he also notes this may have been a correction made by the author of Yalkut Shimoni (Rabbi Shimon Kra of Frankfurt).

Rabbi Heiman, Seder, vol. 1, pp. 344-346 notes three other individuals known as Rav Huna:

  • A student of the first Rav Huna
  • A student of Rav Yosef
  • A student of Rav Ashi

Of these, the first two seem to be the most likely candidates: Both moved to Eretz Yisrael and lived around the time of Rav Shmuel or not long after, and both have other qualifications that tip the scales in their favor: The student of Rav Huna seems to (i.e., he is the most likely candidate for identification) have been explicitly praised by Rav Shmuel (Yerushalmi Sanhedrin 1:2 = Yerushalmi Rosh Hashanah 3:1), while the student of Rav Yosef eventually became a student of Rav Yirmiyah. I would therefore surmise that one of these is the Rav Huna brought in the passage in Beresheet Rabbah, though I'm not sure it's possible to further narrow down the selection.

title: Were the Ten Commandments in Devorim (Voeschanan) said by Hashem or Moshe?
content:
# Were the Ten Commandments in Devorim (Voeschanan) said by Hashem or Moshe? ## Frage

The introduction to the Ten Commandments in Devorim (Voeschanan) reads, Devorim 5 (4-5)

Face to face Hashem spoke to you on the mountain out of the fire— I stood between Hashem and you at that time to convey Hashem’s words to you, for you were afraid of the fire and did not go up the mountain—saying:

Moshe is telling the Jewish people that Hashem spoke the Ten Commandments on the mountain at a previous time.

Commenting on the difference between the Shabbos commandment (in Shemos, remember the Shabbos day; in Devorim, guard the Shabbos day), Rashi says

The explanation is: Both of them (זכור and שמור) were spoken in one utterance and as one word, and were heard in one hearing (i.e. were heard simultaneously).

This strongly suggests that the commandment of Shomor was also said by Hashem and is not Moshe retelling us what Hashem said.

Were the Ten Commandments in Devorim (Voeschanan) said by Hashem or Moshe?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

The verbal form certainly suits the literal meaning of the text, for the first two Commandments were uttered by God in the first person.

https://etzion.org.il

Talmud Bavli, Makot 24b and Horayot 8a, brings a further position that we heard directly from God only its first two Commandments (“I am the Lord your God . . .”; You shall have no other gods . . . ”), since when the experience was too powerful for Israel, “My soul went out in His speaking with me” (Song of Songs 6:6), Moshe taught the rest as they appear in the third person (Bavli Shabbat 88b) based on Deut. 5:20-26. Halakhic authorities thus note[20] how both of the Mekhilta’s two versions of “in one utterance” at mattan Torah are replicated and reenacted in the Aseret HaDibrot Torah Reading on Shavuot with its Ta’am HaElyon cantillating the first two Commandments (“I am the Lord your God . . .”/“You shall have no other gods”) as one verse and the four verse Shabbat Commandment as one.

title: If the seventy sages wrote a Sefer Torah in Greek, shouldn't the Greek transliteration of the Tetragrammaton be a name that may not be erased?
content:
# If the seventy sages wrote a Sefer Torah in Greek, shouldn't the Greek transliteration of the Tetragrammaton be a name that may not be erased? ## Frage

Megillah 8b has Rabban Shimon state that, although there are translations in other languages, only Greek Torah Scrolls possess the sanctity of a proper scroll. Traditionally this is probably related to the Septuagint's composition, but scholars don't recognize the Septuagint as the version permitted for a Greek Sefer Torah. Nonetheless the way the Name itself was written in Greek is known - Iota Alpha Omega - so I would expect it to possess the same properties and restrictions as a Hebrew transcription. Has anyone commented on this?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

This is from Hebrew Wikipedia

מילים שמשמשות כשם ה' בשפות זרות (כמו God ו-الله) – הרמב"ם כותב שדינם ככינויים ולא כשמות ה' ממש,[11] ובכינויים אין איסור מחיקה.[5] על פי זה, הדעה המקובלת בפוסקים היא שאין איסור למחוק שמות אלה.[12] אמנם, רבי יאיר חיים בכרך סובר שאם השם נכתב באותיות כתב אשורי (כגון 'גוד' או אולי גם 'אללה') אסור למחקו.[13]

Here is the English translation of the passage:

"Words that are used as names of God in foreign languages (such as 'God' and 'Allah') – Maimonides (the Rambam) writes that their status is like that of kinuyim (epithets or substituted titles), and not actual names of God.[11] Regarding kinuyim, there is no prohibition against erasing them.[5] Based on this, the commonly accepted opinion among the halachic authorities is that there is no prohibition in erasing these names.[12] However, Rabbi Yair Chaim Bacharach holds that if the name is written in Ashuri script (the traditional Hebrew script), such as 'God' or possibly even 'Allah' written in Hebrew letters, then it is forbidden to erase it.[13]

REFERENCES

5 משנה תורה לרמב"ם, ספר המדע, הלכות יסודי התורה, פרק ו', הלכה ה
' 11 משנה תורה לרמב"ם, ספר שופטים, הלכות סנהדרין והעונשין המסורין להם, פרק כ"ו, הלכה ג'

12 ש"ך, יורה דעה, סימן קע"ט, סעיף ח', סימן קטן י"א; משנה ברורה, סימן פ"ה, סעיף קטן י'

13 שו"ת חות יאיר, סימן ק"ט

So it seems that the Rambam has ruled that there is no prohibition in erasing foreign language translations of the name of Hashem. If it is written in Ashuri script then Rabbi Y C Bacharach forbids erasure.
