title: What is the meaning of Bitachon for the masses according to the predominant medieval view that severely limits hashgacha pratis?
content:
# What is the meaning of Bitachon for the masses according to the predominant medieval view that severely limits hashgacha pratis? ## Frage

Per this, many—if not most—rishonim subscribe to a theory of hashgacha that is extremely limited, with the average man on the street subject to the vagaries of nature.

Bitachon nowadays is typically defined as the belief that all that happens to all people is directly orchestrated by HaShem and for the best, even if we can't see it in the moment.

Such a definition seems to be dependent upon the more popular view of hashgacha nowadays that enlarges the scope of hashgacha to include all people and perhaps even more than that.

How do the majority of the rishonim understand the concept of Bitachon for the average person—if they indeed subscribe to it at all—in light of their view that hashgacha pratis doesn't extend to the masses?

Is it reduced to a general belief in ultimate reward and punishment in a different realm of existence despite most people being subject to nature's morally agnostic ways in the here and now?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

The amount of source material on this is voluminous, and cannot be quoted in this answer. I'd recommend going through all the sources brought by that answer, and seeing them in full.

The short answer: The idea of השגחה פרטית is that Hashem deals with human beings on an individual level, as opposed to a general level (השגחה כללית). Whereas with animals, Hashem leaves them to the forces of nature, human beings are dealt with based on their actions. If a person is good, Hashem will reward him, and if he is bad, he will be punished. Such a concept can't exist with regards to animals, as they have no free will, and cannot choose good or bad.

The closer a person is to God (i.e., the better he is), the better he will be treated by God. The further he is from God (i.e., the worse he is), the worse he will be treated by God. That is all that is meant by השגחה פרטית. We are not subject to the laws of nature, we are subject to the consequences of our actions.

As such, Bitachon is just as applicable to the common man as it is to the Gadol HaDor. A person is judged by his actions, and God responds accordingly. There is no such thing as "natural law" with regards to a human being.

This point is stressed strongly by that Rambam, Ramban, and Sefer HaChinuch quoted in that answer. Once again, I highly recommend looking at all of those sources in detail.

I will quote just a few lines from the end of that Ramban, as he stresses this point in the clearest way:

רמב"ן שמות פרק יג פסוק טז (פרשת בא) שאין לאדם חלק בתורת משה רבינו עד שנאמין בכל דברינו ומקרינו שכלם נסים אין בהם טבע ומנהגו של עולם, בין ברבים בין ביחיד, אלא אם יעשה המצות יצליחנו שכרו, ואם יעבור עליהם יכריתנו ענשו, הכל בגזרת עליון כאשר הזכרתי כבר.

Translation: A person has no share in the Torah of Moshe Rabbeinu until he believes that all our affairs and experiences are miracles — that there is no such thing as 'nature' or the ordinary course of the world. This applies both to the collective and to the individual. Rather, if one performs the commandments, his reward will bring him success; and if he transgresses them, his punishment will cut him off — all by the decree of the Most High, as I have already mentioned.

title: Why is a single Ox of פסולי-המוקדשין considered "two bodies" Kil’ajim?
content:
# Why is a single Ox of פסולי-המוקדשין considered "two bodies" Kil’ajim? ## Frage

Why does Halacha treat a redeemed, blemished sacrificial animal (פסולי-המוקדשין) – although biologically it is only one ox – as two different kinds and therefore prohibits mating (הרבעה) and joint work (הנהגה)?

The section Makkot 22a belongs to the list אלו הן הלוקין – offenses for which a perpetrator receives 39 lashes. Here, surprisingly, the mixing of a single ox is mentioned:

"Whoever covers or jointly drives an ox from פסולי-המוקדשין (consecrated animals that were redeemed due to a blemish) is flogged; for although it is one body, the Torah treated it as two bodies."

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

See Artscroll Makkos 22a note 48. Rivan notes he does not know the source for this extraordinary law.

Tosafos however citing Bechoros 33a, hold that R' Hoshayas ruling is alluded to in Devarim 15:22, where the Torah likens a disqualified offering to a "deer and a hart". The Torah thus regards the disqualified offering as two species at the same time.

See there for additional sources.

Its noted about the statement prior to yours, however, I think the answer can be shared.

title: Help pronouncing ר in the Tiberian tradition
content:
# Help pronouncing ר in the Tiberian tradition ## Frage

I need help pronouncing ר in the Tiberian tradition. I used TiberianHebrew.com as a reference, but I still need clarification on some points, and better audio examples. For example, in what environment does ר become trilled, and in what environment is it "gurgled”? Can someone provide better audio examples than are on the site?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

See Khan’s The Tiberian pronunciation tradition of Biblical Hebrew, §I.1.20.

In the Tiberian tradition, ר had two possible pronunciations: A voiced uvular trill (henceforth “/R/”) and a voiced alveolar trill (henceforth “/r/”). See the links for voice recordings of each one.

Uvular means that the sound is pronounced a bit behind the spot where we pronounce G, K, and “ng” in English. If you know how to pronounce ח and soft כ in Modern Hebrew, you are pronouncing the non-voiced uvular trill. The difference between Tiberian ר and Modern Hebrew ח is just like the difference between B and P, or between V and F. In the first one, your voicebox is activated; but in the second one, you’re exhaling silently. (This is how R is pronounced in French at the beginning of a syllable.)

Alveolar means that the sound is pronounced in the same location as T, D, S, and Z—the spot on the roof of your mouth slightly behind your teeth, using the tip of your tongue. From the guides on YouTube, it seems you have to relax your tongue and breathe out while activating your voice, which causes the tip to vibrate.
Don’t become frustrated if you don’t get it right away: For children whose first language contains /r/ (e.g. Italian, Arabic, Spanish), it’s often the very last sound they learn to pronounce. I myself still haven’t figured out how to do it.

Note that in the Tiberian tradition, /r/ was pharyngealized, meaning you would simultaneously pronounce a subtle ע. This is similar to the Tiberian pronunciation of ט and צ.

The rules for when to use one over the other are, once you memorize them, relatively easy to implement:

  1. /R/ is used by default.

רֶגֶל /ʀe.ɣel/

  1. /r/ is used when preceded by a coronal letter (made with the tip of the tongue). The coronal letters are דזטלנסצשׂ״ת (this includes Sin, but not Shin).

דַרְכּוֹ /dar.kō/
יִשְׂרָאֵל /yis.rɔ̄.ʔēl/
לְרֹאשׁ /le.rōš/

  1. /r/ is also used when followed by נ or ל.

רִנָּה /rin.nɔ̄/
אֲשֶׁר־לוֹ /ʔa.šer.lō/

“Preceded” means the letter comes directly before ר, and “followed” means the letter comes directly after ר. (Note that a maqaf (־) indicates that two words should be pronounced as one, which can affects the pronunciation of ר, as in the final example above.)

The ר in these environments only becomes /r/ if the two letters are not separated by one of the following types of vowels:

  • A long vowel
  • Chataf-Kamatz or Chataf-Segol

If there’s any such vowel between the ר and the coronal letter, and the second letter does not have a silent Shva, then the ר remains /R/ (e.g. נֵרוֹת, /nē.ʀōt̠/, רֹנִי /ʀōnī, צֳרִי /ṣo.ʀī/)

The long vowels are:

  • ◌ָ Kamatz Gadol (ɔ̄)
  • ◌ֵ Tsereh (ē)
  • ‏◌ִי‏/◌ִֽ Chirik Gadol (ī)
  • ◌ֹ/וֹ Cholam (ō)
  • ◌ֻֽ/וּ Shuruk/Kubbutz Gadol (ū)

Sometimes, the last syllable of a word contains a long vowel (e.g. הַיָּם, אַהֲרֹן,). Regarding the pronunciation of ר, it is treated as a short vowel, even though it’s technically a long vowel. Thus, דּוֹר is /dōr/, not /dōʀ/.

Here are some more example words:

בְּרֵאשִׁית /be.ʀē.šīt/
צְרוּרָה /ṣe.rū.ʀā/
אַדִּיר /ʔaddīr/
שָׂר /sār/
שִׁיר /šīʀ/
לָרֹעִים /lā.ʀō.ʕīm/
רְנָנָה /re.nā.nā/
חֲרֹנוֹ /ħa.ʀō.nō/

(P.S. סָרַרְנוּ is interesting: The second ר is in direct contact with the following נ, and therefore becomes /r/. Now, /r/ shares with נ and ל the property of being a sonorant, and I believe it might affect other surrounding רs the same way as נ and ל. Just a theory; but if I’m right, this word would have been pronounced /sɔ̄.rar.nū/, not /sɔ̄.ʀar.nū.)

title: Emotional response to tragedy
content:
# Emotional response to tragedy ## Frage

When the meraglim spoke negatively about Eretz Yisroel, and we cried on the night of Tisha B’av, G-d said, “Since you cried for nothing, this will be a [night of] crying for generations.”

Clearly, in that generation after seeing all the miracles that G-d did for us, we should have had more Emuna/Bitachon to believe that conquering Eretz Yisroel won’t be any problem. And from there we see that mourning for something which isn’t really a tragedy can sometimes be a terrible sin.

But how far do we take that attitude? Every “tragedy” can truly be reframed into something which is good for us in the long run, e.g. a tikkun, a kapparah, or yissurin shel ahava. And I’m not asking about mourning over a death; that’s a mitza to mourn. I’m asking about other things which we commonly perceive as tragedies like divorce, serious medical issues, etc. Should we try to reframe everything in a positive light and not “mourn” over those things? Or should we follow the current psychology theory that excess positivity (“toxic positivity”) is not always emotionally healthy?

No matter what the right answer is, my gut feeling is that we shouldn’t compound anyone’s suffering by making them feel guilty for not having more faith.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

I"m not so sure the sin there was mourning a tragedy per se, it seems from the language of the פסוקים that it was a lack of Bitachon.

במדבר פרק יג פסוק לא (פרשת שלח) וְהָ֨אֲנָשִׁ֜ים אֲשֶׁר־עָל֤וּ עִמּוֹ֙ אָֽמְר֔וּ לֹ֥א נוּכַ֖ל לַעֲל֣וֹת אֶל־הָעָ֑ם כִּֽי־חָזָ֥ק ה֖וּא מִמֶּֽנּוּ:

Numbers 13:31: And the men who went up with him said, 'We are not able to go up against the people, for they are stronger than us.

רש"י שם חזק הוא ממנו - כביכול כלפי מעלה אמרו:

Rashi ad loc.: "He is stronger than us” – as if to say, they spoke against the One Above (God).

It would seem from this the complaint against them was that they literally believed God couldn't save them, and God's response was that their crying was for nothing (i.e. there was no tragedy).

We generally do have a concept of mourning, (e.g., Shiva, Tisha B'av) even though we could reframe those things in a positive way in the long run. In fact, in those instances, the Halacha commands us to mourn. It's hard to say that mourning a tragedy would be something that you could be punished for in that light.

title: Habbani accent?
content:
# Habbani accent? ## Frage

I saw a post here attempting to describe certain details of the traditional Hebrew pronunciation of Habbani Jews (a clan or sub-community of Yemenite Jews).

Unfortunately, the poster’s attempts to describe this accent with intuitive phraseology were, to say the least, very un-intuitive.

I am hoping someone here who knows about the Habbani accent can help describe it, by either 1) referencing other languages which contain these exact sounds, or 2) utilizing symbols or descriptions taken from the IPA.

Here are the relevant segments from the post and its comments (see there):

  1. Hard Resh (I assume this is an alveolar trill):

The main pronunciation of resh is a regular rolled r, like exists in Arabic and Spanish.

  1. Soft Resh:

The soft resh is much like an English r, but more emphatic, as if you were about to roll it but stopped short. You can still hear this sound in some old Arabic music.

Comment: English r is as in American English, or West Country England English. Move your tongue forward more to emphasize the sound….

  1. Gimel with Dagesh:

…In Habbanit our hard gimel is neither j nor g, but a kind of clicking g sound.

Comment: Make a normal g sound, move is SLIGHTLY forward towards your teeth, and emphasize it to the point that it clicks. Ethiopians, who speak Semitic languages, have this sound as well.

  1. Gimel without Dagesh (I assume this is the voiced velar fricative):

Soft gimel is "gh".

  1. Samekh:

Samekh is best described as the s sound… in "Mexico" (since x is truly k-s), with the tongue positioned lower than in a regular s sound.

  1. Quf:

Quf is a guttural "g" sound, not as intense as the Iraqi version.

title: Why does the bull (שׁוֹר) hold such a high status in the sacrificial rite?
content:
# Why does the bull (שׁוֹר) hold such a high status in the sacrificial rite? ## Frage

For a nomadic people, it is unnatural to sacrifice large cattle. A bull = potential for reproduction for years. In the wandering clan of the patriarchs, large cattle were already smaller than the small cattle segment. To set aside a breeding bull for a sacrifice hit the "economic" basis harder than any sheep. The Torah makes this value difference legally visible by setting the fatal damage to a bull at 30 shekels – exactly the maximum compensation rate in ancient Israelite jurisprudence.

We see this from the chronology (Schechem, Bet-El / Ai, Hebron, Be’er Scheva, Morija, Be’er Scheva, Bet-El, Gilead, Schechem, Bet-El, Be’er Scheva). These are the places where the patriarchs made sacrifices (Abraham, Isaac, Jacob). Until Sinai, there are no bull sacrifices.

After Sinai, the bull sacrifice dominates all important stations and processes of the year and months.

Par kohen ha-mashiach, Par heʿelem davar shel tzibbur, Par avodah zarah, Par Yom Kippur, Rosh Chodesh, Pessach / Chag HaMatzot, Schawuot, Rosch HaSchana, Yom Kippur (Musaf), Sukkot, Schemini Atzeret, Korban Chagigah.

What is the reason for this? Are there sources that discuss this?

New findings:

But the Holy One is merciful towards His children, and so provided the offering of a calf as reparation for the soul of which Satan was deprived and as a means of pacifying the world’s accuser. Herein is involved a deep mystery. The offerings of the ox, the cow, the calf, the heifer have all a deep mystical significance, and therefore we make reparation to him in the way mentioned in the text. Hence the declaration, “Our hands have not shed this blood, etc.” (Deut. 21, 7)- they have not shed this blood, and we have not caused his death; and by this means the accuser is thereby kept at a distance.

ZOHAR 114a

By your life, Israel will not depart from here until they slaughter the god of Egypt before their eyes, as I will thereby inform them that their gods are nothing.

In Egyptian mythology, Ptah is the creator god who is said to have created the universe through his thoughts and words (Ptah, Creator God). The Apis bull, which was worshipped as an embodiment of Ptah, played an important role in royal rituals and was considered a living manifestation of the god (Apis Bull, Royal Rituals).

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

According to Maharsha's answer in Chiddushei Aggados given here. It is printed at the end the משניות זכר חנוך, vol. 2 edition, p. 467 on Bikkurim 3:3. It points that the answer comes directly from the verses of the Torah, גזירת הכתוב:

That is, the bull is the first of all offerings, as it is mentioned first in the verses Vayikra 17:3 or 22:27 ... a bull, a sheep, or a goat .... A small animal is not as fit as an offering as compared to a bull, as it is hinted in the verse Devarim 33:17: like a firstling bull in his majesty. That is, the bull is beatitiful for the mitzvah of bikkurim, who is also a first-born, and the head of every offering as brought in various drashos.

One such drasha is given in Esther Rabba 7:11:

He then checked the signs of the Zodiac... Bull [Taurus - month of Iyar] – the merit of Joseph, who was called a bull, was found. That is what is written: “A firstborn bull is his majesty” (Deuteronomy 33:17). And the merit of an offering, as it is stated: “A bull, or a sheep, or a goat, when it is born…” (Leviticus 22:27).

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

The Par/Bull/Cow species corresponds to Abraham - the first of the Patriarchs - who was the paragon of monotheism. Abraham prepared a young calf/cow for his guests - see Genesis 18:7.

title: Do we find any sources that there won't be a third galus?
content:
# Do we find any sources that there won't be a third galus? ## Frage

Any sources that back up the claim I always heard as a child that we can't "lose" Eretz Yisrael/modern day Medinat Yisrael?

Disclaimer: I grew up in a staunchly Mizrachi community, but still I assume there have to be some sources that back up the claim. Or is it based on the assumption that if we are seeing the flowering of the redemption/prophecies being fulfilled (nevuah of Zecharia, land blossoming and producing fruits again, etc.) then the progress won't be reversed?

Am I just touching on the existential challenge the Gush Katif expulsion posed on the dati leumi community? Where can I delve more into this sugya?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

You can start is Midrash Tanchuma, Shoftim 9

https://www.sefaria.org/Midrash_Tanchuma%2C_Shoftim

דָּבָר אַחֵר, וְהַשְּׁלִישִׁית יִוָּתֶר בָּהּ, שֶׁאֵין מִתְיַשְּׁבִין בְּאַרְצָם אֶלָּא בִּגְאֻלָּה שְׁלִישִׁית. גְּאֻלָּה רִאשׁוֹנָה, זוֹ גְּאֻלַּת מִצְרַיִם. גְּאוּלָה שְׁנִיָּה, זוֹ גְּאֻלַּת עֶזְרָא. הַשְּׁלִישִׁית, אֵין לָהּ הֶפְסֵק

Another interpretation (of Zech. 13:8) “but one-third shall remain in it”: [These words mean] that they shall only settle in their land in the third deliverance. The first deliverance was the deliverance from Egypt. The second was the deliverance of [in the time of] Ezra. The third has no interruption

Also, Rav Kook:

"אתחלתא דגאולה ודאי הולכת ומופיעה לפנינו". כמו כן, כתב הרב קוק שזו תתפתח לגאולה שלמה: "מאמין הוא העם כולו, שאין גלות עוד אחרי הגאולה ההולכת ומתחלת שלפנינו" (אורות, עמ' עז). לאחר קום המדינה כתב תלמידו, הרי"מ חרל"פ: "הדבר ברור כשמש בצהרים שחורבן שלישי לא יהיה עוד ומדינת ישראל שקמה לתחיה בל תמוט לעולם ועד" (מעייני הישועה, ע' רכז)

There is the famous story of Rabbi Herzog: The army of Nazis (yemach shemam) were advancing across North Africa towards Eretz Yisrael. Rav Herzog was in the United States fundraising for the Jewish community in Eretz Yisrael. He was urged (I read it was by the British Ambassador, and read elsewhere that it was by the rabbanim) to remain in the United States for his safety. But Rav Herzog told them that there was no need for concern since there would be no third churban "אין שום מקום לפחד, כי ניצחון הנאצים במזרח התיכון פירושו חורבן שלישי… ועל חורבן שלישי כזה לא ניבאו נביאינו

There is good discussion of the issue at https://shabaton1.co.il/?p=33567 with additional sources and discussion, and also at https://jewishlink.news/the-great-reishit-tzemichat-geulatenu-debate/ where Rav Goren is quoted similar to rav Herzog, but on the eve of the 6 day War.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

"Can't lose" can be taken two ways. It could be saying that it is an utter impossibility to lose it because of the hand of God in history, or it could be saying we must not lose it as a political imperative.

Since we do not have prophets today and have not had them for thousands of years, I would say that anyone claiming the first is speaking their hopes, and anyone speaking the second means it as a call to action.

title: Why a bull with gold-plated horns?
content:
# Why a bull with gold-plated horns? ## Frage

Mishnah Bikkurim 3:3

…A bull would go before them and its horns would be plated with gold and it would have a olive wreath around its head…

The bull (שׁוֹר) is a korban shalem.

  1. Why must this bull have golden horns?
  2. Why must it go first?
  3. Why must it be a bull?
  4. Why were sheep or goats not sufficient for this korban shalem?

What deeper meaning does this bull have, since it is adorned with golden horns?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

It seems that questions 1 and 2 of the OP are addressed by R' Moshe Chaim Luzzatto in Mesilas Yesharim 19:57:

The order of offering the first fruits (Bikurim) are a guide for us to see what is "Hidur Mitzva" (beautifying a mitzva). We learned: "an ox with horns overlaid with gold and with an olive crown upon its head walks before them..." (Bikurim 3:3). And later on there: "the wealthy brought their first fruits in baskets of gold, while the poor used baskets of willow branches" (Bikurim 3:8). And "there are three elements in first fruits: the first fruits themselves, the additions to the first fruits, and the decorations of the first fruits..." (Bikurim 3:10). Thus we see just how much it is proper to add on to the body of the mitzva itself in order to beautify it. From here we learn to all the other Mitzvot of the Torah.

(see also a much deeper Maharsha's answer below).

Question 3 Based on mishna Bikurim 2:4:

And they (bikkurim) require a sacrifice, a song, waving, and spending the night in Jerusalem.

Based on the answer in the comments by @JoelK: "A bull was the largest and most expensive animal that could be used for a korban."

Question 4: there is a discussion in Yerushalmi 3:3:3:

Is it obvious that it will be sacrificed as a well-being offering? Rebbi Ammi said, it will be sacrificed as a shlamim (peace) offering. Rav said, one uses it to occupy the altar, i.e. olah offering 1. Rebbi Zeïra asked: Does a private person who was lazy and did not come [with the group] bring a goat with its horns covered in silver2?

1 קיץ המזבח is used for elevation offerings, which are brought any time the altar would otherwise be empty. It is difficult to find the meaning in the root קיץ “summer”; it might be from a verb parallel Arabic قصّ, أِّقصّ, “to appear pregnant”.

2 This is the interpretation of Maimonides who does not quote the statement in his Code. According to Rashba (Responsa 1, #291) it is a prescriptive sentence: “A private person who was lazy and did not come brings a goat with its horns covered in silver.” This agrees with Z. Frankel’s opinion that in the Yerushalmi, בעי does not necessarily imply a question.

The answers to 3&4 are brought collectively by Melekhes Shlomo on on the Mishna, who also notes a girsa that a bull would go with them (not before them).

There is an important limud to questions 3 and 4 brought by Tosefta Kifshutah 2:8:13:

ושלמים... אבל רב אינו חולק על הברייתא כאן, אלא מפרש את המשנה שהשור שהיה הולך לפניהם שהיה בוודאי משל רבים קרב עולה, אבל כל יחיד היה יכול לקנות בהמה בירושלים ולהקריבה שלמים משום שמחה. *עיין בירושלמי פ"ב ה"ג, ס"ה ע"א, ובר"מ פ"ג מה' בכורים הי"ב. ובירושלמי להלן שם אמרו: יחיד שנתעצל ולא בא (כלומר, עם הרבים) מביא גדי וקרניו מצופות כסף. ושמא לשיטת רב גם גדי זה קרב עולה. ובמשנתנו (פ"ב מ"ד) בסתם: "וטעונין קרבן", אבל הקרבן אינו מעכב. *עיין בירושלמי הנ"ל.

However, Rav is not arguing on the words of baraisa here, rather he explains the mishna: the bull that walks before them is for sure (an indication) that it is a public offering and brought as an olah. However, an individual can buy an animal in Yerushalaim and offer as shlamim because of simchah. ...Further, a person who was lazy and brought a goat - it is also brought as an olah. Finally, although the mishna teaches that bikkurim require an offering, the offering does not interfere with the mitzvah.

A deeper answer to Questions 1 & 2 regarding why the horns were covered with gold and why the bull would walk first is quoted in the name of Chiddushei Aggados Maharsha. It is printed at the end the משניות זכר חנוך, vol. 2 edition, p. 467 on Bikkurim 3:3:

Those who bring ... and a bull would walk before them ... and a crown of olives ... One intends in doing so to express joy in the mitzvah of bikkurim which is the first of the gifts of the land of Israel with things similar to it. That is the bull is the first of all offerings, as it is mentioned first in the verses Vayikra 17:3 or 22:27 ... a bull, a sheep, or a goat, .... A small animal is not as fit as an offering as compared to a bull, as it is hinted in the verse Devarim 33:17: like a firstling bull in his majesty. That is the bull is beatitiful for the mitzvah of bikkurim, who is also a first-born, and the head of every offering as brought in various drashos. And it says that its horns are plated with gold, which is a hint that Israel made a Golden Calf which is a kind of bull, as in Tehilim 106:19-20 They made a calf at Horeb and bowed down to a molten image. They exchanged their glory for the image of a bull that feeds on grass. The verse intends to say that they did not make a bull with horns, rather they made a calf that gets nursed from its mother, who is only like an image of a grown bull, its kind, that feeds with grass. Thus, this bull with horns is still in purity (not soiled by a sin) and it is going to be the first of all offerings. That is why the horns are covered with gold for this mitzvah, since the horns were not present on the Golden Calf when it was made.

It will be great to find where in the Gemara Maharsha gives this drash.

title: How to understand yeshaya 29:12
content:
# How to understand yeshaya 29:12 ## Frage

In light of the quranic exegesis by Dr. Mustafa Khattab, The Clear Quran - of Isaiah 29:12, which explains:

The Prophet (ﷺ) was retreating at a cave in the outskirts of Mecca when the angel Gabriel appeared to him, squeezing him tightly and ordering him to read. Since the Prophet (ﷺ) was unlettered, he responded, “I cannot read.” Ultimately, Gabriel taught him: “Read in the Name of your Lord …” Some scholars believe that this encounter is the fulfilment of Isaiah 29:12, which states, “Then the book will be given to the one who is illiterate, saying, ‘Read this.’ And he will say, ‘I cannot read.’”

How is the pasuk in Yeshaya meant to be understood and how can one refute this claim?

The claim is that when the verse states

וְנִתַּן הַסֵּפֶר עַל אֲשֶׁר לֹא־יָדַע סֵפֶר לֵאמֹר קְרָא נָא־זֶה וְאָמַר לֹא יָדַעְתִּי סֵפֶר׃

It is referring to Muhammad who was illiterate.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

On a basic p'shat level the Ibn Ezra explains simply:

ונתן וגו'. הטעם לא יבינו זאת הנבואה החכמים המבינים, ואשר אין בינה להם

"And the book is delivered, etc." - Neither the wise men nor those that have no intellect will understand this prophecy.

In other words, it is a closed book that won't be explained by the Novi.

And following on from this, for those who want to say it is referring to Muhammed, we can see from the above that it is something most definitely that he would not be able to comprehend.

Refer to Radak:

ונתן הספר לאשר לא ידע ספר. ואמר לא ידעתי לקרות ספר, ואפילו יהיה פתוח, כי הכסילים שבכם ימצאו עילה אין אנחנו מבינים דברי אלהים אמרו לחכמינו והנה חכמיהם ונביאיהם יטעום הנה כי בין זה ובין זה הספר לא יקרא, כן דברי ה' לא ישמעו ביניכם לא לחכמים ולא לכסילים, ויתכן לפרש חזות הכל שלא יהיה חזות סמוך, ויהיה הכל כמו לכל ופירוש הנבואה היא לכולכם בין לחכמיכם בין לכסיליכם כדברי הספר החתום

“And the book is given to one who does not know how to read…” And he says, “I do not know how to read a book,” even if it is opened — because the fools among you will find an excuse, saying: “We do not understand the words of G-d.” Our sages said this refers to their wise men and prophets, who will err — for whether it is this one or that one, the book will not be read; so too the words of G-d will not be heard among you — neither by the wise nor by the fools. And it is possible to interpret “cḥazus hakkol” (“the entire vision”) as not referring to a connected vision (i.e., not as a specific prophetic revelation), but rather that “kol” (“all”) means “everyone.” And the explanation is: the prophecy is addressed to all of you — to both your wise and your fools — just like a sealed book.

title: How is it possible to say vidui in plural for others?
content:
# How is it possible to say vidui in plural for others? ## Frage

We confess everything in vidui in plural.

Gozalnu

we stole.

How is it possible to include others in our vidui? Doesn’t the person that sinned need to say vidui themselves?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

The Ben Ish Hai shana Aleph, introduction to Ki Tisa writes in the name of the ARIZAL that, since we are all one group, the sins of an individual affect the entire nation of Israel. Adding to this, he writes that even if one has not committed a certain sin delineated in the vidui, he still must say it since what one person does affects all of us. ,

והנה הדבר הזה יפלא: משה בחיר ה' מה עון ומה חטאת יש בידו שהכניס עצמו בכללם באומרו לעוננו ולחטאתנו, ואולם הדבר מובן על פי מה שכתב רבינו האר"י ז"ל בשער הכונות דמלבד מה שנענש האדם על חטאיו, עוד נענש על חבירו מטעם ערבות שכל ישראל הם גוף אחד כלול מאברים רבים, ולכן תקנו אנשי כנסת הגדולה הוידוי בלשון רבים, ולא בלשון יחיד שאינו אומר אשמתי בגדתי וכו', ולא עוד אלא שצריך האדם לומר כל פרטי הודוי אע"פ שיודע בעצמו שאין בו מכל הדברים האלה, ואינו חושש שנראה כמדבר שקר, והיינו טעמא כי הוא יתחייב בעונות של אחרים מצד הערבות יעוין שם, ולכן מובן הדבר הזה שגם משה רבנו עליו השלום שהיה צדיק גמור כלל עצמו עמהם ואמר לעוננו ולחטאתנו מכח הערבות

title: Can one use fresh dish towels during the 9 Days?
content:
# Can one use fresh dish towels during the 9 Days? ## Frage

Can one use fresh dish towels during the 9 Days?

If the restrictions against wearing fresh clothes is for mourning, and not getting happiness or being seen in freshly laundered garments… what about fresh dish towels?

If it's about laundry (AKA Chol Moed) I understand.

If it's about mourning… nobody goes into a kitchen and says "Ahhh!!!! Fresh dish towels! I guess your father didn't mean that much to you, eh?"

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

If dish towels are equivalent to hand towels and table cloths and mats (מטפחות הידים והשלחן) then No. See SAOC 551:3:

During the week in which Tisha B'Av falls, it is forbidden to cut hair or do laundry, even if you don't want to wear the garment now, but rather lease it until after Tisha B'Av, and even if you only have one shirt, it is forbidden. Similarly, previously laundered items, whether for clothing or whether for arranging a bed with them, and even cloths for the hands or the table, are forbidden. [Nevertheless] Our method of laundry is permitted, but the Gihutz (ironing) (Explanation - We pass over the clothes a smooth stone, to smooth it. Aruch) that we do is not. For linen garments, there is no concept of Gihutz, so this is considered "our method of laundry," and permitted. But these words only apply for ironing it and putting it aside until after Tisha B'Av, but it is forbidden to wear it during that week. And the general custom has become to forbid even linen garments, and even with our method of washing, whether to wear [now] or whether to launder and put aside, and one should not be lenient in this matter since this has become the common practice, and even more so since it it possible that it is also forbidden in law, since there are those who who wrote that our method of laundry is call Gihutz of the people of Bavel that does not whiten very well, for their water is soiled, since it is not a land and mountains and valley like to land of Israel, thus it is possible that the method of laundry in other countries is like the laundry of the land of Israel and is prohibited. Furthermore there are those that explain that 'Gihutz' is water and ash or bicarbonate and soap, and laundry means using water only. In these times we never launder with water only, and we find that all laundry in these times is considered Gihutz, and is forbidden by law even for linen garments for wearing them at any time.

Rema Note: We [Ashkenazim] are accustomed to to be strict about all of this from the beginning of 'Rosh Chodesh' until after the fast, if it is not for the need of a Mitzvah, like a woman [at a time in her cycle] where she wears whites, and to arrange [the sheets] under her {to sleep on} (Rokach and the Ohr Zaruah), but on Tisha be-Av itself, she should not wear whites, ratehr she should wear a garment which is clean and nice (notes of the Sha-a-rei Doorah). Similarly for the honour of we wear linen garments and we arrange white [cloths] like on other Shabbatot. It is forbidden to give garments to the a non-jewish launderer from Rosh Chodesh onwards, but before Rosh CHodesh it is permitted to hand them over, even though the laundering will occur after Rosh Chodesh (Tosefot chapter 4 of Ta-anit and Maharil).

סעיף ג

שבוע שחל בו תשעה באב, אסורים לספר ולכבס, אפילו אינו רוצה ללובשו עתה אלא להניחו לאחר ט' באב, ואפילו אין לו אלא חלוק אחד, אסור; וכן המכובסים מקודם, בין ללבוש בין להציע בהם המטה; ואפילו מטפחות הידים והשלחן, אסור. וכיבוס שלנו, מותר; אבל גיהוץ (פירוש מעבירין על הבגדים אבן חלק להחליקו. ערוך) שלנו, אסור. וכלי פשתן, אין בהם משום גיהוץ והרי הם ככיבוס שלנו, ומותר; והני מילי לגוהצן ולהניחן עד אחר תשעה באב, אבל אסור ללבשן בשבוע זה. ונהגו לאסור אפילו כלי פשתן, ואפילו בכבוס שלנו, בין ללבוש בין לכבס ולהניח; ואין להקל בדבר, כיון שנהגו, וכל שכן דאפשר דמדינא נמי אסור, שהרי יש מי שכתב דכיבוס שלנו קרי (גיהוץ) לשל בני בבל שאין מתלבנים יפה, לפי שמימיהם הם עכורים שאינו ארץ הרים וגבעות כארץ ישראל, וכיבוס של שאר ארצות אפשר שהוא ככיבוס של ארץ ישראל ואסור. ועוד יש מי שפירש דגיהוץ היינו מים ואפר או נתר ובורית, וכיבוס היינו במים לבד, ובזמן הזה אין מכבסים במים לבד ונמצא שכל כיבוס של זמן הזה הוי גיהוץ, ואסור מדינא אפילו בכלי פשתן ללבשן מיהא.

הגה: ואנו נוהגין להחמיר בכל זה מתחלת ראש חודש עד אחר התענית, אם לא לצורך מצוה, כגון אשה הלובשת לבנים מותרת לכבס וללבוש לבנים ולהציע תחתיה (רוקח ואור זרוע), אבל בט' באב עצמו לא תלבש לבנים רק לובשת חלוק בדוק ויפה (הגהות שערי דורא). וכן לכבוד שבת לובשים כלי פשתן ומציעין לבנים כמו בשאר שבתות. ואסור ליתן כלים לכובסת אינה יהודי לכבס מראש חודש ואילך, אבל קודם ראש חודש מותר לתת, אף על פי שכובסת אחר ראש חודש (תוספות פ"ד דתענית ומהרי"ל).

title: What species of fish attacked, then was caught by, Tobias?
content:
# What species of fish attacked, then was caught by, Tobias? ## Frage

This is from Tobit 6:1-12; see e. g. the KJV translation. The great fish attacked Tobias while he was washing in the Tigris river, so the natural candidate would be a freshwater shark such as the bull shark, which does occasionally attack swimmers in the river.

The chapter goes on to tell how Tobias and "Azarias" eat the fish after preserving its viscera for therapeutic purposes. So, even arguing that "Azarias" knows best, being actually an angel of the Holy One, it is safe to assume the great fish looked at least kosher. So:

Are sharks and rays (roughly, elasmobranchii) usually considered as having scales for kashrut purposes? Does it matter if the fish is caught in freshwater? Else, to what species is the "great fish" traditionally assigned?

title: What is meant by "I am He" in Isaiah 43:10-13
content:
# What is meant by "I am He" in Isaiah 43:10-13 ## Frage

What does “I am He” mean in Isaiah 43:10-13?

”You are My witnesses," says the Lord, "and My servant whom I chose, in order that you know and believe Me, and understand that I am He; before Me no god was formed and after Me none shall be. I, I am the Lord, and besides Me there is no savior. I told and I saved, and I made heard and there was no stranger among you, and you are My witnesses," says the Lord, "and I am God. Even before the day I am He, and there is no saving from My hand; I do, and who retracts it?"

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Refer to Ibn Ezra who writes:

כי אני הוא. זה הייחוד שאי' למעלה ממנו, כי כל יש איננו הוא בעצמו

I am He. This is the sublimest expression of the unity of G-d; for every other being is different from its real form.

The Metzudos Dovid there adds:

ותבינו כי אני הוא. ממנה שאין מי יודע עתידות כמוני תבינו אשר אני הוא לבד ואין עוד אלהים

"And you will understand that I am He" — from the fact that there is none who knows future events like Me, you will understand that I alone am [G-d], and there is no other deity.

title: How did the high priests enter the holy of holies in the tabernacle if there was no door in the veil?
content:
# How did the high priests enter the holy of holies in the tabernacle if there was no door in the veil? ## Frage

I read somewhere in a commentary that the high priests would go through the veil since there was no door. Please help me understand this.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

There was 1 curtain in the Tabernacle (Mishkan) and it's a Machloket (disagreement) whether there was 1 or 2 curtains in the Bait Hamikdash. He would enter and exit by going in between the curtain and the wall. Since his hands were both full when he entered, the curtain was slightly pinned open sometime beforehand on Yom Kippur so he could enter and exit without using his hands to move the curtain. See footnote 16 on page 51b3 in the Schottenstein Talmud Yoma.

title: Seeking to understand the Bnai Ephraim's calculation
content:
# Seeking to understand the Bnai Ephraim's calculation ## Frage

The Talmud in Sanhedrin 92b indicates that members of the tribe of Ephraim (mis)calculated the end of the Egyptian slavery and attempted to journey to the land of Israel and were slain by the men of Gath (based in part on 1 Chronicles 7:20-22). Rashi ad loc explains that their calculation posited the beginning of the period of slavery to commence from the birth of Yitzhak, based on their reading of Genesis 15:13. I have not seen any other explanations for their calculation.

I am having difficulty understanding this because it seems to omit the subsequent verse, which states:

וְגַם אֶת־הַגּוֹי אֲשֶׁר יַעֲבֹדוּ דָּן אָנֹכִי וְאַחֲרֵי־כֵן יֵצְאוּ בִּרְכֻשׁ גָּדוֹל׃
but I will execute judgment on the nation they shall serve, and in the end they shall go free with great wealth.

Do any commentaries explain how the Bnai Ephraim understood the exile to have reached its conclusion when the Egyptians had not been judged, nor were they set free with great wealth?

title: Why did the angels tell Avraham about Yitzchak being born at the same time S'dom was destroyed?
content:
# Why did the angels tell Avraham about Yitzchak being born at the same time S'dom was destroyed? ## Frage

In bereishis 18-19 we're told the story of three angels coming to Avraham, (healing him) telling him he'll have a son, and then going to destroy S'dom and save Lot. Why did these two events (or three, including Abraham's bris milah) happen at the same time? Do any mefarshim explain why S'dom had to be destroyed now specifically (and not earlier or later)?

(This question asks why the angel who destroyed S'dom needed to visit Avraham, and the answers there give various reasons, but none quite touch on my question)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Rabbi Tzadok HaKohen (Kometz HaMincha 2:42) explains that because Yitzchak represents the attribute of Gevurah (severity) in the realm of holiness, the time of his birth was therefore the appropriate time to destroy Sedom, which represented the attribute of Gevurah in the realm of Kelipah and impurity.

title: Why is Torah study praised only in relation to bumming around and not vis a vis higher pursuits such as productive work/secular study?
content:
# Why is Torah study praised only in relation to bumming around and not vis a vis higher pursuits such as productive work/secular study? ## Frage

Rabbi Neḥunya ben Hakana is reported as praying prior to entering the beit midrash and praising God for his portion upon exiting.

The praise he said afterward is given as follows:

בִּיצִיאָתוֹ מַהוּ אוֹמֵר? מוֹדֶה אֲנִי לְפָנֶיךָ, ה' אֱלֹהַי, שֶׁשַּׂמְתָּ חֶלְקִי מִיּוֹשְׁבֵי בֵּית הַמִּדְרָשׁ וְלֹא שַׂמְתָּ חֶלְקִי מִיּוֹשְׁבֵי קְרָנוֹת, שֶׁאֲנִי מַשְׁכִּים וְהֵם מַשְׁכִּימִים, אֲנִי מַשְׁכִּים לְדִבְרֵי תוֹרָה, וְהֵם מַשְׁכִּימִים לִדְבָרִים בְּטֵלִים; אֲנִי עָמֵל וְהֵם עֲמֵלִים, אֲנִי עָמֵל וּמְקַבֵּל שָׂכָר, וְהֵם עֲמֵלִים וְאֵינָם מְקַבְּלִים שָׂכָר; אֲנִי רָץ וְהֵם רָצִים, אֲנִי רָץ לְחַיֵּי הָעוֹלָם הַבָּא, וְהֵם רָצִים לִבְאֵר שַׁחַת.

Upon his exit, what did he say? I give thanks before You, Lord my God, that You have placed my lot among those who sit in the study hall, and that you have not given me my portion among those who sit idly on street corners. I rise early, and they rise early. I rise early to pursue matters of Torah, and they rise early to pursue frivolous matters. I toil and they toil. I toil and receive a reward, and they toil and do not receive a reward. I run and they run. I run to the life of the World-to-Come and they run to the pit of destruction.

Why does Rabbi Neḥunya ben Hakana contrast Torah study only with idleness and not with other productive pursuits, as if Torah’s merit only shines in contrast to idleness?

That's a pretty low bar to set, and it doesn't make Torah study seem all that praiseworthy.

(This question assumes, per Rav Steinsaltz's translation, that he is contrasting Torah study with idleness.)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Rashi there describes יושבי קרנות as

חנוונים או עמי הארץ שעוסקים בדבר שיחה.

Storeowners or ignorant people who engage in idle conversation.

"Street corners" would thus likely refer to the best location for a storeowner to advertise or to set up shop. Based on that, the idleness is their intellectual pursuits and their conversations, not their livelihoods or their productivity.

title: History of יד/Yad appellation for Rambam's Mishneh Torah
content:
# History of יד/Yad appellation for Rambam's Mishneh Torah ## Frage

Rambam's hugely influential halacha code, named by him Mishneh Torah, connoting a distillation of all Torah law, is divided topically into 14 books, leading to its popular moniker Yad HaChazakah or just plain Yad, as יד is 14 in gematria and this book is Moshe's, in this case Moshe Ben Maimon's, metaphorical strong hand, riffing on the last pasuk in the Torah—וּלְכֹל הַיָּד הַחֲזָקָה וּלְכֹל הַמּוֹרָא הַגָּדוֹל אֲשֶׁר עָשָׂה מֹשֶׁה לְעֵינֵי כׇּל יִשְׂרָאֵל.

I'm curious as to how early this catchy shorthand nickname emerged and how quickly it gained popularity, as it appears to be more widely used than its official name.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

In an article about the Mishneh Torah ("The Classification of the Law in the Mishneh Torah," p. 529, n. 41), Boaz Cohen discusses the historical popularity of the nickname, and traces it as far back as the thirteenth century in the decades after the Rambam died. Regarding the title Yad HaChazakah, he notes:

This title seems to have become common in the sixteenth century. In the Venice (Justiniani) ed., 1550, the Code is termed משנה תורה היא ספר היד, and in the Venice 1574 ed., משנה תורה היא ספר היד החזקה, occurs for the first time. In the Constantinople ed., 1509, the last verse of the Pentateuch ולכל היד החזקה ולכל המורא הגדול אשר עשה משה לעיני כל ישראל decorates the title page in the form of a square. The northern and most conspicuous side of the square contains the words ולכל היד החזקה. Already Joseph ben Todros Halevi, a thirteenth century Spanish scholar, applied this verse to Maimonides when extolling his Code (קבוצת מכתבים, ed. Halberstam, Bamberg, 1875, p. 7). He terms Maimonides the greatest scholar since the time of Rabina and R. Ashi. On the title page of the Venice ed., 1524, is found the well-known saying op ממשה ועד משה לא קם כמשה. According to Prof. Ginzberg, Joseph Caro refers to the Code as היד הגדולה. The phrase יד החזקה, excerpted from the verse applied to Maimonides, became a rival name for the Code it seems, because of its conspicuous display on the title page of some early editions, and the allusion to the fourteen books in the word יד.

....Jesse b. Hezekiah (Exilarch of Damascus) refers to the Mishneh Torah as the Yad ha-Hazakah, היד החזקה אשר קראו משנה תורה, in a letter which he wrote at the end of the thirteenth century, excommunicating all those who are in possession of writings antagonistic to Maimonides.

title: What is the difference between טֶנֶא (tene) and סַל (sal)?
content:
# What is the difference between טֶנֶא (tene) and סַל (sal)? ## Frage

Why is טֶנֶא (tene) used only four times and specifically in Deuteronomy 26 and 28?

Are there any Halachot derived from this?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

According to the Etymological dictionary of the Hebrew Language by Ernest Klein, טֶנֶא is

A loan word from Egyptian dn’ (= basket, metal vessel). For other Egyptian loan words in Hebrew see אָחוּ and words there referred to: הִין, חוֹתָם, טֶנֶא, שֵׁשׁ, possibly also אִי (= island), גֹּמֶא, דְּיוֹ, קֶסֶת. cp. טְנִי.]

The word סַל is rooted in Akkadian,

Prob. a loan word from Akkadian sellū (= basket), whence also Aramaic סַלָּא, סַלְּתָא, whence Arabic sall, salla (= basket). cp. סַלְסִלָּה.

The same is the conclusion of the HALOT dictionary by Koehler and Baumgartner. Therefore, one may conclude that both words are synonymous.

In fact, we have Rashi on Devarim 28:5

ברוך טנאך BLESSED SHALL BE THY BASKET — i.e. thy fruits (which are kept in baskets). — Another explanation of טנאך is that it means liquids which you filter בְּסַלִּים - through baskets (wicker work).

R' Eliyahu Mizrachi adds here:

(the fruit) is called "your basket" because it is gathered in a basket. Alternatively, it means liquids like fresh wine, fresh olive oil, and similar, because they are filtered through the סַלִּ - basket, which is טנא.

Finally, the comment of @Harel13, that it is possible that טנא is related to Aramaic צנא: in the Michael Sokoloff's "Dictionary of Jewish Babylonian Aramaic", צנא refers to a basket made out of palm leaves, maybe related to צנים - thorn, prick Bamidbar 33:55), i.e. it could mean a thinner basket with more flexible walls used for light things or filtering liquids. Likely, such a tzana basket covered with pitch was used for baby Moshe, since a thin wicker work requires less pitch to seal it, which would make it light enough to float on water.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

In addition to @Fred's comment, the Sefer Ḥeshek Shelomoh - Shorashim (ספר חשק שלמה שרשים - פפנהיים), p. 248 by R' Shlomo Pappenheim writes:

"טנא" - שם של מין סל. "וְשַׂמְתָּ֣ בַטֶּ֑נֶא" (דברים כו, ב), "בָּר֥וּךְ טַנְאֲךָ֖ וּמִשְׁאַרְתֶּֽךָ׃" (דברים כח, ה) והוא מין סל המיוחד להניח בו פירות, עשוי מנצרים קלועים מלא נקבים ואוִירים שלא יתקלקלו הפירות. ומלשון "טנא" שם "אטון". "חֲ֝טֻב֗וֹת אֵט֥וּן מִצְרָֽיִם" (משלי ז, טז) והוא בגד צמר ופשתן עשוי מעשה מחט נקבים נקבים, כמעשה הטנא. ולפי שהמצרים אומנים ובקיים ביותר בזות המלכה נקרא "אטון מצרים".

"טנא"/ "Tene" - the name of a type of basket. "And you shall put it in a basket" (Deuteronomy 26:2), "Blessed is your basket and your remnant" (Deuteronomy 28:5) and it is a type of basket specially designed for placing fruit in, made of woven twigs full of holes and openings so that the fruit will not spoil. And from the word "טנא" comes the name "אטון" / "eitoun" - dyed Egyptian linen. "sheets of the eitoun /dyed linen from Egypt" (Proverbs 7:16) and it is a wool and linen fabric made with needlework, similar to the wicker work of the tene. Since the Egyptians were skilled and highly understanding makers, it is called the "eitoun of Egypt".

title: terumat yadchem, bikurim and terumah
content:
# terumat yadchem, bikurim and terumah ## Frage

Why does the rabbinic tradition understand the "offering of your hand" (terumat yadchem) as Bikurim (first fruits) and not as the ordinary Terumah for the priests? Deuteronomy 12:6

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

It's worth considering the context (Devarim 12:5-7):

כִּ֠י אִֽם־אֶל־הַמָּק֞וֹם אֲשֶׁר־יִבְחַ֨ר יְהֹוָ֤ה אֱלֹֽהֵיכֶם֙ מִכׇּל־שִׁבְטֵיכֶ֔ם לָשׂ֥וּם אֶת־שְׁמ֖וֹ שָׁ֑ם לְשִׁכְנ֥וֹ תִדְרְשׁ֖וּ וּבָ֥אתָ שָּֽׁמָּה׃ וַהֲבֵאתֶ֣ם שָׁ֗מָּה עֹלֹֽתֵיכֶם֙ וְזִבְחֵיכֶ֔ם וְאֵת֙ מַעְשְׂרֹ֣תֵיכֶ֔ם וְאֵ֖ת תְּרוּמַ֣ת יֶדְכֶ֑ם וְנִדְרֵיכֶם֙ וְנִדְבֹ֣תֵיכֶ֔ם וּבְכֹרֹ֥ת בְּקַרְכֶ֖ם וְצֹאנְכֶֽם׃ וַאֲכַלְתֶּם־שָׁ֗ם לִפְנֵי֙ יְהֹוָ֣ה אֱלֹֽהֵיכֶ֔ם וּשְׂמַחְתֶּ֗ם בְּכֹל֙ מִשְׁלַ֣ח יֶדְכֶ֔ם אַתֶּ֖ם וּבָתֵּיכֶ֑ם אֲשֶׁ֥ר בֵּֽרַכְךָ֖ יְהֹוָ֥ה אֱלֹהֶֽיךָ׃

But to the place which the Lord your God shall choose out of all your tribes to put his name there, there shall you seek him, at his dwelling, and there shalt thou come: and there you shall bring your burnt offerings, and your sacrifices, and your tithes, and the offerings of your hand, and your vows, and your freewill offerings, and the firstlings of your herds and your flocks: and there you shall eat before the Lord your God, and you shall rejoice in all that to which you put your hand, you and your households, wherein the Lord thy God has blessed thee.

As Malbim points out, the verses are discussing things which are only eaten in Jerusalem. Therefore תרומת ידכם cannot be talking about regular terumah, which we know can be eaten anywhere, but instead bikkurim.

(The technical way in which we get to the understanding of bikkurim from these words is via gezeirah shavah, as can be seen in Sifrei.)

title: Is Samson referred to/mentioned in the siddur/liturgy?
content:
# Is Samson referred to/mentioned in the siddur/liturgy? ## Frage

Is Samson expressly or implicitly mentioned in the siddur? This includes festive piyutim etc.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 17)

Hatarat Nedarim - Before Rosh Hashanah, many communities perform a ceremony to annul personal vows. The printed text includes a clause that also annuls Nazirite vows. Since a Nazirite vow like that of Samson cannot be revoked by a court, the formula explicitly mentions it: "all types of Nazirite vows that I have taken upon myself - even a Nazirite vow like that of Samson (נזירות שמשון)"

Hoshanot for Hoshana Rabbah - A processional piyyut for Hoshana Rabbah recalls miracles where God provided water; one verse states: "For the sake of the solitary one who struck his oppressors, who was consecrated as a Nazirite from the womb; from a mortar cavity in the donkey's jawbone you brought forth water for him; for the sake of your holy name, save us"; commentators explain that the "solitary one" is Samson—he fought alone against the Philistines, was consecrated as a Nazirite before birth, and God made water flow for him from the hollow of a donkey's jawbone; this piyyut is recited in Ashkenazi machzorim on Hoshana Rabbah and also appears in some Sephardic versions.

Abet Sevel - Some North African and Near Eastern communities sing a Piyut about Samson called "Abet Sevel" ("See the Suffering [of Samson]") as part of the Shabbat or holiday liturgy. The poem, written by R. Yitzchak Mazuz, asks God to "consider the suffering of the son of Manoah," reminds Him that Samson was designated as a Nazirite from birth and defeated the Philistines, describes his blindness and downfall – "From my mother's womb you have chosen me... hear, for a Nazirite pours out his soul to you." This Piyut is not universal, but it shows that Samson appears in local Piyutim.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

The Bedtime Sh'ma Prayer for both nuschaos Ashkenaz and Sefard has the verse Bereshis 49:18

לִישׁוּעָֽתְךָ֖ קִוִּ֥יתִי יְהֹוָֽה׃

I wait for Your deliverance, O Hashem!

One recites this verse 3 times as a rotation by moving the name of Hashem:

:לִישׁוּעָתְךָ קִוִּיתִי יְהֹוָה: קִוִּיתִי יְהֹוָה לִישׁוּעָתְךָ: יְהֹוָה לִישׁוּעָתְךָ קִוִּיתִי

It also a part of the full Tefilas haDerech (the Travelers' Prayer). During Bris Milla the mohel also says this verse after placing the baby on the Chair of Eliyahu without the above repetition. It also occurs in selichos and other places.

Rashi on this verse comments based on Bereshis Rabba 98:14:

HOPE FOR THY AID, O ETERNAL — He prophesied that the Philistines would put out his (Samson’s) eyes, and that he would have to say (Judges 16:28) “Remember me, I pray Thee, and strengthen me, I pray Thee, only this once etc.”

title: Why is reward & punishment a necessary component of religion?
content:
# Why is reward & punishment a necessary component of religion? ## Frage

Several Rishonim include s'char v’onesh (reward and punishment) as a core principle of faith.

Rambam includes it explicitly in Principle #11 of his 13 Ikkarim, but in truth, Principles 10-13 (divine knowledge, reward/punishment, coming of Mashiach, and resurrection) are all manifestations of recompense.

Tashbetz (R. Shimon ben Tzemach Duran) includes it as one of three foundational beliefs in Magen Avos (Intro), ditto for R. Yosef Albo in Sefer HaIkkarim (1:3–4).

Even if s'char v'onesh is important practically or pedagogically, why is it treated as a theological essential to the definition of religion?

Shouldn’t belief in God and His Revelation suffice, regardless of consequences?

To the contrary, the ideal is: "Do not be like servants who serve the master in the expectation of receiving a reward, but be like servants who serve the master without the expectation of receiving a reward" (Avos 1:3).

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

In classical Jewish thought the idea of sʹchar va‑onesh is not added simply to “motivate” people; it is part of the very definition of divine law. Several reasons given by the medieval authorities show why a religion that believes in revelation must also believe that Hashem rewards and punishes human actions.

Torah itself links behaviour to consequence

Reward–punishment expresses divine justice and providence

Without reward and punishment there is no meaningful free will

Reward and punishment as a natural outgrowth of the deed

Belief in reward and punishment is treated as an essential principle not because Judaism wants people to act only for ulterior motives but because it reflects the Torah’s view of a just, providential Hashem. The Tanach repeatedly links obedience to consequences, and medieval philosophers such as Rambam and Albo saw recompense as a necessary corollary of Hashem’s knowledge and revelation. While the Mishnah exhorts us to serve Hashem without making reward our motive, it does not deny that reward and punishment exist; rather, it urges us to internalise the intrinsic value of mitzvot.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

To understand why reward and punishment are fundamental to Judaism, we should consider Lawrence Cohlberg's stages of moral development.

As we observe, reward and punishment are fundamental moral principles that underpin how any society operates. This serves as the foundational level of any educational system, typically linked to preschool, and it represents the lowest common moral denominator among all intelligent members of society.

Since the Torah, as the foundational text in Judaism, conveys a moral message that even children can easily understand (as in Lev 26.3 "If you follow My laws and faithfully observe My commandments..."), we can conclude that it communicates on this level. In fact, throughout the book, God threatens to severely punish wrongdoers and promises incredible rewards for obedience, as it states (Ex 20.5),

"For I YHWH, your God, am an impassioned God, visiting the guilt of the parents upon the children, upon the third and upon the fourth generations of those who reject Me, but showing kindness to the thousandth generation of those who love Me and keep My commandments.".

In Jewish moral thought, this level is called "Fear" (יראה). However, this is not the only level of Biblical morality, but it is undoubtedly the most prominent one and the one everyone agrees on.

Note, "higher" levels of understanding divine morality, that can be found in the books of the Prophets and later Rabbinic thought, do NOT nullify Pre-Conventional morality but merely build on it. Rabbis who attained the "highest" levels of Post-Conventional morality (aka "Fear out of Love" - "יראה מאהבה", acc. to the Lureanic tradition) would agree that reward and punishment exist as fundamental ways of God's providence, it is just that they are not motivated by them.

The Mishna you quoted, "Do not be like servants who serve the master in the expectation of receiving a reward, but be like servants who serve the master without the expectation of receiving a reward" (Avos 1:3), is a good example of Post-Conventional morality one is prescribed to achieve. But which, nevertheless, is not attainable by a significant portion of the population - children and dull/feebleminded individuals.

As such, you are completely right, assuming that subscription to Pre-Conventional moral principles would be inapplicable to individuals who deeply associate with Post-Conventional ideals.

title: Are the “sons of the stranger” in Isaiah 56:6-7 circumcised?
content:
# Are the “sons of the stranger” in Isaiah 56:6-7 circumcised? ## Frage

Genesis 17:13:

He that is born in thy house, and he that is bought with thy money, must needs be circumcised: and my covenant shall be in your flesh for an everlasting covenant.

Isaiah 56:6-7:

Also the sons of the stranger, that join themselves to the LORD, to serve him, and to love the name of the LORD, to be his servants, every one that keepeth the sabbath from polluting it, and taketh hold of my covenant;

Even them will I bring to my holy mountain, and make them joyful in my house of prayer: their burnt offerings and their sacrifices shall be accepted upon mine altar; for mine house shall be called an house of prayer for all people.

The “sons of the stranger” who serve the Lord are said to take hold of the covenant. Does that mean they are circumcised? Or are they saved by just obeying the rules of sojourners, and not those of the children of Israel?

I think that anyone who served God, even a non-Jew, must have been circumcised. Otherwise, would he be regarded as part of the covenant? But I am not sure if this is correct.

NEW ---------------------------------------------------------------- Other places in the scripture taken in consideration.

Numbers 15:14 And if a stranger sojourn with you, or whosoever be among you in your generations, and will offer an offering made by fire, of a sweet savor unto the LORD; as ye do, so he shall do.

(The stranger can do sacrafices to the Lord - does this mean that he is circumcised? Or uncircumcised stranger could do that? Having in mind Exodus 12:48)

Leviticus 17:8-9 8 And thou shalt say unto them, Whatsoever man there be of the house of Israel, or of the strangers which sojourn among you, that offereth a burnt offering or sacrifice, 9 And bringeth it not unto the door of the tabernacle of the congregation, to offer it unto the LORD; even that man shall be cut off from among his people.

Leviticus 22:18 Speak unto Aaron, and to his sons, and unto all the children of Israel, and say unto them, Whatsoever he be of the house of Israel, or of the strangers in Israel, that will offer his oblation for all his vows, and for all his freewill offerings, which they will offer unto the LORD for a burnt offering;

Exodus 12:48 And when a stranger shall sojourn with thee, and will keep the passover to the LORD, let all his males be circumcised, and then let him come near and keep it; and he shall be as one that is born in the land: for no uncircumcised person shall eat thereof.

Numbers 15:13-16 13 All that are born of the country shall do these things after this manner, in offering an offering made by fire, of a sweet savor unto the LORD. 14 And if a stranger sojourn with you, or whosoever be among you in your generations, and will offer an offering made by fire, of a sweet savor unto the LORD; as ye do, so he shall do. 15 One ordinance shall be both for you of the congregation, and also for the stranger that sojourneth with you, an ordinance for ever in your generations: as ye are, so shall the stranger be before the LORD. 16 One law and one manner shall be for you, and for the stranger that sojourneth with you.

Numbers 15:22-31 22 And if ye have erred, and not observed all these commandments, which the LORD hath spoken unto Moses, 23 Even all that the LORD hath commanded you by the hand of Moses, from the day that the LORD commanded Moses, and henceforward among your generations; 24 Then it shall be, if ought be committed by ignorance without the knowledge of the congregation, that all the congregation shall offer one young bullock for a burnt offering, for a sweet savor unto the LORD, with his meat offering, and his drink offering, according to the manner, and one kid of the goats for a sin offering. 25 And the priest shall make an atonement for all the congregation of the children of Israel, and it shall be forgiven them; for it is ignorance: and they shall bring their offering, a sacrifice made by fire unto the LORD, and their sin offering before the LORD, for their ignorance: 26 And it shall be forgiven all the congregation of the children of Israel, and the stranger that sojourneth among them; seeing all the people were in ignorance. 27 And if any soul sin through ignorance, then he shall bring a she goat of the first year for a sin offering. 28 And the priest shall make an atonement for the soul that sinneth ignorantly, when he sinneth by ignorance before the LORD, to make an atonement for him; and it shall be forgiven him. 29 Ye shall have one law for him that sinneth through ignorance, both for him that is born among the children of Israel, and for the stranger that sojourneth among them. 30 But the soul that doeth ought presumptuously, whether he be born in the land, or a stranger, the same reproacheth the LORD; and that soul shall be cut off from among his people. 31 Because he hath despised the word of the LORD, and hath broken his commandment, that soul shall utterly be cut off; his iniquity shall be upon him.

(Does this mean that uncircumcised stranger could be forgiven sins? Or is this a stranger that has converted to a Jew - but if this is the case why is it said stranger and not only children of Israel?)

This verses are from KJV, it was easier to copy and paste.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Your assumption that this verse is talking about non-Jewish servants of G-d is incorrect - the Abarbanel here says that the "sons of the stranger" are, in fact, converted Jews (and therefore circumcized on that basis):

אמר כנגד הגרים ובני הנכר הנלוים על ה' לשרתו, רוצה לומר שבני הנכר המתגיירים לא לתכלית כבוד ומעלה כ"א לחסות תחת כנפי השכינה לשרת את השם ולאהבה את שמו להיות לו לעבדים במקום שהיו בגיותם אדוני הארץ, ויעשה לסימן זה שמירת שבת כוללת את האמונות ובשאר המצות יהיו מחזיקים בבריתו ותורתו, הנה יהיה שכרם ראשונה שאתן להם חלק בנחלת הארץ

He said opposite the converts and "the sons of the stranger who are joined to G-d to server Him" - that is to say, the "sons of the stranger" that convert, not for the purpose of honor or stature but rather to take refuge underneath the wings of the Shechinah, to serve Hashem and to love His Name, to be His servants instead of the lords of the land they were when they were not Jewish. As a sign of this type observe the Shabbos, which is inclusive of all faith, and in all other mitzvos they strengthen themselves in His covenant and Torah. Their reward will be first when I give them a portion of inheritance of the Land.

title: Rav Yosef Leib Bloch: "leftover ink" and Torah-lessons in each mitzvah
content:
# Rav Yosef Leib Bloch: "leftover ink" and Torah-lessons in each mitzvah ## Frage

Rabbi Immanuel Bernstein in the book "The Call Of Sinai" (p. 75) quotes from Shiurei Daas (Chomer V'tzurah) from Rav Yosef Leib Bloch, the Rosh Yeshivah of Telz. He begins by citing a Midrash Rabbah (Shemos Rabbah 47:6):

Rabbi Yehuda bar Naḥman says in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish: While he was writing with a quill, a bit [of ink] remained. He passed [the quill] over his head and from it the rays of splendor were formed for him, as it is stated: “Moses did not know that the skin of his face was radiant [upon His speaking with him].”

Rav Bloch seems to explain that every mitzvah in the Torah contains lessons for how to live life, and there are many situations beyond the actual setting of that mitzvah where those lessons can be applied.

The more a person has absorbed the message of the mitzvah into his being, the more he will be able to aplly the Torah's lessons to life's various situations.

I tried looking for the original text from Rav Bloch, but could not find this exact text. Does anyone know what he exactly says and where? Also, what does the "leftover ink" has to do with this?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

In Chomer V’Tzurah Rav Bloch reads these Midrashic images as symbols for the two components of every area of Torah and mitzvah – the material (chomer) and the form (tzurah): https://beta.hebrewbooks.org/pagefeed/hebrewbooks_org_39046_11.pdf

Transmitted vs. inexpressible Torah: Rav Bloch stresses that when a sage teaches, he can only express the “material” of the wisdom. The “form” – the inner soul of the idea – cannot be conveyed fully in words. Because of his desire to share it, the wisdom “bursts forth through his entire being” and is conveyed through his facial expressions and movements. Only a student who remains close to his teacher, hears his words and “sees his face,” can absorb this spiritual dimension. This is why the students of R. Meir said they attained the Torah not from the explanations themselves but from seeing his appearance or even his finger. https://beta.hebrewbooks.org/pagefeed/hebrewbooks_org_39046_10.pdf

Three parts of Torah: Rav Bloch applies this distinction to the Midrash. He explains that the Torah has three “parts”: one was in Moshe’s hand – the revealed Torah that can be grasped rationally; a second was in God’s hand – the ultimate secrets that no person can grasp; the middle portion, represented by the two handbreadths in the middle of the tablets, lies between man and God. Human beings cannot fully comprehend it, but Moshe was allowed to “glimpse its radiance”.

Leftover ink and the “form” of Torah: According to Rav Bloch, the second Midrashic opinion (“leftover ink”) teaches that Moshe’s radiance did not come from secrets beyond human reach. Instead it came from “that little bit” of the Torah that remained on his quill after he had written down and transmitted all the teachings. Even after he exhausted himself to teach and clarify the Torah, a “form of the wisdom” remained in his heart that no language could express. He “passed it over his head,” meaning he internalised it, and that inner, unarticulated essence burst forth through his face as a radiant light. Hence the Midrash’s phrase “from it the rays were formed” – the light came naturally from his intense desire to convey the Torah’s inner meaning. https://beta.hebrewbooks.org/pagefeed/hebrewbooks_org_39046_12.pdf

title: What did Chava say to Adam?
content:
# What did Chava say to Adam? ## Frage

Gen. 3:17 explicitly says that Hashem punished Adam "because you listened to the voice of your wife" (ולאדם אמר כי-שמעת לקול אשתך). What did she say? It's not there in the text.

I would have expected a lacuna like this to attract midrashim, but there's hardly anything in Bereishis Rabbah - only a suggestion that "קול" implies weeping; that in fact there were no actual words. That midrash does explain the posuk, but it doesn't seem to be acknowledged by the major commentators, which makes me wonder if I'm missing something.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

The Gra in Aderes Eliyahu on this pasuk says, quite simply, that she told him it was good:

שמעת בקול אשתך שאמרה כי טוב הוא בלי טעם האמנת לה יותר ממני לעבור על מצותי והוא מפני שכרוך אתה אחריה בעבור רוב העונג ולא תחסר לך כל

...You listened to the voice of your wife who said that it was good without any reason because you believed her more than to ignore my commandments, and that's because you're bound up with her because of the abundance of pleasure [you have] and you're lacking nothing...

That doesn't clarify what was good - whether it tasted good, was healthy, or was spiritually or otherwise physically advantageous to eat - but regardless, her comments to Adam were that "it's good" and Adam apparently didn't seek to clarify further and on the basis of those comments he ate.

The Alshich, on the other hand, says even simpler - she outright told him to eat:

שמעת לה באומרה לך שתאכל וז"א כי שמעת לקול אשתך ותאכל על פיה במקום אשר צויתיך לאמר לה לא תאכל ממנו

...You listened to her when she told you to eat and that's what the pasuk means "for you listened to the voice of your wife and you ate 'on her mouth' in the place of my commanding you saying to her don't eat from this...

(Parenthetically, the Ha'emek Davar cites this as a reason why Adam didn't die immediately.)

The Chida in Chomas Anach, however, goes in a completely different direction, interpreting this pasuk not as Chavah having said something in particular but rather as being Adam's fault for not clarifying to Chavah what exactly the parameters of the prohibition were, versus the gedarim he himself added:

אפשר במה שכתבו הרב תורת חיים והרב כלי יקר ז״ל דאדה״ר הזהיר לחוה על הנגיעה לגדר וכך ראוי לעשות גדר ומשמרת למצות ה׳. אך היה לאדה״ר לומר לחוה דהמצוה היא האכילה וצריך לעשות גדר שלא לנגוע. אך אדה״ר אמר סתם דאכילה ונגיעה אסור ובחדא מחתא מחתינהו. וחוה סברה דגם נגיעה היא מצות ה׳ וזה גרם דדחפה הנחש ומזה באה לטעות. ונמצא דאדה״ר הוא היא גרמא דלא פירש הצווי שהוא האכילה לבד ומשום גדר צריך להתרחק מנגיעה. וזהו התוכחה כי שמעת וכו׳ אשר צויתיך לאמר לחוה לא תאכל ממנו ואתה אסרת הנגיעה בסתם וסברה דהנגיעה גם כן ציווי ועי״ז טעתה ואכלה והאכילתו ונמשך זה דלא ביררת הציווי והגדר.

It's possible that which the Toras Chaim and Kli Yakar wrote - that Adam Harishon warned Chavah about touching, as a safeguard - and it was appropriate to create a safeguard around the mitzvos of Hashem. But Adam was supposed to tell Chavah that the mitzvah was eating and he needed to make a safeguard of not touching. Instead, Adam said outright that eating and touching were prohibited and lumped them together. And Chavah understood that touching was also the commandment of Hashem and this caused [the situation] that when the snake pushed her and she came to make a mistake. And so we find that Adam is the cause for why she didn't clarify that the commandment was eating itself and that physical distancing was just a safeguard. And that's the rebuke he received that "You listened to your wife... that I commanded you" to say to Chavah not to eat, but you prohibited touching on its own and she thought that touching was a commandment and therefore erred and ate and fed him and this was because you didn't clarify the commandment and the safeguard.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 3)

She did more than just weep, refer to the Bereishis Rabbah 20:8

וּלְאָדָם אָמַר כִּי שָׁמַעְתָּ לְקוֹל אִשְׁתֶּךָ (בראשית ג, יז), רַבִּי שִׂמְלָאי אוֹמֵר בְּיִשּׁוּב הַדַּעַת בָּאת עָלָיו, אָמְרָה לוֹ, מָה אַתְּ סָבוּר שֶׁאֲנִי מֵתָה וְחַוָּה אַחֶרֶת נִבְרֵאת לָךְ (קהלת א, ט): אֵין כָּל חָדָשׁ תַּחַת הַשָּׁמֶשׁ, מָה אַתְּ סָבוּר שֶׁאֲנִי מֵתָה וְאַתָּה יוֹשֵׁב לְךָ הָטֵלִיס (ישעיה מה, יח): לֹא תֹהוּ בְרָאָהּ לָשֶׁבֶת יְצָרָהּ. רַבָּנָן אָמְרִין הִתְחִילָה מְיַלֶּלֶת עָלָיו בְּקוֹלָהּ הֲדָא הוּא דִכְתִיב: וּלְאָדָם אָמַר כִּי שָׁמַעְתָּ לְדִבְרֵי אִשְׁתֶּךָ, אֵין כְּתִיב כָּאן, אֶלָּא לְקוֹל אִשְׁתֶּךָ וגו'.

“And to Adam He said: Because you heeded your wife’s voice, and ate from the tree that I commanded you, saying: You shall not eat from it, the ground is cursed on your account; in suffering you shall eat of it all the days of your life” (Genesis 3:17). “And to Adam He said: Because you heeded your wife’s voice” – Rabbi Simlai said: She approached him persuasively. She said to him: ‘What do you think, that I will die and another Eve will be created for you? “There is nothing new under the sun” (Ecclesiastes 1:9). What do you think, that I will die and you will sit alone? “He did not create it for emptiness; He formed it to be inhabited”’ (Isaiah 45:18). The Rabbis say: She began sobbing at him with her voice. That is what is written: “And to Adam He said...” “Because you heeded your wife’s words” is not written here, but rather, “your wife’s voice.”

title: Mouthwash allowed on Shabbos before a fast?
content:
# Mouthwash allowed on Shabbos before a fast? ## Frage

Josh finished eating on Shabbos, erev Tisha B'av. Now he would like to rinse with mouthwash before the fast. Is this allowed, or not? Is it considered hachana?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

As long as Josh does not say the words "I am using mouthwash now in preparation of the fast tomorrow" or something to that effect, it would be mutar.

This is the same halacha as eating extra on a Shabbos that is an erev fast, or going to sleep on a Shabbos afternoon that is Erev Shavuos.

See Shmiras Shabbos Kehilchasa 28:77, Ashrei Haish 2:34:17, Piskei Teshuva (New Edition) 290:4, Mishna Berura 290:4

title: Sephardic communities who differentiate between tav with or without a dagesh
content:
# Sephardic communities who differentiate between tav with or without a dagesh ## Frage

This siddur is nusah sephardi/edot hamizrah. On the first page, shown below, the siddur lists all the letters of the hebrew alphabet. I noticed that it lists tav with and without dagesh as different letters, and it does so for pe, kaf, and bet. yet it doesnt do the same for dalet, or gimmel. I know there are some sephardic communities who pronounced tav differently based on if it had a dagesh or not, however those same communities also differentiated between the other bgdkft letters such as dalet or gimmel. Are there any Sephardic communities who historically differentiate between tav with or without a dagesh, but dont do so for dalet or gimmel?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

Greek Jews in general differentiate between ת and תּ, while not differentiating ג and גּ and ד and דּ. Perhaps they did traditionally, but I did not hear it. You can also hear non-differentiation in this recording of the Shema: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1sISJuToH1I

Additionally, Iraqi and Yemenite Jews differentiate ת and תּ, but both also differentiate between ג and גּ, and Yemenite Jews between ד and דּ.

Source: based on personal experience from visiting the Romaniote synagogue in New York, as well as listening to recordings.

However, as DoubleAA stated in the comments, this page may have been taken out of an Ashkenazi siddur and reused.

title: Are you allowed to take a slow release capsule of caffeine on Shabbos to help you fast on Tisha Bav - Sunday or is it hachana for the weekday?
content:
# Are you allowed to take a slow release capsule of caffeine on Shabbos to help you fast on Tisha Bav - Sunday or is it hachana for the weekday? ## Frage

This year Tisha Bav is on Sunday. Can you take capsules with slow release caffeine or Tylenol on Shabbos to help you fast on Sunday? Is that considered Hachana- preparation for during the week?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

According to this article, Hachana is not an issue so long as the reason for taking the capsules is left unstated:

As concerns the prohibition of Hachana – preparing for a weekday on Shabbos – the Poskim explain that it is not an issue in this case. Firstly, the vitamins already begin to be released and affect the body on Shabbos itself. Secondly, it is not self-evident that the action is being performed for the following day. To this end, it is reported in the name of Rav Shlomo Zalman Ullman zt”l that one should not verbally state that he is taking the pills for the purpose of easing his fast.

The more complicated question is whether it falls under the prohibition against taking non-essential medication on Shabbos. See the rest of the article for discussion of that issue.

title: Actual goring ox?
content:
# Actual goring ox? ## Frage

Is there an instance where the Talmud expressly records an actual instance of a goring ox having been stoned after being found guilty of killing a man?

The closest I can find is Eduyot 6:1 where R Yehuda testifies:

שֶׁנִּסְקַל תַּרְנְגוֹל בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם עַל שֶׁהָרַג אֶת הַנֶּפֶשׁ.

This cannot be the only instance. Are there others from Baba Qamma or elsewhere?

You may be interested to know that this practice caught on in Medieval Europe, explicitly citing Exodus 21 for authority. Testimonies from the Talmud may be the oldest record of this practice.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The lone example of an animal being stoned occurs not with an ox but with a rooster. Rabbi Yehudah b. Bava testified that a rooster in Jerusalem killed a person, “and it was stoned to death in Jerusalem for killing a person, to teach that the Torah’s law of stoning an ox that killed a person applies to other animals as well” https://www.sefaria.org/Niddah.8a.7. The Gemara explicitly notes that this anecdote was preserved to show the scope of the law rather than to record a typical case https://www.sefaria.org/Niddah.8a.7. No parallel story of an ox (or any other larger domestic animal) being tried and executed appears in the Bavli or Yerushalmi.

The only other Talmudic case in which an animal that harmed a human is killed is an incident involving a cat. When three sages were waiting outside Rav’s house, “a cat came and severed the hand of a child.” Rav emerged and ruled that “a cat may be killed and it is forbidden to keep it; one has no obligation to return such an animal to its owner” https://he.wikisource.org/wiki/%D7%91%D7%91%D7%9C%D7%99_%D7%91%D7%91%D7%90_%D7%A7%D7%9E%D7%90_%D7%A4%D7%A8%D7%A7_%D7%96#:~:text=%D7%A9%D7%9E%D7%95%D7%90%D7%9C%20%D7%9C%D7%90%20%D7%A2%D7%99%D7%99%D7%9C,%D7%91%D7%A2%D7%99%D7%90%20%D7%9C%D7%99%D7%94%20%D7%A8%D7%91%D7%99%D7%A0%D7%90. The passage allows killing a dangerous cat but says nothing about convening a court or stoning the animal.
