title: Why did Lot offer his daughters to the men of Sodom?
content:
# Why did Lot offer his daughters to the men of Sodom? ## Frage

Why did Lot offer his daughters to the men of Sodom?

I’ve been told it was to protect his guests, but this is a vile act.

How did the Sages view him?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

There is no doubt that Lot's offer to hand over his daughters was wrong and forbidden; if a Beit Din (court) were to judge, it would find Lot guilty of committing a grave sin (or at least the intention to do so); although Lot was in some ways a learning student of Avraham (in the commandment of hospitality), he failed in the fundamental moral hierarchy; Halacha and ethics unanimously demand: no person may fulfill their duty at the expense of another; should such a tragic situation arise, one must remain passive or bear the consequences oneself, but not sacrifice innocents.

The scholars remind us that the Torah tells us such disturbing stories "ללמד ולא לעשׂות" – to learn from them, not to imitate them; in Lot's case, we learn the limits of hospitality, the seductive power of a bad society, and the necessity to remain true to one's conscience under pressure; and we learn that even from the greatest mistakes – in God's hidden plan – sparks of redemption can eventually emerge (Moab → Ruth, Ammon → Na’ama); yet this does not diminish personal responsibility: from a Jewish perspective, Lot's actions remain wrong; no Posek would decide otherwise; a father must never give up his children – and indeed, no one may do wrong so that supposed good may result; this is the binding judgment of our Torah and tradition on this matter.

title: How to know if a dagesh is hazak or qal
content:
# How to know if a dagesh is hazak or qal ## Frage

When a begedkefet letter has a dagesh, how can one know if its a dagesh hazaq or qal?

For example, how can I tell whether the word שַבָּת is pronounced “shabbat” or “shabat”?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

There are rules for this, which I will let others more learned than me point you to references for.

But if you want to "cheat" ...

For Biblical words, you can consult an edition making this difference visible, such as the core text of the Al-Hatorah Mikraot Gedolot.

For prayer words, similarly, there are some siddurim that make this difference visible.

Paper publishers who distinguish dagesh ḥazaq from dagesh qal in at least some of their books include the following:

  • פלדהיים (Feldheim)
  • מנהגי אבות (Minhagei Avot)
  • מכון הרב מצליח (The Rav Matzliach Institute)
  • למען שמו באהבה (Lema·an Shemo Be·ahavah)

BTW based on my proposal, this week the Unicode Technical Committee (UTC) agreed to provisionally assign U+05C9 to HEBREW POINT HEAVY DAGESH. Not a good name in my opinion, but a good step forward in Unicode support for publishing pointed Hebrew.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

Edits in progress

A dagesh qal occurs whenever a בגדכפ״ת letter does not immediately follow a vowel. This includes two situations:

  1. The letter is after a consonant. For example, מִדְבָּר where the ב is preceded by ד, and עַל־פְּנֵי where the פ is preceded by ל.
  2. The letter is at the beginning of a word, and the previous word ends in a vowel, but is also at a grammatical pause (indicated by disjunctive trope). This grammatical pause separates the vowel from the start of the next word, so if the next word starts in a בגדכפ״ת letter, it takes a dagesh qal. For example, אֶת־אָזְנוֹ בַּמַּרְצֵעַ, where the בּ follows a Cholam, but the phrase את אזנו ends the previous phrase (as indicated by the פשטא trope on אזנו).

Ten verses¹ have a word starting with a בגדכפ״ת letter that takes a dagesh qal, even though it should apparently be rafe. They are listed several Masoretic works. They cannot be predicted, and must simply be memorized.

A dagesh ħazaq, on the other hand, indicates gemination. There are several types of Gemination in Chumash Hebrew:

  1. Semantic. Some words and affixes are geminated inherently, where affects their meaning. This gemination has the same function as letters and vowels, and is just as important.
  2. Inflectional. Some grammatical inflections, like pi‘el, involve gemination.
  3. De-ambiguative. A letter of a certain word can sometimes be geminated in order to differentiate it from a homophone.
  4. Fortative. A letter can be geminated to preserve it, since it’s prone to being elided.
  5. Compensatory. When a long is shortened due to historical sound changes, the following consonant might be geminated to preserve the word’s prosody.

3 and 4 didn’t develop naturally; they were added by the Masoretes reading hyper-deliberately, with extra emphasis on parts that were ambiguous or prone to elision. Therefore, they are not prone to Hebrew phonotactics, and there’s no way to predict them with certainty. Still, you can tell that they’re a dagesh ħazaq, because they aren’t in the [list of exceptional dageshīm qalīm] (mentioned above).

On the other hand, 1, 2, and 5 did develop naturally, and therefore must obey Hebrew phonotactics, which dictate that gemination can only occur on letters between vowels. This means it can’t occur after a consonant, and it can’t occur at the beginning of a clause.

There’s a reason why I just wrote “clause” instead of “word”: There is a category of cases, called דְּחִיק and אֲתֵי מֵרֲחִיק, where a dagesh ħazaq can come at the beginning of a word. Basically, under complex conditions, a word that ends in a vowel can cause a dagesh ħazaq in the first letter of the following word, which is otherwise impossible.

However, this can only occur when the first word is grammatically connected to the next word, with a conjunctive trope. This conjunction connects the vowel to the first letter of the next word, thereby causing that letter to be between two vowels. This makes a dagesh ħazaq possible.

So be sure to remember about דְּחִיק when dealing with a word-initial Dagesh.

This gives us a convenient rule: If the letter with dagesh is between two vowels, it’s a dagesh ħazaq. If it’s not between two vowels, it’s a dagesh qal.

So, using your example, the ב in שַׁבָּת is between two vowels—a preceding Patach a following Kamatz. Therefore, it must be a dagesh ħazaq, and can’t possibly be a dagesh qal.

Conversely, the Dagesh in בְּרֵאשִׁית comes at the beginning of a word (and isn’t subject to conditions that cause דְּחִיק). Therefore, it must be a dagesh qal, and can’t possibly be a dagesh ħazaq.

Remember about Fortative and De-Ambiguative dagesh ħazaq, and memorize the short list of words with an exceptional dagesh qal. Otherwise, this rule always works.

¹The list is as follows: שמות ט״ו א (גָּאָה), י״א (כָּמוֹךָ), י״ג (גָּאַלְתָּ), ט״ו (כָּאָבֶן), כ״א (גָּאָה), [ישעיהו][יש׳] (כַּדְכֹּד), [ירמיהו][יר׳] (כַּלכֹּל), [דִּתְבֵריָא][ב], [דִּתְבֵריָא][ג], [כְּחֻכְמַת][ב].

title: Why isn't Jordan included in the borders of Eretz Yisrael?
content:
# Why isn't Jordan included in the borders of Eretz Yisrael? ## Frage

In the borders of Eretz Yisrael listed in Bamidbar 34, the eastern border goes from the Kinneret in the north through the Jordan to the dead sea in the south. Rashi (34:2) says that the borders are listed in order to teach where the מצוות התלויות בארץ are applicable.

From what I understand, the East side of the Jordan river (עבר הירדן המזרחי), which was where Reuven, Gad and half of Menasheh settled, was also considered Eretz Yisrael and obligated in those mitzvos during the first Beis Hamikdash. It only lost its kedusha after the churban, and during the second Beis Hamikdash, when that land wasn't under Jewish control, (and therefore wasn't considered as part of the land of עולי בבל), didn't gain the kedushah back.

Based on this, shouldn't the borders of Eretz Yisrael include the east side of the Jordan, at least according to Rashi's understanding of why the borders are listed? An I wrong in my understanding that these mitzvos were applicable there as well?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

For Transjordan, the rule remains: "לא יבואו עולי בבל ויקדשו" – without a new "Olej Bavel" event (i.e., a settlement supported by Torah authority), it remains unholy; only with the occurrence of the scenarios described in Isaiah 11 and Zechariah 14 will we no longer distinguish Jordan from Eretz Yisrael on a spiritual level.

Jordan currently does not belong to the biblically defined borders of Eretz Yisrael because the Torah only delineated the permanent core area where holiness never completely extinguishes; the East Jordan land had a temporary Kedusha and Mitzvah obligations (during the time of the First Temple) but lost them due to the lack of Kiddushat Sheniya; therefore, it is excluded in Bamidbar 34 – according to Rashi – from the borders that mark the validity of the commandments; halachically, the commandments do not currently apply there until a future re-sanctification occurs; once that happens – whether through the Mashiach or renewed Jewish settlement with the Sanhedrin – עבר הירדן will also be considered a full-fledged Eretz Yisrael and enjoy all the associated Mitzvot and blessings, כפי ה’ ביד נביאיו.

title: Usage of non-Jewish segulot (charms)
content:
# Usage of non-Jewish segulot (charms) ## Frage

For a side research project I've recently started going through manuscript collections of segulot and amulets (קמעות in Hebrew). I've been struck by many surprising and fascinating details in the various types of segulot (little understanding as I have of the deeper spiritual intricacies behind each detail). One particularly eye-catching detail is the obvious usage in some cases of non-Hebraic or non-Aramaic words. Sometimes they have undergone some form of semiticization, as in writing them in Hebrew characters. But there have been some cases - albeit more rarely - whereby actual Latin characters were used in passages. Perhaps the most shocking example that I came across earlier this week was the following, from the 17th century MS Kaufmann A 247, p. 76:

"beronix לעצור הדם כתוב במצחו השם הכתוב למטה אם הוא איש בירוניס ולנצרים
beronisa ואם היא אשה כתוב בירוניסה ולנצרים"

A quick search online revealed that the word "beronix" was in fact used in certain types of European Christian charms (the non-Jewish equivalent of segulot) for staunching blood (see e.g. here and here).

What's unusual about this case - unlike (perhaps?) most other cases of usages of non-Hebrew words - is that the author seems to have some awareness that he is describing a segulah of non-Jewish origins, by using a clearly non-Hebrew word (the Latin characters are right there in the manuscript) and prescribing the segulah to both Jews and non-Jews.

I should mention that - though I don't know who the scribe is1 - where he could, he did explicitly cite his sources - some segulot were copied from other manuscripts or books ("ספר קדמון אחר", "ספר כנפי יונה חלק שני", etc), and many were attributed to a great number of rabbis, including Ramban, Rabbi Yosef Gikatilla, Rabbi Menachem Chazan of Londres (London), the Ari, Rabbi Yehudah Ha'Chassid, and many others. This one was not attributed to anyone. Perhaps this scribe was not a great talmid chacham and simply copied what came into his possession, but there's no real way to know (the few personal details he mentions have to do with his interactions with other Jews from around the world who informed him of tried-and-tested segulot which he was happy to pass on).

This brings me to my question: Is there any problem with using segulot of non-Jewish origins that don't seem to have any explicit problematic content, such as Christian figures and the like? Or to put it another way, if we assume that the scribe was not a total ignoramus in terms of halacha, what might have possessed him to feel comfortable with sharing this segulah? Or perhaps this is a wrong assumption, and what the scribe did was indeed problematic?

1 On p. 181 appears simply the name משה דאנאטא בן חנה. This may be the scribe's name, or it may be the name of a previous owner of the manuscript. Or it may have been another person's name written there for other purposes.

title: How far beyond halacha is observance allowed to go?
content:
# How far beyond halacha is observance allowed to go? ## Frage

Some Jews choose to do more than halacha requires. They fast more, take vows, observe kashrut and Shabbat more stringently than necessary, dress more modestly than required, etc. (You may have seen the Chumrah of the Week Club joke.) However, excess stringencies are frequently discouraged by the rabbis ("A Nazirite is a sinner" [Taanit 11a]). The Jerusalem Talmud asks rhetorically:

Hasn’t the Torah forbidden enough that you want to add more prohibitions?! [Nedarim Y 9:1)

My question is: Does halacha actually prohibit specific excesses even though they don't violate the Torah? Which?

title: Eisav and Yaakov grabbing months
content:
# Eisav and Yaakov grabbing months ## Frage

There’s that famous midrash/Zohar that Yaakov took Nissan, Iyar, and Sivan as his months, making them months of miracles and good, while Eisav took Tamuz, Av, and Elul as his months, making them months of bad; but eventually Yaakov took back Elul.

What is this midrash implying about the other months? Are they neither good nor bad?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

The statement is found in Zohar Yisro 13:241. However, R. Elazar Rokeach of Amsterdam, Nethelands, (do not confuse him with the rishon R' Eleazar Rokeach of Worms, Germany), found the words of Zohar cryptic, so he gave the following drasha Maaseh Rokeach on Mishna Taanis 4:6 about it:

בפרק ד' (משנה תענית ד:ו) "חמשה דברים אירעו את אבותינו בשבעה עשר בתמוז וחמשה בתשעה באב". להבין לך למה באלו החדשים גברה כח של ס"א לעשות כל אלו המעשים להחריב את בית מקדשינו ועיר הקודש ושארי דברים, בהקדים דברי הזוהר פרשת יתרו בפסוק "בחדש השלישי" וזה לשונו (זהר חלק ב עח, ב): "יעקב נטיל ברזא דיליה תרין ירחין - ניסן ואייר, ואתכליל איהו ברזא דסיון דאיהו תאומים. עשו נטיל ברזא דיליה תרין ירחין - תמוז אב וכו' דהא אלול אתאביד מיניה".

In the Mishna Ta'anis 4:6 we learn: "Five calamitous matters occurred to our forefathers on the seventeenth of Tammuz, and five other disasters happened on the Ninth of Av." To understand why in these months strengthened the power of Sitra Achara (impurity), to do all these acts, to burn our Beis haMikdash (Temple) and the Holy City and other things. We start with the words of Zohar Yisro 13:241, parashas Yisro on the verse Shemos 19:1 "On the third new month":

Yaakov took for himself a period of 2 months - Nisan and Iyar. And it includes the portion of Sivan which has the Zodiacal sign of Twins, meaning that it was intended for both brothers. Eisav took for himself two months Tamuz and Av, and it was not forgotten. However, since Eisav abandoned the way of mitzvos, Elul does not belong to him. Even in Av, Eisav has only nine days and not more. And since Eisav abandoned the way of mitzvos, it was not forgotten, so that the month of Sivan, the portion of "Twins" is not his. He separated himself and turned towards impurity, in chaos and desolation, as it says in Tehilim 9:7: "The enemy is no more — ruins everlasting; You have torn down their cities; their very names are lost."

הגם שדברי הזוהר המה ודאי רזין, מכל מקום צריכין להבין אותם גם על פי פשוטה שהיה חלוקה בין יעקב לעשו במנין החדשים. אך קשה, דלמה אתאביד אלול מן עשו אם היה ראוי לחלקו, מאחר שיעקב נטל ג' חדשים ניסן אייר סיון? גם מה נעשה בששה חדשים הנותרים? למי הם שייכים?

Albeit, the words of Zohar are surely cryptic, nevertheless we must understand them according to simple meaning that there was a division in the months count between Yaakov and Eisav. This is hard to understand! Perhaps Elul was abandoned by Eisav even if it is fitting for his portion, once Yaakov took three months Nissan, Iyar, and Sivan? What about the six remaining months? To whom do these months belong?

לכן נלע"ד להבין הכל על נכון בהקדים מה שנתנו הקדמונים סימן בענין הפטרות שאמרו מי"ז בתמוז ואילך מפטירין ג' דפורענותא ושבעה דנחמתא ותרתי דתיובתא. מאי בעו בזה הסימן? ובזוהר פרשת שמות (ח"ב יב, א) איתא בפסוק "ותצפנהו שלשה ירחים" "אילין תלת ירחין דדינא קשיא שריא בעלמא ומאי ניהו תמוז אב טבת וכו'". ויבואר הכל בחדא מחתא, דכבר כתבתנו במסכת ראש השנה אליבא דר' יהושע דאמר בניסן נברא העולם, והכי סתם לן תנא דמתניתין בכמה דוכתי כאשר כתבתי שם, היינו בריאת אדם הראשון היה ביום ו' שהוא ראש חדש ניסן, אבל תחלת הבריאה היה בכ"ה באדר. וכבר ידוע שיעקב קנה הבכורה מעשו והקב"ה הסכים על המכירה וקרא לו "בני בכורי ישראל". ונמצא בחלוקת החדשים היה מגיע ליעקב שני חלקים, ונטל יעקב ארבעה חדשים ראשונים, דהיינו: אדר – שהוא תחלת בריאת עולם, ניסן, אייר, סיון. ואחר כך לקח עשו בחלקו תרין ירחין אילן תמוז אב. ולכך היה כח לס"א ס"מ שר של עשו בתרין ירחין אילין בעונותינו להחריב בית מקדשינו ושארי דברים שאירעו לנו בתרין ירחין אילין.

Thus, in my humble opinion, to understand it all, it is good to start with the signature that preceding generations made with the choices of the Haftora from the 17th of Tamuz (till the end of the year). We read three haftoras of calamities and seven haftoras of consolation, and two haftoras of repentance. Why do we need this signature? In the Zohar Shemos 18:193 on the verse Shemos 2:2 "...she hid him for three months":

These are the three months in which the world is under the aegis of stern Justice, namely Tammuz, Av, and Tevet. Etc.

And it all comes together (literally in one coal-pan). We already wrote in masekhta Rosh Hashanah 11a, where R' Yehoshua says: "In Nisan the world was created" and so for us the mishna teaches in several places, as I wrote there, that Adam haRishon was created on the sixth day, which was Rosh Chodesh Nisan. However, the beginning of Creation was on the 25th of Adar. And so it is known that Yaakov acquired the bekhora (the first-born priviledge) from Eisav and HKBH approved the sale and called Shemos 4:22 "... Israel is My First-born!" So we find in the division of the months, Yaakov takes two portions. Thus Yaakov took first four months: Adar, which was beginning of Creation of the World; Nisan; Iyar; and Sivan. Afterwads, Eisav took in his portion two months - that is Tamuz and Av. Therefore, the power of Sitra Achara (impurity) "the time of duty" (seder moed) for the angel of Eisav is in these two months. Due to our sins it brought us to the destruction of our Temple and other things that we experienced in these two months.

ואחר כך המה שני חדשים אלול תשרי שהמה ימי התשובה ועוסקים בכמה מצות ובודאי אילו עשו ישראל תשובה גמורה היה נתבטל כחו של עשו עם שר שלו למעלה לגמרי. אך בעו"ה אין עושים תשובה גמורה. ועל כל פנים מועיל התשובה ומעשים טובים שעושים בשני חדשים אלו שלא יקח עשו חלק כנגדם. ואחר כך לקח יעקב ב' חדשים חשון כסליו לחלקו. ועשו לקח טבת לחלקו. לכן גם בחדש זה היה כח לס"א שבו צום העשירי, וכמבואר בזוהר הנ"ל פרשת שמות.

And afterwards there are two months Elul and Tishrei, which are days of repentance and we are busy with many mitzvos. For sure, if Jewish people made complete repentance, then the power of Eisav and that of his Angel would be completely nullified. Albeit, in this world we cannot repent completely. And in any case, repentance and good deeds done in these two months are beneficial, so that Eisav does not take a portion in them. Afterwards, Yaakov took two months Cheshvan and Kislev for his portion. And Esau took Tevet for his portion. Therefore, in this month too, there is power for the Sitra Achara (impurity), so that we fast on the tenth of Tevet, as explained in the aforementioned Zohar Shemos 18:193.

נשאר חודש שבט. מזה מגיע ב' חלקים ליעקב, והואיל שרובו בקדושה נדחה ממנו עשו לגמרי ולא נשאר לו מכל י"ב ירחים רק ג' והיינו תמוז אב טבת. ‏(כן הוא הגירסא נכונה בזוהר, ולא כמו שהעמידו בגליון "נ"א שבט", דליתא. הגם ידעתי שבזוהר איכא איתא "טבת ושבט אינון ימי הרעה" ועיין שם. היינו דסבירא ליה שם דעשו נטיל חלק שליש.)

The month of Shvat remains. Yaakov took 2 portions in it. Because majority of the month has holiness, Eisav is pushed out of it completely. Thus, from the whole 12 months, only 3 months remain for him, and they are Tamuz, Av, and Tevet. (That is a correct wording in the Zohar and not like "other wording: Shvat", which is not correct. I also know that it is written in Zohar Chadash, Midrash haNe'elam al Eikhah 83 "Tevet and Shvat - these are days of evil" and look there. Meaning, that Eisav took also a third portion.)

מכל י"ב ירחים נמצא דיעקב נטיל שמנה חדשים לחלקו וכפי הסדר שכתבתי שמתחיל מן אדר; לקח יעקב ד' חדשים, ואחר כך עשו ב' חדשים, עוד לקח יעקב ד' חדשים ועשו ב' חדשים. אבל לפי סברת הזוהר בפרשת שמות שכתב תלת ירחין דדינא קשיא שדיא בעלמא ודאי המה תמוז אב טבת כמו שמבואר בפני' ולא כמו שכתבו נ"א בגליון ומטעם שכתבתי דמחודש אלול ותשרי נדחה עשו לגמרי.

From all twelve months we find that Yaakov took eight months for his portion. According to the order that I described, that he started from Adar and took 4 months. Afterwards, Eisav took 2 months. Then Yaakov took 4 months and Eisav took 2 months. However, according to the opinion of Zohar Shemos 18:193, who wrote about three months of judgement - a hard difficulty (kush'ya shad'ya) in general - for sure they are Tamuz, Av, and Tevet, as we described before, and not according to the other wording in the "gilyon*, for the reason that from the months of ELul and Tishrei Eisav is pushed out completely.

וזה שרמזו הקדמונים בסימן הפטרות: ג' דפורענותא ושבע דנחמתא ותרתי דתיובתא. היינו כנגד י"ב חדשי השנה. והמשכיל יבין מאליו.

This is what was hinted in the signature of the Haftoras: three of calamities, seven of consolation, and two of repentance - that is in parallel to the twelve months of the year. An intelligent mind will understand from this.

ולכך אירע לנו באותן ג' חדשים, תמוז אב טבת, מה שאירע. והמה צום הרביעי וצום החמישי וצום העשירי. וה' ברחמיו יעשה למען שמו להפוך אותם לששון ושמחה במהרה בימינו אמן. ועיין עוד מה שאכתוב בסמוך.

So whatever occured for us in those three months, Tamuz, Av, and Tevet, - occured. And they are the fast of the fourth month (Tamuz), and the fast of the fifth month (Av), and the fast of the tenth month (Tevet). And Hashem in his mercy will act for His name to turn them to happiness and joy soon in our days. Amein. (And look what is written next to it).

Summary

Zohar presents two opinions regarding division of months.

  1. The first opinion, based on Zohar Chadash, Midrash haNe'elam al Eikhah 83 implies that Tamuz, Av, Tevet, and Shvat are the months of judgement, which were taken by Eisav. The remaining eight months: Nisan, Iyar, Sivan, Elul, Tishrei, Cheshvan, and Adar are moths of mercy and were taken by Yaakov, who as a first-born gets a double portion.

  2. There is a considerable difficulty with understanding the opinion in Zohar proper, since Zohar Yisro 13:241 and Zohar Shemos 18:193 imply that only three months are the months of judgement, namely Tamuz, Av, and Tevet, which are taken by Eisav. According to this opinion, the months Nisan, Iyar, Sivan, Cheshvan, Kislev, and Adar are the months of mercy taken by Yaakov. The months of Elul and Tishrei are filled with repentance and mitzvos, so Eisav does not have any portion in them. It is possible to resolve the month of Shvat: since Yaakov as firstborn takes two portions in it, majority, Eisav cannot touch it.

  3. The last opinion has its parallel in the established count of haftoras that we read from 17th of Tamuz until the end of the year. The three haftoras of calamities parallel the months Tamuz, Av, and Tevet. The seven haftoras of consolation parallel the months Nisan, Iyar, Sivan, Cheshvan, Kislev, Shvat, and Adar. The two haftoras of repentance parallel the months Elul and Tishrei. In other words, the last 12 weeks of the year carry the signature of the entire year according to his commentary.

Geshmak!

title: Is there Lifnei Iver by a goy? Am I allowed to tempt a goy to steal?
content:
# Is there Lifnei Iver by a goy? Am I allowed to tempt a goy to steal? ## Frage

Is there Lifnei Iver by a goy? Meaning am I allowed to tempt a goy to steal?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The Gemara in Avodah Zarah (6a) is quite clear that there is לפני עור by a Goy. The discussion over there is doing business with him to help him celebrate his holiday (Avodah Zarah). Whether this can be applied towards stealing, and precisely what "temptation" we are dealing with, is a question for you LOR.

title: If you can wrong a third party, does the 3rd party have a right to be angry at you, or it is Hashem that caused the harm?
content:
# If you can wrong a third party, does the 3rd party have a right to be angry at you, or it is Hashem that caused the harm? ## Frage

The mussar sefarim say that if someone wrongs you, do not get angry at them. Rather everything comes from Hashem and he ordained it to happen. My question is if your free will allows you to wrong someone and even harm them. Doesn’t that mean that you are to blame?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The Rambam discusses this question at the end of the 6th chapter of Hilchos Teshuvah. His answer is that while it's true that what happened to you only happened because Hashem willed it, the person who did it to you didn't have to be the one to do it.

For example, Hashem wanted the Jewish people to suffer in Egypt (as he told Avraham Avinu). If so, why were the Egyptians punished? The answer is that no individual Egyptian had to torture a Jew. If Egyptian A didn't want to do it, Egyptian B would have done it. As such, Egyptian A is held responsible for his actions, even though the result would have been the same either way.

See the Rambam there for more detail.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

Of course the one who commits an evil is at fault. The point isn’t to shift the blame away from the wrongdoer, but to recognize that the only reason they were able to wrong you is that Hashem allowed them to. Hashem is the one who decreed that a wrongdoer’s actions should target you, as opposed to someone else. Hashem decreed that they should succeed in wronging you.

In other words, you can and should blame a wrongdoer for acting badly. But you should not blame them for acting badly to you. The former was their own choice; the latter was Hashem’s.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 0)

This has always helped me answer this sort of question.

Who does the book of Job say was responsible for the death of Job’s servants and the theft of his camels?

A. The Chaldeans.

ע֣וֹד ׀ זֶ֣ה מְדַבֵּ֗ר וְזֶה֮ בָּ֣א וַיֹּאמַר֒ כַּשְׂדִּ֞ים שָׂ֣מוּ ׀ שְׁלֹשָׁ֣ה רָאשִׁ֗ים וַֽיִּפְשְׁט֤וּ עַל־הַגְּמַלִּים֙ וַיִּקָּח֔וּם וְאֶת־הַנְּעָרִ֖ים הִכּ֣וּ לְפִי־חָ֑רֶב וָאִמָּ֨לְטָ֧ה רַק־אֲנִ֛י לְבַדִּ֖י לְהַגִּ֥יד לָֽךְ׃ This one was still speaking when another came and said, “A Chaldean formation of three columns made a raid on the camels and carried them off and put the boys to the sword; I alone have escaped to tell you.” (Job 1:17)

B. Satan.

וַיֹּ֨אמֶר יְהֹוָ֜ה אֶל־הַשָּׂטָ֗ן הִנֵּ֤ה כׇל־אֲשֶׁר־לוֹ֙ בְּיָדֶ֔ךָ רַ֣ק אֵלָ֔יו אַל־תִּשְׁלַ֖ח יָדֶ֑ךָ וַיֵּצֵא֙ הַשָּׂטָ֔ן מֵעִ֖ם פְּנֵ֥י יְהֹוָֽה׃ The LORD replied to the Adversary, “See, all that he has is in your power; only do not lay a hand on him.” The Adversary departed from the presence of the LORD. (Job 1:12)

C. Hashem.

וַיֹּ֩אמֶר֩ עָרֹ֨ם יָצָ֜תִי מִבֶּ֣טֶן אִמִּ֗י וְעָרֹם֙ אָשׁ֣וּב שָׁ֔מָּה יְהֹוָ֣ה נָתַ֔ן וַֽיהֹוָ֖ה לָקָ֑ח יְהִ֛י שֵׁ֥ם יְהֹוָ֖ה מְבֹרָֽךְ׃ He said, “Naked came I out of my mother’s womb, and naked shall I return there; the LORD has given, and the LORD has taken away; blessed be the name of the LORD.” (Job 1:21)

וַיֹּ֨אמֶר יְהֹוָ֜ה אֶל־הַשָּׂטָ֗ן הֲשַׂ֣מְתָּ לִבְּךָ֮ אֶל־עַבְדִּ֣י אִיּוֹב֒ כִּי֩ אֵ֨ין כָּמֹ֜הוּ בָּאָ֗רֶץ אִ֣ישׁ תָּ֧ם וְיָשָׁ֛ר יְרֵ֥א אֱלֹהִ֖ים וְסָ֣ר מֵרָ֑ע וְעֹדֶ֙נּוּ֙ מַחֲזִ֣יק בְּתֻמָּת֔וֹ וַתְּסִיתֵ֥נִי ב֖וֹ לְבַלְּע֥וֹ חִנָּֽם׃ The LORD said to the Adversary, “Have you noticed My servant Job? There is no one like him on earth, a blameless and upright man who fears God and shuns evil. He still keeps his integrity; so you have incited Me against him to destroy him for no good reason.” (Job 2:4)

וַיָּבֹ֣אוּ אֵ֠לָ֠יו כׇּל־אֶחָ֨יו וְכׇל־אַחְיֹתָ֜יו וְכׇל־יֹדְעָ֣יו לְפָנִ֗ים וַיֹּאכְל֨וּ עִמּ֣וֹ לֶ֘חֶם֮ בְּבֵיתוֹ֒ וַיָּנֻ֤דוּ לוֹ֙ וַיְנַחֲמ֣וּ אֹת֔וֹ עַ֚ל כׇּל־הָ֣רָעָ֔ה אֲשֶׁר־הֵבִ֥יא יְהֹוָ֖ה עָלָ֑יו וַיִּתְּנוּ־ל֗וֹ אִ֚ישׁ קְשִׂיטָ֣ה אֶחָ֔ת וְאִ֕ישׁ נֶ֥זֶם זָהָ֖ב אֶחָֽד׃ All his brothers and sisters and all his former friends came to him and had a meal with him in his house. They consoled and comforted him for all the misfortune that the LORD had brought upon him. Each gave him one kesitah and each one gold ring. (Job 42:11)

(All quotes copied from Sefaria.)

Or,

D. All of the above— yet in different ways.

Apply this to your question. You get angry at someone and harm them. Who made that happen?

A. You, since you decided to do it?

B. Satan, if he influenced you to do it?

C. Hashem, since He “willed it” or “decreed it” (from the two previous answers)?

Or, D. All of the above— yet in different ways.

Yet Hashem decreeing or Satan influencing never justify our disobedience: we still made the decision to transgress the Law, and we are still accountable for it.

title: Meaning of Rambam's "stateful" ("to be") Mitzvas
content:
# Meaning of Rambam's "stateful" ("to be") Mitzvas ## Frage

Here's a short sample of [weird] Positive Mitzvos that Rambam lists in Sefer Hamitzvos (90s-100s), that are not actionable but "stateful", i.e., a certain state (e.g., impurity) is a "Mitzva to be":

להיות שמונה שרצים מטמאין For the dead bodies of the eight species of crawling animals to impart ritual impurity
להיות האוכלין מיטמאין For [certain] foods to impart impurity
להיות הנידה טמאה ומטמאה לאחרים. For a woman in the niddah state to be impure and to impart impurity to others.
להיות היולדת טמאה כנידה. For a woman who gives birth to be impure like a woman in the niddah state.
להיות המצורע טמא ומטמא. For a person afflicted with tzara’at to be impure and to impart impurity.
להיות בגד מנוגע טמא ומטמא. For a garment afflicted with tzara’at to be impure and to impart impurity.
להיות בית מנוגע מטמא. For a house afflicted with tzara’at to impart impurity.
להיות הזב מטמא. For a zav to impart impurity.
להיות שכבת זרע מטמאה. For semen to impart impurity.
להיות זבה מטמאה. For a zavah to impart impurity.
להיות המת מטמא. For a corpse to impart impurity.

  • What does it mean for those to be a Mitzva?
  • Who/what is commanded to perform those Mitzvahs?
  • How does "dead body being impure" fulfill a Positive Mitzvah?
  • Should one strive to fulfill those mitzvahs by making more dead insects, niddas, or corpses?
  • Why are there so many of them? Why can't "being impure" be one Mitzvah with all those being details (as opposed to "Love thy neighbor)?
## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Your quotes here are not from Rambam's Sefer Hamitzvot as you claim, but from the brief list of the commandments which forms part of the introduction to his Mishneh Torah.

In Sefer HaMitzvot Aseh 96, Rambam explains exactly what he understands these mitzvot to be:

That is that He commanded us that when any person touches a carcass, he becomes impure. And this commandment includes the impurity of a carcass and all of its laws.

And I will now present a preface that is appropriate that we remember anytime we mention the various types of impurity. And it is that that which we count each type as a positive commandment - its content is not that we are obligated to become impure with a certain impurity, and also not that we are prohibited from becoming impure from it and that it be a negative commandment.

Rather the Torah said that anyone who touches this type [of object] becomes impure; or that this thing renders one who touches it impure according to this description. And that is the positive commandment - meaning that this law with which we have been commanded is a positive commandment. And that is His saying, whoever touches this according to this description has become impure; and whoever according to that description does not become impure. But the matter itself is optional - if he wants, he becomes impure; if not, he doesn't become impure.

And the language of the Sifra (Sifra, Shemini, Chapter 4:10) is, "'And their carcass do not touch' (Leviticus 11:8) - I might think that if one touched a carcass, he receives lashes. [Hence] we learn to say, 'and to these you shall become impure' (Leviticus 11:24). I might [then] think that if one saw a carcass, he should go and become impure from it. [Hence] we learn to say, 'and their carcass do not touch.' How is this? You shall say, it is an option."

And this commandment that has been told to us about this law - that one who touches this become impure; and that he will be impure, such that he will be obligated about everything that impure people are obligated, [such as] to exit from the camp of the Divine Presence, not to eat consecrated food, not to touch it and other things besides this - this is the command. That means to say, one becoming impure from this type when he touches it or was proximate to [it] in such a manner.

And remember this matter with every one of the types of impurity.

So, to directly answer your questions based on the above Rambam:

  • What does it mean for those to be a Mitzva?

The mitzvah is for one who comes into contact with a source of impurity to act in accordance with the relevant rules.

  • Who/what is commanded to perform those Mitzvahs?

The person who comes into contact with a source of impurity, and possibly anyone else for whom his impurity has an effect.

  • How does "dead body being impure" fulfill a Positive Mitzvah?

It doesn't. The mitzvah is for the one who came into contact with the dead body to follow the rules.

  • Should one strive to fulfill those mitzvahs by making more dead insects, niddas, or corpses?

No.

  • Why are there so many of them? Why can't "being impure" be one Mitzvah with all those being details (as opposed to "Love thy neighbor)?

This is admittedly not directly answered by the piece I quoted, but my sense from Rambam is that since each form of impurity has a different set of rules, it makes sense that each one forms its own mitzvah. (Maybe we can draw an analogy to the separate mitzvot of not doing melachah on shabbat, yom kippur, chag, shemittah, yovel - even thought conceptually you could have one overarching umbrella prohibition of melachah on holy occasions, they are split up into separate prohibitions.)

title: How can a perfect God have desires?
content:
# How can a perfect God have desires? ## Frage

The question here is somewhat similar to "why did God create the world," but it's a little bit different in that I'm not asking why God created the world in any particular way, but why did God have a desire to create in the first place?

Before creation, God should have been a perfect, infinite unity. Even the concept of separation didn't exist yet. The problem here is that if God had a desire to create, then it must be that the concepts of desire and non-desire already existed, which isn't possible in a perfect unity.

If God's desire to create was all that there was and there was not even the concept of not desiring, then because God desires, and therefore lacks, how can we say that God is perfect?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

You are thinking of desire from a human lens. We desire things external to ourselves - we see something and then we want it. The objects of our desire "sell themselves" to us, and we are aroused and want them. This type of desire implies a lack.

Hashem doesn't desire in this way. His desire comes from His ultimate "bechira chafshis", free choice, from His will.

We have to redefine free will to understand this. Let's start with the basics: what is "free" and what is "will"?

Free

Free from influence; no external influence - the decision arises totally from my self, my essence.

Will

What I want. Synonyms/near misses: desire; enjoy; value.

What is Free Will?

I have the ability to desire whatever I want, based solely on me, without being told what to desire. The "object" of His choice in no way influences Him or draws/repels Him in the slightest.

So, it is possible to desire what you desire based solely on yourself. This is called Ratzon Atzma'i, essential will. This is very hard for humans to wrap our heads around (but Hashem does invite us to become this mature and elevated as well). This type of desire does not express any form of lack, but is a perfection - He chooses "based on", so to speak, His own perfection; a choice that is of course, a perfect choice.

Sources: Rambam Moreh Nevuchim 3:13 ("Hashem's Essence is identical to His Ratzon"); and from Chassidus, see לקוטי תורה, אמור ו׳ (38b); החודש הזה לכם, ש"פ שמיני, פ' החודש, מבה"ח ניסן, ה'תשל"ג, מאמר יבחר לנו את נחלתינו תשכ"ג, and finally this essay by Reb Yoel: נתאווה הקב"ה להיות לו דירה בתחתונים. May I also recommend this answer on the Kabbalah of Ratzon, and this answer which is a full essay on the concept of Hashem's Essence and attributes as understood by Kabbalah and Chassidus, and this answer on Hashem's ultimate desire/need.

title: Why are Jewish people named Anat?
content:
# Why are Jewish people named Anat? ## Frage

Anat, the sister of Baal, was a pagan goddess. How did it come to be that Jewish women are now named after her?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

According to the New Name Dictionary by Alfred J. Kolatch, the name Anat (עֲנָת) is derived from the root ענה meaning to sing. Typically, female immigrants from Eastern Europe with name Anna would change their name to Anat in Israel instead of Chanah. The Rabbinic authorities were not consulted. Generally, people in Israel were not versed in Canaani mythology after the World War 2 when the name became popular.

title: Anything wrong with defaulting and buying back at an auction?
content:
# Anything wrong with defaulting and buying back at an auction? ## Frage

A person who buys an item that will be paid off in installments, such as a home or expensive vehicle, where the standard agreement indicates that failure to pay will result in the repossession of the item (eg, the bank will evict the buyer and resell the home at auction).

May a buyer purchase these items with the intent to default on the payments and then purchase the exact same item, which will be resold at auction (either directly or through a business) for a dramatically reduced price?

Assume there is no law of the land prohibiting such a tactic; would it be considered halachically allowable? If not, why not?

It is self-understood that the buyer could be outbid at auction.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Pirkei Avos, Chapter 2

איזוהי דרך שיתרחק ממנה האדם... רבי שמעון אומר: הלווה ואינו משלם אחד לווה מן האדם כלווה מן המקום ברוך הוא, שנאמר: "לווה רשע ולא ישלם, וצדיק חונן ונותן" (תהלים לז כא)

What is an evil way that a man should distance himself from? One who borrows and does not pay. Whether he borrows from a man it is if he borrows from the Almighty, blessed be He, as is stated (Tehillim 37:21), "The wicked man borrows and does not repay."

The prohibition of refusing to repay a loan is codified in halacha. The Shulchan Aruch (based on .גמרא בבא מציעא דף קי"א) writes that this violates the Biblical prohibition of Oshek. (Choshen Mishpat siman 359, si'if 8)

title: Obtaining ordinations of a religious nature outside Judaism
content:
# Obtaining ordinations of a religious nature outside Judaism ## Frage

Can anybody point me to source materials discussing whether it is appropriate, and/or halachically permitted or prohibited, to obtain certifications, ordinations, or other consecrations of a religious nature outside of Judaism.

For example, it is possible to obtain "ordination" on-line from various "non-denominational religions" which have no religious or theological tenets, and such "ordinations" may provide various uses and benefits in the secular world. But does doing so raise a halachic issue?

I note than many Rabbis, who have the titles, go by "Rabbi Doctor," and Rabbi Jonathan Sacks A'H went by Rabbi Lord Sacks, although those secondary titles do not necessarily have any theological connotations or basis. By asking the question, I am not criticizing or questioning the conduct of any such Rabbis.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: -1)

In England, priests were tried in priestly courts, not regular secular court. This court tended to be more lenient, which was benefit and privilege to priests. Eventually all you needed to do to demonstrate you were a priest and get this privilege was to read a passage from the Bible. It was not only for capital offenses.

In 1670, they made a law that a Jew who had not converted to Christianity could not claim this privilege. That implies that Jews would claim to be Christian priests (and had to be stopped). American and English Jews should continue this minhag and claim titles when convenient.

title: Help with Mishnah Yevamoth 6:4
content:
# Help with Mishnah Yevamoth 6:4 ## Frage

Why does Yevamoth 6:4 permit a divorcee to a Kohen Gadol אֵרֵס אֶת הָאַלְמָנָה, וְנִתְמַנָּה לִהְיוֹת כֹּהֵן גָּדוֹל, יִכְנֹס when Levitucus 21:14 prohibits this to all Kohanim?

Is this permitted Bedieved according to the Talmud on this on the word Eem?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

An אַלְמָנָה is a widow, not a divorcee. Only a Kohen Gadol is forbidden to a widow, but in this case it is allowed because he had done Kiddushin before he was appointed Kohen Gadol.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

The Gemara in Yevamos (59a) addresses this question. The verses in the beginning of Parshas Emor (Leviticus 21:13-14) discuss whom a Kohen Gadol can take as a wife.

:ויקרא פרק כא פסוק יג (פרשת אמור): וְה֕וּא אִשָּׁ֥ה בִבְתוּלֶ֖יהָ יִקָּֽח

The Gemara (ibid.) asks if this word יקח is referring to אירוסין or נישואין. It proves from the Mishnah you quoted that it must be referring to אירוסין. See the Gemara there for a question and answer on this interpretation.

title: How were passers-by warned the scapegoat should not be touched or hunted?
content:
# How were passers-by warned the scapegoat should not be touched or hunted? ## Frage

Lev.16 only specifies the scapegoat is to be sent "to Azazel" by the hand of a man, who will "let him go" and purify himself upon returning to the camp: so, the kid is impure and is alive when disposed of. Even if the (non-Biblical) custom was to throw it down a cliff, there was no guarantee it would be killed on impact, so there was a definite chance passers-by would find it alive, possibly maimed. Hence the question:

Did the scapegoat carry a specific amulet, plate, badge, brand or any kind of sign indicating, at least to the children of Israel, it was tabu to touch or eat, even if found alive?

The motivation for this question is I wish to test the hypothesis that the protocol for Yom-Kippur parallels Gen.4, with Aaron's offering representing Abel's sacrifice, the goat offering representing his murder and the scapegoat representing the curse on Cain. According to this interpretation, there should be a ritual device reminiscent of the mark on Cain.

My (uneducated) first guess would be a badge bearing a crimson inscription. This is because a Catholic priest once explained to me he understood Psalm 22:6 as alluding to the mark of Cain: an eczema plaque of crimson color, like the dye from the worm.

I believe the answer must rely on sources outside the Bible. According to ChatGPT, Josephus is of no help as he ignores the scapegoat when discussing Yom-Kippur.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

It was a really big and rocky cliff with no chance of survival. The Mishnah in Yoma 6:6 writes:

ולא היה מגיע לחצי ההר עד שנעשה אברים אברים

Before it got halfway down, it was torn limb from limb

title: "Tumas t'hom" from merely walking on a non-Jewish grave?
content:
# "Tumas t'hom" from merely walking on a non-Jewish grave? ## Frage

Is there any "tumas t'hom" (d'rabonnon or otherwise) transmitted to a Jew from walking on a non-Jewish grave?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

From here:

Rabba bar Avuha met Eliyahu in a non-Jewish cemetery… He said to him: Are you not a priest; why then do you stand in a cemetery? He replied: Has the master not studied the laws of purity? For it has been taught: Rabbi Shimon bar Yochai said: The graves of gentiles do not defile, for it is written: "And you My flock, the flock of My pastures, are men" (Yechezkel 34:31) – only you are designated "men," but gentiles are not designated "men." (Bava Metzia 114b)

The Rambam rules (Hilkhot Tum'at Met 1:12-13) that the corpses of gentiles impart impurity through touch, but not through being in the same tent.

title: Is DNA testing valid in cases of suspected bastardy?
content:
# Is DNA testing valid in cases of suspected bastardy? ## Frage

Generally, when a married couple has a child, the father is deemed to be the mother's husband, especially if they live together. But what if there is suspicion that he isn't -- that the mother had an affair? The sotah procedure is on hold today. Before DNA testing, rabbis generally ruled that the husband is the father, regardless of a strong suspicion that he isn't, to avoid tarring the child with the brush of bastardy. But now that there is DNA testing, do the rabbis accept its conclusion? If not, is uncertainty of test reliability their only reason?

title: Pain to prevent sin
content:
# Pain to prevent sin ## Frage

Is one permitted to carry around a lighter so that when he is tempted to sin he can feel the fire and remember Gehinnom? If it is permitted, is it a good idea?

Moderator note: Regardless of anything you might read here, if this is a matter you are considering practically, we strongly recommend consulting your Rabbi and relevant physical and mental health professionals. Mi Yodeya does not offer personalized professional advice.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

This is the kind of question which should have been closed because of a rule against asking for practical advice. The reason one should consult your local Orthodox rabbi (LOR) is that he can both give practical advice about how to act; because he can assess individual circumstances to see what is uniquely appropriate for a specific situation; and because he is sensible to see what stands behind the question (like the famous story of the question of whether milk can be use for the four cups at the Seder). Further, random strangers on the Internet who might know nothing or who might misinterpret sources (like Biblical verses or Talmudic stories) should not be trusted for such an important question.

Putting aside religion for a moment, self-harm such as burning is not healthy for one's psyche. Self-harm is associated with even worse things like suicide attempts. This is not a good path to go down. Going back to religion, there's an idea of וְנִשְׁמַרְתֶּ֥ם מְאֹ֖ד לְנַפְשֹׁתֵיכֶ֑ם, that one should be exceeding careful when it comes to guarding one's life.

Also, there is a possibility of channeling mental health issues into a religious expression and thereby giving it legitimacy. For instance, an anorexic can point to Sages who have fasted. There is a phenomenon across religions including Judaism called Scrupulosity which is a way of legitimizing Obsessive Compulsive Disorder. Rabbis and therapists dealing with an individual with scrupulosity would even tell them that they need to violate halacha as a way of breaking out of it.

Therefore, even if other people provide answers which seem to suggest that self-harm like burning oneself (or heating oneself) with a lighter is either allowed or even encouraged, do not listen to them. That is wrong and shortsighted.

There is a skill of a posek (decider of halacha) in knowing which Talmudic sources should or should not be applied. Sometimes, stories in the Talmud are not meant to be normative halacha, but are to be inspirational of the extent of an idea. Or, these stories made sense for the particular Sage, who had a certain quality, but was not intended for any person off the street.

For one example of this, see Berachot 20a. Rav Pappa who asks Abaye why his generation does not merit miracles like prior generations, despite knowing more. Abaye answers that it is because the prior generations were moser nefesh. He relates how Rav Adda bar Ahava I pulled a forbidden garment from a woman he thought was Jewish in the marketplace and was fined for it.

That kind of extreme behavior was not deemed appropriate even in Abaye and Rav Pappa's generation. He was not really saying that people should take such action, of ripping off women's clothing. And certainly not today.

My point is that you cannot just point to extreme actions of various Talmudic Sages and claim that it is normative halacha. Don't listen to random people who tell you otherwise, especially if it reinforces potentially harmful behavior. Consult your local Orthodox rabbi.

### Antwort 2 (Score: -6)

Sure, that's exactly what Rabbi Tzaddok did in Kiddushin 40a:

" Rabbi Tzadok was enticed by a certain noblewoman to engage in sexual intercourse with her. He said to her: My heart is weak and I am incapable at present; is there something to eat that can strengthen me? She said to him: There is something non-kosher. He said to her: What difference is there? One who performs such an act eats such food as well.
She lit the oven and placed the non-kosher food in it to roast. He climbed and sat in the oven. She said to him: What is the meaning of this? He said to her: One who performs this act falls into this, i.e., the fires of Gehenna. She said to him: If I had known that the matter was so serious for you, I would not have caused you such anguish."

There are additional examples of Rabbis, like Rabbi Elazar ben Dordia (Avodah Zarah 17a), who self-inflicted emotional and physical anguish (weeping until death), leading to immediate and complete atonement.

While Maimonides (Hilkhot Rotze’ach) rules that one may not injure oneself just like one may not injure others, he refers to "sinful" (or meaningless) injury. There are numerous cases where inflicting pain is prescripted, e.g, the fasts ( "י֧וֹם הַכִּפֻּרִ֣ים ה֗וּא מִֽקְרָא־קֹ֙דֶשׁ֙ יִהְיֶ֣ה לָכֶ֔ם וְעִנִּיתֶ֖ם אֶת־נַפְשֹׁתֵיכֶ֑ם"), educational beating of children, corporal punishment, forcing other to pay debts, and more.

title: From Onkelos to Rashi, was anyone concerned with anthropopathy?
content:
# From Onkelos to Rashi, was anyone concerned with anthropopathy? ## Frage

"Anthropopathy - attribution of human feelings and emotions to non-human beings".

The Torah says:

"כִּי ה' אֱלֹהֶיךָ אֵשׁ אֹכְלָה הוּא אֵל קַנָּא׃"
"For YHWH your God is a consuming fire, an impassioned God." (Deut 4.24)

Onkelos recognizes anthropomorphism and replaces "God IS fire" with "God's WORDS are fire", but doesn't recognize anthropopathy and leaves "an impassioned God" untouched:

"אֲרֵי יְיָ אֱלָהָךְ מֵימְרֵיהּ אֶשָּׁא אָכְלָא הוּא אֵל קַנָּא:"

For comparison, here are two additional Targums:

"אֲרוּם יְיָ אֱלָהָכוֹן מֵימְרֵיהּ אֵישָׁא אָכְלָא אֵישָׁא הוּא אֱלָהָא קַנָאִי וּמִתְפְּרַע בְּקִנְאָה"
"אֲרוּם יְיָ אֱלָהָכוֹן אֶשָׁא דְאָכְלָא אֶשָׁא הוּא אֱלָהָא קִנְאַן וּמִתְפְּרַע בְּקַנָּאִין הוּא:"

Similarly, Rashi is fine with "an impassioned God".

"אל קנא. מְקַנֵּא לִנְקֹם, אנפר"מנט בְּלַעַז, מִתְחָרֶה עַל רָגְזוֹ לְהִפָּרַע מֵעוֹבְדֵי עֲ"זָ:"

Before Rambam's transcendentalism, were there commentators who expressed uneasiness regarding Biblical anthropopathy?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

To answer the OP's question, R' Saadia Gaon in The Book of Beliefs and Opinions, Treatease II, Chapter VIII is also concerned with Anthropopathy (I am using Rosenblatt's translation, so that the relevant points begin in the middle of the chapter):

"ואחר כן אדבר על האיכות, והם המקרים, ואומר: שהוא באמת לא יתכן שיקרהו מקרה, כי הוא בורא ‏המקרים כלם. וזה אשר נמצא שאומר שהוא אוהב דבר או שונא דבר, הענין בזה שכל אשר צונו בו ‏קראו אהוב אצלו, כאשר חייבנו לאוהב אותו, באמרו (תהלים ל"ז כ"ח) כי י"י אוהב משפט. (שם י"א ‏ז') צדיק י"י צדקות אהב והדומה לזה. וקבץ רבים מהם, ואמר (ירמיה ז' כ"ג) כי באלה חפצתי נאם ‏י"י. וכל אשר הזהירנו ממנו שלא נעשהו, קראו שנוא אצלו, מפני שחייבנו לשנאתו, כמו שאמר (משלי ‏ו' ט"ז) שש הנה שנא י"י. (ישעיה ס"א ח') שונא גזל בעולה. וקבץ מהם רבים, ואמר (זכריה ח' י"ז) כי ‏את כל אלה אשר שנאתי נאם י"י, ומה שאנו רואים שאומר שהוא רוצה ושהוא כועס, הענין בו, שקצת ‏ברואיו כאשר חייב להם ההצלחה והגמול קורא זה רצון, כאמרו (תהלים קמ"ז י"א) רוצה י"י את ‏יריאיו. (שם פ"ה ב') רצית י"י את ארצך. וכאשר יתחייב קצתם הצער והענש, קורא זה כעס, כאמרו ‏‏(שם ל"ד י"ז) פני י"י בעושי רע. ..."

I preface my remarks with a general observation, and say (1) that whenever any reference is made in this connection to such matters as substance or accident or the attribute of substance or accident, neither "much" nor "little" thereof can be applied in the case of the Creator. (2) For it is our firm conviction that He is the Creator of the Universe. There does not, therefore, remain a substance or accident or attribute that was not acquaired or discerned or put together by Him or about which it is not certain that this Creator was its maker. Hence it is out of question and impossible to declare Him to be anything that He has Himself created.

(3) Consequently for all divine attributes pertaining to either substance or accident that are encountered in the books of prophets it is necessary to find in the Scriptiure nonanthropomorphic meanings that would be in keeping with requirements of reason. Whenever then, we the community of believers apply to G-d epithets that have the appearance of automorphisms, this is due to our endeavor to give a proximate and figurative description of deity. They are not to be taken in material sense in which we would apply them to human beings.

Since, then, these three points ((1), (2), and (3)) have been cleared up by me, thou must no longer be led astray or thrown into uncertainty, Oh thou who studiest this book, by such statements that thou mayest make as "[G-d] was" and "[G-d] wanted" and "[G-d] was pleased" and "[G-d] was angry" and other such remarks and similar utterances that occur in Scriptures. For these expressions are used by us only on the basis of the principle previously established by us, to which they must constantly be referred and related. An edifice, let it be noted, is always built from foundations upward, never from top down. Do not, therefore become confused because of some antropomorphic attribute of G-d that thou seest in the Scriptures, or of which thou findest us making common use, with the result that thou wouldst lapse back again, on its account, into doubt.

(added by ibn Tibbon) But check it against the principle, the true nature of which has already been clarified and firmly established.

Saadia Gaon then discusses specific applications of these principles in Chapter IX and Chapter X of the treatese to specific examples in the Scripture. Specifically, in chapter IX, regarding the OP's example Devarim 4:24, Saadia Gaon states that it should be translated as He is as punishing as a devouring fire.

Regarding the Targum Onkelos view

Scholars Israel Drazin and Stanley Wagner discuss this point in the book "Understanding Onkelos", Parashas Noach pp. 15-18. They note that while Onkelos frequently omits anthropomorphism and explains what the Torah intends to say, he sometimes does not do so for several reasons:

(1) Replacing every anthropomorphism would alter Scripture too drastically and reduce it to an unrecognizable text because the Torah has so many anthropomorphic statements.

(2) (Onkelos) might retain the anthropomorphism when the description is included in a metaphorical phrase that he feels is well known and frequently used by his reading audience, like tzelem Elokim.

(3) (Onkelos) ignores the anthropomorphism when he cannot imagine that a person would accept the word or phrase literally as in Bereshis 2:8, where the verse reads "The Lord planted a garden..." No one would think of G-d engaged in an afternoon of planting.

According to Drazin and Wagner, Onkelos' omissions of modifying every anthropomorphism in the Torah are necessary for textual clarity of his translation. Onkelos would not be understanding these anthropomorphisms as the simple reading suggests.

More on Targum Onkelos

R' Posen "The Consistency of the Targum Onkelos Translation", Perek 1, Section 8 Theology in Targum Onkelos: Research Directions

R' Posen notes that the approach to change anthropomorphisms has source in Tosefta Megila 3:21 and also Talmud Bavli Kiddushin 49a:

Rabbi Yehuda says: One who translates a verse literally is a liar, since he distorts the meaning of the text, and conversely, one who adds his own translation is tantamount to one who curses and blasphemes God. Rather, to which translation is Rabbi Yehuda referring? He is referring to our accepted translation.

R' Posen then proceeds to say that Saadia Gaon was seemingly the first to deal with this point before it reached Rambam, although later studies of Onkelos took a more balanced view.

Rambam's historical circumstances

One can also suggest that in part Rambam was addressing the point of Scripture anthropomorphisms because of the Karaite and muslim ibn Hazm attacks on pro-anthropomorphism book Shi'ur Qomah, attributed to R' Yishmael and admired by Sherira and Chai gaons. (according to Lenn Goodman and Phillip Liberman translations of the "Guide...")

title: Divine decree and free will, how can they be reconciled?
content:
# Divine decree and free will, how can they be reconciled? ## Frage

How does Jewish teaching understand the relationship between divine predestination and human free will?

Various rabbinic statements seem at first glance to be in tension: On one hand, Chazal state "Everything is in God's hands, except for the fear of God". It is also taught that much about a person is predetermined before birth—such as whether he will be strong or weak, wise or foolish, rich or poor—"but not whether he will be righteous or wicked". These statements suggest an all-encompassing divine determination of all circumstances, except for moral choices.

On the other hand, the Torah itself emphatically emphasizes human decision-making freedom. Thus, Moshe Rabbenu declares: "See, I have set before you today life and good, and death and evil… therefore choose life". Similarly, the promise to Cain: "Sin is crouching at the door… but you can rule over it", implies that humans have the ability to overcome evil.

How can these teachings be reconciled with the concept of divine omniscience and providence? Does the idea that God determines or at least knows everything in advance contradict human free will?

title: Why does scripture reverse the order of the Shema in Deut 6 and 11?
content:
# Why does scripture reverse the order of the Shema in Deut 6 and 11? ## Frage

Devarim 6:7-8 reads teaching "these words to your children when you sit at home, walk by the way, lie down and rise up." then it mentions the verse for T'filin.

וְשִׁנַּנְתָּ֣ם לְבָנֶ֔יךָ וְדִבַּרְתָּ֖ בָּ֑ם בְּשִׁבְתְּךָ֤ בְּבֵיתֶ֨ךָ֙ וּבְלֶכְתְּךָ֣ בַדֶּ֔רֶךְ וּֽבְשָׁכְבְּךָ֖ וּבְקוּמֶֽךָ׃

וּקְשַׁרְתָּ֥ם לְא֖וֹת עַל־יָדֶ֑ךָ וְהָי֥וּ לְטֹטָפֹ֖ת בֵּ֥ין עֵינֶֽיךָ׃

וּכְתַבְתָּ֛ם עַל־מְזוּזֹ֥ת בֵּיתֶ֖ךָ וּבִשְׁעָרֶֽיך׃

but in Devarim 11:18-19, it reverses the order, the T'filin verse precedes the verse of V'Limadtem otam...

וְשַׂמְתֶּם֙ אֶת־דְּבָרַ֣י אֵ֔לֶּה עַל־לְבַבְכֶ֖ם וְעַֽל־נַפְשְׁכֶ֑ם וּקְשַׁרְתֶּ֨ם אֹתָ֤ם לְאוֹת֙ עַל־יֶדְכֶ֔ם וְהָי֥וּ לְטוֹטָפֹ֖ת בֵּ֥ין עֵינֵיכֶֽם׃

וְלִמַּדְתֶּ֥ם אֹתָ֛ם אֶת־בְּנֵיכֶ֖ם לְדַבֵּ֣ר בָּ֑ם בְּשִׁבְתְּךָ֤ בְּבֵיתֶ֨ךָ֙ וּבְלֶכְתְּךָ֣ בַדֶּ֔רֶךְ וּֽבְשָׁכְבְּךָ֖ וּבְקוּמֶֽךָ׃

וּכְתַבְתָּ֛ם עַל־מְזוּז֥וֹת בֵּיתֶ֖ךָ וּבִשְׁעָרֶֽיךָ

is there an explanation as to why the order is reversed? Also, in Deut, 6 the word used is

וְשִׁנַּנְתָּ֣ם לְבָנֶ֔יךָ

and in Deut. 11 it reads

וְלִמַּדְתֶּ֥ם אֹתָ֛ם אֶת־בְּנֵיכֶ֖ם

is there a meaning to the different usage of these words?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Ramban on Devarim 11:18 views this reversal of the order as an indication of continuation of the chain of tradition:

וְשִׁנַּנְתָּ֣ם ... וּקְשַׁרְתָּ֥ם ... : ... וּקְשַׁרְתֶּ֨ם ... וְלִמַּדְתֶּ֥ם

in two different ways. First, the commandments are applicable not only in Eretz Israel, but also in the exile:

Now I have already written on the meaning of this matter, that these commandments [the T’fillin and the Mezuzah mentioned by Rashi] are personal obligations and, as such, their laws apply in all places just as in the Land! But there is in this Midrash a profound secret, and I have already alluded to it. Now he repeated these commandments about the T’fillin, the study of the words of the Torah, and the Mezuzah, a second time in order to allude to this analogy, that we shall be obligated to observe them after being exiled from the Land of Israel. From these [texts] we learn that all commandments that are personal obligations are binding in all places and that, outside the Land of Israel, we are exempt from duties which apply to ground, such as heave-offering and tithes. So it is interpreted in the Sifre. And the intent of this interpretation is suggested by the fact that he placed the expression therefore shall ye put [these my words in your heart] next to [the verse], and ye shall perish [quickly from off the good Land thus clearly intimating that even after ye shall perish from off the good Land you shall still put these My words in your heart]. But the main reference of the verse [even regarding personal obligations] applies to the Land, as it is written, that your days may be multiplied, and the days of your children, upon the Land; or it may be that the verse is stating: “that your days may be multiplied, so that you will return [to the Land] and you will prolong your days on it forever.”

Second, Ramban states that it is important to teach the commandments to children until they start teaching them to their children and also start sharing with you their ideas about the reasons for commandments:

In line with the plain meaning of Scripture, it is possible that he comes to add here the expression to speak of them, for there [in the first charge to the individual] he commanded and ‘thou’ shalt speak — you yourself — of them when ‘thou’ sittest in thy house, and here [in the charge to the community he stated that we are to teach the words of Torah to our children until they speak of them always. So also he added here and ye shall ‘teach’ them, for the term v’shinantom [mentioned there] means only that he shall “tell” them the commandments, and here [he added that the obligation extends] until they teach the words of Torah [to their children] and they understand them and their reasons [well enough] to discuss them with you at all times. So also he added here as the days of the heavens above the earth which means “for all generations,” or it may refer to the first heaven and earth, and the days of old.

title: Does Hashem not love us?
content:
# Does Hashem not love us? ## Frage

"Only your forefathers did Hashem desire, to love them." (Deuteronomy 10:15)

So Hashem doesn't love us? Why? Because we do not walk in his ways? So, if we are not afraid of Him, does He hate us?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Your presupposition is incorrect: It's not that Hashem loves our forefathers to the exclusion of us, it's to the exclusion of everyone else - "only" in this case refers to "only your forefathers amongst all the other people of their time." This can be extrapolated from the words of Rashi on this pasuk:

כְּמוֹ שֶׁאַתֶּם רוֹאִים אֶתְכֶם חֲשׁוּקִים מכל העמים היום הזה

Just as you see yourselves as the most beloved of all peoples, as it is this day.

In other words, "the same way as you're the most beloved of all peoples today, your forefathers were the only ones I desired in their time."

title: How does Kabbalah understand Iyov 35:6-7?
content:
# How does Kabbalah understand Iyov 35:6-7? ## Frage

Iyov 35:6-7 reads as follows:

(ו) אִם־חָ֭טָאתָ מַה־תִּפְעׇל־בּ֑וֹ וְרַבּ֥וּ פְ֝שָׁעֶ֗יךָ מַה־תַּֽעֲשֶׂה־לּֽוֹ׃ (ז) אִם־צָ֭דַקְתָּ מַה־תִּתֶּן־ל֑וֹ א֥וֹ מַה־מִּיָּדְךָ֥ יִקָּֽח׃

(6) If you have sinned, how do you affect Him? And if your transgressions are multiplied, what do you do to Him? (7) If you are righteous, what do you give Him, or what can He receive from your hand?

My understanding is that Kabbalah posits a rupture/imbalance/disharmony in the divine sefirot which our deeds are able to rectify.

How does Kabbalah understand these verses?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Answering this question makes up a large part of the ספר נפש החיים. He addresses these exact verses in section 2, chapter 4.

The short answer (he really elaborates on this throughout the entire book), is as follows:

There are two aspects to God (as we see it), one of them is His essence, and the other is His relationship/interaction with us.

We have ABSOLUTELY no understanding of His essence. It is above and beyond anything we can possibly relate to. It is only His relationship with us that we can [somewhat] grasp.

These verses in Iyov are referring to His essence. No human action can possibly impact God's essence. He has no needs. He was, is, and will always be exactly the same.

The concept of ספירות is God's interaction with this world. This is our relationship with Him, and in turn how He treats us. This is impacted (and really entirely based) by human action. If we do good, we strengthen and improve this relationship, and God in turn is kinder to us, spiritually and physically. If we do bad, we damage and hurt this relationship, and God in turn hides himself from us, resulting in bad spiritual and ultimately bad physical consequences.

This answer barely scratches the surface, most of נפש החיים discusses this, but that is the short answer to your question.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

The basic answer for this given is that Hashem doesn't need our Mitzvot in the way a human master needs the services of a servant. A human master needs the food that his servant prepares, needs the light and warmth of the fire that his servant starts, needs the produces of the fields that his servants work.

Hashem doesn't need the light of our menora. Hashem doesn't get injured if we shecht an animal from the back of the neck rather than the front of the neck. Those things are there to refine us, not Hashem, who doesn't need any refinement, improvements or the fulfilment of any lacks, ch'v.

However, who needs us to be refined? Hashem. This is the meaning of "Tzorech G'voha" we see throughout the Torah She'ba'al Peh, from Gemara, to Rishonim, to Kabbalah, to Chassidus and even Mussar. It is absolutely a Divine Need that His creations should be perfected.

So, don't try to be a tzaddik - are you trying to impress Hashem? What difference does it make to Him if you are a tzaddik or not? Just do the Mitzva. Your service is absolutely essential to Him.

Sources:

Avodat HaKodesh 3.

See it explained by the Sfat Emet in Likkutim to Sefer Netzach Yisrael:

בס׳ עבודת הקודש (פ״ג) מה איכפת לו להקב״ה בין שוחט מצואר כו׳, ותמה כי הלא עבודה צורך גבוה עיין שם מה שתירץ, ודבריו חסרין תבלין כי בקיצור הוה לי׳ למימר כנודע כי ב׳ בחינות יש, שפע לקיום תמידי ושפע להשפיע כמו שכתוב בס׳ ובזוה״ק על פסוק שחת לו לא עיין שם פירושו, ואפשר זה כוונתו גם כן אבל הנראה מפשטות לשונו הוא רחוק לדעתי כי מה איכפת לקב״ה קאי גם כן על בחינה זו שהוא צורך גבוה שהרי מסיים אלא לצרף כו׳, ובגוף הקושיא הי׳ נראה לתרץ כי שלימות האדם ודאי צורך גבוה מה שיקיים האדם מצות הש״י ועושה נחת רוח ליוצרו ומעלה מיין נוקבין ומקשר העולמות זה בזה על ידי שמעשיו על פי החכמה והשכל ומשפט דעת התורה, ומכל מקום גוף השחיטה אין צורך גבוה רק שאדם יאכל כשנשחט דוקא זה שניתן לצרף האדם, וצירוף האדם צורך גבוה, כי המדרש בא לומר שמצות הש״י הוא לצורך שלימות האדם ולא לטובת גבוה אבל שלימות האדם ודאי צורך גבוה כן נראה לי נכון, אבל מה שכתבתי מקודם הרא האמת ושניהם כאחד טובים ולשון המחבר מגומגם לענ״ד:

In Avodat HaKodesh (Chapter 3), [he asks]: “What difference is it to the Holy One, blessed be He, whether one slaughters from the neck [or from the back of the neck]?” And he expresses wonder at this, for divine service is, ostensibly, a Divine need. See there what he answers.

But his words are lacking seasoning, for he should have simply said what is well known, that there are two aspects: one is the flow [of Divine influence] for continual sustenance, and one is [the flow] to bring forth influence, as is explained in the Zohar and in sifrei Kabbalah on the verse “He corrupted (shichet) to Him, not [to Him]”; see there his explanation. And perhaps this is also his intent, but the simple reading of his words seems distant to me, because the expression “What difference is it to the Holy One, blessed be He” refers also to that level which is a Divine need, for the Midrash concludes: “[He commanded this] only to refine...”, etc.

And regarding the core question, it seems possible to answer as follows:

That the perfection of man is certainly a Divine need, in that man fulfills the commandments of the Holy One, blessed be He, and brings pleasure to his Creator, elevates the Mayin Nukvin, and connects the worlds with one another, through actions performed with wisdom, intellect, and the judgment of Torah knowledge.

Nevertheless, the act of shechita itself is not [intrinsically] a Divine need, but rather, that a person should eat only from what was slaughtered specifically in the manner prescribed. And this was given in order to refine the person, and the refinement of the person is a Divine need. For the Midrash comes to teach that the mitzvot of the Holy One, blessed be He, are for the purpose of the perfection of man, and not for the benefit of the Divine. But that perfection of man is, without a doubt, a Divine need. This, it seems to me, is the correct interpretation.

However, what I previously wrote reflects the true perspective, and both explanations are valid and complement one another. Still, in my opinion, the author’s wording is unclear and lacking precision.

See also Lo Tih'ye Mishakela 5712 by the Lubavitcher Rebbe, who says the same thing (and even quotes OP's Iyov in part 1), and clarifies in part 4 that this need - for His people to be refined - applies to Hashem Himself. Stunning!

title: Yehuda Handed Over Samson to the Philistines Because he was a Rodef; but Isn't Battling the Philistines (What Samson did) the Right Thing to do?
content:
# Yehuda Handed Over Samson to the Philistines Because he was a Rodef; but Isn't Battling the Philistines (What Samson did) the Right Thing to do? ## Frage

The Rambam (Laws of Foundations of Torah 5:5) states:

. וְכֵן אִם אָמְרוּ לָהֶם עוֹבְדֵי כּוֹכָבִים תְּנוּ לָנוּ אֶחָד מִכֶּם וְנַהַרְגֶּנּוּ וְאִם לָאו נַהֲרֹג כֻּלְּכֶם. יֵהָרְגוּ כֻּלָּם וְאַל יִמְסְרוּ לָהֶם נֶפֶשׁ אַחַת מִיִּשְׂרָאֵל. וְאִם יִחֲדוּהוּ לָהֶם וְאָמְרוּ תְּנוּ לָנוּ פְּלוֹנִי אוֹ נַהֲרֹג אֶת כֻּלְּכֶם. אִם הָיָה מְחֻיָּב מִיתָה כְּשֶׁבַע בֶּן בִּכְרִי יִתְּנוּ אוֹתוֹ לָהֶם. וְאֵין מוֹרִין לָהֶם כֵּן לְכַתְּחִלָּה. וְאִם אֵינוֹ חַיָּב מִיתָה יֵהָרְגוּ כֻּלָּן וְאַל יִמְסְרוּ לָהֶם נֶפֶשׁ אַחַת מִיִּשְׂרָאֵל:

Similarly, if gentiles told [a group of Jews]: "Give us one of you to kill. If not, we will kill all of you," they should allow themselves all to be killed rather than give over a single soul to [the gentiles]. However, if [the gentiles] single out [a specific individual] and say: "Give us so and so or we will kill all of you," [different rules apply]: If the person is obligated to die like Sheva ben Bichri, they may give him over to them. Initially, however, this instruction is not conveyed to them. If he is not obligated to die, they should allow themselves all to be killed rather than give over a single soul to [the gentiles].

The Or Sameach:

ומה שבשמשון באו אנשי יהודה לאסרך לתתך ביד פלשתים, אף שלא הי' חייב מיתה, נראה משום דמסכן רבים והוי כעוסק בזיופים סימן תכ"ח בהגה. וזה מה עשית לנו כו'. and that regarding Samson, where the men of Judah came to tie you to hand you over to the Philistines, even though he was not liable to die, it appears because he endangered the masses and was tantamount to one who enages in forgery (Choshen Mishpat, section 428 in the Rama glosses) "and that is "what have you done to us."

But shouldn't Yehuda have waged war to conquer the land as mandated by God? How can they avail themselves of a Rodef analysis? Joining Samson and waging open war and thus willingly endangering themselves was arguably the right thing to so!

title: How does Rav Kotler assign final letters in 5 cases in Vayikra-Bamidbar?
content:
# How does Rav Kotler assign final letters in 5 cases in Vayikra-Bamidbar? ## Frage

I heard in the name of Mishnas Rabbi Aharon that there is a correspondence between the final letters of Hebrew Alphabet (ך-ם-ן-ף-ץ) and the five cases in the Torah when people did not know the halakha so they asked Hashem about it, namely

  1. The case of blasphemer (Vayikra 24:10-23)
  2. Pesach Sheini (Bamidbar 9:1-14)
  3. The gatherer of the wood (Bamidbar 15:32-36)
  4. The affair with b'nos Moav (Bamidbar 25:1-18)
  5. The case of b'nos Tzlafchad (Bamidbar 27:1-23 and Bamidbar 36:1-12)

I do not have the sefer. How does R' Kotler assign letters to these cases? Is it his chidush? What is the reasoning for the assignment?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 11)

The mnemonic is as follows:

מ - מקושש העצים ביום השבת ... (במדבר ט"ו, לב)

נ - נוקב שם ה' ... (ויקרא כ"ד, י"ב)

צ - צלפחד ... (במדבר כ"ז, ה)

פ - פסח שני ... (במדבר ט, ח)

כ - כזבי במעשה זימרי ... (במדבר כ"ה, ט"ו)
