title: Comprehensive explanation of targum onkelus
content:
# Comprehensive explanation of targum onkelus ## Frage

I have the sefer ya'in hatov which translates and explains select passages from the various targumim on the chumash.

What I'm looking for is a sefer that does this word for word.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

I highly recommend Parshegen (explanations and sources for Targum Onkelos) by the scholar Rabbi Refael Binyamin Posen. That sefer goes through the Chumash verse by verse, explaining when Onkelos' translation is not straightforward or literal. You should be able to find it at quality Jewish book stores or by searching the internet for Parshegen and Onkelos. Unfortunately, this has been published for only four of the five books of Chumash so far; a volume on Sefer Devarim (Deuteronomy) has not yet been published.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 5)

Artscroll has recently put out a set of full Targum Onkelos Translation with commentary. Previously a similar work was done by Israel Drazin and Stanley Wagner as Onkelos on the Torah (Rav Posen quotes this work). Other Targumim are translated in Sefaria but with little commentary.

There are also other helpful books about the outlook and style of the Targum Onkelos author, which illustrate common patterns in the texts:

  • "The Consistency of Targum Onkelos' Translation" (in Hebrew) by R' Rafael B. Posen
  • "Understanding Onkelos, the Greatest Bible Translator" by Stanley W. Wagner and Israel Drazin

title: Why aren't Chesed-related Mitzvot stand-alone Biblical commandments?
content:
# Why aren't Chesed-related Mitzvot stand-alone Biblical commandments? ## Frage

In MT Mourning 14.1, Rambam lists several Chessed-related Miztvahs:

"Those are Rabbinic commandments:
~ to visit the sick,
~ to comfort mourners,
~ to prepare for a funeral,
~ prepare a bride, ~ to welcome guests,
~ to attend to all the needs of a burial,
~ to carry a corpse on one's shoulders,
~ walk before the bier,
~ to mourn,
~ to dig a grave, and bury the dead,
~ to bring joy to a bride and groom and help them in all their needs.
These are deeds of kindness that one carries out with their person that have no limit.
Although all these mitzvot are of Rabbinic origin, they are included in the Scriptural commandment Leviticus 19:18: "Love your neighbor as yourself.""

Why didn't the Torah care to explicate all those "deeds of kindness" as stand-alone Mitzvahs?

For comparison, there are 13 stand-alone action-less Mitzvahs for something to "become impure" / "inflict impurity" (Positive_Mitzvot.96-108):

96 For everyone who comes in contact with the corpse of an animal to become impure,
97 For the dead bodies of the eight species of crawling animals to impart ritual impurity,
98 For certain foods to impart impurity,
99 For a woman in the niddah state to be impure and to impart impurity to others.
910 For a woman who gives birth to be impure [like a woman] in the niddah state.
101 For a person afflicted with tzara’at to be impure and to impart impurity.
102 For a garment afflicted with tzara’at to be impure and to impart impurity.
103 For a house afflicted with tzara’at to impart impurity.
104 For a zav to impart impurity.
105 For semen to impart impurity.
106 For a zavah to impart impurity.
107 For a corpse to impart impurity.
108 For the sprinkling water used for the red heifer to impart impurity.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

For all the mentioned impurities, they are all mentioned in the Torah each one in a Pasuk.

For the Chesed related Mitzvos, they are all "deeds of kindness that one carries out with their person that have no limit", which is part of the Mitzvah of Ve'ahavta Lera'acha Kamocha.

title: Why is birkat hamazon so long?
content:
# Why is birkat hamazon so long? ## Frage

I've heard it said that the current Birkat HaMazon is the result of various additions over millennia. How was it put together and why is it so long today?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

Yeah, that’s accurate.

I made a document of Birkat Hamazon, but only including what every attested nusach contains, and excluding the rest. (Parenthesis and slashes indicate an unresolvable wording difference.):

בָּרוּךְ אַתָּה יְיָ אֱלֹהֵינוּ מֶלֶךְ הָעוֹלָם הַזָּן אֶת הָעוֹלָם כֻּלּוֹ בְּטוֹב בְּחֵן בְּחֶסֶד וּבְרַחֲמִים. בָּרוּךְ אַתָּה יְיָ הַזָּן אֶת הַכֹּל.
נוֹדֶה לְּךָ יְיָ אֱלֹהֵינוּ (כִּי/עַל שֶׁ־) הִנְחַלְתָּנוּ אֶרֶץ חֶמְדָּה טוֹבָה וּרְחָבָה בְּרִית וְתּוֹרָה חַיִּים וּמָזוֹן. עַל הַכֻּל אֲנוּ מוֹדִים לַךְ וּמְבָרְכִים אֶת שְׁמַךְ. בָּרוּךְ אַתָּה יְיָ עַל הָאָרֶץ וְעַל הַמָּזוֹן.
רַחֵם יְיָ אֱלֹהֵינוּ עַל יִשְׂרָאֵל עַמָּךְ וְעַל יְרוּשָׁלַיְם עִירָךְ וְעַל צִיּוֹן מִשְׁכַּן כְּבוֹדָךְ וְעַל הַבַּיְת הַגָּדוֹל וְהַקָּדוֹשׁ שֶׁנִּקְרָא שִׁמְךָ עָלָיו. (וּבְנֵה/וְתִבְנֶה) יְרוּשֲׁלֵם בְּקָרוֹב. בָּרוּךְ אַתָּה יְיָ בּוֹנֵה יְרוּשֲׁלֵם: בלחש אָמֵן
בָּרוּךְ אַתָּה יְהֹוָה אֱלֹהֵינוּ מֶלֶךְ הָעוֹלָם, הָאֵל אָבִינוּ, מַלְכֵּנוּ, בּוֹרְאֵנוּ, הַמֶּלֶךְ הַטּוֹב וְהַמֵּטִיב, שֶׁבְּכָל יוֹם וָיוֹם הוּא גוֹמְלֵנוּ חֵן וָחֶסֶד וְרַחֲמִים וְכָל-טוֹב.
הָרַחְמָן יִשְׁתַּבַּח לְדוֹר דּוֹרִים (וְ־/הָרַחְמָן)יִתְפָּאַר לְנֵצַח נְצָחִים. הָרַחְמָן יְפַרְנְסֵנוּ בְּכָבוֹד.

As we go back in history, we find shorter and shorter texts of Birkat Hamazon; so this reconstruction is a reasonable approximation of an ancient version.

It is stated in Rabbinic sources that the fourth blessing—an extended version of הטוב והמיטיב—was added by Rabbinic decree. So that, and the three ״הָרַחְמָן״s after it, can be removed for something very roughly approximating the post-exilic version.

It is also stated that the third blessing was added by דוד המלך. This leaves only the first two paragraphs as original.

We can also assume that the text preceding the second blessing was added later.

This leaves the following very minimal, and very speculative, pre-davidic blessing:

בָּרוּךְ אַתָּה יְיָ אֱלֹהֵינוּ מֶלֶךְ הָעוֹלָם הַזָּן אֶת הָעוֹלָם כֻּלּוֹ בְּטוֹב בְּחֵן בְּחֶסֶד וּבְרַחֲמִים. בָּרוּךְ אַתָּה יְיָ הַזָּן אֶת הַכֹּל.
בָּרוּךְ אַתָּה יְיָ עַל הָאָרֶץ וְעַל הַמָּזוֹן.

(It might be possible that the פתיחה of the first blessing is also a Rabbinic addition. Removing that would get an even shorter prayer of thirteen words.)

### Antwort 2 (Score: 3)

A short answer, is that there was accumulation of variations as stated by @Qwertrl. A fuller answer to this question is given in the book "Birkas haMazon" based on the commentary of R. Shabtai Soffer with various additions, produced by R. Yitzchak Satz, R. David Yitzchaki, and R. David Salomon. It was published by Otzreinu, Toronto, Canada. Specifically, pp. 83 - 128, Kuntres Birkas haMazon, gives all the variations in the nusach of the blessing with many sources. Since it is not an easily found edition, the book title and Kuntres title are enclosed.

title: In the days of Ezra, why did the returned exiles put away Egyptian wives?
content:
# In the days of Ezra, why did the returned exiles put away Egyptian wives? ## Frage

Deuteronomy 23:8-9 seems to give permission to marry Egyptian wives:

לֹֽא־תְתַעֵ֣ב אֲדֹמִ֔י כִּ֥י אָחִ֖יךָ ה֑וּא לֹא־תְתַעֵ֣ב מִצְרִ֔י כִּי־גֵ֖ר הָיִ֥יתָ בְאַרְצֽוֹ׃ You shall not abhor an Edomite, for such is your kin. You shall not abhor an Egyptian, for you were a stranger in that land. בָּנִ֛ים אֲשֶׁר־יִוָּלְד֥וּ לָהֶ֖ם דּ֣וֹר שְׁלִישִׁ֑י יָבֹ֥א לָהֶ֖ם בִּקְהַ֥ל יְהֹוָֽה׃ {ס}         Children born to them may be admitted into the congregation of יהוה in the third generation.

Why, then, in Ezra 9:1-2 did the returned exiles consider it wrong to have married Egyptian women?

וּכְכַלּ֣וֹת אֵ֗לֶּה נִגְּשׁ֨וּ אֵלַ֤י הַשָּׂרִים֙ לֵאמֹ֔ר לֹֽא־נִבְדְּל֞וּ הָעָ֤ם יִשְׂרָאֵל֙ וְהַכֹּהֲנִ֣ים וְהַלְוִיִּ֔ם מֵעַמֵּ֖י הָאֲרָצ֑וֹת כְּ֠תֹעֲבֹֽתֵיהֶ֠ם לַכְּנַעֲנִ֨י הַחִתִּ֜י הַפְּרִזִּ֣י הַיְבוּסִ֗י הָֽעַמֹּנִי֙ הַמֹּ֣אָבִ֔י הַמִּצְרִ֖י וְהָאֱמֹרִֽי׃ When this was over, the officers approached me, saying, “The people of Israel and the priests and Levites have not separated themselves from the peoples of the land whose abhorrent practices are like those of the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Jebusites, the Ammonites, the Moabites, the Egyptians, and the Amorites. כִּֽי־נָשְׂא֣וּ מִבְּנֹֽתֵיהֶ֗ם לָהֶם֙ וְלִבְנֵיהֶ֔ם וְהִתְעָֽרְבוּ֙ זֶ֣רַע הַקֹּ֔דֶשׁ בְּעַמֵּ֖י הָאֲרָצ֑וֹת וְיַ֧ד הַשָּׂרִ֣ים וְהַסְּגָנִ֗ים הָ֥יְתָ֛ה בַּמַּ֥עַל הַזֶּ֖ה רִאשׁוֹנָֽה׃ They have taken their daughters as wives for themselves and for their sons, so that the holy seed has become intermingled with the peoples of the land; and it is the officers and prefects who have taken the lead in this trespass.”

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

Deuteronomy is talking about converts from those nations. As the Ralbag points out, in Ezra's time, Jewish men had married non-Jewish women who hadn't converted (and had no interest in doing so).

Ralbag:

ידמה שנשאום בגויתן שאם לא היה כן לא היה אסור בדבר בכל הגוים שזכר כי אם כמצרי

Presumably they married them in a non-Jewish state; otherwise [i.e. had they converted], there would have been no prohibition in all of the nations mentioned here, other than the Egyptians [who require a two-generation delay].

Malbim basically drives this point home as well -- note the language. "These Jews are not separate from the locals and their abominations." That once the Jewish men married local non-Jewish women, their behavior was no different than the surrounding nations:

לא נבדלו, פי' שאין הבדל ביניהם ובין עם הארץ, א] במה שהם עושים כתועבותם

כי נשאו מבנותיהם להם, ואמר מלת כי, באשר מה שנשאו מבנותם הוא הסבה שיעשו כתועבותיהם,

There is no "separation", i.e. difference, between the Jewish men and the local nations in their doing the same abominations; their marrying non-Jewish women is the reason that they followed the local abominations.

The two explanations go hand-in-hand. The women hadn't converted, and were in fact influencing their husbands away from Judaism. That's very different from Deuteronomy's case, of a sincere convert, where our only concern is national lineage -- and the language used is of them joining us. (Ezra's case really was us joining them.)

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

There is a more extended comment on this subject with some musar from Chofetz Chaim on the Torah, parsha Ki Tisa:

בימי עזרא היו ראוין ישראל להעשות להם נס כבימי יהושע בן נון, אלא שגרם החטא. והטאם היה שלוש מאות איש נשאו נשים נכריות ועבר זמן של יותר משלושים שנה עד שבאו לכלל ממשלה קטנה ברשיון מלכי פרס. בשביל מה? בשביל ששלוש מאות איש נשאו נשים נכריות. והגע בעצמך, שלש מאות איש מבין ארבעים אלף, איזה אחוז הוא זה? והקולר היה תלוי בצואר כל ישראל.

In the days of Ezra, Israel merited to have a miracle to be performed for them, as in the days of Yehoshua bin Nun, except that sin prevented it (see Berachos 4a). And the problem was that three hundred men married foreign women (without converting them). It took the Jewish community more than thirty years to address the matter, and as a result, they got a small government rule with the permission of the Persian kings. For what? Because three hundred men married foreign women. And come to think of it, three hundred men out of forty thousand, what percentage is that? And the "chain/collar got hanged" around the necks" (Shavuos 31a) of all Israel.

In other words, the wives of the men did not convert, and they had children who did not grow up Jewish.

title: Is the Targum Onkelos halachically binding?
content:
# Is the Targum Onkelos halachically binding? ## Frage

While many meforshim use Onkelos in their exegesis, are his translations of the Hebrew halachically binding? Sources will be highly appreciated.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 10)

As noted by Rabbi Binyamin Posen zt"l (who was an expert on Targum Onkelos) in Parshegen on Beresheet (in Hebrew), pp. 36-37, n. 23; and in "Targum Onkelos According to the Writings of Maimonides" (in Hebrew), pp. 240-241, nn. 9-10, Rambam is known to have ruled on occasion according to Onkelos, whom he viewed in high regard (see here). Some examples of such rulings:

Sefer Ha'Mitzvot, Positive no. 36

"And that is that He commanded us that the priests serve in watches, each watch serving one week. And the hand of all should not be mixed together (in service); except on festivals when all of the watches serve equally and anyone who comes from them can offer a sacrifice. [...] I might think that all of the watches are [also] equal for offerings brought on the festival not for the sake of the festival. [Hence] we learn to say, 'aside from the sale of the fathers' (Deuteronomy 18:8) - what the fathers sold to each other, i.e., 'You [take them] on your Shabbat, and I on my Shabbat.'" This means their agreement about all of the watches of the service, one watch for each week. And so did Onkelos (Targum Onkelos on Deuteronomy 18:8), explain, "except for the allotment which comes on Shabbat, as our (fore)fathers have regulated." And they have already explained the laws of this commandment at the end of the Gemara in Sukkah."

Ibid., Negative no. 128

"That He prohibited us from feeding the Pesach-offering to an Israelite who has defected. And that is His, may He be exalted, saying, "no foreigner may eat from it" (Exodus 12:43). The translator (Targum Onkelos Exodus 12:43) [translated this as], "no Israelite that defected." [...]"

Laws of Forbidden Intercourse 12:13

"This transgression should not be light in one's eyes, because it does not involve lashes according to Scriptural Law. For this [act] also causes the son to be turned away from following God. For a son born of a maid-servant is a servant and is not a [full] member of Israel. Thus he causes [Israel's] holy seed to be profaned and produce servants. Behold Onkelos the translator included relations with a servant and a maid-servant in [the prohibitions, Deuteronomy 23:18]: "There shall not be a promiscuous man and there shall not be a promiscuous woman.""

Laws of Mourning 5:19:

"Which source teaches that a mourner is forbidden to uncover his head? Ezekiel was instructed Ezekiel 24:17: "Do not veil your face until the lips." Implied is that others are obligated to cover their heads. He should use the sash with which he covers his head and wind a portion of it over his mouth slightly. In this vein, Onkelos renders Leviticus 13:45: "He should veil his face until his lips," as "He should cover himself like a mourner.""

There are also instances in which Rambam ruled differently than Onkelos and the targum was brought up as a source for overruling the Rambam's position, as the Kesef Mishneh does in his commentary on Laws of Daily Offerings and Additional Offerings 3:12, along with Tosfot Yom Tov on Mishna Tamid 3:9 and Ateret Zekenim on Shulchan Aruch, O"C § 48, and as the Mishneh La'Melech demonstrated in Laws of the Temple Vessels and Those Who Serve Therein 9:6.

Some other poskim who cited Onkelos as a halachic authority include: Ran on Kiddushin 14a; Ma'aseh Rokeach in Laws of Defilement by Leprosy 1:6, Aroch Ha'Shulchan, E"H § 4:1 (though he disagreed with him), and so forth.

title: How are we to understand the history of machlokot?
content:
# How are we to understand the history of machlokot? ## Frage

It seems to be a simple question, but not one I was taught to think about when learning mishna/gemara.

Take the machloket of Rabbi Yose Hagelili and the rabbis regarding eating chicken and milk, where Rabbi Yose holds that one is allowed to eat them together and the rabbis (Rabbi Akiva) hold that is is rabbinically prohibited. What in essence is the argument? Are they arguing on whether a gezera actually was decreed upon in the past? Or is their machloket happening in real time such that in that specific time period the Sanhedrin declared it to be rabbinically prohibited? If the former, are we saying that the people forgot whether or not an official gezera was made? If the latter, how did the people of the Galil continue to eat chicken and milk if the Sanhedrin declared it prohibited?

The same can be asked about other machlokot such as Rabbi Shimon and Rabbi Yehuda regarding muktzeh or Beit Hillel and Beit Shammai regarding an egg that is laid on Yom Tov.

Note that I am asking in all these cases about rabbinic prohibitions but I believe the same can be asked about machlokot regarding Biblical prohibitions.

title: Onkelus's choice of translation to Babylonian Aramaic
content:
# Onkelus's choice of translation to Babylonian Aramaic ## Frage

Being that Onkelus, the author of Targum Onkelus, lived in Eretz Israel. Why did he write his translation in Babylonian Aramaic?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 11)

In the past it was supposed by some scholars that the language of Targum Onkelos is Babylonian Aramaic, but today it is more commonly accepted that TO was composed in Eretz Yisrael using Eretz-Yisraeli Aramaic. Its final editing stages, however, occurred later, in Babylon. See for example Rimon Kasher, "The Aramaic Targums on the Pentateuch" (in Hebrew), Pe'amim 83 (2000/5760), pp. 80-81. Edward Cook however proposed in 1994 that TO was composed in Central Aramaic. Either way, it seems that the linguistic base of TO was not an Eastern Aramaic dialect (which is what Babylonian Aramaic is).

title: Why is the Midrash criticizing Noach for planting a vineyard?
content:
# Why is the Midrash criticizing Noach for planting a vineyard? ## Frage

Jewish tradition views the act of Noach planting a vineyard negatively, for example, Midrash Rabba 36:3:

“Noah, man of the soil, began [vayaḥel]” – he became profaned and unholy [ḥulin]. Why? “And he planted a vineyard.” Should he not have planted something else, that was constructive, a fig tree branch or an olive tree branch? Instead, “he planted a vineyard.”

In this link there is a quote from Ralbag who suggested that perhaps it was not so.

Indeed, water is the basic need for men. A man cannot survive without water more than 3-7 days (from being fully fit and healthy), compared to much longer times that a man can survive without food. In the ancient world, the most common technology to purify water was to add wine to it. A typical ratio was one measure of wine to 3-4 measures of water. Boiling water was not always possible, especially after the flood, when no dry wood could be found (or in arid areas). Why is the act of Noach perceived negatively from the beginning if it was a good deed necessary for survival?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Thus, in Jewish discourse, Ralbag’s sober observation and the Midrash’s moral rebuke are not necessarily contradictory, but rather illuminate two sides of the same coin. Jewish tradition often preserves divergent interpretations without contradiction; here, philosophical realism (Ralbag) and ethical admonition (Midrash) together build a fuller picture.

Ralbag tells us: Noah wanted to produce wine and succeeded – that is a fact. Ralbag presents the account as a plain statement of events, focusing on human agency and capacity without immediate judgment.

The Midrash tells us: But it was the wrong decision at that time – that is a value judgment. The Midrash adds a moral frame, interpreting Noah’s choice as flawed due to its timing and spiritual insensitivity.

Together they teach: In all your actions, consider not only whether you can do it, but whether you should, whether it is appropriate now, and where it might lead. This joined lesson encourages ethical reflection before action – a key principle in Jewish ethics rooted in both ability and discernment.

Noah was “wise in agriculture,” yet the wisdom of the righteous path only emerged through the critique of his misstep. Noah’s technical skill is not denied, but true wisdom — in the eyes of the Torah — is moral wisdom, which becomes visible through the consequences of his actions.

Thus Noah, the righteous one, becomes a lasting figure of instruction: His story warns us to recognize the boundaries between enjoyment and responsibility. Despite his title as a “tzaddik” (righteous man), Noah’s failings are made instructive; his status enhances, rather than diminishes, the significance of the lesson.

In the words of the Sages: “Beware the passion of wine,” for to Noah it brought a loud “וַי” – Woe! – in multiple forms. A play on words from the Torah’s “vayachel” and “vayishkar” leads to the sound “vay” (woe), symbolizing sorrow. The sages warn of wine’s power to bring downfall even to the righteous.

Had he instead begun with a fig tree, perhaps the Torah would tell a different story – but then we would have learned less about ourselves. This counterfactual highlights that Noah’s mistake serves a didactic function: through his error, readers gain insight into human weakness and the need for restraint.

Noah’s vineyard is ultimately both encouragement and warning: On the one hand, it shows the pitfalls of human nature (even a righteous man is not immune to temptation), on the other, it reminds us never to lose sight of our divine mission due to worldly enticements. His act stands as both caution and hope — acknowledging human frailty but calling for spiritual vigilance.

The Torah criticizes Noah so that we may do better: First plant what is necessary and good – then, at the right time and in moderation, wine may also gladden the heart without defiling it. The final teaching is aspirational: the Torah’s critique aims at improvement. When priorities are rightly ordered, even pleasures like wine can be sanctified rather than corrupted.

The Rambam (Hilchos Brachos 10:18) says:

וְכֵן כְּשֶׁתַּחֲזֹר הַלְּבָנָה לִתְחִלַּת מַזַּל טָלֶה בִּתְחִלַּת הַחֹדֶשׁ וְלֹא תִּהְיֶה נוֹטָה לֹא לְצָפוֹן וְלֹא לְדָרוֹם. וְכֵן כְּשֶׁיַּחֲזֹר כָּל כּוֹכָב וְכוֹכָב מֵחֲמֵשֶׁת הַכּוֹכָבִים הַנִּשְׁאָרִים לִתְחִלַּת מַזַּל טָלֶה וְלֹא יִהְיֶה נוֹטֶה לֹא לְצָפוֹן וְלֹא לְדָרוֹם. וְכֵן בְּכָל עֵת שֶׁיִּרְאֶה מַזַּל טָלֶה עוֹלֶה מִקְּצֵה הַמִּזְרָח עַל כָּל אֶחָד מֵאֵלּוּ מְבָרֵךְ עוֹשֶׂה בְּרֵאשִׁית:

Similarly, the blessing "who performs the work of creation" should be recited when the moon reaches the beginning of the zodiac constellation taleh at the beginning of the month when it is not pointing to the north or the south, when any of the other five stars [that revolve in separate spheres] arrive at the beginning of the constellation taleh and do not point to the north or the south, and when one sees the constellation taleh ascend to the eastern corner [of the sky].

Are there any Poskim who rule practically that we make a brachah on the moon (or any of the five stars) when they reach Mazal Taleh? This seems to be the understanding of some Rishonim in Brachos (59b).

title: Why did people cook wine 2,000 years ago?
content:
# Why did people cook wine 2,000 years ago? ## Frage

Today wine is cooked for pasteurization which is a relatively recent invention.

Nevertheless the Talmud discusses "ya'in mevushal" (cooked wine) at length: it is invalid for avoda zarah so the restrictions are somewhat relaxed.

My question is why did people 2k years ago bear the expense and trouble of cooking wine.

Just to be able to have a drink with a gentile friend?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

There are other reasons for why one could cook the wine. At the time of mishna wine was used as water desinfectant as technology to purify water was not developed. As reported by Santorini Wine Tour:

The ancient Greeks and Romans indeed mixed water and wine – but technically they put wine in their water more than they put water in their wine. At that time, wine was also considered a way to purify and improve the taste of (often stagnant) water, but mainly by mixing wine with water, they could avoid all the unpleasant consequences of still wine.

Three or four parts water to one part wine are usually reported but other ratios have also been recorded. There are also reports of adding lemon, spices, or even seawater to dilute the wine. You may have heard of a mixture of honey and wine that sounds strange today but was very popular back then.

The quality of the wine was taken into account in the mixing ratio. That is, strong wines were diluted with more water. The ratio of the mixture was three parts water to one part wine. Hesiod, advising his brother Persis, in the summertime, suggests to him three parts of water to one part of the wine.

Hesiod was an ancient Greek poet, his words about deluting wine are found in his poem "Works and Days" written as an advice to his brother Persis on the virtues of work and wisdom over material wealth. Additionally, according to R. Phillips, A Short History of Wine, pp. 35–45, "on average, each member of Rome's urban population (man, woman, or child) consumed half a litre of undiluted wine daily." Therefore, daily handling of open bottles with wine was extremely important, because in some situations Jews had to rely on non-Jews to do so. Having wine mevushal provided the possibility to do so.

According to halacha, open bottles of mevushal wine can be handled by non-Jews and this was important for Jews working with non-Jewish laborers, or for a Jewish family operating an eatery / restaurant or a hotel with non-Jewish workers.

This point is also discussed elsewhere at more extent.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

A secular reason for boiling wine would be to make a wine syrup. You could use it as a sauce, additive to other wines, or as a portable wine.

# Finding out you have been using the wrong name ## Frage

A person has been called Avraham his whole life, including being called up to the torah, signing ketuba, etc. Now, Avraham finds out that the name given to him at his brit milah is actually Yaakov. What now?

Should he start going by Yaakov when being called up to the Torah and change/rewrite his ketuba? Or does the fact that he was always called Avraham have any halachic significance? Additionally, what if he had two names, and found out only one of them was correct, or he went by one name, and found out he had two?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

This talks about a case where a man had two names but only one was written on his ketuba. It was ruled that he did not need to alter his ketuba, because the name used on his ketuba was the name he was always called. Based on this, Avraham should continue to be called Avraham. The source does mention however that on a gett, they would mention the second name as well. Consult an orthodox rabbi.

title: Can you buy a lottery ticket from a Tzedaka Organization using maaser money?
content:
# Can you buy a lottery ticket from a Tzedaka Organization using maaser money? ## Frage

Can you buy a lottery ticket from a Tzedaka Organization using maaser money? And if you win can you just donate the original amount paid for the lottery ticket and keep the rest?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Many authorities permit buying lottery tickets from Tzedakah organizations, using Maaser money. Among them is Rabbi Shmuel Wosner (Shut Shevet Halevi Vol.9, #200).

The question is what happens if the ticket wins a prize.

Rabbi Moshe Feinstein (Shut Igros Moshe, OC IV, #76.2) posits, that essentially the winnings belong to the person who bought the ticket, however it is worthy to return the price of ticket to Maaser.

R' Feinstein adds, that the person would also have to give Maaser on the gain from the winning, and the Maaser should be given to the organization that ran the lottery.

Rabbi Yisrael Yaakov Fisher (Shut Even Yisrael, Vol. 8, #64) argues on R' Feinstein and holds that the entire winnings must be turned over to Maaser.

Rabbi Chaim Kanievsky (Derech Emunah, Matnos Aniim, Chap. 7, p.123a, in Biur Hahalachah) also leaned to this position. R' Kanievsky adds, that one may also not stipulate [when buying the ticket], that if the ticket wins then he will return the price of ticket, and retain the winnings for himself.

Further discussion, see Rabbi Moshe Sternbuch (Shut Tshuvos Ve'Hanhagos, Vol. 3, #289).

title: How were the borders of the 12 regions of Eretz Yisroel determined?
content:
# How were the borders of the 12 regions of Eretz Yisroel determined? ## Frage

In the Torah portion of Pinchas the division of the Land of Canaan is described as being determined by a lottery system, with two boxes containing the names of the tribes and the regions. Can you provide insight into how the 12 regions were defined and allocated prior to the lottery? Specifically, who and how were the boundaries determined for these regions?

Did Hashem tell Moshe the borders of all the 12 portions, which were then put on lots into the box?

This suggested duplicate sounds like my question but there is no real answer there: How the tribes' borders were determined?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

In Yehoshua 13:7, Hashem tells Yehoshua:

ועתה חלק את־הארץ הזאת בנחלה לתשעת השבטים וחצי השבט המנשה

Therefore, divide this territory into hereditary portions for the nine tribes and the half-tribe of Manasseh.

Metzudat David comments:

רצה לומר, בתחלה חלק הארץ לתשעה חלקים ומחצה כמנין השבטים הנוחלים, ואחר זה הטל הגורל לדעת איזה חלק למי

i.e. first divide the land up into 9.5 portions, corresponding to the number of tribes taking a portion, and then cast lots to decide who gets which portion.

So, according to Metzudat David, it was Yehoshua who divided the land up into its various portions, which were then allocated between the tribes via a lottery.

title: What happens when an Onen writes a Torah?
content:
# What happens when an Onen writes a Torah? ## Frage

When someone's relative has died and the relative has not yet been buried, the living person is an "Onein" and is said to be exempt from positive mitzvot.

We say women, minors, insane are exempt from mitzvot to various degrees. If one of these people were to write a Torah or Mezuzah, the item would be pasul because they don't have an obligation to write it.

Since the Onein is also exempt from positive Mitzvot, is the Torah, Mezuzah, Tefillin he writes pasul?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

Rabbi Yosef Shaul Nathanson, in Shut Sho'el Umeishiv (Tinyana,IV,end of #174) posits that if a scribe became an Onen, and he continued writing STaM, his writing is kosher, because he is NOT considered "אינו בר קשירה" (one who is totally removed from the מצוה of Tefillin), and his writing would not be disqualified.

This ruling is echoed by the Sdei Chemed, cited in Shut Pri HaSadeh (Vol. 4, #33).

For further discussion: Shut Divrei Chein, by R' Chaim Nathanson (#24).

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

Came across the following in the Tur OC 98:4

טור אורח חיים צ"ח:ד' שהתפלה היא במקום הקרבן דכתיב ונשלמה פרים שפתינו (הושע יד) וכתיב ולעבדו בכל לבבכם וכי יש עבודה בלב אלא איזו היא עבודה שהיא בלב הוי אומר זו תפלה ולכך צריך ליזהר שתהא דוגמת הקרבן בכוונה ולא יערב בה מחשבה אחרת כמו מחשבה שפוסלת בקדשים ומעומד דומיא דעבודה דכתיב לעמוד לשרת והשוואת הרגלים ככהנים בשעת העבודה וקביעות מקום כמו הקרבנות שכל אחד קבוע מקומו לשחיטתו ומתן דמיו ושלא יחוץ דבר בינו לבין הקיר ובינו לקרקע דוגמת הקרבן שחציצה פוסלת בינו לבין הכלי ובינו לרצפה וראוי הוא שיהיו לו מלבושים נאים מיוחדים לתפלה כגון בגדי כהונה אלא שאין כל אדם יכול לבזבז על זה ומ"מ טוב הוא שיהיו לו מכנסים מיוחדים לתפלה משום נקיות ואחר שיעשה דוגמת הקרבן עולה לריח ניחוח למקום שהקרבן עולה והמלאך עושה אותו כתר לקונו.

Since prayer stands in place of the sacrifice, as it is written, 'So we will offer the words of our lips instead of bulls' (Hosea 14:3), and it is written, 'And to serve Him with all your heart'—and is there a service of the heart? What is the service that is in the heart? You must say: this is prayer—therefore, one must take care that it be like the sacrifice, with intention, and that no foreign thought be intermingled within it, just as an improper thought invalidates sacrificial offerings. And [prayer must be recited] standing—similar to the Temple service, as it is written, 'to stand and serve.' One should keep the feet together like the priests during the Temple service, and establish a fixed place for prayer, just as the offerings each had a designated place for their slaughter and for the application of their blood. And nothing should interpose between him and the wall, or between him and the ground—similar to the offering, where an interposition invalidates between it and the vessel, or between it and the floor. And it is fitting that one have special, fine garments designated for prayer, like the priestly garments. However, not everyone is able to spend on this. Still, it is good to have pants designated specifically for prayer, for the sake of cleanliness. And after one has made [his prayer] like a sacrifice, it ascends as a pleasing aroma to God, as the sacrifice ascends, and the angel makes it into a crown for his Creator."

title: Did the use of Adar II cause the months to be out of synchronization with the moon for one month?
content:
# Did the use of Adar II cause the months to be out of synchronization with the moon for one month? ## Frage

I am trying to understand how leap months were handled in the days of Moses. I know that the month of Nisan will always contain 30 days. The month of Shevat always has 30 days. In a regular year Adar will have 29 days which means the following Nisan can contain 30 days and the months stay in sync with the lunar cycle. But what happens when an additional leap month is inserted? It seems like the additional month disrupts the alternating 30 day followed by 29 days sequencing.

Scenario #1: Adar I will have 29 days because Shevat had 30 days. This means that Adar II will have 30 days to maintain lunar synchronization within the current year. But this means that Nisan in the following year should only have 29 days. This scenario seems highly unlikely because the following Nisan must have 30 days. This scenario maintains the 30-29-30-29 sequence for the current year but it disrupts the sequence going into the following year.

Scenario #2: Adar I and Adar II both contain 29 days. This scenario means that the following year can correctly begin with 30 days in Nisan but the calendar for the current year is not in perfect synchronization with the moon for Adar II.

Scenario #2: Adar I has 30 days and Adar II has 29 days. This scenario means that the following year can correctly begin with 30 days in Nisan but the calendar for the current year when Adar I moves into Adar II. This scenario appears to be out of lunar synchronization for one month but enable the following Nisan to contain 30 days.

I am making a mistake somewhere or they compromised the integrity of lunar synchronization for one month. Any input would be greatly appreciated.

title: What is the history of the search for the chilazon?
content:
# What is the history of the search for the chilazon? ## Frage

In the past century and a half, there have been two attempts to find the chilazon. One, the Radzyner Rebbe's, was never widely accepted and is viewed to have been conclusively disproven. The other, the Murex trunculus, has significant supporters and detractors.

I was listening to a shiur series by R' Mordechai Hershfeld about proofs for and against these two attempts to procure the techeiles. One argument he makes against the Murex in particular is the inyan of nignaz (which he discusses in three parts) - essentially arguing that chilazon will not reemerge until the time of the Moshiach. To me that rung untrue because no one's argument against the Radzyner was "nignaz."

This whole train of thought led me to wonder - had there been any other attempts throughout history, however unsuccessful, to find the chilazon?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Rav Yitzchak Isaac Halevi Herzog spent much time in attempting to identify the chilazon, writing his PhD thesis on the topic.

His preferred candidate was, in fact, neither of the two you listed in the question, but rather a different genus of sea snail, janthina.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

The Radbaz and others were already with the idea that they could find the chilazon any time. This matches the idea that in the 16th century there was a high messianic fervour, so the restoration of techelet is a necessity and harbinger of the redemption.

But no formal candidates were ever proposed perhaps because whoever really knew about it mentioned that it was the porphyra, although they might not have been able to precisely gotten their hands on it or try to experiment with it.

Until the fall of Constantinople, there was a formal ban to use any murex trunculus in the lands of the Byzantine and Holy Roman Empire. As the empire fell you see acharonim all the sudden talking about the chilazon and even identifying it with the porphyra, aka murex trunculus.

So it could be well that we all knew along which animal was but we did not dare to write it down due to fear of repression or censorship. The Ramban clearly stated that the chilazon was in power of the Melech Goyim and no one would dare to wear it, so it is possible that any open discussion of the identify was frown upon too.

title: Is there such a thing as reverse Sechita (the Dilatancy effect)?
content:
# Is there such a thing as reverse Sechita (the Dilatancy effect)? ## Frage

Is Sechita strictly speaking the act of squeezing/wringing a material whereby liquid emerges as a result, or does Sechita include the opposite act, wherein a liquid emerges from the material when a force is no longer applied (also known as the Dilatancy effect)?

For example, there is a phenomenon by moist sand that by squeezing the sand together, the pressure actually increases the space between the sand molecules, causing any surrounding liquid to be absorbed more, and when letting go of that same clump, the liquid then starts to get released. It acts counterintuitively, since you would expect that the normal act of squeezing should force liquid out, and the act of letting go should cause more liquid to go back into the clump. But sand does the opposite.

So does squeezing sand on Shabbos, aside from the issue of forming or kneading, also incur Sechita?

title: Was the land of Israel private property or collective
content:
# Was the land of Israel private property or collective ## Frage

I’m curious as to who the land belonged to. As far as I know the Land belonged to God then the tribes. The sages or kings if they could then confiscate land etc if needed. But it never truly belonged to anyone.

Meaning you could never sell the land to another forever, the land d was Gods and given to the Hebrews to keep.

Maybe my understanding is wrong?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: -3)

A Covenantal Stewardship Rather than Absolute Ownership

The Land of Israel was conceived as a unique blend of private stewardship and collective ownership under God. On one hand, each Israelite family received its own portion of land – there was a concept of private property and inheritance. On the other hand, that ownership was never absolute: it was circumscribed by God’s commandments and the community’s welfare. Rabbi Hirsch’s commentary on Deuteronomy 8:11 highlights the spiritual truth behind this arrangement:

Through Birkat Hamazon, the consciousness should always be kept awake to whom WE owe the land and its blessings, under what conditions and for what purpose we receive it, that we remain worthy of the received blessings only as long as we remain mindful of the obligation that renews with every received divine gift, to become a "blessing" ourselves, a blessing of God's work, fulfillers of the divine will on earth. Beware lest you forget, for it is precisely the abundance that could make us forget God. (Deuteronomy 8:10-11)

The Land of Israel in Jewish law was neither a purely private commodity nor a free-for-all collective in the modern sense, but something higher: a holy inheritance held in trust as we see in Zohar I 83a (15:144-145):

The inner meaning of this story is: Had Abram not descended to Egypt and been tested there, his portion would not have been with HaShem. Likewise, his descendants, whom HaShem wanted to make into a unique and perfect nation and bring close: Had they not first descended to Egypt and been tested there, they would not have become HaShem's chosen people. Similarly, the Holy Land: Had it not first been given to Canaan for dominion, it would not have become the lot and portion of the Holy One, blessed be He.

Therefore, each person’s plot was a piece of the national patrimony under God’s domain, with the entire people responsible for each other and for the land itself. The divine rules of ownership ensured that the land’s benefits were shared and sustained collectively – whether through mandatory charity from the harvest, communal rest for the soil, or restrictions on harmful farming practices as we see in Mishnah Bava Kamma 7:7:

One may not raise small domesticated animals, i.e., sheep and goats, in settled areas of Eretz Yisrael, as they graze on people’s crops. But one may raise them in Syria, despite the fact that with regard to many other halakhot Syria is treated like Eretz Yisrael, and in the wilderness of Eretz Yisrael.

title: How can a Jewish store sell a gift card at a discount, isn’t that a problem of Ribbis. A gift card is really a loan as it gives the store capital now?
content:
# How can a Jewish store sell a gift card at a discount, isn’t that a problem of Ribbis. A gift card is really a loan as it gives the store capital now? ## Frage

How can a Jewish store sell a gift card at a discounted price. A gift card is a loan that provides capital to the to store at the time of purchase of the gift card. So this should be Ribbis?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Generally speaking, Ribbis involves charging for allowing someone to use your money for a given amount of time (אגר נטר).

Since the person buying the gift card could use the gift card today, for its entire value, there is no time component here, and hence there is no transgression of Ribbis.

See Shulchan Aruch Harav (Hilchos Ribbis, 23) that in a case where the vendor has goods to sell (יש לו סחורה), at the time of receipt of the money, there is not even a prohibition of אבק ריבית.

  1. The definition of chilazon as a snail, quoting many rishonim who use terms that clearly identify the chilazon as a snail/worm.
  2. The argument against the Murex relating to a lack of mesorah. During this portion he explains that the inyan of mesorah as it relates to concepts in halachah is important vis-a-vis definitions, i.e. knowing what a word means based on a definition passed through generations as opposed to defining a term by sevarah. He says that it's important to have definitions passed through generations, and he says that part of the challenge to the Radzyner's techeiles is that he attempted to define חלזון by sevara rather than by שאל אביך ויגדך, by mesorah.

My questions are as follows. If the definition of חלזון is so clearly passed through the generations to mean "snail"/"worm" based on the opinions of many mainstream rishonim,

  1. How did the Radzyner come to conclude that it was a cuttlefish, which is clearly not a snail; and
  2. Did anyone challenge his conclusion on the basis of those rishonim who describe the חלזון as a snail/worm?
## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

The Radziner Rebbe expanded the word chilazon to include other creatures that have an encasement (nartik), but there is no doubt that even according to him, the murex is a species of chilazon.

Definitely, many rabbonim did not agree to his identification because of the points you brought. See for example Yeshuot Malko where the Radziner’s claims about identifying the chilazon are described as ‘nothing but mere supposition’ (Sec. 2) and ‘nothing but conjecture’ (Sec. 3).

Interestingly, he did check with zoologists who may have told him that the cuttlefish is from the mollusc family, so he may have thought that was enough to qualify it as a chilazon.

title: Why מצרי and not מצרימי
content:
# Why מצרי and not מצרימי ## Frage

Why does the Torah call a person from "מצרים", a מצרי instead of a מצרימי?

Is it because the second-to-last letter is a yud? Or does it have to do with the origin of the name? Or maybe something else?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 8)

The Malbim (style) Haggadah (s.v. עבדים היינו לפרעה) explains:

השם מצרים אינו שם עצם סתם בלי טעם, כמו "ירושלים", דאז היה נגזר היחס בשם מצרימי ומצרימים, ומה שנגזר בשם "מצרי", זה מורה ש"מצרים" הוא שם הקיבוץ, ורוצה לומר מדינה קשה של מצירים ומעיקים רבים.

This is also cited in Sefer Hacarmel, (מצרים).

The name Egypt is not a mere noun without meaning, in which case the relation would be derived from the name מצרימי and מצרימים. The reason we use "מצרי", is because it is derived from מצרים, which refers to the collective, and is intended to convey that it was a difficult country of many oppressors.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

One of the ancient Egyptian names for “Egypt” was taʀwai, which literally means ”two lands”, referring to the fact that it was split into two districts—the north and the south.

When we came to Egypt, we loan-translated that endonym into Hebrew as miṣraim (“two countries”), from the stem m-ṣ-r (literally “border”)¹. Because that stem was rare in Hebrew, its main usage became that regarding Egypt, so that it eventually connoted specifically Egypt by default.

The word miṣrī, therefore, meant “countryman”, and almost exclusively connoted a specifically Egyptian countryman.

Theoretically, if the Egyptian word for “Egypt” were somehow miṣraim, we might very well have considered it a base noun without parsing it into miṣr and the dual suffix, and our word for “Egyptian” would’ve been miṣraimī. But that’s not what Ancient Egyptian word was, so this isn’t what happened.

(Note that this answer explains the historical origins of the Hebrew words for Egypt and its people, and is not an exegesis. @IsraelReader’s answer offers a wonderful exegesis.)

¹Possibly influenced by c’Vrwai or c’Vraw, meaning “[two] borders”.

title: May mourners take their children out to have fun during sheloshim?
content:
# May mourners take their children out to have fun during sheloshim? ## Frage

When someone dies, the siblings must observe sheloshim. But what about their children? Sure, sheloshim is obligatory only on the siblings themselves, but they are the ones who would take their children to amusement parks, movies, vacation spots, and other forms of entertainment, especially in the summertime. Are they allowed to do that?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

R Simcha Bunim Cohen in his book The laws of aveilus (pp. 224) partly answers your question

One is permitted to take a trip with immediate family members (i.e., parents with their children).

A mourner may participate in a joyful activity of a young child who is incapable of comprehending and accepting the concept that the mourning parent cannot participate. However, the parent's participation should be limited to what is required. When music is being played the parent should avoid listening to it as much as possible (i.e., by using earplugs or by not paying attention).

title: Did Napoleon come to Jerusalem and want to rebuild the temple?
content:
# Did Napoleon come to Jerusalem and want to rebuild the temple? ## Frage

I heard one Rav said that Napoleon came to Jerusalem and saw us lamenting the destruction of the Temple and wanted to rebuild it, however the rabbis said no.

Is that reported elsewhere?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Responding to the title question, Napoleon was not able to reach Jerusalem during his campaign in the Land of Israel. Famously, he laid siege on Acre (Akko) in 1799, but lost, and from there backtracked to Egypt (for a short summary of his time in the Land of Israel, see here). So at least that part of the story isn't true.

However, there were a couple of instances during his reign where he said things that were either explicitly related to the Temple or could be hinted at that. First, he had pre-prepared a proclamation to be announced in Jerusalem after he captured it, where he would have proclaimed the Land of Israel (Palestine in his words) a Jewish state. Such autonomy would likely have allowed the Jews to rebuild the Temple. In 1800, Napoleon declared: "If I governed a nation of Jews, I should reestablish the Temple of Solomon." (source; see here for the full quote and the original French).

So these are indications that Napoleon at a time was interested in rebuilding the Temple, as he saw that as the best way to gain favor in the eyes of the Jews. Having failed in the Land of Israel, however, he chose a different practical and ideological approach: the French Emancipation of the Jews. There are certain arguments to be made that at some point he shifted more into an ideological direction of attempting to redefine the Jewish belief in the redemption as something surrounding himself (as the messianic figure) and France (as the New Jerusalem), and the Emancipation as the Jewish Redemption (Geulah) (see here for info). Thus, for example, he established the Grand Sanhedrin which was mainly intended to give supposed Jewish halachic legitimacy to the emancipation. If you look at the topics discussed by the Grand Sanhedrin, you'll see that one of their decisions was announcing that Jews should see their birthplace as their fatherland. This was of course important in establishing primacy of French identity over Jewish identity (with the hopes of similar views spreading across Europe during a time when it was believed Napoleon would be able to conquer at least all of the West), solidifying the view that France was the new Jerusalem and the new Land of Israel.

title: Who is Rabbi Abba bar Mimi
content:
# Who is Rabbi Abba bar Mimi ## Frage

As mentioned here https://library.alhatorah.org/?r1=Shir_HaShirim_Rabbah_1:10 in Shir HaShirim Rabbah, this Rabbi Abba bar Mimi is given as the prime example of someone who would discuss and debate Halacha with his friends. Who exactly is this rabbi? A quick concordance search shows no other results for him anywhere else except for here. And is Mimi his mother’s name?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

According to Rav Aharon Hyman in Toledot Tannaim vaAmoraim, this is his sole occurrence. Rav Hyman also cites Rav Yerucham Leiner in Seder HaDorot HaShalem, that in Rosh HaShanah 35a, which reads:

כִּי סְלֵיק רַבִּי אַבָּא מִיַּמֵּי, פֵּירְשַׁהּ: מוֹדִים חֲכָמִים לְרַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל בִּבְרָכוֹת שֶׁל רֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה וְשֶׁל יוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים, וַהֲלָכָה מִכְּלָל דִּפְלִיגִי בִּבְרָכוֹת דְּכׇל הַשָּׁנָה.

The Gemara answers: When Rabbi Abba returned from his travels at sea, he explained the matter as follows: The Sages concede to the opinion of Rabban Gamliel with regard to the blessings of Rosh HaShana and of Yom Kippur, that in these cases the prayer leader fulfills the obligation on behalf of the many. And Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement that the halakha is in accordance with Rabban Gamliel, which, by inference, indicates that the tanna’im still disagree, is referring to the blessings of the entire year.

that perhaps instead of reading מימי as מִיַּמֵּי, from the Seas (which Rashi explains as שהפליג בספינה לים וחזר, that Rabbi Abba set out by boat to sea and returned), that we should read it as a single name with a missing "bar", such that it is Rabbi Abba bar Mimi.

I examined various manuscripts on Hachi Garsinan and, while there are several variants, none are bar Mimi.

In terms of Mimi being his mother, there is no reason to make such an assumption, even though Mimi is a female name in modern times. The default assumption should be that this is his father's name.

title: Why are Gil'ad's children considered their own family?
content:
# Why are Gil'ad's children considered their own family? ## Frage

In Bamidbar (26:30-32), the children of Gil'ad, son of Machir ben Menasheh, are mentioned as heads of their own families. Every other time a grandson of one of the twelve tribes is called their own family, Rashi (26:24, 26:36) explains why: either because they were born before Ya'akov went to Mitzrayim, or because they were fathers of exceptionally large families.

However, when it comes to the six sons of Gil'ad, Rashi doesn't explain why they're considered separate families. What makes this even stranger is the fact that these are the only great-grandchildren considered heads of their own families! (Also, per Rashi, the only reason Gil'ad is mentioned is because he had a large family, so further "watering down" the families into smaller groups seems counterintuitive).

So why were these great-grandchildren considered their own families, and why didn't Rashi explain it?

title: Could Chiram be a Descendant of a Child That Samson Conceived with Plishti, Married Women While Incarcerated?
content:
# Could Chiram be a Descendant of a Child That Samson Conceived with Plishti, Married Women While Incarcerated? ## Frage

The Talmud in Sota (10a) states that Plishti men brought their wives to Samson while he was in jail to conceive:

״וַיְהִי טוֹחֵן בְּבֵית הָאֲסוּרִים״. אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: אֵין טְחִינָה אֶלָּא לְשׁוֹן עֲבֵירָה, וְכֵן הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״תִּטְחַן לְאַחֵר אִשְׁתִּי״. מְלַמֵּד שֶׁכׇּל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד הֵבִיא לוֹ אֶת אִשְׁתּוֹ לְבֵית הָאֲסוּרִים כְּדֵי שֶׁתִּתְעַבֵּר הֵימֶנּוּ. With regard to Samson’s capture, the verse states: “... and he did grind in the prison-house” (Judges 16:21). Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Grinding is nothing other than a language of a transgression of sexual intercourse, and so the verse says: “Then let my wife grind unto another man” (Job 31:10). This teaches that each and every Philistine man brought his wife to the prison in order that she should be impregnated by Samson.

Divrei Hayamim 2 3,17 states:

וַיָּ֤קֶם אֶת־הָֽעַמּוּדִים֙ עַל־פְּנֵ֣י הַהֵיכָ֔ל אֶחָ֥ד מִיָּמִ֖ין וְאֶחָ֣ד מֵֽהַשְּׂמֹ֑אול וַיִּקְרָ֤א שֵׁם־[הַיְמָנִי֙] (הימיני) יָכִ֔ין וְשֵׁ֥ם הַשְּׂמָאלִ֖י בֹּֽעַז׃ {ס}         He erected the columns in front of the Great Hall, one to its right and one to its left; the one to the right was called Jachin, and the one to the left, Boaz.

Rashi on Divrei Hayamim 2 3,17 states:

ד"א חירם שהיה מבני דן עשה את העמודים קרא את האחד יכין על שם אביו שמשון שנאמר בו (שופטים ט״ז:כ״ח-כ״ט) וילפת שמשון שני עמודי התוך (וגו' נכון וגו') ושלמה קרא לשני בועז Another explanation: Huram, who was one of the sons of Dan, made the pillars. He called one Jachin after his father Samson, about whom Scripture states (Jud. 16:29): “And Samson grasped the two pillars of the center, etc.” And Solomon called the second one Boaz after his grandfather, Boaz.

I see three possibilities here:

  1. Samson was the honorary father of everyone in Dan. He has no actual genetic connection to Chiram.
  2. Chiram descends from one of Samson's Jewish offspring. Per the Rambam, Samson converted his wife(s). The challenge here is that there is no mention of children in connection with any of the three women he encountered.
  3. Perhaps, Chiram descends from a child of one of the non-Jewish Plishtim that Samson had relations with in jail, * and said child (or decendant) subsequently converted to Judaism.*

*Does the third possibility - the tribe of Dan redux - work?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The Chiram referred to here (called Chiram/Chirom in Melachim, and Churam in Divrei HaYamim) is an Israelite who built the Temple, who lived in Tyre, from the tribes of Naftali and Dan. Not to be confused with King Chiram of Tyre, who was also involved in the building of the Temple.

Here is how (Pseudo-)Rashi explains his lineage (Divrei HaYamim 2:13):

ואביו איש צורי - יהודי היה יושב בצור דוגמא עובד אדום הגתי (שמואל ב' ו) שהיה יושב בגת ולוי היה ובמלכים (א ז) כתיב ובן אשה אלמנה ממטה נפתלי ואביו איש צורי אלא אמו מדן ואביו מנפתלי ומה צריך לייחס מאיזה שבט היה אביו ואמו זהו שכתוב (בראשית ל') דנני אלהים וגם נפתולי אלהים וגו' (שם) אמרה רחל מעתה עקמתי פתולים עקמומיות עשיתי עד שאני יכולה לדמות עצמי ללאה אחותי אם לאה תתפאר בבצלאל בנה שיעשה המשכן יצטרך להשתתף במלאכתו אחד מבני דן שנאמר ואתו אהליאב בן אחיסמך למטה דן ואם שלמה בן אחותי יבנה ב"ה צריך להשתתף עמו מבני דן ונפתלי

So this Chiram was descended from Dan on his mother's side. And so the (Pseudo-)Rashi you quote surmises that he may have been descended from Shimshon, as an attempt to explain the choice of the name Yachin for the pillar.

title: Did Chava eat the fruit before or after Adam?
content:
# Did Chava eat the fruit before or after Adam? ## Frage

A simple reading would imply the serpent convinced Chava to eat first, and she did so because she was caught up in his words at the time. Then, she gave it to Adam.

But Rashi says that she gave it to Adam because she was worried that if she passed away and not him, then he would marry another woman.

Does Rashi suggest that Chava gave the fruit to Adam first?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Im not sure your implication. She was scared she would pass away since she ate from it. Since she didn't want him to marry another woman she therefore gave him to eat so if she dies so does he.

### ✅ Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

There is nothing in the verse itself (Bereishit 3:6) that suggests that she gave it to Adam to eat first. That verse reads:

וַתֵּ֣רֶא הָֽאִשָּׁ֡ה כִּ֣י טוֹב֩ הָעֵ֨ץ לְמַאֲכָ֜ל וְכִ֧י תַֽאֲוָה־ה֣וּא לָעֵינַ֗יִם וְנֶחְמָ֤ד הָעֵץ֙ לְהַשְׂכִּ֔יל וַתִּקַּ֥ח מִפִּרְי֖וֹ וַתֹּאכַ֑ל וַתִּתֵּ֧ן גַּם־לְאִישָׁ֛הּ עִמָּ֖הּ וַיֹּאכַֽל׃ When the woman saw that the tree was good for eating and a delight to the eyes, and that the tree was desirable as a source of wisdom, she took of its fruit and ate. She also gave some to her husband, and he ate.

Further, there is nothing in Rashi's words that would specifically lend an interpretation that runs contrary to that interpretation, that should cause us to revisit that assumption. Rashi wrote:

ותתן גם לאישה. שֶׁלֹּא תָמוּת הִיא וְיִחְיֶה הוּא, וְיִשָּׂא אַחֶרֶת: ותתן גם לאשה AND SHE GAVE ALSO TO HER HUSBAND so that she should not die and he remain alive to take another wife (Genesis Rabbah 19:5).

The idea could very well be that, after eating, she reflected and decided that she should give to her husband. Such contemplation that she would die is not something that she would do and then, despite that, eat it! It would be after eating and having regrets, now that she realizes the repercussions.

Indeed, Rashi seldom innovates his own interpretations to Torah. Instead, he "channels" existing midrashim. In Bereishit Rabba 19:5, this appears as:

וַתִּקַּח מִפִּרְיוֹ וַתֹּאכַל (בראשית ג, ו), אָמַר רַבִּי אַיְבוּ סָחֲטָה עֲנָבִים וְנָתְנָה לוֹ, רַבִּי שִׂמְלָאי אָמַר בְּיִשּׁוּב הַדַּעַת בָּאת עָלָיו, אָמְרָה לֵיהּ מַה אַתָּה סָבוּר שֶׁאֲנִי מֵתָה וְחַוָּה אַחֶרֶת נִבְרֵאת לְךָ (קהלת א, ט): אֵין כָּל חָדָשׁ תַּחַת הַשֶּׁמֶשׁ, אוֹ שֶׁמָּא אֲנִי מֵתָה וְאַתְּ יוֹשֵׁב לְךָ הַטְלִיס, (ישעיה מה, יח): לֹא תֹהוּ בְרָאָהּ לָשֶׁבֶת יְצָרָהּ, רַבָּנָן אָמְרֵי הִתְחִילָה מְיַלֶּלֶת עָלָיו בְּקוֹלָהּ

She took from its fruit and ate” – Rabbi Aivu said: She squeezed grapes and gave it to him [Adam]. Rabbi Simlai said: She came to him persuasively. She said to him: ‘What, do you think that I will die and another Eve will be created for you? “There is nothing new under the sun” (Ecclesiastes 1:9). Or, perhaps [you think that] I will die and you will sit alone? “He did not create it [the world] for emptiness, He formed it to be inhabited”’ (Isaiah 45:18). The Rabbis say: She began sobbing at him plaintively with her voice.

This reads fairly clearly as her already facing death, for having eaten it, and now trying to convince Adam to eat as well.

Welcome to Mi Yodeya!

title: Balak's Messengers - multiple titles
content:
# Balak's Messengers - multiple titles ## Frage

From what I can see, the messengers that Balak sends are referred to, in the same few verses, using multiple different titles. First they are called the Elders (of Midian - Bamidbar 22:4), then "messengers" (ibid 5), then the Elders of Moab and the Elders of Midian (ibid 7) then the Princes of Balak (ibid 13), then the Princes of Moab (ibid 13), then the servants of Balak (ibid 18), then "the men" (anashim - ibid 20), and then the Princess of Moab again (ibid 21).

I understand there are commentaries on each verse, for example Ibn Ezra on ibid 13 says that they are the Princess of Balak specifically (and not Moab) to indicate that he was the protagonist of sending them, but is anyone aware of a more general, comprehensive discussion on why the verses refer to them in so many different ways across the chapter?

title: Understanding the ending of Ruth - Naomi's benefits, Oved's name, and the memory of Mahlon
content:
# Understanding the ending of Ruth - Naomi's benefits, Oved's name, and the memory of Mahlon ## Frage

Please, help me understand the ending of the Book of Ruth (4.10-17). For convenience, I grouped several questions in one here:

  1. "And may your house be like the house of Perez whom Tamar bore to Judah—
    through the offspring which the LORD will give you by this young woman     -
    The whole point of Perez's lineage was King David. What was special about the house of Perez (except for being born "in sin") for Oved to be likened backward to?
  2. "And the women said to Naomi, 'Blessed be the LORD, who has not withheld a redeemer from you today!'... He will renew your life and sustain your old age; for he is born of your daughter-in-law, who loves you and is better to you than seven sons. " -
    The ending glorifies Naomi and presents Boaz's acquisition as Naomi's benefit. What does she have to do with the move? How does she profit from the deal?
  3. "Naomi took the child and held it to her bosom. She became its foster mother, and the women neighbors gave him a name, saying, “A son is born to Naomi!” They named him Obed; he was the father of Jesse, the father of David." -
    The child, Obed, was born to Ruth and Boaz. What does he have to do with Naomi to be considered her son? Why did the neighbor women give him the name - what kind of practice is this? Why doesn't the text tell how Boaz named his son upon circumcision

Maybe a stand-alone question:
4. "I am also acquiring Ruth the Moabite, the wife of Mahlon, as my wife, so as to perpetuate the name of the deceased upon his estate, that the name of the deceased may not disappear from among his kinsmen and from the gate of his home town. -
Doesn't "perpetuate the name of the deceased that his name may not disappear" mean that the child will be called after Mahlon and Elimelech, rather than Boaz? Otherwise, how didn't Mahlon's name disappear?

title: Excessive details of Boaz marrying Ruth
content:
# Excessive details of Boaz marrying Ruth ## Frage

Ruth 4.13 says:

"וַיִּקַּח בֹּעַז אֶת־רוּת So Boaz married Ruth;
וַתְּהִי־לוֹ לְאִשָּׁה and she became his wife,
וַיָּבֹא אֵלֶיהָ and he cohabited with her.
וַיִּתֵּן יי לָהּ הֵרָיוֹן The LORD let her conceive,
וַתֵּלֶד בֵּן׃ and she bore a son."

What explains such a level of specificity?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

Because Boaz was extremely old, he had no sons previously, and he was only alive with Ruth a short amount of time. Someone may say that Boaz was not the father. Some may say that the marriage was invalid. So the Megillah emphasizes all of steps to enforce that they are real and good.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 6)

Malbim has a clever reading: there is actual Yibum -- marrying the widow of one's deceased, childless brother -- and then there is quasi-Yibum: in the spirit of the law of Yibum, having other family members marry the widow to carry on the name.

As Boaz was a cousin, this was in-the-spirt-of Yibum, not actual Yibum.

In real Yibum, a marriage ceremony is (technically) not required -- they just move in together. (The rabbis later added a for-show ceremony, for obvious reasons.) In a sense, it's that the first brother's marriage never really ended, and just transferred to the living brother.

So the verse is stressing that this was quasi-Yibum. It required proper marriage ("he took her", and then she became his wife) before cohabitation.

An alternative suggestion -- the narrator notes that by the end of the book, Naomi was walking around with baby Oved, and the townspeople are saying, "hey look, Naomi's new baby!". So the narrator is making sure that future generations understand that the actual mother of the baby was, in fact, Ruth.

title: How does one choose his Rav - Do the Talmidim of Beis Shamai have an obligation to follow Beis Hillel?
content:
# How does one choose his Rav - Do the Talmidim of Beis Shamai have an obligation to follow Beis Hillel? ## Frage

TLDR: How does one choose a Rav in the first place? And what does one do if they listen to 2 Rabbeim that contradict one another?

Apologies for such a large post:

When the Gemara was compiled, arguably the 2 largest camps of schools of thought were Beis Shamai and Beis Hillel, and the law was decided in favor of Beis Hillel. At that point in time, did the Talmidim of Beis Shamai have an obligation to start holding like Beis Hillel as well, in direct contradiction to what their own Rabbeim told them to do?

Imagine if today, hypothetically speaking, an Ashkenazi Jew who has an Ashkenazi Rov, is told that the correct approach in life is actually Sefardi. On the one hand, he literally has his own Rebbe that he turns to and follows, and on the other hand, the law has now officially been decided opposite of his Mesorah. Do we now tell him to stop doing things in an Ashkenaz way? Is he liable to punishment for LITERALLY FOLLOWING HIS REBBE? Who has a Mesorah? What happens in that case? Because on the one hand, Mesorah is so important, and on the other hand, so is following the CORRECT Halacha?

This question deeply bothers me because there are so many differences in Yiddishkeit, so many Rabbanim saying so many things, and it seems impossible (in my humble perspective) for someone to be doing something correctly according to everyone. Ok realistically, I know there are a bunch of things we all agree on, but how is a person supposed to know they're really doing the ratzon Hashem when there are so many different shitos, hashkafos, and minhagim?

Examples:

  1. Tefillin Rashi versus Rabbeinu Tam
  2. Tefillin on Chol HaMoed or not
  3. Techeiles actually being from the Murex snail or not
  4. The myriad differences between Beis Shamai and Beis Hillel
  5. Eating Gebrukts or not on Pesach
  6. Cholov Yisroel
  7. Pas Yisroel
  8. Eating cholent on Thursday night or not
  9. Where the true international dateline is Halachically
  10. Many more Minhagim some do others don't
  11. Neitz versus Olos and Shkiah versus Tzeis (GRA vs Magen Avraham)

The point is - what is the correct way of doing something in accordance with what Hashem wants if we have differences in opinion?

How does one choose a Rov?

What if someone has many Rabbis they follow or listen to? My perspective is that why should I "nail the coffin shut" and only choose 1 Rav, if A: there is the possibility the Rav might be wrong or B: I'm fostering close mindedness by only following 1 way of Da'as Torah?

And please do not suggest asking your LOR. This question premises on trying to find which Rov or Rabbanim to follow when he doesn't have anyone that he solidly clings tightly and blindly to.

title: When to write B”H or BS”D
content:
# When to write B”H or BS”D ## Frage

There is a custom to write B”H or BS”D at the top right corner of letters. Do we need to write B”H or BS”D every time we write anything at all?

For example, do we need to write B”H or BS”D on a post-it note or while writing the contents of a box on the box itself or while making a shopping list or every page of homework etc etc?

Lets say a person needs to write the measurements of a piece of wood, on the wood itself; would he need to write B”H or BS”D first at some spot on the wood?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The question rightly compares Halachos (mandatory conduct) and educational practices. Many daily activities are not approved by Halachah but express spiritual aspirations.

Rambam codifies those in Hilchos Deos (Human Despositions) 3.3:

"זֶה צִוּוּ חֲכָמִים וְאָמְרוּ (משנה אבות ב יב) "וְכָל מַעֲשֶׂיךָ יִהְיוּ לְשֵׁם שָׁמַיִם".
וְהוּא שֶׁאָמַר שְׁלֹמֹה בְּחָכְמָתוֹ (משלי ג ו) "בְּכָל דְּרָכֶיךָ דָעֵהוּ וְהוּא יְיַשֵּׁר אֹרְחֹתֶיךָ":"
"On this matter, our Sages have directed and said (Avot 2.12):
"And all your deeds should be for the sake of Heaven."
This is what Solomon declared in his wisdom (Proverbs 3:6):
"Know Him in all your ways and He will straighten your paths".

Adding B"H or BS"D at the start of writing is purely symbolic: it reminds the writer to acknowledge Hashem as the ultimate source of wisdom and understanding, and it shows connection with the Jewish religious community.

Another example would be clothing or Peos - they both represent a level of personal adherence and communal affiliation.

Therefore, it is the writer's responsibility to determine where they draw their line.

title: Are you allowed to drink hot chocolate before davening?

# Are you allowed to drink hot chocolate before davening? ## Frage

Are you allowed to drink hot chocolate before davening? Rabbi Belsky says no (see attached). Are there others that disagree?

CHAPTER FOUR

Do's and Don'ts Before Shacharis

Years ago, drinking coffee with milk and sugar was considered a haughty act.1 Today, this is not the case, and one is permitted to drink coffee with sugar and milk before davening if it is necessary for better concentration during davening.[2]

Hot cocoa is a rich drink made with a lot of milk, and therefore it is not permitted for adults prior to davening.[3] Children may drink hot cocoa before davening, as is a common incentive in camp.

Cappuccinos and iced coffee made with a lot of milk are not permitted either.[4] Some poskim permit soda before davening,[5] however, this should not be done.[6]
