אֶדְרֶעִי. וּלְשׁוֹן סִפְרֵי (דברים ד) בְּעַשְׁתָּרוֹת שֶׁהָיָה קָשֶׁה כְּעַשְׁתָּרוֹת, בְּאֶדְרֶעִי זֶה מְקוֹם מַלְכוּת. וְכָתַב רַשִׁ"י (רש"י על דברים א':ד') עַשְׁתָּרוֹת לְשׁוֹן צוּקִין וְקֹשִׁי, וְעַשְׁתָּרוֹת זֶהוּ עַשְׁתְּרוֹת קַרְנַיִם שֶׁהָיוּ בָּהּ רְפָאִים שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר (בראשית יד ה) וַיַּכּוּ אֶת רְפָאִים בְּעַשְׁתְּרֹת קַרְנַיִם. בְּאֶדְרֶעִי שֵׁם מַלְכוּת, וְכֵן כָּתוּב עַשְׁתְּרוֹת צֹאנֶךָ (דברים ז':י"ג) כְּתַרְגּוּמוֹ. וְרַבּוֹתֵינוּ אָמְרוּ (חולין פד) לָמָּה נִקְרָא שְׁמָן עַשְׁתָּרוֹת, שֶׁמְּעַשְּׁרוֹת אֶת בַּעֲלֵיהֶן וּמְחַזְּקוֹת אוֹתָן, כָּעַשְׁתָּרוֹת הַלָּלוּ שֶׁהֵם סְלָעִים חֲזָקִים. וְהָרַב מַרְכִּיב בּוֹ שְׁתֵּי לְשׁוֹנוֹת, וְלֹא יָדַעְנוּ מֵאֵיזֶה מָקוֹם הוֹצִיא שֶׁיִּהְיֶה עַשְׁתָּרוֹת שֵׁם צוּקִין וּסְלָעִים. אֲבָל יִתָּכֵן שֶׁנֹּאמַר שֶׁהוּא שֵׁם עֶדְרֵי הַצֹּאן מִלְּשׁוֹן עֹשֶׁר כְּדִבְרֵי חֲכָמִים, וְעַשְׁתָּרוֹת קַרְנַיִם הָיוּ הָרִים גְּבוֹהִים שֶׁעֲלֵיהֶם מְצוּדוֹת סְלָעִים, יְדַמֶּה אוֹתָם הַכָּתוּב לְקַרְנֵי הַבְּהֵמוֹת כְּמוֹ שֶׁיְּדַמֶּה אוֹתָם לְשִׁנַּיִם, כְּעִנְיָן שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר (איוב לט כח) עַל שֶׁן סֶלַע וּמְצוּדָה, וְכֵן עַל קַרְנוֹת הַמִּזְבֵּחַ (שמות כט יב), וְכֵן בְּקֶרֶן בֶּן שָׁמֶן (ישעיהו ה א), אָמַר הַתַּרְגּוּם בְּטוּר רָם בְּאַרְעָא שַׁמִּינָא. וְשָׁם יַעֲלוּ עַשְׁתְּרוֹת הַצֹּאן הַתְּיָשִׁים וְהָעִזִּים וְהַיְּעֵלִים וְכַיּוֹצֵא בָּהֶן, וּלְכָךְ יִקָּרֵא עַשְׁתְּרוֹת קַרְנַיִם. וְכֵן לַבַּעַל וְלָעַשְׁתָּרוֹת (שופטים ב יג) הע"ז הָעֲשׂוּיָה כְּצוּרַת הַצֹּאן לְהָגֵן עֲלֵיהֶם כְּפִי סִכְלוּתָם, וּבְשִׁפְלוּת הָהָר בָּנוּ עִיר וּשְׁמָהּ אֶדְרֶעִי, וְהוּא שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר (דברים ג':א') וַיֵּצֵא עוֹג מֶלֶךְ הַבָּשָׁן הוּא וְכָל עַמּוֹ לַמִּלְחָמָה אֶדְרֶעִי, כִּי אָסַף אֶת כָּל חֵילוֹ אֶל הָעִיר אֲשֶׁר שָׁם אַרְמוֹן הַמֶּלֶךְ וְכִסֵּא הַמַּלְכוּת. וְעִנְיַן סִפְרֵי (שם) מִדְרָשָׁם אָמְרוּ זַ"ל אֲשֶׁר יוֹשֵׁב בְּעַשְׁתָּרֹת בְּאֶדְרֶעִי, אִלּוּ לֹא הָיָה עוֹג קָשֶׁה וְשָׁרוּי בְּעַשְׁתָּרוֹת קָשֶׁה הָיָה, שֶׁהַמְּדִינָה קָשָׁה וְכוּ', וּלְפִיכָךְ יִדְרְשׁוּ בְּעַשְׁתָּרוֹת שֶׁהָיָה קָשֶׁה כְּעַשְׁתָּרוֹת, כְּלוֹמַר שֶׁהָיָה מְקוֹם מוֹשָׁבוֹ כְּמוֹ עַשְׁתְּרוֹת קַרְנַיִם הָעִיר הַחֲזָקָה שֶׁהָיָה הוּא וּמִשְׁפַּחְתּוֹ מִשָּׁם, כִּי עַתָּה אֵינֶנּוּ יוֹשֵׁב בְּעַשְׁתָּרוֹת כִּי בְּאֶרֶץ אֱמוֹרִי הוּא יוֹשֵׁב, וּמְקוֹם מַלְכוּת כְּלוֹמַר הַמְּדִינָה שֶׁהָיָה יוֹשֵׁב בָּהּ אֶדְרֶעִי, כִּי שֵׁם אֶרֶץ מַלְכוּתוֹ הַבָּשָׁן:

AFTER HE HAD SMITTEN SIHON, THE KING OF THE AMORITES, WHO ‘DWELT’ IN HESHBON — for Heshbon was not his, but he conquered it from the king of Moab and he built it to be his royal capital. Similarly, and Og the king of Bashan, who ‘dwelt’ in Ashtaroth, at Edrei means that it was previously the land of Rephaim [and then it was occupied by the king of the Amorites] as I will explain with the help of G-d. And because Scripture states, who dwelt in Ashtaroth, at Edrei, it indicates that Ashtaroth is the name of a place in which Edrei is located [as will be explained further]. The text of the Sifre is as follows: “‘B’ashtaroth’ — it was as hard as ashtaroth. ‘B’edrei’ — this was the seat of the government [i.e., the royal city].” Rashi wrote: “Ashtaroth — is an expression denoting rocks and hardness. Ashtaroth is Ashteroth-karnaim where the Rephaim were, as it is said, and they smote the Rephaim in Ashteroth-karnaim. ‘B’edrei’ — this was the name of the kingdom [indicating that the kingdom of Edrei was located in Ashteroth-karnaim]. And so it is written, ‘ashteroth’ of thy sheep, meaning, as Targum [Onkelos] rendered it [‘the flocks of thy sheep’]. And our Rabbis have said: Why is the name ashtaroth given to them [i.e., flocks of sheep]? It is because they ‘enrich’ [from the Hebrew word ashir — rich] their owners and strengthen them like these ashtaroth which are strong rocks.” [This is Rashi’s language].Now the Rabbi [Rashi] incorporated into the word [ashtaroth] two meanings [strength and riches], but we do not know from what source the Rabbi inferred that ashtaroth is a name for rocks and stones. But it is possible for us to say that ashtaroth is a term for flocks of sheep, from the word ashir (rich) as in the words of the Sages [quoted above: “Why is their name ashtaroth? It is because they enrich their owners”]. Ashteroth-karnaim was a place of high mountains upon which there were strongholds of stone, these being likened by Scripture to “the horns of cattle,” just as Scripture likens them to “teeth,” as it says upon ‘the crag’ [literally: “the tooth”] of the rock, and the stronghold. Similarly, upon ‘the horns’ of the altar. So also, ‘b’keren’ ben shamen [literally: “in a fruitful ‘horn'”] which the Targum [Yonathan ben Uziel] renders: “On a high hill, in a fruitful land.” There, [upon these high hills,] the flocks of sheep ascend, the he-goats, the she-goats, and the wild-goats and their like; and therefore the place is called Ashteroth-karnaim [because the flocks which “enrich” their owners (ashtaroth) ascend to the “horns” of the mountain (karnaim)]. So also, and they served Baal and the Ashtaroth — ‘Ashtaroth’ because the idol was made in the form of a sheep in order to protect them [the flocks of sheep], in accordance with their foolish belief. [This is in line with our explanation of the word ashtaroth as a synonym for sheep.] Now at the foot of the mountain they built a city whose name was Edrei, this being intimated in the verse which states, and Og the king of Bashan came out against us, he and all his people, unto battle at Edrei, denoting that he gathered his entire army to the city where the palace of the king and the throne of the kingdom were. And this is the purport of the [following] Midrashic text [which seems to agree with Rashi’s interpretation], wherein the Rabbis, of blessed memory, have stated: “Who dwelt in Ashtaroth, at Edrei. Even if Og himself had not been difficult to defeat but had resided in Ashtaroth, he would have been difficult to defeat, because the city was a difficult one to capture etc.” Therefore they interpreted, Ashtaroth to mean that it was “as hard as Ashtaroth,” [the phrase from which Rashi, quoted above, deduced that the word ashtaroth is defined as “hard”], as if to say that his residence was like the fortified city of Ashteroth-karnaim from which he and his family originated; for at that time he was not residing in Ashtaroth, but was residing in the land of the Amorites. And “the place of the government” [mentioned in the Sifre above] means that the city where he lived was Edrei but Bashan was the name of the land of his kingdom.

title: Talmud Bavli - Moses is Heman?
content:
# Talmud Bavli - Moses is Heman? ## Frage

In the Babylonian Talmud Bava Basra 15a, it is reported that Rav said Heman, mentioned in 1 Kings 5:11, is the same person as Moses.

קָא חָשֵׁיב מֹשֶׁה וְקָא חָשֵׁיב הֵימָן, וְהָאָמַר רַב: הֵימָן זֶה מֹשֶׁה – כְּתִיב הָכָא: ״הֵימָן״, וּכְתִיב הָתָם: ״בְּכׇל בֵּיתִי נֶאֱמָן הוּא״! תְּרֵי הֵימָן הֲווֹ.

The Gemara asks: The baraita counts Moses among the ten elders whose works are included in the book of Psalms, and it also counts Heman. But doesn’t Rav say: The Heman mentioned in the Bible (I Kings 5:11) is the same person as Moses? This is proven by the fact that it is written here: “Heman” (Psalms 88:1), which is Aramaic for trusted, and it is written there about Moses: “For he is the trusted one in all My house” (Numbers 12:7). The Gemara answers: There were two Hemans, one of whom was Moses, and the other a Temple singer from among the descendants of Samuel.

How is this possible?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

First off, the original text of the Talmud does not specify 1 Kings 5:11. That is the interpolated English commentary from Rav Adin Steinsaltz, and based on Rashi ad loc. It might be absolutely correct as an interpretation, but clarity is important. All the Talmud literally says is (translated):

But doesn’t Rav say: Heman is Moses.

To expand on Rav's approach to certain Biblical books, I would point to Vayikra Rabba 1:3:

רַבִּי סִימוֹן בְּשֵׁם רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי וְרַבִּי חָמָא אֲבוּהָ דְּרַבִּי הוֹשַׁעְיָא בְּשֵׁם רַב, אָמְרֵי, לֹא נִתַּן דִּבְרֵי הַיָּמִים אֶלָּא לִדָּרֵשׁ...

Rabbi Simon, in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, and Rabbi Ḥama father of Rabbi Hoshaya, in the name of Rav, said: Chronicles was given only for expounding...

He goes on to show certain absolute contradictions between Divrei Hayamim (Chronicles) and other narratives. The idea seems to be that we should not look to the plain meaning of such verses. Rather, the only purpose of such verses is as coded references, conveying some deep midrashic meaning. As I have argued elsewhere in the past, this idea of לא ניתן אלא / "it was only given for" could be understood as that it was only canonized in respect to its midrashic meaning. Therefore, we should not be troubled with contradictions with other Biblical books.

That midrash in Vayikra Rabba, from Rav, goes on to interpret this verse (I Chronicles 4:18):

“His Judahite wife bore Yered father of Gedor, [Ḥever father of Sokho, and Yekutiel father of Zano'aḥ; these are the sons of Bitya daughter of Pharaoh whom Mered took as a wife]”

such that many of the names in the verse are actually coded references to Moshe and aspects of his personality.

Heiman is presumably another instance of Rav interpreting a verse in this way.

Now, which Heiman verse is being referenced regarding the identification of הֵימָן זֶה מֹשֶׁה? Rav Steinsaltz, following Rashi, says that it is I Melachim 5:11 that refers to Moshe:

He was wiser than anybody else—including Ethan the Ezrahite, and Heman, Chalkol, and Darda the sons of Mahol. His fame spread among all the surrounding nations.

But other verses also refer to this same Heiman, such as I Divrei Hayamim 2:6:

וּבְנֵ֣י זֶ֗רַח זִ֠מְרִ֠י וְאֵיתָ֧ן וְהֵימָ֛ן וְכַלְכֹּ֥ל וָדָ֖רַע כֻּלָּ֥ם חֲמִשָּֽׁה׃ {ס}

The sons of Zerah: Zimri, Ethan, Heman, Calcol, and Dara, five in all.

As Rashi on that verse in Melachim notes, there is a Midrash Aggadah that goes through the people in the verse. Even so, I don't think that is predicated on the verse in Melachim but on a different verse in Divrei Hayamim. Again, we can look to Vayikra Rabba 9:1, where I can excerpt:

דִכְתִיב (דברי הימים א ב, ו): וּבְנֵי זֶרַח זִמְרִי וְאֵיתָן וְהֵימָן וְכַלְכֹּל [ודרע] [ודרדע] כֻּלָּם חֲמִשָּׁה, זִמְרִי, רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי אָמַר זֶה עָכָן, וְלָמָּה קוֹרְאוֹ זִמְרִי, שֶׁעָשָׂה כְּמַעֲשֵׂה זִמְרִי. וְרַבָּנָן אָמְרֵי שֶׁנִּזַּמְּרוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל עַל יָדוֹ. אֵיתָן זֶה אַבְרָהָם אָבִינוּ עַל שֵׁם (תהלים פט, א): מַשְׂכִּיל לְאֵיתָן הָאֶזְרָחִי. הֵימָן זֶה משֶׁה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר (במדבר יב, ז): בְּכָל בֵּיתִי נֶאֱמָן הוּא. רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר נַחְמָן אָמַר זֶה עָכָן, עַל שֵׁם (יהושע ז, כ): אָמְנָה אָנֹכִי חָטָאתִי. כַּלְכֹּל זֶה יוֹסֵף, עַל שֵׁם (בראשית מז, יב): וַיְכַלְכֵּל יוֹסֵף. [ודרע] [ודרדע] זֶה דּוֹר הַמִּדְבָּר שֶׁכֻּלּוֹ דֵּעָה. כֻּלָּם חֲמִשָּׁה, וְכִי אֵין אָנוּ יוֹדְעִים שֶׁכֻּלָּם חֲמִשָּׁה, אֶלָּא מְלַמֵּד שֶׁאַף עָכָן הָיָה עִמָּהֶן לָעוֹלָם הַבָּא,

That is what is written: “The sons of Zeraḥ: Zimri, Eitan, Heiman, Kalkol, and Darda; all of them were five” (I Chronicles 2:6). Zimri – Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: This is Akhan, as he performed the act of Zimri. The Rabbis say: It is because Israel was pruned [nizmeru] on his account. Eitan – this is Abraham our patriarch, based on: “A contemplation by Eitan the Ezrahite” (Psalms 89:1). Heiman – this is Moses, as it is stated: “In all My household he is trusted [ne’eman]” (Numbers 12:7). Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥman said: This is Akhan, based on: “Indeed [omna], I have sinned” (Joshua 7:20). Kalkol – this is Joseph, based on: “Joseph sustained [vaykhalkel]” (Genesis 47:12). Darda – this is the generation [dor] of the wilderness, which was full of knowledge [de’a]. “All of them were five” – do we not know that all of them were five? Rather, it teaches that even Akhan was with them in the World to Come.

The verse that mentions כֻּלָּם חֲמִשָּׁה is the one in Divrei Hayamim. Thus, this seems to be the similar approach of interpreting that names that appear in Divrei Hayamim, rather than taking them in the straightforward peshat meaning.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

Not sure what's bothering you. Two different people named Heiman.

The point in Bava Basra is to really expand on King Solomon's wisdom.

"He was even wiser than Ethan the Ezrachite, Heiman, Kalkol, and Darda, people of Machol."

If these are just random people from his time who were smart, eh okay. The Midrashic reading, however, is that all of these names are coded references to great leaders before King Solomon, which would therefore make King Solomon sound a whole lot greater:

"He was even wiser than [Abraham], who was mighty [in spreading monotheism] and yet a good citizen [as he showed respect to those around him]; and [Moses], the faithful one [as "meheimna" is Aramaic for "faithful"]; and [Joseph], the sustainer/provider [for the ancient Middle East during the famine], and the whole generation who knew G-d's presence intensely while witnessing miracles in the desert, the people who achieved forgiveness.

So yes, there was a literal Heiman, a Levite Temple chorister; but the verse in Kings is giving a coded reference to Moses. Whether the verse intended both literally the chorister and, if you read between the lines, Moses; or was only intending for Moses ... is a question of whether that homiletic line in the Talmud is intended as the interpretation, or another level of interpretation. (Both approaches are acceptable.)

title: Is it Chukat Hagoy to stand for a Kallah?
content:
# Is it Chukat Hagoy to stand for a Kallah? ## Frage

Is it chukat hagoy to stand for a bride when she walks down the aisle?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

There is some disagreement regarding Chukat Hagoyim regarding instances when we have a specific practical reason to do something that also happens to be done by the goyim. For example, the Rema (O"C 494) cites a custom to adorn the Shul with greenery on Shavuot. The Gra held that it is forbidden to do so because the Goyim similarly decorate their houses of worship (there is discussion about what kinds of greenery were forbidden by the Gra). Some poskim disagree with the Gra on the grounds that if we have our own reason to do something, then it cannot be considered Chukat Hagoyim (see for example Daat Torah O"C 494). In the case of standing for the Kallah, there has been a reason given, which according to this opinion would then take it out of the category of Chukat Hagoyim:

The Mishnah relates that when people would come to bring the bikkurim, the people in Jerusalem would stop what they were doing and stand up. Rav Ovadiah Mebartenura explains they did this out of respect for those engaged in a mitzvah. He writes that this principle applies to certain other mitzvot as well, such as carrying a coffin to burial and carrying a baby to the bris milah. There are those who suggest that this is the basis for the practice to stand when the Chattan and Kallah walk down the aisle.

title: Does אפי תלתא apply to someone who is dead?
content:
# Does אפי תלתא apply to someone who is dead? ## Frage

The Chofetz Chaim Hilchos Lashon Hara 2:2 states:

וּמַה שֶּׁנִּמְצָּא הֶתֵּר בְּדִבְרֵי חֲזַ"ל לוֹמַר בִּפְנִי שְׁלֹשָה, הַיְנוּ בְּדָבָר שֶׁאֵינֶנּוּ גְּנַאי גָּמוּר וְהַדִּבּוּר שֶׁלּוֹ יֵשׁ לוֹ שְׁנִי פָּנִים. וְעִנְיָן כָּזֶה יָדוּעַ שֶׁתָּלוּי לְפִי הַדִּבּוּר, שֶׁאוֹמֵר אוֹתוֹ הַמְסַפֵּר בְּעֵת סִפּוּרוֹ, בָּזֶה הִתִּירוּהוּ חֲזַ"ל לוֹמַר בִּפְנֵי שְׁלֹשָה וְתָלוּהוּ, כֵּיוָן שֶׁאוֹמֵר הַדְּבָרִים בִּפְנִי שְׁלֹשָה, יוֹדֵעַ בְּוַדַּאי שֶׁיָּבוֹאוּ הַדְּבָרִים לְאָזְנָיו, דְּחַבְרָךְ חבְרָא אִית לֵה {שחברך חבר יש לו}, וְעַל כֵּן הוּא שׁוֹמֵר אֶת עַצְּמוֹ בְּעֵת אֲמִירָה לוֹמַר, בְּאֹפֶן שֶׁלֹּא יִהְיֶה מִנְכָּר מִלְּשׁוֹנוֹ לְשׁוֹן גְּנַאי.

As to there being found a heter [a halachic permit] in the words of Chazal to speak it before three, this applies to something which is not an absolute taint and which can be understood in two ways. It is well known that such things depend on how they are said. It is such a thing that Chazal permitted to say in the presence of three, the rationale being that since he says it before three, he knows for a certainty that these things will come to his [the object's] ears (for "your friend has a friend, etc."). The speaker, therefore, heeds himself in speaking, that what he says will not be understood negatively.

If the principle is that it could potentially get back to the person about whom it was said, does this principle hold when that person is dead? There is no way it will get back to that person.

title: What are the differences between the assorted GR"A related siddurim
content:
# What are the differences between the assorted GR"A related siddurim ## Frage

The following siddurim purport to be attempts at constructing a siddur around the GR"A's nusach and teachings, though information on them is scarce and often conflicting.

  • Ishei Yisrael -- אשי ישראל

  • Siddur Vilna -- סידור וולנא

  • Siddur HaGra - B'Nigleh Ve'Nistar -- סידור הגר׳׳א בנגלה ובנסתר

  • Ezor Eliyahu -- אזור אליהו

  • Aliyot Eliyahu -- עליות אליהו

Other answers on this site have discussed that Ezor Eliyahu is a popular siddur among the followers of the GR"A, and that it was revised into Aliyot Eliyahu, though I may have misunderstood that comment, which is why I have labeled them separately. I believe Ishei Yisrael is a yet older version, which may have been revised into Ezor Eliyahu.

I have never heard anyone mention Siddur Vilna, nor Siddur HaGRA B'Nigleh Ve'Nistar.

I believe the B'Nigleh Ve'Nistar version is a siddur with footnotes on the GR"A mysticism, so its reason for separation and printing are clear.

Do any of these siddurim contain differences in the davened prayers, or are the differences are entirely paratextual? If so, what does their paratext focus on, eg: what's the motivation for the siddur's distinction? A blog post: "The Perils of Ignoring Precedent: Alterations in the Kaddish Prayer" seems to hint that the three sidurrim I have lumped together (Ishei Yisrael -> Ezor Eliyahu -> Aliyot Eliyahu) do contain slight liturgical differences, though I'm not certain.

Does anyone have concrete information or sources to share on the liturgical and or paratextual differences between these related siddurim?

title: Help finding source - Avraham, Ur Kasdim, and the Fire of Gehenom
content:
# Help finding source - Avraham, Ur Kasdim, and the Fire of Gehenom ## Frage

Below is a tweet from Josh Rosenfeld (@shuaros) on October 19, 2016:

Avraham forced out of Ur Kasdim against his will/wanted to prepare for pain of Gehinnom/so he could remain there to save his children
~תפא״ש

What is the original source for this idea? Or at least, what sefer is referenced by the rashei teivot at the bottom?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Thank you user "Sholom" for the answer - Tiferet Shlomo, Sukkot, section 17.

ואברהם עודנו עומד לפני ד'. דהנה ידוע גודל מעלת אברהם אבינו ע"ה במסירות נפש לד' ותוקף אהבתו ותשוקתו לעשות רצונו להאבד הוא וכל מאודו לכבוד השם יתעלה. וכל הימים הי' משתוקק ומצפה מתי יגיע לידו איזה נסיון להמסר נפשו להאבד על קדושת שמו ע"כ בפ' העקידה כתיב וישכם אברהם בבקר. כוונתו להשכים בבקר למהר ולבצע את מעשהו לשחוט את בנו יחידו מיד כי ירא פן אח"כ לא יגיע לידו ולא יקום מחשבתו לקיים המצוה הזאת לבצע מעשהו וכאשר הי' באמת הדיבור אל תשלח ידך אל הנער. וכן באור כשדים כתיב והוצאתו מאור כשדים ר"ל בע"כ כי לא רצה לצאת מהכבשן בראותו כי לא נשרף והי' מתעכב והולך בו פן ישרף ומצפה על זה לכבוד הש"י עד שהוציאו הקב"ה בעצמו בע"כ וזהו אשר הוצאתיך מאור כשדים. והנה מסירות נפש ותוקף האהבה לד' היא העומדת לבניו אחריו בכל דור ודור לבטל מהם כל גזירות קשות כמ"ש ויעקד את יצחק בנו הוא הטובה שהיתה לישראל כי עקד כל נשמות ישראל עמו. וזה וישם את בנו ממעל לעצים ר"ל למעלה מבחי' עץ הדעת ועי"ז נתקנו. וז"ש ואברהם עודנו עומד כמ"ש חכז"ל כי אברהם אבינו ע"ה עומד על פתחו של גיהנם וכו':

And Abraham still stands before God. Thus is known the greatness of the virtue of our forefather Abraham, ע"ה, in his devotion to God, and the strength of his love and desire to do His will, even to perish, and with all his resources, for the glory of God, may He be exalted. And all the days he longed and awaited for whichever test to surrender His soul to perish for the sanctity of His Name. Therefore, in the Story on Akkeidah it is written, "And Abraham awoke in the morning." His intention was to get up early in the morning to hurry and carry out his deed of slaughtering his only son immediately, because he feared that later he would not be able to do so and that his mind would not arise to fulfill this commandment to carry out his deed, and when it's later written, "do not lay your hand on the boy." And so it is written in the Ur of Chaldeans, that God took him out of the Ur of the Chaldeans. The intent to say, because he did not want to come out of the furnace when he saw that he was not burned, and he delayed and walked in it, lest he burn up in honor of the God until the Holy One, blessed be He, brought him out Himself from Ur of Chaldeans. And that is why it's written "He brought him out of the Ur of Chaldeans". And his (Abraham's) dedication of the soul and the strength of the love for God stands for his sons after him in every generation to abolish from them all harsh decrees, as it says, "And he bound Isaac his son," that is the good that was to Israel, because he bound all the souls of Israel with him. And this, and "he placed his son upon the pieces of wood", means to say, above the test of the tree of knowledge, and this way it was established. "And Abraham still stood" that why חז"ל say Bereshis Rabba 48:8, "For Abraham our father, may God bless him, stands at the entrance of Gehenna, etc."

title: How can a Sotah profit from sinning?
content:
# How can a Sotah profit from sinning? ## Frage

A Sotah is a woman who went into seclusion with someone after her husband warned her not to go into seclusion with that man. This is a sin.

If a Sotah didn’t do a sexual act while in seclusion, she is rewarded with having children.

We know there a concept in Gemara that a sinner can’t profit. So how can this lady be rewarded with children as a consequence of sinning by going into seclusion?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The Divrei Cheifetz (end of top paragraph) answering a different but related question, suggests that having children is not a reward per se, but rather a natural consequence of the humiliation the accused woman undergoes during the sotah process. He cites the principle of Chazal that inability to have children is one of the things which depends on mazal, not on merit. When someone undergoes great embarrassment Chazal say that on some level they experience death. If so, he writes, their mazal is automatically reset and the old mazal that was stopping them from having children is removed.

(If something is a natural consequence rather than a reward, it does not fall into the category of not rewarding the sinner. To illustrate: if someone robs a bank, they may profit from their sin, but it doesn't contradict this principle because they are not being rewarded, the fact that they have the stolen money is just a natural result).

However, as @Nahum pointed out, this answer will not suffice for the opinion in the Gemara that women who can already have children but with a painful childbirth will now be able to have easier births, etc.

The Divrei Mussar offers a different approach. He writes that there is a principle in Chazal that Hashem does not hold back reward even for someone steeped in sin. This woman who defied her husband to be together with this man, and yet held herself back from sinning, is deserving of some reward for her great restraint, even in the context of her previous failures. When she undergoes the humiliation of the Sotah process, this atones for the sin of secluding with the man. But the zchus of holding back and not completing her sin is still there to be rewarded.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

Perhaps it can be explained based off of another comment by Chazal brought in Rashi to Bamidbar 5:12 that if one withholds what should be given to the kohen then he will end up going to the kohen with his sotah wife in tow (as the kohen is the one that administers the process).

Now, why would someone withhold matnos kehunah? He may not recognize what the kohen is doing for him or doesn't appreciate it enough that he feels the need to support him for it. Or he may be downright miserly and tight-fisted. Whatever the exact reason, these middos, brought over to the home front with regard to his wife, will no doubt have a devastating effect on their relationship. His wife will not feel appreciated, treasured, loved, worthy of her husband spending his money on her and on and on. She will then potentially be open to a more generous and attentive man's attentions.

It turns out that to some extent the husband is to blame, for through his mistreatment of his wife he is pushing her to do things she would otherwise not consider doing.

Therefore, if she doesn't actually commit adultery it makes sense that she receives some compensation for being put through the wringer of the sotah ordeal, as she was somewhat responding to her husband's mistreatment.

(See here for more.)

### Antwort 3 (Score: 0)

While it is of course true that she shouldn't have secluded herself especially with a man that her husband specifically cautioned her regarding, however, once she did, with the ostensible purpose of committing adultery, it is also true that during the seclusion she resisted the enormous pull and desire she has for the man, overcoming the strong attraction she feels toward him.

Although it was certainly wrong of her to seclude herself with him initially and while it was definitely a mess of her own making still and all she did ultimately avoid acting carnally on her feelings and it is for not taking it to the next level that she is rewarded.

Compare it to say someone that goes to a brothel but at the last minute leaves before committing the sin.

title: Using tablets of law as a car decoration
content:
# Using tablets of law as a car decoration ## Frage

Would it be acceptable to use decorative tablets of law as a hood ornament or other decoration as described in Chaim Potok's Book of Lights?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

As no one has answered so far, I'll post my comment as an answer:

I wouldn't use anything with the full text of the Ten Commandments. If it just says 'Alef Bet Gimel' -- something like the US military's symbol for it chaplains:

Personally I'd find it a little tacky, unless someone needed people to know they carried out a religious role. (Parking in the "reserved for clergy" spot at the hospital, for instance.) Otherwise, why are you shouting it out to the world? Tacky ... but I can't say "unacceptable."

The Talmud talks quite a bit about yuhara, the notion that it's wrong for an average person to walk around trying to look like they're a pious sage. There's even a funny story of a fellow who got arrested for wearing a style of clothing only associated with pious sages ... who was able to prove he was, in fact, enough of a sage, and therefore was released.

That's about a hood ornament, which is basically you shouting it to others.

If you want to put it inside the car as a decoration ... again a generic "tablets" symbol like this, without the full text ... if you like it, fine; again, not something I really see a lot of Jews do. But there's no sanctity to a symbol like that, so if it makes you happy, why not. (I definitely have seen car interiors adorned with the text of the Wayfarer's Prayer, but that's a little different.)

title: How does an unmarried woman nurse children?
content:
# How does an unmarried woman nurse children? ## Frage

In Avodah Zarah 26a, the gemara provides two excuses that a woman might give if asked by a non-Jewish woman to nurse her baby. She can say that she desires to get married, so does not want anybody to see her nursing, and she can also say (if she already is married) that she does not wish to become repulsive to her husband.

I am wondering how an unmarried woman nurses a child. Is the implication that she had a baby but its father died or divorced her? Or is the passage predicated on a belief that women could nurse children without having first given birth themselves?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The gemara does not say anything about her being embarrassed to be seen nursing. I also don't see that implied in the commentaries. All I see is a very "diplomatic" statement that covers all possibilities.

I want to get married.

This carries everything:

  1. I have never had a baby so I cannot lactate.
  2. Even if I could lactate, I don't want to harm my prospects of getting married.

Possibility 2 covers all cases:

  • She already has a baby and that would embarrass her
  • It would not embarrass her to reveal she had a baby, but it would otherwise disrupt her prospects of getting married
  • They did know how to induce lactation back then

So, the excuse the gemara provides for single women is designed to be diplomatic and cover all possibilities without implying any of them, and without causing enmity.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

I don't understand the question. Yes, the Talmud was dealing with reality, and not suggesting something that does not accord with reality. The passage in question:

סָבַר רַב יוֹסֵף לְמֵימַר: אוֹנוֹקֵי בְּשָׂכָר שְׁרֵי מִשּׁוּם אֵיבָה. אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: יָכְלָה לְמֵימַר, אִי פְּנוּיָה הִיא — ״בָּעֵינָא לְאִינְּסוֹבֵי״, אִי אֵשֶׁת אִישׁ הִיא — ״לָא קָא מִזְדַּהַמְנָא בְּאַפֵּי גַּבְרַאי״.

Rav Yosef also thought to say: Nursing the child of a gentile woman in exchange for payment is permitted due to enmity. Abaye said to him: The concern of enmity does not apply, because she can say, if she is unmarried: I wish to get married. And if she is a married woman, she may say: I do not wish to become repulsive to my husband. Since she can provide a reasonable excuse for refusing to nurse a gentile child, the concern of enmity does not apply.

That is, a woman who can nurse, and perhaps has functioned as a wetnurse in the past, is approached to be employed by a gentile woman. This is targeting women who can nurse, not all women in the world. Abaye explains how there would be no enmity caused by refusal, because of a credible excuse. For those women who are not married, they would say X; for those who are married, they would say Y.

So yes, we would read the gemara in a way that conforms to reality, that there are some unmarried women who are wetnurses. That could arise due to out-of-wedlock pregnancies, or a woman who was divorced or widowed. Indeed, this newfound singlehood might have not even occurred recently, as a wetnurse who continues in the profession without pause can do so for years. Abaye said this to comprehensively cover all cases, so that there is no enmity in a subset of cases.

content:
# Must a gadol have two pubic hairs? ## Frage

According to Mishna Niddah, for a male to have the halachic status of a גדול (an adult obligated in the mitzvot), he must be over 13 years old, and have at least two pubic hairs.

Anecdotally, I have never seen a case where the second condition had practical ramifications (e.g. a late-developing boy having his בר מצְוה ceremony postponed, or not being counted in a Minyan, etc). Personally, when I turned 13, nobody asked me whether I had pubic hair before allowing me to say a ברכה on the Torah, or to say קִדּוּשׁ, or to count in an Minyan, and so on.

Does the second condition still apply today? Does a child need to have pubic hair before being considered a גדול?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

See Pitchei Teshuva on Shulchan Aruch Yoreh Deah 1:11

שנעשה בר מצוה. עי' במג"א סל"ט סק"א דבדבר דקטן פסול מדאורייתא בעינן שיהא גדול ממש דהיינו שהביא ב' שערות אחר שהוא בן י"ג שנה ועי' ברמ"א שם סימן נ"ה ס"ה דלמידי דרבנן סומכין על החזקה שהביא ב"ש ע"ש. ומזה נלמוד לנדון זה דאף אחר יג"ש ויום א' אסור לשחוט לצורך אכילה מאחר שהוא פסול מדאורייתא או מטעמא דהלבוש שאינו בר זביחה או מטעמא דהש"ך שאינו בר עדות אם אין אחר עומד על גביו עד שיוודע שהביא ב"ש או שהוא בן ל"ה שנה ויום א' (ומ"ש המג"א עד שיהא בן י"ח שנה כבר תמהו עליו האחרונים) או שנתמלא זקנו כמבואר בח"מ סל"ה

I'll translate the parts in bold:

See Magen Avraham [Orach Chaim] 39:1, where something that a minor would be Biblically disqualified, it is required that he be an actual adult, i.e. have 2 pubic hairs after they are 13 years old. And see the Rema in 55:5 where if it is a Rabbinical matter, we can rely on the assumption that he has 2 pubic hairs...[Alternatively, he is considered an adult even without pubic hair] once he reaches 35 years and one day, or has a full beard, as is explained in Choshen Mishpat 35[:1]

title: What is the commentary שדה צופים on the Rosh?
content:
# What is the commentary שדה צופים on the Rosh? ## Frage

Curiosity got the better of me and I was looking in the back of the Gemara Megilah at the Rosh to see what he says. Then I noticed that there is a commentary on the Rosh called שדה צופים. All it does is quote the Rosh in other places in shas.

My question is why? When was it written? And why is it called that name?

Any other trivia is welcome as well.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

A little bit of digging led to me find on the Otzar Website here that the author was the Dayan and Rosh Yeshiva Rabbi Bezalel Ronsburg/Ranschburg who lived 1760-1820.

According to here:

He devoted himself to commenting on those tractates of the Talmud on which there are few commentaries, such as his Horah Gever on *Horayot (Prague, 1802) and Pitḥei Niddah (1957; published in Jerusalem 1928 under the title Hokhmat Beẓalel). His Sedeh Zofim on *Asher b. Jehiel's halakhot was appended to the Prague Talmud edition (1839–46). His Ma'aseh Rav (Prague, 1823) deals partly with tractate Nazir. *Haggahot based on it are included in all subsequent editions of the Talmud. Many letters on halakhic subjects which he wrote to the censor Carolus Fischer (partly signed "Ilan Shoshan") are preserved in the Prague University Library (mgwj, 62 (1918), 49–56).

  • "Asher b. Jehiel" (Asher ben Yechiel) is the Rosh.

title: Samson is Marked for Punishment for Following his Eyes Before He is Described as Actually Following his Eyes - Why?
content:
# Samson is Marked for Punishment for Following his Eyes Before He is Described as Actually Following his Eyes - Why? ## Frage

Judges 14:

וַיֹּ֨אמֶר ל֜וֹ אָבִ֣יו וְאִמּ֗וֹ הַאֵין֩ בִּבְנ֨וֹת אַחֶ֤יךָ וּבְכׇל־עַמִּי֙ אִשָּׁ֔ה כִּֽי־אַתָּ֤ה הוֹלֵךְ֙ לָקַ֣חַת אִשָּׁ֔ה מִפְּלִשְׁתִּ֖ים הָעֲרֵלִ֑ים וַיֹּ֨אמֶר שִׁמְשׁ֤וֹן אֶל־אָבִיו֙ אוֹתָ֣הּ קַֽח־לִ֔י כִּי־הִ֖יא יָשְׁרָ֥ה בְעֵינָֽי׃
His father and mother said to him, “Is there no one among the daughters of your own kindred and among all our people, that you must go and take a wife from the uncircumcised Philistines?” But Samson answered his father, “Get me that one, for she is the one that pleases me.”

Then he meets her and is described as:

וַיֵּ֖רֶד וַיְדַבֵּ֣ר לָֽאִשָּׁ֑ה וַתִּישַׁ֖ר בְּעֵינֵ֥י שִׁמְשֽׁוֹן׃
Then he went down and spoke to the woman, and she pleased Samson.

This means that he is described later on as finding her pleasing - after he said that she was pleasing.

The Talmud imputes guilt to Samson as the get-go (Sota 9b):

גְּמָ׳ תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: שִׁמְשׁוֹן בְּעֵינָיו מָרַד, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיֹּאמֶר שִׁמְשׁוֹן אֶל אָבִיו אוֹתָהּ קַח לִי כִּי הִיא יָשְׁרָה בְעֵינָי״ — לְפִיכָךְ נִקְּרוּ פְּלִשְׁתִּים אֶת עֵינָיו, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיֹּאחֲזוּהוּ פְלִשְׁתִּים וַיְנַקְּרוּ אֶת עֵינָיו״.
GEMARA: The Sages taught (Tosefta 3:15): Samson rebelled with his eyes, as it is stated: “Then his father and his mother said to him: Is there never a woman among the daughters of your brethren, or among all my people, that you go out to take a wife of the uncircumcised Philistines? And Samson said to his father: Get her for me; for she is pleasant in my eyes” (Judges 14:3). Therefore, the Philistines gouged out his eyes, as it is stated: “And the Philistines laid hold on him, and put out his eyes” (Judges 16:21).

Thus, Samson is already guilty of following his eyes at the moment he said she was pleasing even though the story has not yet described him as coming to that realization himself.

The Talmud thus finds him guilty of following his eyes from the get-go (the first mention in the Psukim).

אִינִי? וְהָכְתִיב: ״וְאָבִיו וְאִמּוֹ לֹא יָדְעוּ כִּי מֵה׳ הִיא״. כִּי אֲזַל מִיהָא — בָּתַר יַשְׁרוּתֵיהּ אֲזַל.
The Gemara asks: Is that so? But isn’t it written: “But his father and his mother knew not that it was from the Lord; as he sought a subterfuge against the Philistines” (Judges 14:4), indicating that Samson’s searching for a Philistine wife was due to a Divine mission? The Gemara answers: Although God did plan the punishment of the Philistines, in any event when he went, he followed his inclination and did not act for the sake of Heaven.

Why is he characterized as following his eyes before being described as finding her pleasing in his eyes?

title: Does a store need to honor gift cards sold by a previous store which went bankrupt?
content:
# Does a store need to honor gift cards sold by a previous store which went bankrupt? ## Frage

If you bought a gift card from store A, which then goes bankrupt, with store B then selling the original material, does store B have to honor the original gift card sold by store A?

(I was told that Reb Moshe says yes. Where is that teshuvah located?)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

It is impossible to give a definite answer without knowing the details. This is likely to be highly dependent on

  1. the terms of the purchase agreement between store B and store A. In some cases, the terms cover only the purchase of the stock and rental agreement, in others, it might be a full takeover of the business with all its debts. In the first case, the gift card wouldn't be covered, in the second, it would
  2. the law of the land, in case it prescribes a certain set of mandatory behaviors (e.g., to honor the previous store's debts if you continue their business)

This being said, R Moshe Feinstein addresses business bankruptcies in Igrot Moshe CM II:62 where he emphasizes the need to apply the law of the land. Specifically there he forbids the owner from repaying certain debts ahead of others and favoring certain debt-holders.

title: Why EXACTLY did Moshe make a copper snake?
content:
# Why EXACTLY did Moshe make a copper snake? ## Frage

B"H

In parshas Chukas, 5th reading, it discusses how Hashem sent snakes on the Jewish people, after they spoke out again Hashem and Moshe, because the snake, who was punished for not being able to speak at all anymore, is taking vengeance on the people who complained with their language etc, as Rashi writes:

6 G-d sent the venomous snakes against the people, and they bit the people, and many Israelites died. ו וַיְשַׁלַּ֨ח יְהֹוָ֜ה בָּעָ֗ם אֵ֚ת הַנְּחָשִׁ֣ים הַשְּׂרָפִ֔ים וַיְנַשְּׁכ֖וּ אֶת־הָעָ֑ם וַיָּ֥מָת עַם־רָ֖ב מִיִּשְׂרָאֵֽל: אֵת הַנְּחָשִׁים הַשְּׂרָפִים - The venomous snakes - i.e., that burn (שׂוֹרְפִים) a person with the poison of their teeth. אֵת הַנְּחָשִׁים הַשְּׂרָפִים. שֶׁשּׂוֹרְפִים אֶת הָאָדָם בְּאֶרֶס שִׁנֵּיהֶם: וַיְנַשְּׁכוּ אֵת הָעָם - And they bit the people. Let the snake, who was punished for slander, come and exact punishment from these people who slander; let the snake, to whom all types of food taste the same, come and exact punishment from ungrateful people for whom one thing (the manna) can have several varying tastes. וַ יְנַשְּׁכוּ אֵת הָעָם. יָבֹא נָחָשׁ שֶׁלָּקָה עַל הוֹצָאַת דִּבָּה וְיִפָּרַע מִמּוֹצִיאֵי דִּבָּה, יָבֹא נָחָשׁ שֶׁכָּל הַמִּינִין נִטְעָמִין לוֹ טַעַם אֶחָד וְיִפָּרַע מִכְּפוּיֵי טוֹבָה שֶׁדָּבָר אֶחָד מִשְׁתַּנֶּה לָהֶם לְכַמָּה מַטְעַמִּים (תנחומא):

But then, when they're being healed, Hashem told Moshe to make a snake model (without specific the material), and Moshe on his own decided to make it out of copper (נחשת), because "it's a language falling on a language" (i.e., it's a submission language to נחש, snake):

9 Moses made a copper snake and put it on a pole. If a snake had bitten a person and he looked toward the copper snake, he lived. ט וַיַּ֤עַשׂ משֶׁה֙ נְחַ֣שׁ נְח֔שֶׁת וַיְשִׂמֵ֖הוּ עַל־הַנֵּ֑ס וְהָיָ֗ה אִם־נָשַׁ֤ךְ הַנָּחָשׁ֙ אֶת־אִ֔ישׁ וְהִבִּ֛יט אֶל־נְחַ֥שׁ הַנְּח֖שֶׁת וָחָֽי: נְחַשׁ נְחשֶׁת - A copper snake. He was not told to make it from copper. However, Moses said: “The Holy One, blessed be He, calls it נָחָשׁ, and I will make it from copper (נְחֹשֶׁת), since they are similar words.” נְחַשׁ נְחשֶׁת. לֹא נֶאֱמַר לוֹ לַעֲשׂוֹתוֹ שֶׁל נְחֹשֶׁת, אֶלָּא אָמַר מֹשֶׁה, הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא קוֹרְאוֹ נָחָשׁ וַאֲנִי אֶעֱשֶׂנּוּ שֶׁל נְחֹשֶׁת, לָשׁוֹן נוֹפֵל עַל לָשׁוֹן

I was thinking about the two comments, and it seems it had something to do with fixing the mistake of the Jewish people regarding their language, that somehow through making this copper snake which has a "language falling on a language", that could rectify the negative language they spoke.

But how exactly? What is the explanation for why specifically a copper snake would fix this sin? And why did Moshe decide on his own to make it out of copper, when apparently based only on what Hashem told him, it may have been enough to just use any material for the snake?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Ramban on Bereshis 21:9 is not satisfied with Rashi and offers his take. The punchline is the last two paragraphs:

AND MOSES MADE ‘NECHASH NECHOSHETH’ (A SERPENT OF BRASS). “He was not told to make it of brass. But Moses said: ‘The Holy One, blessed be He, called it a nachash (serpent); therefore I will make it of nechosheth (brass) — since the one word resembles the other [in sound].” This is Rashi’s language, based upon the words of our Rabbis. (Bereshith Rabbah 31:8).

But I do not understand this, for the Holy One, blessed be He, did not mention to Moses [the word] nachash, but said to him, Make thee ‘saraf’ (a fiery serpent)! (Bamidbar 21:8). But the intention of the Sages is that Moses was guided by the substantive name thereof [which is nachash; and saraf is merely a particular description of a certain kind of serpent — a “fiery” serpent — hence he made the saraf which G-d mentioned to him from nechosheth (brass), corresponding with its substantive name].

It appears to me that the secret of this matter is that this is one of the ways of the Torah, every deed of which is a miracle within a miracle. Thus [the Torah] removes injury by means of the cause of the injury, and heals illness by means of the cause of the sickness, as the Rabbis have mentioned in connection with [the verse], and the Eternal showed him a tree (Exodus 15:25), and as occurred with the salt that Elisha [cast] into the water. (II Kings 2:21).

Now it is a well-known medical principle that all people bitten by poisonous creatures become dangerously ill when they see them, or [even] when they [only] see their likeness, so that if people who have been bitten by a mad dog or other mad animals look into water (“or any mirror.”), they see there the image of the dog or the attacker, and [this] can [cause them to] die, as is written in medical books and mentioned in the Gemara of Tractate Yoma, daf 84a. Similarly doctors protect them from [people] mentioning in their presence the name of the animal that bit them, [and they forbid people] to mention it at all, because their minds cling to this thought and do not turn away from it altogether until it causes their death.

[The doctors] have already mentioned that it is an empirical fact, amongst the wonders of reproduction, that if the urine of a person bitten by a mad dog is put in a glass receptacle after he has become rabidly sick, there will appear in that urine the likeness of the young of small dogs. And if you pass the liquid through a cloth and filter it, you will not find any trace of them at all; but if you return the liquid to the glass bottle, and it remains there for about an hour, you will again clearly see in it the small dogs. This is a true fact, and of the wonders of the powers of the soul.

Now in view of all this, it would have been correct that the Israelites, who had been bitten by the fiery serpents, should not look upon a serpent, and should not mention it or bring it to mind at all. But the Holy One, blessed be He, commanded Moses to make for them the likeness of a fiery serpent, which was [the creature] that killed them. And it is well-known that these fiery serpents have red eyes and wide heads, and their bodies at their necks are like brass. Therefore Moses could not fulfill His command to make a fiery serpent except by making a serpent of brass, which appears similar to a fiery serpent. For had he made it of any other material, it would have had the likeness of a serpent, but not that of a saraf (a fiery serpent). And the Rabbis (Bereshith Rabbah 31:8) who said [that Moses was to make a brass serpent] because “one word corresponds [in sound] to the other,” [meant to imply] that the mere mention of the name [saraf, which is a particular form of nachash, as explained above] was harmful [for the people who had been bitten, and yet G-d wanted to heal them through it].

The general intention [of this section, then] is that G-d commanded that they should be healed by the harmful agent whose nature is to kill; therefore they made its likeness in form and name, and when a person concentrated his gaze upon the brass serpent which resembled totally the offending agent, he lived. This was to make them realize that it is G-d [alone] Who sendeth death and maketh alive. (I Samuel 2:6).

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

A couple of answers...

First note the Sforno - The copper colour induced remorse:

נחש נחשת. אחר שהבין כונת קונו הסכים לעשותו של נחשת ולא של זהב כדי שיזכיר להם עונם מצד מראה החומר ושמו ותבניתו שעשו מעשה הנחש בהבל פיהם בדברם נגד ה' ונגד פעלו ונגד עבדו

נחש נחושת - After Moshe had understood what G-d had intended with His command, he agreed to make this replica of a snake out of copper and not out of gold. Copper would be more likely to induce thoughts of remorse as they would associate its colour with the sensation of burning.

Chizkuni - It served a functional purpose i.e.copper when shiny is highly visible

נחש נחשת לפי שהנחושת מבהיק ומבריק כענין שנאמר ונוצצים כעין נחשת קלל ואע״‎פ שמחנה ישראל היה שלש פרסאות על שלש פרסאות מי שהיה נשוך רואהו ממקומו.

נחש נחשת - “A copper snake.” This metal was chosen, as, when polished, it shines and reflects light and therefore is highly visible. We know this from Ezekiel 1,7, where the prophet describes his vision of angels whose hooflike feet were described as sparkling like burnished copper. Even though the area of the Israelites camp was three miles square, anyone who had been bitten by a snake could see the copper snake that Moses had mounted on a pole.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 1)

I posted a link to the maamar in Likkutei Torah above under a comment to the original question. I will summarize the maamar here to the best of my ability bez’H:

ויעש משה נחש נחשת To which the alter rebbe first brings the Mishnah from Rosh hashana “was it the snake that gave life or the opposite? Rather, as long as bnei Yisrael looked above and subjugated their hearts to their father in heaven…etc. על זה בזמן שישראל מסתכלין כלפי מעלה ומשעבדין את לבם לאביהם שבשמים כו׳

The alter rebbe immediately asks two questions on this Mishnah. 1) if bnei Yisrael only needed to look above, why a snake? Seemingly it would have sufficed to just put a sign on a pole that says “look up”. 2) there is a Gemara in yevamos that specifically states when a person davens he should put his eyes towards the eretz and his heart towards shamayim, seemingly contradicting our Mishnah that says they should look up and pray.

The alter rebbe begins by explaining the entire tachlis the neshama descends into a guf is to cleave to Hashem with Ahavah and yirah because this reaches the depths of a person more than machshava dibur or masseh expressed when fulfilling 613 mitzvos (which are considered levushim for the neshama). And we know, tefilah is avodah sheba lev. So therefore it follows the entire purpose of the neshama to come down into this world is for tefilah.

This answer seemingly doesn’t make sense though because before the neshama descends, it experiences infinitely greater revelation of G-dliness in the higher realms, and therefore the love and awe it feels are also infinitely higher! (Additionally during the times of the first and second Beis Hamikdash there was very little tefilah compared to what we have today-partially due to the fact tefilah is substituting for korbanos during golus). So how did they fulfill the their purpose of descending into this world ?

To this, the alter rebbe brings a Zohar that says “any person who does not transform the bitter into sweet does not have a portion in olam haba, for this is the entire purpose of creating man”. The alter rebbe explains turning bitter to sweet is “sweetening the dinim at their source”. What does that mean…?

The alter rebbe first begins by explaining everything’s source is hashem. Even things that appear bad in this world such as suffering or the like (rachmana litzlan) all have their source in hashem. It’s just when they come down through the hishtalshelus the light and goodness becomes concealed and hidden. In this way, our rabbis zl explained the term “meod” in “very good” that was said after the 6 days of creation as the malach hamaves and the yezter hara. The alter rebbe brings the mashal of the zonah hired by the king to tempt the prince. It is only to elevate the prince by revealing his inner qualities and strengths. That’s the entire purpose of a test is to elevate a person to a higher level. And the harlot who is attempting to seduce the prince is actually working for the king! Not only that, but she also wants to fail and the prince to succeed knowing how much pleasure this is going to give the king.

And this is sweetening the judgements: to understand everything that happens is hashgacha pratis and its source is good. Specifically, when a person takes this to heart the judgment itself actually changes. It’s not that the person’s perspective changed and so now the situation is good according to his new view, but the situation itself changes and becomes good.

This is most famously highlighted with the stories of nachman ish gam zu, who saw everything as good. Not that it would be good at some future time, but that it was currently good. (“Zu”=“this” denotes something physically in front of the observer that he can point to). And this in turn actually transformed the current reality (As evidenced by the fact that the dirt in the chest literally changed into the dirt of Avraham etc. see Gemara there)

So that was the message of the snake, it’s not that the snakes were bad, they were merely a conduit for building a deeper and stronger connection with Hashem. And they were sent from Hashem. And bnei Yisrael needed to look and see, this itself was actually good. And once they internalized this, the “bad” literally become the source of “life” and healing.

As for the reason they were made out of copper, the alter rebbe says from the Gemara regarding the doors of nikanor (see Yoma) “that they were the only thing in the Beis Hamikdash that was not replaced with gold. And some say they shone even more brilliantly than gold.” Copper changes color when hit by the sun. So too do our challenges and struggles change from sorrows rachmana litzlan to newfound levels of divine connection and blessings when we connect with The Source.

title: Not believing in G-d - Jews in the Desert
content:
# Not believing in G-d - Jews in the Desert ## Frage

I am a little bit confused on how to understand the disbelief of the Jews in the desert, and it is somewhat difficult to phrase my question.

How is it possible to not believe in G-d when the Jews saw all these many miracles in Egypt: the giving of the Torah, the filling of the Mishkan with G-d's Shekhina etc.?

Trying to answer my question, I could say that they might have believed that the miracles were done by Moshe, Aaron and Miriam. They could not see beyond! However, I would accept that once but not so many times. This rebelliousness prevailed all along.

How come then it is so "easy" to believe in G-d today, when we no longer witness unnatural miracles but back then, when people saw all these miracles and signs and so on, derailed so easily

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

A very thoughtful question! The Midrashim go at length to explain how the overwhelming majority of Jews did not participate in the sin of the Golden Calf, and the ones that did still believed in God, they just thought that they needed an intermediary in order to receive His blessings and guidance. Even the Eruv Rav - the Egyptian converts who started the whole matter, believed in God, but they also believed in other gods too.

The Midrashim, as usual, base on this on a close reading of the verses, rather than mere apologetics, and in this case, it's very easy to see when you know where to look. In order to see this methodically laid out, I recommend this shiur by Rabbi Dovid Gottleib. I will also share a Drasha that I wrote, based on it, for Parashat Ki Tisa, especially because it also deals with Bitachon, one of your tags:

There are two ways to hide a diamond. One is to hide it, and one is to bury it among  mundane items, like toy diamonds. In the case of the Chet HaEgel, the general flow of the story seems like the Jewish people bowed down to an idol, right after Har Sinai, and everyone focuses on that. However, the truth of the story is that only a few actually bowed down to the idol, a tiny tiny minority, probably just the Eruv Rav, and the rest of the 3 million Jewish people were doing something else…, and if we look closely at the pasukim, we can see it, without needing to look at Drash, Remez or Kabbalah.

Look at the language carefully: “The people saw that Moshe delayed in descending the mountain, and they gathered around Aaron and said, ‘Rise up, make for us gods that will go before us, because this man Moshe who brought us up from Egypt—we don’t know what happened to him.’” (Shemot 32:1). The problem begins not with a desire to abandon Hashem, but with confusion and fear over Moshe’s absence. They weren’t looking for a new god—they were looking for guidance, for something tangible to take Moshe’s place.

Even more striking is Aaron’s response. After making the calf, the people say, “These are your gods, O Israel, who brought you up from the land of Egypt.” (32:4). But Aaron immediately declares, “Tomorrow will be a festival for Hashem.” (32:5). If this was outright idol worship, why would Aaron sanctify it in Hashem's name? Clearly, the calf was never meant to replace Hashem for the vast majority of the 3 million Jews (as only 10,000 total ended up dying afterwards)—it was meant to replace Moshe to connect them to Hashem.

So, everyone thinks that the main message of Ki Tisa is how bad the Jews were, but that’s not true. The real message is the ending of the story. Hashem said to Moshe וְשָׁלַחְתִּי לְפָנֶיךָ מַלְאָךְ … and when Moshe told Benei Yisrael this, וַיִּשְׁמַע הָעָם אֶת־הַדָּבָר הָרָע הַזֶּה וַיִּתְאַבָּלוּ וְלֹא־שָׁתוּ אִישׁ עֶדְיוֹ עָלָיו. Moshe said to Hashem אִם־אֵין פָּנֶיךָ הֹלְכִים אַל־תַּעֲלֵנוּ מִזֶּה, and then וַיֹּאמֶר ה' אֶל־מֹשֶׁה גַּם אֶת־הַדָּבָר הַזֶּה אֲשֶׁר־דִּבַּרְתָּ אֶעֱשֶׂה כִּי־מָצָאתָ חֵן בְּעֵינַי וָאֵדָעֲךָ בְשֵׁם.

So, what was the sin? The sin was a sin of Bitachon. This one sin is something even the greatest of the greats failed in – such as Yaakov preparing gifts for Esav and bowing to him. It came from a place of humility – we felt we didn’t deserve Hashem. Hashem held that against us – nobody wants a friend, or a spouse, who is constantly feeling unworthy, not believing your promises to love them and look after them!

So let’s discuss some halachot about Bitachon for the remainder of the Dvar Torah, to help us do teshuva for the Chet Ha’egel and bring Moshiach!

People are very confused about Bitachon. There’s always an argument – someone says “just trust in Hashem” and someone retorts “but you have to make a hishtadlut!”, and the first person says “but it’s a mitzva to put our trust in Hashem, don’t you know the story of the man who sold his donkey and became a millionaire?” and the other person says “don’t YOU know the story of the person who’s child was sick, and he didn’t take them to the doctor and they died!”.

This is actually a battle between someone whose soul is rooted in Chesed, vs someone whose soul is rooted in Gevura. What is the answer to this puzzle? Well, it’s actually quite simple – we have a mitzva to make hishtadlut, but we are also commanded to realise that we are only doing that hishatdlut because Hashem commanded us to, not because we believe that hishtadlut has any power on its own. It doesn’t – we have to keep in mind that the blessing and success comes only from Hashem. This is why the Tzemach Tzeddek in Derech Mitzvotecha says that when it comes to hishtadlut, we are not allowed to make even one extra drop of effort more than required. If we need £5000 to get through the month, we must calculate exactly how much effort it takes to earn that, and then do that effort and no more.

So, why does Hashem want us to make effort? There are many reasons for this, but to cut to the chase, His blessings for us are so lofty, that they mamash do not fit into nature. They descend from the highest of heavens down to the level of Gan Eden, but to make the leap to the physical world, they need a vessel to be made by our own efforts. If they were to come any other way, the miracles would disrupt Hashem’s plan for a natural world. This is of course possible, but requires a huge zechus. Therefore, we need to partner with Hashem, and through our efforts, especially our efforts in tefilla, we enable the blessings to come down through non-miraculous means.

This helps explain another halacha about Bitachon – the more bitachon we have, the less effort we need to put in. This is what Rabbeinu Ovadia wrote in Etz Anaf Avot – he brought a story from the Chafetz Chaim, when people were being drafted for the army they came to him to ask what to do. The Chafetz Chaim reminded them about what it says in Avot: whoever accepts upon himself the yoke of Torah, the yoke of government will be removed from him. Rav Ovadia asks: how then so many yeshiva students are being drafted and he said that the heavenly court deals with people measure for measure – if they dedicated themselves to their Torah study with strength and unwavering commitment, without being interrupted, the yoke of government is removed completely. If they are lazy and undedicated, their acceptance of the yoke of Torah is weak and so the removal of the yoke of government is also weak.

So yes, indeed the greatest tzaddikim do indeed not have to put in any effort and can sit back and do nothing and Hashem will bless them, although this is something only one in a million can achieve. Anyone else who does this will be punished for it. The blessings that Hashem sent for them will remain for their soul in Gan Eden, but they will cause sorrow down here on earth due to not bringing the blessings down to where they were meant to go!

So, yes, we are all meant to engage in effort. We are meant to take out life insurance, go to the doctor when we are sick, teach our children a trade, and ourselves work, and not sit back and learn Torah and hope for the best. We must also make sure to put in all our effort to help our friends when they are in need and not lecture them about having bitachon. However, we must always work on our bitachon, never letting our work and efforts overshadow our Torah learning, and always remember that it is Hashem who sends the blessings and He can and will give us a good life if only we trust in Him with all our hearts. Emunah means everything is ultimately for the good, but bitachon means that we can trust that Hashem will make it good and sweet, and our prayers will come true in a way that we can visibly and tangibly see. We must remain optimistic at all times, even in the face of trouble, and certainly never panic and rush to a decision like Benei Yisrael did with the Egel!

The point of bitachon is to give us a life free of worry and anxiety, a life of tranquillity and peace. Shaar Habitachon says that anyone can have an easy life – one where we don’t have to work very much, and have a tranquil life of peace, serenity, with our families, and have our dreams come true – if only we have bitachon! The only thing stopping us from having all this is lack of bitachon. This comes from love and fear of Hashem; indeed as we saw with Benei Yisrael, bitachon is the essential ingredient for a good relationship,  most of all our relationship with Hashem – He promised to look after us, and bless us, and never abandon us – why do we doubt him?! We shouldn’t, we should be glad that He is our God and He is looking after us at all times, and love Him for it, and our bitachon will increase and we will not need anyone else, not even a malach.

We only want You Hashem! Shabbat Shalom.

### Antwort 2 (Score: -1)

I heard a very beautiful answer that also relates to a well known story in the psychology field called “the marshmallow test”. For those unfamiliar, you can read about it here https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanford_marshmallow_experiment As noted in that source, it was later discovered the test didn’t have so much to do with “willpower” but many other factors such as trust and security. That part is nogea to our question here.

Bnei Yisroel were in mitzrayim for a couple hundred years (210) and were steeped in a culture who worshiped nature. Everything about the Egyptian society and religion was centered around nature being divine (sun god, moon god, river god, wind god, etc). And this is why pharaoh specifically said “וַיֹּאמֶר פַּרְעֹה מִי ה” using the name Havaya (denoting above nature and time [hayah, hoveh, yihyeh]) and they were so concerned with proving the makos were a “natural” phenomenon (“this is the finger of Elokim”- elokim genatria hateva). This is the society and influence bnei Yisroel were subjected to.

So what did Hashem do? He sent signs and wonders and miracles to destroy and break this false paradigm. The issue was bnei Yisroel had trust issues due to their abuse over the generations. So Hashem had to show them. And show them again. And again. Like a parent that has to keep reaffirming their support and love and dependability to a damaged child who grew up in an unhealthy environment.

Just as a side note, we are still in golus and G-d forbid it should last another second, but I think most people (especially myself) still struggle with this. How much importance do we place on “nature” and what is “likely” to occur? How many of us can confidently walk as nachum ish gam zu and declare “gam zu letovah” for everything we encounter in this world? Being “in mitzrayim” is just as much a physical golus as a spiritual golus. And for that, Hashem is constantly and continuously creating miracles for us every second of every day and we still struggle with trust. The story of yetzias mitzrayim is just as relevant today as it was in the year 2448

title: Can a Jew wear a linen shirt with a wool tallis?
content:
# Can a Jew wear a linen shirt with a wool tallis? ## Frage

Is it allowed for Jews to wear a linen shirt when one is wearing a wool tallis, for example during Shacharit or when one is leading a service? Does just layering or contact constitute shatnez or does it require weaving or sewing?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Yes it is allowed. The prohibition of shatnez applies when the two materials are combine via combing, spinning, sewing, etc. does not apply to different garments layered on one another
