title: Sheva mayos vishivim (770), mi yodeya?
content:
# Sheva mayos vishivim (770), mi yodeya? ## Frage

B"H

What are some significances of the number 770 in the Torah and Judaism? Gematrias are allowed if they are relevant to a specific topic.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Gematria of the word קערת is 770. It is significant in Midrash Bamidbar Rabba 14:12 describing the offering of Nachshon ben Aminadav:

Rabbi Shemaya said: From where do you say that it is regarding Adam the first man that kaarat kesef (קערת כסף) is stated? It is because the tally of the years of Adam the first man was nine hundred and thirty years, and the numerical value of kaarat kesef is nine hundred and thirty.

The full calculation here is

  • Kof – 100; ayin – 70; resh – 200; tav – 400; together they sum to 770.
  • Kaf – 20; samekh – 60; peh – 80; together they sum to 160.

The two sums together equal 930 (we do not have a question about 930 on Mi Yodeya).

Alternatively, several words from Tanakh have gematria 770.

  • The well named עין-שמש - Ein Shemesh (Eye of the sun) on the border between Binyamin and Yehudah, Yehoshua 15:7 or Yehoshua 18:17.
  • משכית - image, figure; imagination, conceit, Vayikra 26:1, Bamidbar 33:52, Yechezkel 8:12, Tehilim 73:7, Mishlei 18:11, Mishlei 25:11.
  • עשת - bar of metal, tablet (of ivory) Shir haShirim 5:14; steel (in modern Hebrew).
### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

בית משיח — “Beit Moshiach / the House of Moshiach”

בית: ב(2)+י(10)+ת(400)=412

משיח: מ(40)+ש(300)+י(10)+ח(8)=358

412+358=770

Used homiletically for the dwelling/manifestation of the Davidic redemption.

### Antwort 3 (Score: -1)

B"H

770 E. Parkway is the address of the Chabad headquarters of America, which also has the gematria of בית משיח and פרצת, and is the place that the future Messiah will first be revealed at, according to the words of the Lubavitcher Rebbe. (Kuntress Beis Rabbenui Shebebbavel).

It's significant because that's the location where the Moshiach is waiting to redeem Yisroel, in the house of our Rebbe in Babylon.

ולהעיר, ש"בית משיח" בגימטריא "פרצת" (770). ודו"ק

title: Re-using the tune from a song about Avoda Zara
content:
# Re-using the tune from a song about Avoda Zara ## Frage

I heard in a shiur a cute story about someone who made a tikkun for a neshama, by singing one of his tunes during hakafot. The story was about taking a tune and making it holy, and how this is a positive. It made me think of this question.

So, unrelated to said positive, I want to ask if we are generally allowed to take a tune from a song about Avoda Zara - just the melody, not the lyrics - and make it into a song about something holy?

We are strictly forbidden to get hana'ah (pleasure or benefit) from Avoda Zara, even indirectly, but the melody is abstract. Maybe it is similar to benefiting from a mountain that was worshiped?

הגוים העובדים את ההרים ואת הגבעות, הן מתרין

With regard to the halakha in the case of the gentiles who worship the mountains and the hills, the mountains and hills are permitted [but what is upon them is forbidden] (Mishna Avoda Zara 3:5)

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

There's a great article on Contrafaction in Jewish prayer by Joshua Jacobson. Pulling out some of the relevant halachic opinions from it, because it is rather lengthy!

Opinions against:

Rabbi Yehudah He-Hasid (c. 1150 - 1217) wrote, “In the case of a hymn composed by a priest for worship in a non-Jewish service, even if a Jew considers it to be a beautiful form of praise, he should not chant it to God in Hebrew.”

Rabbi Yehudah Al-Harizi (c. 1170-1235) wrote of his visit to a Baghdad synagogue in 1220: “The cantors don’t understand the words, and the people have no idea what they are saying. And instead of the holy (k’doshim) songs of [King] David, they sing the songs of prostitutes (k’deishim).”

In the Shulhan arukh, Rabbi Joseph Caro (1488-1575) wrote, “If a sh’liah tsibbur sings using gentile melodies, you should protest that he should not do such a thing. And if he doesn’t listen, you should remove him.”

The Italian Rabbi Samuel ben Elhanan Archivolti (1515-1611) wrote, “What can we say? How can we justify the actions of a few hazzanim of our day, who chant the holy prayers to the tunes of popular secular songs? While reading sacred texts they are thinking of obscenities and lewd things.”

In 1605 Rabbi Ben Zion Sarfati (d. 1610) wrote that in his youth in the synagogue of Padua, Italy, his choir “used to sing the whole order of K’dushah at the request of [Rabbi Meir]. Certainly it was not worse, indeed better than the those who raised their voices against us, singing [the K’dushah to the tunes of] the vulgar songs that are sung outdoors in the streets.”

In his Shirei y’hudah published in Amsterdam in 1696, Rabbi Y’hudah Leib Zelichower (d. 1709) wrote, But now, in this generation… they know not, they do not understand, they walk in darkness, they abandon the ancient melodies and toss them behind their backs, they laugh and make fun of them saying, “that’s old stuﬀ, and we get no pleasure from them,” and they fabricate new melodies to take their place, either [melodies] of their own, or they borrow them from their theaters and bring them into God’s Temple, and they sound like the melodies that go with mixed dancing. And there are even some of them who learn melodies from the uncircumcised… and sing them in our synagogues. Have you ever heard of such evil? Could God desire this kind of song and music?

In an anonymous pamphlet entitled Tokhehah m’gulah (Open Demands), written in Styria (now Austria) in the seventeenth century, we find several complaints lodged against hazzanim, including, “If you become used to foreign melodies, you will manage to destroy the proper kavvanah. And the listeners are focused on the melodies to such an extent that even Torah scholars haven’t a clue how to concentrate and achieve kavvanah. What happens is that people become used to going to the synagogue [merely] to listen to pleasant singing.”

Moshe Vital, a well-known Sephardic cantor in Jerusalem in the early twentieth century wrote, “For artistic and theological reasons a Sephardic cantor is forbidden to introduce secular songs into the synagogue… Sometimes one of our cantors works also as a secular singer who entertains others with secular songs, and it is quite common to hear from his mouth the melody of a love song merged with sections of prayers, such as a Kaddish or a K’dushah… But he should allow himself to do this only if the melody is not recognizable to the congregation.”

Opinions for:

Yet not all opinions have been against contrafaction. Some rabbis entertained a more positive view. Some expressed the hope that using melodies that people already knew and loved would encourage greater participation in the worship service. Others subscribed to the Kabbalistic idea that there is a spark of holiness in even the most degraded objects, and that it is a great mitzvah to rescue these sparks and redeem them into the service of the Holy One.

In the sixteenth century, Rabbi Israel Najara (c. 1555–c. 1625) wrote He- brew sacred lyrics to be sung to melodies of then-popular Arab and Turkish songs. His intention was to distract young people from the secular world, allowing them to sing their favorite tunes, but with new, uplifting lyrics. “The mouths of liars and the singing of sensual songs will be blocked, and they will no longer think about love songs when they see [my] songs.”

Mizrahi (Eastern) Jews, in particular Syrians, continue the practice of contrafaction in their pizmonim. The Syrian payy’tan Raphael Isaac Antibi defended this practice, citing the Kabbalistic interpretation. A melody is a holy spark. When you play love songs the spark is hidden in its shell. Therefore in every new melody that the gentiles compose you must establish words from the scribes, words of holiness, in order to extract the spark from the “other side” [i.e. Satan] to the side of holiness. And this is an obligation no less than preventing sinners from sinning, causing many people to turn from sin, to extract that which is precious from that which is evil, to choose the sparks of holiness.

Rabbi Israel Moshe Hazzan (1808-1862), who served in Jerusalem’s High Religious Court, defended the practice of borrowing a beautiful melody that had been used in non-Jewish worship. And I testify by heaven and earth that when I was in Smyrna, the great city of scholars and mystics, I saw some of the outstanding religious authorities who were also great creators of the science of music, headed by the wonderful Rabbi Abraham Ha-Kohein Ariash of blessed memory, who secretly used to go (behind the screen) of the Christian church on their holy days to learn the special melodies from them and to adapt them to the High Holiday prayers which require great humility. And from those same melodies they would arrange the most remarkable blessings and holy prayers, and it is clear from this that the tune is not of the essence, but the sacred words.

Jacob S. Kassin (1900-1994), Chief Rabbi of the Syrian Community of New York, echoed this sentiment. [Borrowing melodies and providing them with new, sacred Hebrew texts is done for a] good reason, a reason of fundamental importance, and it is correct that it is said about it “that it is good.” This is so because the melody is a holy spark. Because when one plays sensual love songs, the spark is submerged in the k’lippot [waste coverings]. It is for this reason that it is necessary to establish a foundation of holy words—drawn from the mouths of scholars and from the mouths of books—for any tune with a non-Jewish source, in order to lead the spark from the realm of evil to the realm of holiness. This is an obligation in the same way that it is an obligation to draw sinners to good, to turn away from iniquity, and to bring out the precious from the vile. It is an obligation to make clear the holy sparks. So it is with holy songs. The holy sparks bring light to the just.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 3)

Those who say that it is assur to use a tune that is used for avodah zara:

The Magen Avraham Orach Chaim Siman 53:31 quoting the Sefer Chasidim Siman 238 says any melody that is played in front of idolatry should not be used as a melody for Hashem. Mishneh Berurah in Chaim Siman 53:82 quoting the Bach Siman 127 says that the issur applies only to those specific melodies that are uniquely designated for avodah zara. Kaf Hachaim in Orach Chaim Siman 53:115 quotes all the above sources as well. Shu"t Yabia Omer Orach Chaim 6:7 in the first few paragraphs implies that it's assur.

See חבל נחלתו ט:ה for a full discussion with many sources.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 2)

Bach (responsum 127) forbids repurposing a tune that is uniquely associated with idolatry. On the other hand, if it is merely used in an idolatrous ritual, without being identified with idolatry, he permits it:

[השמטה: מה שמזמרי' בבתי כנסיות בניגוני' שמזמרי' בהם בבית תפלתם. נראה שאין אוסר אלא דווקא באותן ניגונים שהם מיוחדי' להעכ"ם מאחר שהוא חוק לע"ז כמו מצבה שאסורה בכל מקום מפני שעשאוה כנעני' חוק לע"ז. ואין ראי' להתיר גם את זה מהא דתנן בפ' ד' מיתות מצות הנהרגי' היו מתיזי' כו' ע"ש ובגמר' תנינא א"ל ר' יהודא לחכמים אף אני יודע שמיתה מנוולת היא ע"ש וא"כ איכא למימר ה"נ בניגוני' דלאו מינייהו קא גמרי אלא ע"י חכמת המוסקי' דאין לומר להחמיר כר' יודא דלית ליה סברא זו דהא כבר פסקו הפוסקים הלכה כרבנן מ"מ נראה דאין ראי' מכאן לפי מ"ש התוספות וז"ל תימא דמשמע הכא דאע"ג דחוקה היא כיון דכתיב ק' כו' ע"ש אלמא דאפילו כתוב באורייתא לא מהני כשנעשה חוק לע"ז. כ"ש באותן ניגוני' אבל אם אינם מיוחדי' נראה דאין בזה איסור דבהא ודאי איכא למימר דלא מינייהו גמרינן:]

Omission: regarding what is sung in synagogues using the melodies that are sung in their (non-Jewish) house of worship. It appears that the prohibition applies only to those specific melodies that are uniquely designated for the gentiles, since this constitutes a ḥoq (a fixed custom or statute) of idolatry—just as a matzevah (sacred pillar) is forbidden everywhere, because the Canaanites established it as an idolatrous practice. And there is no proof to permit even these melodies from the case taught in the chapter "Four Types of Capital Punishment" [Sanhedrin], regarding the execution method of beheading, where the Mishnah states: “The prescribed method for those executed by the sword was decapitation,” etc. And in the Gemara, Rabbi Yehuda says to the Sages, “I too know that it is a degrading death,” etc. Thus, one could argue similarly here: that in the case of the melodies, we are not learning from the gentiles themselves, but rather through the musical knowledge of experts. And one should not claim that we must be stringent in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda’s position, for his reasoning was not accepted—since the halakhic authorities have already ruled that the law follows the Sages. Nonetheless, there is no proof from that case (of execution) to our issue, in light of what Tosafot writes, and I quote: “It is difficult, for it seems from here that even though it is a ḥoq, since it is written in the Torah…” etc. (see there). From this it emerges that even if something is written in the Torah, it does not help if it has already become an idolatrous custom. All the more so, then, regarding those melodies that are uniquely identified with idolatrous worship. However, if the melodies are not uniquely associated [with idolatry], then it would seem there is no prohibition. For in that case, one can certainly say that we are not deriving from them (the gentiles).

title: How did Rabbi Eliezer cause Rabban Gamliel to die by saying Tachanun?
content:
# How did Rabbi Eliezer cause Rabban Gamliel to die by saying Tachanun? ## Frage

The Gemara (B"M 59b) says that Rabbi Eliezer said Tachanun and Rabban Gamliel died as a result. Hashem allots a certain number of years to each person.

How can someone’s prayer shorten someone else’s lifespan?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

I love this story. Most, if not ALL, scholars misunderstand it, focusing on "Not in heaven" as the Talmudic Asmachta for breaking out of existing tradition.

In reality, the whole story is about the respect one should pay to the sages and the heavy price one pays for disrespecting them.

To take the story of Akhnai in the proper context, one should start with a list of sayings that precede it on 59a:

"Rav Hisda says: All the gates of Heaven are apt to be locked, except for the gates of prayer for victims of verbal mistreatment"
"Rabbi Abbahu says: There are three sins before whose transgressors the curtain [hapargod] between the world and the Divine Presence is not locked; their sins reach the Divine Presence. They are: Verbal mistreatment, robbery, and idol worship..." "And Rabbi Ḥelbo says: A person must always be careful about sustaining the honor of his wife, as a blessing is found in a person’s house only because of his wife."

And check out the statement that immediately follows the story:

" The Sages taught: One who verbally mistreats the convert violates three prohibitions."

TLDR: As you can see, our story is set within the discussion of "verbal mistreatment"; therefore, we can conclude that R"G's indirect insult of R"E through the Herem and his resulting death demonstrate the severity of the disgrace of Talmidey Chachamim.

Explanation:

In Rosh Hashana Mishna 2.9, we encounter R"G's [somewhat undemocratic] attempt to establish his political authority over more prominent sages (R"Y here). As the Gemmora explicates, that move was mandated, as the survival of the sages and the tradition depended on cooperation and adaptation to the Roman rulership. E.g., it says that the sages can't fix the new year until the Nassi coordinates it with the Roman authorities in Syria.

Our story is the continuation and escalation of the aforementioned affair. R"Y clearly acted under the command of R"G to force R"E to comply with R"G's authority and let the latter install practices not supported by the existing tradition. To remind you that R"E was the only sage who was mentioned as "*one who never says things he didn't hear from his rabbis", so he was the one who insisted on sticking to the tradition.

Here are some textual clues to prove my point:

  • R"E won all reasonable arguments
  • Nobody claimed the existence of an alternative tradition
  • There was NO voting, and "follow the majority" was NOT mentioned in this clash
  • The divine voice was proven authoritative in the argument of B"H and B"S (Eruvin 13b): "a Divine Voice emerged and proclaimed: Both these and those are the words of the living God. However, the halakha follows the opinion of Beit Hillel." Therefore, "Not following divine voice" could NOT be an existing practice.
  • The divine voice did NOT rule a single case, but claimed that R"E's traditional opinion should be followed EVERYWHERE!
  • To prove his point, R"Y stood on his feet. This is the sign of authority, not intellect. He personified R"G's will as the Nasi.
  • R"Y claimed, "Not in Heaven". What is it? If it were an existing principle, it would be explained by reference to earlier rabbis. However, in the text, it is apologized for by a later Tanna/Amora, R' Yeremiya. Another evidence that the principle was conceived "on the spot".
  • As the Gemmora continues, the court was not satisfied with the intellectual discussion, but continues to humiliate R"E: "the Sages brought all the ritually pure items deemed pure by the ruling of Rabbi Eliezer concerning the oven and burned them in fire" - was that really necessary?
  • Furthermore, "... the Sages reached a consensus in his regard and ostracized him". Why? Was it a Halachic or a political move? Let's see God's reaction: "[R"E's] eyes shed tears, and as a result the entire world was afflicted: One-third of its olives were afflicted, and one-third of its wheat, and one-third of its barley. And some say that even dough kneaded in a woman’s hands spoiled. The Sages taught: There was great anger on that day, as any place that Rabbi Eliezer fixed his gaze was burned."
  • Why would there be divine anger if the sages were motivated purely by the desire to fulfill God's will?
  • Wait, wasn't God pleased by the fight? Isn't He quoted saying, "My children have triumphed over Me"? Let's see who says that. It was brought, again, in the name of a later Tanna, R' Nathan. As one can notice, that later insertion does not fit the divine rage. Clearly, that was an attempt to harmonize the harsh event.
  • R"G knew exactly why God was angry with him when he experienced a storm. He rightfully admitted his involvement in the affair and claimed that it wasn't for his personal gain, but the necessity to revive Judaism. He wished to utilize his political authority to minimize Rabbinic disagreements, even at the price of breaking the tradition.
  • Since the sea calmed down, we could infer that the heavens agreed with his approach. So why did he die at the end? I suggest, [probably in his briefing with R"Y and going as far as banning R"E], that he crossed the line of mistreating a great sage. As I mentioned above, he was already warned in the story "Is Maariv mandatory?". But he didn't listen.
  • The story ends with R"E described as being in great pain and suffering enormous humiliation. So, since the Gemmora has already established that "the gates of mistreatment are never shut", once R"E had an opportunity to pour his soul before Heaven, his distress outweighed R"G's honor and the latter was "executed".

So the moral of this story is simple - if you disrespect and disgrace a renowned sage, God takes it very personally.

title: Is it allowed to add ketchup to a plate of cholent on Shabbos (klei sheini)?
content:
# Is it allowed to add ketchup to a plate of cholent on Shabbos (klei sheini)? ## Frage

Is it allowed to add ketchup to your plate of Cholent on Shabbos, where that plate is considered a kli sheini?

Do we assume the ketchup is getting cooked?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 8)

Rav Moshe Feinstein writes in Igros Moshe O.C.4 74:5 (bottom of left column) that you may pour ketchup on hot meat in a kli sheini, because in order to forbid it you would need 2 chumrahs: בִּשּׁוּל אֲחַר בִּשּׁוּל בִּדְבַר לַח, and that a דָבָר גּוּשׁ is treated like a kli rishon.

title: Does a Jewish man who did not have Bar Mitzva count for a minyan?
content:
# Does a Jewish man who did not have Bar Mitzva count for a minyan? ## Frage

I'm a Jewish man and I chose not to have a bar mitzva ceremony. Occasionally, I get asked to participate in a minyan. Would I even halachically count?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 14)

There is no such thing as a bar mitzvah ceremony that confers adulthood on you.

If you are halachically Jewish, male, and have had your 13th Hebrew birthday you are an adult and can be counted for a minyan.

title: Are blessings and curses something other than prophecy or prayer?
content:
# Are blessings and curses something other than prophecy or prayer? ## Frage

It seems that blessings/curses can either be prophecies regarding the future or positive/negative prayers regarding someone else's future.

However, in Tanach (e.g., those of Yitzchak, Bilam & Birchas Kohanim) it seems that they are something else, quite apart from prophecy or prayer.

Is there another option for defining what curses and blessings are and how they work? Are they somehow causal? If so, how are they different than prayer which isn't as sure a bet? Are they meant to influence a person psychologically?

title: Difference between writing/written "בספר" and "על ספר"
content:
# Difference between writing/written "בספר" and "על ספר" ## Frage

"וְהָיָ֣ה כְשִׁבְתּ֔וֹ עַ֖ל כִּסֵּ֣א מַמְלַכְתּ֑וֹ וְכָ֨תַב ל֜וֹ אֶת־מִשְׁנֵ֨ה הַתּוֹרָ֤ה הַזֹּאת֙ עַל־סֵ֔פֶר מִלִּפְנֵ֥י הַכֹּהֲנִ֖ים הַלְוִיִּֽם׃" (Deut 17.18)
"וַיְהִי כְּכַלּוֹת מֹשֶׁה לִכְתֹּב אֶת־דִּבְרֵי הַתּוֹרָה־הַזֹּאת עַל־סֵפֶר עַד תֻּמָּם׃" (Deut 31.24)
"וַיִּדֹּ֨ם הַשֶּׁ֜מֶשׁ וְיָרֵ֣חַ עָמָ֗ד עַד־יִקֹּ֥ם גּוֹי֙ אֹֽיְבָ֔יו הֲלֹא־הִ֥יא כְתוּבָ֖ה עַל־סֵ֣פֶר הַיָּשָׁ֑ר" (Josh 10.13)
"וַיֵּלְכ֤וּ הָֽאֲנָשִׁים֙ וַיַּעַבְר֣וּ בָאָ֔רֶץ וַיִּכְתְּב֧וּהָ לֶֽעָרִ֛ים לְשִׁבְעָ֥ה חֲלָקִ֖ים עַל־סֵ֑פֶר" (Josh 18.9)

"וַיֹּ֨אמֶר יי אֶל־מֹשֶׁ֗ה כְּתֹ֨ב זֹ֤את זִכָּרוֹן֙ בַּסֵּ֔פֶר" (Ex 17.14)
"וְ֠כָתַב אֶת־הָאָלֹ֥ת הָאֵ֛לֶּה הַכֹּהֵ֖ן בַּסֵּ֑פֶר וּמָחָ֖ה אֶל־מֵ֥י הַמָּרִֽים" (Num 5.23)
"וַיִּכְתֹּ֤ב יְהוֹשֻׁ֨עַ֙ אֶת־הַדְּבָרִ֣ים הָאֵ֔לֶּה בְּסֵ֖פֶר" (Josh 24.26)

What is the difference between the use of the two prepositions - when something is written על הספר and when בספר?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Malbim Beur Hamilot on Yirmiyahu 8:8 writes (with clarifications from Sefer haCarmel, כתב, p. 433, and also ספר, סופר, p. 596):

יש הבדל בין כותב ובין סופר, הכותב יהיה על כל דבר, וכתבתם על מזוזת, כתבם על לוח, וכתבת על האבנים והסופר כותב בספרים, ולא תמצא שם תואר כותב בשום מקום :

There is a difference between writing and inscribing. Person writing (כותב) is doing so upon any matter (requiring על): writes upon (על) mezuzah (Devarim 6:9, 11:20), upon (על) a board, upon (על) stones (Devarim 27:8) (in these cases the focus is on material of writing or the product created by writing).

The person inscribing is perfoming in (-ב) books. (In these cases the focus is on the process of writing).

We do not find the adjective כותב describing the writer in any place in scripture, (but סופר).
