title: Distinctive cultural traits of ancient Israelites in the Tanakh
content:
# Distinctive cultural traits of ancient Israelites in the Tanakh ## Frage

The following description of the Israelites during the Egypt Exile appears numerous times in the Midrash (Sefaria Midrash):

"וְלֹא שִׁנּוּ אֶת שְׁמָם, וְלֹא שִׁנּוּ אֶת לְשׁוֹנָם"
"[the Israelites in Egypt] didn't change their language and clothes"

Maintaining cultural distinction was always important for the Jewish nation, as it says (Lev 20:23): "Do not follow the statutes of the nation [that I am driving out before you]," or (Lev 18:3): "Do not follow their statutes", and so rules Rambam in MT Foreign_Worship and Customs of the Nations.

However, all I can find in the Tanakh is the divine demand for differences only in cultic/religious practices, but no positive examples of native Biblical Jewish culture, such as language (i.e., the Torah doesn't demand to speak a specific language), clothes, cuisine, architecture, tools, furniture, houseware, personal names, music, dances, national symbols (the Star of David), and more.

That leads me to the questions:

  • Are there descriptions of distinctive cultural traits of the ancient Hebrews/Israelites/Judeans in the Tanakh or 2nd-Temple literature that I miss?
  • If not, why doesn't the Torah establish distinctively Jewish cultural traits?
## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Rav Moshe Feinstein (Igros Moshe OC vol. 4 nu.66) argued that it could be that these rules only applied before the giving of the Torah. After that, following the Torah is enough.

title: Why does the Mishnah specify that the poor person obligated to recline Pesach night is Jewish?
content:
# Why does the Mishnah specify that the poor person obligated to recline Pesach night is Jewish? ## Frage

The Mishnah in Pesachim (10:1) obligates even a Jewish poor person in reclining:

וַאֲפִלּוּ עָנִי שֶׁבְּיִשְׂרָאֵל לֹא יֹאכַל עַד שֶׁיָּסֵב

Even the poorest of Jews should not eat the meal on Passover night until he reclines on his left side, as free and wealthy people recline when they eat

Why does the Mishnah need to specify that the indigent person is Jewish? Isn't it obvious that a non-Jew isn't obligated in the passover rituals?

(Not my question. Heard it recently and haven't seen it addressed)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

The issue was originally raised in the Tosafos Rabbi Akiva Eiger on Pesachim 1:10, who suggested removing שֶׁבְּיִשְׂרָאֵל.

בתוי"ט ד"ה ואפילו עני. עד שתחשך. ובספר ברית שלום על התורה כ' (בפרשת בא) בשם החכם מוה' יעקב זצ"ל דיש לפרש לפי מה דאי' ריש ברכות משעה שעני נכנס לאכול פתו. ופירש"י עני שאין לו נר אוכל מבע"י. ולזה קאמר הכא דאפילו עני שבישראל שאין לו לקנות נר ובכל השנה אוכל מבע"י אפ"ה בליל פסח לא יאכל עד שתחשך:

Tosafos Yom Tov, heading and even a poor person. Until it gets dark. And in the sefer Bris Shalom on the Torah in the name of Moreh Horaah Yaakov זצ"ל, it is possible to explain according to what's brought in Brachos 2b Rabbi Ḥanina says that the time for the recitation of the evening Shema begins when the poor person enters to eat his bread (with salt). Rashi explains (this comment is missing in our gemara) *a poor person, who does not have a candle, eats while it's still daytime. Regading such a person it is stated here that even poor Jewish people who cannot purchase a candle during the year and eat while it's still daytime, even so, on the night of Pesach he should not start eating until it gets dark.

The heading in Tosafos Yom Tov includes שֶׁבְּיִשְׂרָאֵל as one can check here: ואפילו עני כו'.

The commentary on gemara יפה עינים by R. Aryeh Leib Yellin from Bielsk Podlaski, Poland, rejects the modification of R. Akiva Eiger. On Pesachim 99b, R. Yellin states:

אפי' עני שבישראל. שמ"ר פ"כ מבאן כו' אפי' עני כו' עד שיסב שכבר עשה להם הקב"ה שנא' ויסב אלהים ומזה ראיה דלא כמ"ש הגרע"א בשם ס' ברית שלום לפרש דהאי אפי' עני כו'מוסב על למעלה דלא יאכל עד שתחשך אפי' עני שדרכו לאכול קודם צה"כ דמהמדרש מוכח אלמטה קאי כמש"ש מכאן אמרו רבותינו אפי' עני כו' וכפרש"י והרשב"ם:

Even the poor Jewish person. Midrash Shemos Rabba 20:18 has a drasha on the verse Shemos 13:18 on words וַיַּסֵּ֨ב אֱלֹהִ֧ים ׀ אֶת־הָעָ֛ם כו - so G-d led the people round about, etc:

מִכָּאן אָמְרוּ רַבּוֹתֵינוּ אֲפִלּוּ עָנִי שֶׁבְּיִשְׂרָאֵל לֹא יֹאכַל עַד שֶׁיֵּסֵב, שֶׁכָּךְ עָשָׂה לָהֶם הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: וַיַּסֵּב אֱלֹהִים.

from here our Rabbis said: “Even the poor of Israel may not eat until he reclines [yasev]” (Mishna Pesaḥim 10:1) as that is what the Holy One blessed be He did to them, as it is stated: “G-d led [the people] around [vayasev].”

From this (midrash) we have a proof that (the girsa in the mishna) is not like suggested by the G"R Akiva Eiger in the name of Sefer Bris Shalom which explains that the words "even a poor etc." refers to the above that he should not start eating until it gets dark, even the poor who usually eats before tzeis hakokhavim (3 average stars). Because the midrash proves about (using the word שֶׁבְּיִשְׂרָאֵל) above as it states "from here our Rabbis said: Even the poor, etc." and like the comment Rashi on Chumash and Rashbam on Pesachim 99b

The point of R. Yellin is that the halakha of הסיבה - reclining or leaning to the left at the table is derived from the drasha in Shemos Rabba 20:18, and has to mirror its language. In turn, the reason why the midrash uses the word שֶׁבְּיִשְׂרָאֵל, is because it comments on the verse that uses the word הָעָ֛ם - the nation (with definite article the), which refers to the nation of Israel.

On a personal note, on many occasions I heard the explanation that eating with leaning at the seder represented דרך חרות - way of freedom, which meant that in the olden days free people used to lean while eating. I have never understood this idea, because sitting and leaning to the side regularly can damage one's spine.

However, the deep point of R' Yellin about sitting with derekh cheirus at the seder is different. At the seder,

חַיָּב אָדָם לִרְאוֹת אֶת־עַצְמוֹ כְּאִלּוּ הוּא יָצָא מִמִּצְרַיִם

each person must see himself as if he himself had come out of Egypt.

As the map below suggests, leaving Egypt, going east towards Sinai and leaning to the left means leaning towards Eretz Israel - the eventual destination, from which we are supposed to draw our sustenance. Hence we do so at the seder.

title: How could Korah know the number of parshiyos in the Torah?
content:
# How could Korah know the number of parshiyos in the Torah? ## Frage

The answer here notes that when Korach argued with Moshe and Aharon, according to Midrash Tanchuma Korach 1, Korach mentioned that the number of parshiyos in the Torah is 275. How could he know this number, if the Torah itself had not yet been written?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Potential answers:

  1. He didn't and a later rabbi is fleshing out the dispute.
  2. He was on such a holy spiritual plane that he intuited that there were 275 parshiot.
  3. 275 is the gematria for evil and Korach really said the Torah was bad. A later rabbi bowdlerized his complaint.
  4. He learned it in a prophecy when everyone temporarily became a prophet at Har Sinai.
  5. A angel or demon told him.

title: How did they verify membership of seven Canaanite nations?
content:
# How did they verify membership of seven Canaanite nations? ## Frage

Following "defining-a-defensive-war", in Rambam Kings_and_Wars.5.5, we've established conditions for killing non-combatants:

"It is a positive commandment to annihilate the seven nations... Anyone who chances upon one of them and does not kill him violates a negative commandment... [However] The memory of them has already been obliterated.
Similarly, it is a positive commandment to destroy the [memory of] Amalek".

I imagine myself leaving Egypt, surviving 40 years in the wilderness, and joining Joshua in his legendary conquest of the land of Israel. As a part of a Legion, I enter a local house and meet a family with no visible national attributes.

As Rambam mentions, we do not currently possess a proper understanding of those nations' qualities, but in Biblical times, those were either evident or passed down through the tradition.

  • How were members of the 8 nations determined, including women and children? For example, did they not take foreign wives?
  • Was there a test (similar to יודעת איש), or was it based on Chazakah alone?
  • (Maybe unrelated) Should they be allowed to live out of Safek (doesn't "do not murder" still apply)?

A similar question would apply to Moses waging war on the Midianites (Num 31). In this case, they went out to another kingdom. How did they determine the borders of their kingdom and distinguish the natives from immigrants and tourists?

Another example is Saul's war against the Amalekites - I don't see the scripture mentioning any clear criteria for humans or animals, nor do I see any magic involved. How did they determine if a person is or is not an Amalekite?

title: Problem of tribal courts in case of litigants from different tribes
content:
# Problem of tribal courts in case of litigants from different tribes ## Frage

On Sanhedrin 16b we learn from the verse Devarim 16:18 that each city and tribe were required to set up a court of 23. The Ramban asks the question, why is it necessary to establish a tribal court if there is a court in every city? He suggests two anwers: either it is necessary when a city is divided between two tribes (see Sanhedrin 111b or Tosafot), or the tribes appointed a tribal supreme court for the difficult cases. But what happens if חו"ח there is an adultery or other forbidden relations, and the two individuals are from a different tribe?* Each should go to her/his own tribal court (see Rashi), which is ambiguous in this case.

* I suppose this rule only applies to capital cases and not monetary ones, and I can only think about arayot that involves more than one litigants. If you know other examples, please comment!

title: What is the simple, literal meaning of "shor habar" when moshiach comes?
content:
# What is the simple, literal meaning of "shor habar" when moshiach comes? ## Frage

B"H

There's a midrashic statement that's often quoted that says that when Moshiach comes, Hashem will arrange a battle between the Leviasan (giant fish that was created during the 6 days of creation), and the "Shor HaBar", usually translated as "wild ox", and the Leviasan with slaughter it with its fins etc.

For some reason, I recall reading somewhere that this Shor HaBar is actually going to be a giant ox, similar to how the Leviasan is a giant fish.

But what exactly is it (in the simple meaning)? It makes sense that the Leviasan is hidden in the ocean, so we don't see it now even though it's really big, but the Shor HaBar? If it's a land animal that's allegedly really huge, why don't we find it now? What exactly is it, according to commentaries?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

So whilst it is described as "Shor Habar" (e.g. by the Metzudos Dovid), it is more prominently related as "Behemoth" in several sources.

I will list the initial context and then as it relates to the battle with the Levyasan - hopefully it will provide more information.

A good starting point is Tehillim 50:10:

כִּי־לִ֥י כׇל־חַיְתוֹ־יָ֑עַר בְּ֝הֵמ֗וֹת בְּהַרְרֵי־אָֽלֶף

For Mine is every animal of the forest, the beasts on a thousand mountains.

Rashi there explains as follows:

The behemoth of the thousand mountains - That is (the bull) destined for the future feast [of the righteous], which grazes on a thousand mountains daily, and every day they grow back. Others explain this to mean one thousand mountains or one thousand parasangs (i.e., one mountain that is 1,000 parasangs long, or perhaps it should read: 1,000 bulls. The plural “mountains” indicates that there were many mountains of that type.[Shem Ephraim]) Others explain that this is like (Deut. 7:13): “the litter of your cattle (אלפיך).” i.e., mountains full of cattle, because he says, “I will not take from your household a bull.”

So we see from Rashi that this giant bull/ox is destined to be part of feast for the righteous.

This is brought famously in the Medrash in Vayikra Rabbah 13:3

מַר רַבִּי יוּדָן בְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן כָּל בְּהֵמוֹת וְלִוְיָתָן הֵן קֶנִיגִין שֶׁל צַדִּיקִים לֶעָתִיד לָבוֹא, וְכָל מִי שֶׁלֹּא רָאָה קֶנִיגִין שֶׁל אֻמּוֹת הָעוֹלָם בָּעוֹלָם הַזֶּה, זוֹכֶה לִרְאוֹתָהּ לָעוֹלָם הַבָּא, כֵּיצַד הֵם נִשְׁחָטִים, בְּהֵמוֹת נוֹתֵץ לַלִּוְיָתָן בְּקַרְנָיו וְקוֹרְעוֹ, וְלִוְיָתָן נוֹתֵץ לַבְּהֵמוֹת בִּסְנַפִּירָיו וְנוֹחֲרוֹ. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים זוֹ שְׁחִיטָה כְּשֵׁרָה הִיא, וְלֹא כָּךְ תָּנִינַן הַכֹּל שׁוֹחֲטִין וּבַכֹּל שׁוֹחֲטִין וּלְעוֹלָם שׁוֹחֲטִין חוּץ מִמַּגַּל קָצִיר, וְהַמְגֵרָה, וְהַשִּׁנַּיִם, מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהֵן חוֹנְקִין. אָמַר רַבִּי אָבִין בַּר כַּהֲנָא אָמַר הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא (ישעיה נא, ד): תּוֹרָה חֲדָשָׁה מֵאִתִּי תֵצֵא, חִדּוּשׁ תּוֹרָה מֵאִתִּי תֵצֵא. אָמַר רַבִּי בֶּרֶכְיָה בְּשֵׁם רַבִּי יִצְחָק אֲרִיסְטוֹן עָתִיד הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא לַעֲשׂוֹת לַעֲבָדָיו הַצַּדִּיקִים לֶעָתִיד לָבוֹא וְכָל מִי שֶׁלֹּא אָכַל נְבֵלוֹת בָּעוֹלָם הַזֶּה זוֹכֶה לִרְאוֹתוֹ לָעוֹלָם הַבָּא, הֲדָא הוּא דִכְתִיב (ויקרא ז, כד): וְחֵלֶב נְבֵלָה וְחֵלֶב טְרֵפָה יֵעָשֶׂה לְכָל מְלָאכָה וְאָכֹל לֹא תֹאכְלֻהוּ, בִּשְׁבִיל שֶׁתֹּאכְלוּ מִמֶּנּוּ לֶעָתִיד לָבוֹא, לְפִיכָךְ משֶׁה מַזְהִיר לְיִשְׂרָאֵל וְאוֹמֵר לָהֶם (ויקרא יא, ב): זֹאת הַחַיָּה אֲשֶׁר תֹּאכֵלוּ.

Rabbi Yudan ben Rabbi Shimon said: The Behemoth and the Leviathan will engage in an animal fight before the righteous in the future. Anyone who was not a spectator at the animal fights of the nations of the world in this world, will merit to see it in the World to Come. How will they be slaughtered? The Behemoth will stab the Leviathan with its horns and tear it open, and the Leviathan will smash the Behemoth with its fins and stab it to death. The Sages say: Is this a valid ritual slaughter? But did we not learn: Everyone slaughters, and one may always slaughter, and one may slaughter with any item, except for the serrated side of the harvest sickle, a saw, the teeth of an animal, and a fingernail, because they strangle? Rabbi Avin bar Kahana said: The Holy One blessed be He said: “For [a new] Torah will emerge from Me” (Isaiah 51:4); a novel Torah ruling will emerge from Me. Rabbi Berekhya said in the name of Rabbi Yitzḥak: The Holy One blessed be He is destined to make a feast for His righteous servants in the future, and anyone who did not partake of unslaughtered carcasses in this world will be privileged to see it in the World to Come. That is what is written: “And the fat of an unslaughtered carcass and the fat of a mauled animal may be used for all labor; but you shall not eat it [ve’akhol lo tokheluhu]” (Leviticus 7:24). So that you will be able to partake of it in the future, therefore Moses cautions Israel and says to them: “These are the living beings that you may eat” (Leviticus 11:2).

This battle is also noted in the Midrash Tanchuma on Shemini 7:1:

וְהֵיכָן הֵן נִשְׁחָטִין. אֶלָּא זֶה לָזֶה מִזְדַּוְגִין שְׁנֵיהֶם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: אֶחָד בָּאֶחָד יִגָּשׁוּ (איוב מא, ח). בְּהֵמוֹת יִגַּשׁ בַּלִּוְיָתָן וְאוֹחֵז בְּקַרְנָיו וּבוֹקֵעַ. וְלִוְיָתָן הֵפֶךְ יִהְיֶה מִיתָתוֹ, שֶׁמַּכֶּה אוֹתוֹ בִּזְנָבוֹ וְהוֹרְגוֹ, וְהַצַּדִּיקִים הוֹלְכִין וְנוֹטְלִין מָנוֹת מָנוֹת. מִכָּאן שְׁחִיטָה. אֶלָּא בִּשְׁבִיל לִבְדֹּק וּלְצָרֵף אֶת יִשְׂרָאֵל

And [so] how are they slaughtered? Rather, they come and fight, one with the other, as stated (in Job 41:8), “One approaches to the other.” The behemoths approach the leviathan and hold him by his horn and split him, and the leviathan’s death [that he inflicts] will be the opposite, as he smites him with his tail and kills him. [Then] the righteous ones go and all take portions. From here [we see] that ritual slaughter was given only to examine and to purify (rt.: tsrp) Israel.

As far as a greater background, we can begin to answer your questions as to why we don't find it now...

First note the Gemara in Bava Basra 74b

וְאַף בְּהֵמוֹת בְּהַרְרֵי אֶלֶף – זָכָר וּנְקֵבָה בְּרָאָם, וְאִלְמָלֵי נִזְקָקִין זֶה לָזֶה מַחֲרִיבִין כָּל הָעוֹלָם כּוּלּוֹ. מָה עָשָׂה הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא? סֵירַס הַזָּכָר, וְצִינֵּן הַנְּקֵבָה וּשְׁמָרָהּ לַצַּדִּיקִים לֶעָתִיד לָבֹא, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״הִנֵּה נָא כֹחוֹ בְמׇתְנָיו״ – זֶה זָכָר, ״וְאוֹנוֹ בִּשְׁרִירֵי בִטְנוֹ״ – זוֹ נְקֵבָה.

And He created even the beasts on the thousand hills (see Psalms 50:10) male and female. And they were so enormous that if they would have coupled and produced offspring, they would have destroyed the entire world. What did the Holy One, Blessed be He, do? He castrated the male and cooled the sexual desire of the female and preserved it for the righteous in the future. As it is stated about the beasts: “Lo now, his strength is in his loins” (Job 40:16); this is referring to the male. The continuation of the verse: “And his force is in the stays of his body”; this is the female, alluding to the idea that they did not use their genitals for the purpose of procreation.

This idea is similarly expressed in Bereishis Rabbah 7:4

So it was created but it did not produce any kin and is clearly being "saved" until the right time.

As per the Pirkei DeRebbi Eliezer 11:4 it was created on the sixth day of creation and the midrash in Vayikra Rabbah 36:4 relates that it was created only due to the merit of Yaakov Avinu.

And the sheer size of it is noted in Vayikra Rabbah 22:10

בְּהֵמוֹת בְּהַרְרֵי אָלֶף, רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן וְרֵישׁ לָקִישׁ וְרַבָּנָן, רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אוֹמֵר בְּהֵמָה אַחַת הִיא וּרְבוּצָה עַל אֶלֶף הָרִים וְאֶלֶף הָרִים מְגַדְּלִין לָהּ כָּל מִינֵי עֲשָׂבִים וְהִיא אוֹכֶלֶת, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר (איוב מ, כ): כִּי בוּל הָרִים יִשְׂאוּ לוֹ. וְרֵישׁ לָקִישׁ אָמַר בְּהֵמָה אַחַת הִיא רְבוּצָה עַל אֶלֶף הָרִים וְאֶלֶף הָרִים מְגַדְּלִין לָהּ מַאֲכָל לַאֲכִילָתָן שֶׁל צַדִּיקִים, וְהִיא אוֹכֶלֶת, מַאי טַעְמָא (ישעיה סה, י): וְהָיָה הַשָּׁרוֹן לִנְוֵה צֹאן. וְרַבָּנָן אָמְרֵי בְּהֵמָה אַחַת הִיא וּרְבוּצָה עַל אֶלֶף הָרִים וְאֶלֶף הָרִים מְגַדְּלִין לָהּ מִינֵי בְּהֵמוֹת, וְהִיא אוֹכֶלֶת, מַאי טַעְמָא, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר (איוב מ, כ): וְכָל חַיַּת הַשָּׂדֶה יְשַׂחֲקוּ שָׁם, וְאֶפְשָׁר כֵּן אִית בְּעִיר אָכֵיל בְּעִיר, אָמַר רַבִּי תַּנְחוּמָא גְּדוֹלִים הֵם מַעֲשֵׂה הָאֱלֹהִים מַה מְּשֻׁנִּין הֵם מַעֲשָׂיו שֶׁל הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא, וּמֵהֵיכָן הוּא שׁוֹתֶה, רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן לָקִישׁ, רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר כָּל מַה שֶּׁהַיַּרְדֵּן מַכְנִיס אַחַת לְשִׁשָּׁה חֳדָשִׁים הוּא עוֹשֶׂה גְּמִיעָה אֶחָת, מַאי טַעְמָא, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר (איוב מ, כג): הֵן יַעֲשֹׁק נָהָר וְלֹא יַחְפּוֹז. רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן לָקִישׁ אָמַר כָּל מַה שֶּׁהַיַּרְדֵּן מַכְנִיס לִשְׁנֵים עָשָׂר חֳדָשִׁים הוּא עוֹשֶׂה אוֹתוֹ גְּמִיעָה אַחַת, מַאי טַעְמָא (איוב מ, כג): יִבְטַח כִּי יָגִיחַ יַרְדֵּן אֶל פִּיהוּ, וְיֵשׁ בָּהֶם לִכְלוּךְ פֶּה, רַב הוּנָא בְּשֵׁם רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אָמַר אֵין בָּהֶם לִכְלוּךְ פֶּה, וּמֵהֵיכָן הוּא שׁוֹתֶה, תָּנֵי רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן יוֹחָאי נָהָר יוֹצֵא מֵעֵדֶן וּשְׁמוֹ יוּבַל וּמִשָּׁם הוּא שׁוֹתֶה, מַאי טַעְמָא, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר (ירמיה יז, ח): וְעַל יוּבַל יְשַׁלַּח שָׁרָשָׁיו

“Animals on thousands of hills” (Psalms 50:10); Rabbi Yoḥanan, Reish Lakish, and the Rabbis, Rabbi Yoḥanan says: It is one animal that is lying on one thousand mountains, and one thousand mountains grow many varieties of grasses for it, and it eats, as it is stated: “For produce of mountains will be carried to it” (Job 40:20). Reish Lakish said: It is one animal lying on one thousand mountains, and one thousand mountains grow food for it, so it will be food for the righteous, and it eats. What is the source? “The Sharon will be a pasture for flocks” (Isaiah 65:10). The Rabbis say: It is one animal and it is lying on one thousand mountains, and one thousand mountains grow various types of animals for it, and it eats. What is the source? “All the beasts of the field will frolic there” (Job 40:20). Is that possible, that an animal [behema] eats an animal? Rabbi Tanḥuma said: God’s deeds are great, how extraordinary are the deeds of the Holy One blessed be He. From where does it drink? Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Everything that the Jordan takes in over the course of six months, it swallows in one gulp. What is the source? As it is stated: “Behold, it can swallow a river, it need not rush” (Job 40:23). Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: Everything that the Jordan takes in over the course of twelve months, it swallows in one gulp. What is the source? “It is secure, even if it draws the Jordan into its mouth” (Job 40:23). It has enough just to wet the mouth. Rav Huna said in the name of Rabbi Yosei: It is not even enough just to wet the mouth. From where, then, does it drink? Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai taught: A river emerges from Eden and its name is Yuval, and it drinks from there, as it is stated: “And it shall spread its roots alongside a stream [yuval]” (Jeremiah 17:8).

title: How many children did Datan and Aviram have?
content:
# How many children did Datan and Aviram have? ## Frage

The Torah in Parshat Korach - Bamidbar 16:27 - mentions that Datan and Aviram had wives, children and infants.

Do any Mefarshim or Midrashim say how many children and infants they were?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

Malbim on Tehilim 106:16-17 states:

תִּפְתַּח־אֶ֭רֶץ וַתִּבְלַ֣ע דָּתָ֑ן וַ֝תְּכַ֗ס עַל־עֲדַ֥ת אֲבִירָֽם׃

The earth opened up and swallowed Dathan, closed over / covered the congregation (עֲדַ֥ת) of Abiram.

והיה בהם שלשה מיני עונשים, דתן ואבירם נבלעו, ועז"א תפתח ארץ, ודתן נבלע לבדו ואבירם היה לו עדה של בנים ובנות שהם עשרה, ועז"א ותכס על עדת אבירם:

There were 3 punishments about which it is said the earth opened up, Dathan was swallowed alone. Abiram had an eida - a "congregation" of sons and daughters, ten in number, and regarding them it says and it covered the congregation of Abiram.

Likely, Malbim means in addition to wives. I.e. Dathan with his wife, Abiram with his wife and 10 children. Also, the usage of gzeirah shavah to the word eida suggests 10 grown up sons, similar to the case of eida of the 10 spies in parashas Sh'lach.

There are also midrashic sources which modify the number of children. For example, the verse Bamidbar 16:27 implies that both Dathan and Abiram had children and babies:

וַיֵּעָל֗וּ מֵעַ֧ל מִשְׁכַּן־קֹ֛רַח דָּתָ֥ן וַאֲבִירָ֖ם מִסָּבִ֑יב וְדָתָ֨ן וַאֲבִירָ֜ם יָצְא֣וּ נִצָּבִ֗ים פֶּ֚תַח אׇֽהֳלֵיהֶ֔ם וּנְשֵׁיהֶ֥ם וּבְנֵיהֶ֖ם וְטַפָּֽם׃

So they withdrew from about the abodes of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram. Now Dathan and Abiram had come out and they stood at the entrance of their tents, with their wives, their adult children, and their little ones.

Midrash Tanchuma Korach 3:1 and similarly Bamidbar Rabba 18:4 comment on the verse:

R. Berekhyah said, “How harmful is dissension! An emissary of the court on high only imposes a penalty [on people] from the age of twenty years, while the court below [only imposes a penalty] from the age of thirteen years. In the case of Korah's dissension, however, one-day-old babies were burned and swallowed up in nethermost Sheol.

In other words, both Dathan and Abiram had 1 day old babies, or one of them did, or someone else who was swallawed with them (*).

(*) In addition to descendands of Dathan and Abiram, the other people included Korach and his wife, as well as more distant followers according to Rabbeinu Bachya on Bamidbar 16:31.

The verse Bamidbar 16:27 suggests, both Dathan and Abiram had young children. This is noted in Midrash Agadah on Bamidbar 16:25 (there are similar statements in Tanchumah Korach and Midrash Bamidbar Rabba):

(When coming to see Korach and his congregation) Moshe sought to frighten and terrify them by telling them the words of the Omnipresent. However they continued to sin, as it is said Bamidbar 16:27 Dathan and Abiram came out standing, defying, just like it is said regarding Goliath Shmuel A 17:16 "he made a stand for 40 days". They (Dathan and Abiram), their wives, [their children], and their babies - all defied Moshe.

Furthermore, midrash Tanna d'bei Eliyahu Rabba 18:10 suggests that Dathan and Abiram also had grandchildren:

שתי מדות של רשעים כיצד צא ולמד מן דתן ואבירם הרשעים שנתכוונו ועשו מחלוקת בין ישראל לאביהם שבשמים ובין ישראל עם הארץ לתלמיד חכם ובין חכם לחכם ובין אדם לחבירו ובין איש לאשתו ומתוך דרכיהם הרעים נקבע שם רע להם ולבניהם ולבני בניהם עד סוף כל הדורות שנאמר (במדבר כו) הוא דתן ואבירם.

Two types of evil people, how so? Come to learn from the evil Dathan and Abiram, who intentionally made a disagreement between Israel and Our Father in Heaven, between an unlearned Jew and and a Talmid Chakham, between Chakham and a Chakham, between a man and his fellow, between a man and his wife, and through their evil ways they established a bad name for themselves, their children, and their children's children until the end of generations, as it is said: "They are Dathan and Abiram..." (Bamidbar 26:9)

Summary: The commentaries differ in their assessment on the number of children for Dathan and Abiram. A simple reading of the verse Tehilim 106:16-17, as done by Malbim, suggests no children for Dathan and 10 grown up children for Abiram. Other commentaries based on Bamidbar 16:27 note presence of younger children, 1-day old babies, and even grandchildren for one of them or both. The exact number is not provided.

title: Midrash on Korach and the mezuza
content:
# Midrash on Korach and the mezuza ## Frage

I have a question about a famous Midrash on Parshat Korach, Midrash Tanchuma, siman 2 on Parshat Korach:

וַיִּקַח קֹרַח. מַה כְּתִיב לְמַעְלָה מִן הָעִנְיָן, דַּבֵּר אֶל בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל וְאָמַרְתָּ אֲלֵיהֶם וְעָשׂוּ לָהֶם צִיצִת (במדבר טו, לח). קָפַץ קֹרַח וְאָמַר לְמֹשֶׁה, אַתָּה אוֹמֵר, וְנָתְנוּ עַל צִיצִת וְגוֹ' (שם). טַלִּית שֶׁכֻּלָּהּ תְּכֵלֶת, מַה הִיא שֶׁיְּהֵא פְּטוּרָה מִן הַצִּיצִית. אָמַר לוֹ מֹשֶׁה, חַיֶּבֶת בְּצִיצִית. אָמַר לוֹ קֹרַח, טַלִּית שֶׁכֻּלָּהּ תְּכֵלֶת אֵינָהּ פּוֹטֶרֶת עַצְמָהּ, וְאַרְבָּעָה חוּטִין פּוֹטֵר אוֹתָהּ. בַּיִת מָלֵא סְפָרִים, מַהוּ שֶׁתְּהֵא פְּטוּרָה מִן הַמְּזוּזָה. אָמַר לוֹ: חַיֶּבֶת בִּמְזוּזָה. אָמַר לוֹ: כָּל הַתּוֹרָה כֻּלָּהּ מָאתַיִם שִׁבְעִים וְחָמֵשׁ פָּרָשִׁיּוֹת שֶׁיֵּשׁ בָּהּ, כֻּלָּן אֵין פּוֹטְרוֹת אֶת הַבַּיִת, וּשְׁתֵּי פָּרָשִׁיּוֹת שֶׁבַּמְּזוּזָה פּוֹטְרוֹת אֶת הַבַּיִת

“‘And Korach took'(16:1): What Parsha precedes this episode? – ‘Speak to the Israelites concerning the making of Tzitzit (fringes).'(15:34)

Korach stepped forward turning to Moses: ‘You say, “Put on the fringe a thread of blue (t’chelet) wool.”(ibid.) What about a garment that is itself a blue colour (t’chelet), would it not be exempt from the blue thread (on the Tzitzit)?’

Moses replied, ‘It is obligatory to have the blue thread.’

Said Korach, ‘A garment which is all blue is not exempt and four meagre threads do the trick!?’

Korach attacked again: ‘A room full of Sifrei Torah, would it need a Mezuza?’

Moses answered in the affirmative.

Korach replied, ‘The Torah contains 275 sections and they are not enough to fulfill the house’s obligation to have a Mezuza, but these two sections (written in the Mezuza scroll) will fulfil the obligation for the entire house!

– Moses, you must be making this stuff up!”

The first part of this famous Midrash answers the question about what Korach took - since the Torah doesn't say explicitly what he took. The Midrash then answers that he took Tzitzit/Talit since the last section in the previous parsha, Parshat Shlach, is Parshat Tzitzit. But I don't understand the point of the 2nd part of that Midrash with the Mezuza and the room full of Sifrei Torah.

How does that second part of the Midrash about Mezuza/Sefer Torah answer the question of what Korach took? Does it really answer that question?

Another question still on that 2nd part: it seems that this Midrash highlights the importance of the figure 275 which is the number of units/paragraphs/Parshyot in the whole Sefer Torah. How is that number relevant and what's the textual connection here?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Before giving an answer, it is important to note that we are working exclusively with the text of Midrash Tanchuma Korach 1 and not with the general question "What did Korach take?" addressed in a different post, although one could modify the answer there by additional commentaries, which may bundle different opinions. For example, Targum Yonasan on Bamidbar 16:1 says:

ויקח קרח וּנְסֵיב גוּלְיָיתֵיהּ דְכוּלָא תִּיכְלָא קרַח בַּר יִצְהָר בַּר קְהָת בַּר לֵוִי וְדָתָן וַאֲבִירָם בְּנֵי אֱלִיאָב וְאוֹן בַּר פֶּלֶת בְּנֵי רְאוּבֵן

But Korach took his robe which was all of hyacinth; (he was) bar (son of) Yitzhar bar Kehath, bar Levi with Dathan and Abiram the sons of Eliab, and On bar Peleth, of the Beni-Reuven.

Targum Yerushalmi here says:

וּנְסֵיב עֵצָה וּפְלַג קרַח:

And Korach took counsel, and made division.

Peirush Yonathan ties the approach of Midrash Tanchuma with Targum Yerushalmi:

וּנְסֵיב גוּלְיָיתֵיהּ. דקשה ליה מה הקשה רש"י מאי לקח, אלא לקח טליתו. וכן לשון זה בגמרא בבא בתרא פרק יש נוחלין (קיא.) בַּר אִינָשׁ דַּאֲתָא לְקִיבְלַנָא, הוּא יָאֵי, וְגוּלְּתֵיהּ יָאֵי. וירושלמי מתרגם ונסיב עצה, גם כן מפרש מאי לקח אלא נטל עצה. וכן הוא בתנחומה (קרח ג) שנטל עצה מאישתו:

Took his robe (גוּלְיָיתֵיהּ) The difficulty of Targum Yonathan is why does Rashi asks what Korach took, if he took his tallis? Such is also the language of gemara Bava Basra, perek Yesh Nochalin (111a) (*) "The person who is coming toward us is handsome and his cloak (וְגוּלְּתֵיהּ) is handsome." But Targum Yerushalmi renders took counsel, which also answers the same question, What did he take? He took councel. And the same approach is in Midrash Tanchuma Korach 3.1 that he took counsel from his wife.

* Here the peirush uses somewhat corrupted text which is also found in Sefer haAruch גל

The first question of the OP is answered by the Midrash Tanchuma slightly earlier, Korach 1:1 (the passage is also found in Bamidbar Rabba 18:2):

וַיִּקַּח, אֵין וַיִּקַּח אֶלָּא מְשִׁיכַת דְּבָרִים רַכִּים, שֶׁמָּשַׁךְ כָּל גְּדוֹלֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל וְהַסַּנְהֶדְרָאוֹת אַחֲרָיו. בְּמֹשֶׁה הוּא אוֹמֵר, וְיִקַּח מֹשֶׁה וְאַהֲרֹן אֶת הָאֲנָשִׁים הָאֵלֶּה (במדבר א, יז). וְכֵן הוּא אוֹמֵר, קַח אֶת אַהֲרֹן וְאֶת בָּנָיו אִתּוֹ (ויקרא ח, ב). וְכֵן הוּא אוֹמֵר, קְחוּ עִמָּכֶם דְּבָרִים וְשׁוּבוּ וְגוֹ' (הושע יד, ג). וְכֵן הוּא אוֹמֵר, וַתֻּקַּח הָאִשָּׁה בֵּית פַּרְעֹה (בראשית יב, טו). הֱוֵי, וַיִּקַּח קֹרַח, שֶׁבִּדְבָרִים רַכִּים מָשַׁךְ לִבָּם.

(Numb. 16:1:) “[Now Korah …] took.” “Took” can only be a word for "attracting with persuasive words," in that he attracted all the leaders of Israel and the sanhedraot [to follow] after him. (Numb. R. 18:2). Concerning Moses it is written (in Numb. 1:17), “So Moses and Aaron took these men.” And similarly it is written (in Numb. 8:2), “Take Aaron and his sons with him.” And so does it say (in Hos. 14:3), “Take words with you and repent….” And so does it [also] say (in Genesis 12:15), “and the woman was taken to the house of Pharaoh.”

(*) In this and some of the following sections, the midrash is explaining the fact that the transitive verb, TOOK, has no object. Biblical translations offer solutions such as translating the verb intransitively, e.g., BETOOK HIMSELF, or by supplying an object, e.g., TOOK MEN.

In other words, Korach did not physically take Tzitzit/Tallit, rather he presented an argument first about Tzitzit/Tallis, and then about a room full of sefarim and a mezuzah.

The second question about the figure 275 needs to be understood in the context of the Korach's argument. The commentary ביאור האמורים by R' Avraham Meir Rosen printed in the Zichron Aharon 4-volume edition of Midrash Tanchuma states:

כל המפרשים נתחבטו לכוון החשבון הזה ולא יכולו

All commentators struggled to resolve this number (275) and were not able.

Therefore, one needs to take this number 275 as designating a large amount, comparable to the number of Sifrei Torah in the room, or strings of blue tekheles in the hypothetical Korach's tallis made of the tekheles.

The midrash tells that Korach and his congregation were challenging the leadership of Moshe and Aharon. For example, the four strings of tekheles in the first Korach's dismissal, as the ביאור האמורים explains:

היינו שני חוטין כפולין שהם ארבעה בכל כנף לדעת רש"י ותוס', או חוט אחד פשוט לכול כנף לדעת הרמב"ם, עיין תוס' יו"ט ריש פרק ד' דמנחות

They are two double strings that are four in each corner according to the opinion of Rashi and Tosafos, or one string in each corner according to Rambam, see Tosafos Yom Tov beginning of perek 4 in Menachos.

We can take these to mean a reference to Moshe and Aharon (the strings of the front two corners) and Aharon's two sons Elazar and Ithamar (the strings of the back two corners). All these people were appointed by Hashem for the work in the Mishkan, just like the strings of tzitzis were commanded by Hashem to be worn in 4-cornerd garments. All the techeles strings of the Korach's tallis were not having any halakhic status at the same time. (By the way, we do encounter a garment of four corners which was fully made of techeles, the Meil of the Kohein Gadol, as discussed here whether it needed tzitzis. It is possible, that this is a source that Korach wanted to be a Kohein Gadol instead of Aharon). Similarly, other Jewish people in the camp were not commanded to serve in the Mishkan.

The second challenge follows the same pattern, the two parshios written on the mezuzah scroll exempt the room even if it does not have any Sifrei Torah because these parshiyos were commanded to be written by Hashem. This is again a reference to Moshe and Aharon who could enter the Kodesh haKodashim (the room). All single "275" parshios in all Sifrei Torah do not constitute a mezuzah scroll to exempt a room. Likewise, other Jewish people did not have a priviledge to enter the Kodesh haKodashim.

(For completeness I could quote the the ביאור האמורים explanation of the Korach's intent, but it seems to be out of scope of the OP's question).

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

It is possible to interpret the number 275 in a way of remez, 275 is gematria of the word רעה - bad. I.e. Korach hinted that the whole Torah of Moshe is bad. The commentary ביאור האמורים by R' Avraham Meir Rosen printed in the Zichron Aharon 4-volume edition of Midrash Tanchuma states:

השאלה זו מבית מלא ספרים לא הוצרך לשום אדם עדיין, שהספר תורה הראשונה לא נכתבה עד סוף ארבעים שנהליציאת מצרים, ואין זה אלא דברי לצנות, כמעשה שספר בשוחר טוב (מזמור א) באלמנה ושתי יתומות שהיה לה שדה. והמעשה הזה לא היה ולא נברא אלא קרח בדאה מלבו כדי להתלוצץ על מושה רבינו ע"ה ותורתו, והראה העשק וגזל רש הנמצה בתורת מושה.

...this question regarding a house full of Sifrei Torah had not yet been necessary for anyone, since the first Torah scroll written at the end of forty years after the Exodus from Egypt. This was nothing but words of mockery, like the incident narrated in Midrash Tehilim 1:13 about a widow and two orphan daughters who had a field. The incident had never been and was only created by a whim of Korach's heart in order to mock Moshe Rabbeinu ע"ה and falsify his Torah, showing the oppression and plunder of the poor supposedly mentioned in it.

Indeed, the Midrash Tehilim 1:13 fully supports the remez regarding 275:

Another matter: Fortunate is the man who is not one of the sons of Korah, who did not follow the counsel of their father, as it is said (Numbers 16:26), "Depart now from the tents of these wicked men." And they sinned in the manner of sinners (ibid. 17:3), [which was] the censers of sinners. And in the company of the scorners, [there was] Korah, who mocked Moses and Aaron. What did he do? He assembled the entire congregation, as it is said (ibid. 16:19), "And Korah gathered against them the entire congregation." He began to speak disparagingly and said to them, "There was once a widow in my neighborhood with two orphaned daughters and she had one field. When she came to plow, Moses said to her (Deuteronomy 22:10), 'You shall not plow with an ox and a donkey together.' When she came to sow, Moses said to her (Leviticus 19:19), 'Your field shall not be sown with two different kinds of seed.' When she came to reap and make a pile [of sheaves], Moses said to her (Deuteronomy 24:19), 'You shall leave [some stalks] for the poor and the stranger.' When she came to make a threshing floor, he said to her, 'You shall give tithes [of your crop] and [separate] terumah, tithes, first tithe, and second tithe.' The righteous woman accepted [the ruling] and complied. What did she do? She sold the field and bought two lambs to clothe herself with their fleece and to enjoy their fruits. When Aaron's firstborn son was born, he came to her and said, 'Give me the firstborns, as the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to me (Deuteronomy 15:19), "Every firstborn that is born in your cattle and your flock, the male [belongs to] Him."' The righteous woman accepted [the ruling] and complied. When it came time to shear them, he said to her, 'Give me the foreleg, cheeks, and stomach.' She said to him, 'Even though I slaughtered them, I did not escape from your hand. Behold, I am under a ban.' He said to her, 'Give [them to me], as the verse states (Numbers 18:14), "Every ban among the people of Israel shall be yours."' He took [the portions] and went on his way. She left weeping, as did her two daughters. Such is the way of these [men], who taunt [others] and hang [their claims] on the Holy One, Blessed be He. [They have done] so much [harm], yet they still continue [to provoke] the Holy One, Blessed be He.

title: Did the Arizal "talk" with Rashbi?
content:
# Did the Arizal "talk" with Rashbi? ## Frage

I've heard that the Ari used to go to Meron and "speak" with Rashbi, who would teach him Torah.

Is this written anywhere?

How is that not considered Doresh el haMetim (i.e., necromancy)?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

There are a number of sources describing the Ari going to Meron and praying and/or studying by Rashbi's grave, but regarding speaking to Rashbi himself so far I've only found the following, from Shaar Hakavanot (Hilchot Pesach, Drush 12):

"גם העיד הה"ר אברהם הלוי כי בשנה הנזכר הלך גם הוא שם והיה נוהג לומר בכל יום בברכת תשכון "נחם ה' אלקינו את אבלי ציון כולי", וגם בהיותו שם אמר נחם כו'. ואחר שגמר העמידה אמר לו מורי ז"ל כי ראה בהקיץ את רשב"י ע"ה עומד על קברו ואמר לו "אמור אל האיש הזה אברהם הלוי כי למה אומר נחם ביום שמחתינו והנה לכן הוא יהיה בנחמה בקרוב". ולא יצא חדש ימים עד שמת לו בן א' וקבל עליו תנחומין."

"And Rabbi Avraham Halevi testified that in the same year (that the Ari visited Meron with his family coming from Egypt) he (Rabbi Avraham) also went there and he used to say every day in the blessing of "Tishkon" "Nachem Hashem Elokeinu et Evlei Tzion etc" and so also when he came there he said "Nachem etc". And after he finished the Amidah prayer, my Teacher (the Ari) z"l said to him that he saw Rashbi A"H in a vision standing upon his grave and he told him: "Tell that man, this Avraham Halevi why he said Nachem during our day of festivity, and for this he will be "Benechama" soon" (i.e., he will receive condolences). And not a month passed until one of his sons passed and he received condolences."1

Regarding whether this falls under Doresh el Ha'metim, Rabbi Eliezer Melamed in Pninei Halacha, Emunah u'Mitzvoteiah, vol. 2, Laws of Necromancy and Demonic Witchcraft, pp. 287-289 (Hebrew) wrote that there are many poskim that find leniencies for the following:

  • Asking for assistance/advice from a deceased person's spirit (rather than their body, which may still contain remnants of the lower parts of a person's soul even post-death).
  • Visiting tombs of righteous people and requesting assistance, advice or salvation.
  • Visiting tombs of righteous people and praying to Hashem there, perhaps at most asking for the righteous to intercede before Hashem on the visitor's behalf.

See sources in the footnotes in the link.

Regarding the first two points, there are poskim who rule that even these aren't allowed. But regarding the third, simply praying to Hashem is not considered problematic. From the story it seems the Ari met Rashbi's spirit, which falls under the leniency of the first point. Also, the meeting seems to have happened against the will of the Ari (i.e., the instigator of the vision was Rashbi, not the Ari seemingly forcing Rashbi to speak to him).

1 R' Moshe Goldstein, a chassid of the Munkacher Rebbe, recounted in his book Masa'ot Yerushalayim a story he heard from the Rebbe in the name of the Munkacher's own rabbi, the Shinower Rebbe, who heard it from the elders of Tzfat, that one time during Lag Ba'omer the Ari and his students were dancing at Meron, and at one point Rabbi Elazar Azikri (author of Sefer Charedim) moved to dancing with an old man, and after awhile the Ari noticed and took the hands of the old man and danced with him. Later, the Ari informed the other students that the old man was Rashbi himself who came to honor Rabbi Elazar (whose greatness was still unknown until that point). It's not clear from the story whether the Ari spoke with Rashbi while dancing. But here too, the Ari was not the instigator of the meeting.

title: Source for chalav stam nowadays?
content:
# Source for chalav stam nowadays? ## Frage

B"H

It's well known that Rav Moishe Feinstein gave a heter for Chalav Stam when there are government inspections (Igros Moshe YD 1:47).

But I haven't been able to find any recent discussions about if this applies at the present time, when chalav yisroel is available within a few hour drive almost everywhere in the world where Jews exist, because of Chabad houses, due to the very strict parameter that Rav Moshe himself specified regarding the heter:

Although there are halachic reasons to allow drinking [non-Cholov Yisroel] milk produced by companies [under government supervision], obviously this leniency only applies in places where one cannot obtain Cholov Yisroel milk, supervised by G-d-fearing rabbonim. However, in places where such milk is available, one must be strict and only drink supervised milk. The same applies to other dairy products.

It is especially important to be careful about this if one is accustomed to only consume supervised dairy products at home. In such a case, [drinking non-Cholov-Yisroel milk] may involve violating a neder [vow].

Therefore, hospitals that provide kosher food should do whatever they can to obtain dairy products under rabbinic supervision, for here in New York there is no difficulty involved in doing so. At the very least, they should obtain supervised dairy products for those patients who only eat Cholov Yisroel at home, and they should not force them, chas veshalom, to eat what they are careful not to eat.

Original handwriting of Reb Moishe:

I often times see people on frum communities, even communities that have kosher stores within a half hour walk from everywhere, frequently eat cholov Stam products, sometimes claiming to rely on Rav Moshe.

Does this heter apply anymore, due to the close proximity of almost all world jewry to either a Chabad house (whom one can order cholov yisroel from), or Jews living close to a kosher store?

title: When was belief in Moshiach required before the exile?
content:
# When was belief in Moshiach required before the exile? ## Frage

According to Rambam's 12th principle of faith one must believe and anticipate the coming of the Messiah. I would like to understand when this principle first came into effect.

Meaning right after the giving of the Torah at Sinai were all Jews obligated in this belief? If not, at what point in history would we have expected someone to have this belief? Did the requirement to harbor this belief begin after Moshe died and they entered the land of Israel, during the period of Joshua?

Would it have begun with the appointment of the first king, Shaul? Or perhaps it began at the time of the first Davidic king? I would assume the last possible time the necessity for this belief would have commenced at the destruction of the first temple and the beginning of exile.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

This is a great question. Just a couple of thoughts:

  • The concept of a Messianic age is referred to a number of times in the Chumash, sometimes clearly and sometimes by hint. (Devorim 30, Bereishis 49:10, Bamidbar 24:17)
  • The concept of a Messianic age where the entire world would recognise Hashem, and there would be peace etc. would have been something appropriate for any generation to yearn for - even before the exile.
  • I assume that the people would have been bound by this belief at the point that it was taught to the people - which at the latest would have been before the death of Moshe, but perhaps even earlier.

title: Calling on the MT"T?
content:
# Calling on the MT"T? ## Frage

Calling on the Archangels is well known in Judaism, for example the common "Binding of the Chariot" prayer in bedtime Shema, "To my right, be Michael, to my left, be Gabriel, before me Uriel, behind me Refael, above me Shekhinat El." And some have the practice after Birkhot haTorah in the morning and after Yevarekhekha etc., to say, "Michael, the High Priest! Minister and Guardian of Yisrael!" Repeated three times.

My question is why not call mention of the Big Angel, the MT"T himself? Or are there times or customs where he is mentioned?

For those interested in reading about the MT"T, I might suggest the Wikipedia article on Metatron, and also this imo astounding critical piece based on Hekhalot Literature I found, analyzing his roles, history, the texts, his promotion and demotion, etc.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Reference to angels is only done contextually in the tefillah. We do not pray to angels.

The significance of directions mentioned in the Bed Time Sh'ma Prayer, one can learn from the haGR"A's commentary on Sefer Yetzira HaGR"A 1.5:9-14 or other sources, such as "The Four Species" by R. Dov-Ber Pinson, p. 39:

South - Right - Chesed; North - Left - Gevurah; East - Front - Tiferes; Up - Netzach; Down - Hod; West - Back - Yesod; Center - Malchus

Placing angels according to the Bed-Time Sh'ma prayer means that Michael is in charge of Chesed, Gavriel is in charge of Gevura, Uriel is in charge of Tiferes, and Raphael is in charge of Yesod. This is an allusion to the 4 camps when Jewish people travelled in the desert under the protective clouds of glory of Shechina, as we see Torah Shebikhtav, Bamidbar, Nasso, Beha'alotcha, Torah Ohr 19 in the name of Rekanati (although other placings of Uriel and Raphael are abound):

It follows that the pictures on the 4 flags which the Israelites had in the desert were of the four חיות that support G–d's throne, that they also hinted at the four camps of the שכינה, namely the four emanations mentioned, and that they also reflected the concept of the four basic elements in our world as well as the four compass directions. The Zohar elaborates on all this. The Rekanati says that the four basic elements are presided over by the four angels מיכאל, גבריאל, אוריאל, and רפאל.

מיכאל presides over the element water, and establishes a link between the waters in the upper regions, the waters of חסד. He does this in his capacity of "High Priest” of the Celestial Regions. He atones on behalf of Israel, since the region of atonement is in the domain of חסד. As a result, his position in those regions is on the right of G–d's throne.

גבריאל presides over the element אש הגדולה "the great fire," hence his position is on the left. His official title is "Commander in Chief" of the celestial armies. (i.e. he represents גבורה)

אוריאל is in front, presiding over the element רוח, the region whence light comes to the world, since it is positioned in the East. The sun rises in the East, of course. (i.e. he represents תפארת)

רפאל is in the West, presiding over the element עפר, earth. The Rabbis say that he is in charge of the earth that is attached to the throne of G–d, a material known as the חומר הראשון, "original raw material” (i.e. he represents יסוד)

(compare Bamidbar Rabbah 2:10). The Midrash there states that just as G–d had created four compass directions in our lower world, so He has surrounded His Throne with four angels, i.e. מיכאל, גבריאל, אוריאל, רפאל. So far the words of the Rekanati. The letters in the holy name of G–d are imbued with the glory of the שכינה, G–d's Presence.

Alternatively, these angels represent a Heavenly Court which works in the orderly fashion, despite the fact that these angels represent elements exclusive to each other (water, fire, light, earth). Thus, we request to remain just as balanced and at peace.

The reference to מט"ט is mentioned in the Yehi Ratzon addition to the Shofar service on Rosh Hashanah following the first 12 blows of shofar:

יְהִי רָצוֹן מִלְפָנֶיךָ, שֶׁתְּקִיעַת "תקיעה. שׁברים-תרועה. תקיעה" שֶׁאֲנַחְנוּ תּוֹקְעִין, תְּהֵא מְרוּקֶּמֶת בִּירִיעָה, עַל יְדֵי הַמְּמוּנֶּה [טרטיא"ל], כְּשֵׁם שֶׁקִּבַּלְתָּ עַל יְדֵי אֵלִיָהוּ ז"ל וּ**[מט"ט]** שַׂר הַפָּנִים, וּתְמַלֵּא עָלֵינוּ בְּרַחֲמִים. בָּרוּךְ אַתָּה בַּעַל הָרַחֲמִים

May it be your will that the tekiah. shevarim-teruah. tekiah. blasts that we sound be embroidered into the [heavelnly] curtain by the appointed angel טרטיא"ל just as you accepted prayers through Eliyahu, who is remembered for good; and the ministering angel [מט"ט] of the Inner Chaber; and may you be filled with mercy upon us. Blessed are you, Master of Mercies.

Gemara Chagiga 15a gives us an insight of who the angel מט"ט is:

The Gemara stated earlier that Aḥer chopped down the saplings, becoming a heretic. With regard to him, the verse states: “Do not let your mouth bring your flesh into guilt” (Ecclesiastes 5:5). The Gemara poses a question: What was it that led him to heresy? He saw the angel Mitatron, who was granted permission to sit and write the merits of Israel. He said: There is a tradition that in the world above there is no sitting; no competition; no turning one’s back before Him, i.e., all face the Divine Presence; and no lethargy. Seeing that someone other than God was seated above, he said: Perhaps, the Gemara here interjects, Heaven forbid, there are two authorities, and there is another source of power in control of the world in addition to God. Such thoughts led Aḥer to heresy.

Since מט"ט is מֶיטַטְרוֹן, we see that he is responsible for making records of the Jewish people's merits. On Rosh Hashana we pray for a כְּתִיבָה וְחֲתִמה טוׂבָה - good writing and seal, hence we mention the name of the angel.

title: Mishnayot with Niqud
content:
# Mishnayot with Niqud ## Frage

I'm searching the edition of Mishnayot with the best quality of Niqud from a grammatical point of view. Kehati made the choice to follow modern Hebrew style, not the style of scriptures or Sidur. Eshkol seems very good. But I'm not a specialist in Niqud.

I'm interested to know the opinion of knowledgeable experts.

I feel that accuracy is important for the reading of Mishnayot despite that this not scriptural Tora.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Based on information available on the internet, such as haMichlol, it appears that a critical unified scientific edition of the Mishnah with nussach verified in accordance with all available manuscripts has not yet been compiled.

Several tractates have been published in scientific editions as doctoral theses and books: Sukkah (Menachem Tzvi Fox), Niddah (Tirza Mitshem), Avoda Zara (David Rosenthal), Oholot, Shabbat, Eruvin (Avraham Goldberg), Avot (Shimon Sharvit), Ketubot (Yerachmiel Brody), Shekalim (Eliezer Pinchover), Middot (Asher Zelig Kaufman), Shavuot (David Schachnai), Horayot (Aryeh Stulberg). Prof. David Rosenthal completed his work on a scientific edition of each Mishnah in Seder Nezikin, but it has not yet been published.

Two attempts to produce an accurate edition of the Mishnah have been made so far:

  • A Mishnah with formula changes, published by the Complete Israeli Talmud Institute (מכון התלמוד הישראלי השלם). Only one volume has been published on the Seder Zeraim, with detailed nussach changes.
  • The Mishnah Project of the Israel National Academy of Sciences (האקדמיה הלאומית הישראלית למדעים) is collecting all the manuscripts and Geniza fragments of the Mishnah with the aim of producing a scholarly edition of them in the distant future.

Out of the classic editions, one of the most complete to-date editions of Mishnah is the 13-vol Mishnayot Zecher Chanoch published by Moznaim, which gives a review of the known versions. There is an even longer 15- or 21-vol edition Mishna Behirah by the haMaor Institute (מכון המאור) with more commentaries, bells and whistles.

Oz VeHadar also has a long 15-vol set as well as a short 6-vol student edition (it has additional nekudos in R' Ovadia m'Bartenura text).

Artscroll editions of Mishnah are also fairly accurate, both Hebrew and English compared to other editions.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

I have found a very interesting resource. The text is based on the Kaufman manuscript and worked by Rav Dan Beeri.

משנה על פי כתב יד קאופמן על פי הנקדן המגיה

It's available in Wikitext:

מִשְׁנָה מְנֻקֶּדֶת וּמְעֻצֶּבֶת

This is quite different from the standard Niqud we know by the classical editions. I am interested to know what people who love to read Mishnayot think about it.

This is an interesting book, מבוא לניקוד המשנה an introduction to the vocalization of the Mishna by Chanoch Yalon, who made the vocalization of the Mishna's edition commented by Chanoch Albek

title: Looking for sources regarding working in a mixed gender environment
content:
# Looking for sources regarding working in a mixed gender environment ## Frage

I'm looking for as many sources as possible that talk about working in a mixed gender environment. Specifically, modern-day Rabbanim who talk about possible problems that may arise, and factor those into p'saks. (Or older Rabbanim, assuming their concerns or heters are still applicable).

I am interested in sources that talk about problems that might arise specifically in an office or retail work or similar "day-to-day" environments (whether that involves coworkers or clients, Jews or Goyim), not in a place that tends to be more problematic because of the dress, physical activity, personal connection, or touch involved (like a gym, swimming pool, psychologist or doctor). Of course, sources that discuss both are welcome.

Note: I'm looking for a lot of sources, so I don't expect to have them all copied, translated, or summarized in answers. I'm ok with "Rabbi Ploni talks about Shmiras Negiya at work here [link]", or "... In siman 35 of Even Ha'ezer". I'd be grateful for summaries too, but more sources are preferable to summaries.

In addition (I understand from @mbloch's answer that this wasn't clear): I'm not looking for a product to buy, I'm looking for a list of sources. If a sefer brings a lot of sources, but I don't have access to that sefer, then that won't help me.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

R Ari Wasserman wrote an entire book on the topic, called Making it work (as luck would have it the second edition is just out) which brings hundreds of sources in context.

There is a companion volume called Halachic Q & A on the Job and even a version for women (Making It All Work: Women Surviving and Thriving at Work).

The main volume has specific sections covering

  • Kiddush Hashem
  • Geneivat Da’at
  • Marit ayin
  • Tzniut
  • Kashrut, eating/drinking with non-Jews
  • Yichud, shomer negia, shemiras enayim
  • Social interactions
  • Hashkafa
  • and a lot more

These books were translated and rewritten for an Israeli public as well if relevant.

title: Minhagim of Western Poland (Posen, Breslau, West Preußen)?
content:
# Minhagim of Western Poland (Posen, Breslau, West Preußen)? ## Frage

Do old eastern Germans Jews (ethnically German or Polish) in Western Poland (Silesia, Posen, W.Preussen) tend to be Hasidic, Non-Hasidic, most probably Minhag Polin (like Berlin, Hamburg)

How does it compare to “minhag America” and the generic Ashkenazi minhag prevalent nowadays? Is it similar?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The border between Minhag Ashkenaz and Minhag Polin was not completely stable over time. In Thesaurus of Hebrew Oriental Melodies, vol. 7, Songs of the South German Jews (1932), A. Z. Idelsohn writes:

The Rhineland and Eastern France is considered to be the cradle of the Ashkenazic song. We also know that up to the expulsion of the Jews from France in 1394 the synagogue song in both countries was alike. On the other hand, in the synagogue song in Eastern Europe many variants and changes had developed. With these Jacob Levi (Maharil) was acquainted. The Danube was considered the border between West and East European rites, so that, in Regensburg for example, the eastern rite prevailed.

Idelsohn cites, Maharil, Warsaw 1873, p. 47 "When he (Jacob Mollin) once officiated on the High Holydays in Regensburg as a precentor and sang the prayers according to the Austrian rite, which was traditional in that congregation, it occurred to him that he chanted the Haftara (Prophets) according to the mode traditional in the Rhineland."

This geographical division remained in Southern Germany, however in Eastern Germany (Berlin, Stettin, Poznan, etc.) the situation continued to change. While Idelsohn doesn't draw a second geographic line, I have seen written in other sources that the Elbe River became a rough division between Minhag Ashkenaz and Minhag Polin by the 18th Century. Idelsohn writes:

Toward the end of the 17th century the East-European Synagogue Song developed its present features. After the excesses of Chmelnitzki (1648-1660) East-European Jews migrated to the West, especially Rabbis and precentors, and within a short time we find them officiating in most German congregations. The East European precentors distinguished themselves at that time by their art and virtuosity and were superior to their German colleagues. They introduced into the German congregations the so-called Polish song, i.e. the Synagogue Song as developed in eastern Europe.

In a footnote, he adds:

We here likewise of Polish precentors in Prague, Fürth, Hamburg, and Amsterdam, etc. more details in my Jewish Music, chaps. IX, XI, and XIV.

On pages 212-213 of Jewish Music in It's Historical Development, he writes:

If until the seventeen century Germany had supplied Eastern Europe with rabbis and chazzanim, the one transplanting thither Ashkenazic Jewish learning, and the other Ashkenazic traditional songs and customs, that role was no longer hers after the massacres of Chmelnitzki (1648-60), which caused the Polish and Ukrainian Jews to leave their dwelling place and to migrate westward. In the course of a very short time, the Polish influx colored the character of many a Central European congregation; or, in some instances, separate Polish congregations were established.

While this migration of eastern Jews happened to some extent throughout Germany, (In HOM, vol. 7, Idelsohn gives the counterexamples of Issac Lachmann, born in Dubno 1838, spent his career as cantor in Bavaria, and Fabian Ogutsch, born in Lithuania 1845, cantor in Frankfort, both of whom adapted to the local traditional Minhag Ashkenaz rather than importing Polish melodies), it was in the the cities of the north and east that Minhag Polin made major inroads. One can find the names of many prominent figures that migrated to northern Germany, such as R. Tzvi Ashkenazi, the father of R. Yaacov Emden to Altona, along with many other examples. Eric Werner writes in A Voice Still Heard: The Sacred Songs of the Ashkenazic Jews:

Moreover, turned out that the cities were more prone to admit Jewish settlers than the rural environments—a complete reversal of the situation 150 years previously. Toward the end of the seventeen century, the Jews returned to Holland, Denmark, Prussia, and somewhat later to Saxony. In this climate of a devastated Germany, ravaged by the Wars of Religion, a "new tolerance" seemed to dawn; and it remains the unforgotten merit of the pietists to have set both example and pace toward a kind of "friendship" with a weary and anxiety-ridden Jewry.

Yet the communities were beset by the beginnings of a mass reimmigration of Jews from Poland and the Ukraine in consequence of the pogroms that had started in 1648. As usual, cantors were in the vanguard of the refugees. Surprisingly, the German Jews took quickly to the somewhat "exotic" type of Polish ḥazanut. Where there was strong resistance, separate congregations for the Jews from Poland were established. In the long run the "Polish style" became so popular in Germany that it served as a counterweight against the complete Germanization of minhag ashkenaz. 200 years later, Abraham Baer separated the two traditions in his Ba'al Tefillah, the first serious musical source and compendium of minhag ashkenaz, which has been quoted extensively above.

While there is no guarantee that the musical development of Ashkenaz into two distinct styles that Idelsohn and Werner trace perfectly correlates with the geographical distribution of other differences between Minhag Ashkenaz and Minhag Polin, say what age to start wearing a tallis or which yotzros to include, it can be used as a general proxy for the movement of people and customs.

title: How was Rebbi allowed to learn Torah with Antoninus
content:
# How was Rebbi allowed to learn Torah with Antoninus ## Frage

Rebbi learned Torah with Antoninus.

  1. A Goy that learns Torah is supposed to be put to death?
  2. How did Rebbi learn Torah with him, isn’t that Lifnei Iver- enabling someone to do a sin?
## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

There are a few possible explanations:

  1. The Yerushalmi in Meggilah 1:11 says that some say Antoninus converted and even before conversion, it was allowed, as the Maharasha in Shabbat 31a says that one can teach Torah to a non Jew before he/she converts.

  2. Rambam in Shu"t HaRambam 147 he says that its assur to teach Torah to a non Jew only if he rejects the divinity of the Torah. Antoninus however did not reject it.

  3. The Seridei Esh 2:63 says:

״לענ"ד נראה שגזל איכא רק במי שקובע יום שבת לשבת, וכן באומר שהתורה היא שלו, שעל ידי כך גוזל בכורתו ויתרונו של ישראל, משא"כ מי שהולך בטל כל השבוע, או שלומד תורה לשם חכמה כמו שאר החכמות - אין בכך משום גזל.״

"In my humble opinion, it seems that theft only applies to someone who establishes Shabbat on a different day (than the seventh day), or to one who claims that the Torah is his own [i.e., that he authored it or it is his exclusive domain] — for through this, he steals the birthright and superiority of Israel. However, one (non-Jew) who idles all week, or studies Torah merely as a form of wisdom like other sciences — this does not constitute theft."

Sources: Sourced taken from here and here

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

My understanding is that a Jew may learn the seven Noachide laws with a non-Jew. Moreover, per those who say that Antoninus converted, Rebbe was allowed to teach him all of Torah.

title: The Mosaic law and sin in Judaism
content:
# The Mosaic law and sin in Judaism ## Frage

Please read my question carefully. This is not an off topic question. This question is about Judaism, even if Christianity is mentioned.

Paul of Tarsus, a 1st century Pharisaical Jew turned Christian, made the following statement about the Mosaic law in his letter to the church in Rome:

Now we know that whatever the law says, it says to those who are under the law, so that every mouth may be silenced and the whole world may be held accountable to God. For no one is declared righteous before him by the works of the law, for through the law comes the knowledge of sin. (Romans 3:19-20)

Here, Paul claims that one of the purposes of the Mosaic law was to expose human sin and lawlessness.

My question is this: is this a novel understanding coming from Paul? Does this idea exist within Judaism at all? Do any rabbis speak of the Mosaic law exposing man's sin and imperfection? Thanks!

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

I see two ideas presented by Paul that you've highlighted. The first one is very much a Jewish idea, as I'll explain:

Twice daily we recite the Shema. This is a citation of three paragraphs from the Torah, the first of which comes from Devarim (Deuteronomy) 6:4-9, and the second from Devarim (Deuteronomy) 11:13-21.

The Gemara Brachos 13a discusses why the first paragraph is read first, and the second paragraph is read second:

אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן קָרְחָה: לָמָּה קָדְמָה פָּרָשַׁת ״שְׁמַע״ לְ״וְהָיָה אִם שָׁמוֹעַ״ — כְּדֵי שֶׁיְּקַבֵּל עָלָיו עוֹל מַלְכוּת שָׁמַיִם תְּחִלָּה, וְאַחַר כָּךְ מְקַבֵּל עָלָיו עוֹל מִצְוֹת.

Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa said: Why, in the mitzva of the recitation of Shema, did the portion of Shema precede that of VeHaya im Shamoa? This is so that one will first accept upon himself the yoke of the kingdom of Heaven, the awareness of God and God’s unity, and only then accept upon himself the yoke of the mitzvot, which appears in the paragraph of VeHaya im Shamoa.

Indeed, recognition of our subservience to G-d is the sine qua non of performance of mitzvos, as the Gemara Yerushalmi Shabbos 13:3 says on Vayikra (Leviticus) 27:34:

אָמַר רִבִּי אִילָא. אֵ֣לֶּה הַמִּצְוֹ֗ת. אִם עֲשִׂיתָן כְּמִצְווֹתָן הֵן מִצְוֹת. וְאִם לָאו אֵינָן מִצְוֹת.

Rebbi Ila said, these are the commandments. If you did them the way they were commanded they are a good deeds; otherwise they are not good deeds.

R' Meir Kahane expands on this idea in his sefer Ohr Haraayon in the fifth chapter:

א"כ, על אחת כמה וכמה אדם בישראל הכופר במצוות מן השמים רח"ל, והמקיים "מצוה" מן התורה כגון כבוד אב ואם או שנותן צדקה וכדומה, אך לא משום שאלו הן גזרת מלך, צו אלוקי מסיני, אלא רק בגלל ההסכמה "המוסרית" שלו, שלא עשה ולא כלום, ואינו מברך או מקדש או מקיים אלא מנאץ.

If so, all the more so a person of Israel who denies that the commandments are from Heaven, (Heaven hear our prayers) [ed. "Heaven forbid such a thing"], and fulfills a "commandment" from the Torah like honoring one's father and mother or giving charity or the like, but not because it is a decree of the King but because it agrees with his "morality" - he has done nothing [ed. of fulfillment of commandments] and hasn't blessed or made holy or fulfilled, but rather has blasphemed.

Now, inherent in knowledge of the law is the knowledge of our struggle - sometimes success, sometimes failure, or as Paul calls it, "knowledge of sin" - to uphold that law. This is not some major innovation on Paul's part, it's the definition of being inherently imperfect as humans. Your interpretation of this line is completely divorced from the words of Paul, but is nonetheless straight out of a verse in Bereishis (Genesis) 8:21:

וַיָּ֣רַח ה אֶת־רֵ֣יחַ הַנִּיחֹ֒חַ֒ וַיֹּ֨אמֶר ה אֶל־לִבּ֗וֹ לֹ֣א אֹ֠סִ֠ף לְקַלֵּ֨ל ע֤וֹד אֶת־הָֽאֲדָמָה֙ בַּֽעֲב֣וּר הָֽאָדָ֔ם כִּ֠י יֵ֣צֶר לֵ֧ב הָֽאָדָ֛ם רַ֖ע מִנְּעֻרָ֑יו וְלֹֽא־אֹסִ֥ף ע֛וֹד לְהַכּ֥וֹת אֶת־כָּל־חַ֖י כַּֽאֲשֶׁ֥ר עָשִֽׂיתִי:

And the Lord smelled the pleasant aroma, and the Lord said to Himself, "I will no longer curse the earth because of man, for the imagination of man's heart is evil from his youth, and I will no longer smite all living things as I have done.

All this being said, Paul's antinomian theology is purely and utterly nonsensical. To quote R' Tovia Singer: "Anything you find in the New Testament of the Christian Bible - if it's true, it isn't new, and if it's new, it isn't true."

title: Making sense of R' Yishmael's meeting with Akatriel
content:
# Making sense of R' Yishmael's meeting with Akatriel ## Frage

In bBrachot 7a R' Yishmael ben Elisha claims to have entered the Holy of Holies to offer the ketoret (assumedly on Yom Kippur) where he encountered (an Angel?) Akatriel.

My question is that this story seems to be historically impossible. R' Yishmael ben Elisha was perhaps born in the year 90 CE1 but was certainly too young to have ever performed the service on Yom Kippur as he was taken captive as a youth (Tosefta Horiyot 2:6, Giṭtin 58a).

However his grandfather, who was also named Yishmael, was a Kohen Gadol and could have performed the service.

I have not seen any manuscript evidence that the words בֶּן אֱלִישָׁע were interpolated. Do any commentaries either suggest there is a textual error here, or offer another explanation to this story?

  1. Wikipedia, unsourced
## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

A few possible answers I'm familiar with:

One possibility is that Rabbi Yishmael Kohen Gadol was Rabbi Yishmael ben Piabi,1 a Kohen Gadol during the final decades of the Second Temple Period. This was suggested by Yitzchak Baer, 'The Service of Sacrifice in Second Temple Times', Zion 40 (1975) pp. 135-136 (in Hebrew).2 The tanna Rabbi Yishmael ben Elisha (he who was supposedly born ca. 90 CE) was probably his descendant. Rabbi Prof. Shmuel Klein, 'Studies in Names and Titles' (לחקר השמות והתוארים), Ha-Soker 5 (1936-1938), p. 10 (in Hebrew) suggested identifying Phebus, one of two envoys sent by Agrippus II to try to disperse the fledgling Jewish rebellion movement (Josephus, War of the Jews, 2:19:3), with Rabbi Yishmael ben Piabi. He identified the second envoy, Borceus, with Yissachar of Kefar Barkai, another one-time Kohen Gadol. Phebus was slaughtered by the crowd while Borceus, though injured, managed to escape with his life. This might be some kind of alternate version for Rabbi Yishmael's death in the tale of the Ten Martyrs.

A precursor of this suggestion was brought by Tosfot on Yevamot 104a, s.v. אמר ר' ישמעאל, simply stating that there were two Rabbi Yishmael ben Elishas, one a Kohen Gadol before the destruction, another a tanna after the destruction - without identifying the former with Rabbi Yishmael ben Piabi.

Another possibility is that during the Bar Kochva Revolt the Temple service was reinstated, and according to some, the Temple was rebuilt in some capacity.3 Following this proposal, Yaakov Hakohen Shachi, 'The Construction of the Temple by Bar Kokhba', Yerushalayim 6 (1903), p. 307 (in Hebrew) suggested that Rabbi Yishmael ben Elisha the Kohen Gadol served in the role in the Bar Kochban Temple. A kind of variant of this proposal was suggested by Rabbi Yehoshua Domb, Kuntress Imrei Yehoshua, pp. 30-31. He argued that there were indeed two Rabbi Yishmael ben Elishas, one a Kohen Gadol during the Second Temple Period and another a Kohen Gadol in the time of Bar Kochva.

A third possibility was suggested by Rabbi Yaakov Schor in his commentary on Rabbi Yehudah Barceloni's Sefer Ha'Itim, Hilchot Ner, p. 223, n. 16. According to his suggestion, Rabbi Yishmael ben Elisha did not really burn incense in the Temple, but rather envisioned the whole event in some kind of mystical spiritual fashion. And see further clarification by the editor, pp. XVIII-XIX, n. 10, as well as a note by Binyamin Horowitz in Kovetz He'arot Ha'temimim ve'Ana"sh - Morristown 39 (5745), p. 4.

1 The rabbinic honorific was applied to him in a number of sources, e.g. Mishna Sotah 9:15; Yerushalmi Yoma 3:6; Bavli Yoma 35b.

2 This seems to have also been held by John Richards, who simply stated in The Illegality of the Trial of Jesus, New Orleans 1915, p. 15 that Ishmael ben Phabi was "the handsomest man of his time", evidently identifying him with Rabbi Yishmael of the Ten Martyrs, identified in Eleh Ezkerah with the Rabbi Yishmael Kohen Gadol of the sources brought by the OP.

3 A number of scholars have suggested this over the years. See for example: Kalman Schulman, The Ruins of Beitar (הריסות ביתר), no-pagination-online-edition here (in Hebrew); Avraham Kotlar, 'Clarifying Issues' (יתבררו ויתלבנו הדברים), Otzar Hachaim 14 (1937), pp. 19-20; ibid. pp. 85-86 (in Hebrew) [and see rebuttal by G. Ben-Menachem, 'The Temple of Shimon Bar Kokhba (בית־המקדש של שמעון בר־כוכבא), ibid. pp. 45-46 (in Hebrew)]; Prof. Yehoshua Peleg, 'The Dating of the Temple in Tractate Middot' (זמנו של המקדש במסכת מידות), Techumin 17 (1997), pp. 480-496 (in Hebrew) [and see rebuttal by editor Rabbi Itamar Varheftig, 'Appendix: Was It Built and Did It Exist?' (נספח: האם היה והאם נבנה?), ibid. pp. 496-498 (in Hebrew)].
