title: Timing of sabbath (sundown)
content:
# Timing of sabbath (sundown) ## Frage

For strict observers, do they measure the days, especially sabbath and passover, by the exact sundown for their location or by the time zone they are in?

Toledo, Ohio, and Syracuse, New York are in the same time zone, but their actual sundowns are more than an hour apart.

Just curious…

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

It's definitely localized to your location. (We can debate exactly how much to the split-second, but -- it's not just "all cities in Eastern time zone pretends sunset is 7pm.") There are plenty of rabbis who dabble in astronomy who spend a lot of attention on this.

"Zemanim" is Hebrew for "times"; besides sunrise and sunset, there are laws that kick in when it is "medium-sized stars are visible sunset" (and endless debate how do define that mathematically), at "local solar noon", i.e. when the sun is actually at the top of the sky, at "one-quarter of daylight hours past sunrise", and so on. Hence there are online "zemanim" calculators like this one where you input a date and a latitude/longitude, and it will figure out sunrise and sunset times for that particular location, and then the rest of the math from there.

There's a popular booklet called "Ezras Torah Luach" (I'd link you a copy but it's paywalled) that has preprinted the start-of-Sabbath time for each Friday of the year ... for each city in the US with a significant Orthodox Jewish population. I'm flipping through my copy now: New York, Atlanta, Baltimore, Boston, Buffalo, Chicago, Cincinnati ...

title: Why Should Anyone Nazirite-Abstain from Wine after Seeing a Sota in her Disgrace?
content:
# Why Should Anyone Nazirite-Abstain from Wine after Seeing a Sota in her Disgrace? ## Frage

The Talmud Nazir (2a) states that

Anyone who sees a Sota in her disgrace should Nazirite-abstain from wine.

The Talmud, prima facie, is discussing a full Nazir vow in this case. Why? Should not a simple vow from wine do the trick?

In fact, per the Maharsha Chidushei Agadot Shabbat 139(a) (.ולקדקד נזיר וגו):

a vow from wine v. being a full Nazir, in essence, accomplish very similar things when it comes to repudiating the evils of indulgences / excesses.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

A vow is something you make once and people tend to forget about them or lose interest. Being a nazir is a complete lifestyle change. Once you have the whole "package", it's harder to backslide. You have to do it all at once.

The Gemara isn't giving a command that you should become a nazir, it's saying "If you're REALLY serious about not getting involved with sotah situations..." People who are pious about certain mitzvot go above and beyond.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

Notwithstanding the Maharsha (both, Nazir and a vow from wine, potentially protect one from the evils of excess and indulgence), a Nazir must, in fact, observe more biblical wine oriented stringencies in order to distance himself from wine. FE, a Nazir may not drink משרת אבנים biblically a la the rabbinical אָמְרִין נְזִירָא; סְחוֹר סְחוֹר, לְכַרְמָא לָא תִּקְרַב״. we say to a nazirite; go around and go around, but do not come near to the vineyard.

Thus, one who sees a Sota in her state of utter disgrace and demise should be so moved by the experience that the natural thing to do would to become a full Nazir in order to take on ALL of the biblical and rabbinical wine stringencies that prevent any possibility of drinking wine and becoming Sota-like.

An example of Nazir is given in midrash Bereshis Rabba 98:20:

Joseph, on the head of the elect among his brothers” (Genesis 49:26). ... “On the head of the elect [nezir] among his brothers” – as his brothers distanced him and caused him to be isolated [nazir]. (see, e.g., Leviticus 22:2; Isaiah 1:4), and so too, Joseph was separated from his brothers. Rabbi Yitzḥak of Migdal said: You are the crown of your brothers. Rabbi Levi said: He was an actual nazirite, as Rabbi Levi said: All twenty-two years that he did not see his brothers, he did not taste the taste of wine. They, too, did not taste wine until they saw him. That is what is written: “They drank and became intoxicated with him” (Genesis 43:34) – with him they drank; without him they did not drink.

I found a Yedei Moshe on Midrash Bereshis Rabba 98:20 that underscores the idea of complete separation (see his second answer, which I will translate):

אף הם לא טעמו טעם יין. ... י"ל דה"ק הוא היה נזיר לגמרי עשא"כ הם לא שתו יין ומ"מ לא היו נזירים שאסורים בחרצנים וזגים וכו':

... he (Yosef) was a complete Nazir, (unlike his brothers) who (merely) did not drink wine, and were not prohibited from seeds and skin.

In other words, Yosef who lived among promiscuous Egyptian women, such as Potifar's wife, had to be stringent.

title: Why does one need koach gavra for netilat yadayim?
content:
# Why does one need koach gavra for netilat yadayim? ## Frage

When washing hands for a meal, one needs koach gavra, i.e., using human power to pour water on the hands (typically done by pouring water from one hand onto the other, see SA OC 159:7 and ff). Why is this?

I am not asking for the details of the law, but rather for the reason attributed to the law.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

In the Beit Yosef Orach Chaim Siman 159 ד״ה וצריך שיבואו המים מכח אדם he says:

וכתבו הגהות מיימון דהא דבעינן כח אדם נפקא לן מדכתיב והזה הטהור דבעינן כח גברא

"And the Hagahot Maimoni wrote that the requirement for כח גברא is derived from the pasuk (Parashat Chukat 19:19 regarding מי חטאת) 'והזה הטהור,' from which we learn that it must be through the force of a man (i.e., human action)."

So one of the reasons behind requiring כח גברא is because of/learned from the מי חטאת.

title: Potential gentile prophets such as Buddha, Zoroaster, Krishna
content:
# Potential gentile prophets such as Buddha, Zoroaster, Krishna ## Frage

I am inquiring about people considered prophets by other religions potentially being prophets to the gentiles. My question is really 2 parts:

  1. What is exactly the tradition relating to gentile prophets? I have heard that in Islam they believe other prophets came but their messages were changed. Do we believe this too? Is there any specificity as to where the gentile prophets lived? Was it around the world?

  2. What is the feasibility of people like Buddha or Zoroaster being gentile prophets? Considering they both lived before Malachi, is it possible?

Thank you.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

While prophecy for Israelites ended by Chaggai, Zecharia, and Malachi, in Vayikra Rabba 1:13, various restrictions on prophecy to the other nations are listed. One of these, given by Rabbi Yitzchak, is that this was only until the Mishkan was erected.

אמר רבי יצחק: עד שלא הוקם המשכן היתה נבואה מצויה באומות העולם. משהוקם המשכן נסתלקה מביניהם, שנאמר: (שיר ג)אחזתיו ולא ארפנו. אמרו לו: הרי בלעם מתנבא?! אמר להן: לטובתן של ישראל נתנבא. (במדבר כג) מי מנה עפר יעקב. (שם ) לא הביט און ביעקב. (שם) כי לא נחש ביעקב מה טובו אוהליך יעקב. (שם כד) דרך כוכב מיעקב. (שם) וירד מיעקב.

Rabbi Yitzḥak said: Until the Tabernacle was erected, prophecy was found among the nations of the world. When the Tabernacle was erected, it departed from their midst, as it is stated: “[When I found the one whom my soul loves,] I grasped him and would not release him” (Song of Songs 3:4). They said to him: But Bilam prophesied. He said to them: He prophesied for the benefit of Israel: “Who has counted the dust of Jacob” (Numbers 23:10); “One has seen no evil in Jacob” (Numbers 23:21); “For there is no divination in Jacob” (Numbers 23:23); “How goodly are your tents, Jacob” (Numbers 24:5); “a star rises from Jacob” (Numbers 24:17); “One from Jacob shall rule” (Numbers 24:19).

Bilaam was considered an exception to this for a particular reason, in that he prophesied for the benefit of Israel.

Buddha, at 6th century BCE, post-dates that. Zoroaster, at 7th century BCE, also post-dates that.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

What is exactly the tradition relating to gentile prophets?

Non-Jews who were prophets certainly existed. The Gemara Bava Basra 15B list several of them.

I have heard that in Islam they believe other prophets came but their messages were changed. Do we believe this too?

No. Number 9 of the 13 principles of faith listed by the Rambam is The belief in the immutability of the Torah.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 1)

B"H

Prophecy did not end according to all opinions, it still can exist today, and it did exist in very recent times.

The Lubavitcher Rebbe in a famous speech on Shabbos Parshas Shoftim, 5751, brought many proofs from the Rambam that prophecy still exists now.

The first proof is from Hilchos Yesodei Hatorah chapter 7, where the Rambam starts off categorically:

"It is one of the foundations of the Torah to know that the Creator prophecizes humans", and significantly he does NOT bring the statement of the Talmud that,

"From the time of Chagai Zechariah and Malakia, prophecy was "removed" (סלקא) from Yisroel"

This proves that according to the Rambam, that statement on the Talmud was not a halachos one, it was just agadah, which doesn't have any legal effect.

The language in that context in the talmud is simply saying it was "removed" from them, not that it ceased (בטל) unlike many other things that are mentioned in that same context, which it does say explicitly that they ceased.

This proves that prophecy, even according to the talmud, never actually "ceased", it was just (temporarily) removed.

Not only that, but based on the Rambam's wording, "that Hashem prophesizes humans", without mentioning that being Jewish is a necessary condition, it's implied that prophecy can also apply to non Jews, IF they don't contact the prophecy of Moshe at all, and meet all of the other necessary criteria.

Then, the Rambam in Igeres Taiman chapter 3 says explicitly that even though prophecy ceased temporarily, it actually returned in the Hebrew year 4976 (1216 CE), based on a verse from parshas Bilam which says,

"Like this time, it will be asked from Yisroel, "what is Hashem doing"?"

Meaning, "like this time", that existed then, which was the year 2488 from creation, in the future from that time, which is 2488 times 2, people will be able to ask from Bnei Yisroel what Hashem is telling them, implying they will be prophets again from that year

Not only that, but the Rambam continues in that chapter, that he has personal family testimony of coming into contact with a real prophet who already received prophecy from that time

So not only is the Rambam's wording hypothetical that prophecy could exist, but we have actually testimony that it did start to literally exist.

וביאור הדבר שבנבואת בלעם רמז שתחזור הנבואה לישראל אחר שתפסוק מהם לפי שיש בתורה פסוקים שאף על פי שהכונה בהם לשום ענין אף על פי כן יש בהם רמז לענין אחר כמו שמצינו ממאמר יעקב אבינו עליו השלום שאמר לבניו (בראשית מ"ב ב') "רדו שמה" שעכבו במצרים כמנין רד"ו שהם מאתים ועשר שנים וכן מאמר משה רבינו עליו השלום שאמר (דברים ד' כ"ה) "כי תוליד בנים ובני בנים ונושנתם בארץ" שישבנו בארץ ישראל מיום שנכנסנו בה עד גלות המלך יויכין כמנין "נושנתם" והם שמנה מאות ארבעים ושש שנה וכזה הרבה ועל הענין הזה קבלנו שזה שאמר בלעם (במדבר כ"ג כ"ג) "כעת יאמר ליעקב ולישראל מה פעל אל" יש בו סוד שמן העת ההיא יש לחשב כמנין שיש מששת ימי בראשית ועד אותה העת ותחזור הנבואה לישראל ואז יאמרו להם הנביאים "מה פעל אל" ונבואה זו נאמרה בשנת הארבעים לצאתם מארץ מצרים ותמצא התחלת החשבון עד אותה העת אלפים ארבע מאות שמונים ושמנה שנה שהסימן "בתפ"ח גאולים" ולפי ההקש הזה והפירוש הזה תחזור הנבואה לישראל בשנת ארבעת אלפים תשע מאות שבעים ושש ליצירה ואין ספק שחזרת הנבואה היא הקדמת משיח שנאמר (יואל ג' א') "ונבאו בניכם ובנותיכם".

זהו יותר אמתי מכל חשבון שנאמר בשום קץ וזה שאמרנו שהוא אמתי אחר שהוזהרנו עליו ומנעונו תכלית המניעה לגלותו שלא יהיה בעיני העם ברחוק וכבר הודעתיך אותו וברוך היודע.

And the explanation of the matter—that in the prophecy of Bilaam there is an allusion that prophecy will return to Israel after it had ceased from them—is because there are verses in the Torah that, although their intention pertains to one matter, nevertheless contain an allusion to another matter. As we find in the statement of our father Yaakov, peace be upon him, who said to his sons (Genesis 42:2) “Go down there (‘redu shamah’),” and they were delayed in Egypt for the numerical value of “רד"ו” (Reish-Dalet-Vav), which is 210 years. And likewise the statement of Moshe our teacher, peace be upon him, who said (Deuteronomy 4:25), “When you beget children and grandchildren and have grown old (‘venoshantem’) in the land,” and we dwelled in the Land of Israel from the day we entered it until the exile of King Jehoiachin for the numerical value of “venoshantem,” which is 846 years. And so too many similar things.

And regarding this matter we have received that which Bilaam said (Numbers 23:23), “At that time it shall be said to Jacob and to Israel what has God wrought,” contains a secret: that from that moment, one should count a number equivalent to the number of years from the Six Days of Creation until that moment, and then prophecy will return to Israel. And then the prophets will say to them, “What has God wrought.” And this prophecy was said in the fortieth year after they left the land of Egypt. And you will find that the beginning of the count until that moment is 2,448 years, the sign being “ב'תפ"ח גאולים” (“in 2448 [come] the redeemed”).

And according to this correlation and this interpretation, prophecy will return to Israel in the year 4976 from creation. And there is no doubt that the return of prophecy is the forerunner of the coming of the Messiah, as it is said (Joel 3:1), “And your sons and daughters shall prophesy.”

This is truer than any calculation ever stated regarding the end [of days]. And this that we have said is true, even though we have been warned and utterly prohibited from revealing it, so that it should not appear to the people as something distant—and yet I have already informed you of it. Blessed is He who knows.

title: Defining a Defensive War
content:
# Defining a Defensive War ## Frage

Several questions (example) addressed proper conduct during a Mandatory war (Milchemet Mitzvah). In Kings_and_Wars.5.1, Rambam defines Milchemet Mitzvah:

"What is considered a milchemet mitzvah?
-The war against the seven nations that occupied Eretz Yisrael,
-The war against Amalek, and
-a war fought to assist Israel from an enemy which attacks them".

The last concept requires defining three terms: "Israel", "enemy", and "attack"

1. "Israel"

In my understanding, Rambam's view of the collective "Israel" that he uses consistently is somewhat anachronistic, referring to the Jewish absolute monarchy.

However, "Israel" might alternatively mean many things, e.g.:

  • a city with a large Jewish population
  • a city with a Jewish majority
  • a Jewish autonomy
  • a democratic secular state with a Jewish majority (aka the State of Israel), with or without the majority of worldwide Jewry
  • a Jewish monarchy, with or without the majority of worldwide Jewry

2. "Enemy"

An enemy who targets Jewish lives could be:

  • a stand-alone terrorist/serial killer
  • a local terrorist group
  • an international terrorist group
  • a sovereign state

3. "Attack"

That could also have different meanings, e.g.:

  • threatens to attack
  • sabotages resources (roads, electricity, water)
  • kills single individuals
  • kills a group of Jews
  • organizes a pogrom
  • launches missiles into Jewish settlements
  • launches full-scale war against a Jewish political entity

A proper definition of a Mandatory war has immense implications, e.g., total mobilization or the permission to exterminate non-combatants.

How do different commentators define a Defensive war?

title: How did Eve Knew About Childbirth, Adam Know About Bread and Parents before Anyone Was Born or Anything Baked?
content:
# How did Eve Knew About Childbirth, Adam Know About Bread and Parents before Anyone Was Born or Anything Baked? ## Frage

In Genesis 3, God curses Adam and Eve after their sin. But the language of the curses seems to assume a level of worldly understanding that Adam and Eve simply couldn’t have had especially if, as many traditional Jewish sources maintain, the sin happened very soon after their creation.

Let’s break it down:

1. Eve and Childbirth “I will greatly increase your pain in childbearing…” (Genesis 3:16)

But Eve had never had children. In fact, she may not even have known that children were a concept. The Torah gives no indication that she was ever told about reproduction or what childbirth is so how could this curse be meaningful or comprehensible to her?

2. Adam and Bread “By the sweat of your brow shall you eat bread…” (Genesis 3:19)

But bread is a human invention, not something found in the wild. It requires harvesting grain, grinding it, mixing it with water, kneading, and baking. Adam had just been placed in the Garden; who says he even knew to grind anything, let alone complex food processing that probably took a lot of trial and error with a good dose of luck to ultimately come up with the real bread?

3. "A Man Shall Leave His Father and Mother" — Who? “Therefore, a man shall leave his father and his mother and cling to his wife…” (Genesis 2:24)

This verse comes before there were any fathers or mothers. Adam and Eve had no parents, and the concept of family lineage didn’t yet exist. How could this verse describe social behavior based on generations, when they were the first human beings?

These examples all suggest the Torah is speaking in post-civilizational terms, as if Adam and Eve were familiar with concepts like childbirth, family structure, and processed food despite supposedly living at the very dawn of human existence.

Obvious Responses I'm Not Asking About: I’m aware that some commentators (e.g., Abarbanel) take the story metaphorically that’s not what this question is addressing.

Some might claim Adam and Eve had prophetic knowledge, but the Torah is very clear when people receive prophecy and we see no mention of that here. All prior instructions to them are simple and concrete (e.g., don’t eat from the tree).

So there’s no textual basis to assume they somehow understood complex aspects of future human society.

The Real Question: Are there traditional Jewish sources (Rashi, Ramban, Midrashim, etc.) that address these anachronisms?

Did Adam and Eve truly comprehend these experiences and concepts?

Or is the Torah describing things for the reader’s understanding, rather than what the characters actually knew?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

Sanhedrin 38b:

"אמר רבי יוחנן בר חנינא: שתים עשרה שעות הוי היום. שעה ראשונה הוצבר עפרו, שניה נעשה גולם, שלישית נמתחו אבריו, רביעית נזרקה בו נשמה, חמישית עמד על רגליו, ששית קרא שמות, שביעית נזדווגה לו חוה, שמינית עלו למטה שנים וירדו ארבעה, תשיעית נצטווה שלא לאכול מן האילן, עשירית סרח, אחת עשרה נידון, שתים עשרה נטרד והלך לו"

Which clearly states that Adam and Chavah had children before the sin. Also, rashi to berreishis 4:1 says explicitly that Adam knew Chavah and had already conceived and given birth to Cain prior to the sin.

The posuk regarding a man leaving his parents to cleave to his wife does not say anywhere that this was specifically said to Adam by Hashem. In fact, rashi says on the verse that Ruach hakodesh said this in order to prohibit immoral relations for bnei Noach

Regarding the question with the lechem, it says in a Midrash that there were multiple opinions of what pri eitz ha daas was. An esrog, a fig, a grape, and yes, you guessed it, wheat. Rashi also brings this Medrash on the posuk (Genesis) 2:17, s.v. "ומעץ הדעת טוב ורע": רבי יהודה אומר: חטה היתה, שאין התינוק יודע לקרוא אבא ואמא עד שיטעום טעם דגן. Rabbi Yehuda says: It was wheat, because a child does not know how to say “father” and “mother” until he has tasted the taste of grain. And this is very significant to note, that rashi only brings this one opinion from the Midrash on what the eitz hadaas was (later when they make clothing he cites the opinion that it was a fig tree because they “rectified themselves with that which they had degraded themselves”)

In another source it says that before the sin bread came up from the ground in ready made loaves and will again be so in the times of Moshiach. The mention of bread growing whole and baked (like in Gan Eden) is on Berachos 57a, Rashi s.v. "pat".

Anyway, I think from all these sources it is quite clear according to peshat, Adam and Chavah knew firsthand about these inyonim

title: Which binyan is וַיָּצֵץ in Bamidbar 17:23? What would the infinitive form be?
content:
# Which binyan is וַיָּצֵץ in Bamidbar 17:23? What would the infinitive form be? ## Frage

וַיֹּ֤צֵ֥א פֶ֨רַח֙ וַיָּ֣צֵ֥ץ צִ֔יץ וַיִּגְמֹ֖ל שְׁקֵדִֽים

Are the three verbs here each in a different binyan? I think the first would be hifil (‏‏להוציא) and the third would be pa'al (‏לגמול) but I am less sure about the one in the middle.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

The first two are in the same Binyan, /wayyaḳṭil/→/wayyiḳṭēl/, while the last one is in /wayyaḳṭul/→/wayyiḳṭōl/.

וַיֹּצֵא /wayyōṣē/ developed from proto-Hebrew /wayyawṣiʔ/.
וַיָּצֵץ is now pronounced /wayyāṣēṣ/, from the Biblical pronunciation /wayyaṣiṣ/.

וַיִּגְמֹל /wayyiḡmōl/ developed from the Biblical pronunciation /wayyagmul/.

The infinitive of the second root is לָצוּץ /laṣūṣ/.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

A. According to Sefer אמרי מדריך - Imrei Madrikh, the word וַיָּצֵץ is subject to an argument:

  1. RaDaQ in Sefer haShorashim assigns it to the binyan הפעיל.
  2. The Anonymous Condordance printed in year 5342 (שבי"ל, which is 1582 CE) assigns it to the binyan קל.

While both RaDaQ and the Concordance define the root as ציצ (we also we see so in the @DoubleAA's comment Hebrew Academy link), there are also opinions that the root should be צוצ (see Hebrew Root Dictionary by R' Nehorai Kotkin, or the comment by @JoelK giving the Project Ben-Yehudah link). The later opinion implies that וַיָּצֵץ has the binyan is הפעיל unquestionably. Similar cases occur in Bereshis 2:8 וַיָּשֶׂם (either the root is שימ or שומ, Devarim 28:63 יָשִׂישׂ (either the root is שיש or שוש). In modern Hebrew, the root is צצ.

So if the binyan is הפעיל, the infinitive should be לְהָצֵיץ, regardless of the fact if the root is ציצ or צוצ. The opinion that says that the binyan is קל, believes that the root is ציצ, so their form of infinitive is לָצֵיץ. However, the mainstream opinion is that the קל infinitive is לָצוּץ.

B. In Sefer Imrei Madrikh the word וַיּׂצֵא has binyan הפעיל (the infinitive is לְהוֹצִיא); and the word וַיִּגְמׂל has binyan קל (the infinitive לִגְמֹל).

title: Why does חטא have an אל"ף
content:
# Why does חטא have an אל"ף ## Frage

The א at the end of the word חטא is not pronounced. It's not even like a "נח נסתר" i.e. a consonant at the end of a syllable which is swallowed by the preceding vowel (א, ה, ו or י), because the ט closes the syllable. Why is the א there? Shouldn't the word be spelled חט?

Are there any other words like this?

And why isn't the שו''א under the ט in חטא a שו''א נע?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Note: Most transcriptions between slashes are from the standard IPA-based phonemic transcription of Semitic languages.

All languages with a standard written form quickly develop silent letters. This occurs because languages change, but standardized spelling doesn’t as much. Hebrew was not immune to this.

For example, the English word “Light” is currently pronounced /läit/, but in Middle English was pronounced /lixt/. The digraph “gh” was used to represent /x/ (like Hebrew soft כ), and when that sound disappeared from English, the spelling remained the same.

חטא has a similar story. Originally, the word was pronounced /ḥiṭʔ/, ending with a consonant cluster. The final consonant, /ʔ/, was written with a א. Later, /ʔ/ at the end of consonant clusters was elided; but by then the spelling was standardized, and didn’t change with the times. So even though we currently pronounce the word like /ħēṭ/, the spelling reflects the original pronunciation.

There are a number of words like this, including שַׁוְא /šav/, originally pronounced /šawʔ/.

I’m not sure if the following applies to you, but I’m going to put this note here just in case: Usually, questions of this nature about Hebrew are asked under the premises that Hebrew pronunciation hasn’t changed too much from Biblical times, and that every non-phonemic spelling must have some mystical purpose¹. Both assumptions are baseless. This is agreed upon by both Jewish tradition and modern historical linguistics.

¹Purpose is different from אסמכתא. Mystical concepts are often arbitrarily attached to details of Hebrew orthography, but the concepts don’t actually arise from the orthography. It’s just a convenient tool for memorization of the concepts.

title: Is extermination of the civilian population of an enemy state Halachically permitted?
content:
# Is extermination of the civilian population of an enemy state Halachically permitted? ## Frage

There are many examples in the Tanach where either God Himself (such as the 10 plagues, especially the killing of the firstborns) or the Israelites are commanded to wipe out seemingly innocent people. These include the Midianite genocide by Moses, various campaigns of conquest by Joshua (such as Ai, Hazor, Jericho, etc.), or Mordechai's decree calling for the indiscriminate killing of women, the elderly, and children of the so-called "enemies of the Jews."

I understand that the ultimate justification for all of the above is the concept of Biblical collectivism, applied equally to the Jewish nation (as it says "פֹּקֵד עֲוֺן אָבֹת עַל־בָּנִים עַל־שִׁלֵּשִׁים וְעַל־רִבֵּעִים לְשֹׂנְאָי"), where all members of the group are held responsible for the actions of their leaders, ancestors, or random fellows.

In theory, halachically speaking, does the same approach apply today? For example, given the existential wars in Gaza and Iran, would the label of "an enemy of the Jews" apply to all their civilian populations, justifying mass killings? Should an observant Jewish pilot consult his rabbi before participating in a bombing mission that could cause significant civilian casualties?

Where can I find sources that deal with those questions?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

In Megillat Esther, several terms are used to describe the people the Jews killed.

9-2. They assembled to lay hands on those who sought to harm them. (Mevakshei Raatam)

9-5. Slew their Oyveihem and soneihem.

9-16. They had rest from their Oyveihem and slew their foes (soneihem. I.e. haters)

So we seem to have people who plot harm (mevaksheim), people who perform the harm that the Jews needed rest from (Oyveihem) , and people who don't seem to transform their hatred into actions. (Soniim)

There is a fourth kind of person: a collaborator, like Rahav. Caleb and Pinchas didn't really need her help. Just like pharaoh was powerless to harm Moshe, the people of Jericho should have been powerless against these 2 big tzaddiks. nevertheless, dealing with her seems to be permitted, even though they could have killed her and her family.

I would therefore say, it is permissible to kill a noncombatant population if they don't like you and it is permissible to accept collaborators.

title: Halachos on sta”m: specifically mukaf gvil and separating touching letters
content:
# Halachos on sta”m: specifically mukaf gvil and separating touching letters ## Frage

In shulchan aruch siman 32:16 it addresses the laws of writing, specifically when a letter is intercepted by a hole in the klaf. According to Beis Yosef, the reason that a letter with the hole at the bottom is still kosher is because he understands the requirement that the letter be “mukaf gvil” as either

  1. the letter cannot be touching any other letter (at the time of writing or after), or

  2. that the letter has to actually be written with klaf surrounding the perimeter of the letter all around, but this is only at the time of writing.

And so we see, if a hole formed in a letter after the writing, it satisfies both possibilities (it is not touching another letter and when it was written it was surrounded by klaf since the hole only developed later).

Now in siman 32:18, the shulchan aruch says that a letter which touches another is able to be scraped apart and there is no concern for “chok tochos” (a separate din stating the letters cannot be formed by scraping off ink) and it does not matter if this happened before the letter was formed or after.

So my question is this, if a letter touches another during it’s writing (a ז written so close to a ד that the Kepel of the zayin touches the kepel of the Dalet) how can this letter be scraped apart after and still be kosher? Seemingly it lacked Beis Yosef’s requirement above that it be mukaf gvil at the time of writing? (According to his second possibility of what it means to be mukaf gvil)

Also to strengthen my question, Mishnah berurah says regarding a ך that touches the bottom of the klaf that even if it already had its requisite tzurah (meaning it was already a kosher ך before it touched the bottom), the shulchan aruch is coming to add a chidush and tell us all the while the sofer’s hand has not left the letter it is considered “the time of writing” (Mishnah berurah to 32:16 ד״ה רגל)

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

A hole intercepting a letter and two letters touching are two separate aspects of Mukaf Gevil.

First to understand what’s behind the Beit Yosef’s reasonings:

In Menachot 29a it is taught:

דאמר רב יהודה אמר רב כל אות שאין גויל מוקף לה מארבע רוחותיה פסולה Rav Yehuda says that Rav says: any letter that does not have parchment surrounding it is invalid.

Later in 29b it is taught:

ראמי בר תמרי דהוא חמוה דרמי בר דיקולי איפסיקא ליה כרעא דוי"ו דויהרג בניקבא אתא לקמיה דרבי זירא א"ל זיל אייתי ינוקא דלא חכים ולא טפש אי קרי ליה ויהרג כשר אי לא יהרג הוא ופסול Rami bar Tamrei the father-in-law of Rami bar Dikulei had the vav of ויהרג perforated by a hole and he came before Rabbi Zeira. He [Rabbi Zeira] said to him: go to a child who is neither wise nor stupid. If he reads it ויהרג it is valid. If not, then it’s יהרג and it is invalid.

The Beit Yosef (32:23) questioned how is it possible to validate a letter that is not surrounded by parchment on all four sides. He brings two lines of reasoning as to how this is possible.

His first line of reason is that according to Rashi on the statement of Rav Yehuda, this means that two letters are touching each other. Then according to this logic, the only time when a hole would invalidate letter is if it intervenes between two letters. So if a hole only touches one letter, even if it was at the time of writing, then the letter remains valid as long as it does not change its form.

His second line of reason is that, concerning a hole, the din of mukef g’vil only applies at the time of writing. Should a hole appear after writing was completed and the letter is still recognizable, then the letter remains valid as according to the Rambam Hilchot Tefillin Chapter 1 Halacha 20.

Concerning Shulchan Aruch 32:18, this falls in line with the first line of reasoning where whenever two letters touch it lacks Mukaf Gevil. Even after writing (Mishnah Berurah 32:78)

As for why one just needs to separate the letters, it is because each letter was properly written (Shulchan Aruch 32:18). Meaning, the letters are recognizable as separate letters. However there are cases where two letters touching forms a new letter. For example כו to מ or ינ to צ. In those cases the chok tochot would apply.

Keep in mind there are other opinions (Radak and Rashba) that hold that when two letters touch at the time of writing then the letters are possul due to Ketiva Tama. The Keset Hasofer is stringent and holds that if the touch occurs at the time of writing then it’s possul and the second letter must be erased. (Keset Hasofer 8:15)

title: What explains Locust's Kosherness?
content:
# What explains Locust's Kosherness? ## Frage

Locust is a weird insect, making it hard to imagine being allowed for consumption. And, still, it is.

Kosherness is closely associated with goodness, using the terms Tahor and Tameh. According to Rambam (source needed), it is one of the three axes of "good" (מותר-אסור, טהור-טמא, פטור-חייב).

What explains Locust's Kosherness? What good qualities does it possess that other insects don't (IIRC, the Gemmorah says that only selected species of Locust are Kosher, which makes the question even harder)? Why is it important for the Jewish diet?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

David Grimaldi, the author of Entomology Blog posted an article "What Diseases Do Locusts Carry?" He describes locusts' behavior and biology and also lists a number of factors relevant to the question asked. For additional information, please see the published article by Mark S. Goettel, "Diseases of Grasshoppers and Locusts", Encyclopedia of Entomology, 2008, pp. 1229 - 1233.

As a summary: locusts are herbivorous, they do not prey on humans and animals. Locusts do not bite, even if they nibble they never pierce the skin. Diseases that locusts carry are not harmful to humans. Although they damage crops, they have been used as food throughout human history. These signs and behavior make locusts similar to kosher animals.

What are locusts

Locusts, a type of short-horned grasshopper in the Acrididae family, are primarily plant-eaters and do not typically bite humans like mosquitoes or ticks. Locusts differ from regular grasshoppers as they have long wings and can swarm, while grasshoppers' wings are shorter and they do not swarm. The picture below shows same locust appearance in two different phases: solitary phase (non-swarming), gregarious phase (swarming).

Are locusts harmful to humans and animals?

Locusts are not dangerous to people or pets. ... Although locusts are primarily herbivorous, they sometimes exhibit nibbling behavior towards humans without causing severe harm. Locusts do not attack or bite humans in the same manner as mosquitoes or ticks. Their bites, if they occur, are unlikely to break the skin, leading only to mild irritation or itching.

Individuals with allergies to locusts might experience respiratory symptoms due to swarms... Contact with large swarms can create respiratory issues due to dust particles generated by these insects. Some scientific studies also suggest a potential for allergic reactions in individuals exposed to large swarms.

Despite their formidable appearance, locusts do not seek out humans or animals as prey, focusing instead on vegetation in their environment.

Do Grasshoppers carry diseases or parasites?

Locusts do not pose a direct threat to humans or animals, nor do they transmit diseases harmful to humans. Paranosema (Nosema) locustae, a microsporidian parasite, infects most locust species and is being utilized as a biological control agent. This parasite poses no threat to human health and can consume its weight (approximately 2 grams) in a day. The parasite acidifies locusts' lower guts, inhibiting bacteria that produce swarm-inducing pheromones, leading to fewer pheromones in infected locust droppings.

Locusts may pose danger to agriculture

Locusts themselves are not aggressive towards humans or animals, although their swarming behavior can significantly impact agriculture by stripping vegetation and causing extensive environmental damage. Locust swarms can reach speeds of up to 8 miles per hour and cover distances of 80 miles in a single day, posing severe challenges to farmers by destroying crops. Understanding their behavior, implementing effective control strategies, and advancing predictive technologies are crucial for mitigating their impact on food security, particularly in regions of Africa and Asia where smallholder farmers are most vulnerable.

As we know, in areas damaged by locusts people have used these locusts as food throughout history.

Kashrus of Locusts

According to the article by Zohar Amar, "The Eating of Locusts in Jewish Tradition After the Talmudic Period", The Torah u-Madda Journal, 11, 2002-03, pp. 186 - 202:

A reliable tradition was preserved until our own times only regarding the arbeh (locust) and only among the Jews of Yemen and some of the Jews of North Africa.

In Mishlei 30:27, arbeh is described as "The arbeh-locusts have no king, yet they all march forth in formation," signifying their ability to organize. The arbeh-locust is also described in gemara Chullin 65b as "a species that comes before a person and does not have a smooth forehead," which may indicate that locusts are not harmful to humans.

I once attended a Daf Yomi shiur in which Moed Katan was left to be learned privately and not in the public shiur.

My question is not related to whether the parents of the attendees are alive as in: Learning laws of aveilut when your parents are alive? and accepts that this Masechta can be learned by individuals. It is related only to giving a public shiur on the Masechta.

What are the considerations involved in giving a public shiur on Masechet Moed Katan?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

I was once learning Moed Katan as part of a group. The magid shiur went to R Chaim Kanievski to ask if he could teach the third chapter. R Chaim answered it was best to start the chapter during the 3 weeks, and once started we could finish it.

Not saying this is the halacha for everyone but that was his ruling then.

title: Difference and significance of how Aaron and Bezalel created objects of worship?

So the Rashi for that section explains that the word translated as engraving tool could mean engraving/etching, etc. or it could have a meaning associated with bundling.

In Targum Sheni on Esther 2:5, Mordechai's lineage is traced back to Binyamin, including Shaul HaMelech in it:

מרדכי בר יאיר בר שמעי בר שמידע בר בענה בר אלה בר מיכה בר מפיבושת בר יהונתן בר שאול בר קיש בר אביאל בר צרור בר בכורת בר אפיח בר שחרית בר עוזיה בר שישק בר מיכאל בר אליאל בר עמיהוד בר שפטיה בר פתואל בר פיתון בר מלוך בר ירובעל בר ירוחם בר חנניה בר זבדי בר אליפעל בר שמרי בר זבדיה בר מרימות בר חושים בר שחורה בר גזה בר בלע בר בנימין בריה דיעקב

However, this seems difficult to reconcile with the genealogy of David HaMelech, who is only 10 generations from Yehuda (as listed in Ruth 4:18–22). Is it possible that the Targum Sheni is not presenting a literal genealogy? Maybe this is not even a problem!

title: Does HaShem need every Yid?
content:
# Does HaShem need every Yid? ## Frage

To the best of my knowledge there's been a recent brouhaha regarding a bumper sticker that says "HaShem needs every Yid" with some pushing back that HaShem has no needs etc with another sticker emerging which has it as "Every Yid needs HaShem".

There are various pesukim throughout Tanach that are relevant to this issue however I'd like to focus on Iyov 22:3:

הַחֵ֣פֶץ לְ֭שַׁדַּי כִּ֣י תִצְדָּ֑ק וְאִם־בֶּ֝֗צַע כִּֽי־תַתֵּ֥ם דְּרָכֶֽיךָ׃

Is it any advantage to the Almighty, that you are righteous? Or is it any gain to Him, that you make your ways blameless?

as Ramban's comment there is very germane:

החפץ לשדי כי תצדק – יגזור כי אין בהעשות הטוב לאלהים טובה, או רעה בהעשות הרעות, רק ירצה בטוב וביושר לטובת העושים אותם, וכן יאמרו עוד: אם חטאת מה תפעל בו, ורבו פשעיך מה תעשה לו (איוב ל״ה:ו׳).

“Would He desire your plain fields so that you may be righteous?” – He states categorically that there is no benefit or gain for God when good is done, nor harm or loss when evil is committed. Rather, He desires goodness and uprightness for the sake of those who do them — for their benefit. Similarly, they say further: “If you sin, what do you accomplish against Him? And if your transgressions are many, what do you do to Him?” (Job 35:6).

While it is of course true that God is perfect and no benefit or harm accrues to Him based on how we act however the fact remains that He didn't create the world for naught and as Ramban writes He desires that humans live a flourishing life which is best done by living according to the Torah.

Isn't living in a way which allows us to experience goodness itself giving something to HaShem as it fulfills His desire that humans live well? And conversely, isn't living a dissolute life depriving Him of that emotional pleasure?

(Pardon the anthropomorphisms, I'm trying to get a point across)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The way you've gone about solving it is very similar to how the Rebbe solves it in לא תהי׳ משכלה תשי״ב, parts 1-4.

He starts off with the phrase "צורך גבוה" ("Divine need", a phrase from Gemara regarding the Avodah of the Beit HaMikdash), and "elevates" it to being "relevant to Hashem Himself" (Atzmus), and does so via the basic logic that Hashem needs us to be refined by Mitzvot.

This is a conclusion based on over 1,000 years of discussion on the phrase/concept and how it applies to the Divine. See this answer for more detail and theology.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

Pirkei Avot: 4-3 He used to say: do not despise any man, and do not discriminate against anything, for there is no man that has not his hour, and there is no thing that has not its place.

Every yid and non-yid is required for the order in which the "place" occurs.

They are needed in the sense of the plan that God has set up. Philosophers have debated whether God can need things if he is perfect.

title: Does the Rama (Samson's Nezirut Didn't Include the Prohibition of Tumaat Meit Because of Samson's Weakness for Women) Argue with Midrash Rabba?
content:
# Does the Rama (Samson's Nezirut Didn't Include the Prohibition of Tumaat Meit Because of Samson's Weakness for Women) Argue with Midrash Rabba? ## Frage

The Rama in Torat Haola Chapter 71 (above) states that "... Samson did not distance himself from the excesses of sexuality; this caused his wives to turn his heart away and sap his strength, and for this reason Tumat (Meit) was not made forbidden to him because that proscription expresses/indicates a separation from excess sex."

The Rama (above) explains in Chapter 71 that the way to curb a propensity for excess sex is to not be able to become Tammei Meit - this underscores the existential idea that each individual dies alone and cannot rely on others on the day of death - even those closest to him or her (so why engage in excess sex, if, existentially speaking, consanguinity does not count for anything?). The prohibition against drinking however mitigates an excess desire for food.

Here is a link to Chapter 71:

https://www.sefaria.org/Torat_HaOlah%2C_Part_Three.71.1?lang=bi

What however does the Rama do with the Midrash Rabba (below) in Naso that states that wine is what leads to excess sexuality? (God knew that Samson would sin with Women so He made him a Nazir from birth and specifically proscribed wine so as to give Samson a chance to be good despite his weakness for women).

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Firstly, on a logical level, saying that A → B is not the same as saying that only A → B. Nor does it show that B → A. That is if is not the same as saying iff, meaning if and only if.

So, saying that wine → excess sexuality is not the same as saying that ¬wine → ¬excess sexuality.

Secondly and relatedly, it could be that, with wine, Shimshon would have pursued sexual excess even moreso.

Thirdly, the Rama need not answer to every midrash. Indeed, what we call Midrash Rabba is actually a compilation of separate works from separate authors in separate times and places. Bemidbar Sinai Rabba is actually the latest of these. To cite Wikipedia:

It is the latest component of Midrash Rabbah on the Torah, and as such was unknown to Nathan ben Jehiel (c. 1035–1106), Rashi (1040–1105), and Yalkut Shimoni.

This portion of the Numbers Rabbah shows all the marks of the late haggadic age. There is much which can be referred to Rabbi Moses ha-Darshan (11th Century), and which reveals a connection with Midrash Tadshe. The work is, according to Zunz, hardly older than the 12th Century.

Now, the Rama is admittedly an Acharon, but must he conform in all his understanding of the Biblical narrative to the aggadic thoughts of Rav Moshe HaDarshan, more so than that of other Rishonim, such as Rashi, Ibn Ezra, or Abarbanel?

title: Are (most) Jews Jewish by presumption only?
content:
# Are (most) Jews Jewish by presumption only? ## Frage

A big to-do is made of the fact that Kohanim nowadays aren't definitely Kohanim (as in tracing one's lineage back to the original Kohanim) but rather only presumptively (using the halachic principle of Chazakah).

Isn't that true for Jewishness as well?

Unless one is a convert or can trace oneself to a convert in the relatively recent past then we are all relying on the fact that we're presumptively Jewish.

Over and above the fact that say non-Jews may not study Torah or keep Shabbos but shouldn't the fact that most are only Jewish by presumption render the Kohen issue moot?

Namely, if we rely on Chazakah for our Jewishness then it ought to hold for Kehunah as well; and if we don't rely on it for Kehunah then by the same token the Kohen isn't even Jewish, nor are most non Kohanim for that matter.

Two illustrations:

  • if the Kohen isn't a Kohen and therefore can't eat terumah then the person that grew and separated it isn't Jewish and the terumah isn't terumah

  • if the Kohen isn't a Kohen and therefore should limit his engagement with Birchas Kohanim then he (and the congregation) isn't either Jewish and not saying Birchas Kohanim isn't one of the 7 noahide commandments

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

B"H

The reason why the Kohanim are in doubt nowadays is because there are no exclusive mitzvos duraysa that are practiced only by Kohanim and not by anyone else (according to the Rambam, getting called up to the Torah first or doing birkas kohanim Lane included in that. There's no specific prohibition for other Jews to do that, it's just not their obligation)

Therefore if one can trace one's paternal lineage to a Kohen that servd in the Beis Hamikdash, that's a definite status verification, because the Sanhedrin would not allow anyone who wasn't able to trace their lineage at that time back to Aharon to serve in the Beis Hamikdash (Rambam).

Similarly, prior to a couple hundred years ago or so, there was no such thing as a "reform" or an "invalid" conversion, and therefore there was never a doubt as to who was Jewish and who wasn't.

If one finds a kesuba, for example, between one's maternal ancestors, that's a definite verification, because the Sofer that wrote it definitely wouldn't have done so unless he had other ways of verifying they were Jewish.

It's assumed that either of one's parents at a certain time kept the laws of the Torah, then either they have an unbroken maternal lineage to the original Jews at Mount Sinai, or am unbroken maternal lineage at least to a convert, and all converts (until recently) were completely Jewish

Source for this idea:

The law of a questionable Jew: If one is unsure if his mother is Jewish, then he is considered a gentile, until proof is found of his mother’s Jewish identity.[8] [Thus, there is no such concept as a questionable Jew, if he has question as to whether his mother was Jewish, as one is considered a gentile until he determines that his mother is Jewish.] However, the concept of a questionable Jew does apply in a case that a person claims to be Jewish [either due to having a Jewish mother, or due to conversion] but his claim contains suspicion, or requires Halachic proof according to the Poskim. Below we will discuss when we believe a person’s claim of being Jewish and when we require proof of his claim.

Marrying a Jew: If a person who was known to be a gentile, claims that he went through a Kosher conversion and became Jewish, he is not believed to be allowed to marry a Jew unless he supplies witnesses [or other proof of his conversion], or reconverts. This applies even if this person now acts like an observant Jew. If, however, the person was always held to be Jewish, and now says that in truth he converted, then he is believed without witnesses.[17] Now, although some Poskim[18] argue that even such a person must bring witnesses, nevertheless, the custom is like the former opinion.[19] [In Israel, the Rabbanut requires all foreigners to prove their Jewish identity and provide authorized conversion papers, in order to be allowed to marry, or make Aliyah.]

Other matters, such as Tefillin:[20] The above requirement for a gentile to bring proof of his conversion even if he is now an observant Jew, only applies with regards to allowing him to marry a Jew. However, regarding all other matters of Judaism [such as Tefillin, Minyan etc], if he acts as an observant Jew he is believed to have converted even if he does not bring proof of his conversion.[21]

How to verify the claims of a person who says that his mother is Jewish:[22]

As explained in B, the custom today is to require proof of Jewishness for people who come from out of the country, from areas where assimilation was common, and in any case that there is reasonable doubt. The Batei Dinim have several ways of verifying a person’s claim of Jewishness. Some Poskim[23] suggest the following criteria:

Checking the legal identification cards of the person or his mother, and seeing if it says that he or she is Jewish. Verifying the Jewish names of the person and his family. Knowledge of Yiddish, and acting like a Jew or knowledge of Jewish customs. The person in question must fulfill at least two of the above three conditions to be considered a Jew, and there must not be any other reason to cast doubt on his Jewishness.[24] In today’s times, one also heavily relies on the opinion of an investigator who is trained and experienced in verifying whether the person’s claim is true or not. [So is done today in all Batei Dinim].

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

Your question is an important one and I'd answer it in a few different ways.

  1. I would hold Kohanim to a separate standard from the rest of the Jewish community. Due to the importance of that line, the Kohanim end up encompasses a very protected population bubble. There have even been studies which show Kohanim carry a very unique DNA type which is even separate from the wider common Jewish community genetic subtype. This implies we managed to maintain the purity of the Kohanim line even if we don't have a direct link or evidence back to Aaron, himself.
  2. While "in theory" you could make the argument that every Jewish line going back far enough could be invalid, the fact is we have evidence to the contrary. For example, the DNA answer I gave previously also applies to Judaism as a whole. The Jewish people, regardless of their sub-community or location, all generally share the same common ancestral lineage back to Israel. This fact implies that we've maintained the integrity of the Jewish community even in exile.

While DNA is not used in Jewish law when it comes to determining Jewishness, this information is important in that it helps substantiate religious claims. It's not binding under Jewish law but it provides context which validates a claim made in Judaism.

As far as the core of the question. Unless we have a reason to suspect a person's family line isn't valid, we don't go about searching for it. People have the chazakah (the presumption) if a status unless evidence is shown to the contrary.

If it turns out a Jew may have doubts about their status and are concerned about it, a Jew can perform something called a giyur l’chumra (a conversion out of stringency) which is when a Jew wants to cover their bases and ensure their status if they for some reason have conflicting information about their family line.

title: Can one take advantage of a listing mistake on Amazon?
content:
# Can one take advantage of a listing mistake on Amazon? ## Frage

If someone bought soap on Amazon fresh, that stated in the description "pack of 4". When the item was delivered, it was a pack of 1. He then called Amazon and got a full refund, and they told him to keep the soap.

If he then tells his friend what happened, can the friend do the same thing and place the order and get refunded, as there is a mistake in the listing and description of the item?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Please ask your LOR for the Psak:

The Rema in Choshen Mishpat 348:2 says:

״טעות עכו"ם כגון להטעותו בחשבון או •להפקיע הלואתו מותר ובלבד שלא יודע לו דליכא חילול השם (טור ס"ג) וי"א דדאסור להטעותו האלא אם טעה מעצמו שרי (מרדכי פרק הגוזל בתרא):״

"A gentile’s mistake, for example to mistake in counting or repaying his loans, is permitted, and provided that he doesn’t know, so that there is no chilul Hashem. And there are those who say that it is forbidden to mislead him except if he makes the mistake from his own, and then it’s allowed."

From the Rema (in the first opinion) we see that טעות עכו״ם works only when the non Jew doesn't realize the mistake (and then there would still be a discussion with regards to their being a chilul Hashem or not), however in this case because Amazon is aware of the mistake, if his friend and others were to do it, Amazon would for sure catch on and it would be a big chilul Hashem to see people trying to benefit from their mistake.

Let us not forget the Sefer Chasidim Siman 974 cited by the Beer Hagolah Choshen Mishpat 348:5:

"Many who sanctified Hashem's name and returned mistakes made by non-Jews in significant matters became great and wealthy and successful and left their riches to their children.”

In conclusion: Therefore, I think that both halachically and morally, one is not allowed to buy the soap in this case.

title: How did Rambam envision the reemergence of Davidic monarchy?
content:
# How did Rambam envision the reemergence of Davidic monarchy? ## Frage

Following my last question, "when-does-jewish-democracy-turn-into-monarchy",

IIRC, Rambam traveled to the Land of Israel in 1165. He visited Acre, Jerusalem, where he prayed on the Temple Mount, and Hebron, where he visited the Cave of Machpelah. He was somewhat displeased with the affairs in the Holy Land, and, after his time in Israel, he and his family moved to Egypt, settling in Alexandria and later Cairo.
