As a pragmatic philosopher who didn't rely on miracles (at least regarding the Messianic process), how did he envision the transition from 12th-century Palestine to the kingdom of the Messiah?

title: Can someone please translate this small section by Arnold Ehrlich?
content:
# Can someone please translate this small section by Arnold Ehrlich? ## Frage

Arnold Ehrlich (1848-1919) was a brilliant scholar of the Bible and rabbinic literature. He is best known for his Bible commentary book called Mikra Kiphshuto, “The Bible according to its Literal Meaning.” I have here three screenshots from his book Die psalmen; neu uebersetzt und erklaert, "The Psalms; newly translated and explained." Could someone, please, translate this small section by Arnold Ehrlich (both the Hebrew and German)?

PS please do not rely on AI. I prefer an actual human translating the text. Its more authentic and true to the text. Thank you.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

Note: Much of Arnold Ehrlich's perspective is non-traditional and follows prevailing views of the secular academia of his era, as can be seen, for instance in the translated Endnote 24 at the bottom of this post.

Psalm 19, Verses 1—7

The German text of Ehrlich's 'Die Psalmen' (Psalms 19, 1—7) reads:

38 Ps. 19, 1—7.

19.

1 *Ein Psalm David

2 Der Himmel erzählt die Herrlichkeit Gottes, und von seiner Hände Werk zeugt sein Gewölbe.

3 Ein Tag lallt dem andern die Botschaft, und eine Nacht offenbart der andern die Kunde.

4 Es gibt keine Sache und kein Ding, darüber ihre Stimme sich nicht hören liesse.

5 In alle Welt dringt ihre Stimme, und bis an's Ende des Erdkreises ihre Worte — Hat er doch dem Sonnenball an ihm sein Zehlt angewiesen,

6 und der verlässt wie ein Bräutigam seine Kammer, freut sich wie ein Held, die Bahn zu durchlaufen.

7 Von einem Ende des Himmels geht er aus und gelangt in seinem Umlauf bis zum andern; und ihm ist es zu danken, dass nichts verborgen bleibt. —

This translates to:

  1. *A Psalm of David

  2. Heaven tells the glory of God, and his canopy testifies to the work of his hands.

  3. One day babbles the message to another, and one night reveals the tidings to another.

  4. There is no matter and no object concerning which their voice would not let itself be heard.

  5. Their voice reaches throughout all the world, and their words to the ends of the globe. He has indeed assigned the orb of the sun its tent upon it.

  6. And he departs like a bridegroom from his chamber, rejoices like a mighty man to run the course.

  7. From one end of the heavens he goes forth, and in his circuit arrives at the other end; and it is thanks to him that nothing remains hidden. —

Footnote immediately below the main text

There is a note at the bottom of the page. It is merely the continuation of a footnote on the end of Psalm 18.a

Footnotes on 19:3—7

The next two images contain footnotes on Psalm 19, verses 3 through 7. Here is the footnote to verse 3:

3 נִבַּע hat mit נבא nichts gebein, sondern ist seiner Form nach ein intensives נָבַע und heisst zunächts stossweise sprudeln, dann kunstlos Worte ausstossen. Die kunstlosigkeit der Worte kann beabsichtigt sein oder von Nachlässigkeit oder endlich von Unfähigkeit herrühren.23)

Translation (my inline comments appear in brackets):

3 נִבַּע has nothing in common with נבא [prophecy], but is, in form, an intensive נָבַע and means, first, to bubble up in spurts, then to expel words artlessly. The artlessness of the words may be intentional, or may stem from carelessness, or finally from incompetence.23)

Footnote to verse 4:

4 אמר ist, wie arab. أمر = Sache, Angelegenheit.24) Für דברים בלי lies דָּבָר מִבְּלִי. Im zweiten Versglied ist, wie öfter in der Poesie, die Rückbeziehung auf das logische Subjekt (مبتدأ) unterlassen. Auch LXX scheint diese Worte so verstanden zu haben.

Translation:

4 אמר is like the Arabic أمر ['amr] = matter, affair.24) For דברים בלי read דָּבָר מִבְּלִי.b In the second verse, as is often the case in poetry, the reference to the logical subject (مبتدأ [mubtada']) is omitted. The LXX also seems to have understood these words in this way.c

Footnote to verse 5:

5 קום ist offenbar für קוֹלָם verschrieben. Auch sonst ist der überlieferte Text vielleicht nicht ganz in Ordnung. Der Vers ist überladen, und das dritte Glied schleppt hinkend nach. In Ermangelung einer besseren Aushilfe muss man das letzte Glied mit dem folgenden verbinden.

Translation:

5 קום is evidently written in error in place of קוֹלָם. Also in other respects, the Masoretic text is perhaps not entirely in order. The verse is overloaded, and the third clause drags limping afterwards. In the absence of a better substitute, one must connect the last clause to the following verse.

Despite Erlich's comment here, the classical commentators explain קַוָּם ("their line") as referring to the comprehensive coverage of the heavens over the earth that causes their message of praise of the Almighty to spread throughout the world. Rashi explains this as referring to the line that the heavens traverse from one side of the sky to the other, and Radak understands it as a metonym for the structure of the heavens, the metonym deriving from the fact that plumb lines (which is the meaning of קו in multiple verses, such as II M'lachim 21:13, see Rashi ad loc.) are essential in building structures.d

Additionally, the introduction of a new topic (the sun) at the end of verse 5 (and continuing into the following verse) is not atypical in Tanach, and it is not clear why this provoked Erlich's concern.

Footnote to verse 6:

6 Nach Kimchi wäre der Sonnenball mit einem aus der Brautkammer kommenden Bräutigam verglichen, weil er wie dieser sicherlich zum Ausgangspunkt zurückkehrt. Danach ware der zweite Vergleich hinzugefugt, um zu sagen, dass, bei aller Liebe fur das Zelt, der Weg, der zeitweilig davon trennt, dennog freudig unternommen wird.

Translation:

6 According to Kimchi [the Radak citing his father R' Yosef Kimchi], the sun's orb would be compared to a bridegroom coming forth from the bridal chamber because it, like the him, surely returns to its starting point. Then, the second comparison would be added in order to say that, with all the love for the tent, the path that temporarily separates him from it is nevertheless joyfully undertaken.

Footnote to verse 7:

7 Für מֵחַמָּתוֹ lies מֵחֲמָתוֹ = ejus impetu, d.h. dank ihm oder durch ihn. Das Wort findet sich in diesem Sinne in der Mischna sehr oft, z.B. Baba kamma 8,1. Der Sinn ist also der: der Sonne und ihrem Umlaufe ist es zu verdanken, dass überall Licht ist und nichts im Dunkeln bleibt. Die traditionelle Erklärung scheitert schon daran, das die Hitze eine Plage ist, der Sonnenball aber hier mit einem glücklichen Bräutigam, der, weit entfernt, irgend jemandem ein Leid zuzufügen, jeden freundlich anlächelt. Dazu kommt noch, das Hitze חֹם nicht חַמָּה heisst. Den das poetische חמה = Sonne, welches stets mit לבנה und nie mit ירח gepaart wird, mit Hitze nichts zu tun hat, sondern eigentlich die Dunkle heisst, wie לבנה die Weisse bedeutet. So gefasst, vermittelt auch das dritte Glied gewissermassen den Uebergang zu dem Folgenden, welches sonst ausser allem Zusammenhang ist.

Translation:

7 For מֵחַמָּתוֹ, read מֵחֲמָתוֹ = ejus impetu [his impetus], i.e., "thanks to him" or "through him". The word is found in this sense very often in the Mishnah, e.g., Baba Kamma 8:1. So the meaning is this: thanks to the sun and its orbit, there is light everywhere and nothing remains in darkness. The traditional interpretation fails on the grounds that heat is a plague, whereas here the sun's orb is depicted as a happy bridegroom who, far from intending to harm anyone, smiles kindly at everyone. Furthermore, the word חֹם is not called חַמָּה. The poetic חמה = sun, which is always paired with לבנה and never with ירח, has nothing to do with heat, but rather means the dark one, just as לבנה means the white one. Understood in this way, the third clause also provides, in a sense, the transition to what follows, which otherwise stands out of all context.

Ehrlich's analysis is dubious for multiple reasons:

  1. The sense of "מחמת" meaning "on account of" is first attested in Mishnaic Hebrew.

  2. Heat is not necessarily a plague, and there are multiple verses describing heat in a positive way (e.g., I M'lachim 1:2 and Koheles 4:11. As such, the beneficially warm sun fits the context of the passage. Incidentally, when spelled חַמָּה, the word refers to the sun and related properties (especially warmth), and negative words that mean fury or venom are spelled differently (the letters are the same, as they are for Ehrlich's proposed מֵחֲמָתוֹ, but those words lack the dagesh forte and have different vowelization).

  3. The traditional pairing of חמה with לבנה does not imply that חמה is etymologically derived from its color, and it seems odd that it would be described as "the dark one" considering its characteristic brightness. Indeed, the appellation "חַמָּה" is used for the sun in conjunction with its ability to shine light and dispel darkness (e.g., Iyov 30:28, "קֹדֵר הִלַּכְתִּי בְּלֹא חַמָּה").

aThe continuation of the footnote reads: "...Ortsname ist. Diese Worte bilden das im vorherg. Verse versprochene Lob oder vielmehr eine Probe davon." "Ortsname ist" translates to, "It is a place name" (referring to the word מַגְדִּל). The rest of the note characterizes Psalm 18:51 as the Psalmist fulfilling (in part) the declaration made in verse 18:50 that he would thank and praise the Almighty: "Diese Worte bilden das im vorherg. Verse versprochene Lob oder vielmehr eine Probe davon." This translates to: "These words form the praise promised in the preceding verse, or rather a sample thereof."

bI.e., Ehrlich adds a mem to clarify that he interprets the end of the verse as a concessive such that the heavens' voice is heard rather than unheard

c"οὐκ εἰσὶν λαλιαὶ οὐδὲ λόγοι ὧν οὐχὶ ἀκούονται αἱ φωναὶ αὐτῶν," meaning, "There are no words or speeches whose voices are not heard"

dEven some non-Jewish translators, such as Adam Clarke, who prefer the alternate reading “their voice” based on LXX's φωνή, have acknowledged the sufficiency of the Masoretic reading, pointing to the sound a line/cord could emit or a possible Arabic cognate of קו that connects the term with sound or outcry

Endnote 23 English translation: "Regarding 19:3. An example of intentional artlessness in speech is found in אביעה לכם רוחי (Proverbs 1:23). But before this can be demonstrated, it must first be noted that the first verse there does not read, 'Turn to my rebuke,' as it is generally rendered, for תשובו is not an imperative, nor does שוב mean to turn to something. תשובו לתוכחתי means, 'You will still return to my rebuke,' i.e., you will still remember it and the one from whom it comes. This is said with reference to the day of trouble, when, according to verse 28, the fools are supposed to call on wisdom, but only to be ignored by her. According to this, אביעה לכם רוחי means, 'I will tell you my intention, i.e., what I intend for you, bluntly.' A more striking example is the artless speech resulting from carelessness. This can be found in Proverbs 15:2, which correctly translates as follows: 'The tongue of the wise man clothes good sense beautifully, but the mouth of the fool utters bare folly.' That is, the wise man strives to present good sense beautifully, but the fool speaks his folly as his beak suggests, and never considers it worthwhile to make up for what his speech lacks in content with form. On תיטיב, see 2 Kings 9:30. Kautzsch, who, following Dysernick, changes תיטיב to תַטִּיף and renders יַבִּיעַ as 'bubbles,' parodies the beautiful saying by depriving it of the punch line without which no saying deserves the name. Furthermore, the Old Testament speaks of dripping lips, but never of a dripping tongue, and in this image, the dripped thing is always honeycomb, which can actually be dripped, but not something like דעת, however that may be understood."

Endnote 24 English translation: "Regarding 19:4. Let us remember once and for all that a large, if not the majority, of the Psalms were written a full six hundred years after Amos, Hosea, and Isaiah, and that a living language, in its development over such a long period of time, must undergo many changes and receive many additions. Therefore, one must be prepared from the outset to find many entirely new words in the Psalter, and many of the old ones used differently than in the writings of the prophets, whose language is closest to poetry. If one considers this, one will find much in our explanations understandable that may seem strange at first glance."

title: Is this lenient opinion of Rav Hai Gaon regarding tefach b'isha erva cited by the poskim?
content:
# Is this lenient opinion of Rav Hai Gaon regarding tefach b'isha erva cited by the poskim? ## Frage

Rav Hai Gaon permits (mentioned by Talmidei Rabbeinu Yonah on the Rif in Berachos 17a) a person to say holy words when seeing an immodestly dressed woman so long as one doesn't intentionally gaze at her.

Do any authoritative poskim mention this opinion and if they do are there any that adopt it l'halacha?

In today's day and age it would go a long way . .

Here is the relevant text:

עֶרְוָה בְּעַשָּׁשִׁית — אָסוּר לִקְרוֹא קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע כְּנֶגְדָּה. וְכָתַב רַבֵּנוּ הַאי גָּאוֹן זִצ"ל, דְּהוּא הַדִּין לְכָל אִשָּׁה שֶׁמְּגַלָּה טֶפַח בְּמָקוֹם מְכֻסֶּה שֶׁבָּהּ — שֶׁאָסוּר לִקְרוֹא כְּנֶגְדָּה, דְּטֶפַח בְּאִשָּׁה עֶרְוָה. וְכֵן אֵין לוֹ לִקְרוֹת בִּשְׁעָה שֶׁמְּנַגֶּנֶת, דְּקוֹל בְּאִשָּׁה עֶרְוָה. אֲבָל כְּנֶגֶד פָּנֶיהָ, אוֹ כְּנֶגֶד מָקוֹם שֶׁאֵין דֶּרֶךְ לְכַסּוֹתוֹ, אוֹ בִּשְׁעָה שֶׁהִיא מְדַבֶּרֶת כְּדַרְכָּהּ — מֻתָּר. וַאֲפִילוּ בִּשְׁעָה שֶׁהִיא מְנַגֶּנֶת, אִם הוּא יָכוֹל לְכַוֵּן בְּלִבּוֹ לִתְפִלָּתוֹ, בְּעִנְיָן שֶׁאֵינוֹ שׁוֹמֵעַ אוֹתָהּ וְאֵינוֹ שָׂם לִבּוֹ אֵלֶיהָ — מֻתָּר, וְאֵין לוֹ לְהַפְסִיק קְרִיאָתוֹ. וְכֵן כְּשֶׁמְּגֻלֶּה טֶפַח — אֵינוֹ אָסוּר אֶלָּא כְּשֶׁמִּסְתַּכֵּל בָּהּ, אֲבָל בִּרְאִיָּה בְּעַלְמָא — מֻתָּר.

A nakedness [i.e., an area of ervah] behind a glass pane—one may not recite the Shema facing it. And our teacher Rav Hai Gaon, of blessed memory, wrote that the same applies to any woman who exposes a handbreadth in a normally-covered area of her body: it is prohibited to recite [the Shema] facing her, for “a handbreadth in a woman is [considered] nakedness (ervah).” Similarly, one may not recite [the Shema] while she is singing, for “a woman’s voice is ervah.” However, [reciting] opposite her face, or opposite a place that is not typically covered, or when she is speaking in her usual manner—is permitted. And even when she is singing, if he is able to focus his heart on his prayer in such a way that he does not hear her and does not pay attention to her, it is permitted, and he should not interrupt his recitation. Likewise, when a handbreadth is exposed, the prohibition applies only when one gazes at it; but seeing it incidentally (i.e., without gazing) is permitted.

(Similarly, notice his allowance when hearing a woman's singing voice if one is able to tune it out.)

title: Can Moshiach come on Erev Shabbos?
content:
# Can Moshiach come on Erev Shabbos? ## Frage

I heard in a shiur that, even though the Gemara says that normally Moshiach can’t come on Erev Shabbos, in our times the poskim say that since it is Pikuach Nefesh (life and death), he can come on any day, even Erev Shabbos.

Can you provide a source for this?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

B"H

Rambam in "Laws of Teshuva" says that at the end of the exile, when the people of Yisroel do Teshuva, "Immediately they will be redeemed".

If there was a specific time limit on when he could come, the Rambam would have specified it

However, in Hilchos Nezirus the Rambam cites a halacha that if one makes a nazirite vow on the condition that Moshiach will come on that day, if that day is a weekday, it's valid, but if that day is shabbos, it doesn't take effect, because there's a doubt whether or not moshiach will come on shabbos, since he will need to descend from the heavens to the earth, which is traveling outside of the Techum (according to some opinions):

  1. The following rules apply when a person takes a vow, saying: “I will be a nazirite on the day when the son of David comes.” If he took the vow during the week, he is forbidden to perform any act that violates the nazirite prohibitions forever. If he took the vow on the Sabbath or a festival, he is permitted on that Sabbath or festival. Afterwards, he is forbidden forever. The rationale is that there is a doubt concerning the question whether the son of David will come on a Sabbath or festival or not. Since the matter is an unresolved question, on the day he took the nazirite vow, the nazirite restrictions do not apply to him. For whenever there is a question whether the nazirite restrictions apply, we rule leniently.
    הָאוֹמֵר 'הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר בְּיוֹם שֶׁבֶּן דָּוִיד בָּא בּוֹ': אִם בַּחֹל נָדַר - הֲרֵי זֶה אָסוּר לְעוֹלָם; וְאִם בַּשַּׁבָּת אוֹ בְּיוֹם טוֹב נָדַר - אוֹתָהּ שַׁבָּת אוֹ אוֹתוֹ יוֹם טוֹב מֻתָּר, מִכָּאן וְאֵלֵּךְ אָסוּר לְעוֹלָם. שֶׁהַדָּבָר סָפֵק אִם יָבוֹא בַּשַּׁבָּת וְיוֹם טוֹב אוֹ לֹא יָבוֹא, וְהוֹאִיל וְהוּא סָפֵק, בְּיוֹם שֶׁנָּדַר
  • לֹא חָלָה עָלָיו נְזִירוּת, שֶׁסָּפֵק נְזִירוּת לְהָקֵל. מִכָּאן וְאֵלֵּךְ חָלָה עָלָיו נְזִירוּת.

Note 26 elaborates:

The Rambam’s ruling is based on Eruvin 43b. The Kessef Mishneh interprets the Rambam’s understanding of that passage as follows: There is a question whether the prohibition against going beyond one’s Sabbath boundaries (see Hilchot Shabbat, ch. 27) applies ten handbreadths above the ground or not. Thus there is a question whether Mashiach - who obviously will observe the Sabbath laws - can come on the Sabbath for that will require him descending from heaven and thus going beyond his Sabbath boundaries. (Kin’at Eliyahu questions the entire issue, noting that according to the Rambam, Mashiach will be a flesh and blood human being who will “wage the wars of G‑d... build the Temple” (see Hilchot Melachim 11:1). Nowhere does the Rambam make mention of him descending from heaven.)

So, at least according to some opinions, he can't come on the Shabbos itself. But nowhere is it mentioned that he can't come on Friday - if that were the case, then that would contradict the halacha here, which says that if one made the vow on Friday (which is during the week), it would be effective.

If one were to ask, however, whether or not Moshiach will come on shabbos according to all opinions, because this generation is different than the generations of the Rambam and the Gemara, which would require it to be violated, that would be a different question.

The implication of that question is that nothing that existed in the times of the Gemara or the Rambam, including the nusach of our tefillos (which were composed by the men of the Great Assembly),

"speedily send the scion of David" (moshiach),

And the bracha to get rid of the heretics and the evil kingdoms of exile (which was composed during the time of the Gemara),

and the fact that the Rambam says in the end of the laws of kings that one should "deeply hope" (מחכה) for him all the time, and the fact that

"all of the wise people of Yisroel have hoped for the days of moshiach.. to be free from the kingdoms that don't allow them to engage in the Torah and it's commandments properly",

And the fact that the Jewish people even in their times were being scattered all of the world and oppressed (which is why they were forced to write down the Talmud, even though they weren't supposed to, because of the great and pressing needs of the time),

And the Roman oppression and the crusades and many many other oppressions of the entire Jewish people since the destruction of the second Beis Hamikdash until the time of the Rambam,

All of that wouldn't apply, since the opinion that said he can't come on shabbos also knew about all of those things, but still said it.

It's a bit of a dochak to say that nowadays moshiach arriving is such a life threatening emergency, requiring the violation of shabbos, more so than millions of Jews literally being attacked and driven from their homes constantly etc. in the times of the Gemara/Rambam...

### Antwort 2 (Score: 3)

The gemara (in Eruvin 43b) says explicitly that although one might think that Mashiach will not come on Erev Shabbat/Yom Tov, that is not the case, and in fact it can happen on Erev Shabbat/Yom Tov.

קָא סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ מִדְּאֵלִיָּהוּ לָא אֲתָא, מָשִׁיחַ נָמֵי לָא אָתֵי, בְּמַעֲלֵי שַׁבְּתָא לִישְׁתְּרֵי! אֵלִיָּהוּ לָא אָתֵי, מָשִׁיחַ אָתֵי.

title: Best Iyun Shiurim in the world
content:
# Best Iyun Shiurim in the world ## Frage

I recognize that "best" is a very subjective term, plus, what one person thinks is the "best", is probably due to their extremely limited perspective of Iyun Shiurim. My definition of "best" is gauged by the Maggid shiur's ability to cut away all the extraneous fancy svaros and whatnot and get to the intent of the author. I am someone who believes that just because something "can be" true in the Rambam, does not automatically make it true, and a shiur that is just trying to be fancy and not trying to understand what the author meant is not worth listening to. The gauge used for the veracity of a svara (and quality of a shiur) is if it is "מוכרח", meaning that the svara MUST be the intent of the author, either because the author says so in other place, or because the other options don't make sense. So far, I have found Rabbi Tzvi Berkowitz and certain shiurim coming out of the Beis Medrash of כסא רחמים, which follows the דרך הלימד of הרב מאיר מאזוז, who wrote a sefer on דרכי העיון. Anyone have any other suggestions? So far I have tried out a bunch of shiurim YuTorah although not Rabbi Werblowsky's shiur, which I hear is quite good.

title: Why didn't Hashem forgive Adam and Chava? Problem with Teshuva?
content:
# Why didn't Hashem forgive Adam and Chava? Problem with Teshuva? ## Frage

Why didn't Hashem forgive Adam and Chava? Was it because they did not do teshuva? Was their teshuva incomplete or inconvincing? Or maybe teshuva was not an option and they had to be punished? Maybe they did teshuva, but only death could expiate their sin?

The whole situation looks tricky, since Hashem planted both trees in the middle of the garden: It looks like a trap.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

A. In Bamidbar Rabah 13:3 it says that Adam Harishon did not do teshuvah/nor wanted to when asked to by Hashem:

״בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁעָבַר אָדָם עַל צִוּוּיוֹ שֶׁל הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא וְאָכַל מִן הָאִילָן, בִּקֵּשׁ הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא שֶׁיַּעֲשֶׂה תְּשׁוּבָה וּפָתַח לוֹ פֶּתַח, וְלֹא בִּקֵּשׁ אָדָם, הֲדָא הוּא דִכְתִיב (בראשית ג, כב): וַיֹּאמֶר אֱלֹהִים הֵן הָאָדָם וגו'. אָמַר רַבִּי אַבָּא בַּר כַּהֲנָא מַהוּ וְעַתָּה, אֶלָּא שֶׁאָמַר לוֹ הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא אֲפִלּוּ עַכְשָׁו עֲשֵׂה תְּשׁוּבָה וַאֲנִי מְקַבְּלָךְ, וְאָמַר אָדָם אִי אֶפְשִׁי. הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא אָמַר וְעַתָּה, וְאָמַר אָדָם פֶּן, אִי אֶפְשִׁי. אָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן לָקִישׁ כֵּיוָן שֶׁיָּצָא אָדָם מִן הַדִּין הִתְחִיל מְחָרֵף וּמְגַדֵּף, נֶאֱמַר כָּאן כְּרֻבִים, (בראשית ג, כד): וַיַּשְׁכֵּן מִקֶּדֶם לְגַן עֵדֶן אֶת הַכְּרֻבִים, וְנֶאֱמַר בְּסַנְחֵרִיב כְּרֻבִים, (ישעיה לז, טז): ה' צְבָאוֹת יוֹשֵׁב הַכְּרֻבִים, מַה לְּהַלָּן חֵרוּפִים וְגִדוּפִים, אַף כְּרֻבִים שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר כָּאן חֵרוּפִים וְגִדוּפִים, הֱוֵי גַּאֲוַת אָדָם תַּשְׁפִּילֶנּוּ, לְפִי שֶׁנִּתְגָּאָה עַל הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא מֵעֲשׂוֹת תְּשׁוּבָה הִשְׁפִּיל אוֹתוֹ וְגֵרְשׁוֹ מִגַּן עֵדֶן.״

"When he violated the command of the Holy One blessed be He and ate from the tree, the Holy One blessed be He sought to have him repent, and He provided him with an opening. Adam did not seek to do so. That is what is written: “The Lord God said: Behold, the man [has become as one of us, to know good and evil, and now, lest] [pen]…” (Genesis 3:22). Rabbi Abba bar Kahana said: What is “and now”? It is, rather, that the Holy One blessed be He said to him: ‘Even now, repent and I will accept you.’ Adam said: ‘I do not wish to do so.’ The Holy One blessed be He said: “And now,” and Adam said: ‘pen, I do not wish to do so.’ Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: When Adam emerged from judgment, he began cursing and blaspheming. “Cherubs” is stated here: “He stationed the cherubs east of the Garden of Eden” (Genesis 3:24), and “cherubs” is stated by Sennacherib: “Lord of hosts, God of Israel, who abides over the cherubs” (Isaiah 37:16). Just as there, cursing and blaspheming, so, too, here, cursing and blaspheming. That is, “a man’s pride will humble him.” Because he was too haughty vis-à-vis the Holy One blessed be He to repent, He humbled him and banished him from the Garden of Eden."

However, we then find the complete opposite, that Adam Harishon wanted and did do teshuvah:

Beresheit Rabah 22:13 says:

״וַיֵּצֵא קַיִן מִלִּפְנֵי ה' (בראשית ד, טז), מֵהֵיכָן יָצָא, רַבִּי יוּדָן בְּשֵׁם רַבִּי אַיְבוּ אָמַר הִפְשִׁיל דְּבָרִים לַאֲחוֹרָיו וְיָצָא, כְּגוֹנֵב דַּעַת הָעֶלְיוֹנָה. רַבִּי בֶּרֶכְיָה בְּשֵׁם רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אָמַר, יָצָא כְּמַפְרִיס וְכִמְרַמֶּה בְּבוֹרְאוֹ. רַבִּי חָמָא בְּשֵׁם רַבִּי חֲנִינָא בַּר רַבִּי יִצְחָק אָמַר, יָצָא שָׂמֵחַ, הֵיךְ מָה דְאַתְּ אָמַר (שמות ד, יד): הִנֵּה הוּא יֹצֵא לִקְרָאתֶךָ וגו', פָּגַע בּוֹ אָדָם הָרִאשׁוֹן אָמַר לוֹ מַה נַּעֲשָׂה בְּדִינְךָ, אָמַר לוֹ עָשִׂיתִי תְּשׁוּבָה וְנִתְפַּשַּׁרְתִּי. הִתְחִיל אָדָם הָרִאשׁוֹן מְטַפֵּחַ עַל פָּנָיו, אָמַר, כָּךְ הִיא כֹּחָהּ שֶׁל תְּשׁוּבָה וַאֲנִי לֹא הָיִיתִי יוֹדֵעַ, מִיָּד עָמַד אָדָם הָרִאשׁוֹן וְאָמַר (תהלים צב, א): מִזְמוֹר שִׁיר לְיוֹם הַשַּׁבָּת וגו'. אָמַר רַבִּי לֵוִי הַמִּזְמוֹר הַזֶּה אָדָם הָרִאשׁוֹן אֲמָרוֹ וְנִשְׁתַּכַּח מִדּוֹרוֹ וּבָא משֶׁה וְחִדְּשׁוֹ עַל שְׁמוֹ, מִזְמוֹר שִׁיר לְיוֹם הַשַּׁבָּת טוֹב לְהוֹדוֹת לַה' וגו'.״

“Cain departed [vayetze] from the presence of the Lord, and lived in the land of Nod, east of Eden” (Genesis 4:16). “Cain departed from the presence of the Lord” – from where did he depart? Rabbi Yudan said in the name of Rabbi Aivu: He cast the words behind him and departed, as though deceiving the Most High. Rabbi Berekhya said in the name of Rabbi Elazar ben Rabbi Shimon: He departed as one who shows a split hoof, and as one who deceives his Creator. Rabbi Ḥama said in the name of Rabbi Ḥanina bar Rabbi Yitzḥak: He departed joyfully, just as it says: “Here he is going out [yotze] to meet you [and he will see you and he will rejoice in his heart]” (Exodus 4:14). Adam the first man encountered him. He said to him: ‘What became of your sentence?’ He said to him: ‘I repented and reached a settlement.’ Adam the first man began beating himself on the face, saying: ‘Such is the power of repentance, and I did not know.’ Immediately, Adam the first man stood and said: “A psalm, a song for the Shabbat day…” (Psalms 92:1). Rabbi Levi said: Adam the first man said this Psalm, but it was forgotten from his generation, and Moses came and reintroduced it in his own name: “A psalm, a song for the Shabbat day. It is good to give thanks [lehodot] to the Lord…” (Psalms 92:1–2)."

1. The Eitz Yosef ד״ה לא הייתי יודע says that from Eruvin 18b we see that Adam Harishon did teshuvah for eating from the Eitz Hadaar for 130 years after understanding the power of teshuvah from Kain. He fasted 130 years, seperated from his wife, and wore belt figs leaves.

2. The Radal in Pirkei Derebbi Eliezer Chapter 19 ד״ה שנאמר טוב להודות לה says that when Adam Harishon admitted to his sin of the eitz hadaat he was saved מדינה של גהינם and then sung to Hashem.

3. Gemera in Avodah Zara 8a says the following:

״תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: יוֹם שֶׁנִּבְרָא בּוֹ אָדָם הָרִאשׁוֹן, כֵּיוָן שֶׁשָּׁקְעָה עָלָיו חַמָּה, אָמַר: אוֹי לִי, שֶׁבִּשְׁבִיל שֶׁסָּרַחְתִּי עוֹלָם חָשׁוּךְ בַּעֲדִי, וְיַחְזוֹר עוֹלָם לְתוֹהוּ וָבוֹהוּ, וְזוֹ הִיא מִיתָה שֶׁנִּקְנְסָה עָלַי מִן הַשָּׁמַיִם. הָיָה יוֹשֵׁב בְּתַעֲנִית וּבוֹכֶה כׇּל הַלַּיְלָה, וְחַוָּה בּוֹכָה כְּנֶגְדּוֹ.״

"On the day that Adam the first man was created, when the sun set upon him he said: Woe is me, as because I sinned, the world is becoming dark around me, and the world will return to the primordial state of chaos and disorder. And this is the death that was sentenced upon me from Heaven. He spent all night fasting and crying, and Eve was crying opposite him."

Although the sun was setting because nighttime was coming, Adam and Chava did not know this and started doing teshuvah for the sin of the eitz hadaat they did, even though the setting of the sun had nothing to do with their sin, but nonetheless it can be considered teshuvah.

Answer to the contradiction: The Eitz Yosef in Bamidbar Rabah 13:3 ד״ה אי אפשי answers that the Midrash in Beresheit Rabah, etc are discussing teshuvah he did after not wanting to do teshuvah when asked to by Hashem.

B. Did Hashem forgive Adam for this teshuvah, and why yes or no?

In Pirkei Derebbi Eliezer 20:9, it says:

״אמר אדם לפני הקב"ה רבון כל העולמים העבר נא חטאתי מעלי וקבל את תשובתי וילמדו כל הדורות שיש תשובה ואתה מקבל תשובת השבים. מה עשה הקב"ה פשט יד ימינו והעביר את חטאתו מעליו וקבל את תשובתו שנאמ' חטאתי אודיעך ועוני לא כסיתי סלה מן העולם הזה וסלה מן העולם הבא.״

"Adam said before the Holy One, blessed be He: Sovereign of all worlds ! Remove, I pray Thee, my sins from me and accept my repentance, and all the generations will learn that repentance is a reality. What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? He put forth His right hand, and accepted his repentance, and took away from him his sin, as it is said, "I acknowledge my sin unto thee, and mine iniquity have I not hid: I said, I will confess my transgressions unto the Lord; and thou forgavest the iniquity of my sin. Selah" (Ps. 32:5). Selah in this world and Selah in the world to come."

From here, we see that at the end of the day, Hashem accepted Adam's teshuvah.

However, the Gemera in Shabbat 55b says the following:

״אָמְרוּ מַלְאֲכֵי הַשָּׁרֵת לִפְנֵי הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא: רִבּוֹנוֹ שֶׁל עוֹלָם! מִפְּנֵי מָה קָנַסְתָּ מִיתָה עַל אָדָם הָרִאשׁוֹן? אָמַר לָהֶם: מִצְוָה קַלָּה צִוִּיתִיו וְעָבַר עָלֶיהָ. אָמְרוּ לוֹ: וַהֲלֹא מֹשֶׁה וְאַהֲרֹן שֶׁקִּיְּמוּ כׇּל הַתּוֹרָה כֻּלָּהּ, וּמֵתוּ! אָמַר לָהֶם: ״מִקְרֶה אֶחָד לַצַּדִּיק וְלָרָשָׁע לַטּוֹב וְגוֹ׳״!״

"The ministering angels said before the Holy One, Blessed be He: Master of the Universe, why did You penalize Adam, the first man, with the death penalty? He said to them: I gave him a simple mitzva, and he violated it. They said to Him: Didn’t Moses and Aaron, who observed the whole Torah in its entirety, nevertheless die? The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to them, citing the verse: “All things come alike to all; there is one event to the righteous and to the wicked etc."

Question: From this Gemera it seems that he didn't fully accept Adam Harishon's teshuvah?!

Answer: In Sefer קשת יהונתן ו,ב, Rebbi Yonatan Eybeschutz explains that Hashem didn't fully accept his teshuvah since its equivalent to the Gemera in Chagigah 15a, of one which ידע רבונו ומרד, knows his master and rebells, and the same applies with Adam Harishon.

C. With regards to both the Eitz Hadaat and Eitz Hachaim being next to each other in the middle of the garden:

In Beresheit 2:9 Rabbeinu Bechaye says that since it is impossible for both trees to be precisely in the centre of the garden, we must assume that they had a single trunk and that the two trees branched out at a certain point above the ground, one side becoming the עץ החיים, the other the עץ הדעת. Even according to this peshat I don't understand how you can say that Hashem put a trap or tricked them to eating the eitz hadaat, what is your proof?

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

This Zohar seems to imply that they didn't do Teshuva. Adam didn't even know about Teshuva, and if he had, he would have done it. It's implied that the Teshuva would have led to forgiveness and atonement:

ועוד אמרו כד נפק קין מן קדם ה"אמר לו אדם ברי מה אתעביד על דינך. אמר לו קין אבא כבר אתבשרית דמחל לי קודשא בריך הוא בנוד בלחודוי. אמר לו היאך הוא. אמר לו בגין דתבית ואודית קמיה. אמר אדם וכי דין הוא רב ותקיף חילא דתשובה ואנא לא ידיעת. שרא לשבחא למריה ולאודאה ליה פתח ואמר, (תהילים צ״ב:א׳-ב׳) מזמור שיר ליום השבת טוב להודות לה; כלומר טוב לשבחא ולאתבא ולאודאה קמיה קודשא בריך הוא. (עד כאן תוספתא)

And they further said: When Cain went out from before the Lord, Adam said to him, "My son, what happened with your judgment?" Cain replied, "Father, I have already been informed that the Holy One, blessed be He, has forgiven me - through the offering of only one measure of confession." Adam said to him, "How did that happen?" He replied, "Because I repented and confessed before Him." Adam then said, "Is this how powerful and great the force of repentance is - and I did not know it?" He then began to praise his Creator and give thanks to Him. He opened [his mouth] and said: (Tehillim 92:1-2) "A Psalm, a Song for the Shabbat day. It is good to give thanks to the Lord." That is, it is good to praise, repent, and give thanks before the Holy One, blessed be He.

(End of the supplemental passage)

### Antwort 3 (Score: 1)

I read in a sefer by some Ashkenazi gadol (I'm still looking for the source) that Adam didn't do proper teshuva, as he tried to justify his actions. Correct teshuva is simply admitting you're a human that made a mistake and needs mercy, like a son in front of a father. If a son tried to justify why his father should forgive him, it would detract significantly from the apology.

So Adam did basic teshuva, but not on a high enough level.

title: Did the Vilna Gaon Explain Why Yaakov’s Stones Merged (Not Became a Pillow)?
content:
# Did the Vilna Gaon Explain Why Yaakov’s Stones Merged (Not Became a Pillow)? ## Frage

In Mishpacha Magazine (Issue 1066 • 22 Sivan 5785 • June 18, 2025), Rabbi Chaim Aryeh Zev Ginzberg relates the following:

When I was in Eretz Yisrael a few months ago, a friend shared a precious insight he had heard from one of the yakirei Yerushalayim in the name of the Vilna Gaon. (I would be indebted if anyone knows the source—I haven’t been able to locate it.)

The Background:

Rashi (Bereishis 28:11) quotes Chazal that Yaakov Avinu gathered 12 stones to rest his head on, and they quarreled over the zechus of supporting him. A miracle occurred, merging them into one large stone.

The Question:

If Hashem was already performing a miracle, why not transform the stones into a soft pillow instead of a hard stone?

The Vilna Gaon’s Insight (as relayed):

"Whatever begins as a machlokes can, at best, become a single large stone—but a pillow, it will never be."

I’m seeking:

  1. Primary sources for this idea (is it indeed from the Vilna Gaon?).
  2. Any related discussions in Chazal, Rishonim, or Acharonim about the symbolism of the stones merging vs. becoming soft.

Thank you in advance for any leads!

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Not sure exactly what you mean by primary sources in this case, but I found this drush in two sources, neither in the name of the Gr"a.

The first is Pninei Yeshayah (can be found on Otzar Hachochmah), a collection of ideas by Rabbi Yeshayahu Krischevski HY"D (p. 142):

"וישם מראשותיו. פרש"י...ובעלי מוסר פירשו בזה: למה נהיו דוקא סביב לראשו כעין כרית, ללמדנו לדורות שדבר שיש בו מחלוקת ובני אדם מריבים זה עם זה, הרי כרית נוחה אינו נעשה מזה, ורק כאשר משלימים לחיות בשלום אז יש מנוחה שלמה."

So according to him this was recounted by some anonymous Ba'alei Mussar (masters of the Mussar movement).

The second is Le'David u'Lezar'oh, vol. 8 by R' Yitzchak Cohen (can be found on Otzar Hachochmah). On the verse in Bechukotai "ונתתי שלום בארץ ושכבתם באין מחריד..." (Vayikra 26:6), he wrote (p. 375):

"נראה לי בס"ד שמה שהסמיך הפסוק את השלום ל"ושכבתם ואין מחריד" על פי מה שאמרו בדרך הלצה למה האבנים שרבו ביניהם על מי יניח יעקב את ראשו נעשו אבן אחת ולמה לא נעשה נס שיהיה לו גם כרית למראשותיו. ועונים על זה שהסיבה לזה משום שבמקום שיש מחלוקת אין כרית... עד כאן. לכן בא הפסוק לבשר שיהיה שלום בלי מחלוקת, וממילא ושכבתם ואין מחריד."

According to him, the idea is (nowadays, I suppose) brought even more anonymously, and mainly as a humorous vort.

title: What is or became of Eden?
content:
# What is or became of Eden? ## Frage

In Ezekiel 31, Assyria is figuratively spoken of as a mighty and beautiful tree that made the trees in the Garden of Eden jealous. Obviously the Assyrian kingdom was historically after Noah’s flood. This suggests then that Eden persisted through the flood and is even present to this day.

Is Eden a physical place? Or perhaps the heavenly Jerusalem or heavenly temple?
Did it survive the flood? Or is it used here purely symbolically?

Ezekiel 31:3 (Revised JPS, 2023)

Assyria was a cedar in Lebanon with beautiful branches and shady thickets, Of lofty stature, with its top among leafy trees.

Ezekiel 31:8-9 (Revised JPS, 2023)

Cedars in the garden of God could not compare with it; Cypresses could not match its boughs, and plane trees could not vie with its branches; No tree in the garden of God was its peer in beauty.

I made it beautiful In the profusion of its branches; And all the trees of Eden envied it in the garden of God.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

According to the Rambam (introduction to Sanhedrin chapter 10), the Garden of Eden is a physical place on earth, which would be revealed to people at a future time.

ואולם גן עדן הוא מקום דשן ושמן מבחר הארץ, יש בו נהרים רבים ואילנות עושים פירות, יגלה אותו השם יתברך לבני אדם לעתיד לבא, ויורה אותן הדרך להלך אליו ויתענגו בו, ואפשר שימצאו בו צמחים מופלאים עד מאד מועילין תועלת גדולה ערבים ומתוקים הרבה, מלבד אלה הידועים והמפורסמים אצלנו. וכל זה אינו מן הנמנע ולא רחוק, אבל הוא קרוב להיות ואפילו לא היה כתוב בתורה, כל שכן שנתבאר זה בתורה ונתפרסם.‏

The Ramban (Shaar HaGemul) also takes it to be a physical place, adding that it's placed by geographers south of the equator, and cites a visit to it "beyond India" in the distant past.

דבר זה עיקרו בתורה ופירושו מדברי סופרים, שגן עדן מצוי הוא בעולם הזה - במקום ממקומות הארץ

title: Why would the Talmud record a debate about Mekoshesh identity?
content:
# Why would the Talmud record a debate about Mekoshesh identity? ## Frage

The Gemara (Shabbat 96b) debates who the Mekoshesh was. Rabbi Akiva says it’s Tzlophchad. Then R Yehuda ben Beteira told him “Why’d you teach that? If you’re correct, then you just revealed the secrets of the Torah. And if you’re incorrect, then you just falsely slandered an innocent man.”

My question is, then why is the Gemara recording this debate? If Rabbi Akiva is wrong, it’s just further spreading this rumor about Tzlophchad. And if he’s right, clearly by the response it’s not our right to know this information.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

As the gemara itself makes it clear (top of 97a), R Akiva had a tradition from his teachers regarding a gezeira shava by which the Torah itself revealed the identity to be Tzelophchad.

The reason R Yehuda ben Beteira challenged him, as the gemara makes it clear, is that he did not have the same tradition, and as Rashi makes it clear, one cannot derive a gezeira shava on one's own.

### Antwort 2 (Score: -1)

Meforshim say Tzelofchod did it L'Shem Shemayim. After the Chet Haegel and the decree of wandering 40 years in the Midbar,the Dor Hamidbar became despondent and thought perhaps Shabbos doesnt apply in the Midbar, only in EY. So they began to be mechallel Shabbos. Tzelofchod wanted to show them that the laws of Shabbos still applied and he did by violating Shabbos purposefully and accepting the death penalty upon himself. This is what his daughters argued before Moshe. That he died in the Midbar but not because of the rebellion of Korach and more so, as a Kiddush Hashem. Immediatley after this Hashem gave the Yidden the mitzvah of Tzitzis so that on Shabbos when they are not wearing tefillim, they wear Tzitzis to remind them of all the mitzvohs in the Torah including SHabbos. [![Tosfos Bava Basra 119b]

### Antwort 3 (Score: -1)

Please also see the Ben Yehoyuda in Shabbos 150b that relates the story of a certain pious man whose fence to his field became broken on Shabbos and he initially thought to fix it but then remembered it was Shabbos. As a reward a "caper" tree, "Tzelaf Ecahd", grew on his property, and he made a living from this tree for the rest of his life. (Caper trees are very valuable as their leaves, berries and other parts are usable).The Arizal is quoted as well that the letters making up "tzelaf echad", can be rearranged to form Tzelofchad. See https://www.sefaria.org/Shabbat.150b.4?lang=bi&with=Commentary&lang2=en

title: How come in Pirkei Avot 5:4 it specifies that our ancestors tested Hashem 10 times in the desert?
content:
# How come in Pirkei Avot 5:4 it specifies that our ancestors tested Hashem 10 times in the desert? ## Frage

Were they counting the total number of times we tested Hashem in the desert or they just wanted to repeat what Hashem said at the time when the spies sinned?

If it was the total amount how come they didn’t count the times after the sin of the spies like the sins of Korach and his assembly and Datan and Aviram or when Bnai Yisroel complained the next day and Hashem killed 14,000 in a plague until Aharon stood between the dead and the living or with the various sins that followed. Hashem specified ten at the time when the spies sinned, how come the sins thereafter didn’t count in the times we tried Hashem in the desert?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

Gemara Arakhin 15a enumerates these 10 times

It is taught in a baraita that Rabbi Yehuda says: Our ancestors tried the Holy One, Blessed be He with ten trials: Two at the sea, and two with water, two with the manna, two with the quail, one with the golden calf, and one in the wilderness of Paran.

The gemara gives then a long description of what these were. To sum up, the list is as follows by the order of verses:

  1. Shemos 14:11: And they said to Moses, “Was it for want of graves in Egypt that you brought us to die in the wilderness? What have you done to us, taking us out of Egypt?

  2. Shemos 15:23-24 due to bitter water in Marah And the people grumbled against Moses, saying, “What shall we drink?” Perhaps the complaint was justified but it indicated lack of faith.

  3. Shemos 16:3 in the wilderness of Sin , the Children of Israel complained: “If only we had died by the hand of יהוה in the land of Egypt, when we sat by the fleshpots, when we ate our fill of bread! For you have brought us out into this wilderness to starve this whole congregation to death.”

  4. Shemos 16:20 Moshe instructed them not to let the manna remain overnight, but they defied him.

  5. Shemos 16:25-27 Moshe told them that on Friday they were to take to measures of manna because on the Shabbos they would find no manna to collect. They did not believe him and went out to collect manna on the Shabbos.

  6. Shemos 17:2-4 the Children of Israel complained violently for water so much that Moshe feared for his life: The people quarreled with Moses. “Give us water to drink,” they said; and Moses replied to them, “Why do you quarrel with me? Why do you try Hashem?” But the people thirsted there for water; and the people grumbled against Moses and said, “Why did you bring us up from Egypt, to kill us and our children and livestock with thirst?” Moses cried out to Hashem, saying, “What shall I do with this people? Before long they will be stoning me!”

  7. Shemos 32:4 The incident with Golden Calf.

  8. Bamidbar 11:1 The people took to complaining bitterly before Hashem. Instead of looking forward to the promised land, they deplored the conditions in which they found themselves.

  9. Bamidbar 11:4 Having being satiated with manna, The riffraff in their midst felt a gluttonous craving; and then the Israelites wept and said, “If only we had meat to eat!

  10. Bamidbad 13 the episode of the spies.

Abarbanel in his peirush Nachalas Avos concurs to this list. He notes that the number 10 was chosen in line with mishna Avos 5:2 that Hashem waited for 10 generations from Adam to Noach and then from Noach till Avraham. While, there were other acts of malice and ill-will against G-d, such as episode of Korach, these were the 10 occurences after which the punishment was meted. Abarbanel also offers additional analysis of each of these occurences and why they were malicious.

title: Tosfos Yom Tov on Sanhedrin 3 4 - is a mother's brother an uncle?
content:
# Tosfos Yom Tov on Sanhedrin 3 4 - is a mother's brother an uncle? ## Frage

The Misnha in Sanhedrin 3 4 says:

  • A וְאֵלּוּ הֵן הַקְּרוֹבִין, אָבִיו וְאָחִיו וַאֲחִי אָבִיו וַאֲחִי אִמּוֹ וּבַעַל אֲחוֹתוֹ וּבַעַל אֲחוֹת אָבִיו וּבַעַל אֲחוֹת אִמּוֹ וּבַעַל אִמּוֹ וְחָמִיו וְגִיסוֹ, הֵן וּבְנֵיהֶן וְחַתְנֵיהֶן, וְחוֹרְגוֹ לְבַדּוֹ.
  • B אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי, זוֹ מִשְׁנַת רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא. אֲבָל מִשְׁנָה רִאשׁוֹנָה, דּוֹדוֹ וּבֶן דּוֹדוֹ.
  • C וְכָל הָרָאוּי לְיָרְשׁוֹ, ...

The תוי"ט explains the opinion of רע"ב who follows the רמב"ם, who says A- the list of 11 relatives is ר"ע. B- משנה ראשונה is just the uncle and cousin. And C- כל הראוי לירשו reverts back to ר"ע and his 11 cases (which requires some explanation, how is it that those 11 cases are ראוי לירשו).

רש"י, by contrast, explains that A- ר"ע has 11 cases (not necessarily ראוי לירשו), and B+C are both משנה ראשונה which holds on ראוי לירשו cases (e.g. through the father).

First תוי"ט, presumably is explaining the רע"ב\רמב"ם, his preferred opinion, says:

דודו ובן דודו. לאפוקי אחי האם. וקרובי האישות. עיין בנ"י:

But the next תוי"ט says:

וכל הראוי ליורשו. כתב הר"ב תשלום משנתו של ר"ע היא וכו' [*וכ"כ הרמב"ם בפירושו. וכתב בחכמת שלמה שכך נ"ל דלא כפירש"י וכו'. ע"כ. ופשוט הוא דהא בכלל דודו ובן דודו אף מן האם. ואינם ראוים ליורשו. וכי תימא דאדרבא וכל הראוי ליורשו פירושו [של] דודו ובן דודו דדוקא מן האב. א"כ לא לתני דודו ובן דודו כלל] ומיהו בעל אחותו ראוי לירש האחות. והיא ראוי ליורשו ובעל כאשתו. וכן בעל אחות אביו. וגיסו נמי שתי האתיות ראויות לירש זו את זו. ובעל כאשתו. ראשון בראשון אפילו בתרי בעל. לכולי עלמא. ומ"ש הר"ב אבל הוא ראוי לירש אחי אמו. כדתנן בריש פ"ח דב"ב אחי האם מנחילין ולא נוחלין:

I don't understand how to square the comments in bold, "ופשוט הוא דהא בכלל דודו ובן דודו אף מן האם. ואינם ראוים ליורשו." with his previous comment. Both according to רש"י and רע"ב\רמב"ם, the uncle mentioned is only the father's brother?

title: How do we know Ezekiel saw a chariot?
content:
# How do we know Ezekiel saw a chariot? ## Frage

Ezekiel's vision in chapters 1 and 10 is often described as the "work of the chariot" ("ma'aseh merkava"); however, the term chariot is not used in either chapter. Nor is the image described one of a chariot. There are wheels described, but no other parts of a chariot are mentioned (such as the platform, dashboard, or rails). Furthermore, in the ancient Near East, kings never sat in chariots, but rather stood.

Do any commentators explain why Ezekiel's vision is known as a chariot when there is nothing in the vision to suggest an image of a chariot is intended?

title: Half free Eved Cana'ani that already has children
content:
# Half free Eved Cana'ani that already has children ## Frage

The Gemara at Chagigah 2b mentions that Beis Hillel eventually agreed with Beis Shamai to force the remaining owner of an Eved Cana'ani to free him due to the Eved's Mitzvah of P'ru Urvu. And the owner gets an IOU of half of the slave's value.

Would they also say to free him if this Eved already had children and fulfilled his Mitzvah to procreate?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

It sort of depends when he had children...

If the eved had children while he was an eved

According to most Rishonim, he has not fulfilled his obligation. His children are not related to him neither in name (ייחוס) or forbidden relationships (שאר) because of the rule of עם הדומה לחמור - אין זרעו מיוחס אחריו.

Having said that, Tosafos Chagiga 2b c.f. לא תהו argues, see minchas chinuch who explains that even Tosafos is referring to while he is still an eved, with children he fathered as an eved - once he is freed, he "loses" the mitzva, so to speak.

If the eved had children prior to becoming an eved

The טורי אבן (chagiga 2b) writes that he has fulfilled his mitzva - HOWEVER, once again, only once he has been freed.

If the eved (illegally) had children while in a state of half-freedom

No, The מנחת חינוך there is no obligation to fulfil (I cannot find his source unfortunately... maybe someone wiser than me can).

To summarise:

The question of whether there is a necessity to free the remaining half-eved due to the obligation of p'ru u'rvu may be influenced by any children he has had previously, in the following cases:

  • in case 1, according to Tosafos in Chagigah
  • in case 2

My thoughts

In case 1, presumably there would be a requirement to free the servant, to allow the "freed" half the opportunity to fulfil the mitzva - as stated, even tosafos chagiga agrees (according to the minchas chinuch) that once freed, you lose the mitzva that was previously fulfilled - so the "freed" half has not fulfilled any obligation.

In case 2, there would be no requirement to free the servant, ממ"נ. As far as the "freed" half is concerned, he has fulfilled the requirement from the children he fathered as a non-Jew. As far as the "enslaved" half is concerned, he has no obligation (aside from the opinion of Tosafos in Chagiga...)

title: Commentator on Kedesha vs Zona
content:
# Commentator on Kedesha vs Zona ## Frage

I've read an explanation that Kedesha is different from Zona: a Zona is a prostitute, whereas a Kedesha is a cult or sacred prostitute associated in some way with Avodah Zara (idolatry).

I feel like it's a really good Pshat that answers several questions (though it raises some new ones), but I've only seen it in academic sources.

Is there a "classical" commentator who makes this distinction? Or who explains a difference between the two terms?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

See Shadal to Devarim 23:18:

וטעם השמות קדשה וקדש הוא (ככתוב בנתיבות השלום) כי היה מנהג עובדי האלילים להפקיר עצמם לכבוד עצביהם, ומה שהיו מקבלין לאתנן היו מקדישים לאליליהם, ואולי נשאר שם קדשה וקדש גם למפקירים עצמם להנאתם להשתכר, בלי שיעשו זה לכבוד הגלולים, ונראה כי (כדעת תלמידי רמב"ם) חששה תורה שמא יעלה בלבם לעשות זה לכבוד אלהי ישראל, להפקיר עצמם ולהביא אתנניהם לביתו, ולפיכך הוסיפה ואסרה הבאת האתנן לבית ה'.

And the reason for the names kedeishah and kadesh is (as explained in Netivot HaShalom) that it was the custom of idol worshippers to offer themselves freely in honor of their idols, and what they received as payment for their prostitution they would dedicate to their gods. And perhaps the name kedeishah and kadesh remained in usage even for those who gave themselves over for their own pleasure, to earn money, without doing so in honor of the idols. And it seems that (in accordance with the view of the disciples of the Rambam) the Torah was concerned that it might enter someone’s heart to do this in honor of the God of Israel — to offer themselves and bring their earnings into His House — and therefore it further prohibited bringing the earnings of a prostitute into the House of the Lord.”

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

Technically speaking, (1): If an unmarried Jewish woman- either never married, divorced, or widowed has connection with either a non Jew or one of the forbidden incestuous relations even just one time- she is then classified as a "zona"- no matter how righteous she may be after a single indiscretion. A "kadeisha" on the other hand implies, as has been stated above, is a woman who is dedicated to impropriety and lewdness on an ongoing basis. This may or may not be related to idol worship.

title: Did the spies not realize that the people would want to return to Egypt?
content:
# Did the spies not realize that the people would want to return to Egypt? ## Frage

B"H

In shlach it discusses how 10 of the spies gave an overly exaggerated report about the land, claiming that even Hashem Himself wouldn't be able to conquer the nations there

According to chassidus, the spies wanted to stay in the desert, where they wouldn't have to do (many) physical commandments connected with the land, and have all of their needs taken care of

Seemingly then their plan would be to convince the Jews why they should stay in the desert

What we actually find, though, is (even before Moshe telling them that hashem told him they were an evil congregation etc. And them deciding, based on that, to go to the land of Israel) the people immediately said: "let's go back to Egypt!"

2All the Israelites complained against Moses and Aaron, and the entire community said to them, “If only we had died in Egypt, or if only we had died in this desert. בוַיִּלֹּ֨נוּ֙ עַל־משֶׁ֣ה וְעַל־אַֽהֲרֹ֔ן כֹּ֖ל בְּנֵ֣י יִשְׂרָאֵ֑ל וַיֹּֽאמְר֨וּ אֲלֵהֶ֜ם כָּל־הָֽעֵדָ֗ה לוּ־מַ֨תְנוּ֙ בְּאֶ֣רֶץ מִצְרַ֔יִם א֛וֹ בַּמִּדְבָּ֥ר הַזֶּ֖ה לוּ־מָֽתְנוּ: 3Why is God bringing us to this land to fall by the sword? Our wives and children will be spoils of war. Is it not better for us to return to Egypt?” גוְלָמָ֣ה יְ֠הֹוָ֠ה מֵבִ֨יא אֹתָ֜נוּ אֶל־הָאָ֤רֶץ הַזֹּאת֙ לִנְפֹּ֣ל בַּחֶ֔רֶב נָשֵׁ֥ינוּ וְטַפֵּ֖נוּ יִֽהְי֣וּ לָבַ֑ז הֲל֧וֹא ט֥֥וֹב לָ֖נוּ שׁ֥וּב מִצְרָֽיְמָה: 4They said to each other, “Let us appoint a leader and return to Egypt!” דוַיֹּֽאמְר֖וּ אִ֣ישׁ אֶל־אָחִ֑יו נִתְּנָ֥ה רֹ֖אשׁ וְנָשׁ֥וּבָה מִצְרָֽיְמָה:

Did the spies not realize that the people would want to go back to Egypt? If their plan was to get the people to want to stay in the desert, then I guess they were pretty obviously wrong. Wouldn't the spies have been smart enough to predict that would happen?

So what were the spies hoping to accomplish with their report?

title: Why is the mekoshesh only mentioned now?
content:
# Why is the mekoshesh only mentioned now? ## Frage

The passuk (bamidbar 15:32) says that there was a mekoshesh eitzim - a man who gathered wood - on shabbos. Rashi (there) says:

בגנותן של ישראל דבר הכתוב שלא שמרו אלא שבת ראשונה ובשניה בא זה וחללה

The passuk is speaking ot the detriment of Israel,that they only kept the first shabbos, and on the second,this man came and desecrated it.

Rashi seems to be saying that this story happened one week after Marah, or possibly one week after Matan Torah. Either way, that's over a year before Sh'lach happens. So why is this story only brought now?

I'm aware that Rashi later (passuk 41) says in the name of Rabbi Moshe Hadarshan that shabbos is put next to the Korban of Avoda Zara and tzitzis because all three are weighed against the entire Torah, however this doesn't answer my question for two reasons: the story could still be brought earlier, and we could talk about shabbos as a general mitzvah here; also, we could in theory leave all three of these parshiyas together, but put them in the correct position chronologically.

I'm also aware that אין מוקדם ומאוחר בתורה. Even so I'd like an explanation for why that's used here.

title: Carrying Money in the Temple Area (Mishnah Berakhot 9.5)
content:
# Carrying Money in the Temple Area (Mishnah Berakhot 9.5) ## Frage

Mishnah Berakhot 9.5

In deference to the Temple, one may not enter the Temple Mount with his staff, his shoes, his money belt, or even the dust on his feet.

Was the rule against money belts already in effect while the Temple still stood? If so, how could people conduct necessary commerce in the Temple area? Were they expected to carry their money in another manner, or was this rule only instituted after the Temple was destroyed?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

There was no prohibition to bring money to the Temple Mount (even non-consecrated money), only a money belt, because of the disrespectful appearance of entering for business purposes (Tosafot Bava Metzia 26a). Money itself was brought into the Temple, both the first (2 Kings 12:10) and the second (Shekalim 5:4).

title: Worse things in a place with no yetzer hara
content:
# Worse things in a place with no yetzer hara ## Frage

Can someone help me understand what this is saying? It seems to say that more bad things happen in a place with less of a yetzer hara? Why?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

This quote is found in the Sefer Chasidim Siman 1168. He is saying that a land that has a strong inclination (yetzer) — if people sin in that land more than in one that does not have such a strong inclination — the judgment of the souls of the people of that place is according to the inclination (yetzer) they face. For a land that does not have such a strong evil inclination is judged more harshly for punishment than one that has a strong inclination. Similarly, one who is under a spell (enchanted or bewitched) — his sin is not as severe as that of someone who is not bewitched and sins.

This might be because:

  1. Someone with a strong yetzer hara has more internal resistance when trying to do good. Someone with a weaker yetzer hara has fewer obstacles and therefore is expected to do better.

  2. When a place (or person) has fewer negative influences (i.e., less yetzer hara), Hashem expects more from them. If they fail, it shows a greater degree of negligence or rebellion. Think of it like a top student failing an easy test — the teacher is much more disappointed.

title: Locating a Midrash: "When they enter the Land, what will become of Me?"
content:
# Locating a Midrash: "When they enter the Land, what will become of Me?" ## Frage

In different sources, the Chida (Marit HaAyin on Shabbat 86b, Tzaverei Shalal, Haftarah of Kedoshim 2:3 and in Nachal Sorek, Haftarah of Achrei Mot Kedoshim 2) quotes an idea that G-d said:

as our Sages said — that when the Israelites entered the Land, the Torah said: “Now the Israelites are entering the Land — one will run to his field, another to his vineyard — what will become of the Torah?” And the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to her: “I have given them the Shabbat, on which they will engage in Torah.”

It seems that this comes from the Tur in Orach Chaim, siman 290. However, the Tur also quotes a Midrash.

Does anyone know what the original source for this statement is? Where does it originally say:

as our Sages said — that when the Israelites entered the Land, the Torah said: “Now the Israelites are entering the Land — one will run to his field, another to his vineyard — what will become of the Torah?” And the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to her: “I have given them the Shabbat, on which they will engage in Torah.”

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

It seems it can be found in the Midrash Tanchuma on Parshas Beshalach:

The Holy One, blessed be He, said: If I lead them into the land by the most direct route, they will each take possession of a field and a vineyard and neglect the law. Therefore I will lead them through the wilderness for forty years and cause them to eat the manna and drink the water of the well so that the law may penetrate into their very beings.

As brought down from the sefer Imrei Eliezer (Shemos, Parshas Beshalach, p. 74).

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

Very likely, the Tur is combining several midrashim. The first one was given by @Shmuel. The second one is Bereshis Rabba 11:8:

Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai taught: Shabbat said before the Holy One blessed be He: ‘Master of the universe, all of them [the other days] have partners, but I do not have a partner.’ The Holy One blessed be He said to it: ‘The congregation of Israel is your partner.’ When Israel stood before Mount Sinai, the Holy One blessed be He said to them: ‘Remember the matter that I said to Shabbat: The congregation of Israel is your partner.’ That is the meaning of the statement in the Ten Commandments: “Remember the Shabbat day to keep it holy” (Exodus 20:8).

The third one Pesikta Rabbati 23 (in the middle). In the Zikhron Aharon edition it is printed as the last one in perek 23: Pesikta Rabbati 23:10 (including Hebrew for identification):

ר' ברכיה] בשם ר' חייא (בי רבא) [בר אבא] לא ניתנה השבת אלא לתענוג רבי חגי] בשם רבי שמואל בר נחמן לא ניתנה השבת אלא לתלמוד תורה ולא פליגי (מאן) [מה] דאמר רבי ברכיה בשם רבי חייא בר אבא לתענוג אלו תלמידי חכמים שהם יגיעים בתורה כל ימות השבת ובשבת הם באים ומענגים (מן) מה דאמר רבי חגי בשם רבי שמואל בר נחמן לתלמוד תורה אילו הפועלים שהם עסוקים במלאכתן של ימות השבת ובשבת הם באים ומתעסקים בתורה. רבי יהושע דסכנים בשם רבי לוי כל שהוא מתענג בשבת שואל והקב"ה נותן לו משאלותיו מאי טעמא והתענג על ה' ויתן לך משאלות לבך (תהלים ל"ז ד'):

[Rabbi Berechya in the name of] Rabbi Chiya bar Abba said: "Shabbos was given only for pleasure." Rabbi Chaggai in the name of Rabbi Shmuel bar Nachman said: "Shabbos was only given for learning the Torah." And they do not argue. Regarding what Rabbi Rabbi Berechya in the name of] Rabbi Chiya bar Abba said "for pleasure" -- that's for students of Torah (talmidei chachamim) who delve in the Torah all the days of the week, and on Shabbos they come to rest and have pleasure (summarizing their studies). Regarding what Rabbi Chaggai in the name of Rabbi Shmuel bar Nachman said "for learning the Torah" -- that's for workers who labor all the days of the week, and on Shabbos they come and delve in the Torah. Rabbi Yehoshua of Sachnin in the name of Rabbi Levi said: "Everyone who experiences pleasure on Shabbos, makes a request and HKBH gives him in accordance with his request, the reason is stated in Tehilim 37:4 "Seek the favor of the LORD (literally seek the pleasure in serving G-d), and He will grant you the desires of your heart."

title: Can God's emanations or epithets be anthropomorphised?
content:
# Can God's emanations or epithets be anthropomorphised? ## Frage

We've already established that ontologically, God (the big thing) can not be anthropomorphised in any way.

However, we're used to referring to divine "emanations", like the Sefirot (Hessed, Gevura), or God's epithets like Hakadosh Baruch Hu, the Shechina, Ribono Shel Olam, Hamakom, etc.

Here's a metaphor - we all know that a cloud LLM is an abstract entity with no resemblance to a human body or psyche; however, a specific instance I'm currently interacting with appears very humanlike, and I handle this interaction as if it were a human, especially if it is a two-way chat.

Could those be anthropomorphized, i.e., attributed human-like qualities?

E.g., would the following passage be permitted to teach to kids, (איכה רבתי, הקדמה, כ"ח): "באותה שעה היה הקב"ה בוכה ואומר: אוי לי, מה עשיתי?", since it uses הקב"ה?

title: Should Birkat Hagomel be recited after visiting bomb shelter?
content:
# Should Birkat Hagomel be recited after visiting bomb shelter? ## Frage

I have been in Israel since the 2025 Iran War started and have made many visits to the bomb shelter. Please excuse me from giving particulars, but there are many worse off than I.

If anyone has seen halachic guidance on when or if to say birkat hagomel in/after such situations, please forward on. The question, unfortunately, cannot be a new one, but I have not found it addressed.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

I would suggest, based on my argument with my son who lives in Petach Tikva next to the lethal hit yesterday ("Elderly couple identified after Iranian missile strike kills four in Petah Tikva").

From Shulchan Arukh, Orach Chayim 219.9,

"These four cases (of Birkas Hagomel) do not apply only to those who have experienced a miracle, such as when a wall collapsed on them, or they survived being trampled or gored by a bull, or a lion confronted them in the city to attack them, or when robbers came, or nighttime bandits from whom they escaped, and so on,
all of them must recite the Birkat HaGomel.
Some say that Birkat HaGomel should only be recited for these four specific cases, and it is preferable to recite it without mentioning God’s Name (Shem) or Kingship (Malchut)."

We can learn that if you were under direct attack, i.e., the missile hit your building, street, or block, so that you, sort of "escaped", you have permission (maybe even obligated) to recite the blessing in full (unless you keep the stringency of pronouncing sacred names).

However, if your trip to the shelter was just a precaution, you definitely shouldn’t say the blessing with the sacred names. Since a blessing without names does not count as one, you can still say it without them.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

R Yitzchak Yosef answers your question (footnote 4, here)

There are many soldiers who have asked me if they should recite the Birkat HaGomel if they were saved from being hit by a missile.

I told them that if they traveled from one city to another (for a distance where they would be obligated to recite HaGomel), then they should recite HaGomel and have in mind being saved from the missile as well.

In general, we do not recite HaGomel for being saved from something that is normal to occur. Only in situations which are extremely strange, such as being attacked by a lion and not being hurt, or if one is trapped under a fallen building and one is saved, then one can recite HaGomel and also can also say “She’asa li ness bamakom hazeh.”

Other miracles, which are viewed as a more normal occurrence since it is common to survive such situations, and does not warrant HaGomel. There is no doubt that everything is from Hashem, and it is certainly a miracle to not be hurt from a missile or shooting attack, but this is not called something that is an abnormal occurence.
