title: When Gad went to David, was it 3 or 7 years of famine?
content:
# When Gad went to David, was it 3 or 7 years of famine? ## Frage

When Gad went to David, 1 Chronicles 21:12 gave him 3 years of famine as an option, but in 2 Samuel 24:13 it says 7 years. What is the meaning behind this? Was this a copyist error or is there another meaning behind it like other verses that appear contradictory on the surface but have a deeper meaning?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Radak on both verses points out that there had already been three years of famine shortly before this (Shmuel 2:21:1), and that practically speaking the year after a famine is over tends to be a lean one (and anyway that they wouldn't have a harvest until later in the year), so that another three years of famine now would effectively make seven altogether.

Malbim on Shmuel says that since this was towards the end of David's life, only three years of the seven would be during his lifetime; the rest, if he chose that option, would be during the reign of his son Shlomo. (In Divrei Hayamim he says somewhat differently: if David chose that option, then in fact there would be only three years of famine out of the seven, because Shlomo's reign had already been promised as a time of peace and prosperity.)

title: What do people do in the World to Come?
content:
# What do people do in the World to Come? ## Frage

The World to Come exists now, and there are people in it. What are they doing? Rav said:

In the World-to-Come... the righteous sit with their crowns upon their heads, enjoying the splendor of the Divine Presence. [Berakhot 17a]

Most people will find that this lacks excitement. Anticipating this reaction, the Rambam wrote:

There is no way for us in this world to know or comprehend the great goodness which the soul experiences in the world to come, for in this world we know only of material pleasures, and it is these we desire. [Rambam, Yad, Teshuvah 8]

Fair enough. But still, however satisfying it is to "enjoy the splendor of the Divine Presence", one would think that working for a purpose is also a must for existence to be satisfying, and that's not a "material pleasure".

So my question is: Did the Sages elaborate further on what people are actually doing today in the World to Come?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

Isaiah 65:17-25

For, behold, I create new heavens and a new earth: and the former shall not be remembered, nor come into mind.

65:18 But be ye glad and rejoice for ever in that which I create: for, behold, I create Jerusalem a rejoicing, and her people a joy.

65:19 And I will rejoice in Jerusalem, and joy in my people: and the voice of weeping shall be no more heard in her, nor the voice of crying.

65:20 There shall be no more thence an infant of days, nor an old man that hath not filled his days: for the child shall die an hundred years old; but the sinner being an hundred years old shall be accursed.

65:21 And they shall build houses, and inhabit them; and they shall plant vineyards, and eat the fruit of them.

65:22 They shall not build, and another inhabit; they shall not plant, and another eat: for as the days of a tree are the days of my people, and mine elect shall long enjoy the work of their hands.

65:23 They shall not labour in vain, nor bring forth for trouble; for they are the seed of the blessed of the LORD, and their offspring with them.

65:24 And it shall come to pass, that before they call, I will answer; and while they are yet speaking, I will hear.

65:25 The wolf and the lamb shall feed together, and the lion shall eat straw like the bullock: and dust shall be the serpent's meat. They shall not hurt nor destroy in all my holy mountain, saith the LORD.

It seems we’ll will live like we do now but as Adam did before the fall, no death, no illness, no poverty, we will know God is real and have His indwelling presence.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

According to Gemara Horayos 10b life goes as it should be going: the righteous people do not suffer hardships and enjoy their life, while the wicked suffer:

Apropos the homiletic interpretation of the term asher, Rav Naḥman bar Ḥisda interpreted a verse homiletically: What is the meaning of that which is written: “There is a vanity that is [asher] performed upon the earth; that there are [asher] righteous men to whom it happens according to [asher] the action of the wicked, and there are wicked men to whom it happens according to the action of the righteous” (Ecclesiastes 8:14)? Happy [ashrei] are the righteous, to whom it happens in this world according to the experiences of the wicked in the World-to-Come, i.e., they suffer in this world. Woe unto the wicked, to whom it happens in this world according to the experiences of the righteous in the World-to-Come, i.e., they enjoy this world.

According to Bava Basra 75b the distinction between righteous and wicked will be strong as only the righteous will be allowed to ascend Jerusalem:

§ The Gemara returns to the verse: “And the Lord will create over the whole habitation of Mount Zion, and over those who are invited to it, a cloud and smoke by day” (Isaiah 4:5). What is the meaning of the phrase: “And over those who are invited to it”? Rabba says that Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Jerusalem of the World-to-Come is not like Jerusalem of this world. With regard to Jerusalem of this world, anyone who wants to ascend there can ascend. With regard to Jerusalem of the World-to-Come, only those who are invited to it can ascend.

title: Is anthropomorphism a blasphemy or a misunderstanding?
content:
# Is anthropomorphism a blasphemy or a misunderstanding? ## Frage

Is an act of publicly proclaiming that God has a form, a structure, or body parts (excluding reading biblical passages, of course) a form of blasphemy and idolatry, or a form of "misunderstanding", a lack of knowledge?

If yes, is it punishable?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

No and maybe.

Rabbi Shimon revealed God's "body parts" and their "dimensions" in the Sifra d'Tzniuta. To Rashbi definitely does not apply, 'blasphemy and idolatry, or a form of "misunderstanding", a lack of knowledge?'

Was he punished? Maybe. He said, Dammed if we reveal! Damned if we don't! -- reveal the anthropomorphism. In turmoil and weeping, this is how the holy Idra Rabbi begins. I'm not that familiar with all his bio, maybe someone can fill in.

See also Likutei Moharan #60 which you can say is a perush on the Idra. It cites the Idra on why Rashbi feels they have to "make to Hashem.." (!) (עת לעשות ליקוק) -- because "..they have not validated Thy Torah" -- namely the Torah of the Zeir Anpin -- the Anthropomorphus Minoris. Translation follows.

It also discusses wealth in the beginning. "Life," there are 9 hits further down; you can search them there. Being that health and wealth are a way people judge quality of life, you might determine from there the quality of "maybe" in answer to your question, whether it was punish[ed], or aferaba, rewarded.

#60 RABBI SHIMON OPENED:

The holy Idra Rabba ["The Great Assembly:" a part of the Zohar where Rashbi and nine other sages gather together and they explain deep secrets of the Divine "Anatomy." This Torah is an explanation and commentary on this beginning passage from it]: Rabbi Shimon opened [the discourse] and said: "Eth laasoth laShem..." [Simply read, "Time for Hashem to act," but which the Sages read midrashically as: It is time (for us) to act for Hashem, Ps. 119:126]: Why is it "time to act for Hashem"? Because "...heferu Toratekha/they have annulled your Torah." What is, "They have annulled your Torah?" The Supernal Torah [which is the secret of the Zeir Anpin], for it is nullified if it is not carried out with these repairs of it [which follow]; and this [verse] is said concerning the Atik Yomin/Ancient of Days. One verse states [Deut. 33:29], "Ashreikha Yisrael, mi khamokha/Fortunate are you, Yisrael; who is like you?" whereas another verse states [Ex. 15:11], "Mi khamokha ba'elim Hashem/Who is like You among the mighty, Hashem?" He called to Rabbi Elazar his son [whose soul was rooted in Chokhmah] and sat him in front of him, and Rabbi Abba [whose soul was rooted in Binah, he seated] from the other side [while R. Shimon's soul was rooted in Daat] and said, "Anan klala dekhola/We are the embodiment of everything! Ad kan it'taknu kayamin/Up until now the Pillars have been repaired." They were silent, heard a sound, and their knees [aRKuVatan] trembled [lit. kissed each other]. What was the sound? The voice of the supernal assembly assembling [namely, the meRKaVot of HK"BH]. [Zohar Nasso 128a]

ALEF. Know that there are pathways of the Torah which contain very profound hitbonenut [contemplation; understanding; insight; discernment]; that it is impossible to come to this hitbonenut except by way of wealth. Just as with the simple teachings of the Torah, "Im ein kemach ein Torah/If there is no flour, there is no Torah" [Avot 3] — and in any case a person needs sustenance — so accordingly for this hitbonenut which is extremely great it is necessary for him to have very great riches; to have great hon/wealth without any lack in it whatsoever. For, one needs all the abundance of the world for this hitbonenut.

And the children of Yissakhar, who had this hitbonenut, in the aspect of, "Umibnei Yissakhar yod'ei vinah/And of the children of Yissachar, [people] knowing discernment..." [I Chron. 12:33], were not privileged to this except by way of wealth, as in, "Yissakhar chamor garem/Yissakhar is a {bony, strong} ass" [Gen. 49], and its Targum is: "rich in property." Therefore Moshe and all the prophets had very great riches in order to come thereby to this hitbonenut. And on account of there being this hitbonenut in the Torah therefore the Torah is called hon/wealth [see Eruvin 54b].

And similarly, whoever the Torah passed through their hands ...

I think Rabbi Nachman is suggesting the Torah of the Zeir Anpin, the anthropomorphism, passing through Rashbi's hands, made him wealthy, as whoever the Torah passed through his hands became wealthy, as R Ashi who compiled the Gemara etc. New Torah passing through Rabbi Nachman's hands, per Breslev viewpoint, would imply that made him as well wealthy, which he was. Point being aderaba they were blessed and not punished. However, R Nachman faced tremendous opposition for his teachings and big claims (e.g. the time he sat on the chair the Alter of Teplik the shochet brought him, and he sits on it and says, When sitting on the chair, then one is a Man! cf. Eze. 1. And the time he raised his hands from head upwards..), and did Rashbi? Idk. So maybe they were punished? I mean perhaps they suffered biydey Shamayim but not punished like halakhicly.

title: App for Sof Z'man Kriat Shema reminder
content:
# App for Sof Z'man Kriat Shema reminder ## Frage

Does anyone know of an app or service that sends a notification or reminder when the local Sof Z'man Kriat Shema is approaching?

Failing that, does anyone know of another app that can be configured to perform the same function?

(This app will need to:

  • use location services to identify (at least) the time zone of the user
  • have knowledge of local sunrise and sunset timings
  • have the ability to schedule and send notifications)

I'm looking for precision of around 15 mins notice.

Thanks

edit:

The issue I have with merely scheduling an alarm on my phone (as a couple of comments suggested) is that knowing me, it will just become white noise that I will likely ignore - whereas a notification that changes, even minimally, from day to day is more likely to draw my attention.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

For context on why such a simple app doesn't exist, I am going to paste these notes from here: https://github.com/natsu1211/Alarm-ios-swift

As far as I know, it's impossible to make a full clone of official alarm app using existing APIs. The major issues are: Third-party alarm app rely on notification to notify user, whether local or remote. However, notifacation cannot override the ringer switch behaviour nor can they override “Do Not Disturb” mode, which means your alarm app may could not even make any sound. Moreover, User may disallow your app to send notificaiton, which make the alarm app just useless. Notification cannot wake up the app, it depends on whether user response to the notifacation to bring your alarm app to foreground. moreover, Notification sounds have a maximum duration of 30 seconds. This means that once the 30 seconds is up, no more sound. If user just ignore or failed to reponse before the notification dismissed, the alarm app could not do anything more. No snooze, no sound, which is critical to an alarm app. Applications cannot set the volume above or below the devices set volume, nor can it suppress the sounds of other applications.

Apple has always prevented developers from setting their own alarms. Even as of iOS 26, Apple launched a new AlarmKit framework for 3rd party apps to use in order to notify their users without having to rely on notifications. However, that framework only works on simple alarms that will go off everyday at a certain fixed time or at fixed intervals. Z'manim constantly change and therefore need to be recalculated and set for each day. So, we still need to wait until apple allows the developers to set multiple alarms in advanced with AlarmKit. (And also allow us to hide them)

I think for iOS local notifications is your best bet unless you set the system alarm yourself. Android does not have this issue as developers can set alarms if they are given permission.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

There is an app called Zemaneh Yosef which one can download in the App Store or on Google Play. It is worldwide Halachic times according to the zmanim of Rav Ovadia Yosef based on your location. On the app there is the ability in the settings to send notifications precisely 15 minutes (or any time you choose) before any important time in the day (sof zman Shema, sof zman teffilah, and many more). I personally know the developer, and it is a very commonly used app by Sephardim all around the world. The app recently also got an haskama from Rav Yitzchak Yosef Shelita. See here for more info.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 1)

Simana (an Android alarm clock app based on halachic/temporal hours and the user's location) can remind you when the local Sof Z'man Kriat Shema (or any other halachic time) is approaching.

title: The sin of the meraglim: slipping in order to awaken a new level of faith
content:
# The sin of the meraglim: slipping in order to awaken a new level of faith ## Frage

The Satmar Rav (Divrei Yoel Al HaTorah, Parshas Shelach, p. 347) explains that the sin of the spies actually was so that the Jewish people would not enter Eretz Yisroel immediately:

"היתה זו בגזירת שורש — דאף ששלח משרע"ה מרגלים על פי ה' ולא היתה הוראת שעה בלבד, כי היה הכרח לסבב כן שלא יכנסו ישראל תיכף לארץ — ואין למדין מזה למקום אחר, של נורא עלילה סיבב הדבר כדי שישארו בני הדור ההוא במדבר ולא יכנסו לארץ."

This was by decree of [its] root — for even though Moshe Rabbeinu sent the spies by the word of G-d and it was not merely a temporary directive, there was a necessity to orchestrate it so that Israel would not enter the Land immediately — and no inference may be drawn from this to another case, for He who is awesome in counsel arranged the matter so that the people of that generation would remain in the wilderness and not enter the Land.

Why? The Rebbe explains that G-d wanted the people to remain in the midbar, because the Torah was not "blended into their bodies":

על כן משב הקב"ה לעכבם במדבר כדי שתבלל התורה בגופן. אכן כדי שתתקיים התורה יתברך הוצרך הקב"ה לסבב עליהם עילה להתעכב במדבר בבחינת נורא עלילה. נסתבב עליהם ענין המרגלים כי הוצרך למען צדקו מחשבתו שבגללה יוכרחו ישראל להתעכב ולזכותם.

וזהו שאמרו חז"ל אמר הקב"ה על בני אדם, על כן לטובת גני שתהיה התורה נבללת בגופם ולא תסור מלבם לעולם.

יהיה זה ביאור דברי רש"י 'חייהם שאני' – נותן להם מקום לטעות בדבריי, וכדאמרן – דטעם שעיכבן הקב"ה במדבר על ידי המרגלים וכו' היה כדי שתבלל התורה בגופם, שבזה תלוי מיישוס של ישראל.

כי אילו היו נכנסים תיכף לארץ לא היה להם פנאי לעסוק בתורה, זה פונה לכרמו וזה פונה לזיתו, וכדי שתהיה לתורה קיום נצחי בקרב ישראל – נתן הקב"ה מקום לטעות לדברי המרגלים.

Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, caused them to be delayed in the wilderness so that the Torah would become blended into their very bodies. Indeed, in order for the Torah to be sustained, may He be blessed, G-d had to orchestrate a pretext for them to remain in the wilderness, in the aspect of 'Awesome in counsel.' Thus, the matter of the spies was arranged for them, because it was necessary — for the sake of His righteousness — that Israel be forced to delay, in order to merit them.

And this is what our Sages said: The Holy One, blessed be He, said regarding human beings — therefore, for the benefit of My saplings, that the Torah should be blended into their bodies and never depart from their hearts, ever.

This is an explanation of Rashi’s words: ‘By their lives, I shall give them room to err in My words,’ as we said — that the reason G-d delayed them in the wilderness through the episode of the spies, etc., was so that the Torah would become blended into their very flesh, for upon this depends the firm establishment of Israel.

For had they immediately entered the Land, they would not have had the leisure to engage in Torah — this one would turn to his vineyard, that one to his olive grove. And in order for the Torah to have eternal endurance within Israel, the Holy One, blessed be He, gave room for error in the words of the spies.

I have trouble understanding the interpretation of the Satmar Rav. What is the positive outcome of people stumbling in the Torah? And why would G-d want to prevent the people from entering Eretz Yisroel and let them stay in the midbar. Why would this help in "infusing Torah into their bodies"?

Any meforshim on this? The only one I found helpful was that from the Or HaChaim HaKadosh (Bamidbar 14:11):

Their souls would undergo a process of transmigration to be able to emerge as a spiritually stronger nation.

title: Sources explaining Divine Anthropopathy vs Anthropomorphism
content:
# Sources explaining Divine Anthropopathy vs Anthropomorphism ## Frage

Anthropopathy is the attribution of human emotions, feelings, cognitions, or passions to non-human entities, particularly deities. It is different from anthropomorphism that deals with the attribution of human form/body to non-human entities, and does not contradict it.

Innumerable commentators poured oceans of ink to explain/apologize for Biblical anthropomorphism. But negation of anthropomorphism does not automatically negate anthropopathy.

I don't recall sources that aim at coherently explaining divine anthropopathy as detached from the question of God's forms. Usually, after anthropomorphism is negated, it is somehow accepted for granted that God's feelings are similarly allegorical. However, I don't see why - I can imagine God as an abstract mind (AI) capable of emotions.

What Jewish sources deal comprehensively with Biblical anthropopathy (not anthropomorphism in general)?

If it is not clear, the question asks for sources, not the explanation of the phenomenon.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

The OP asked:

"What Jewish sources deal comprehensively with Biblical anthropopathy (not anthropomorphism in general)?"

"If it is not clear, the question asks for sources, not the explanation of the phenomenon."

A primary source is the Rambam: Laws of the Foundations of the Torah: 1:12

IMHO (and based on the previous part of the Rambam which discusses anthropormorphism), the Rambam connects anthropopathy with the failings of a limited body.

  1. Since this is so, all such descriptions and the like which are related in the Torah and the words of the Prophets — all these are metaphors and imagery. For example, “He who sits in the heavens shall laugh” Psalms 2:4, “They angered Me with their emptiness” Deuteronomy 32:21, and “As God rejoiced” ibid . 28:63. With regard to all such statements, our Sages said: “The Torah speaks in the language of man.” This is borne out by the rhetorical question (Jeremiah 7:19): “Are they enraging Me?”

Behold, Malachi 3:6 states: “I, God, have not changed.” Now were He at times to be enraged and at times be happy, He would change. Rather, all these matters are found only with regard to the dark and low bodies, those who dwell in houses of clay, whose foundation is dust. In contrast, He, blessed be He, is elevated and exalted above all this.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 3)

Well, "אם לא אני לי מי לי". I did some LLMing and came up with the following book, which I actually downloaded and read. It is Rav Joseph B. Soloveitchik's "Halakhic Man (download here)".

Rav Joseph B. Soloveitchik (1903–1993), one of the most influential 20th-century Jewish theologians, reinterprets anthropopathic language in the Torah through the lens of his seminal work, Halakhic Man (1944). His approach bridges philosophy, halakhic thought, and religious psychology, offering a nuanced understanding of how humans relate to God’s "emotions."

He argues that Cognitive Anthropopathy is necessary for Religious Experience (Human beings must use emotional terms to describe God) to allow for prayer, repentance, and halakhic engagement (e.g., fearing God’s "anger" motivates moral behavior)

On the other hand, he rejects Ontological Anthropopathy - The mistaken belief that God actually possesses human-like emotions or psychological states, which risks anthropomorphizing God, undermining transcendence.

In Halakhic Man, Rav Soloveitchik describes the ideal religious personality as one who embraces anthropopathy existentially (e.g., feeling God’s "closeness" during prayer) while simultaneously rejecting it ontologically (knowing God is beyond human categories).

title: Authorship of the Peirush Kadmon on Midrash Tanchuma
content:
# Authorship of the Peirush Kadmon on Midrash Tanchuma ## Frage

The Makhon Zikhron Aharon edition of the Midrash Tanchuma includes the Perush Kadmon commentary. The author of the commentary is quoted to be

להג"ר עזרה מפאנו והג"ר מנחם מן זצ"ל

A simple reading of the quote implies that there are two authors. According to the book "The Early Acharonim", p. 125, by R' Hersh Goldwurm, by matching names, the first one is likely R' Ezra of Fano, Italy (although with missing זצ"ל), who is known to be the teacher of kabbalah of R' Menachem Azariah of Fano. Later, R' Ezra was a rabbi in Mantua, Italy.

What is the identity of R' Menachem Mann, זצ"ל?

It is somewhat counterintuitive that a peirush has two authors. What is the story behind it?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Zichron Aharon summarized the history of the commentary further on (Tanchuma vol. 1 [seventh-eighth pages; unpaginated on Otzar Hachochmah]) (emphasis in the original):

"פירוש קדמון. שזהו למעשה הביאור הראשון שנדפס על המדרש תנחומא, ונתחבר ע"י כמה מחברים, החל ממהדורת מנטובה שכ"ג שנדפסה ע"י ר' עזרא מפאנו זצ"ל אשר כתב פירושים קצרים משולבים בתוך גוף המדרש, ובעיקרם הם ביאורי מילים קשות, ואח"כ באמסטרדם בשנת תס"א ע"י ר' מנחם מן ב"ר שלמה הלוי אמעלנדר זצ"ל נוספו בו עוד ביאורים קצרים, כמו כן בדפוס פראנקפורט דאדר תקנ"ב שנדפס ע"י הרב צבי הירש ב"ר מאיר [במהדורת כיס] ניתוספו עוד ביאורים שונים. ולמעשה ביאורים אלו היו היסוד לפירושו המפורסם של בעל העץ יוסף שהרבה פעמים מציין כמקור מפרש ראשון, וממנו שאבו כל המפרשים שבאו אחריו, ובמשך עבודתינו ראינו שחלק גדול מביאוריו הקצרים מקורם בפירושים אלו אף שלא ציין מקורם ודבר הוא חשוב מאוד בהגלות לפנינו מקור הפירושים, ורבות פעמים הם יותר ברורים במקורם. וקראנו לחיבור זה בשם פירוש קדמון שהוא הראש וראשון וגם הקדום ביותר."

"Perush Kadmon. This is the first printed commentary on Midrash Tanchumah, and was authored by R' Ezra of Fano zt"l who wrote short commentaries added into the body of the midrash, mainly explanations of difficult words, and later in Amsterdam in 1701 R' Menachem Man b. R' Shlomo Halevi Amelander zt"l added more short explanations, and also in the Frankfurt an der Oder edition of 1792 more explanations were added by Rabbi Tzvi Hirsch b. R' Meir [in the pocket edition]. Essentially, these explanations formed the basis of the famous commentary of the author of Etz Yosef who many a time cited as his source "First Commentator", and from him drew all of the commentators who came after him, and during our work we found that many of his short explanations also originated from these [older] commentaries, though he did not state their source, and this is an important discovery, to have found the source of these commentaries, and many times they are clearer in their original form. And we named this commentary Perush Kadmon for this is the first and the head [of the commentaries] and the oldest of them."

title: Did Shimon the Just receive tradition from a prophet or other members of the Great Assembly?
content:
# Did Shimon the Just receive tradition from a prophet or other members of the Great Assembly? ## Frage

In Avot 1.1-2, "Moses received the Torah at Sinai and transmitted it to Joshua, Joshua to the elders, and the elders to the prophets, and the prophets to the Men of the Great Assembly. Shimon the Righteous was one of the last of the men of the great assembly."

Rambam in Mishneh_Torah, Transmission_of_the_Oral_Law, writes:

בֵּית דִּינוֹ שֶׁלְּעֶזְרָא, הֶם הַנִּקְרָאִין אַנְשֵׁי כְּנֶסֶת הַגְּדוֹלָה. וְהֶם חַגַּי זְכַרְיָה וּמַלְאָכִי, וְדָנִיֵּאל חֲנַנְיָה מִישָׁאֵל וַעֲזַרְיָה, וּנְחֶמְיָה בֶּן חֲכַלְיָה, וּמָרְדֳּכַי, וּזְרֻבָּבֶל; וְהַרְבֵּה חֲכָמִים עִמָּהֶם, תַּשְׁלוּם מֵאָה וְעֶשְׂרִים זְקֵנִים. הָאַחֲרוֹן מֵהֶם הוּא שִׁמְעוֹן הַצַּדִּיק, וְהוּא הָיָה מִכְּלַל הַמֵּאָה וְעֶשְׂרִים, וְקִבַּל תּוֹרָה שֶׁבְּעַל פֶּה מִכֻּלָּן; וְהוּא הָיָה כּוֹהֵן גָּדוֹל, אַחַר עֶזְרָא.

IIRC, Malachi, the last prophet, lived around 420 BCE, and Shimon the Just (acc. to Josephus) around 300 BCE.

From Rambam's description, I can't understand whether, for him, they were a single body of 120 sages with Simeon outliving the others, or an institute that lasted several generations. Hence the question:

Did he receive the oral tradition from a prophet as if the Great Assembly was a one-time institution, or from other members of the Great Assembly if it lasted several generations?

Thanks to @Shmeeeel for the idea.

title: Avot 1: the transition from "passed to" to "received from"
content:
# Avot 1: the transition from "passed to" to "received from" ## Frage

Pirke Avot 1.1 describes a series of "X passed (מסר) to Y".

Avot 1.2 presents Shimon the Just as the last of the men of the great assembly, without mentioning that he received from someone or passed on to someone else.

Avot 1.3 starts a long series of rabbis who received (קיבל) from the previous generation.

How could this transition be explained and what is the difference between the two methods?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Interesting observation. May I offer a speculation? Maybe because with the introduction of the inyan of the Tzaddik (surely there were tzaddikim before Shimon haTzaddik, but this is the first use of the title in Pirkei Avot), comes also the introduction of the Kabbalah and hence the change of lashon to kibbel.

But I'm not sure, because it's said (in Breslev tradition) the Way of Truth was brought and renewed in the world only five times by the Tzaddik haEmet, the first being Moshe Rabbeinu, and the second being Rashbi; until Rashbi basically no new teachings were revealed. I was taught that the concept of the Tzaddik haEmet was first revealed in the holy Idra Rabba.

But conceptually, my thesis is correct, because per Prov. 11:30 Etz haChayim is the Torah, which is the fruit of the Tzadiq:
ל פְּרִי-צַדִּיק, עֵץ חַיִּים; וְלֹקֵחַ נְפָשׁוֹת חָכָם.
30 The tree of life is the fruit of the Tzadik; and the Chakham takes souls. And see related https://judaism.stackexchange.com/a/130941/11675

P.S. Of course there are five "massar," five transmissions, for the five Chumashim. Mi Yodea?

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

I’ve heard an idea that Torah Sheb’ksav can only be “accepted” once, by Moshe, and then “passed down”, as it is unchanging across generations.

Torah Shebaal Peh, on the other hand, whose age was ushered in during the time of the Anshei Knesses Hagdolah (specifically by the Purim miracle when they “reaccepted” the Torah), must be reaccepted by every subsequent generation (both because of its “subjective” nature, and because there actually is new Torah Shebaal Peh added in each generation that the next generation must accept).

[This might also explain why it says that Yosei ben Yoezer and Yosei ben Yochanan “received from them”, despite both (presumably) being students of Antigonos Ish Socho; this is because each generation accepts not just the Torah of the preceding one but of all the preceding generations, in this case Antigonos and Shimon Hatzaddik / Anshei Knesses Hagdolah.]

title: "And Beyt Hillel retracted their opinion and taught as Beyt Shammay" - how?
content:
# "And Beyt Hillel retracted their opinion and taught as Beyt Shammay" - how? ## Frage

According to Sefaria site, the following pattern appears some 20 times in the Mishna:

Beyt Hillel taught X,
Beyt Shammay taught Y (usually not X),
Beyt Shammay brought several reasons to support their view,
Beyt Hillel retracted (חזרו) [their opinion] to teach as Beyt Shammay.

I understand that given two (or more) opinions, the ruling Halachah could follow either opinion.

But, given that B"H and B"S relayed existing oral traditions from Sinai and did not use their own inferences, how is "retracting their school's traditional stands" possible?

Does it mean that they "deleted" those Halochos from their tradition?

Related, "why-record-retracted-opinions".

title: Gentile slaves owned by Jews in Tanakh?
content:
# Gentile slaves owned by Jews in Tanakh? ## Frage

Following "can-a-slave-be-a-lost-item", the Tanakh is full of laws but very scarce on practical observance.

While Jewish forefathers and kings are mentioned to have had slaves in large numbers, I was wondering whether there are mentions of specific Gentile individuals owned by a Jew in the Tanakh, so that we could learn the proper conduct from them?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

A few examples:

  • Yarcha (ירחע) was an Egyptian slave owned by Sheshan from the tribe of Yehuda. Having birthed no sons, Sheshan freed Yarcha and wed him to his daughter (Chronicles 1:2:34-41). Some sources identify their last known descendant, Elishama, as the grandfather of Yishmael b. Netanyahu, who famously assassinated Gedalyahu b. Achikam.
  • From a p'shat perspective, likely Eved Melech the Cushite, a eunuch in the court of King Tzidkiyahu (e.g. Yirmiyahu 38:7).
  • Avdei Shlomo - their descendants are mentioned multiple times in Ezra and Nechemiah (e.g. Ezra 2:55). The very foreign character of most of their names (סטי, הסופרת, פרודא, יעלה, דרקון, גדל, שפטיה, חטיל, פוכרת הצביים, אמי) seems to indicate - as several sources state - that their ancestors were foreign slaves owned by King Shlomo.
### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)
  • Gibeonites, the servants of the House of Hashem, Yehoshua 9:22-27
  • (likely) servants of Abigail Shmuel A 25:42, likely Nabal and Abigail had more servants mentioned as young men earlier in the section.
  • Tziva (צִיבָ֔א), the Canaani slave of the house of Shaul, Shmuel B 9:2 and going forward.
  • (likely) servants of the Shunamite woman and her husband Melakhim B 4:22:24
  • Eved-Melekh the Kushite, a eunuch in the kings palace Yirmiyahu 38:7-13

While the text does not explicitly mention that Tziva was a Canaani, we have a proof from the words of Radak Shmuel B 9:2:

And he was the slave of the house of Saul. He was a Canaanite slave, and he was passed as an inheritance to Saul's descendants, as it is written regarding such slaves Vayikra 25:46 "and you shall inherit them for your sons after you". As we learn Shmuel B 9:9-10, and the sons of Ziba and his servants are all servants to the house of Saul represented by Mephibosheth. And so it appears from the words of the RZ"L that Ziba was a Canaanite slave, and so it appears from the verses. And if you ask, then whatever David gave him when he said, "Here is everything that belongs to Mephibosheth," and did not everything that a slave bought his master bought? Nevertheless, it was a king's commandment, and the king could take from one and give to the other.

title: Why Was Tamar Punished While Judah Avoided Trial in Their Story?
content:
# Why Was Tamar Punished While Judah Avoided Trial in Their Story? ## Frage

In the story of Judah and Tamar:

  1. how did they accept Judah's ruling (and its annulment) after Judah admitted that it was Tamar, his daughter-in-law, and that he was disqualified from judging her?
  2. why did he order death by burning for a woman who was a widow and had committed adultery? Is that the law?
  3. why didn't they put Judah on trial after he was guilty of adultery with a woman who was a relative of his?
## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

B"H

"In the story of Judah and Tamar, how did they accept Judah's ruling (and its annulment) after Judah admitted that it was Tamar, his daughter-in-law, and that he was disqualified from judging her? "

Because he was one of the judges

"And why did he order death by burning for a woman who was a widow and had committed adultery? Is that the law? "

Simple answer: Yes. See Rashi, she was considered a bas Kohen (daughter of Shem).

and let her be burned. Ephraim Miksha’ah said in the name of Rabbi Meir: She was the daughter of Shem, who was a priest. Therefore, they sentenced her to be burned. [From Gen. Rabbah 85:10] וְתִשָּׂרֵֽף. אָמַר אֶפְרַיִם מִקְשָׁאָה מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי מֵאִיר, בִּתּוֹ שֶׁל שֵׁם הָיְתָה, שֶׁהוּא כֹהֵן, לְפִיכָךְ דָּנוּהָ בִשְׂרֵפָה:

But to clarify: it wasn't "adultery"; adultery is only of a married woman has relations with someone other than her husband.

There's a different law about the daughter of a Kohen

This law about the daughter of a Kohen being tried with burning is elaborated by the Rambam:

6The only instance in which forbidden sexual relations are punishable by execution by strangulation is adultery, as derived from Leviticus 20:10: “The adulterer and the adulteress shall surely be put to death.” Whenever the Torah mentions “putting to death” without further description, the intent is strangulation.22 If the adulteress is the daughter of a priest, she should be executed by burning and the adulterer by strangulation, as ibid. 21:9 states: “The daughter of a priest, when she begins to act promiscuously, she shall be burnt with fire.”23 If the adulteress is a consecrated24 maiden,25 both she and the adulterer should be stoned,26 as Deuteronomy 22:23-24 states: “When a virgin maiden.... they shall be stoned with rocks....” Whenever the Torah uses the phrase “They shall surely be put to death, they are responsible for their own blood” Leviticus 20:11 - they are executed by stoning.27ואֵין לְךָ עֶרְוָה בְּחֶנֶק אֶלָא אֵשֶׁת אִישׁ בִּלְבַד - שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר "מוֹת יוּמַת הַנֹּאֵף וְהַנֹּאָפֶת" (ויקרא כ, י), וּמִיתָה הָאֲמוּרָה בַּתּוֹרָה סְתָם הִיא חֶנֶק. וְאִם הָיְתָה בַּת כּוֹהֵן - הִיא בִּשְׂרֵפָה וּבוֹעֲלָהּ בְּחֶנֶק, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר "וּבַת אִישׁ כֹּהֵן כִּי תֵחֵל לִזְנוֹת בָּאֵשׁ תִּשָּׂרֵף" (ויקרא כא, ט). וְאִם הָיְתָה נַעֲרָה מְאֹרָסָה - שְׁנֵיהֶם בִּסְקִילָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר "כִּי יִהְיֶה נַעֲרָה בְתוּלָה... וּסְקַלְתֶּם אֹתָם בָּאֲבָנִים" (דברים כב, כג - כד). וְכָל מָקוֹם שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר בַּתּוֹרָה "מוֹת יוּמְתוּ דְּמֵיהֶם בָּם" (ויקרא כ, יא; ויקרא כ, יב; ויקרא כ, יג; ויקרא כ, טז; ויקרא כ, כז), הֲרֵי הֵן בִּסְקִילָה.

"And why didn't they put Judah on trial after he was guilty of adultery with a woman who was a relative of his?"

No crime to have relations with a "relative", unless it's a very specific forbidden relative, which it wasn't in this case.

Also, adultery does not apply to a man according to Torah law, only a woman (or a man that has relations with a married woman).

And adultery in general, as mentioned, is only defined if a woman is already married. Tamar, being single at the time, did not commit adultery, nor did Judah.
